In trying to perform his impossible task, the NRA’s director, General Hugh Johnson, was reduced from a reformist hellcat to a sobbing alcoholic, and within two years the NRA and its mandate were tossed out by the courts.

相反，新政采取了另一种方法——以监管代替所有权或国有化，以反垄断代替集中和合理化，以分散控制代替计划经济。通过这种方式，新政建立了一套监管市场并确保其更好地运作的体系——顺便也拯救了资本主义于水火之中。尽管各个监管机构的目标各不相同，但有两个共同的主题——市场失灵和垄断问题。

Instead, the New Deal pursued another approach—regulation instead of ownership or nationalization, antitrust rather than concentration and rationalization, decentralized control instead of planning. In so doing, the New Deal put in place a system to regulate markets and ensure that they worked better—and, by-the-by, to save capitalism from itself. Despite the wide variety in the purposes of the various regulatory agencies, there were two unifying themes—the failure of markets and the problem of monopoly.

美国证券交易委员会（SEC）是这项努力中一个备受瞩目且至关重要的组成部分。它的目的是改善遭受重创的金融市场运作，并通过提高信息披露要求和建立公平竞争环境（不让内部人士获得不公平优势）来恢复市场信心。还有什么比任命一位金融家——约瑟夫·P·肯尼迪（未来总统的父亲）——来掌管这项事业更好的方法呢？当肯尼迪提名的反对者指出他实际上是一位投机大师时，罗斯福回应说，这完全是好事，因为肯尼迪深谙投机之道。

The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) was a highly visible and critically important part of this effort. It was meant to make the battered financial markets work better, and to restore confidence in them through increased disclosure requirements and the establishment of a level playing field that did not give insiders an unfair advantage. How better to do it than by putting a financier, Joseph P. Kennedy (father of a future president), in charge? When opponents of Kennedy’s nomination pointed out that he had in fact been a master speculator, Roosevelt replied that it was all to the good, because Kennedy knew the tricks of the trade.

当人们发现纽约证券交易所杰出的总裁、同时也是美国证券交易委员会（SEC）的主要反对者理查德·惠特尼（Richard Whitney）竟然挪用了3000万美元——在20世纪30年代，这无疑是一个天文数字——用于弥补坏账时，SEC的形象得到了极大的提升。和罗斯福一样，惠特尼也曾就读于格罗顿公学和哈佛大学；当罗斯福得知此事时，他惊呼：“不会吧，迪克·惠特尼！” 但事实的确如此，连迪克·惠特尼也犯下了这样的罪行。为了杜绝此类行为再次发生，SEC制定了一系列旨在帮助投资者的报告要求。要清楚自己投资的是什么。信息披露和公平竞争是基本原则。罗斯福说，不仅买家要谨慎，卖家也要谨慎。其中一点是，他们应该谨言慎行。罗斯福呼应了布兰代斯的著作《别人的钱》，阐述了“经手或使用他人资金的人是受托人，代表他人行事”这一原则。5

The SEC got a great boost when it turned out that Richard Whitney, the distinguished president of the New York Stock Exchange and a leading opponent of the SEC, had himself embezzled $30 million—a truly dizzying number in the 1930s—to cover bad debts. Like Roosevelt, Whitney had attended Groton and Harvard; and when Roosevelt was told of this particular villainy, he was heard to gasp, “Not Dick Whitney!” But, yes, even Dick Whitney. In order to enjoin such behavior in the future, the SEC created a whole series of reporting requirements that were intended to help investors understand in what they were investing. Disclosure and a level playing field were the basic principles. Not only buyers, said Roosevelt, but also sellers should beware. Among other things, they should beware to tell the truth. Echoing Brandeis’s book Other People s Money, Roosevelt laid out the principle that those “handling or using other people’s money are trustees acting for others.”5

“规章制度的先知”

“The Prophet of Regulation”

美国证券交易委员会（SEC）的创建者是詹姆斯·兰迪斯，他出生于东京，父母是美国传教士。和布兰代斯一样，他也是一位才华横溢的律师。不到三十岁，他就获得了哈佛法学院的终身教职，不到四十岁就成为了院长。在此期间，他加入了罗斯福新政，成为当时最耀眼的新星之一。正如历史学家托马斯·麦克劳所说，他与路易斯·布兰代斯一起，成为了“监管的先知”，他曾担任布兰代斯在最高法院的书记员。事实上，兰迪斯似乎注定要成为布兰代斯在学术研究和政策制定方面的接班人，为下一代定义国家与市场之间的关系。他似乎注定要像布兰代斯那样，在国家层面取得辉煌的成就。

The guiding hand in the creation of the SEC was James Landis, raised in Tokyo by his American missionary parents and, like Brandeis, a brilliant lawyer. He was tenured at Harvard Law School before age thirty and was its dean before age forty. In between, he joined the New Deal, where he was among the brightest of its young stars. He also became, in the historian Thomas McCraw’s phrase, one of the “prophets of regulation”—along with Louis Brandéis, for whom he worked as a Supreme Court clerk. Indeed, Landis looked to be Brandeis’s likely heir at the intersection of intellectual work and policy, defining the relationship between state and marketplace for the next generation. He seemed destined for the same sort of grand national career that Brandéis had achieved.

1933年4月的一个星期五，兰迪斯接到导师费利克斯·弗兰克福特的紧急召见，弗兰克福特是哈佛大学教授，也是罗斯福的密友。兰迪斯原本打算待一个周末，帮忙处理一些事务，然后周一就返回剑桥。结果，他一待就是四年。他是典型的“新政”支持者，日复一日地工作到午夜，经常在办公室的行军床上睡几个小时，在经济危机期间几乎昼夜不停地起草法案，并频繁往返白宫与总统直接磋商。“你不能像驾驭一匹酿酒马那样驾驭你的大脑，”弗兰克福特警告他。但他并没有放慢脚步。日常生活的细节被他忽略了，这种马虎最终给他带来了麻烦。他的个人生活被国家危机置于次要地位。当妻子受邀带丈夫参加聚会时，她回答说：“什么丈夫？”

An urgent summons from his mentor Felix Frankfurter, Harvard professor and Roosevelt confidant, took Landis down to Washington on a Friday train in April 1933. Landis expected to stay the weekend, help out, and then head back to Cambridge by Monday. As it turned out, he stayed four years. He was the quintessential New Dealer, working day after day until midnight, often sleeping for a few hours on a cot in his office, drafting legislation almost around the clock through the economic emergency, and rushing back and forth to the White House to confer directly with the president. “You can’t drive your mind as though it were a brewery horse,” Frankfurter warned him. But he did not give up the pace. Details of daily living eluded him, a sloppiness that would come back to haunt him. His personal life took second place to the national emergency. His wife, invited to bring her husband to a party, responded, “What husband?”

兰迪斯先是担任联邦贸易委员会委员，之后又担任新成立的证券交易委员会委员，而他本人也为该委员会的创建做出了巨大贡献。在创建证券交易委员会的过程中，他力求让所有利益相关方都能参与其中。他创建证券交易委员会最明智的决策之一，就是让商界成为这一过程的合作伙伴。例如，对上市公司的一项要求就是接受独立审计。通过推行这项要求，兰迪斯为独立会计师这一职业的建立做出了巨大贡献。

Landis served first as a federal trade commissioner and then as a commissioner on the new Securities and Exchange Commission, which he had done much to create. And in so doing he set out to give all the interested parties a stake in the new system. Among his shrewdest decisions in creating the SEC was to enroll the business community as a partner in the process. For instance, one of the requirements instituted for public companies was the disinterested audit. By instituting this requirement, Landis did much to establish the profession of the independent accountant.

兰迪斯的另一项重要成就便是1935年的《公共事业控股公司法》，该法案为美国电力行业构建了框架，这一框架一直沿用至20世纪90年代中期。电力行业曾是……在众多问题中，电力问题最令罗斯福总统感同身受。他将电力视为经济发展和环境保护的强大工具，不顾重重阻力，大力推进农村电气化和田纳西河谷管理局的成立。后者史无前例——这家影响深远的公共机构修建水坝、发电量巨大、生产化肥、控制洪水、恢复森林、改良土壤——所有这一切都是为了促进经济发展。罗斯福对此引以为豪。

Another of Landis’s monuments was the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935, which created the structure for the electric power industry in the United States that lasted until the middle 1990s. Electric power was among the issues that most viscerally engaged President Roosevelt personally. Viewing electricity as a great tool for economic development and conservation, he promoted, against enormous opposition, both rural electrification and the Tennessee Valley Authority. The latter was unprecedented—a far-reaching public corporation that built dams, generated huge amounts of power, manufactured fertilizers, controlled floods, restored forests, and replenished the soil—all of it in the cause of economic development. Roosevelt was very proud of it.

但电力行业也存在私营层面的问题。罗斯福认为控股公司，尤其是电力控股公司，是国家的祸害之一，也是金融崩溃的主要原因。他决心永远铲除“那些垄断企业”。他指出，这些控股公司凭借其“集中的经济力量”，构成了一种私人社会主义，并补充道：“我反对私人社会主义的程度与我反对政府社会主义的程度一样。两者同样危险；摧毁私人社会主义对于避免政府社会主义至关重要。”

But there was also the private side of electric power. Roosevelt regarded holding companies, particularly in electric power, as one of the nation’s scourges and a principal cause of the financial collapse. He was intent on banishing “the Insulls” forever. These holding companies, with their “concentrated economic power,” constituted a form of private socialism, he said, adding, “I am against private socialism as thoroughly as I am against governmental socialism. The one is equally as dangerous as the other; and destruction of private socialism is utterly essential to avoid governmental socialism.”

最终出台了《公共事业控股公司法》。该法案拆除了大部分控股公司结构，并对剩余部分进行了严格限制，以防止控股公司“剥削”运营公司。它还赋予美国证券交易委员会（SEC）权力，以促进电力公司的物理整合，从而提高工程效率。该法案遭到业界的强烈反对，他们甚至拉拢了约翰·福斯特·杜勒斯、迪安·艾奇逊以及1924年民主党总统候选人约翰·W·戴维斯等法律界名人加入反对阵营。经过整整十年的法律挑战，该法案最终才得以通过。

The result was the Public Utility Holding Company Act. The legislation dismantled much of the holding-company structure and severely restricted what remained, in order to prevent holding companies from “exploiting” operating companies. It also gave the SEC power to promote physical integration of electric utilities to achieve greater engineering efficiencies. The act was bitterly opposed by industry, which enlisted in its cause such legal luminaries as John Foster Dulles, Dean Acheson, and John W. Davis, the 1924 Democratic presidential candidate. It took a full decade of legal challenges before the law was finally accepted.

兰迪斯不仅是一位行动家，更是一位理论家，他对经济监管理论的阐述无人能及。作为一名年轻的法学教授，他率先开展了立法程序​​和法律实施的研究。1938年，离开美国证券交易委员会后，他将自己的思考写成了一部关于监管的经典著作—— 《行政程序》。他指出，市场本身存在着巨大的问题，这些问题规模庞大、错综复杂，传统的政府根本无力应对，因为政府过于软弱、缺乏协调，也缺乏专业知识。“从政治理论的角度来看，行政程序的出现源于简单的三权分立政府模式无法有效应对现代问题。”立法只是开始，而非结束。实际上，我们需要第四个政府分支——“行政分支”——它由独立的监管机构构成，这些机构将“兼具立法、行政和司法职能”，以确保法律的有效实施。他还告诫政策制定者，不要被这项任务所带来的政府活动增长所吓倒。“政府对工业领域各个环节日益增长的兴趣必然导致更多行政机构的设立，以满足对专业知识的需求……提高政府监管流程的效率，最佳途径是……”与其减少机构，不如增设更多机构。而当务之急是提高效率。”这个部门的人员不会是政客或业余人士，而是那些“一年52周，年复一年”全身心投入到相关事务中的专家。这听起来多么像詹姆斯·兰迪斯本人在新政时期繁忙的工作描述啊。6

Landis was not only an activist. He was a theorist, and did more than anybody else to set out the doctrine for economic regulation. As a young law professor he had pioneered the study of the legislative process and the implementation of law. In 1938, having left the SEC, he put down his thinking in what became a classic work on regulation, The Administrative Process. Markets themselves, he said, had big problems, problems too large and sprawling for traditional government, which was simply too weak, too incoherent, and too lacking in expertise. “In terms of political theory, the administrative process springs from the inadequacy of a simple tripartite form of government to deal with modern problems.” Legislation was the beginning, not the end. There was a need for, in effect, a fourth branch of government—the “administrative branch”—embodied in independent regulatory agencies that would be “quasi-legislative, quasi-executive, quasijudicial” and that would ensure the implementation of the legislation. And he admonished policy makers not to be cowed by the growth of government activity this task would entail. “A consequence of an expanding interest of government in various phases of the industrial scene must be the creation of more administrative agencies if the demand for expertness is to be met…. Efficiency in the processes of governmental regulation is best served by the creation of more rather than less agencies. And it is efficiency that is the desperate need.” This branch would be staffed not by politicians or amateurs but by experts who devoted themselves to the issues “52 weeks a year, year after year.” How much that sounded like the job description for James Landis himself during the hectic New Deal years.6

兰迪斯的言论写于监管盛行的时期，新政通过前所未有的行政监管权力扩张，巩固了他的战略。除了原有的州际商务委员会和联邦贸易委员会（这两个机构都得到了加强）之外，新政还赋予联邦电力委员会新的职责，使其能够监管电力和天然气价格。罗斯福政府不仅创建了证券交易委员会，还创建了联邦通信委员会、民用航空委员会和国家劳工关系委员会。20世纪30年代末，对企业的攻击愈演愈烈，自由派人士指责企业因投资不足（即所谓的“资本罢工”）而导致经济严重衰退。罗斯福谴责“经济保皇党”故意制造衰退，以破坏新政。因此，随着20世纪30年代的结束，罗斯福政府在经历了早期的磕磕绊绊之后，终于完成了新政战略的蓝图。新政初期设想的与企业建立亲密伙伴关系的愿景，已经让位于詹姆斯·兰迪斯更为尖锐和警惕的愿景。

Landis’s words were written in the heyday of regulation, as the New Deal entrenched his strategy through unprecedented extension of administrative regulatory powers. In addition to the preexisting Interstate Commerce Commission and the Federal Trade Commission, both of which were strengthened, the New Deal also bolstered the Federal Power Commission with new responsibilities for electricity and natural gas prices. The Roosevelt administration created not only the Securities and Exchange Commission but also the Federal Communications Commission, the Civil Aeronautics Board, and the National Labor Relations Board. The attack on business took on an added fervor in the late 1930s, when liberals blamed business for a steep recession because of what was its alleged failure to invest (the “capital strike”). Roosevelt denounced “economic royalists” for deliberately fostering the recession in order to undermine the New Deal. Thus, as the 1930s came to a close, the Roosevelt administration had finally completed the blueprint of the New Deal strategy, after its early fits and starts. The cozy partner relationship with business envisioned in the early New Deal had given way to James Landis’s more prickly and vigilant vision.

凯恩斯的美国滩头阵地

Keynes’ American Beachhead

但监管体系的真正考验却因新的经济形势而推迟。20世纪30年代末的经济衰退分散了国家对监管的热情。政府的应对措施反映了一种新的经济战略——凯恩斯主义的兴起。在新政初期，凯恩斯曾给罗斯福写过几封“公开信”，并且，通过忙碌的费利克斯·弗兰克福特的斡旋，他于1934年拜访了罗斯福总统。罗斯福向弗兰克福特汇报说，他与凯恩斯进行了一次“意义非凡的谈话，非常喜欢他”，尽管他对其他人的评论表明，他对凯恩斯居高临下的态度感到有些恼火。凯恩斯则表示，他觉得这次谈话“引人入胜，发人深省”。不过，他也抱怨罗斯福的手法——“有点令人失望。手法坚定有力，但不够灵巧，也不够圆滑。”没有证据表明，凯恩斯此时虽然正忙于撰写《通论》，却采取了任何措施来改变总统或新政的立场。事实上，罗斯福对赤字支出持怀疑态度；在他一本预示了凯恩斯论点的书的空白处，他写道：“好得令人难以置信——天下没有免费的午餐。”

But the true test of the regulatory system was stayed by fresh economic exigencies. The recession in the late 1930s distracted the country from its regulatory fervor. And the government’s response reflected the emergence of a new economic strategy—Keynesianism. During the early years ofthe New Deal, Keynes had written a couple of “public letters” to Roosevelt and, indeed, through the good offices of the ever-busy Felix Frankfurter, had called on the president in the White House in 1934. Roosevelt reported back to Frankfurter that he had had a “grand talk with Keynes and liked him immensely,” although comments to others suggested that he had been somewhat irritated by Keynes’ patronizing manner. For his part, Keynes said that he had found the talk “fascinating and illuminating.” He did, however, complain about Roosevelt’s hands—“Rather disappointing. Firm and fairly strong, but not clever or with finesse.” There is no evidence that Keynes at this point, although much engaged in writing The General Theory, did anything to convert the president—or the New Deal—to his thinking. In fact, Roosevelt was suspicious of deficit spending; in the margin of a book that prefigured Keynes’ arguments, he had written, “Too good to be true—you can’t get something for nothing.”

《通论》于1936年出版，凯恩斯的思想由此而来。凯恩斯主义以惊人的速度跨越了大西洋。其中最强大的滩头阵地是哈佛大学经济系，由阿尔文·汉森教授领导，并得到了众多其他皈依者和新成员的支持——从正教授到本科生。他们以创纪录的速度吸收、提炼和传播凯恩斯主义思想。反过来，他们的传播影响力也十分巨大。学术研究的核心是汉森的财政政策研讨会，该研讨会定期将最新的学术研究成果与华盛顿的政策制定者聚集在一起。凯恩斯主义迅速在华盛顿获得了拥护者，很大程度上是因为它似乎提供了一种解决基本经济问题的方法，“避免了其他更具干预性的方法中存在的危险的国家主义特征”。正如20世纪30年代末哈佛大学研究生、诺贝尔经济学奖得主保罗·萨缪尔森所言，“可以说，汉森的影响使富兰克林·罗斯福的新政从其第一任期的民粹主义混合体……转变为一个奉行连贯且明智的宏观经济政策的混合经济体。” 1938年至1940年间，凯恩斯主义财政政策开始在美国实施。随着凯恩斯主义的到来——再加上对经济衰退的关注以及国际冲突阴影的日益加剧——监管创新逐渐被边缘化。7

The General Theory was published in 1936, and Keynes’ ideas thereupon crossed the Atlantic with remarkable rapidity. The most powerful beachhead proved to be the Harvard economics department, led by Professor Alvin Hansen and supported by a host of other converts and recruits—from full professors right down to undergraduates. They absorbed, refined, and transmitted the Keynesian message in record time. Their propagatory influence in turn was enormous. The intellectual work was centered in Hansen’s Fiscal Policy Seminar, which brought the latest academic research and Washington policy makers together on a regular basis. Keynesianism quickly gained adherents in Washington, in large part because it seemed to provide a way to address basic economic questions “without the dangerously statist features of other, more intrusive methods.” In the judgment of Nobel laureate Paul Samuelson, a Harvard graduate student in the late 1930s, “The Hansen influence can be said to have transformed the New Deal of Franklin Roosevelt from its first-term populist melange… to a mixed economy pursuing coherent and informed macroeconomic policies.” Between 1938 and 1940, Keynesian fiscal policies began to be applied in the United States. And with the arrival of Keynesianism—combined with the focus on recession and the growing specter of international conflict—regulatory innovation passed into the background.7

迈向充分就业

Toward Full Employment

第二次世界大战并未推动监管干预的进程。一战期间，战时工业委员会对经济的管理被视为一项巨大成功，并广受赞誉。该委员会的领导人伯纳德·巴鲁克几乎被奉为圣人。然而，第二次世界大战的情况截然不同。无论是经济规模还是战争规模，都远超前两次世界大战。罗斯福及其战时政府面临的挑战远比伍德罗·威尔逊和伯纳德·巴鲁克当年所面临的要复杂得多。而政府的记录也反映了这种复杂性。二战期间，两大主要协调机构——物价管理局和战时生产委员会——所遇到的困难，削弱了战后政府加强对经济干预的计划。历史学家艾伦·布林克利指出，物价管理局“或许是美国历史上最具侵入性的官僚机构”。它的例子“是对第二次新政的惊人逆转……它让公众意识到，国家权力不仅可以用来提供帮助，也可以用来剥夺他人的权利。”战争生产委员会也受到了类似的批评。因此，战时经济的管理与国家复兴署一起，成为美国避免采取高度干预主义政策的警示。“1945年，经过四年的努力和成就，各战争机构的成立与第一次世界大战时期战争委员会在1918年底所享有的地位和权威相比，简直天壤之别。如果说它们曾经起到过任何示范作用，它们是国家管理经济弊端的典型案例，而不是其前景的体现。”即使是自由主义者，在战后也希望“找到一种政府角色，使其能够在不干预经济机构的情况下管理经济”。8

World War II did not help the cause of regulatory intervention. The War Industries Board’s management of the economy during the First World War had been considered a great success and was much praised. The leader of the effort, Bernard Baruch, was virtually beatified. World War II would be an altogether different story. The scale of both the economy and this war effort dwarfed the previous world war’s. Roosevelt and his wartime administration confronted a much more complex challenge than that which had faced Woodrow Wilson and Bernard Baruch. And the government’s record reflected that complexity. The difficulties encountered by the two main coordination agencies during World War II, the Office of Price Administration and the War Production Board, undercut plans for increased government intervention in the economy after the war. The Office of Price Administration, observed historian Alan Brinkley, “may have been the most intrusive bureaucracy ever created in America.” Its example was “a jarring reversal of the Second New Deal… it reminded much of the public that state power could be used not only to assist but to deny.” The War Production Board was the target of similar criticism. Thus the management of the wartime economy stood alongside the National Recovery Administration as a warning to America against highly interventionist policies. “In 1945, the war agencies emerged from four years of effort and achievement with nothing even remotely comparable to the standing and authority the war boards of World War I had enjoyed at the end of 1918. If they served as models at all, they were models of the perils of state management of the economy, not of its promise.” Even liberals wanted, in the aftermath of the war, “to find a role for government that would allow it to manage the economy without managing the institutions of the economy.”8

此外，二战后，资本主义在美国并没有像在欧洲那样遭受重创。工业界的动员发挥了作用；那些在20世纪30年代末被罗斯福抨击为“经济保皇党”的商人，在40年代积极投身于战争事业，做出了巨大贡献。如今，他们成了英雄，成了爱国者，成了务实肯干的“一年只赚一美元”的实干家。战后，美国经济非但没有像人们担心的那样再次陷入萧条，反而迎来了蓬勃发展。

Moreover, after World War II, capitalism was not in the doghouse in America as it was in Europe. Mobilization by industry had worked; the businessmen attacked as the “economic royalists” by Roosevelt in the late 1930s had rallied to the cause and contributed mightily to the war effort in the 1940s. Now they were heroes, patriotic, get-it-done “dollar-a-year men.” And after the war, the American economy, instead of slipping back into a new depression as feared, took off on a great boom.

然而，战后，所有主要的西方国家都在尝试各种形式的混合经济模式。尽管战时政府干预的负面影响以及资本家和资本主义地位的显著提升，美国也不例外。关于1945年后美国经济走向何方的争论，在国会围绕《充分就业法案》的辩论中体现得淋漓尽致。该法案的早期草案中包含这样的条款：保障“所有有劳动能力且正在寻找工作的美国人”享有“有用且有报酬的工作”的权利。这种说法的支持，至少部分源于有意效仿英国福利国家建立的论证。1943年，国家资源规划委员会发表了一份题为《安全、工作和救济政策》的小册子。由于其内容和结论与贝弗里奇1942年那份影响深远的报告（该报告开启了英国福利国家的先河）极为相似，这份小册子被戏称为“美国版贝弗里奇计划” 。事实上，美国很有可能效仿其盟友，构建混合经济。

Yet in the aftermath of the war, all of the major Western nations were engaging in experiments with various flavors of the mixed economy. And despite the negative experience of government intervention during the war and the sharply improved status of capitalists and capitalism, America was no exception. The debate over which direction the American economy would take after 1945 manifested itself in the congressional battle over the Full Employment Act. In its early drafts, the bill contained language that would have guaranteed a “useful and remunerative job” as a right to “all Americans able to work and seeking work.” The support for such statements came, at least in part, from arguments consciously paralleling the birth of the British welfare state. In 1943 the National Resources Planning Board had published a tract entitled Security, Work, and ReliefPolicies. It was dubbed the American Beveridge Plan owing to the similarity of its content and conclusions to Beveridge’s phenomenally influential 1942 report, which had launched the welfare state in Britain. There was, indeed, considerable momentum for America to follow the lead of its allies in constructing a mixed economy.

但最终，美国的政治传统和独特的战争经历限制了政府直接控制的扩张，而这种直接控制本应体现在为所有公民提供就业保障上。最终，《充分就业法》被简化为《就业法》，并于1946年获得通过，其中仅包含一项条件繁琐且晦涩的承诺：政府将“采取一切切实可行的手段，在符合自身需求、义务和其他国家政策考量的前提下……促进和改善……为那些有能力、有意愿且寻求工作的人提供有益就业机会的条件。”

But ultimately, American political traditions and the unique American war experience limited the expansion of direct government control that would be implied in underwriting employment for all citizens. In the end, the Full Employment Act was transformed into merely the Employment Act and was passed in 1946, loaded down with the very conditional and convoluted promise only that government would “use all practicable means consistent with its needs and obligations and other considerations of national policy… to foster and promote … conditions under which there will be afforded useful employment, for those able, willing, and seeking to work.”

然而，即便美国比其盟友更倾向于市场力量，新政的监管框架依然保留了下来。在杜鲁门和艾森豪威尔执政时期，监管方面的冲突并不多见。美国正处于其辉煌的三十年之中，日益增长的繁荣削弱了新政式的监管热情。经济扩张是那个时代的精神，抑制市场发展的想法似乎早已被公众抛诸脑后。哈佛大学经济学家约翰·肯尼斯·加尔布雷思指出……“一切都仿佛是圣彼得在天堂接收灵魂，决定将一些人送往天堂，另一些人送往地狱时，只问了他们一个问题：‘你们在地球上为提高国民生产总值做了什么？’”9

Yet even as America deferred to the forces of the market more than its allies, the regulatory framework of the New Deal remained. Throughout the Truman and Eisenhower years, there was little regulatory conflict. America was in the midst of its own thirty glorious years, and increasing prosperity diluted New Deal-type regulatory zeal. Economic expansion was the spirit of the era, and thoughts of dampening the progress of the market seemed far from the public’s mind. Harvard economist John Kenneth Galbraith noted at the time that “everything happens as if Saint Peter, when receiving souls in heaven to send the ones to Paradise and the others to Hell, asked them only one question: ‘What have you done on earth to increase the gross national product?’”9

监管与改革

Regulation and Reform

因此，战后时期是一个监管趋于平衡的时期。詹姆斯·兰迪斯在1938年承诺的积极行动和热情，再次因经济重心的转变而受阻。但并非所有人都对监管状况如此乐观。早在1946年，一项调查就得出结论，需要制定新的规则——即《行政程序法》——以确保平等对待和正当程序。但更令人担忧的是，人们对于政府究竟该如何监管日益分散且形同虚设的“行政部门”缺乏清晰的认识。1949年，杜鲁门总统任命前总统赫伯特·胡佛负责调查此事。胡佛委员会建议按职能重组行政部门，但它却不知如何处理监管机构的问题。

Thus, the postwar years were a time of a regulatory equilibrium. The activism and zeal promised by James Landis in 1938 were once again stayed by a changing economic focus. But not everyone was quite so sanguine about the state of regulation. As early as 1946, an investigation concluded that new rules—in the form of the Administrative Procedures Act—were needed to ensure equal treatment and due process. But more troubling was the lack of understanding about exactly how the government would oversee the decentralized and growing hydra of the “administrative branch.” In 1949 Truman appointed former president Herbert Hoover to examine the issue. The Hoover Commission recommended that the executive branch be reorganized along functional lines, but it had no idea how to deal with the regulatory agencies.

德怀特·艾森豪威尔也同样感到困惑。他的团队于1952年上任，被誉为“意志坚定、甚至有些轻快的改革者，‘现代’共和党人终于掌控了政府，而此前二十年来，政府一直被自由派滥用”。但艾森豪威尔逐渐意识到，他甚至无法控制行政部门。新政通过其雄辩的言辞以及通过“授权”过程建立的新行政部门，不可逆转地扩大了政府的义务。艾森豪威尔执政期间的监管并不特别鲜明或突出。它是一项稳定的工作，本质上相当封闭。

Dwight Eisenhower was similarly baffled. His team entered office in 1952 as “determined, even jaunty reformers, ‘modern’ Republicans at last in charge of government which for twenty years has been misused by liberals.” But Eisenhower slowly came to realize that he did not even have control over the executive branch. The New Deal had irreversibly extended government obligations with its rhetoric and its creation of a new administrative branch through the process of “delegation” of authority. Regulation during the Eisenhower administration was not particularly vivid or distinguished. It was a stable business, rather clubby in nature.

约翰·肯尼迪试图重振监管理念。他任命了一些强势的主席，例如联邦通信委员会主席牛顿·米诺，后者曾因宣称电视已沦为“一片荒芜之地”而登上全国新闻头条。然而，真正对这套根深蒂固、效率低下、案件堆积如山且处理速度远不及新政缔造者设想的监管体系进行严格审查的，却是詹姆斯·兰迪斯——正是他一手缔造了这套体系。

John Kennedy sought to revivify the regulatory idea. He appointed strong chairmen—such as Newton Minow, at the Federal Communications Commission, who captured national headlines by declaring that television had become a “vast wasteland.” But real scrutiny of the regulatory system, which had become entrenched, inefficient, and overloaded with cases that it moved through with none of the vigor envisioned by its New Deal framers, would come from the man who had been so instrumental in creating it—James Landis.

新政之后，兰迪斯的境遇并不好。与布兰代斯不同，他未能兑现早年展现出的卓越才能。在经历了一段不愉快的任期后，他辞去了哈佛法学院院长的职务，在杜鲁门政府时期担任民用航空委员会主席，直到被杜鲁门解雇。之后，他转而为他在美国证券交易委员会的老上司约瑟夫·肯尼迪工作。他做过各种零工，包括协助约翰·肯尼迪撰写其荣获普利策奖的著作《勇气之剖析》。 1960年肯尼迪当选总统后，他邀请兰迪斯准备一份详细的……对监管体系的诊断。兰迪斯重拾昔日激情，对自他1938年乐观报告发表以来发展不尽如人意的体系进行了严厉的批判。尽管在20世纪30年代，他曾赞扬监管是提高效率的手段，但如今他却谴责监管的僵化和无能。报告指出，“拖延已成为联邦监管的标志”，并列举了两个主要原因：缺乏总体监管政策和监管人员素质下降。他指出，联邦电力委员会是“行政程序崩溃”的“典型例子”。他表示，仅处理已积压的天然气价格案件就需要13年时间。即使人员增加两倍，这13年内可能提交的案件数量也得等到2043年才能处理完毕。10

Landis had not fared well after the New Deal. Unlike Brandéis, he had not fulfilled his early brilliant promise. After an unhappy tenure, he resigned as dean of the Harvard Law School, served as head of the Civil Aeronautics Board during the Truman administration until Truman fired him, and then went to work in the private sector for his old boss at the SEC, Joseph Kennedy. He did a variety of odd jobs, including helping with the research for John Kennedy’s Pulitzer Prize-winning book, Profiles in Courage. When Kennedy was elected president in 1960, he asked Landis to prepare a detailed diagnosis of the regulatory apparatus. And with all his old fire renewed, Landis delivered a devastating critique of the system that had developed unsatisfactorily since his optimistic 1938 work. Whereas in the 1930s he had celebrated the idea of regulation as the means to efficiency, he now denounced the practice for its rigidity and incapacity. The report found that “delay had become the hallmark of federal regulation,” and cited as two main causes the absence of an overall regulatory policy and the deterioration of the quality of regulatory personnel. He identified the Federal Power Commission as “the outstanding example” of “the breakdown of the administrative process.” It would take thirteen years, he said, to clear up the natural-gas-price cases already pending. And the number of cases likely to be filed over those thirteen years would not be cleared up until 2043—even with a tripling of staff.10

肯尼迪任命兰迪斯为特别助理，负责改革监管体系，提升监管机构的素质和工作效率。尽管兰迪斯最初影响显著，但他却再也没有机会重返政坛。原因在于他的个人恩怨。原来，兰迪斯出于不明原因，连续几年拖欠税款。他被迫辞职，接受审判，最终被判入狱30天，缓刑一年，并被吊销律师执照一年。他作为监管理念领军人物的卓越声誉就此终结。几年后，人们发现他漂浮在自家游泳池中，已经身亡。政府没收了他的房产，用于偿还他剩余的税款。

Kennedy made Landis a special assistant, with the charge to reform regulation and upgrade the quality of the regulators and their output. Despite his initial impact, Landis never really had a chance to get back into the fray. The reason was personal. It turned out that Landis had failed, for inexplicable reasons, to pay his taxes over several years. He resigned, stood trial, spent thirty days in jail plus a year on probation, and was suspended from the practice of law for a year. His brilliant reputation as the leading thinker about the regulatory idea was spent. A few years later, he was found floating in his swimming pool, dead. His house was seized by the government, to pay off his remaining tax penalties.

尽管监管对被监管者而言仍然至关重要，但它在公众关注的焦点却逐渐淡出，部分原因是当时经济运行良好。然而，监管的重点已从市场监管转向通过凯恩斯主义财政政策对经济进行监管。凯恩斯主义关注的是整体经济的管理，而非市场的具体运作。那几年经济高速增长，数千万美国人从拥挤的城市生活迁往郊区绿草茵茵的住宅区。车库里的割草机与汽车一样，都成为了繁荣的象征。凯恩斯主义似乎正在兑现其关于增长和充分就业的承诺。肯尼迪-约翰逊执政时期良好的经济表现和长期扩张（直至被越南战争中断）标志着凯恩斯主义的鼎盛时期，证明了可以通过宏观经济管理以及税收和支出等财政工具对经济进行精细调节。约翰·肯尼迪在接受耶鲁大学荣誉学位时，对这种理念进行了总结。他首先表示，他获得了最好的资源——“哈佛大学的教育和耶鲁大学的学位”。他总结道：“现在关键的不是席卷全国的意识形态之争，而是现代经济的实际管理。”

While regulation still mattered very much to those who were regulated, it continued to remain well in the background of public concern, partly because things were working. But there was a shift of focus from regulation of the market to regulation of the economy through Keynesian fiscal policies. Keynesianism was about managing the overall economy, not the specific workings of the marketplace. These were years of great economic growth, and tens of millions of Americans migrated from cramped urban life to the green grass of suburban housing. The lawn mower in the garage was as much a symbol of prosperity as the automobile. Keynesianism seemed to be fulfilling its promises of growth and full employment. The good economic performance and long expansion of the Kennedy-Johnson years (until disrupted by the Vietnam War) marked the high point of Keynesianism, offering proof that the economy could be fine-tuned through macroeconomic management and the fiscal tools of taxation and spending. The attitude was summed up by John Kennedy when he received an honorary degree from Yale University. He began by saying that he had obtained the best of all worlds—“a Harvard education and a Yale degree.” He concluded, “What is at stake is not some grand warfare of rival ideologies which will sweep the country with passion but the practical management of the modern economy.”

这些年是美国政府知识体系鼎盛时期。凯恩斯的“随笔”花了三十年时间才从剑桥国王学院的房间里流传开来，成为标准教材。政府政策。为了强调这一点，凯恩斯在去世19年后，也就是1965年，登上了《时代》杂志的封面。他是第二位获此殊荣的已故人士（第一位是西格蒙德·弗洛伊德）。

These years were the apogee in the United States of the belief in government knowledge. It had taken three decades for Keynes’ “scribblings” to move from rooms in King’s College, Cambridge, into standard-issue government policy. To underline the point, Keynes made the cover of Time magazine in 1965—nineteen years after his death. He was only the second deceased person to be so honored (Sigmund Freud was the first).

上一届自由党政府

The Last Liberal Administration

真正大规模地管控市场的举措出现在后来的政府时期，该政府试图对工资进行彻底的政府控制。尤其令人匪夷所思的是，这项举措并非出自左翼自由派之手，而是出自理查德·尼克松政府之手。尼克松是一位立场温和的保守派共和党人，他一直批评政府干预经济。二战期间，年轻的尼克松在加入海军之前，曾在价格管理局的轮胎配给部门担任初级律师，这段经历让他对价格管制产生了持久的反感。

The most massive effort to actually manage the marketplace came in a subsequent administration, which sought to put in place thoroughgoing government control of wages. What was particularly odd was that this initiative was not the handiwork of left-wing liberals but of the administration of Richard Nixon, a moderately conservative Republican who was a critic of government intervention in the economy. As a young man during World War II, prior to joining the navy, Nixon had worked as a junior attorney in the tire-rationing division of the Office of Price Administration, an experience that left him with a lasting distaste for price controls.

那么，究竟是什么力量促使尼克松试图将政府干预强加于市场最基本的要素之上呢？诚然，经济问题并非他的挚爱。他更热衷于外交政策。即便在外交经济政策方面，他也兴趣寥寥。在一次国际货币动荡时期，他曾粗鲁地提出如何处置里拉，这着实令人难忘。至于国内经济，他喜欢在周六中午发表经济广播讲话，因为他坚信听众只会是驾驶拖拉机的农民，而这些人很可能都是他的支持者。

What, then, were the forces that led Nixon to try to impose government management on the most basic elements of the market? Certainly, economic matters were hardly his passion. That was reserved for foreign policy. Even foreign economic policy did not much interest him. There was a memorable time during some moment of international monetary perturbation when he rudely suggested exactly what should be done with the lira. As for domestic economics, he liked to give his radio talks on economics at noon on Saturdays, because he was convinced that the only listeners would be farmers riding their tractors, and they were likely, in any event, to be his supporters.

首先，无论越南战争对20世纪60年代的全国共识产生了何种影响，人们对政府管理经济和通过诸如“向贫困宣战”之类的项目解决重大社会问题的能力都抱有信心。尼克松至少在某种程度上也认同这些观点。1971年1月，他宣称：“我现在是凯恩斯主义者了。”随后，他让助手们起草回复保守派支持者涌入白宫的愤怒信件。他提出了一项凯恩斯主义的“充分就业”预算，该预算允许通过赤字支出来降低失业率。一位来自伊利诺伊州的共和党众议员告诉尼克松，他将勉强支持总统的预算，“但我恐怕得把以前很多谴责赤字支出的演讲稿都扔掉。”对此，尼克松回答说：“我和你处境相同。”

For one thing, whatever the effects of the Vietnam War on the national consensus in the 1960s, confidence had risen in the ability of government to manage the economy and to reach out to solve big social problems through such programs as the War on Poverty. Nixon shared in these beliefs, at least in part. “Now, I am a Keynesian,” he declared in January 1971—leaving his aides to draft replies to the angry letters that flowed into the White House from conservative supporters. He introduced a Keynesian “full employment” budget, which provided for deficit spending to reduce unemployment. A Republican congressman from Illinois told Nixon that he would reluctantly support the president’s budget, “but I’m going to have to burn up a lot of old speeches denouncing deficit spending.” To this Nixon replied, “I’m in the same boat.”

尽管尼克松在哲学上可能反对干预经济，但在政治面前，哲学退居其次。1960年，他以微弱劣势败给了约翰·肯尼迪——普选票得票率分别为49.7%和49.5%。他有时会将败选归咎于伊利诺伊州，该州的选举人票起到了决定性作用，而芝加哥的民主党机器以其强大的动员能力而闻名，能够动员所有可能的选民，无论生死。肯尼迪最终仅以8858票的微弱优势赢得了伊利诺伊州。但尼克松也坚信，经济管理不善也是他败选的原因之一。“他把……归咎于……”经济学家兼尼克松顾问赫伯特·斯坦写道：“尼克松在1960年大选中落败，很大程度上要归咎于当年的经济衰退。他将这场衰退，或者至少是衰退的深度和持续时间，归咎于那些把抑制通货膨胀置于降低失业率之上的经济官员，也就是所谓的‘金融人士’。”展望1972年的连任竞选，尼克松绝不会让这种情况重演。他必须重视经济形势。尽管人们对政府管理经济的能力抱有乐观态度，但经济状况已经开始恶化。通货膨胀率从20世纪60年代初的1.5%上升到5%。失业率也从60年代末的3.5%上升到5%。

While Nixon may have philosophically opposed intervention in the economy, philosophy took a rear seat to politics. He had lost very narrowly to John Kennedy in 1960—49.7 to 49.5 percent of the popular vote. He sometimes blamed the state of Illinois, whose electoral votes had made all the difference and where the Chicago Democratic machine was known for its effectiveness in getting out all possible voters, dead as well as living. Kennedy won Illinois by just 8,858 votes. But Nixon certainly believed that mismanagement of the economy had also cost him the election. “He attributed his defeat in the 1960 election largely to the recession of that year,” wrote economist and Nixon adviser Herbert Stein, “and he attributed the recession, or at least its depth and duration, to economic officials, ‘financial types,’ who put curbing inflation ahead of cutting unemployment.” Looking toward his 1972 reelection campaign, Nixon was not going to let that happen again. And he had to pay attention to economics. Despite the optimism about government’s ability to manage the economy, economic conditions had begun to deteriorate. The inflation rate, which had been 1.5 percent at the beginning of the 1960s, had risen to 5 percent. Unemployment was also up from the 3.5 percent level of the late 1960s to 5 percent.

因此，核心经济问题变成了如何以一种不会在政治上自毁的方式来平衡通货膨胀和失业之间的关系；换句话说，如何在不拖累经济增长和加剧失业的情况下降低通货膨胀。一种方法似乎越来越能提供答案——收入政策，即政府干预以设定和控制工资，无论是通过劝导还是法律规定。此类政策在西欧国家已十分普遍。20世纪70年代，民主党控制的国会通过立法，授权总统强制推行相关政策，从而为实施此类政策提供了工具。

So the central economic issue became how to manage the inflationunemployment trade-offs in a way that was not politically self-destructive; in other words, how to bring down inflation without slowing the economy and raising unemployment. One approach increasingly seemed to provide the answer—an income policy, whereby the government intervened to set and control wages, whether in hortatory words or legal requirements. Such policies had become common in Western European countries. In the 1970s, the Democratic Congress provided the tools by passing legislation that delegated authority to the president to impose a mandatory policy.

政府表面上仍然奉行市场经济。但内部也有人认为，“市场”与其说是对当前经济运行方式的准确描述，不如说是对过去美好时光的缅怀。在他们看来，经济就像列宁提出的问题—— “谁能对谁做什么？”（ Kto kvo?） ——也就是说，他们认为经济“是由权力、地位、竞争和效仿的关系所组织的”。政府干预对于平衡强大的企业和强大的工会之间争夺权力的斗争至关重要，因为这种斗争会推高工资和物价，导致螺旋式上升。

The administration remained overtly dedicated to markets. But there were those in it who believed that the “market” was more an idyll of the past than an accurate description of how the current economy functioned. To them, the economy was like the question that Lenin had expressed—Kto kvo?—Who could do what to whom? That is, they saw the economy “as organized by relations of power, status, rivalry and emulation.” Government intervention was required to bring some greater balance to the struggles for power between strong corporations and strong unions that would drive the wage-price spiral upward.

推动收入政策的关键力量来自阿瑟·伯恩斯，尼克松任命他为美联储主席。伯恩斯是一位知名的保守派经济学家；尼克松特别重视伯恩斯，因为伯恩斯曾在1960年警告尼克松，美联储的紧缩货币政策会加剧经济衰退，从而威胁到尼克松在与肯尼迪的竞选中获胜的机会——而事实也正是如此。十年后的1970年5月，伯恩斯公开宣布他改变了对经济政策的看法。由于企业和工会的影响力日益增强，经济运行已不再像过去那样顺畅，它们共同推高了工资和物价。传统的财政和货币政策被认为不足以应对当前的经济形势。他的解决方案是：成立一个由杰出人士组成的工资物价审查委员会，负责对重大的工资和物价上涨进行评判。按照伯恩斯的新逻辑，该委员会的权力仅限于说服，包括友好说服和其他形式的说服。

A critical push toward an income policy came from Arthur Burns, whom Nixon had appointed to be chairman of the Federal Reserve. Burns was a well-known conservative economist; Nixon paid special attention to Burns because he had warned Nixon in 1960 that the Federal Reserve’s tight monetary policy would accentuate the economic downturn and thus threaten Nixon’s chances in the race against Kennedy—which is exactly what had happened. Now, a decade later, in May 1970, Burns stood up and declared that he had changed his mind about economic policy. The economy was no longer operating as it used to, owing to the now much more powerful position of corporations and labor unions, which together were driving up both wages and prices. The now-traditional fiscal and monetary policies were seen as inadequate. His solution: a wage-price review board, composed of distinguished citizens, who would pass judgment on major wage and price increases. Their power, in Burns’s new lexicon, would be limited to persuasion, friendly and otherwise.

随着前德克萨斯州民主党州长约翰·康纳利被招募来填补空缺，控制的压力进一步加剧。财政部长这一关键职位。强势的康纳利对经济管制并无任何哲学上的抵触。事实上，他对经济政策似乎并没有特别强烈的倾向。“我可以采取宽松政策，也可以采取保守政策，”他常说，“告诉我该怎么做。”康纳利真正喜欢的是戏剧性的举动，大手笔；而扼住通胀的咽喉，将其从经济体系中彻底清除，正是这样一步棋。

Further reinforcement of the pressures toward control came with the recruitment of former Texas Democratic governor John Connally to fill the critical slot of Treasury secretary. The forceful Connally had no philosophical aversion to controls. Indeed, he did not seem to have strong feelings one way or the other on economic policy. “I can play it round or I can play it flat,” he would say. “Just tell me how to play it.” What Connally did like was the dramatic gesture, the big play; and grabbing inflation by the neck and shaking it out of the system would be such a move.

第二个问题也随之浮出水面——美元。自罗斯福政府时期以来，黄金价格一直固定在每盎司35美元。但美国不断扩大的国际收支逆差意味着外国政府正在大量囤积美元——其总量远远超过美国政府的黄金储备。这些政府或其中央银行随时可能出现在美国财政部的“黄金窗口”，坚持用美元兑换黄金，这将引发挤兑。这个问题并非纸上谈兵。1971年8月的第二周，英国大使前往财政部，要求将30亿美元兑换成黄金。11

A second issue was also now at the fore—the dollar. The price of gold had been fixed at thirty-five dollars an ounce since the Roosevelt administration. But the growing U.S. balance-of-payments deficit meant that foreign governments were accumulating large amounts of dollars—in aggregate volume far exceeding the U.S. government’s stock of gold. These governments, or their central banks, could show up at any time at the “gold window” of the U.S. Treasury and insist on trading in their dollars for gold, which would precipitate a run. The issue was not theoretical. In the second week of August 1971, the British ambassador turned up at the Treasury Department to request that $3 billion be converted into gold.11

随着通货膨胀加剧，政界和媒体要求采取行动的呼声日益高涨。1971年6月底，尼克松曾告诉他的经济顾问：“我们不会设立工资价格委员会，我们只会靠口头劝说。”但随着时间的推移，对收入政策的抵制逐渐减弱。1971年8月13日至15日，尼克松和15位顾问前往总统山间度假地戴维营，局势达到高潮。正是在这次秘密会议上，出台了新的经济政策，该政策将暂时冻结工资和物价90天，以抑制通货膨胀。人们认为，这将解决通货膨胀与就业之间的困境，因为这种控制措施将使政府能够推行更宽松的财政政策——在1972年总统大选前刺激就业，同时又不加剧通货膨胀。黄金窗口将被关闭。阿瑟·伯恩斯对此强烈反对，他警告说：“《真理报》会报道说，这是资本主义崩溃的标志。”伯恩斯的提议被否决了。黄金窗口将被关闭。但这将加剧抑制通货膨胀的必要性；因为关闭黄金窗口会削弱美元对其他货币的汇率，从而推高进口商品价格，加剧通货膨胀。放弃金本位制和固定汇率制度是国际经济史上一个意义重大的里程碑。

With inflation rising, the clamor to do something was mounting in both political circles and the press. At the end of June 1971, Nixon had told his economic advisers, “We will not have a wage price board. We will have jawboning.” But resistance to an income policy weakened with each passing month. The climax came on August 13-15, 1971, when Nixon and fifteen advisers repaired to the presidential mountain retreat at Camp David. Out of this conclave came the New Economic Policy, which would temporarily—for a ninety-day period—freeze wages and prices to check inflation. That would, it was thought, solve the inflation-employment dilemma, for such controls would allow the administration to pursue a more expansive fiscal policy—stimulating employment in time for the 1972 presidential election without stoking inflation. The gold window was to be closed. Arthur Burns argued vociferously against it, warning, “Pravda would write that this was a sign of the collapse of capitalism.” Burns was overruled. The gold window would be closed. But this would accentuate the need to fight inflation; for shutting the gold window would weaken the dollar against other currencies, thus adding to inflation by driving up the price of imported goods. Going off the gold standard and giving up fixed exchange rates constituted a momentous step in the history of international economics.

戴维营会议的大多数与会者都对他们做出的重大决定感到兴奋不已。在讨论过程中，他们非常关注新政策的宣传，尤其是电视宣传。尼克松总统非常担心，如果他在周日黄金时段发表讲话，将会抢在当时非常受欢迎的电视剧《大淘金》（Bonanza）播出之前，从而可能疏远那些沉迷于卡特赖特一家在庞德罗萨牧场冒险故事的观众。但他的顾问们说服他，讲话必须在周一早上市场开盘前发表，这意味着必须在黄金时段。一些顾问后来回忆说，他们花了更多时间讨论讲话的时间。演讲中更多地提及了经济方案的具体运作方式，而几乎没有讨论最初的90天冻结期结束后会发生什么，或者新体系将如何终止。

Most of the participants at the Camp David meeting were exhilarated by all the great decisions they had made. During their discussions, much attention was given to the presentation of the new policy, particularly to television. President Nixon expressed grave concern that if he gave his speech during prime time on Sunday, he would preempt the tremendously popular television series Bonanza, thus potentially alienating those addicted to the adventures of the Cartwright family on the Ponderosa ranch. But his advisers convinced him that the speech had to be given before the markets opened on Monday morning, and that meant prime time. A few of the advisers would recollect that more time was spent discussing the timing of the speech than how the economic program would work. Indeed, there was virtually no discussion of what would happen after the initial ninety-day freeze or how the new system would be terminated.

尼克松的幕僚长霍尔德曼在尼克松发表演讲的前一天晚上，私下拜访了戴维营的总统。“总统当时在书房里，关着灯，壁炉里的火烧着，尽管外面很热，”霍尔德曼在日记中写道，“他当时正处于一种神秘的状态。”尼克松告诉霍尔德曼，“他所有的重大思考都在这里进行……他说，真正重要的是，就像他对罗斯福说的那样，我们需要提振国家精神，这将是演讲的核心……我们必须改变这种精神，然后经济就能飞速发展。”在准备演讲稿的过程中，尼克松备受煎熬，担心新闻标题会是“尼克松大胆行动”还是“尼克松改变主意”。尼克松后来写道：“直到不久前我还在谈论工资和物价管制的弊端，我知道我这样做会招致指责，要么是背叛了自己的原则，要么是掩盖了自己的真实意图。” 但尼克松是一位务实的政治家，这一点在他对自己立场转变的精辟解释中体现得淋漓尽致。“然而，从哲学层面来说，我仍然反对工资和物价管制，尽管我确信客观的经济形势迫使我不得不实施这些管制。”

Nixon’s chief of staff, H. R. Haldeman, went in to see the president privately at Camp David the evening before his speech. “The P. was down in his study with the lights off and the fire going in the fireplace, even though it was a hot night out,” Haldeman wrote in his diary. “He was in one of his sort of mystic moods.” Nixon told Haldeman “that this is where he made all his big cogitations…. He said what really matters here is the same thing as did with [Franklin] Roosevelt, we need to raise the spirit of the country, that will be the thrust of the rhetoric of the speech…. We’ve got to change the spirit, and then the economy could take off like hell.” As he worked on the speech, Nixon tormented himself, worrying whether the headlines would read NIXON ACTS BOLDLY or NIXON CHANGES MIND. “Having talked until recently about the evils of wage and price controls,” Nixon later wrote, “I knew I had opened myself to the charge that I had either betrayed my own principles or concealed my real intentions.” But Nixon was nothing if not a practical politician, as he made clear in his masterful explanation of his shift. “Philosophically, however, I was still against wageprice controls, even though I was convinced that the objective reality of the economic situation forced me to impose them.”

尽管尼克松的演讲被《大淘金》（Bonanza）抢先播出，但依然大获成功。公众感到政府正在挺身而出，打击哄抬物价者。国际投机者遭受了致命一击。第二天晚上的新闻节目中，90%的篇幅都用来报道尼克松的新政策，而且报道一片赞扬之声。道琼斯工业平均指数上涨了32.9点，创下了当时单日最大涨幅纪录。

Nixon’s speech—despite the preemption of Bonanza—was a great hit. The public felt that the government was coming to its defense against the price gougers. The international speculators had been dealt a deadly blow. During the next evening’s newscasts, 90 percent of the coverage was devoted to Nixon’s new policy. The coverage was favorable. And the Dow Jones Industrial Average registered a 32.9-point gain—the largest one-day increase up to then.

生活成本委员会接管了价格管制的工作。最初的九十天过后，管制措施逐步放松，这套系统似乎运转良好。但失业率并未下降，政府随即启动了更为扩张性的经济政策。尼克松在1972年成功连任。接下来的几个月里，受多种因素影响，通货膨胀再次抬头——国内工资和物价压力、国际经济同步繁荣、苏联农作物歉收，以及甚至在阿拉伯石油禁运之前油价的上涨。在水门事件调查带来的日益增长的政治压力下，尼克松于1973年6月不情愿地重新实施了价格冻结。政府官员开始干预物价和工资的制定。然而，这一次，很明显，这套管制体系已经失效。牧场主停止向市场运送牲畜，农民淹死了他们的鸡，消费者也抢购超市的商品。尼克松从时任管理和预算办公室主任乔治·舒尔茨指出的一个意外好处中得到了些许安慰。“至少，”舒尔茨告诉总统，“我们现在已经说服了其他人，让他们相信这是正确的。”我们最初的立场是，工资价格管制不是解决办法。”该制度的大部分最终在 1974 年 4 月被废除，当时距离尼克松击败乔治·麦戈文赢得连任胜利已经过去了 17 个月，距离尼克松辞去总统职务还有 4 个月。

The Cost of Living Council took up the job of running the controls. After the initial ninety days, the controls were gradually relaxed and the system seemed to be working. But unemployment was not declining, and the administration launched a more expansionary policy. Nixon won réélection in 1972. In the months that followed, inflation began to pick up again in response to a variety of forces—domestic wage-and-price pressures, a synchronized international economic boom, crop failures in the Soviet Union, and increases in the price of oil, even prior to the Arab oil embargo. Nixon, under increasing political pressure from the investigations of the Watergate break-in, reluctantly reimposed a freeze in June 1973. Government officials were now in the business of setting prices and wages. This time, however, it was apparent that the control system was not working. Ranchers stopped shipping their cattle to the market, farmers drowned their chickens, and consumers emptied the shelves of supermarkets. Nixon took some comfort from a side benefit that George Shultz, at the time head of the Office of Management and Budget, identified. “At least,” Shultz told the president, “we have now convinced everyone else of the rightness of our original position that wage-price controls are not the answer.” Most of the system was finally abolished in April 1974, seventeen months after Nixon’s triumphant réélection victory over George McGovern—and four months before Nixon resigned as president.

回顾历史，有些人会将尼克松总统任期称为“最后一个自由主义政府”。这不仅是因为其实施了经济管制，还因为它将监管范围大幅扩展至新的领域，启动了平权法案，并建立了环境保护署、职业安全与健康管理局以及平等就业机会委员会。“尼克松政府时期对经济实施的新监管措施，可能比罗斯福新政以来的任何一届总统都多，”赫伯特·斯坦因遗憾地指出。12

In retrospect, some would call the Nixon presidency the “last liberal administration.” This was not only because of the imposition of economic controls. It also carried out a great expansion of regulation into new areas, launching affirmative action and establishing the Environmental Protection Agency, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, and the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. “Probably more new regulation was imposed on the economy during the Nixon Administration than in any other Presidency since the New Deal,” Herbert Stein ruefully observed.12

工资和物价管制体系中，只有一项没有被废除——石油和天然气的价格管制。部分原因是人们对能源领域存在阴谋和垄断的根深蒂固的怀疑，这些管制措施又维持了数年。但华盛顿试图掌控能源市场的做法，却给世人留下了政府接管市场可能带来的种种弊端的深刻教训。天然气是一种相当标准的商品，其分子结构由一个碳原子和四个氢原子组成，但当时却至少有32种不同的价格。石油价格管制体系设立了多个石油价格等级。国内石油生产的价格也被压低，实际上迫使国内生产商补贴进口石油，并进一步刺激了石油进口到美国。整个体系是一个错综复杂、令人困惑的价格管制、配额和分配系统。据估计，仅联邦能源管理局（后来的联邦能源署）的标准报告要求就涉及约20万行业人士，每年耗费约500万工时。

Only one segment of the wage-and-price control system was not abolished—price controls over oil and natural gas. Owing in part to the deep and dark suspicions about conspiracy and monopoly in the energy sector, they were maintained for another several years. But Washington’s effort to run the energy market was a lasting lesson in the perversities that can ensue when government takes over the marketplace. There were at least thirty-two different prices of natural gas, a rather standard commodity, each of whose molecules is based on one atom of carbon and four atoms of hydrogen. The oil-price-control system established several tiers of oil prices. The prices for domestic production were also held down, in effect forcing domestic producers to subsidize imported oil and providing additional incentives to import oil into the United States. The whole enterprise was an elaborate and confusing system of price controls, entitlements, and allocations. It was estimated that just the standard reporting requirements for what became the Federal Energy Administration involved some two hundred thousand respondents from industry, committing an estimated 5 million man-hours annually.

经济萎靡与通货膨胀

Malaise and Inflation

总体而言，20世纪70年代的经济表现长期低迷。1973年阿以赎罪日战争期间爆发的石油禁运给经济带来了巨大冲击。1974年，通货膨胀率达到第一次世界大战结束以来的最高水平。短短几个月内，失业率就高达9.2%，比战后任何时期都高出两个百分点。人们越来越担心通货膨胀和通胀预期会根深蒂固，威胁到每个家庭，以及国家的社会秩序和稳定。为了遏制通货膨胀，杰拉尔德·福特政府的成员开始佩戴印有“WIN”（立即遏制通货膨胀）字样的徽章。在遭到一些嘲笑后，这些徽章被撤下。在1976年的总统选举中，吉米·卡特以局外人的身份参选，并利用经济困境作为竞选的切入点，击败了福特。不久之后，为了提振士气，卡特总统的首席抗击通货膨胀专家将通货膨胀重新命名为“香蕉”。在香蕉利益集团抗议后，他又将代号改为“金橘”。但这也无济于事。

Overall, the 1970s were characterized by chronically poor economic performance. The oil embargo, which accompanied the 1973 Yom Kippur War between Arabs and Israelis, delivered a terrific shock to the economy. In 1974, inflation reached the highest level since the end of World War I. Within months, unemployment stood at 9.2 percent, two points higher than at any time in the postwar years. And there was a growing fear that inflation and inflationary expectations were becoming so embedded as to threaten every household, as well as the social order and stability of the nation. As part of their campaign to conquer inflation, members of Gerald Ford’s administration took to wearing buttons that said WIN—“Whip Inflation Now.” After some ridicule, they were withdrawn. In the 1976 presidential election, Jimmy Carter, running against economic distress and campaigning as an outsider, defeated Ford. Not long after, in an effort to cheer up the nation, Carter’s chief inflation fighter renamed inflation “bananas.” After protests from banana interests, he switched the code word to “kumquats.” That did not do any good either.

20世纪70年代末，伊朗国王被推翻，引发了第二次严重的石油危机。油价从每桶13美元飙升至34美元，全国各地的加油站再次排起长龙，民众的愤怒情绪急剧高涨。通货膨胀率也随之飙升，最高达到13.2%。卡特政府感到四面楚歌。“在许多方面，这似乎是最糟糕的时期，”白宫幕僚长在给卡特的信中写道。总统前往戴维营，反思国家面临的问题。他读了一本新书，书中指出“自恋”是美国困境的根源。他还迫使五名内阁成员辞职或离职，随后发表讲话，将美国的信心危机——很快被重新命名为“精神萎靡”——诊断为侵蚀美国灵魂的顽疾。几个月后，伊朗学生在德黑兰劫持美国官员为人质，他仅存的一点自信也变成了耻辱。

At the end of the 1970s, the shah of Iran was toppled from power, setting off a second severe oil shock. The price of oil went from thirteen to thirty-four dollars a barrel, lines at gas stations snarled across the country again, and the nation’s ire rose dramatically. So did inflation, rising as high as 13.2 percent. The Carter administration felt itself under siege. “In many respects, this would appear to be the worst of times,” the White House chief of staff wrote to Carter. The president retreated to Camp David to meditate on the country’s problems. He embraced a new book that identified “narcissism” as the heart of America’s difficulties. He also forced five members of his cabinet to quit or resign, and followed up with a speech diagnosing America’s crisis of confidence—quickly redubbed “malaise”—as the ailment that was afflicting America’s soul. Whatever self-confidence remained was turned into humiliation a few months later, when Iranian students took American officials hostage in Tehran.

20世纪70年代末，美国陷入困境的原因有很多，从中东政治和伊斯兰原教旨主义到劳动力市场的僵化，不一而足。两次石油危机以其强大的冲击力震惊了全球经济。越南战争的遗留问题包括普遍存在的民族怨恨以及对政府的怀疑和疏离。然而，人们也逐渐意识到，美国诸多弊病源于过去几十年间政府与市场之间形成的平衡——尽管这种平衡正日益向政府倾斜。毕竟，高通胀和高失业率并存是前所未有的现象，这本身就需要重新评估。一些人希望通过更多的计划和控制来应对。但舆论风向已经转变。“我们正处于政府支出、政府税收、政府赤字、政府监管和政府货币供应扩张迅速增长的二十年末期，”赫伯特·斯坦写道。 “二十年后，通货膨胀率居高不下，实际经济增长缓慢，而我们‘正常’的失业率……却达到了历史最高水平。人们自然而然地得出结论：所有这些问题都是由政府的增税政策造成的，而解决这些问题的办法就是扭转局面，或者至少停止这些政策。”

There were many reasons for America’s affliction in the late 1970s—ranging from Middle East politics and Islamic fundamentalism to the rigidity of labor markets. The two oil crises stunned the global economy with their powerful shocks. The legacy of the Vietnam War included a pervasive national bitterness and a suspicion of and alienation from government. Yet it also came to be seen that a good part of America’s ills resulted from the balance between government and marketplace that had been struck over the preceding decades—although it was a balance that had been shifting increasingly toward the side of government. After all, the coexistence of high inflation and high unemployment was new, and that in itself demanded a reassessment. Some wanted to respond with more planning, more controls. But the tide of opinion had turned. “We were at the end of two decades in which government spending, government taxes, government deficits, government regulation and government expansion of the money supply had all increased rapidly,” wrote Herbert Stein. “And at the end of those two decades the inflation rate was high, real economic growth was slow and our ‘normal’ unemployment rate … was higher than ever. Nothing was more natural than the conclusion that the problems were caused by all these government increases and would be cured by reversing, or at least stopping, them.”

曾经对政府的了解充满信心，如今却转为怀疑。凯恩斯主义范式并非表面看起来那样简单。通过运用财政政策来管理经济并非易事。事实上，考虑到种种滞后性和不确定性，这种做法是否可行都值得商榷。批评者甚至认为，凯恩斯主义的运用本身就具有通货膨胀的内在特征。公共支出非但没有像凯恩斯在20世纪30年代提出的那样弥补私人部门投资不足，反而似乎挤占了私人部门的资金。信心也随之动摇。政府通过大规模干预项目解决重大社会问题的能力正在减弱。无论这些项目的初衷多么利他理想，新的成本效益分析方法的应用，加上日常观察，都让人们开始质疑政府是否物有所值地使用了税款。在低通胀、经济增长时期，公众接受了税收负担。但随着经济衰退和增长放缓，以及通货膨胀将人们推向更高收入阶层，税收问题激起了公众的愤怒。保守派历来认为，对劳动者征收高额税款和向非劳动者支付高额转移支付会阻碍经济发展。这种观点历来被斥为右翼的“异想天开”。但如今，这种论断已不容忽视；事实上，新一轮的学术研究也支持了这一观点。13

What had been confidence in government knowledge was now turning to cynicism. The Keynesian paradigm was not what it seemed to be. It was not all that easy to manage the economy by wielding the levers of fiscal policy. In fact, it was not clear, with all the lags and uncertainties, that it could be done at all. Indeed, critics argued that the effort to apply Keynesianism was in itself inherently inflationary. Instead of picking up the slack of inadequate private-sector investment as Keynes had proposed in the 1930s, public spending, it now seemed, was crowding it out. Confidence was also ebbing in the ability of government to solve major social problems through big, interventionist programs. However altruistic and idealistic the purposes of these programs, the application of new methods of cost-benefit analysis, combined with everyday observation, led people to question whether the public was getting value for the tax dollars it spent on them. In a lowinflation, growing economy, the public had accepted the tax burden. But with recession and slow growth—and with inflation pushing people into higher brackets—taxes stoked the anger of the public. Conservatives had traditionally argued that high taxes on working people and high transfer payments to nonworkers held back the economy. That had, no less traditionally, been dismissed as the “fanciful ideology” of the right. But now this contention could no longer be dismissed; indeed, a new wave of academic research supported the assertion.13

这一切都伴随着对罗斯福新政时期形成的监管资本主义体系的根本性质疑。尽管自20世纪50年代以来，知识界就一直在酝酿着相关讨论，但直到70年代的经济困境才将其推到风口浪尖。这套体系似乎已经陷入停滞。它过于僵化、反应迟缓、扭曲市场，甚至可能使情况变得更糟。它阻碍了技术和商业创新。最重要的是，它以自身决策取代了市场决策，剥夺了市场竞争带来的益处。它冻结了商业关系，推高了成本水平，并且，至关重要的是，它使通货膨胀制度化。

All of this was accompanied by the appearance of a fundamental questioning about the system of regulatory capitalism that had emerged out of the New Deal. Although the discussion had been simmering in the intellectual community since the 1950s, it took the economic travails of the 1970s to bring it to the fore. The system seemed to have bogged down. It was too rigid, too slow, too distorting. It could make things worse. It hobbled technological and commercial innovation. Most important, by replacing the decisions of the market with its own decisions, it denied markets the salutary effects of competition. It froze relationships, shored up cost levels, and, of critical significance, institutionalized inflation.

形势需要变革，美国也准备好迈向新的方向。各种想法早已存在。市场失灵的阴影笼罩了过去四十年的政府经济政策。但20世纪70年代传递的信息是：政府也可能失灵。或许，市场并非那么愚蠢。

Conditions warranted change, and America was ready to go in a new direction. The ideas were there. The specter of market failure had shaped four decades of government economic policies. But the message of the 1970s was that government could fail, too. Perhaps markets were not so dumb after all.

*几年前，也就是1919年，斯特芬斯用一句不朽的名言“我看到了未来，它行得通”概括了一些西方知识分子对新生的苏联的乌托邦式憧憬。事实上，在踏上苏联的土地之前，斯特芬斯在前往苏联的火车上就已经开始琢磨这句话了，他尝试过一些变体，比如“我已经去过未来，它行得通”。

*A few years earlier, in 1919, Steffens had encapsulated the Utopian embrace by some Western intellectuals of the new Soviet Union with the immortal phrase “I have seen the future and it works.” Actually, Steffens had been playing with the phrase on the train to the Soviet Union before he even laid eyes on the country, trying out variations such as “I have been over into the future and it works.”

第三章

CHAPTER 3

当晚，新德里的街道上挤满了人；这是殖民主义终结的开始。夜幕降临，火炬在各处点燃，同样的口号在黑暗中回荡。午夜前几个小时——这个时间是为了安抚占星家而选定的——人们吹响了海螺，这种海螺是印度教寺庙中用来祈求神灵的传统乐器。身着标志性夹克的贾瓦哈拉尔·尼赫鲁，情绪激动却又镇定自若地走向印度制宪会议的讲台。仅仅三年前，他还是英国的囚犯——这已经是他第九次沦为囚犯了。如今，午夜即将到来，1947年8月15日即将到来，他将接过英国的衣钵，成为新独立的印度的第一任总理。

MASSES OF PEOPLE filled the streets of New Delhi that evening; it was the beginning of the end of colonialism. With night’s fall, torches were lit everywhere, and everywhere the same few chants resounded through the darkness. In the hours before midnight—the time chosen to appease the astrologers—conch shells, traditionally used to invoke the gods in Hindu temples, were sounded. Emotional but controlled in his trademark jacket, Jawaharlal Nehru strode to the podium of India’s Constituent Assembly. Only three years earlier, he had been Britain’s prisoner—for the ninth time. Now, with midnight about to usher in August 15, 1947, he would assume the role of Britain’s successor, the first prime minister of a newly independent India.

“很久以前，”他说，“我们与命运立下誓约”——为印度赢得独立。“现在，我们兑现承诺的时刻到了。”的确，尼赫鲁和他的盟友们兑现了他们来之不易的承诺。世界上最大的殖民地——大英帝国的核心，帝国政策存在的理由，帝国主义的象征——如今将成为一个独立的国家，世界上最大的民主国家。午夜时分，标志着欧洲所有帝国走向终结的开始，尽管在帝国时代的太阳最终落下之前，还会有无数鲜血流淌——而在此之后，血流成河。

“Long years ago,” he said, “we made a tryst with destiny”—to win independence for India. “Now the time comes when we shall redeem our pledge.” Indeed, Nehru and his allies had made good on their hard-won promise. The world’s biggest colony—the centerpiece of the British Empire, the raison d’être for imperial policy, the very symbol of imperialism—was now to be an independent nation, the world’s largest democracy. That midnight hour marked the beginning of the end of all of Europe’s empires, although much blood would flow before the imperial sun finally set around the world—and much more blood in its aftermath.

但8月15日对尼赫鲁来说并非彻底的胜利；承诺并未完全兑现。虽然避免了分裂成无数邦国和公国的局面，但英属印度还是被分割成了两个国家。印度教徒占多数的印度和穆斯林占多数的巴基斯坦。尽管英国仓促的应对措施避免了人们担心的全面“崩溃”，避免了内战和无政府状态的发生，但印度独立带来的动荡依然巨大。一千五百万印度教徒和穆斯林沦为难民，被迫朝相反的方向逃亡，在新划定的印巴边界上擦肩而过。他们的生活被彻底颠覆，恐惧和怨恨充斥着他们，很快便沦为残酷暴力的牺牲品。满载难民的火车在越过边界前就遭到伏击。当车门在车站打开时，里面只有尸体。在城市里，原本和平共处的邻居反目成仇。据估计，在独立带来的印度教徒和穆斯林之间的冲突中，至少有一百万人丧生。

But August 15 was not a complete victory for Nehru; the pledge was not redeemed in its entirety. While balkanization into a myriad of states and principalities had been avoided, British India was divided into two countries, the Hindu-dominated India and Muslim Pakistan.* And although hurried British improvisation had averted the feared total “breakdown” into civil war and anarchy, the upheaval that came with Indian independence was enormous. Fifteen million Hindus and Muslims fled as refugees in opposite directions, passing each other across the newly drawn India-Pakistan borders. With their lives disrupted, filled with harrowing fear and resentment, they soon fell prey to savage violence. Trains loaded with refugees were ambushed before they crossed the border. When the doors swung open at the stations, they revealed only corpses inside. In the cities, neighbors who had long lived in peace turned on one another. Altogether, at least a million people are estimated to have been killed in the Hindu-Muslim strife that came with independence.

对于争取独立的精神领袖、曾倡导印度教徒和穆斯林团结的圣雄甘地而言，胜利的喜悦被惨痛的失败所掩盖。当尼赫鲁准备掌权时，甘地在加尔各答默默祈祷，绝食，徒劳地希望能够阻止席卷全城的教派冲突。1

For the spiritual leader of the struggle for independence, Mahatma Gandhi, who had preached the unity of Hindus and Muslims, the exultation of victory was lost in the pain of a bitter defeat. While Nehru prepared for power, Gandhi spent Independence Day in silent prayer in Calcutta, fasting in the vain hope ofhalting the communal violence that had engulfed the city.1

国家建设

Nation Building

英国的统治结束了。现在，尼赫鲁和他的国大党的任务是将一个殖民地变成一个国家。他们从英国继承了威斯敏斯特模式，并致力于将印度建设成一个联邦制、议会民主制的国家——并且保持这种状态。但是，迎接“国家建设”的挑战不仅仅意味着建立政治制度，它还需要发展现代经济。尼赫鲁经常说，在一个资源和技能极度匮乏的国家，为了实现这一目标，国家必须掌握并控制经济的制高点。在接下来的四十年里，印度将受到尼赫鲁关于现代化、计划经济、工业化和社会主义经济的愿景的主导。在拥有国际经验和声誉的优秀经济学家的建议下，尼赫鲁坚信自己正在借鉴和整合西方和苏联经济模式的精华，再加上国大党在选举中的优势，几乎没有什么能够阻止他建立起世界上最全面、最复杂、最繁琐，最终也最笨重的国家经济计划和管理体系之一。私营企业得以蓬勃发展。但印度经济的核心，其制高点，却掌握在数量庞大的国有企业手中。

The British Raj was finished. Now the task for Nehru and his Congress Party was to turn a colony into a nation. They had inherited from Britain the Westminster model and were committed to making India a federal, parliamentary democracy—and keeping it so. But meeting the challenge of “nation building” meant more than creating political institutions. It required the development of a modern economy. In order to do so in a country desperately short of resources and skills, Nehru often said, the state would have to capture and control the commanding heights of the economy. And for the next forty years India would be dominated by Nehru’s vision of a modern, planned, industrializing, socialist economy. Advised by talented economists with international experience and reputations, convinced he was drawing on and integrating the best of the Western and Soviet economic models, and buoyed by the electoral dominance of the Congress Party, Nehru found little to stop him from developing one of the world’s most thoroughgoing, complex, tangled, and, ultimately, cumbersome systems of national economic planning and administration. Private firms could prosper. But the core of the Indian economy, its commanding heights, was left to an overwhelming array of public enterprises.

公共部门是印度式计划经济整体愿景的核心。这种模式后来广受欢迎。印度的经济选择体现了对理性主义、可预测性、量化和计划的深刻信仰。这些选择体现了当时的主流经济学，经济学家和国际机构出于好意，在全球范围内推广这种经济学。无论以何种形式，当时的主流观点都归结为一点：国家必须创造发展。别无他法。这种方法的影响深远而持久，遍及整个发展中国家。20世纪70年代达到了顶峰，当时第三世界似乎正在​​与富裕国家对抗中走向胜利。然而，这一切都发生在巨大的幻灭之前。

This public sector was central to the overall vision of the planned economy, Indian-style. The model would come to have wide appeal. India’s economic choices reflected profound faith in rationalism, predictability, quantification—and planning. These choices embodied the dominant economics of the day, which, with the best of intentions, economic thinkers and international agencies were promoting around the world. In one form or another, the prevailing view came down to a single point: The state would have to generate development. There was no other way. The impact of this approach would be far-reaching and lasting, across the entire developing world. The zenith would be reached in the 1970s, when the third world seemed to be on the road to victory in its confrontation with the rich countries. That was before the great disillusion.

尼赫鲁的发现

Nehru’s Discovery

尼赫鲁阐述的方法源于他对现代世界的看法以及他对现代技术的信念，再加上他对印度社会现实的认识——或者，正如他所说，是他对“印度的发现”。

The approach that Nehru articulated grew out of his view of the modern world and his belief in its technology, combined with his confrontation with the realities of Indian society—or, as he put it, his “discovery of India.”

事实上， 《印度的发现》是他二战期间在偏远的艾哈迈德讷格尔堡被监禁二十个月期间所写的一本书的书名。他早前在监狱服刑期间就开始撰写自传，但由于1941年12月初提前获释而未能完成。不久之后，他再次被捕，这次是因为在二战最惨烈的时期领导了反对英国统治的抗议活动。他在狱中总体上没有受到虐待。他曾就读于英国最负盛名的公学之一——哈罗公学，这似乎为他赢得了一些特殊优待。在艾哈迈德讷格尔堡，他每天都要花几个小时在监狱院子里的岩石土壤上挖土，为花圃做准备。此外，他还亲手写了一千多页的手稿，详细阐述了他对未来的憧憬，并解释了他“发现”印度的经历以及印度如何改变了他的人生。

The Discovery ofIndia was, in fact, the title he gave to a book he wrote during his twenty months of incarceration in the remote Ahmadnagar fort during World War II. He had started his autobiography during an earlier prison stint but had never finished, because he was released early in December 1941. Not long after, he was again arrested, this time for leading protests against British rule during some of the worst moments of World War II. He generally was not ill-treated during his prison stays. The fact that he had been a student at Harrow, one of England’s most prestigious public schools, seems to have won him some special consideration. At Ahmadnagar fort, he spent hours each day digging at the rocky soil in the prison yard, preparing beds for flowers. But he also wrote by hand over a thousand pages of manuscript detailing his expectations for the future—and explaining his “discovery” of India and how it had transformed his life.

尼赫鲁在印度北部中心地带恒河岸边的阿拉哈巴德长大，家境优渥。他的父亲莫蒂拉尔是印度最杰出的律师之一，事业有成，财富与日俱增。作为印度早期国家经济精英的领袖，莫蒂拉尔·尼赫鲁是呼吁印度独立的国大党的创始人之一。然而，他也为自己作为帝国统治者的成就感到自豪。少年时期的贾瓦哈拉尔住在拥有五十多名仆人、游泳池和最新款欧洲汽车的豪宅里。他的父亲溺爱有加，希望他能拥有一切。尤其希望他能加入印度公务员队伍——在当时，这是印度人在帝国所能获得的最高荣誉。他把儿子送到哈罗公学（在那里他被昵称为“乔”），然后又送他去剑桥大学三一学院，在那里，这位年轻人对自然科学的学习漠不关心。他沉浸于剑河两岸（当时被称为“河岸”）的社交生活。之后，他在伦敦学习成为一名律师，生活奢靡，游历欧洲，并给他的父亲写信，讲述他在不同城市观看的戏剧中的演员。他对科技有着浓厚的兴趣，尤其着迷于航空业的发展。他还经常梦见自己毫不费力地翱翔于天空。

Nehru had grown up in a privileged setting in the city of Allahabad, on the banks of the Ganges, in India’s northern heartland. His father, Motilal, was among the most prominent barristers in India, successful and increasingly rich. An early leader of India’s national economic elite, Motilal Nehru was one of the founders of the Congress Party, which called for independence. Yet he also prided himself on his achievements as a man of the empire. As a boy, young Jawaharlal lived in a house with fifty or more servants, a swimming pool, and the latest European cars. His father, endlessly doting, wanted everything for his only son. Specifically, he wanted him to join the Indian civil service—at the time, the most prestigious appointment an Indian could enjoy in the Empire. He sent the boy to Harrow (where he was nicknamed Joe) and then to Cambridge, to Trinity College, where the young man studied natural sciences with considerable indifference and amused himself in the social life along the Backs, as the banks of the River Cam were called. He then studied to be a barrister in London, spent rather lavishly, toured Europe, and wrote his father about actors and actresses he saw in plays in different cities. He was deeply interested in technology. He followed with fascination the development of aviation. He also had recurring dreams about flying effortlessly in the sky.

1912年，尼赫鲁回到家乡阿拉哈巴德，在那里做了八年律师，但并不热衷。他的生活近乎奢靡。他做律师，参加聚会，周日阅读《笨拙》（Punch）杂志。但他渴望更多。少年时期，他被1857-58年印度民族起义的故事深深吸引。他还如饥似渴地阅读了朱塞佩·加里波第和其他民族主义者的历史，梦想着成就一番伟业。此外，他曾写道：“我一直像我父亲一样，有点赌徒的倾向，起初是在金钱上，后来则在人生的重大问题上赌上更大的赌注。”此时，圣雄甘地开始了他在全国各地乡村的长途跋涉，聚集追随者，并为国大党的独立运动注入了新的活力。深受触动的尼赫鲁与甘地建立了密切的联系，并投身于这项事业。即使在他自己优渥的生活中，他也深知帝国和英国统治是一种屈辱。英属印度的高级官员会到他父亲家来，喝他父亲的香槟，却从不邀请他父亲到自己家吃饭。

In 1912, Nehru returned home to Allahabad, where for eight years he practiced law without much enthusiasm. His lifestyle bordered on the opulent. He worked as a lawyer, went to parties, and read Punch on Sundays. But he itched for something more. As a boy he had been stirred by stories of the Indian mutiny of 1857-58. He had also devoured histories about Giuseppe Garibaldi and other nationalists, and dreamed of “greatness.” Moreover, he would write, “I was always, like my father, a bit of a gambler, at first with money and then for highest stakes, with the bigger issues of life.” By this time, Mahatma Gandhi had begun his long journeys on foot through the country’s villages, gathering followers and breathing a new urgency into the Congress Party’s independence movement. Emotionally compelled, Nehru grew close to the mahatma, and became engaged in the cause. Even in his own privileged life, he saw that Empire and British rule were a humiliation. The senior officials of the British Raj would come to his father’s house and drink his champagne, but they would never invite his father back to their own houses for dinner.

1919年，英军在阿姆利则城屠杀了抗议者。尼赫鲁义愤填膺，从沉寂中苏醒，投身行动。他加入了国大党成立的独立调查组。但对尼赫鲁而言，真正具有决定性意义的事件发生在第二年，也就是1920年。他的家人为了躲避阿拉哈巴德的酷暑，前往位于山城穆索里的豪华萨沃伊酒店，只留下他一人前往。一支阿富汗穆斯林代表团也住在同一家酒店。英国当局担心印度教徒和穆斯林会勾结，禁止尼赫鲁与他们会面。尼赫鲁不愿受英国当局摆布，决定留在阿拉哈巴德的家中。与此同时，一群农民从内陆的拉埃巴雷利地区来到城里，抗议高额赋税和大规模驱逐，希望能找到甘地。但甘地不在城里。于是，他们转而前往尼赫鲁家的宅邸。于是，他们请尼赫鲁代替甘地前往，领导一项新的调查。尼赫鲁也没什么其他事可做，便答应了。

In 1919, the British Army massacred protesters in the city of Amritsar. Enraged, Nehru was raised out of his lethargy and stirred to action. He joined in an independent inquiry that the Congress Party established. But for Nehru, the decisive event came the next year, in 1920. His family had escaped the stifling heat of Allahabad for the elegant Savoy Hotel in the hill station of Mussoorie, leaving him to follow. A delegation of Afghani Muslims was in the same hotel. The British authorities, fearful of Hindu-Muslim collaboration, forbade Nehru to meet them. Rather than be ordered around by the British, he decided to stay at home in Allahabad. At the same time, a group of peasants, protesting against exorbitant taxes and mass evictions, arrived from the hinterland district of Rae Bareli in hopes of finding Gandhi in the city. But he was elsewhere. So instead, they headed for the Nehru family compound. And there they asked Nehru to go in Gandhi’s stead, to lead a new inquiry. Nehru, with little else to do, agreed.

接下来发生的一切令他难以承受。为了让他的车深入印度乡村，农民们连夜修路；当他的车陷在泥里时，他们一次又一次地齐心协力把他抬起来。尼赫鲁从未见过如此凄惨的贫困。“毕竟，”传记作家M·J·阿克巴写道，“他仍然是一位戴着帽子、穿着丝绸内衣的印度绅士。”但在烈日炙烤下，尼赫鲁彻底改变了。“我感到无比羞愧和悲伤，”他后来写道，“我为自己安逸舒适的生活和我们城市里那些琐碎的政治感到羞愧，这些政治对印度无数衣不蔽体的儿女视而不见。”他对印度的衰败和极度贫困深感悲痛。他也发现了自己的政治使命——以及他毕生抱负的焦点。他与父亲坦诚通信，在信中写道：“伟大正被赋予我。”他投身于独立运动，并成为甘地指定的继承人。这位曾在哈罗公学就读的乔，如今已成为“潘迪特”（意为“教师”），并与甘地一起领导着国大党。2

What followed would overwhelm him. The peasants built roads overnight so that his car could pass deep into rural India; they rallied together again and again to lift his car when it became stuck in mud. Nehru had never seen anything like the wretched poverty he now encountered. “After all,” biographer M. J. Akbar would write, “he was still an Indian sahib in a hat and silk underwear.” But under the scorching and blinding sun, Nehru was transformed. “I was filled with shame and sorrow,” he later wrote, “shame at my own easygoing and comfortable life and our petty politics of the city, which ignored this vast multitude of semi-naked sons and daughters of India, sorrow at the degradation and overwhelming poverty of India.” He had also discovered his political vocation—and the focus for his ambition. To his father, with whom he corresponded candidly, he wrote: “Greatness is being thrust on me.” He moved to the fore in the independence movement and emerged as Gandhi’s designated heir. Joe, the public-school boy at Harrow, had become Pandit—Teacher—and the leader with Gandhi of the Congress Party.2

“拖拉机和大型机械”

“Tractors and Big Machinery”

如果说独立是核心政治议题，那么消除贫困就是核心经济议题。1947年8月独立后，贫困成了当务之急。甘地和尼赫鲁在政治目标上立场一致，但在经济问题上却存在分歧。甘地推崇“斯瓦德西”（swadeshi），即自力更生——在家自制基本生活用品，实现乡村自给自足，每家每户都配备纺车。殖民地时期的印度为什么要向曼彻斯特出口棉花，然后再以昂贵服装的形式进口回来？印度人应该自己做衣服。甘地对社会主义和阶级斗争不屑一顾。独立后，他曾对一群共产党员说：“更令我感到悲哀的是，你们竟然把俄罗斯视为精神家园。你们鄙视印度文化，却梦想着把俄罗斯的制度移植到这里。”尼赫鲁的观点与甘地截然不同。他追求的是另一种自给自足——工业化和钢铁厂。他的核心目标是“消除人民的可怕贫困”。他信仰科技和进步，信仰机器和工业化——“我完全赞成使用拖拉机和大型机械，”他说——并且他打算利用二十世纪的手段来实现他的目标。

If independence was the central political issue, then fighting poverty was the central economic issue. With independence achieved in August 1947, poverty was the problem. Whereas Gandhi and Nehru were united on political objectives, they were divided on economics. For Gandhi, the model was swadeshi, self-reliance—simple home production of basic goods, selfsufficiency in the village, and a spinning wheel in every hut. Why should colonial India export cotton to Manchester, only to import it back in the form of expensive clothing? Indians should make their own clothes. Gandhi had little time for socialism and class warfare. After independence, he lectured a group of Communists: “What to me is even more pathetic is that you regard Russia as your spiritual home. Despising Indian culture, you dream of planting the Russian system here.” Nehru’s view disagreed fundamentally with Gandhi’s. He sought a different kind of self-sufficiency—industrialization and the steel mill. His central objective was “to get rid of the appalling poverty of the people.” He believed in technology and progress, in machines and industrialization—“I’m all for tractors and big machinery,” he said—and he intended to use twentieth-century means to achieve his goal.

列宁曾说过，“共产主义等于苏维埃政权加上电气化”。尼赫鲁则提出了印度发展模式的变体——“重型工程和机械制造工业、科学研究机构以及电力”。他无疑认同艾德礼的共识。他对工党的理念和思想的采纳，在他反复提及制高点、混合经济以及计划经济的必要性时显露无疑。但他同​​时也对苏联模式印象深刻，并拥护五年计划和中央计划。尽管他对共产主义对自由的破坏感到不安，但在他最后一次入狱服刑期间，他写道：“苏维埃革命使人类社会向前迈出了一大步，点燃了永不熄灭的火焰，并为世界迈向新的文明奠定了基础。” 私有财产固然重要，但在印度经济建设中，它必须服从于国家。

Lenin had said that “communism equals Soviet power plus electrification.” Nehru offered a variant in his formula for India’s development—“heavy engineering and machine-making industry, scientific research institutes, and electric power.” He certainly shared in the Attlee consensus. His adoption of the themes and ideas of the Labour Party was evident in his recurrent evocation of the commanding heights, the mixed economy, and the need for planning. But he was also much impressed with the Soviet model, and embraced five-year plans and central planning. While troubled by what communism did to freedom, he wrote during his last term in prison that “the Soviet Revolution had advanced human society by a great leap and had lit a bright flame which could not be smothered and that it laid the foundation for a new civilization toward which the world could advance.” Private property, yes, but it was to be subordinate to the state in the building of the Indian economy.

甘地和尼赫鲁在经济理念上的严重分歧导致两人关系紧张。1945年，甘地指责他指定的继承人不忠。针对他关于“国货运动”和“和谐乡村”的经济愿景，尼赫鲁反驳道：“我不明白为什么乡村就一定要体现真理和非暴力。通常来说，乡村在思想和文化上是落后的，落后的环境不可能带来任何进步。心胸狭隘的人更容易说谎和诉诸暴力。”尼赫鲁认为，这位大师的愿景“完全不切实际”。

Their sharply differing economic visions put Gandhi and Nehru very much at odds. In 1945, Gandhi accused his appointed heir of being unfaithful to his economic vision of swadeshi and an India composed of harmonious villages. “I do not understand why a village should necessarily embody truth and nonviolence,” Nehru shot back. “A village, normally speaking, is backward intellectually and culturally and no progress can be made from a backward environment. Narrow-minded people are much more likely to be untruthful and violent.” The master’s vision, said Nehru, was “completely unreal.”

1948年1月30日，一名印度教极端分子刺杀了甘地。举国震惊，悲痛万分。尼赫鲁失去了他的精神导师。但此时，也再无任何阻碍他推行经济计划的因素，他担任总理期间一直贯彻执行该计划，直至1964年去世。在尼赫鲁的领导下，印度走上了社会主义道路，这条道路早在20世纪30年代末就已在国大党全国计划委员会（由尼赫鲁担任主席）中制定。当时，他将世界分为两类人：一类是“希望推动世界进步，将人民从帝国主义和资本主义的枷锁中解放出来的人”；另一类是“少数人，他们正从现状中获利”。他总结道，印度将坚持“独立和社会主义”的立场，因为他补充说，这正是“我们这个贫困不堪、失业率居高不下的国家”所需要的。3

A Hindu extremist murdered Gandhi on January 30, 1948. The country was thrown into shock and pervasive grief. Nehru had lost his spiritual father. But now there was also nothing left to stop his economic program, which he pursued as prime minister until his death in 1964. Under Nehru, India embarked on a socialist course that had already been laid out in the late 1930s in the Congress Party’s National Planning Committee—chaired by Nehru. He had then divided the world between two groups of people. There were those “who want to advance the world further and free the people from the chains of imperialism and capitalism. On the other side, there are a handful of people who are deriving benefit from the present state of things.” India, he concluded, would take its stand on “independence and socialism” for, he added, that was what was needed, “in our own poverty-stricken country, where unemployment prevails.”3

“规划的理念”

“The Idea of Planning”

1948年至1952年间的一系列措施确立了国家经济计划的进程，制定了实施计划的工具和机构，并设计了第一个五年计划。该计划旨在建立一个以国家为主导的混合经济体制。计划委员会成立于1950年，其重要性很快显现。在尼赫鲁的领导下，计划委员会逐渐成为一个准政府机构，成为经济的实际管理者。

A series of measures between 1948 and 1952 established the process of national economic planning, devised the instruments and agencies to carry it out, and designed the first five-year plan. It was to be a mixed economy, heavily weighted toward the state. The Planning Commission was established in 1950 and its preeminence was quickly clear. Chaired by Nehru, it became a quasi-government on its own, the real manager of the economy.

接下来的几年里，印度重申了其对政府主导型经济的坚持。1954年，国大党和议会都呼吁建立“社会主义社会模式”。但印度的实际目标是混合经济，借鉴欧洲和苏联的模式。与法国一样，印度的经济体系将采用三元结构：由关键重工业组成的国有和国家控制部门、国家监管部门以及私营部门。但印度模式更加强调政府的作用。政府将占据主导地位，通过重工业化提供“强劲推动力”，从而实现发展和增长。国家将成为智慧和公正的守护者，精英阶层将管理发展进程，以确保其满足“国家”的需求，而非“特殊利益集团”的需求。

The next several years reaffirmed India’s commitment to a governmentdominated economy. In 1954, both the Congress Party and the Parliament called for “a socialist pattern of society.” But what India actually aimed for was a mixed economy, borrowing from both the European and Soviet systems. As with France, the system was to be tripartite: a state-owned and state-controlled sector composed of the key heavy industries, a stateregulated sector, and a private sector. But the Indian model put much greater emphasis on the role of government. It was to be dominant; it was to provide the “big push,” through heavy industrialization, that would deliver development and growth. The state would be the guardian of wisdom and impartiality, with the elite managing the development process in order to ensure that it met the needs of the “nation” and not of “special interests.”

为了实现这一切，印度建立了一套比任何欧洲国家都更加复杂精细的计划经济体系，制定了详细的经济“投入”和“产出”表格，仿佛经济是一个可以随意掌控的东西。它可以像物理实验一样精确地进行测量和理性管理。尼赫鲁对整个过程表示赞赏。他说：“计划和计划社会的理念，现在在不同程度上已被每个人接受。”

To achieve all this, India put in place a more complicated and intricate system of planning than any of the European nations, with detailed tables of economic “inputs” and “outputs,” as if the economy were something that could be measured and rationally managed with the precision of a physics experiment. Nehru blessed the entire process. “The idea of planning and a planned society,” he said, “is accepted now in varying degrees by everyone.”

印度“计划与控制体系”的极端理性主义科学论，反映了其塑造者是一位晚年转行经济学的杰出科学家。P.C. 马哈拉诺比斯是当时印度最杰出的经济学家，影响了一代人。与尼赫鲁一样，他也曾就读于剑桥大学自然科学专业；但与尼赫鲁不同的是，他的成绩非常优异，物理学专业获得了最高荣誉。他先是成为了一名统计学家，后来才成为一名经济学家。但他始终秉持着科学家的理性信念，因此，与让·莫内于法国建立的指示性计划不同，他推崇高度量化的计划，并以基于对经济及其部门和企业间联系的“科学”研究而构建的复杂数学矩阵为基础。正如他的一位年轻同事所说，马哈拉诺比斯完全赞同英国物理学家威廉·开尔文的格言：“定性推理只不过是‘糟糕的定量推理’。”马哈拉诺比斯试图将这一原则应用于一个拥有数亿人口的国家的经济中。

The hyperrationalist scientism of the Indian “planning-and-control system” reflected the fact that it was shaped by a brilliant scientist who had turned to economics in later life. P. C. Mahalanobis was the outstanding Indian economist of his time, and he influenced an entire generation. Like Nehru, he had gone to Cambridge to study natural sciences; but unlike Nehru, he had done very well indeed, getting a first in physics. He became a statistician and only later an economist. But he retained the scientist’s belief in rationality, and thus, in contrast to the indicative planning that Jean Monnet had established in France, he promoted highly quantitative planning, fed by complex mathematical matrices based on “scientific” study of the economy and the linkages among sectors and enterprises.
