As one of his younger colleagues put it, Mahalanobis subscribed wholeheartedly to the dictum of the British physicist William Kelvin “that qualitative reasoning was nothing other than ‘poor quantitative reasoning.’” Mahalanobis sought to apply that precept to the economy of a country of many hundreds of millions of people.

公共部门的扩张是在极大的热情下进行的。国家将完全控制某些行业；在其他行业，现有的私营企业可以继续存在，但所有新企业都将由国家接管。经济政策排除了对现有公司进行国有化的可能性，只有少数例外。商业和小规模活动仍然保持私有化，塔塔家族和比尔拉家族等大型私营工业帝国得以保留（塔塔航空除外，该公司被国有化并更名为印度航空）。相反，所有新的大型企业都将由国家接管。大量新的公共公司应运而生——涵盖电力公司、化工厂、汽车组装厂，甚至连锁酒店——以及国有银行。

The expansion of the public sector was carried out with great enthusiasm. The state would control some sectors exclusively; in others, existing private enterprise could survive, but the state would take charge of all new undertakings. Economic policy ruled out nationalization of existing companies, with only a few exceptions. Commerce and small-scale activities stayed private, and the large private industrial empires of the Tata and Birla families, and others, remained intact (with the exception of Tata Air, which was nationalized and became Air India). Rather, the state would take charge of all new large ventures. Hosts of new public companies were created—ranging from power utilities to chemical plants to automobile assemblies, even hotel chains—along with state-owned banks.

这些公司将成为国家冠军，是印度经济独立的象征。它们将向国内和世界展示印度的技能和能力，并有助于凝聚这个新生国家。对于一个正努力从众多省份和公国中挣脱出来的国家而言，最后一个目标至关重要，因为这些省份和公国的世袭统治者曾直接与英国打交道。这些国有企业也将成为民族自豪感的源泉。在招聘启事和信笺抬头，这些公共企业都自豪地在其名称后标注“印度政府企业”。4

These various companies would be national champions, the economic embodiment of India’s independence. They would demonstrate India’s skills and capabilities to the nation and the outside world and they would help tie the new nation together. That last objective was critical to a nation struggling to forge itself out of many provinces, as well as numerous principalities, whose hereditary rulers had dealt directly with the British. And the state companies would be a source of national pride. In their recruitment notices and on their letterheads, the public enterprises proudly announced, after their names, “A GOVERNMENT OF INDIA UNDERTAKING.”4

许可证制度

The Permit Raj

印度体制的影响远远超出了国界。印度是战后非殖民化最显著的典范。尼赫鲁广受尊敬，是一位正直的典范，一位最终取得胜利的人。印度作为第三世界集团的领导者，在没有武力对抗大英帝国的情况下，展现了强大的实力。印度的众多经济学家接受过最前沿的训练，他们忠于自己的理论模型，并且见多识广、口才出众。印度的经济模式似乎始终处于发展的前沿，因此也产生了巨大的影响。

The impact of the Indian system was felt far beyond its borders. India was the most prominent example of decolonization of the postwar years. Nehru was widely respected, a figure of rectitude, the man who had prevailed against the British Empire without a sword, the leader of the third world bloc. India’s many economists were trained in the state of the art; they were committed to their models. They were also worldly and wonderfully articulate. And the Indian economic model seemed to be at the very forefront of development. As a consequence, it proved to be enormously influential.

然而，问题在于，印度经济的实际表现与模型预测相去甚远。这套体系的创建者们认为，他们为解决一个深陷贫困的国家如何实现工业发展、造福社会这一难题，提供了一个极其理性——甚至是唯一理性——的方案。但结果却截然相反。事实证明，印度经济无法用物理定律来解释。中央规划者无法有效地控制它；庞大的国有企业也无法有效地“推动”它发展，因为这些企业不受市场约束和考验。印度非但没有构建出完美的“大推进”机制，反而发展出一套极其复杂且繁琐的体系。这套体系通过错综复杂的数量管制、配额和关税、数不胜数的许可证、工业执照以及其他各种控制措施来运作——在这个迷宫中，激励机制、主动性和企业家精神要么消失殆尽，要么被彻底扭曲。所有这些都导致经济效率日益低下；官僚体制接管了市场的功能。有些人最终会说，英属印度时期已经让位于许可证制度时期。

There was, however, one problem. The Indian economy did not perform as the model had predicted. The creators of the system thought they were putting in place an eminently rational—indeed, the only rational—solution to the conundrum of industrial development for the social good in a country engulfed by poverty. The results proved otherwise. It turned out that the economy of India could not be reduced to the laws of physics. It could not be controlled, at least with any degree of efficiency, by planners at the center; nor could it be satisfactorily “pushed” by a vast collection of state-owned enterprises that were not subject to the discipline and tests of the market. Instead of gaining the perfectly constructed mechanism for the “big push,” India developed a thoroughly complex and enormously cumbersome system. It operated through a byzantine maze of quantitative regulations, quotas and tariffs, endless permits, industrial licenses, and a host of other controls—a maze in which incentives and initiative and entrepreneurship either were lost or became hopelessly distorted. All of this made the economy increasingly inefficient; bureaucratic dispensation took over the functions of the marketplace. The British Raj, some would eventually say, had given way to the Permit Raj.

这些限制导致了经济停滞，令那些曾热情支持国大党和独立运动的商人们感到沮丧，同时也造成了一个巨大的悖论：印度培养了一批才华横溢的世界级科学家和工程师，然而，对自给自足和国有企业的过分强调，却使印度脱离了全球技术潮流，并给自己造成了某种程度的技术落后。在《印度的发现》一书中，尼赫鲁曾预言科学和工程将推动印度的经济增长和发展。但在独立后的二十年里，印度逐渐发现，既有的体制最终会阻碍经济进步，也会阻碍技术发展。这种体制的象征便是“大使牌”（Amby）——这款仿照20世纪60年代英国奥斯汀汽车设计的国产轿车，在20世纪90年代末仍在生产，仿佛是汽车时代的遗物。

The restrictions brought economic stagnation. They frustrated the businessmen who had so ardently supported the Congress Party and independence. They also created a great paradox. India developed an immensely talented world-class pool of scientists and engineers. Yet the emphasis on self-sufficiency and state enterprises meant that India stepped out of the global flow of technology and imposed upon itself a form of technological retardation. In The Discovery of India, Nehru had postulated that science and engineering would drive India into economic growth and development. But in the two decades after independence, India was to discover that the system put into place would end up frustrating both economic and technological progress. Its symbol was seen on the streets of India in the “Amby”—the Ambassador—the domestic car modeled on the British Austin of the 1960s, an automotive time warp still being produced in the late 1990s.

这套体系也沦为了政治的牺牲品。随着尼赫鲁年事渐高，国大党对政治的掌控力开始减弱。面对竞争，该党转而依赖裙带关系，有时甚至诉诸贪污腐败。公共企业发现自己陷入了选区政治博弈和利益集团争斗的漩涡之中。随着印度民主日益活跃、喧嚣纷扰，由知识精英构想、以科学和理性为基础的经济结构，再也无法置身于世俗政治的纷争之外。

The system fell prey to politics, too. As Nehru grew old, the Congress Party’s grip on politics began to loosen. Faced with competition, the party turned to patronage and, sometimes, to graft. Public enterprises found themselves caught between the political tugging of constituencies and the bickering of organized interests. As India’s democracy grew livelier and more clamorous, the economic structures—imagined by an intellectual elite and based on science and rationality—could no longer be kept above the fray of ordinary, “vulgar” politics.

然而，还有其他选择吗？尼赫鲁和政客们并没有。他周围的技术官僚和经济学家们都清楚地看到了这一点。独立后的几年里，国家的政治和经济问题极其严重，国家也极其贫困。几乎没有资本市场可言，中产阶级也寥寥无几。在尼赫鲁看来，过去充满了神秘主义。未来应该建立在理性之上。“发展”意味着利用科学技术。他们等不起一百年。私人资本家从定义上来说就值得怀疑；他们会追求自身的私利。他们没有任何道德或伦理上的诉求。那么，有哪些模式可供选择呢？答案是：西欧混合经济模式和苏联指令控制模式的某种结合，后者以五年计划和大力推进工业化为特征。因此，这些模式融合在一起，建立在甘地自给自足理念和甘地曾与之斗争的帝国文官制度的部分遗产之上——以及可以追溯到莫卧儿王朝的强大国家传统。而整个体系的核心是强烈的信念，即出于必要性，国家的经济未来必须托付给国家。

Yet was there an alternative? None that Nehru and the politicians and technocrats and economists around him could easily see. In the years after independence, the nation’s political and economic problems were enormous and the country was terribly poor. There was no capital market to speak of, and not much of a middle class. The past, as Nehru saw it, was mired in mysticism. The future should be based upon rationality. To “develop” meant to harness science and technology. They could not afford to wait a hundred years. Private capitalists were by definition suspect; they would pursue their own private interests. They had no moral or ethical claim. What models, then, were there to choose from? The answer: some combination of the mixed economy of Western Europe and the command-and-control model of the Soviet Union, with its five-year plans and big push into industrialization. So the models were fused and erected upon the partial legacies of Gandhian self-sufficiency and the imperial civil service that Gandhi had fought—and a strong state tradition going back to the Mogul emperors. And at the heart of the whole system was the powerful conviction that necessity required the nation’s economic future to be entrusted to the state.

《建设更美好世界的议程》：发展经济学家

“An Agenda for a Better World”: The Development Economists

印度并非孤立存在。恰恰相反，印度的经验产生了巨大的影响，它既是各国努力的焦点，也是最大的试验场，更是许多其他国家的榜样。尽管印度是面积最大的国家，但它只是二战后涌现的众多新独立国家中的第一个。随着欧洲殖民帝国的瓦解，非殖民化浪潮席卷而来，独立国家的数量从1947年的55个激增至20世纪80年代末（共产主义帝国解体之前）的150多个。这些国家大多贫困，许多更是赤贫。即使在拉丁美洲等那些早在二战前就已独立的国家，贫困问题也同样普遍存在。

India hardly existed in a vacuum. On the contrary, that country’s experience was to have tremendous impact, both as a focus of effort, the greatest laboratory, and as an example to many other nations. For although India was the largest, it was but the first of the newly independent nations to emerge after World War II. As decolonization cascaded with the disintegration of the European colonial empires, the number of independent countries swelled from fifty-five in 1947 to over 150 by the end of the 1980s (before the breakup of the communist empire). Most were poor; many, desperately poor. Poverty was also endemic in countries whose independence had long predated World War II, as in Latin America.

贫困的阴影曾是一股强大的凝聚力量。战争期间，富兰克林·罗斯福以他提出的四大自由中的第四项——免于匮乏的自由——号召全世界共同对抗贫困。在英国，贝弗里奇报告也同时呼吁消除贫困这一顽疾，并建立福利国家。这成为激励人们努力改善那些过去被称为落后或欠发达地区（不久后将被称为第三世界，或者更乐观地称为发展中国家）人民生活的伟大事业的动力。

This specter of poverty was a powerful rallying point. During the war, Franklin Roosevelt had summoned the world to a battle against poverty with the fourth of his four freedoms—the freedom from want. In Britain, the Beveridge Report had simultaneously called for the slaying of the giant of poverty and the creation of the welfare state. Such became the animating spirit for a great effort to bring a better life to what had been called in former days the backward or underdeveloped areas but would soon enough be known as the third world, or, more optimistically, the developing world.

理想主义和利他主义并非唯一的驱动力。冷战对抗使发展成为西方政府的首要关注点。苏联正利用其发展模式和对外援助来争取各国加入其阵营。与共产主义的竞争促使美国和其他西方政府渴望走一条非共产主义的发展道路，一条能够带来稳定的道路。马歇尔计划和战后重建的成功——以及从中积累的经验——不仅加强了这项工作，也增强了继续推进的信心。事实上，消除发展中国家的贫困和绝望的努力，几乎是战后重建的必然延续。经济学家阿尔伯特·赫希曼回忆道：“马歇尔计划取得成功之后，亚洲、非洲和拉丁美洲的欠发达问题，成为任何‘建设更美好世界议程’中尚未解决的主要经济问题。”

Idealism and altruism were not the only driving forces. The cold war confrontation made development a primary concern for Western governments. The Soviet Union was deploying both its development model and its foreign aid to win countries over to its camp. The competition with communism made the American and other Western governments eager to embrace a noncommunist path to development, one that would lead to stability. And the success of the Marshall Plan and postwar reconstruction—and the experience gained therein—not only reinforced the effort but also provided the confidence to proceed. Indeed, the crusade to overcome poverty and despair in the developing world seemed almost the logical continuation of postwar reconstruction. “After the success of the Marshall Plan,” the economist Albert O. Hirschman recalled, “the underdevelopment of Asia, Africa, and Latin America loomed as the major unresolved economic problem on any ‘Agenda for a Better World.’”

但发展究竟该如何实现？答案来自一群投身于一场变革运动的经济学家。为了应对新兴国家的贫困，他们开创了发展经济学这一新兴学科，并由此成为这场变革运动的战略家。他们试图解答一系列基本问题：经济增长的驱动力是什么？如何加速经济增长？从某种意义上说，这些问题正是亚当·斯密在《国富论》中探讨的核心，因为他试图解释“富裕的自然进程”。但在20世纪40年代末、50年代和60年代，“自然”一词已不再适用。对于发展经济学家而言，当务之急是加速发展——他们不再等待所谓的百年周期，而是着眼于十年内能够取得的成就。他们寻求的是立即启动变革的方法。他们的成果再次印证了凯恩斯关于“学院派文人”影响力的论断，因为他们的思想对世界历史上两代人的时间跨度内数十个国家的经济体系产生了巨大的影响。他们思想的力量源于他们不仅是思想家，更是“实干家”，积极投身于设计和实施工作。

But how was development to happen? The answer came from a group of economists who enlisted in a crusade. In response to the poverty of newly emerging nations, they fashioned a new branch of the dismal science called development economics and, in so doing, became grand strategists of the crusade. They sought to answer a set of basic questions: What drives economic growth? How can it be accelerated? In a way, these questions had been central to Adam Smith’s inquiry in The Wealth ofNations, for he had set out to explain “the natural progress of opulence.” But in the late 1940s and the 1950s and 1960s, “natural” was unacceptable. For the development economists, the urgent drive was to accelerate—not to wait on what was thought to be a one-hundred-year cycle but rather to see what could be achieved in a decade. They asked how to get something going now. And their work was to prove yet again Keynes’ dictum about the impact of “academic scribblers,” for their ideas were to be enormously influential in shaping the economic systems of dozens and dozens of countries across two generations of world history. The power of their ideas arose from the fact that they were not only thinkers but also “doers,” drawn into the work of design and implementation.

他们的信念至少部分源于凯恩斯主义——体现在对国家驱动型增长的关注、宏观经济分析工具的使用，以及凯恩斯主义根深蒂固的自信。贝弗里奇的福利议程也对他们产生了深远的影响。此外，印度也对他们产生了重要影响。“凯恩斯和贝弗里奇都主张积极的国家干预，”汉斯·辛格写道，他是早期发展经济学家中最杰出的人物之一。“这使我自然而然地对发展规划问题产生了浓厚的兴趣，而发展规划在战后初期非常流行，尤其关注印度。在这方面，马哈拉诺比斯成为了发展经济学家的先知（或导师），而加尔各答则成为了他们的圣地。”

Their beliefs were at least in part an outgrowth of Keynesianism—in the focus on state-driven growth, in terms of the tools of macroeconomic analysis, and in the bedrock of Keynesian self-confidence. The Beveridge welfare agenda also influenced them greatly. But so did India. “Keynes and Beveridge were both proponents of active state intervention,” wrote Hans Singer, one of the most prominent of the original development economists. “This preconditioned me to take a direct interest in the problems of development planning, much in vogue in the immediate postwar year, with special focus on India. P. C. Mahalanobis became the prophet (or guru) of the development economists in this respect, and Calcutta became their Mecca.”

理想主义、道德、正义、人道主义、面对贫困的冲击、对美好世界的憧憬——所有这些都将人们投入到这场事业中。他们的观点被阿尔伯特·赫希曼（Albert Hirschman）概括了出来，他是发展经济学领域最杰出的先驱之一。正如他所说：“这些经济学家在二战后投身发展经济学，并非出于狭隘的专业知识，而是受到对美好世界的憧憬的驱使。作为自由主义者，他们中的大多数人认为‘好事相伴而生’，并理所当然地认为，只要能够有效提高相关国家的国民收入，就能带来一系列有益的成果。”其影响将波及社会、政治和文化领域。”总体目标是“使人民彻底摆脱落后状态”。5

Idealism, morality, justice, human sympathy, the shock of confronting poverty, the vision of a better world—all of these brought people into the crusade. Their outlook was summed up by Albert Hirschman, one of the most distinguished of the “pioneers of development.” As he put it, “These economists had taken up the cultivation of development economics in the wake of World War II not as narrow specialists, but impelled by the vision of a better world. As liberals, most of them presumed that ‘all good things go together’ and took it for granted that if only a good job could be done in raising the national income of the countries concerned, a number of beneficial effects would follow in the social, political, and cultural realms.” The overall objective was to “bring all-around emancipation from backwardness.”5

他们的个人经历有助于解释他们为何致力于构建一个更美好的世界。赫希曼的人生经历反映了他所谓的“历史的灾难性偏离”。他出生于柏林，在的里雅斯特大学获得博士学位，二战期间在军队服役五年（先后效力于法国和美国军队），战后曾在美国联邦储备委员会和马歇尔计划工作，并在哥伦比亚担任了四年经济顾问。保罗·罗森斯坦-罗丹出生于波兰克拉科夫，成长于一个即将被纳粹彻底摧毁的世界和文化之中。二战期间，他协助在伦敦皇家国际事务研究所组织了一个研究小组，探讨战后发展中国家即将面临的问题。他的基本观点是：“如果我们想要幸存下来，就不应该回到战前的状态，而应该……创造一个更美好的世界。”在他看来，战后的挑战在于从“国家福利”转向“国际福利”。他写道：“当我们的世界资源足以改善机会不平等和贫困状况时，却没有采取足够的措施来解决这些问题，这才是真正的道德危机。”

Their individual stories help explain their drive to develop an agenda for a better world. Hirschman’s life reflected what he called the “calamitous derailments of history.” He was born in Berlin, received his Ph.D. at the University of Trieste, served five years in the army during World War II (the French and the American), worked after the war for both the U.S. Federal Reserve and the Marshall Plan, and spent four years as an economic adviser in Colombia. Paul Rosenstein-Rodan was born in Krakow, Poland, and grew up in a world and culture that were to be completely obliterated by the Nazis. During World War II, he helped organize a study group at the Royal Institute of International Affairs in London on the upcoming postwar problems of the underdeveloped countries. His premise was that “if we were to emerge alive, we should not return to the previous status quo but…form a better world.” As he saw it, the challenge after the war was to move from “the national welfare to the international” welfare state. “Not to do enough about inequality of opportunity and poverty when our world resources are sufficient to improve the situation is the real moral crisis,” he wrote.

扬·廷伯根，这位后来荣获诺贝尔经济学奖的学者，在二战后担任荷兰中央计划局局长期间，一直致力于战后重建工作。1951年，P.C.马哈拉诺比斯邀请他访问印度。尽管廷伯根在自己的国家也目睹了战争造成的贫困，但“印度普遍存在的贫困——作为一种常态——与我的国家形成了鲜明的对比，这改变了我的思考方式和主要工作方向。” 阿瑟·刘易斯在英属西印度群岛的圣卢西亚长大，14岁辍学。几年后，他获得奖学金进入伦敦政治经济学院深造，这开启了他卓越的经济学生涯，并最终像廷伯根一样荣获诺贝尔经济学奖。消除贫困是他毕生关注的核心：不仅应该消除贫困，而且完全可以消除贫困。“我的母亲从小就教育我，”他回忆道，“要相信他们能做到的，我们也能做到。”沃尔特·罗斯托引用了他名字的由来——诗人沃尔特·惠特曼的几句诗来概括他的职业：“全世界的人们一起航行/驶向同一航程/注定要到达同一个目的地。”

Jan Tinbergen, who was to win the Nobel Prize in economics, was preoccupied with reconstruction as the director of the Central Planning Bureau in the Netherlands after World War II. Then, in 1951, P. C. Mahalanobis invited him to India. Although Tinbergen had seen want as a result of the war in his own country, “the poverty prevailing in India—as a normal situation—was such a contrast that it redirected my thinking and main activities.” Arthur Lewis grew up in St. Lucia, in the British West Indies. He left school at fourteen. A few years later he won a scholarship to the London School of Economics, which launched him on a distinguished career in economics that would lead him, like Tinbergen, to the Nobel Prize. The conquest of poverty was his central preoccupation: Not only should it be conquered, it could be conquered. “My mother had brought me up,” he recalled, “to believe that anything they can do we can do.” Walt Rostow summed up his vocation by citing a few lines from the poet for whom he was named, Walt Whitman: “All peoples of the globe together sail/sail the same voyage/are bound to the same destination.”

发展经济学家从历史中寻求指导。亚历山大·格申克龙的代表作《从历史角度看经济落后》于1951年首次出版，影响深远。格申克龙探讨了工业“后起之秀”——德国、法国、俄国——如何努力追赶英国。他指出，各国实现工业化的道路多种多样。这些后起之秀并非遵循亚当·斯密的路径。相反，它们似乎以两倍甚至三倍的时间完成了工业化进程，这得益于国家更深入的干预——通过引导投资以及政府、金融和产业之间的紧密联盟。这种观点为在资源不足的情况下调动资本提供了思路。制度证明，政府可以缩小差距，并提供加速“富裕进程”的手段。这引起了发展经济学家的强烈共鸣，他们正致力于缩小“后发者”与发达国家之间的差距。

The development economists looked to history for guidance. Alexander Gerschenkron’s masterpiece, Economic Backwardness in Historical Perspective, first unveiled in 1951, was enormously influential. Gerschenkron explored how the industrial “latecomers”—Germany, France, Russia—sought to “catch up” with Britain. He showed that there were many paths by which nations industrialized. The latecomers did not get there by Adam Smith’s route. Rather, they seemed to move in double or triple time, via much more intense involvement by the state—through the direction of investment and a close alliance among government, finance, and industry. This perspective suggested ways to mobilize capital in the face of inadequate institutions and proved that governments could close the gap and provide the means for speeding up the “progress of opulence.” And it struck a deeply responsive chord for the development economists, who were seeking to close the gap for the “late latecomers.”

发展经济学的理论基础是一些基本假设。第三世界拥有丰富的土地、劳动力和自然资源潜力，但却极度缺乏资本。没有资本，市场就会瘫痪甚至消失，其发出的信号也变得不可靠。发展中国家需要基础设施——公路、铁路、电力——来奠定现代经济的基础，而当时功能不全的市场不太可能调动这些项目所需的大量资本。因此，政府必须承担这些责任，因为与受股东短期利益驱动的私人投资者不同，政府可以承担风险，并承担那些可能需要数十年才能成熟的投资的责任。

Certain basic assumptions served as the underpinnings for development economics. The third world was abundant in land, labor, and natural-resource potential, but what it desperately lacked was capital. Without capital, markets were disabled or even absent, and the signals they sent were unreliable. The developing countries needed infrastructure—roads, railways, electric power—to provide the foundations for a modern economy, and markets in their then-truncated state were unlikely to mobilize the vast sums of capital such projects required. Governments would have to do it instead, because, unlike private financiers dogged by shareholders in search of near-term paybacks, governments could assume the risks and bear the responsibilities of investments that might take decades to mature.

发展经济学家对市场及其活力持怀疑态度，因此，他们对发展中国家的私营部门也抱有戒心。他们认为私营部门规模极其有限：在非洲殖民地，私营部门仅限于基本商品贸易商——这显然不是工业化的基础。即使在私营部门规模较大的地区，尤其是在拉丁美洲，它似乎也只是由少数极其富有的家族组成，这些家族安于现状，满足于被视为“剥削性”的社会秩序，并且不愿接受变革。简而言之，私营部门要么追求特殊利益而非尼赫鲁所阐述的“公共利益”，要么缺乏完成任务的能力、活力和“决心”。尽管发展经济学家对私营部门抱有固有的悲观态度，但他们对政府的作用却持乐观态度。结果是：“他们坚信，在欠发达地区，工业化需要深思熟虑、深入细致、有指导性的努力。” 苏联五年计划的“突击式”实施是行不通的。相反，需要集中力量和资本——这被称作“大推进”、“起飞”、“大跃进”，或者不那么形象地称为“前后联系”——这将使发展中国家进入一个新的现实。

The development economists were doubtful about the market and its vigor, and for this reason, they were suspicious of the private sector in the developing countries. It seemed desperately small: In the colonies of Africa, it had been kept confined to the traders of basic goods—surely no base for industrialization. Where a larger private sector existed, especially in Latin America, it appeared to consist of a handful of excessively wealthy families, which were content with what was regarded as an “exploitative” social order and were loath to accept change. In short, either the private sector would pursue special interests rather than the “public good” that Nehru had articulated or it would lack the capability, vigor, and “heart” to get the job done. But if they were inherently pessimistic about the private sector, the development economists were optimistic about what governments could do. The result: “the conviction that, in underdeveloped areas, industrialization required a deliberate, intensive, guided effort.” There was not to be the “storming” of the Soviet five-year plans. Rather, there was to be a concentration of effort and capital—variously called the “big push” or the “take-off” or the “great spurt” or, less colorfully, “backward and forward linkages”—that would carry the developing country into a new reality.

诚然，一些发展经济学家以更为乐观的态度，关注市场、价格和国际贸易的有效性和效用。鲍尔（P.T. Bauer）借鉴其在马来亚与橡胶种植户以及西非贸易商的合作经验，认为企业家精神在第三世界同样存在，而且企业家的努力总和将比政府指导更为有效。然而，像鲍尔这样批评主流发展经济学的人士却被视为特立独行、不切实际。正如20世纪30年代资本主义声名狼藉一样，以市场为中心的经济学也同样如此。经济学家们不再关注市场的运作方式，而是强调市场的缺陷和失灵。发展经济学的主流观点设想了一个更为宏大的未来。政府在其中扮演着核心角色。纠正这些缺陷的显而易见的办法就是建立一个强大的国家。6

To be sure, some development economists focused, with more optimism, on the effectiveness and utility of markets, prices, and international trade. Drawing upon his work with rubber farmers in Malaya and traders in West Africa, P. T. Bauer argued that entrepreneurship existed in the third world, too, and that the sum of the efforts of the entrepreneurs would be much more efficacious than government direction. But critics of mainstream development economics like Bauer were considered eccentric and off the mark. As the 1930s had discredited capitalism, so had it discredited market-focused economics. Instead of concentrating on how markets worked, economists emphasized the imperfections and failures of the market. The dominant view in development economics envisioned a much larger—and central—role for government. The obvious way to correct the imperfections was with a strong state.6

“银行”

“The Bank»

在非殖民化运动的推动下，在大量外援资金的涌入以及冷战时期与新独立国家结盟这一主导性需求的推动下，一个庞大的发展体系应运而生。它由政府捐助机构、私人基金会、国际开发银行、大学和研究机构，以及财政部、工业部和发展部等部门组成。在这一体系中，有一个机构占据核心地位——国际复兴开发银行，即世界银行。它是政策和资金的制定和实施以及相关讨论的枢纽。

Spurred by decolonization, fueled by the profusion of foreign-aid dollars and the dominant cold war imperative of making allies of the newly independent countries, a vast development enterprise was born. It was made up of governmental donor agencies, private foundations, international development banks, universities, and research institutes, along with ministries of finance, industry, and development. Amid this constellation, one institution was central—the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, otherwise known as the World Bank. It was the pivot around which policies and funding were put into place, and around which the debate was organized.

世界银行于1944年在布雷顿森林会议上成立，旨在协调战后欧洲艰巨的经济重建工作。但正如包括凯恩斯在内的创始人所设想的那样，其使命很快扩展至投资发展中国家的基础设施。1948年，世界银行向智利提供了1600万美元的贷款，用于建设发电厂和农业机械，这是其向第三世界国家提供的第一笔贷款。1949年，世界银行向印度提供了第一笔亚洲贷款（不包括对日本的重建贷款），用于建设水电项目。1950年，世界银行向埃塞俄比亚提供了第一笔非洲贷款，用于购置通信设备。到20世纪50年代初，世界银行的重心已完全从欧洲的“重建”转向第三世界的“发展”。其基本使命是从发达国家的资本市场筹集多边资金，并将这些资金以优惠（即非常有利）的条件向发展中国家的公共部门提供长期贷款。这些贷款将由发展中国家提供偿还担保。这样一来，这家银行就能获得跨境资本流动——无论是旧国界还是新国界。但它几乎是从零开始，因为“大萧条和第二次世界大战彻底破坏了国际投资的模式和流动”。

The World Bank was created at the Bretton Woods conference in 1944 to coordinate the awesome job of economic reconstruction in what would soon be postwar Europe. But its mandate quickly expanded—exactly as its founders, including Keynes, had intended—to investing in the infrastructure of developing countries. Its first loan to the third world was $16 million to Chile in 1948, for power-plant and agricultural machinery. It made its first loan to Asia (excluding reconstruction loans to Japan) in 1949—to India, for a hydroelectric project. Its first loan to Africa came in 1950—to Ethiopia, for communications equipment. By the early 1950s its focus had fully shifted from “reconstruction” in Europe to “development” in the third world. Its basic mandate was to raise multilateral finance from the capital markets of developed nations and use that money to make long-term loans on concessional (i.e., very favorable) terms to the public sectors of developing countries. Those loans would be secured by repayment guarantees from the developing country. Thus the bank would get capital flowing across borders—old and new. But it had to start from almost nowhere, for “the pattern and flow of international investment were ruptured beyond recognition by the Great Depression and the Second World War.”

世界银行的作用是帮助确保市场发展的条件到位。它的贷款旨在纠正市场失灵——或者更确切地说是市场缺失。也就是说，它会为市场经济发展所需的、要么不存在要么严重缺乏的基础设施提供资金。因此，其大部分资金都用于交通运输（港口、公路、铁路）、通信，以及最重要的电力——通常是通过大型水电站来实现的。世界银行表示，此类基础设施是“持续经济增长的必要前提”。用世界银行历史学家的话来说，促使其采取这种发展方向的是“一系列紧急情况”。电力短缺在亚洲和拉丁美洲十分普遍；在非洲，基础设施几乎一片空白。巴西宁愿从荷兰进口土豆到里约热内卢，也不愿从内陆一百英里处运过来。印度铁路的货运总是延误数周之久。面对如此重重阻碍、不确定性和混乱局面，又怎能指望私人企业家进行投资并承担风险呢？

The World Bank’s role was to help ensure that the conditions for market development were in place. Its lending was meant to correct market failure—or what might even be called market absence. That is, it would fund the nonexistent or sorely lacking infrastructure that was required for the development of market economies. Thus, most of its funding went for transportation (ports, roads, railways), communications, and, above all, electric power—often by means of large hydroelectric dams. Such infrastructure, the bank said, was “an essential precondition for sustained economic growth.” It was driven to this orientation by, in the words of the bank’s historians, “a series of emergency situations.” Power shortages were endemic in Asia and Latin America; in Africa, there was little infrastructure at all. It was easier for Brazil to import potatoes into Rio de Janeiro from Holland than to ship them from a hundred miles inland. Deliveries by the Indian railway system were weeks and weeks late. How could private entrepreneurs be expected to make investments and take risks in the face of such obstacles, uncertainty, and disorganization?

世界银行之所以介入，是因为发展中国家无法调动足够的国内储蓄来完成此类项目。外国投资者也无法指望获得足够的投资回报率，因此难以被吸引到此类项目中。此外，在当时的“国家建设”时期，外国资本并不受欢迎。私人投资于被视为至关重要的基础设施项目，要么意味着外国管理、外国飞地以及利润汇回国内，要么意味着少数原本就非常富有的家族进一步积累财富和权力。

The World Bank stepped into this role because the developing countries could not mobilize sufficient domestic savings to get such projects done. Foreign investors could not count on a sufficient rate of return to be attracted to such projects. Moreover, foreign capital was not very welcome during this era of “nation building.” Private investment in what were seen as critically important infrastructure projects meant either foreign management and foreign enclaves and the repatriation of profits or further enrichment and power for a few families that were already very rich.

如果说世界银行的使命可以借鉴一个模式，那就是美国的田纳西河谷管理局（TVA）。TVA是一家致力于满足重大需求的公共企业。它高效运作，拥有强烈的使命感和足够的规模，能够有效发挥作用，不受政治和腐败的影响，能够培养和集中人才，并具备长远眼光。TVA在美国中南部取得了巨大的成功，其首任局长戴维·利林塔尔（David Lilienthal）堪称一位尽职尽责、不求回报、能力卓越的公仆典范，他能够高效甚至出色地平衡公共利益和私人利益。正如美国的TVA和欧洲的国有企业一样，国有企业也将成为第三世界发展和现代化的途径。

If there was a single model in the mission of the World Bank, it was America’s Tennessee Valley Authority, a public enterprise devoted to a great need. The TVA was efficient, with a powerful sense of mission and sufficient scale to be effective, insulated from politics and corruption, a generator and focuser of skills, and capable of the longer view. It had succeeded mightily in the middle South of the United States, and its first leader, David Lilienthal, was the living expression of the dedicated, disinterested, capable public servant who could effectively, and even brilliantly, operate at the intersection of public and private interests. As with the TVA in the United States and the state companies in Europe, so state-owned companies would be the means of development and modernization in the third world.

田纳西河谷管理局（TVA）的形象与世界银行的宗旨相符。世界银行只能向公共机构提供贷款，而相比于各部委，半独立的国有企业更能调动技能和资本，以实现重要的国家目标。此外，世界银行希望促进规模化和效率提升，正如田纳西河谷管理局的成立所实现的那样。随着时间的推移，世界银行也越来越愿意与基础设施以外领域的国有企业合作，例如工业和金融领域。世界银行确实在1956年成立了一家附属机构——国际金融公司（IFC），旨在向私营企业提供贷款，但在之后的许多年里，IFC的作用微乎其微。7

The image of the TVA fit the charter of the World Bank. The bank could lend only to public agencies, and better than ministries were semiindependent state-owned companies that would mobilize skills and capital to the achievement of important national objectives. Moreover, the bank wanted to encourage scale and efficiency, just as the creation of the TVA had done. And with the passage of time, it became increasingly open to working with state-owned companies in areas other than infrastructure—for instance, industry and finance. The World Bank did create an affiliate, the International Finance Corporation in 1956, to make loans to private-sector companies, but it played a small role for many years.7

国有企业的崛起

The Rise of the State-owned Company

事实上，发展经济学最显著的体现便是国有企业。这类企业将成为攫取制高点的特定载体。由于私营企业显然无法筹集到发展所需的资金，政府便会通过国有企业调动和引导资源。它们将成为现代化的引擎、经济增长的驱动力、发展的推动者，以及实现更美好未来的机制。它们追求的是公共利益——国家利益——而非特定商人、实业家以及各种超级富豪家族的特殊利益。它们的人员配备将以精英选拔为主，而非任人唯亲或世袭。它们将弥补市场失灵，实现规模经济。通过这些以及其他方式，它们将展现主权、尊严，并在那些正努力构建民族国家的国家中孕育出民族认同。总之，国有企业逐渐被视为发展和民族建构的必要组成部分。

Indeed, the most visible embodiment of development economics was the state-owned company. Such corporations would be the specific vehicle for capturing the commanding heights. Since private enterprise assuredly could not raise the capital necessary for development, the government would mobilize and direct resources through the state-owned companies. They would serve as the engines of modernization, the drivers of economic growth, the mobilizers of development, the mechanisms for achieving a better future. They would pursue the public good—the nation’s interest—rather than the special interests of particular merchants and industrialists and various clusters of super-rich families. They would be staffed by meritocracy, not by patronage or lineage. They would compensate for market failure and achieve economies of scale. And in these ways and more, they would express sovereignty, dignity, and the birth of national identity in countries that were trying to create themselves as nations. In sum, the state company came to be seen as essential both to development and to nationhood.

发展经济学家对公有企业的效率持乐观态度。正如扬·廷伯根所言，“所有权类型”其实并不重要。真正影响效率的是“管理质量”，而这与所有权形式无关。因此，“如果选择公有企业作为促进国家发展的手段，效率考量就不必成为绊脚石。”相反，公有制将简化部长、规划者和公司经理之间的协调流程——这一切都是为了更大的利益。

The development economists were sanguine about the efficiency of the public enterprises. The “type of ownership,” as Jan Tinbergen put it, did not really matter. What did matter for efficiency was “the quality of its management,” and that was quite irrespective of ownership. Thus, “efficiency considerations need not be a stumbling block if public enterprise is chosen as a means for furthering a country’s development.” Rather, public ownership would streamline the process of coordination among ministers, planners, and company managers—all for the greater good.

事实上，发展中国家若想成功实现梦寐以求的产业转型，就必须进行周密的协调。新兴产业一开始就处于劣势，难以与成熟的低成本进口产品抗衡。因此，各国政府通过设置贸易壁垒来保护其“幼稚产业”。只有这样，他们才能推动“进口替代”进程——逐步用国内生产取代进口商品，首先从纺织品和轻工业制品入手，最终目标是重型机械和其他工业产品。一旦这一进程稳步推进，贸易壁垒就可以取消，国家也能重新融入国际贸易。大多数发展中国家都或多或少地遵循了这条道路。但只有少数国家——尤其是在亚洲——能够成功地在恰当的时机让其“幼稚产业”脱离贸易壁垒。在太多国家，保护主义和公有制变得司空见惯；而这些制度非但没有促进私营部门的出现，反而最终限制并排挤了私营部门。“准国有企业”（有时也被称为国有公司）的数量迅速增长，其业务范围不仅涵盖基础设施，还包括工业、金融和服务业。在阿根廷，马戏团甚至归政府所有。

Indeed, careful coordination would be required if the developing countries-were to successfully negotiate the much-desired industrial transition. New industries started off at a disadvantage against established low-cost imports. So governments protected their “infant industries” with trade barriers. Only in this way could they force the process of “import substitution”—gradually replacing imported goods with home production, starting off with textiles and light manufactures and ultimately aiming for heavy machinery and other industrial products. Once the process was securely under way, the trade barriers could come down and the country would reconnect to international commerce. Most developing countries followed this path to some degree. But only a few—particularly in Asia—would prove successful at weaning their “infants” at the right time. In all too many countries, protection and public ownership became commonplace; and rather than facilitating the emergence of the private sector, they would eventually come to constrain and crowd it out. The number of “parastatals,” as state companies were sometimes called, grew rapidly, encompassing not only infrastructure but industry, finance, and services. In Argentina, the government even owned the circus.

公共企业的形式多种多样。有些是政府机构，是现有部委或政府部门的分支机构，负责执行特定任务或提供特定服务。它们既没有自有营运资金，也没有任何自主权，直接受部委控制。（英国工党曾将这种模式斥为“邮政模式”。）另一些则是公共公司——作为独立的法人实体，拥有自有资本，但受一个或多个部委的监管。此外，还有混合型企业——政府持有多数股权，但董事会在一定程度上隔离了管理层和政府。这些国有企业中，有些拥有完全垄断地位；有些则是国家龙头企业，凭借其优势地位参与竞争。与国内外竞争对手的较量中，这些公司往往承担着福利角色——为员工及其家属提供公司城镇、住房、奖学金和医疗诊所。它们致力于培养本土“人力资本”（这个概念在20世纪50年代被重新启用），而这或许最终会成为它们最重要的职责。但它们也可能成为裙带关系和任人唯亲的温床。有时，它们明显隶属于政府部门；而在另一些情况下，它们则成为权力强大的“国中之国”。8

Public enterprises took a variety of forms. Some were government agencies, branches of existing ministries or government authorities, that carried out a specific task or service. They had neither working capital of their own nor any autonomy. They were directly controlled by the ministry. (This was what the British Labourites had dismissed as the Post Office Model.) Others were public corporations—separate legal entities that existed as companies, with their own capital but overseen by one or more ministries. There were also mixed firms—the government held majority ownership, but a board of directors provided some insulation between management and government. Some of these state enterprises had complete monopolies; others were the national champions, which competed from a favored position with domestic and foreign rivals. Often these companies took on welfare roles—providing workers and their families with company towns, housing, scholarships, and health clinics. They would ensure the development of homegrown “human capital”—a term rediscovered in the 1950s—and perhaps that would turn out to be their most important role of all. But they could also become sources of favoritism and nepotism. Sometimes they were clearly subordinated to the government ministries; in other cases, they became powerful “states within states.”8

《变革之风》

“The Wind of Change”

发展需要客户，而客户很快就会蜂拥而至。印度的独立激发了民族主义运动，并为世界各地的非殖民化提供了范例，掀起了一股独立浪潮。旧殖民秩序似乎在各个方面都失去了效力，失去了历史意义。两次世界大战彻底否定了欧洲列强“文明使命”的说法。在国内，殖民统治的支持者越来越多，越来越多的人认为，经济利益已不足以弥补日益沉重的帝国管理负担。与此同时，殖民地各地涌现出一个新的精英阶层，他们是少数幸运儿，接受了西方教育，并带着工程师、律师或会计师等专业资格证书回国。这个新兴的专业阶层也吸收了西方的政治价值观，能够以自身的方式挑战殖民统治。他们组建了政党——在很多情况下，都受到了尼赫鲁和甘地领导的国大党的启发——并争取更大程度的自治。他们也成为了和平移交权力的有力人选。在英国和法国——迄今为止最大的两个殖民强国——20世纪50年代，非殖民化不可避免的观点逐渐盛行。英国首相哈罗德·麦克米伦称之为“变革之风”。当然，凡事皆有例外。法国试图以武力保住其两个殖民地越南和阿尔及利亚，但最终徒劳无功，并造成了惨重的人员伤亡。葡萄牙则一直坚守安哥拉和莫桑比克，直到1975年自身从独裁政权过渡到民主政权。

Development needed customers, and soon there would be many. India’s independence inspired nationalist movements and provided a model for decolonization all over the world, launching a tide of independence. In every way, the old colonial order seemed to have lost its force, its historical relevance. Two world wars had thoroughly discredited the European powers’ claim to a “civilizing mission.” Back at home, colonial rule was losing its advocates, more and more of whom felt that the economic benefits no longer outweighed the growing burden of administering empires. And a new elite was on the rise throughout the colonies, made up of the lucky few who had acceded to Western education and returned with technical credentials as engineers, lawyers, or accountants. This new professional class had also absorbed Western political values, and could ably challenge colonial rule on its own terms. They formed political parties—inspired, in many cases, by the Congress Party of Nehru and Gandhi—and pressed for greater degrees of self-rule. They also became plausible candidates for a peaceful handover of power. In Britain and France—by far the two largest colonial powers—the view grew steadily in the 1950s that decolonization was inevitable. British prime minister Harold Macmillan called it “the wind of change.” There would, of course, be exceptions. France would attempt to hold on to two of its colonies, Vietnam and Algeria, by force—an ultimately futile effort that would carry a dire human cost. Portugal would cling to Angola and Mozambique until its own transition from dictatorship to democracy in 1975.

这一变化在非洲最为显著。法国在1960年一年之内就给予几乎所有非洲殖民地独立；英国则从1957年到1965年逐步推进。几乎在所有地方，独立进程都始于一个临时的自治政府，殖民宗主国保留了对货币、国防和外交事务的最终控制权和责任。随着势头增强，地方团体的职责范围不断扩大。到政府大楼举行激动人心的降旗仪式，以及民选的地方领导人正式接管政权之时，和平的权力交接已经完成。与此同时，经济联系通常也保持完好。

The change was most striking in Africa. France granted independence to almost all its African colonies in a single year, 1960; Britain, more gradually, from 1957 to 1965. Almost everywhere, the process began with an interim self-rule government, the colonial power retaining ultimate control and responsibility for currency, defense, and foreign affairs. As momentum gathered, local groups expanded their scope of responsibility By the time of the emotional flag-lowering ceremony at government house and the assumption of formal power by the elected local leaders, a peaceful transition had taken place. In the background, economic links usually remained intact.

新领导人面临着严峻的挑战。殖民时期的基础设施匮乏，仅有的几条也是为了快速开采自然资源而设计的，而非为了促进当地贸易和公民生活。铁路连接矿区和港口；公路铺设完毕后，则服务于种植园。沿线村庄发展成为贸易站，而旧商道上的历史中心则沦为偏僻落后的地区。城镇的公共服务极其有限。在独立前夕，非洲国家的典型电力网络由不稳定的柴油涡轮机组成，为殖民政府的别墅和办公室供电。工厂和富裕的商人则自行安装了发电机。供水和电话同样不足。初等教育和公共卫生设施也十分简陋。独立后，城镇和乡村居民都对所有这些领域的快速发展寄予厚望。而新领导人，在快速变革和合格技术人员短缺的双重压力下，肩负起了守护这些美好愿景的重任。

The new leaders faced formidable challenges. Colonial infrastructure was scant, and what little existed was designed for swift extraction of natural resources, not for bolstering local trade and civic life. Where railways existed, they connected mines to ports; where roads were paved, they served plantations. Villages along these routes grew into trading posts, while historic centers on old commercial routes became backwaters. In the towns, public services were minimal. The typical electricity network in an African country on the eve of independence consisted of erratic diesel turbines that supplied the villas and offices of the colonial administration. Factories and wealthy traders installed their own generators. Water supply and telephones were similarly inadequate. Primary education and public health were rudimentary. With independence, town and country dwellers alike raised their hopes for rapid growth in all of these areas at the same time. And the new leaders, strained by the quick pace of change and the small numbers of qualified technical staff, became the custodians of these aspirations.

“首先是政治王国”

“First the Political Kingdom”

在非洲的转型时期，加纳是非洲的灯塔国家，于1957年率先获得独立；而最具影响力的人物是其总理、后来的总统克瓦米·恩克鲁玛。恩克鲁玛出生于1910年，当时的加纳仍是黄金海岸，一个以种植园和世界最大可可生产国而闻名的英国殖民地。其疆界是殖民列强——英国、法国和德国——之间谈判的结果，与殖民前王国的历史疆界，特别是曾经强大的阿散蒂帝国的疆界并不相符。恩克鲁玛出身于一个普通的传统家庭，早年接受天主教传教士的教育。他后来成为一名教师，并在沿海城镇的小学任教数年。他颇受欢迎，魅力非凡，生活优渥。但接触政治和一些有影响力的人物激发了他更大的兴趣——前往美国。他申请了美国的大学，并靠亲戚们筹集的钱，于1935年乘轮船启程。他几乎身无分文地抵达纽约，在哈莱姆区投奔了其他西非同胞。之后，他前往宾夕法尼亚州的林肯大学就读并入学；一份小额奖学金和一份校园兼职帮助他维持生计。

In the period of transition, the beacon country from Africa was Ghana, first to achieve independence, in 1957; and the most influential figure was its prime minister, later president, Kwame Nkrumah. When Nkrumah was born in 1910, Ghana was still the Gold Coast, a British colony known for its plantations and for being the world’s largest producer of cocoa. Its frontiers were the result of bargains among the colonial powers—Britain, France, and Germany—that did not correspond to the historical boundaries of the kingdoms that preceded colonization, particularly the once-mighty Ashanti Empire. Nkrumah, who came from a modest, traditional family, received his early education at the hands of Catholic missionaries. He went on to train as a teacher and for a few years taught elementary school in towns along the coast. He was popular and charismatic, and earned a decent living. But exposure to politics and to a few influential figures sparked in him a greater interest—to go to America. He applied to universities in the United States, and with money raised from relatives, he set out on a steamer in 1935. He reached New York almost penniless, and took refuge with fellow West Africans in Harlem. He then presented himself at Lincoln University in Pennsylvania and enrolled; a small scholarship and a campus job helped him make ends meet.

在美国，恩克鲁玛看到了英国传统政府模式之外的其他选择。他也对种族关系的政治意义产生了深刻的认识。与许多试图效仿欧洲导师的非洲新领袖不同，恩克鲁玛深入美国黑人社区。林肯大学成立于南北战争之前，是美国历史最悠久的黑人大学，其独特的氛围激励并慰藉了恩克鲁玛。夏天，他会在学校从事一些体力劳动——在他曾在造船厂、建筑工地和海上工作。他研习神学和哲学；他经常出入纽约和费城的黑人教堂，有时还会应邀布道。他还与美国黑人知识分子建立了联系，在当时政治变革的时代，非洲正成为他们极为关注的领域。二战后，恩克鲁玛移居伦敦，协助组织泛非大会，将非洲殖民地新兴的知识分子群体与来自工业化国家的活动家、作家、艺术家和支持者联系起来。那是一个思想活跃、充满活力和乐观精神的时代。1947年印度获得独立，激发了其他殖民地人民对自由的渴望。“如果我们获得自治，”恩克鲁玛宣称，“我们将在十年内把黄金海岸变成人间天堂。”

In the United States, Nkrumah saw alternatives to the British tradition of government. He also became suffused with an acute consciousness of the politics of race relations. Unlike many new African leaders, who sought to emulate their European instructors, Nkrumah plunged into America’s black communities. Founded before the Civil War, Lincoln University was America’s oldest black college, and its special atmosphere inspired and comforted Nkrumah. In the summers, he worked at physically demanding jobs—in shipyards and construction and at sea. He studied theology as well as philosophy; he frequented the black churches in New York and Philadelphia and was sometimes asked to preach. He also forged ties with black American intellectuals, for whom Africa was becoming, in this time of political change, an area of extreme interest. Moving to London after World War II, Nkrumah helped organize Pan-African congresses, linking the emergent educated groups of the African colonies with activists, writers, artists, and well-wishers from the industrial countries. It was a time of great intellectual ferment, excitement, and optimism. India’s achievement of independence in 1947 stirred dreams of freedom for the other colonies. “If we get selfgovernment,” Nkrumah proclaimed, “we’ll transform the Gold Coast into a paradise in ten years.”

1949年回到黄金海岸后，恩克鲁玛发现印度的独立已经启动了英国其他殖民地逐步移交权力的进程。移交的条件和时间安排极不稳定，而且确实会引发冲突和暴力事件，但自治的基本原则正在逐渐成为共识。恩克鲁玛对现有的民族主义团体感到不满，认为它僵化保守，与殖民地的商业利益联系过于紧密。他与几位同伴组建了新政党——人民大会党（CPP），并在这一过程中展现了他卓越的组织能力。两年内，人民大会党赢得了有限的自治选举，恩克鲁玛成为“政府事务领袖”——实际上的总理，负责国内事务和政策。他坚定地将目光投向独立。他认为，任何程度的自治或自决都无法与一个真正独立的国家中政府和人民的活力、决心和专注力相媲美。这是发展的先决条件。他将自己的理念概括为一句在非洲广为流传且影响深远的口号：“先求政治王国，其他一切都会随之而来。”

Returning to the Gold Coast in 1949, Nkrumah found that India’s independence had set in motion a process of gradual transfer of power in Britain’s other colonies. The terms and timing were highly unsettled, and indeed would provoke conflict and violent clashes, but the basic principle of self-government was becoming the consensus. Nkrumah was dissatisfied with the existing nationalist grouping, finding it staid and conservative, overly tied to colonial business interests. With several associates he set up a new party, the Convention People’s Party (CPP), in the process demonstrating his supreme organizational abilities. Within two years the CPP had won limited self-rule elections, and Nkrumah became “Leader of Government Business”—a de facto prime minister, responsible for internal government and policy. He set his sights firmly on independence. No amount of autonomy or self-rule, he argued, could match the energy, commitment, and focus of a government and people in a truly independent country. It was a precondition for growth. He summarized his philosophy in a slogan that became famous and influential across Africa: “Seek ye first the political kingdom, and all else shall be added unto you.”

为了实现这一目标，恩克鲁玛开始与英国当局密切合作，并与国内反对派达成妥协。过渡进程加速——和平地进行——1957年3月6日，新国旗升起。国家更名为加纳。这是一个刻意的历史性误称。古老的加纳帝国是中世纪时期一个辉煌的非洲国家。但它并不位于黄金海岸——而是位于内陆，也就是今天的马里境内。然而，对非洲昔日辉煌的追求至关重要；恩克鲁玛和他的同伴们选择了他们认为最能体现这一理念的名称，而且没有人提出异议。

To reach this goal, Nkrumah began to work closely with the British administration and reached a compromise with the domestic opposition. The process of transition accelerated—peacefully—and on March 6, 1957, the new flag was hoisted. The country took the name Ghana. It was a deliberate historical misnomer. The old Empire of Ghana had been a glorious African state of the medieval era. But it was not situated in the Gold Coast—instead, it was well inland, in present-day Mali. But the idea of past African glory was paramount; Nkrumah and his associates chose the name that they felt best conveyed it, and nobody complained.

加纳的独立之路成为非洲其他国家的典范。到20世纪60年代中期，已有30多个非洲国家获得独立，其中许多国家拥有魅力非凡的领导人，例如肯尼亚的乔莫·肯雅塔、坦桑尼亚的朱利叶斯·尼雷尔和赞比亚的肯尼斯·卡翁达。他们的经济观点与当时的时代背景高度一致，也符合发展经济学家的共识。同样，只有国家才能调动资金并协调经济转型活动，才能最终实现经济转型。在这些领导人有生之年，更不用说在任期间，他们对市场的悲观情绪就已经存在了。事实上，非洲对市场的悲观情绪甚至比其他地方更为强烈。毕竟，殖民非洲时，当地的教育、医疗和基础设施几乎无人问津，充斥着种族主义和蔑视。结果，人们似乎没有能力参与市场。相反，新领导人开始酝酿“非洲社会主义”的计划，试图将现代发展与传统价值观结合起来。“资本主义对于一个新独立的国家来说过于复杂，”恩克鲁玛辩称，“因此，我们需要一个社会主义社会。” 很少有人反对他的观点。毕竟，这在当时是普遍接受的观念。9

Ghana’s route to independence became the model for the rest of the continent. By the mid-1960s, over thirty African countries were independent and many had charismatic leaders, including Jomo Kenyatta in Kenya, Julius Nyerere in Tanzania, and Kenneth Kaunda in Zambia. Their economic views were very much those of the time, in line with the consensus among development economists. Here again, only the state could mobilize the funds and coordinate the activities of economic transformation if it was to be achieved in the leaders’ lifetime—let alone during their time in office. Indeed, pessimism about markets was even greater in Africa than elsewhere. After all, the colonization of Africa had come with little regard for local education, health, or infrastructure. It was tainted with racism and contempt. As a result, people were not equipped to participate in markets, or so it seemed. Instead, the new leaders hatched schemes for “African socialism” that could somehow combine modern growth and traditional values. “Capitalism is too complicated a system for a newly independent nation,” Nkrumah argued. “Hence the need for a socialistic society.” Few disagreed. It was, after all, the received wisdom of the time.9

营销委员会：控制的工具

Marketing Boards: The Tools of Control

具有讽刺意味的是，非洲新领导人寄予厚望的经济机制本身却是殖民时代的产物——市场委员会，一个负责从农民手中收购农作物并转售出口的公共机构。市场委员会这个名字看似无害，甚至有些乏味，但实际上却是新政府强有力的控制工具。它们的诞生源于无奈，当时大萧条导致世界大宗商品价格暴跌，而战时繁荣又推高了价格。非洲农民生活拮据，极易受到世界市场剧烈波动的影响。他们可能在价格高企时过度种植，而在价格下跌时放弃耕种。与此同时，政府不仅会损失税收，还会失去提前规划的能力。市场委员会的设立正是为了纠正这种情况。它们以稳定的价格收购农作物。在世界价格高企时，它们会积累资金盈余；在世界价格低迷时，它们会利用这些资金盈余来支撑本地价格。这可以保护农民免受他们无法控制的市场动荡的影响。由于市场营销委员会故意向农民支付低于世界市场价格的价格，它们无法在竞争性市场中运作。因此，它们被授予垄断权。几乎所有出口农作物都必须经过市场营销委员会。这几乎是所有非洲国家独立之初普遍采用的制度。各国之间的唯一区别在于涉及的农作物种类和数量。

Ironically, the economic device in which Africa’s new leaders invested their trust was itself a colonial invention—the marketing board, a public agency responsible for buying crops from farmers and reselling them for export. Seemingly innocuous and indeed almost boring in name, marketing boards were in fact powerful tools of control for the new governments. They were born of necessity, when the Great Depression drove down world commodity prices and the wartime boom drove them up again. African farmers lived on a shoestring and were highly vulnerable to such volatile swings in world markets. They might overplant in times of high prices and abandon crops when prices fell. Meanwhile, the state would lose both tax revenue and its ability to plan ahead. The marketing boards were set up to correct this situation. They would purchase crops at stable prices. In times of high world prices, they would accumulate a surplus of money; in times of low world prices, they would use that financial surplus to support the local price. This would protect farmers from the tumult of markets, over which they had no control. Because the marketing boards deliberately paid farmers prices other than the world-market prices, they could not function in a competitive market. Hence, they were granted monopolies. Virtually all crops for export had to go through the marketing board. This was the prevailing system at independence in almost every African country. All that varied from country to country was the exact number and range of crops concerned.

对恩克鲁玛及其同僚而言，保留殖民地市场委员会似乎是权宜之计，甚至是明智之举。这些委员会既能提供获取农业“剩余产品”的机制，又能增加财政收入。通过这种方式征收的资源可以与投资和外援相结合，从而启动工业发展，推动经济从以农村为主向工业化转型。当然，也存在一些问题。当市场委员会设定的价格低于世界价格时，如何阻止农作物流入黑市或越境流入邻国？国界是人为划定的，漏洞百出，而且，毕竟，非洲长途贸易历史悠久。此外，如果市场营销委员会确实积累了现金盈余，谁来监督其稳健的管理和投资？

For Nkrumah and his peers, retaining the colonial marketing boards seemed the expedient, indeed the sensible, thing to do. The boards would provide the mechanism both to capture the “surplus” generated by agriculture and to raise revenues. The resources levied this way could be combined with investment and foreign aid to jump-start industrial development and the “great transformation” away from rural-based economies toward industrialization. There were some problems, to be sure. When the marketing board imposed prices lower than world prices, how would it stop crops from slipping away into a black market or crossing borders into neighboring countries? Frontiers were artificial and porous, and there was, after all, a considerable history of long-distance African trade. Moreover, if the marketing board did accumulate a cash surplus, who would oversee its sound management and investment?

但在人们对独立的热情和对市场失灵的过度担忧之下，这些问题似乎无关紧要。各国政府反而将精力投入到扩大现有市场营销委员会的规模，并为此前不受监管的商品设立新的委员会。他们通过这些委员会来管理经济。在加纳，可可市场营销委员会的规模、人员和权力都迅速增长。不久之后，木材和钻石市场营销委员会也相继成立，还有许多其他国家机构，其目标不仅在于出口，还在于监管食品、鱼类和日用品的本地贸易。国家对投资和商业几乎各个方面无处不在、自信满满——或者如某些人所说，是过度干预——的这种做法，使加纳成为“发展经济学实践”的典型案例。

But amid the enthusiasm for independence and the overriding concern with market failure, these questions seemed of little import. Governments instead threw their energy into enlarging the existing marketing boards and creating new ones for commodities that were hitherto unregulated. They ran their economies through the boards. In Ghana, the Cocoa Marketing Board grew in size, staffing, and power. It was joined in short order by marketing boards for timber and diamonds, and a host of other state organizations aimed not only at exports but also at regulating local trade in foodstuffs, fish, and household goods. This pervasive, confident—or, as some would say, intrusive—involvement of the state in almost every aspect of investment and commerce made Ghana a case of “development economics in action.”

沃尔特大坝：非洲社会主义的高潮

The Volta Dam: The High Tide of African Socialism

同样的信心也延伸到了进程的另一半——工业化。恩克鲁玛坚信“大推进”势在必行，而且可以迅速实现。他将希望寄托于一项宏伟的计划，即沃尔特河工程，这是一项规模庞大的多用途工程。加纳拥有丰富的铝土矿储量，因此有潜力成为主要的铝出口国。但这需要建造一座冶炼厂、一座大型水坝和一座发电厂来为其供能。反过来，这将支撑起国家电网；而廉价且充足的电力将推动全国工业化进程。这是一个宏伟的愿景，与发展理论完美契合。大坝将启动经济学家所追求的“前后向关联效应”，并赋予加纳经济独立。它还将形成世界上最大的人工湖，迫使数万人迁徙。

The same confidence extended as well to the other half of the process—industrialization. Nkrumah very much believed that the “big push” was necessary and could be rapidly achieved. He harnessed his hopes to a dramatic plan for a huge multipurpose undertaking known as the Volta River Project. Ghana had large reserves of bauxite and hence the potential to become a major exporter of aluminum. But this required building a smelter and a very large dam and power plant to feed it. That, in turn, would support a national electricity grid; and the cheap, abundant power would jump-start industrialization all over the country. It was a grand vision that accorded perfectly with development theory. The dam would set in motion the “forward and backward linkages” that the economists sought, and it would give Ghana economic independence. It would also create the world’s biggest man-made lake, forcing the resettlement of tens of thousands of people.

总而言之，沃尔特河项目是当时最雄心勃勃、最复杂的开发项目，也无疑是最引人注目的项目之一。该项目还引发了加纳政府与其潜在合作伙伴——世界银行、英国和美国政府，以及同意建造冶炼厂的凯撒铝业和雷诺兹铝业公司——之间漫长而艰辛的谈判。经过数年令人沮丧的磋商，最终形成了一份合同文件，一位参与者将其形容为“自玛丽王后发行罗马尼亚债券以来世界上最复杂的合同”。

When it was all added up, the Volta River Project was the most ambitious and complicated development project of its day, and certainly one of the most prominent. It also gave rise to lengthy and arduous negotiations between the government of Ghana and its would-be partners—the World Bank, the governments of Britain and the United States, and the aluminum firms Kaiser and Reynolds, which agreed to build the smelter. Several years of frustrating discussion culminated in a series of contract documents that one participant described as the world’s “most complex since Queen Marie was selling Roumanian bonds.”

但交易尚未完成。随着谈判的拖延，风险也越来越大。恩克鲁玛的观点日趋强硬，反映出他对“科学社会主义”的日益青睐以及对控制的日益执着。早在1960年，他就已使加纳成为共和国，并宣布……他亲自担任总统。1961年4月，他发表了著名的“黎明广播”，猛烈抨击“自私自利”和“投机取巧”，并以此迫使潜在的竞争对手辞职。不久之后，政客们遭到逮捕。他还驱逐了负责训练其军队的英国军官。

But the deal was not yet done. As the negotiations dragged on, the stakes grew higher. Nkrumah’s views were hardening, reflecting an increasing attraction to “scientific socialism” and a mounting preoccupation with control. Already in 1960, he had made Ghana a republic and proclaimed himself its president. In April 1961, he delivered a “Dawn Broadcast” in which he lashed out at “self-seeking” and “careerism,” and which he used to force the resignation of potential rivals. Soon there were political arrests. He also threw out the British officers assigned to train his army.

这一切都发生在伊丽莎白二世女王原定于1961年11月对加纳进行国事访问，以庆祝新一轮非殖民化进程之前不久。然而，在首都阿克拉发生数起爆炸事件后，英国下议院内部强烈呼吁取消此次访问，因为安全形势严峻。首相哈罗德·麦克米伦担心，取消访问会促使恩克鲁玛退出英联邦，转而投靠莫斯科。为了防止这种情况发生，他请求美国总统约翰·肯尼迪确认美国将资助沃尔特河工程。在女王启程前夕，当下议院可能投票取消访问的迹象显现时，麦克米伦明确表示，他将在当晚辞职——即使这意味着要叫醒女王也在所不惜。最终，取消访问的投票并未发生，女王如期启程。

All this occurred shortly before Queen Elizabeth II was scheduled to make a state visit to Ghana in November 1961 to celebrate the new area of decolonization. But then, after several bombs went off in the capital of Accra, sentiment mounted in Britain’s House of Commons that the trip should be canceled, because it was too unsafe. Prime Minister Harold Macmillan feared, however, that cancellation would provoke Nkrumah into leaving the Commonwealth and moving into Moscow’s arms. To prevent such a turn, he appealed to President John Kennedy to confirm that the United States would help underwrite the Volta River Project. When, on the eve of the queen’s departure, it became apparent that the House of Commons might vote to cancel the trip, Macmillan made clear that he would resign that very evening—even if it meant having to awaken the queen. The vote against the trip did not eventuate, and the queen took off.

事实证明，这次访问非常成功。加纳当地媒体称赞女王是“世界上最伟大的社会主义君主”。访问结束后，女王安全返回英国，麦克米伦立即致电肯尼迪。“我让我的女王冒了险，”麦克米伦说，“你也必须冒着损失金钱的风险！”肯尼迪慷慨地回答说，他将以自己的行动来回报女王的“勇敢贡献”。美国最终签署了沃尔特河工程协议。

As it turned out, the trip was a great success. The local press in Ghana hailed the queen as “the greatest socialist monarch in the world.” With the conclusion of the visit and the queen safely back in Britain, Macmillan immediately telephoned Kennedy. “I have risked my Queen,” Macmillan said. “You must risk your money!” Gallantly, Kennedy replied he would match the queen’s “brave contribution” with his own. The United States signed on to the Volta River Project.

同年，恩克鲁玛访问苏联，并对苏联的工业化速度印象深刻。他带着一项严格的七年计划回国。“我们必须以最快的速度大量建立工厂，”他力主道。国有企业和公共机构如雨后春笋般涌现，遍布各个领域。与此同时，管理不善和贪污腐败也愈演愈烈。农村地区首当其冲地感受到了这种弊端，因为恩克鲁玛利用官方营销委员会控制的可可收入来弥补国有企业日益增长的亏损。强加给农民的可可价格低得不切实际，再加上臃肿的营销委员会，彻底摧毁了整个产业。许多农民彻底改种其他作物；还有一些人想方设法将可可走私到邻国，因为那里的价格更高。加纳失去了世界最大可可生产国的地位。其外汇储备枯竭，不得不依靠物物交换和来自苏联集团的贷款。

In the same year, Nkrumah visited the Soviet Union and returned much impressed at the pace of industrialization there. He came back with a rigid seven-year plan. “We must try and establish factories in large numbers at great speed,” he argued. State-owned companies and public authorities mushroomed in all fields. So did mismanagement and graft. The price was most painfully felt in the countryside as Nkrumah used cocoa revenues, controlled by the official marketing board, to cover the growing losses of public companies. The imposition of unrealistically low cocoa prices on farmers, combined with the bloated organization of the marketing board, devastated the industry. Many farmers switched crops altogether; others found ways to smuggle their cocoa through neighboring countries, where better prices were offered. Ghana lost its mantle as the world’s largest cocoa producer. Its currency reserves depleted, it fell back on barter trade and loans from the Soviet Bloc.

恩克鲁玛日益疏远民众，他更热衷于非洲统一的宏伟蓝图，而非治理国家。1964年，他将国家变成一党制国家，并沉迷于丑陋的个人崇拜，自封为“救世主”奥萨吉福。民众的怨恨很快蔓延开来。他多次躲过暗杀。1966年1月22日，他为沃尔特大坝举行落成典礼，自豪地按下按钮，将电力输送到新的国家电网——他当时并不知道，即使是这样，也会带来灾难性的后果。这个项目最终只取得了一半的成功。加纳的铝土矿永远不会被开发；冶炼厂发现加工从牙买加进口的铝土矿更经济。就职典礼将是他最后的辉煌时刻。2月24日，在他前往中国开启旨在解决越南冲突的大规模访问之旅途中，途经缅甸时，军官们在国内发动政变并夺取了政权。“围绕夸梅·恩克鲁玛的神话已被打破，”一位陆军上校在电台宣布。恩克鲁玛直到抵达中国才得知政变的消息。周恩来总理不确定该遵循怎样的礼仪，仍然为他举办了一场令人不安的国宴。恩克鲁玛最终流亡到几内亚，那里正在进行另一场“非洲社会主义”的实验。几内亚总统塞古·杜尔的统治日益专制，他授予恩克鲁玛“联合总统”的头衔。恩克鲁玛定期向加纳进行短波广播，发表意识形态论文，并策划重返权力巅峰，直到1972年因病去世，当时他仍流亡在外。“政治王国”的崩塌速度与它建立的速度一样快。“救世主”——这位曾经激励整个非洲大陆的人物——如今已远失宠。10

Nkrumah became increasingly remote, preferring to focus on grand schemes of African unity than on running the country. He turned the country into a one-party state in 1964, and took to indulging in a sordid cult of personality, dubbing himself Osagyefo, “the Redeemer.” It did not take long for resentment to set in. He evaded several assassination attempts. On January 22, 1966, he inaugurated the Volta Dam, proudly pressing the button that released power into the new national grid—unaware that even this project would be only half a success. Ghana’s bauxite mines would never be developed; the smelter found it more economic to process bauxite imported from Jamaica, The inauguration would be his last moment of glory. On February 24, as he stopped in Burma on his way to China at the start of a grand tour aimed at solving the Vietnam conflict, army officers intervened at home and took power. “The myth surrounding Kwame Nkrumah has been broken,” announced an army colonel on the radio. Nkrumah did not learn of the coup until he arrived in China. Premier Zhou Enlai, unsure of the protocol to follow, went ahead and hosted an eerie state banquet in his honor. Nkrumah ended up taking up exile in Guinea, where another experiment in “African socialism” was in progress. Guinea’s president, Sekou Toure, his own rule increasingly repressive and arbitrary, endowed Nkrumah with the title of “co-president.” Nkrumah made regular shortwave broadcasts to Ghana, published ideological treatises, and plotted a triumphal return to power until he grew ill and died in 1972, still in exile. The “political kingdom” had crumbled as fast as it had been built. “The Redeemer,” who had once inspired a continent, had fallen far from grace.10

“第三世界主义”

“Third Worldism”

加纳并非个例。在20世纪60年代，发展中国家对独立的殷切期盼逐渐消退，取而代之的是持续不断的政变和政治动荡。在此过程中，独立时代的乐观情绪被一种新的观念所取代，这种观念将南北——工业化国家和发展中国家——视为永恒的对立面。争取独立的政治斗争演变为一场持续不断的斗争，这场斗争反对被冠以各种名称的“经济帝国主义”和“新帝国主义”，尤其是反对跨国公司。事实上，“剥削”成为看待发达国家和发展中国家之间关系的流行语。卡尔·马克思对发展中国家着墨不多，而且他所言也相当含糊。他认为资本主义是对“亚细亚生产方式”的必要改进。在马克思看来，英国的帝国主义确实促进了像印度这样的“落后”国家的现代化。然而，大多数马克思主义理论家、依附理论家以及许多普通的自由主义理论家都认为，发达国家以及国际贸易和投资的动态机制剥削了发展中国家。强有力的国家控制对于保护发展中国家免受这些力量的侵害至关重要，而国有企业将占据此前由外国势力占据的制高点。

Ghana was hardly an exception. In the decade of the 1960s, the high hopes of independence gave way through much of the developing world to a continuing saga of coups and political upheavals. In the process, the optimism of the independence era gave way to an intellectual reformulation that saw North and South—industrial and developing countries—as permanent antagonists. The political struggle for independence was transmuted into a continuing struggle against what was variously described as “economic imperialism” and “neo-imperalism”—and, particularly, against the multinational corporation. Indeed, “exploitation” became the fashionable way to view relations between developed and developing nations. Karl Marx had not said much about the developing world, and what he had said was quite ambiguous. He saw capitalism as a necessary improvement on the “Asiatic mode of production.” According to Marx, British imperialism definitely served to modernize “backward” lands like India. Nevertheless, most Marxist theorists, dependency theorists, and many plain liberal theorists propounded the argument that developed nations and the dynamics of international trade and investment exploited developing countries. Strong state control was necessary to protect the developing nation against these forces, and the state company would occupy the high ground formerly held by the foreigner.

对于众多依赖初级产品出口生存的国家而言，国家控制问题尤为尖锐，这些初级产品既包括咖啡、橡胶或菠萝等农产品，也包括铜和铝土矿等矿产产品。摆在它们面前的选择似乎是：外国跨国公司是否会介入？跨国公司能否攫取这些产品的全部“利润”，或者一家本土企业能否介入？如果跨国公司发现出口原材料比投资加工厂更划算，那么生产国还有什么希望将种植园转型为现代化农业产业？如果跨国公司带来的不是增长而是扭曲，那么眼睁睁看着外籍经理们开着新车、享受“艰苦津贴”的屈辱感还能继续存在吗？一家国有企业，一家民族的领军企业，难道不更能代表国家的愿望吗？

The problem of national control was most acute for the great many countries that depended for survival on exports of primary products, whether agricultural—like coffee, rubber, or pineapples—or mineral—like copper and bauxite. The choice seemed to be whether foreign multinationals would capture all the “rents” from these products or whether a national firm could step in. If multinationals found it cheaper to export raw materials than to invest in a processing plant, what hope was there that the producer countries would ever turn their plantations to modern agro-industry? And if multinationals brought economic distortion, not growth, then could the humiliating effects of watching expatriate managers drive new cars and enjoy “hardship pay” be justified any longer? Surely a state-owned company, a national champion, could better represent the national aspirations.

混合经济和国家主导在发展中国家的真正意义，是在20世纪60年代末和70年代达到顶峰的。当时，越南战争引发了自由主义者对整个第三世界的愧疚感。随着舆论转向反对战争和美国，反对与美国相关的经济体系的情绪也随之高涨。市场和资本主义似乎失去了合法性，战争的部分原因也被归咎于它们。民族解放运动的目标不仅是推翻亲西方政府，还要以“人民”的名义推翻市场，代之以国有制。社会主义和马克思主义迎来了复兴。资本主义失去了自信，年轻人开始反抗它。道德美德在第三世界及其对第一世界的团结中得以体现。所有这一切都构成了当时在发达国家盛行的“第三世界主义”这一松散意识形态的一部分。但第三世界主义也源于第三世界自身。随着越来越多的国家获得独立，它们结成联盟、组织，并在联合国形成投票集团。早在1955年，在印度尼西亚万隆峰会上，尼赫鲁就与印尼的苏加诺、埃及的纳赛尔和南斯拉夫的铁托共同呼吁建立“不结盟运动”，以绕过冷战。尽管存在分歧，也受到西方的质疑，但这一运动不断发展壮大。在整个20世纪60年代，第三世界国家开始就经济理念进行交流。到60年代末，它们也感到已准备好在世界舞台上展现自身的身份和真正的价值。

The epiphany for the mixed economy and state domination in the developing world was reached in the late 1960s and 1970s, when the Vietnam War generated a liberal guilt about the entire third world. As opinion shifted against the war and the United States, so it did against the economic system identified with the United States. Markets and capitalism seemed to lose legitimacy. The war was partly blamed on them. National liberation movements aimed not only at defeating pro-Western governments but also at overturning the market and replacing it with state ownership in the name of “the people.” Socialism and Marxism enjoyed a renaissance. Capitalism lost confidence in itself, and the young rebelled against it. Moral virtue was to be found in the third world and in its solidarity against the first. All this was part of the loose ideology of “third worldism,” which enjoyed a vogue in the developed world in these years. But third worldism also came from the third world itself. As more and more countries acceded to independence, they formed alliances, organizations, and a voting bloc in the United Nations. As early as 1955, at the Bandung Summit in Indonesia, Nehru joined Sukarno of Indonesia, Gamel Abdel Nasser of Egypt, and Josip Broz Tito of Yugoslavia in calling for a “nonaligned movement” to bypass the cold war. Despite differences—and Western skepticism—the movement grew, and through the 1960s, third world countries transacted in economic ideas. By the end of the decade, they too felt ready to assert their identity and their true worth on the world stage.

再见，可口可乐

Good-bye, Coca-Cola

从某种程度上说，这一切在1973年10月6日达到了顶峰，当时埃及和叙利亚对以色列发动了大规模进攻，赎罪日战争由此爆发。在接下来的几天里，以色列的生死存亡都岌岌可危，直到最终扭转了战局。但在战争结束之前，阿拉伯石油出口国动用了“石油武器”——石油禁运——来惩罚美国和其他西方国家对以色列的支持。到第一次石油危机结束时，石油价格已经上涨了四倍。

In some ways, all this came to a head on October 6, 1973, when Egypt and Syria launched a massive attack on Israel, starting the Yom Kippur War. For a number of days, Israel’s very survival was in doubt, until it finally succeeded in turning the tide. But before the war was over, the Arab oil exporters had used the “oil weapon”—an embargo—to punish the United States and other Western nations for their support of Israel. By the time this first oil crisis had run its course, the price of petroleum had increased fourfold.

这是一件具有里程碑意义的事件。它加速了1973年以前就开始的石油特许权国有化进程。1975年和1976年，沙特阿拉伯、科威特和委内瑞拉的大型石油特许权全部被国有化。这些石油开采活动被整合到新成立的国有石油公司的控制之下，这些公司被寄予厚望，将主导国际石油业务。这些公司的成立不仅旨在终结石油特许权本身，也旨在消除随之而来的屈辱，并为产油国攫取石油收入的大部分。

It was a climactic event. It accelerated the process of nationalization of oil concessions that had begun before 1973. In 1975 and 1976, the great oil concessions of Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, and Venezuela were all nationalized and integrated under the control of newly established state companies that were now expected to dominate the international oil business. The creation of these companies was meant to put an end not only to the concessions themselves but to the humiliation that went with them, and to capture the bulk of the oil earnings for the nations that produced the oil.

但石油危机也被认为意义远不止于此——它标志着国际政治体系权力格局的根本性转变。正如一位杰出的外交政策专家所言，这场危机标志着自1905年日本在对马海战中击沉整个俄国舰队、结束日俄战争以来，第三世界首次战胜了第一世界。它预示着全球收入将从发达国家向发展中国家进行同样彻底的重新分配，从而纠正所谓的剥削错误。各种商品卡特尔的计划被大肆宣传，从铜到铝土矿，但最终都未能成功。国有化被提上了国内议程；只是具体条款尚存争议。世界两大铜生产国将本国境内的外资矿山收归国有。肯尼斯·卡翁达领导下的赞比亚和平地完成了国有化，并向英国矿业公司支付了赔偿金；而萨尔瓦多·阿连德领导下的智利则采取了更为激进的国有化方式，并因此加速了政府的暴力垮台。在印度，1977年至1980年执政的人民党驱逐了那些拒绝与本土企业分享技术的外国公司。IBM被迫撤离，可口可乐也因拒绝公开其秘而不宣的配方而遭到惩罚。在世界范围内，各国政府承担了更大的经济运行责任，而跨国公司和外国投资则被视为必须驱逐的祸害。这的确是政府权力的巅峰时期。

But the oil crisis was also considered to be something much more—a radical shift of power in the international political system. As one eminent foreign policy expert put it, the crisis marked the first time since the Japanese had sunk the entire Russian fleet at the Battle of Tsushima in 1905, ending the Russo-Japanese War, that the third world had defeated the first world. It held out the prospect of a no less radical global redistribution of income from developed to developing nations, thus righting the wrongs of alleged exploitation. Plans were bruited for a variety of other commodity cartels, from copper to bauxite, although, eventually, none was to succeed. Nationalization was on the domestic agenda; only the terms were in question. The world’s two largest copper-producing countries nationalized the foreignowned mines on their soil. Kenneth Kaunda’s Zambia nationalized peacefully, paying the British mining firms compensation; but Salvador Allende’s Chile did it more abruptly and, in so doing, helped precipitate the government’s violent downfall. In India, the Janata Party, in power between 1977 and 1980, expelled foreign firms that refused to share their technology with local champions. IBM packed its bags, as did Coca-Cola—penalized for its refusal to reveal its sacred and jealously guarded formula. Around the world, governments were taking over even greater responsibility for the workings of their economies, while multinational companies and foreign investment were derided as evils to be driven away. This was indeed the apogee for government.

事实证明，许多发展中国家是受石油危机打击最严重的国家之一——随着油价翻四倍后引发的全球经济衰退，它们的商品和制成品市场及价格也随之下跌。但这一现实被第三世界主义精神以及南方国家表面上的团结所掩盖，这种团结被一些人称为围绕“新国际经济秩序”展开的国际阶级斗争。发展中国家在联合国组成了77国集团。他们的论点得到了苏联的支持，即作为商品出口国，它们一直受到工业化国家的剥削，因为发达国家支付给它们的产品价格很低。他们认为，发达国家不仅应该支付更高的价格，还应该支付补偿性赔款。为了缓解南北对抗，1977年在巴黎召开了南北对话。对话旨在重新分配收入，保护商品价格，确保“控制”，并加速技术流动。对话的另一个目的是缓和紧张局势。尽管进行了两年的磋商，但收效甚微。最后，与会代表甚至无法就一份公报达成一致。

As it turned out, many developing countries were among those worst hit by the oil crisis—the markets and prices for their commodities and manufactures declined with the global recession that followed the quadrupling of the oil price. But this reality was submerged by the spirit of third worldism and the apparent solidarity of South against North in what some were to call an international class war over a “New International Economic Order.” Developing nations came together as the Group of 77 in the United Nations. Their argument, supported by the Soviet Union, was that, as commodity exporters, they had been exploited by the industrial countries through the low prices paid for their products. Not only, they said, should the developed countries pay higher prices, they should also pay compensatory reparations. In order to mitigate the North-South confrontation, a North-South Dialogue convened in Paris in 1977. It was intended to redistribute income, protect commodity prices, ensure “control,” and accelerate the flow of technology. It was also meant to defuse tensions. Despite two years of tractations, there was not much to show for it; at the end, the conferees could not even agree on a communiqué.

一个想法的终结

The End of an Idea

然而，在团结一致的言辞和表态之下，人们逐渐意识到一个令人不安的现实。诚然，世界市场有时剧烈的波动确实会损害发展中国家的经济发展计划。但现在看来，问题也出在内部。在拉丁美洲、非洲和南亚的许多国家，普通民众的生活并没有得到改善。国家主导的发展远未达到预期；腐败和可疑投资造成的浪费屡见不鲜。而令人费解的是，一些亚洲国家——这些国家历来自然资源匮乏，依赖进口石油——似乎已经渡过了难关，走上了令人瞩目的增长之路。所有这一切都表明，大宗商品价格和世界市场仅仅是问题的一部分，而问题的根源实际上在于国内。

Yet underneath the rhetoric and expressions of solidarity was the dawning realization of a gnawing, uncomfortable fact. To be sure, the sometimes violent ups and downs of world markets stood to harm the economic programs of developing nations. But the problem, it now appeared, was also internal. In many of the countries of Latin America, Africa, and South Asia, ordinary people were not getting better off. State-led development was falling far short of its promise; corruption and the waste from dubious investments were all too common. And mysteriously, several countries in Asia, which were notoriously poor in natural resources and dependent on imported oil, appeared to have weathered the storm and embarked on an impressive path of growth. All this suggested that commodity prices and world markets were only a part of a problem that, in fact, began at home.

在大多数发展中国家，政治也日渐衰落。在三大洲，民选政府往往被专制政府所取代。到20世纪70年代末，南美洲的大多数国家都处于军人统治之下。臭名昭著的独裁者层出不穷，他们以越来越肆无忌惮的方式掠夺国家资源。在菲律宾，费迪南德·马科斯将国家财富转移到私人腰包，供其家人和亲信过着奢靡的生活。在乌干达，伊迪·阿明·达达以经济民族主义为幌子，驱逐并没收了对国内经济至关重要的印度商人的财产。蒙博托·塞塞·塞科将刚果更名为扎伊尔，并通过窃取外国援助和印钞来资助铺张浪费的开支，导致货币贬值，迫使贸易转移到平行经济。

Politics had also degraded in most of the developing countries. On three continents, elected governments had all too often given way to authoritarian ones. Most countries of South America were under military rule by the late 1970s. Notorious autocrats emerged to plunder national resources in increasingly brash and blatant fashion. In the Philippines, Ferdinand Marcos diverted national wealth into private coffers, bankrolling a lavish lifestyle for his family and cronies. Under the guise of economic nationalism, Idi Amin Dada in Uganda expelled and expropriated the Indian traders who were vital to the domestic economy. Mobutu Sese Seko changed the name of the Congo to Zaire and financed extravagant expenses by stealing foreign aid and printing money, making the currency worthless and forcing trade into the parallel economy.

受害最深的莫过于普通民众。他们无法从无处不在的公共部门中获益，只能忍受物资短缺、基础设施破败、官僚主义的骚扰、小额腐败以及承诺的改善措施一再推迟。其中最令人痛心的莫过于一些农业国家粮食自给能力的下降。20世纪70年代末，很难将世界市场、国家对经济的支配、腐败、贫困和政治衰败之间的确切联系联系起来。但有一点是肯定的：发展经济学家们曾寄予厚望的“万物皆有灵”的理念——这种理念诞生于二战的浩劫和发展中国家的大规模贫困之中——已经破灭，一个理念也随之终结。

The damage was greatest to ordinary people. Unable to profit from the pervasive reach of the state sector, they suffered from shortages, decaying infrastructure, bureaucratic harassment, petty corruption, and the continual postponement of promised improvements. One of the greatest indictments was the decreasing ability of some agricultural countries to feed themselves. In the late 1970s, it was hard to draw precise links among world markets, state domination of the economy, corruption, poverty, and political decay. But one thing was certain. The hope of the development economists—born out of the cataclysm of World War II and mass poverty in the developing world—that “all good things go together” had come undone, tolling the end of an idea.

回顾所有对进步的期盼，著名经济学家亚瑟·刘易斯爵士不禁自问，发展进程究竟犯了哪些根本性的错误。他指出了两个根本性的错误，而这两个错误都付出了惨重的代价。他表示，其一是低估了国际贸易推动经济增长的力量。其二是未能及时认识到“市场价格比部长们的演讲更有激励作用”。11

Looking back on all the hopes of progress, the eminent economist Sir Arthur Lewis asked himself what fundamental errors development had made. He identified two basic mistakes, each of which had proved very costly. One, he said, was the underestimation of the power of international trade to propel growth. The other, he continued, was being too slow to learn that “market prices are more powerful incentives than ministerial speeches.”11

* 1947年独立时，印度次大陆总人口为3亿，其中9500万为穆斯林。如今，印度次大陆人口为9.35亿，巴基斯坦人口为1.2亿，孟加拉国人口为1.25亿，总计11.8亿。

*At the time of independence in 1947, the total population of the Indian subcontinent was 300 million—95 million of whom were Muslim. Today the subcontinent’s population is 935 million in India, 120 million in Pakistan, and 125 million in Bangladesh—a total of 1.18 billion.

第四章

CHAPTER 4

这是有史以来最短的移民之一。大卫·杨是一位白手起家的商人，事业非常成功，直到1972年伦敦房地产市场崩盘，几乎让他倾家荡产。到1975年，他才勉强从经济困境中恢复过来。然而，他对英国的生活越来越不满。这不仅仅是因为他不得不刻意避免让别人知道他是个企业家——尽管这确实是个问题。“在当时的社会，为自己工作是不被接受的，”他后来回忆说，“人们都在大公司上班。”

IT WAS ONE of the shorter emigrations on record. David Young was a businessman, self-made and very successful until the London real estate market collapsed in 1972, virtually wiping him out. By 1975, he had just about dug himself out of the financial rubble. Still, he was increasingly dissatisfied with life in Britain. It was not only that he had to go out of his way to avoid letting people know he was an entrepreneur, although that certainly was a problem. “It was not socially acceptable to work for oneself,” he later recalled. “People worked for big companies.”

真正令他绝望的是英国自身的状况。这个国家似乎正走向衰落和崩溃。事实上，它看起来正在分崩离析。通货膨胀率高达24%。工会刚刚推翻了爱德华·希思领导的保守党政府。持续不断的罢工使工会牢牢掌控了经济，使国家陷入瘫痪。边际税率高得惊人——高达98%——扼杀了人们的积极性。人们担心，英国正走在一条通往西方世界东德的道路上，一个社团主义国家，被磨砺成平庸的灰色地带，任何形式的进取都被视为病态行为，必须被扼杀。杨格受够了。他告诉妻子，他们要离开英国，移民。他们的目的地——美国。

What was really driving him to despair was the state of Britain itself. The country appeared to be locked into descent and decay. Indeed, it seemed to be falling apart. Inflation was running at 24 percent. The trade unions had just brought down the Conservative government of Edward Heath. Constant strikes gave unions a stranglehold on the economy and immobilized the nation. Marginal tax rates were high—up to 98 percent—destroying incentives. Britain was well along the road, people feared, to becoming the East Germany of the Western world, a corporatist state, ground down to a gray mediocrity, and one in which any kind of initiative was regarded as pathological behavior, to be stamped out. Young had had enough. He told his wife they were going to leave Britain; they were going to emigrate. Their destination—America.

杨和妻子周末伊始抵达波士顿，入住丽思卡尔顿酒店，酒店俯瞰波士顿公共花园。周日清晨，他们被警笛声惊醒。之后，他们漫步穿过波士顿公园。很快，他们的眼眶就湿润了——但这并非出于对故土和生活方式的伤感，而是因为催泪瓦斯，那是……警方前往平息因法院强制推行校车接送学生而引发的骚乱。“你一定是疯了，”他妻子一边用手帕揉着眼睛一边对他说，“你疯了才会觉得我会为了这件事放弃我的家人。”

Young and his wife arrived in Boston at the beginning of a weekend and checked into the Ritz-Carlton, which looks out on Boston’s Public Garden. On Sunday morning, they awoke in their hotel room to the sound of sirens. Later, they set off on a walk across Boston Common. Soon there were tears in their eyes—not, however, in sadness for the country and way of life they had left behind. Rather, it was the result of tear gas, loosed by police to break up a riot arising from court-enforced busing of school children. “You must be out of your mind,” his wife said to him as they rubbed their eyes with handkerchiefs. “You’re crazy if you think I’m going to give up my family for this.”

当晚，他们便乘飞机返回伦敦。在返程途中，杨格心想，除了绝望地离开之外，他应该还能做些什么。这意味着他要投身政治。他曾是工党的支持者，直到1964年之后，他对首相哈罗德·威尔逊感到失望。玛格丽特·撒切尔刚刚当选保守党领袖，她似乎对糟糕的英国经济有一些新的想法。但是，女性真的能成为首相吗？和许多人一样，杨格对此表示怀疑。

That very night they took a plane back to London. On the return journey, Young said to himself that there ought to be something more he could do than despair and depart. That meant politics. He had been a Labour voter until disappointed by Prime Minister Harold Wilson after 1964. Margaret Thatcher had just been elected Leader of the Conservative Party, and she appeared to have some new ideas about the dismal British economy. But could a woman become prime minister? Like many others, Young was doubtful.

接下来的几周，他开始阅读一位名叫基思·约瑟夫的英国政治家的演讲。后来，有人称约瑟夫为“疯僧”；约瑟夫本人也自称“一个方便的疯子”。他谈论企业精神、主动性和创业的必要性。约瑟夫说，创业并没有错；事实上，正是企业家为社会创造了财富。约瑟夫的言论与当时的主流观点截然相反，但却深深触动了大卫·杨。他深受启发。在一次慈善午餐会上，他主动向约瑟夫自我介绍，并表示愿意提供帮助。“但你不相信，”约瑟夫回答道。杨把这当成了挑战，全身心投入到这项事业中，成为致力于重塑英国经济和政治思想的核心人物之一。约瑟夫是这个核心人物。正如杨后来所说，“基思·约瑟夫是整个计划的缔造者。”1

Then, over the next several weeks, he started to read the speeches of a British politician named Keith Joseph. Later, others would call Joseph the “Mad Monk”; Joseph would describe himself not much differently—as “a convenient madman.” He talked about such things as enterprise, initiative, and the need for entrepreneurship. There was nothing wrong with starting a business, said Joseph; in fact, it was entrepreneurs who created the wealth for society. Joseph’s words were completely at odds with the dominant opinion of the day, but they struck a most responsive chord in David Young. He was impressed. At a charity lunch, he went out of his way to introduce himself to Joseph, and to volunteer his services. “But you don’t believe,” responded Joseph. Young took that as a challenge and threw himself into the cause, becoming one of the circle intent on reconstructing economic and political thought in Britain. Joseph was the man at the center. As Young later put it, “Keith Joseph was the architect of the whole thing.”1

“我最亲密的政治朋友”

“My Closest Political Friend”

“整个体系”最终远远超出了英国的国界。但可以说，约瑟夫对重塑关于政府与市场的辩论所做出的贡献，不亚于世界上任何其他人，他将各种思想融会贯通，对混合经济进行了强有力的批判，并在此过程中帮助将其塑造成一项政治纲领。而这项纲领又由他最重要的学生玛格丽特·撒切尔阐述并付诸实施。她使这些思想“成为现实”。但正是约瑟夫在20世纪70年代后半期，也就是当时混合经济的前提几乎没有受到质疑，而该体系本身却面临着严重的困境，以至于功能失调，而这五年间，他一手打造了这套体系。正如20世纪40年代的艾德礼共识在之后的三十多年里成为各国政府和政治家的“教条”一样，20世纪70年代在研究机构研讨会上萌芽、并在20世纪80年代撒切尔纲领中成形的思想，也将对20世纪90年代的全球议程产生深远影响。基思·约瑟夫的名字约瑟夫的名气远不及玛格丽特·撒切尔。但她对他的贡献却毫不吝啬。“如果没有基思，我不可能成为反对党领袖，也不可能在担任首相期间取得如此成就，”她说。她还补充道，约瑟夫是“我最亲密的政治伙伴”。

The “whole thing” would eventually extend far beyond Britain’s borders. But arguably, Joseph did as much as any other single person around the world to reshape the debate about government and marketplace, to take a variety of ideas and bind them together into a powerful critique of the mixed economy and, in the course of things, help shape them into a political program. That agenda, in turn, was articulated and put into effect by his most important student, Margaret Thatcher.
