Indeed, what has become commonplace in the late 1990s was considered so radical prior to the 1979 election that even Thatcher’s most committed supporters dared not raise the idea. The most that could be advocated for state-owned industries was the introduction of “inflexible” financial targets, the exclusion of ministerial meddling, the promotion of efficiency, and the ending of government subsidies. Privatization itself was only a small passing reference in the 1979 election manifesto. Going any farther would mean frightening the voters on the eve of the election.

1979年胜利后的最初几次重大举措也遵循着同样的思路。有人说，国有企业应该“商业化”，使其更像私营企业那样运作。唐宁街10号的政策部门对国有企业的“公司化”进行了调查。但政府内部其他人，从玛格丽特·撒切尔和基思·约瑟夫开始，认为这还不够。他们想走得更远。他们认为，让国有企业“模仿”私营企业，就像试图“在骡子背上画条纹，把它变成斑马”一样荒谬。他们的想法更加激进和独创：他们想让政府退出商业领域。为此，他们必须创造一种新型的商业模式，因为无论在发达国家还是发展中国家，都没有他们设想的模式可以借鉴。

The first major sallies after the 1979 victory were along the same lines. State-owned companies, some said, should be “commercialized” and made to operate more like private companies. The policy unit at 10 Downing Street investigated “corporatization” of state companies. But others in the government, beginning with Margaret Thatcher and Keith Joseph, thought that was not sufficient. They wanted to go much farther. They thought that getting a state-owned enterprise to “imitate” a private firm was much like trying “to make a mule into a zebra by painting stripes on its back.” They had something far more radical and original in mind: They wanted to get the government out of business. To do so, they had to invent a new kind of business, for there were no guidelines in either the developed or the developing world for what they intended.

更复杂的是，这项新的“业务”需要一个名称。一个显而易见的候选词是“去国有化” ——即把那些通过国有化而转为国有的企业重新交还给私人所有。但问题在于，有些公司，比如电话服务公司，根本就从未被国有化过；它们最初就是政府部门的附属机构。此外，“去国有化”这个词本身就带有明显的负面含义，令人反感。因此，他们转而选择了另一个词—— “私有化”，尽管有些人认为这个词也好不到哪里去。这个词在这种语境下的使用可以追溯到十多年前。20世纪60年代末，一位名叫大卫·豪厄尔的年轻保守党政治家受命制定一项计划，正如他所说，“旨在瓦解英国庞大的国有部门，同时扩大英国社会的资本所有权”。为了寻找灵感，他在美国四处搜寻，并在经济和社会理论家彼得·德鲁克的著作中看到了“私有化”这个词。豪厄尔认为这个词并不讨喜；然而，他也认为这描述了他的想法，并在1969年的小册子《一种新的政府风格》中运用了这一概念。但正如豪厄尔所说，这个想法一直处于“沉睡”状态，直到约瑟夫和撒切尔重新拾起它。

To complicate matters further, this new “business” needed a name. One obvious candidate was denationalization—as in returning to private hands companies that had passed into state ownership through nationalization. But there was a problem. Some companies, like the phone service, had never been nationalized in the first place; they had begun life as adjuncts to government departments. Moreover, denationalization had a decidedly negative and unappealing connotation. So instead they reached for another term—privatization, although some considered it not much less ugly. Its use in this context went back more than a decade. In the late 1960s, a young conservative politician named David Howell was charged with working out a plan, as he put it, “to unravel Britain’s huge state sector and at the same time widen capital ownership in British society.” Scouring the United States for ideas, he ran across the word privatization in the work of the economic and social theorist Peter Drucker. Howell thought it was an unattractive word; nevertheless, he also thought it described what he had in mind, and he deployed it in a 1969 pamphlet, “A New Style of Government.” But then, as Howell put it, the idea lay “dormant,” until Joseph and Thatcher picked it up.

这个词的奇特之处在于，它的支持者们既觉得它难听，又觉得它非常实用。“我不喜欢这个词，”撒切尔夫人说，“它代表自由企业。但我们必须接受它。它只是一个词而已。”事实上，撒切尔夫人非常讨厌这个词，以至于有一段时间她完全拒绝使用它。但和其他人一样，她最终还是妥协了。“我们谁也想不出更好的词，”曾任能源大臣和财政大臣的奈杰尔·劳森写道，“而且，既然这个词，或者说它的直译版本，现在从西伯利亚到巴塔哥尼亚都在使用，我们不妨就用它吧。”

The odd thing about the word was that its proponents found it both so ugly and yet so useful. “I don’t like it,” said Thatcher. “It’s free enterprise. But we had to accept it. It was one word.” In fact, Thatcher disliked the word so much that for some time she refused to use it at all. But like everyone else, she gave in. “None of us could come up with anything better,” wrote Nigel Lawson, who served as both energy minister and chancellor of the exchequer. “And, as this word, or quite literal translations of it, is now used from Siberia to Patagonia, we may as well stick with it.”

撒切尔夫人采纳了私有化的概念，即便她没有直接使用这个词，因为她从中看到的远不止是为国库增加收入或遏制工会的手段。它关乎改变社会的平衡。“我希望通过私有化来实现我建立资本所有制民主的愿景。在这个国家里，人们拥有房屋、股票，在社会中拥有权益，并且拥有可以传承给子孙后代的财富。”正是这种愿景激发了她的热情。

Thatcher adopted the concept, if not the word, because she saw in it something much more than a means to raise revenue for the Treasury or rein in the unions. It was about changing the balance in society. “I wanted to use privatization to achieve my ambition of a capital-owning democracy. This is a state in which people own houses, shares, and have a stake in society, and in which they have wealth to pass on to future generations.” Out of that ambition came her fervor.

二战前后，工党政客们一直将国有企业视为一种近乎利他主义的事业。“公共公司绝不能仅仅是资本主义企业，其一切目的都在于利润和分红，”对战后国有化计划影响深远的工党政客赫伯特·莫里森曾这样说道，“其董事会和管理人员必须将自己视为公共利益的最高守护者。” 但撒切尔主义者认为，在实践中，这种更高的愿景是无法实现的。政府在预测未来方面真的会比私营企业更胜一筹吗？政府并没有掌握更高层次的知识。事实上，撒切尔主义者并不相信政府拥有预知未来的能力。正如劳森所言，政府“并不拥有通往未来的独家捷径”。而历史的记录恰恰表明了相反的情况——面对变革，政府缺乏灵活性。

The Labour politicians had promoted state-owned enterprise, before and after World War II, as an almost altruistic undertaking. “The public corporation must be no mere capitalist business, the be-all and end-all of which is profits and dividends,” Herbert Morrison, the Labour politician who had so much influence on the postwar nationalization program, had said. “Its board and its officers must regard themselves as the high custodians of the public interest.” But in practice, argued the Thatcherites, that higher vision could not be attained. Was government going to be any better in figuring out the future than private business? It did not have access to a higher level of knowledge. Indeed the Thatcherites disbelieved in government knowledge. As Lawson put it, governments “enjoy no unique hot line to the future.” The record suggested just the opposite—inflexibility in the face of change.

无论愿景如何，国有企业在实践中往往被证明是效率低下、缺乏灵活性、业绩不佳的劳务派遣机构，它们迫于政治压力，不得不维持并扩大远超实际需求的就业规模。它们也无法抵挡来自公共部门工会的工资压力，从而成为通货膨胀的主要推手。由于效率低下、在工会压力面前不堪一击以及与市场竞争隔绝，它们积累了巨额亏损，最终只能诉诸纳税人，或者如劳森所言，“动用取之不尽的公共资金”来解决。每一项决策都可能沦为政治决策，其驱动力并非企业自身利益，而是当权政客的意愿，无论是工资协议还是对工厂选址、重大项目和设备的投资。而恰恰是那些推动国家产业发展的劳工人士最不愿看到的——市场纪律的缺失。劳森在1982年宣称：“公有制的作用在于消除被收购的威胁，最终消除破产的威胁，以及所有私营企业不时需要从市场筹集资金的必要性。” 英式公有制也这意味着产出和产品没有适应市场，消费者（买家）的需求和愿望并没有得到足够的重视。

Whatever the vision, state companies had often proved in practice to be highly inefficient, inflexible, poorly performing employment agencies, politically pressured to maintain and expand employment far beyond what was needed. They were also unable to resist the wage pressure from publicsector unions, thus becoming major generators of inflation. Because of their inefficiency, their weakness in the face of union pressure, and their insulation from competition in the marketplace, they piled up huge losses, which they solved by turning to the taxpayers or, as Lawson put it, by “recourse to the bottomless public purse.” Every kind of decision ran the risk of becoming a political decision, driven not by the interests of the firm but by the desires of politicians in power, whether it was wage settlements or new investments in plant location, major projects, and equipment. What was missing was exactly what the Labour promoters of national industries had most disliked—the discipline of the market. “What public ownership does,” Lawson declared in 1982, “is to eliminate the threat of takeover and ultimately of bankruptcy, and the need, which all private undertakings have from time to time, to raise money from the market.” Public ownership British-style also meant that output and products were not adapted to the marketplace and that the needs and desires of the consumer, the buyer, did not count for all that much.

对撒切尔主义者而言，私有化成为一项事业。它将体现基思·约瑟夫在全国各地演讲中反复强调的“潮流逆转”。扩大所有权，从而赋予民众对私有财产的既得利益，将改变国家的政治文化。它将从根本上限制国家的作用，并使撒切尔议程的至少一部分几乎不可逆转。它还将提高企业自身的效率，为消费者创造更多价值。它将消除企业对“无底洞”资金的依赖，并降低政府在国民生产总值中的份额。顺便一提，它还将带来大量资金流入，进而有助于减税。

For the Thatcherites, privatization became a cause. It would embody the turning of the tide that Keith Joseph had lectured about up and down the country. Widening ownership and thus giving people a vested interest in private property would change the political culture of the nation. It would decisively limit the role of the state and make at least part of the Thatcher agenda virtually irreversible. It would also make the companies themselves more efficient and deliver more value to consumers. It would eliminate the industries’ call on the “bottomless purse” and reduce government’s share of the GNP. And, by the way, it would provide for a considerable inflow of money that would, in turn, help finance tax cuts.

尽管如此，私有化从未获得广泛的民众支持。公务员方面也并未阻挠这一进程。他们在20世纪70年代与国有企业打交道的经历如此痛苦，以至于即使是那些在理论上认同混合经济的人，在实践中也对其能否有效运作感到绝望。此外，他们也提不出任何好的替代方案。传统的理念已经失效。“推动私有化的真正动力之一，”撒切尔内阁大臣约翰·韦克汉姆回忆道，“是官僚们普遍认为他们已经不知道该如何做决定了。计划经济、国有化等等——所有这些都失败了。国有企业亏损严重。人们渴望尝试一些新的东西。你会发现，官僚机构对新保守党政府的反应是‘情况不可能比现在更糟了’。”

With all that said, there was never a sense that privatization had broad popular support. For their part, civil servants did nothing to hinder the process. Their experience with the state-owned companies in the 1970s had been so painful that even those intellectually attracted to the mixed economy had come in practice to despair of its proper functioning. Moreover, they did not have any good alternatives to offer. The traditional ideas were exhausted. “One of the real driving forces for privatization,” recalled Thatcher cabinet minister John Wakeham, “was the consensus among bureaucrats that they did not know how to determine anything anymore. Planning, nationalization, and so on—it had all failed. The state-owned industries were running massive deficits. There was willingness to try something new. You found that the response within the bureaucracy to the new conservative government was that ‘it could not get any worse than it had already got.’”

基思·约瑟夫在工业部启动了私有化进程。新政府上任第一天，他就任命大卫·杨担任其私有化特别顾问。“新政府决心削减政府开支，这意味着要推行私有化，”杨说道。“最大的风险在于，我们必须让企业达到适合私有化的状态。结果发现，真正亏损严重的并非经济支柱企业，而是那些破败不堪的煤矿和其他行业。我们打算出售那些可以出售的企业，同时着手整顿其他企业，减少亏损，进行必要的关闭，并建立新的管理体系。”

Keith Joseph initiated privatization at the Department of Industry, and on the first day of the new government, he appointed David Young to be his special adviser on privatization. “The new government was determined to roll back, to reduce government’s spending, and that meant to privatize,” said Young. “The big risk was that we had to get companies into a fit state to be privatized. It turned out that it was not the commanding heights of the economy but rather clapped-out coal mines and other industries that were losing lots of money. We intended to sell off those that could be sold, and meanwhile work on the others to reduce losses, to do the necessary closures, to establish management.”

在这种情况下，最初的私有化举措与后来的规模相比显得相当温和。英国电讯公司（Cable & Wireless）和英国宇航公司（British Aerospace）是最早一批被私有化的公司。此外，高速公路沿线的加油站、国有铁路系统旗下的酒店以及一家生产医用放射性同位素的公司也被出售。事实证明，早期最重要的私有化形式是将“公屋”（即公共住房）出售给居住其中的居民。

In such circumstances, the initial steps toward privatization would be rather modest compared to what came later. Cable & Wireless and British Aerospace were among the first. Also disposed of were gas stations along motorways, hotels belonging to the state-owned railway system, and a company that manufactured radioactive isotopes for medical treatment. As it turned out, the most significant form of privatization in the early years was the sale of “council” (i.e., public) housing units to the people who lived in them.

有时，哪怕是私有化进程中的一小步，也会遭到媒体、部分公众、国有企业内部工会，甚至企业管理层的强烈反对——他们不愿看到自己的权力和领域被削弱。出售的究竟是什么似乎都无关紧要。英国天然气公司的垄断势力极其强大。这家国有企业的成立，旨在为英国打造一个现代化、一体化的天然气供应系统。它的市场非常广阔，甚至拥有遍布全国的900家展厅，独家销售燃气灶具和其他燃气设备。1981年，政府宣布计划出售这些展厅，因为垄断削弱了竞争，导致价格上涨，也阻碍了出口。此外，这种垄断的存在本身就十分荒谬：政府究竟有什么特殊才能，可以成为全国燃气灶具的守护者？

Sometimes even a small step toward privatization would meet a torrent of opposition from the press, parts of the public, the unions within the state companies—and from the managers of those companies, too, who did not want to see their purview and their realm reduced. It almost did not seem to matter what it was that was being sold off. British Gas’s monopoly was far-reaching. The creation of that state-owned company had been the means of creating a modern, integrated gas supply system in the country. Its market was very broad. It even held the exclusive right to sell gas-fired stoves and other appliances through its nine hundred showrooms around the country. In 1981, the government announced that it intended to sell off those stores, because the monopoly reduced competition, led to higher prices, and also discouraged exports. Moreover, the existence of that kind of monopoly was rather ridiculous: What special skill did the government have that it should be the custodian of the nation’s gas ranges?

但保守党人却丝毫没有意识到等待他们的是什么。英国天然气公司的工会，在不愿失去任何一丝一毫（哪怕是微不足道的）资产的管理层的怂恿下，与工党议员甚至一些保守党议员联手，谴责出售展厅的计划。“我们当中很少有人意识到，”奈杰尔·劳森写道，“一场风暴将会席卷这几乎称不上经济命脉的领域。”他补充说，政府的反对者“非常成功地将这家国有连锁店的私有化描绘成一场意识形态驱动的对英国生活方式的攻击。似乎每个社区的核心既不是教堂也不是酒吧，而是当地的天然气展厅。”在这种情况下，劳森被这突如其来的猛烈抨击弄得措手不及，他通过谈判达成了一项暂时的、挽回颜面的让步：展厅的出售将被搁置，直到新的安全法规获得通过。16

But little did the Tories realize what awaited them. British Gas’s unions, egged on by a management that did not want to lose any of its empire, no matter how tangential, joined together with Labour MPs and even some Conservative ones in denouncing the planned move to dispose of the showrooms. “Few of us realized,” wrote Nigel Lawson, “what a storm would be unleashed over what could scarcely be called one of the commanding heights of the economy.” The government’s opponents, he added, were “remarkably successful in portraying the privatization of this state-owned chain of shops … as an ideologically inspired attack on the British way of life. The heart of every community, it appeared, was neither the church nor the pub, but the local gas showroom.” In this case, Lawson, caught unprepared by the fury of the attack, negotiated a temporary, face-saving retreat by saying that the sale of the showrooms would be put aside until some new safety legislation could be passed.16

但具体该怎么做呢？

But How to Do It?

福克兰群岛战争后，政府有能力开始将真正掌控经济命脉的企业私有化。但劳森回忆说，最大的困难之一是“事实上，这在历史上从未有过先例……没有任何部门档案可以查阅。” 许多问题需要决定。是否应该将这些公司的股份免费分发给所有公民？劳森总理断然否定，并引用美国革命爱国者托马斯·潘恩的名言：“我们轻易得到的东西，我们往往轻视。” 如何给股票定价，既不能太高（吓跑投资者），也不能太低（意味着政府会损失太多价值），但至关重要的是，价格还要足够低，以确保首次发行后价格上涨而不是下跌？ 如何激励员工和投资者？让小投资者参与“公开发行”？为了满足这种愿望，他们制作了一系列电视广告，敦促一个名叫Sid的虚构的现代普通人不要错过成为股东的机会。

After the Falklands War, the government had the muscle to begin to privatize what were truly the commanding heights of the economy. But one of the biggest difficulties, Lawson recalled, “was the fact that, to all intents and purposes, it had never been done before … there was no departmental dossier to dust down.” There were many questions to decide. Should shares in the companies be distributed free to all citizens? Emphatically not, said Chancellor Lawson, citing the American revolutionary patriot Tom Paine: “What we obtain too cheap, we esteem too lightly.” How to price the shares so that they were not too high (discouraging investors) and not too low (meaning that the government would give up too much value) but still—of critical importance—low enough to ensure that the prices would go up, not down, after the initial offering? How to foster incentives for employees and small investors to buy into the “float”? To facilitate that desire, they created a series of television commercials that urged a fictional modern Everyman named Sid not to miss this chance to become a shareholder.

事实证明，最紧迫的挑战之一是为这些公司创建符合传统且易于理解的会计准则的、有意义且准确的财务历史记录。“当我们第一次考察国有化的英国电信时，”劳森说，“我们发现，这家公司完全没有意识到哪些业务盈利，哪些业务亏损，更不用说管理会计的细枝末节了，这很符合东欧的风格。”大卫·杨补充道：“英国电信简直一团糟。”一个只有五百人的小部门就“使用了一套笨拙的会计系统。其他所有账目都混杂在一起。你不知道区域成本，也不知道任何成本。一旦买了什么东西，你就把它忘得一干二净了。”

One of the most urgent challenges, it turned out, was to create meaningful-and accurate financial histories for the companies that corresponded to conventional and intelligible accounting standards. “When we first examined the nationalized British Telecom,” said Lawson, “we discovered that, in true East European style, the corporation had not the faintest idea which of its activities were profitable and which were not, let alone any finer points of management accounting.” Added David Young, “British Telecom was a total mess.” One small unit, with five hundred people, had “a clunky accounting system. Everything else was in one great big pot. You didn’t know regional costs, or any costs. Once something was bought, you forgot about it.”

这揭示了一个更大的挑战。公司只有在“整顿”之后才能私有化——即减少亏损业务、重组组织架构并建立盈利基础。否则，谁会购买这家企业的股票呢？英国钢铁公司就是一个绝佳的案例。从20世纪70年代中期到80年代中期，该公司亏损超过100亿美元。最初进行重组是为了减少对公共资金的消耗。直到20世纪80年代，私有化才成为目标。到该公司最终上市时，其员工人数已经大幅减少，生产率显著提高，设施也得到了合理化。而且，该公司实现了盈利，并在国际上具有竞争力。

This pointed to a larger challenge. Companies could not be privatized until they had been “fixed”—loss-making activities reduced, organization restructured, and the basis for profitability established. Otherwise, why would anybody buy stock in the enterprise? British Steel would prove to be an excellent case study. The company lost over $10 billion from the mid-1970s through the mid-1980s. Restructuring was first undertaken to stem the draw on public funds. Only in the 1980s did privatization become a goal. By the time the company was finally sold to the public, its labor force had already been drastically reduced and its productivity dramatically increased, its facilities rationalized. And it was profitable—and internationally competitive.

但也存在一些特殊情况，涉及的问题远不止“底线”那么简单。例如，对于石油等“战略性”资产，如何确保它们不落入外国之手？毕竟，私有化紧随20世纪70年代的石油危机之后，而正是这场危机促成了北海石油的部分国有化。在这个问题上，劳森展现出了非凡的创造力。他回忆起十年前在《金融时报》担任股市专栏作家时遇到的“奇特的投票结构”，这种结构使得“持有极少量股权的人能够行使不成比例的权力”。作为一名记者，他对此持反对意见。但作为一名政治家，他却认为这简直是天赐良机。于是，他提出了“黄金股”的概念——“一种在私有化后由政府保留的特殊股份，它能够帮助政府防止公司控制权落入不合适的人手中。”这里的“不合适”实际上是“外国”的委婉说法。虽然措辞委婉，但它确实达到了政治目的。17

But there were also special cases with issues that went beyond the “bottom line.” How, for instance, when it came to “strategic” assets like oil, to ensure that they did not fall into foreign hands? After all, privatization was following only a few years after the oil crises of the 1970s, which had, in the first place, precipitated the partial nationalization of North Sea oil. On this subject Lawson proved to be very creative. He recalled “the curious voting structures” he had encountered a decade earlier, when working as a stock market columnist for the Financial Times, that enabled someone with a “very small slice of equity to exercise quite disproportionate power.” As a journalist he had been disapproving. But as a politician he found it a godsend. Thus he came up with the “golden share”—“a special share which would be retained by government after privatization, and which would enable the government to prevent control of the company from falling into unsuitable hands.” The term unsuitable was a euphemism for foreign. However euphemistic, it did the political trick.17

一个规模更大的计划

A Far Bigger Program

最终，撒切尔政府得以推行一项规模远超预期、并大幅拓展国家权力边界的私有化计划。1982年和1984年，政府将其在北海油气领域的股份私有化，由此催生了包括如今全球最大的独立石油公司之一——企业石油公司（Enterprise Oil）在内的多家企业。政府还出售了其在一战前夕由温斯顿·丘吉尔收购的英国石油公司（British Petroleum）的股份。港口和机场也相继私有化。希思罗机场和其他一些机场如今由英国机场管理局（BAA）所有并运营，该公司在美国也运营着多家机场。

Ultimately, the Thatcher government was able to carry out a privatization program far bigger than anyone would have expected at the start, and one that pushed back the frontiers of the state. In 1982 and 1984, the government’s ownership share in North Sea oil and gas was privatized, creating among other things Enterprise Oil, today one of the world’s largest independent oil companies. The government disposed of its share in British Petroleum—acquired by Winston Churchill on the eve of the First World War. Ports and airports were privatized. Heathrow and other airports are now owned and operated by a private company, BAA, which also operates airports in the United States.

第一次真正意义上的大规模私有化是将国有电话系统剥离出来，成立英国电信公司。与其他任何私有化案例相比，这次私有化更彻底地将权力从生产者转移到了“消费者”手中，也成为了私有化进程中的真正突破。北海的石油和天然气储备究竟掌握在国家还是私营企业手中，对人们的日常生活并没有直接影响。但电话却截然不同。当时，真正关注石油和天然气私有化的人寥寥无几；几乎所有人都知道，电话系统即将发生翻天覆地的变化。电话系统在基思·约瑟夫将其剥离之前，一直是邮政系统的一部分，它集中体现了国有企业诸多最糟糕的特征。官僚主义的政府控制扼杀了创新。客户的意见被忽视。安装一部新电话需要几个月的时间。选择只有两种——要么接受现有的设计，要么什么都没有。想要在合理的时间内修好电话，唯一的办法就是私下雇佣那些在业余时间接活的维修工。红色的公用电话亭相对稀少，有时散发着难闻的气味，而且经常出现故障。

The first truly massive privatization was the hiving off of the state telephone system into British Telecom. It, more than any other, shifted the balance from production to the “consumer.” It would also be the real breakthrough for privatization. Whether the oil and gas reserves of the North Sea were in the hands of the state or private industry did not directly affect people in their daily lives. Telephones did. Relatively few people actually paid attention to the oil and gas privatizations; almost everybody knew that something dramatic was going to happen to the phones. The telephone system, part of the post office until separated by Keith Joseph, embodied many of the worst traits of state-owned companies. Bureaucratic state control repressed innovation. The customer did not count. It took months to get a new telephone. There were only two choices—the design offered or nothing. The only way to get a phone fixed in any reasonable time was to pay a repairman, who freelanced after hours, under the table. The red call boxes were relatively rare, sometimes malodorous, and often out of order.

“我们去电话公司办公室和员工谈话时，”大卫·杨回忆道，“他们谈论的是办公条件、养老金以及其他许多事情。从来没有人提到客户。如果英国电信想把一批员工从破旧的办公楼搬到新楼，工会就会敲诈勒索——每个员工几百英镑，理由是改善他们的工作条件会给他们带来‘麻烦’。至于安装新电话，他们总是等到一切都准备就绪才来。”

“When we went into the telephone offices to talk to the staff,” David Young recalled, “they talked about office conditions, pensions, and many other things. No one ever mentioned the customers. If British Telecom wanted to move a group out of a run-down office building into a new building, unions extorted compensation—a few hundred pounds for each employee for the ‘disturbance’ of giving them better working conditions. And when it came to installing new phones, they came along when they were damn well ready.”

在私有化之前，还采取了其他措施。一项名为“水星”（Mercury）的竞争性长途电话服务推出，刺激了进一步的创新。在撒切尔夫人第一任期的一个星期二，基思·约瑟夫在议会宣布，未来商店将被允许出售电话。两天后，大卫·杨在上班途中经过下布鲁克街的一家商店，橱窗里摆满了匆忙进口的电话，尽管当时这种销售方式还不合法。他到达部里后，冲进约瑟夫的办公室，兴奋地宣布：“市场运作良好。”

Other steps were taken prior to privatization. A competitive longdistance service, Mercury, was launched, which stimulated further innovation. On a Tuesday in Thatcher’s first term, Keith Joseph stood up in Parliament and announced that in the future, shops would be allowed to sell telephones. Two days later David Young, on the way to work, passed a shop on Lower Brook Street whose windows were filled with hurriedly imported telephones, although such sales were not yet legal. Arriving at the ministry, he rushed into Joseph’s office to make an excited announcement, “The market is working.”

英国电信的私有化进程实际上发生在1984年11月。第一批股份，略超过50%，以60亿美元的价格出售给了公众。一个巨大的私有化市场由此诞生。奇怪的是，私有化之后公众对服务的抱怨反而增加了，但这并非没有道理。“在私有化之前的美好时光里，没人抱怨，因为抱怨也没用，”杨格说道，“没人会听。”现在，人们终于有了可以抱怨的对象。英国天然气公司、英国航空公司和英国钢铁公司相继私有化。之后，英国煤炭公司和英国铁路公司也相继私有化。国有水务系统被拆分成一系列区域水务公司。其中规模最大的当属国有电力垄断企业被拆分成十二家区域配电公司。*三家发电公司和一家开放式电网公司。

The actual privatization of British Telecom took place in November 1984. The first tranche, just over 50 percent, was sold to the public for $6 billion. A huge popular market for privatization had been created. Curiously enough, the public’s complaints about service rose after the privatization, but with good reason. “In the good old days before privatization, no one complained because there was no point,” Young said. “No one was listening.” Now there was someone to complain to. British Gas, British Airways, and British Steel followed. Later came British Coal and British Rail. The state-owned water system was privatized in the form of a series of regional water companies. Most massive of all was the breakup of the state-owned electric power monopoly into twelve regional distribution companies,* three generating companies, and one open-access grid company.

在长达十五年的时间里，私有化进程遭遇了诸多批评。对于规模较大的交易，人们总是担心资本市场无法消化这些交易。但实际上，这从未成为制约因素。股票定价普遍受到诟病，要么过低，要么过高。保守党前首相哈罗德·麦克米伦是混合经济和中间路线的倡导者，他曾公开表达了许多人的不满，称这些“家族银器”——即那些名称均以“ British”开头的国有企业——正在被出售。对此，人们的回应显而易见：因为“家族”已无力继续维护这些银器了。

The process of privatization encountered many criticisms over a decade and a half. With the larger transactions, there always seemed to be a refrain that the capital markets would not be able to absorb the deal. In practice, that never proved to be a constraint. The pricing of stock was generally criticized, for being either too low or too high. Former prime minister Harold Macmillan, the Tory proponent of the mixed economy and the middle way, weighed in to voice the complaints of many when he declared that the “family silver”—the state companies, all of whose names began with British—was being sold off. The obvious reply was that the “family” could not afford to maintain the silver anymore.

有人指出，许多国有企业在私有化之前就已经提高了效率和生产力。对此，回应是这些改进是迫于无奈，是即将到来的私有化带来的纪律和压力所驱动的。私有化之后，新近私有化公司高管和董事会成员的薪酬增长——包括工资和期权——成为各大报纸头版头条的热门话题，而此前人员过剩的国有企业大幅裁员更凸显了这一点。这些受益者被冠以“肥猫”的恶名，成为民众愤怒的靶子。许多私有化公司的员工人数往往减少了20%到40%。毋庸置疑，服务质量有所提高，运营效率也更高了。但对于许多失业者——通常是在职业生涯后期——来说，找到新的机会并非易事。私有化带来的合理化一度加剧了英国“精简版”经济中的失业潮。然而，失业率的上升最终被证明是暂时的。到 20 世纪 90 年代末，失业率远低于欧洲大陆。

Some pointed out that a number of the state-owned companies had become more efficient and raised their productivity prior to privatization. Here the reply was that those improvements were driven by necessity, by the discipline and pressure of impending privatization. After the fact, the growth in compensation—salary and options—of senior managers and board members in the newly privatized companies became a hot staple on front pages, made all the more vivid by the sharp downsizing in employment levels in what had formerly been the woefully overmanned state companies. The recipients of these benefits became immortalized as the “fat cats” and the target of popular rage. Employment in many privatized companies was often slashed by 20 to 40 percent. Beyond question, the quality of service improved and operations became more efficient. But it would be difficult for many of those who lost their jobs—often late in their careers—to find new opportunities. The rationalization that privatization brought about fed for a time a growing tide of unemployment in the new “lean” Britain. Yet the growth in unemployment proved temporary. By the late 1990s unemployment was much lower than on the European continent.

私有化也带来了监管方面的新挑战。国有企业此前一直受政府部门的控制——当然，这种控制往往效率低下。如今，基本公共服务的提供也面临着新的挑战。天然气、电力、水等公共服务被委托给以盈利为导向的私营企业，而非不惜一切代价提供普遍服务。为了使这一新体系有效运作，需要一个监管机构来确保竞争并保护消费者权益。建立这样的监管机构对于公众接受新安排至关重要。保守党人确信他们能够改进美国的经验，因此寻求一种既能保持监管“轻量级”又能有效运作的方案。毕竟，过于繁琐或干预过多的机构与精简政府的目标背道而驰。因此，他们为每个行业任命了一位负责人——被称为“监管者”——其职责是监督行业惯例并制定定价规则，同时尽可能精简人员。

Privatization also introduced the new challenge of regulation. The nationalized industries had operated under the control—often ineffective, to be sure—of the government ministries. Now the provision of basic public services—gas, electricity, water—was being entrusted to private enterprises guided by profitability, not universal service at any cost. To work, this new system required a regulatory body that could ensure competition and protect the consumer. The establishment of such regulation was essential to public acceptance of the new arrangements. Sure that they could improve on the American experience, the Tories sought a solution that would keep regulation as “lite” as possible while still being effective. After all, excessively burdensome or interventionist structures would run counter to the goal of making government smaller. So they appointed for each industry a single individual—known as “The Regulator”—with the mandate to monitor industry practice and set pricing rules with as lean a staff as possible.

但最初的“轻量级监管”很快发展成规模庞大的监管机构。人们低估了从国家垄断向私营企业转型所带​​来的监管需求。形成私营垄断或“双头垄断”的风险巨大；而且，从技术层面来看，电力等行业的复杂定价机制运行和监管难度极大。鉴于所有这些原因，“监管机构”的最初构想受到了质疑，取而代之的是建立功能齐全的监管机构，其中一些机构甚至拥有数百名员工。18

But what started out as “regulatory lite” soon grew into much larger regulatory establishments. There had been an underestimation of the regulatory needs posed by the movement from state monopoly to private firms. The risks of private monopolies or “duopolies” forming were great; and on the technical side, the sophisticated pricing mechanisms for industries such as electric power proved complex to run and monitor. For all these reasons, the original conception of “The Regulator” came under fire, and a drift began instead toward full-fledged regulatory agencies, some staffed by hundreds of people.18

“有点像个机构”

“A Bit of an Institution”

玛格丽特·撒切尔在1987年第三次赢得大选，这证实了撒切尔主义并非昙花一现，而是一次政策方向的转变。“我想我已经有点像个老古董了，”她随后说道，“人们似乎在想，‘这个玛吉也没那么糟糕，对吧？’” 此后，她又在繁重的公务之外增加了一项私人计划——从头到尾阅读《旧约》，并每天向她的幕僚汇报阅读进度。“有人告诉我，《旧约》讲的是律法，《新约》讲的是怜悯，”她后来说道，“但我不太认同这种说法。”

Margaret Thatcher’s third electoral victory, in 1987, confirmed that Thatcherism was not an aberration but a change of direction. “I think I have become a bit of an institution,” she said shortly afterward. “People seem to think, ‘She isn’t so bad is she, this Maggie?’ “In the aftermath, she was drawn to add a private project to her manifold of duties—reading the Old Testament from beginning to end and reporting daily to her staff on her progress. “I’ve been told that the Old Testament is about laws, and the New Testament about mercy,” she later said, “but I’m not sure I agree.”

但1987年的胜利也标志着一个时代的终结。保守党政府强行推行人头税，对地方税收进行彻底改革，在国内引发轩然大波。撒切尔夫人日益民族主义化，对加强欧洲共同体的举措也愈发愤怒。她痛斥布鲁塞尔正在崛起的新官僚机构，认为它会蚕食威斯敏斯特的主权。她尤其对建立单一欧洲货币的计划感到愤怒，她坚信这将导致德国对欧洲的霸权。她强硬的立场比其他任何因素都更能疏远那些曾是她发起撒切尔主义革命的最重要盟友。这些人坚信英国应该身处欧洲内部，参与塑造欧洲格局，而不是置身事外，攻击欧洲。撒切尔夫人的领导风格更是雪上加霜。她似乎变成了……她越来越自信于自己的观点，也越来越孤立于其他观点之外。她几乎不愿容忍反对意见，甚至羞辱了那些曾经最亲近的人。她不仅在国家政治中，甚至在她自己的党内，都成了一个极具争议的人物。

But the 1987 victory was also the beginning of the end of an era. The Tory government created a domestic furor by “bashing on” to make a radical change in local taxation in the form of the poll tax. And Thatcher became increasingly nationalistic and angry in her attacks on the moves to strengthen the European Community. She reviled what she saw as a new bureaucratic monster rising up in Brussels that would drain sovereignty away from Westminster. She was particularly enraged about plans to create a single European currency, which, she was convinced, would lead to German hegemony over Europe. Her strident stance did more than anything else to alienate some of those who had been her most important allies in creating the Thatcherite revolution. They were convinced that Britain should be inside Europe helping to shape it, not sitting outside and attacking it. All of this was made worse by the style of Thatcher’s leadership. She appeared to have become increasingly confident of her own opinions, increasingly isolated from other points of view. She showed little willingness to brook opposition, and she humiliated even those who had been closest to her. She had become a divisive figure, not only in national politics but within her own party.

短暂的喘息之后，1990年8月萨达姆·侯赛因入侵科威特时，她正与乔治·布什在科罗拉多州阿斯彭参加一个会议。她借此机会确保不会接受既成事实。“记住，乔治，”她对总统说，“现在不是动摇的时候。”福克兰群岛战争以及绥靖政策的教训仍然深深地印在她的脑海中。

There was a brief respite. When Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait in August 1990, she was attending a conference in Aspen, Colorado, with George Bush and she took the opportunity to ensure that there was to be no acceptance of a fait accompli. “Remember, George,” she said to the president, “this is no time to go wobbly.” The lessons of the Falklands—and of appeasement—were still much in her mind.

然而，在国内，她的政治地位却明显动摇了。私有化的倡导者奈杰尔·劳森于1989年辞去了财政大臣的职务。多年来，杰弗里·豪一直是撒切尔最亲密的盟友之一，他在撒切尔执政的前四年担任财政大臣，并在接下来的六年担任外交大臣。撒切尔认为豪的反欧立场不够强硬，便迫使他卸任外交大臣，并以下议院领袖和副首相的职位安抚他。一年多后，豪忍无可忍。他再也无法容忍撒切尔专横跋扈的领导，也无法接受她对欧洲共同体粗暴的民族主义反对。1990年11月，豪发表了辞职演说，遗憾但清晰地阐述了他的分歧。这次演说引发了保守党党魁之争。撒切尔在巴黎得知自己在第一轮投票中胜出，但未能获得所需的多数票时，她正在巴黎访问。当晚，她出席了由弗朗索瓦·密特朗总统在凡尔赛宫举办的一场优雅的芭蕾舞晚宴。她表现得极其沉着冷静。但当另一位领导人祝愿她在竞选中取得好成绩时，她却回答说：“不，一切都结束了。” 有人警告她最终会落败，并且预感到随之而来的羞辱，她便退出了第二轮投票。几天后，保守党新任领袖约翰·梅杰——一位从杂耍艺人转型为商人的儿子——接替她出任首相。

At home, however, her own political position was definitely becoming wobbly. Nigel Lawson, the champion of privatization, resigned as chancellor of the Exchequer in 1989. One of Thatcher’s closest allies over the years had been Geoffrey Howe, who had served as chancellor in the first four years of her government and as foreign secretary for the next six. Deciding that he was not sufficiently anti-European, she forced him out as foreign secretary, consoling him with the posts of Leader of the House of Commons and deputy prime minister. After a little more than a year, he had had enough. He could no longer tolerate Thatcher’s domineering leadership or what he saw as her crudely nationalistic opposition to the European Community. His resignation speech in November 1990 regretfully but clearly laid out his disagreements. The speech precipitated a contest for the leadership of the Conservative Party. Thatcher was in Paris when she learned that she had come out at the top of the first ballot but without the required majority. That evening, she attended a wonderfully elegant ballet and dinner hosted at Versailles by President François Mitterrand. She demonstrated enormous aplomb. But to another leader who wished her well in the unfolding contest, she replied, “No, it’s all over.” Warned that she would eventually lose, and anticipating the humiliation that would follow, she withdrew her name from the second ballot. A few days later the new leader of the Conservative Party, John Major, son of a vaudeville entertainer-turned-businessman, succeeded her as prime minister.

撒切尔时代结束了。她的离世并非伴随着一片感伤的浪潮。她的不受欢迎程度遍及整个政治光谱，甚至波及到她自己党内的大部分成员。她被视为自以为是、固执己见、冷漠无情。她的力量——她的信念——也正是她的致命弱点。杰弗里·豪后来评价她是一位“伟大的首相”。但在他看来，“她的悲剧”在于“她后来鲁莽地试图强加自己日益强硬的观点。在玛格丽特·撒切尔生命的最后几年里，个人、政府、政党和国家之间没有区别……她坚持将个人意见的绝对主权伪装成国家主权，这最终导致了她的垮台。”

The Thatcher era was over. She did not go out amid a great outpouring of sentimentality. Her unpopularity extended right across the political spectrum and into a large segment of her own party. She was seen as selfrighteous, rigid, and uncaring. Her strength—her convictions—had also been her downfall. She was, Geoffrey Howe said afterward, “a great prime minister.” But, in his view, “her tragedy” was “the recklessness with which she later sought to impose her own increasingly uncompromising views. For Margaret Thatcher in her final years, there was no distinction to be drawn between person, government, party, and nation…. The insistence on the undivided sovereignty of her own opinion dressed up as the nation’s sovereignty was her own undoing.”

然而，她的政治遗产却展现出大多数政治家难以企及的强大而深远的影响。她重塑了人们对国家和市场的态度，并减少了政府干预。撒切尔主义削弱了商业活力，也降低了人们对政府能力的信心。它将重点从国家责任转移到个人责任，并力求优先考虑主动性、激励机制和财富创造，而非财富再分配和公平。它推崇企业家精神，私有化成为常态，劳工动荡不再持续扰乱经济。多年来，撒切尔主义几乎在世界各地都被视为异端邪说。但到了20世纪90年代，事实证明，玛格丽特·撒切尔已经在全球范围内确立了新的经济议程。

Yet her legacy proved powerful and lasting in a way that eludes most politicians. She recast attitudes toward state and market, withdrew government from business, and dimmed the confidence in government knowledge. Thatcherism shifted the emphasis from state responsibility to individual responsibility, and sought to give first priority to initiative, incentives, and wealth generation rather than redistribution and equality. It celebrated entrepreneurship. Privatization became commonplace. Labor unrest no longer continually disrupted the economy. For a number of years Thatcherism seemed anathema almost everywhere. But by the 1990s, it would turn out that Margaret Thatcher had established the new economic agenda around the world.

数字可以反映英国的经济变革。到1992年，约三分之二的国有企业已转入私营部门。总共有46家大型企业，拥有90万名员工，完成了私有化，政府从中获利超过300亿美元。曾经的公共财政巨额负担，如今已成为重要的税收来源。持有股份的人数增长了两倍，达到900万，占成年人口的20%，尽管这900万人中许多人只持有少量股份。但私有化最重要的后果是，它与工会改革一道，改变了自1945年以来英国赖以生存的基本制度关系——而正是这些关系在1979年使国家陷入瘫痪。那一年，每1000名劳动者因罢工损失了1274个工作日。到1990年，这一数字下降到108个工作日，不到十分之一。英国的政治和经济文化已发生永久性改变；基思·约瑟夫的思想革命在很大程度上取得了成功，尽管也引发了诸多争议。1975年曾立志移民的戴维·杨，四年后成为基思·约瑟夫的特别顾问，并在玛格丽特·撒切尔执政时期进入内阁。从今天的视角回顾这段历史，他说道：“撒切尔时代使英国从一个生产者主导型经济体转变为一个消费主导型经济体，并逐渐成为一个具有竞争力的经济体。信念推动了这一进程。”19

Numbers give a sense of the economic change in Britain. By 1992, some two thirds of state-owned industries had moved into the private sector. Altogether, 46 major businesses, with 900,000 employees, had been privatized, and the government’s take was well over $30 billion. What was once a massive drain on the public purse had turned into a major source of tax revenue. The number of people owning shares tripled to 9 million—20 percent of the adult population—although many of those 9 million owned only a few shares. But the most important consequence of privatization was that, together with labor union reform, it changed the basic institutional relationships that had defined Britain since 1945—and that had brought the country to a standstill by 1979. In that year, 1,274 working days were lost to strikes for every thousand people working. By 1990, that figure was down to 108—less than one tenth. The political and economic culture in Britain had been permanently altered; Keith Joseph’s intellectual revolution had, in good measure and despite all the controversies, worked. David Young, the would-be emigrant of 1975, was four years later Keith Joseph’s special adviser and then, under Margaret Thatcher, a member of the cabinet. Looking back from today’s perspective, he said, “The Thatcher years turned the United Kingdom from being a producer-led into a consumer-led economy, and it was becoming a competitive economy. Conviction drove the process.”19

“始终怀揣信念”

“Always with Beliefs”

随着时间的推移，人们对撒切尔主义的怨恨逐渐消退。约瑟夫和撒切尔开创的局面不再激进，反而成为英国新共识的核心。“新工党”在1997年上台执政，并非通过抨击撒切尔主义，而是采纳了其大部分言论和政策，尽管其中融入了与撒切尔截然不同的对同情心的强调。

With the passage of time, the bitterness over Thatcherism has ebbed away. What Joseph and Thatcher started is no longer radical but rather very much the heart of a new consensus in Britain. “New Labour” came into power in 1997 not by attacking Thatcherism but by embracing much of its rhetoric and its policies, although leavened with an emphasis on compassion that was distinctly non-Thatcher.

一天上午，玛格丽特·撒切尔（自1992年起被称为撒切尔夫人）与撒切尔夫人探讨了思想和政治。“多年前，普通民众加入工党是为了追求更好的生活，”她坐在位于贝尔格莱维亚优雅联排别墅二楼客厅的一张小沙发上说道，这栋别墅是撒切尔基金会的所在地。“现在他们明白了自由和……”依法经营的企业优于政府对工业和人民的大规模控制。新工党理解社会主义的本质及其弊端，即必须先创造财富才能进行财富再分配。而社会主义的起源恰恰是财富再分配，而非财富积累。

Ideas and politics were the topic one morning with Baroness Thatcher, as Margaret Thatcher has been known since 1992. “Years ago, ordinary people became Labour to get a better life,” she said, poised on a small settee in the second-floor drawing room of the elegant Belgravia row house that is home to the Thatcher Foundation. “Now they understand that freedom and enterprise under law is better than massive government control over industry and people. New Labour has an understanding of what socialism was and how it doesn’t work, that somehow you have to create wealth before redistribution. Socialism started with redistribution before wealth.

“社会主义曾风靡一时，”她继续说道，“我们国家也曾进行过社会主义实验。保守党执政时，并没有采取任何措施来扭转局面。我本人从未对社会主义抱有任何好感。对我来说，道理很简单：国家不应该告诉我们该做什么。我的经历更加坚定了我的信念。人们越来越清楚地认识到，走社会主义道路意味着接受衰落。”她摇了摇头。“你能想象吗——人们竟然会接受衰落？”

“Socialism was the flavor of the time for a long time,” she continued. “We in this country had an experiment in socialism. The Conservatives, when in power, did nothing to reverse it. I myself never had any sympathy for socialism. For me, it was so simple. The state ought not tell us what to do. My experience reinforced my beliefs. It was becoming obvious to people that the socialist way meant accepting decline.” She shook her head. “Can you imagine—people accepting decline?”

那么，政府的任务是什么？“首先，保持财政稳健。其次，确保法律基础健全，使工业、商业、服务业和政府都能蓬勃发展。第三，国防。第四，教育是通往机遇的道路。第五，社会保障体系。社会日益复杂，需要以更成熟的方式来应对根本性问题。如何在不滋生或强化依赖文化的情况下提供有效的社会保障体系？我们如何维护公民社会的美德？此外，一定比例的资金应该用于基础设施建设，一定比例的资金应该用于纯粹的研究……”

And what then are the tasks of government? “First, keep finances sound. Second, ensure a proper foundation of law so that industry, commerce, services, and government can all flourish. Third, defense. Education, the fourth, is the road to opportunity. The fifth is the safety net. Society is more complex and needs to be more sophisticated in how it responds to fundamental questions. How is it to provide an effective safety net without creating or strengthening the dependency culture? How are we to uphold the virtues of civil society? And a certain amount is to be spent on infrastructure and a certain amount on pure research….

她补充道：“还有，别忘了撒切尔定律：意外总会发生。你最好做好准备。”

“And,” she added, “don’t forget Thatcher’s Law: The unexpected happens. You had better prepare for it.”

对玛格丽特·撒切尔而言，她在英国推行的政策在全球范围内产生的影响，是她始料未及的“意外”之一。“1981年，一位财政大臣来拜访我，”她回忆道，“他说：‘我们都非常关注你正在做的事情，因为如果你成功了，其他人也会效仿。’我以前从未想到过这一点。” 事实证明，其他国家——无论他们是否承认撒切尔主义的影响，或者试图与之保持距离——都确实效仿了她的做法。

For Margaret Thatcher, one of the “unexpecteds” has been the global impact of the program she launched in Britain. “In 1981 a finance minister came to see me,” she remembered. “We’re all very interested in what you’re doing,’ he said, ‘because if you succeed, others will follow.’ That had never occurred to me.” As it turned out, the others—whether acknowledging the impact of Thatcherism or distancing themselves from it—have indeed followed.

走到楼梯顶端，她停下来回想上午的讨论。“撒切尔主义革命本身就出乎意料。谁能在20世纪70年代中期预料到如此巨大的变革呢？”她说道，“这一切始于我和基思爵士，始于政策研究中心，也始于经济事务研究所的哈里斯勋爵。是的，一切始于理念，始于信念。”她顿了顿，“就是这样。一切都必须从信念开始。是的，永远都要从信念开始。”

At the top of the stairs, she stopped to reflect on the morning’s discussion.-The Thatcherite revolution itself was unexpected. Who in the mid-1970s would have anticipated the degree of change? “It started with Sir Keith and me, with the Centre for Policy Studies, and Lord Harris, at the Institute for Economic Affairs. Yes, it started with ideas, with beliefs.” She paused. “That’s it. You must start with beliefs. Yes, always with beliefs.”

其中11台已被收购，7 台被美国电力公司收购。

*Eleven of them have since been bought, seven by American electric power companies.

第五章

CHAPTER 5

至今无人确切知晓事情究竟是如何发生的。事后看来，这似乎是不可避免的，然而，1989年11月9日晚发生的一切，也带有偶然性。已知的是，当晚柏林墙东德一侧的边防人员一片混乱。东德共产党中央委员会的成员们正陷入一场无休止的会议，争论不休，互相算计。柏林共产党主席君特·沙博夫斯基正准备召开电视直播新闻发布会，这时，党的书记埃贡·克伦茨递给他一份内政部的新规草案。

NO ONE still quite knows how it happened. In retrospect it seems to have been inevitable, and yet what unfolded on the night of November 9, 1989, was also accidental. What is known is that the border guards along the East German side of the Berlin Wall became wholly confused on that evening. The members of the Central Committee of East Germany’s Communist Party were locked in an endless meeting, arguing and maneuvering for power among themselves. And Günter Schabowski, the head of the Communist Party of Berlin, was just about to go on television for a live press conference when party secretary Egon Krenz handed him the draft of a new regulation from the Interior Ministry.

“这可能会大受欢迎，”克伦茨告诉他。

“This could be a hit,” Krenz told him.

的确如此。这份草案描述了前往西方国家申请签证的拟议新程序。但这并非沙博夫斯基在冗长的记者招待会上所谈及的核心内容；他当时心不在焉，对自己读到的内容并不清楚，更不清楚该如何表达。无论如何，这仅仅是一份草案。然而，在回答一位意大利记者的问题时，他似乎表示东德人可以不受任何限制地立即前往西方。埃贡·克伦茨后来称这些话是“一个小错误”——这至少可以说是一种轻描淡写的说法。

And indeed it would be. The draft described proposed new bureaucratic procedures for obtaining visas in order to visit the West. It was not central to what Schabowski was talking about in his rambling press conference; he was distracted and was not clear about what he had read, and even less clear as to how he would express it. In any event it was only a draft. Yet in reply to an Italian journalist, he seemed to say that East Germans could go to the West with no restrictions—and at once. Egon Krenz was later to describe those words as “a small mistake”—an understatement, to say the least.

当时大约是晚上七点，东德大部分地区都在关注这场新闻发布会。沙博夫斯基讲话后，成千上万的东德民众涌向柏林墙，想要检验这项新政策究竟是什么。许多家庭都加入了游行队伍，其中不少人甚至穿着睡衣。人群在柏林墙前聚集了三个小时，拒绝离开，高喊着“打开大门！打开大门！”在共产主义统治的漫长岁月里，在压迫之下，守卫们接受了无数详尽的指示，指导他们如何应对任何试图突破柏林墙的人。然而，现在发生了不可思议的事情：他们对此毫无准备。没有任何指令告诉他们该如何应对这种情况，守卫们顿时束手无策。他们是该开枪，还是该打开城门？在混乱中，他们选择了后者。成千上万的东柏林人涌入城门，迎接他们的是另一边熙熙攘攘的西柏林人，他们热情地拥抱他们，用香槟和啤酒泼洒在他们身上。

It was now just about seven o’clock in the evening, and much of East Germany was watching the press conference. In response to Schabowski’s words, thousands and then tens of thousands and then hundreds of thousands of East Germans headed toward the Wall to test the new policy, whatever it was. Whole families joined the march, many of them in their pajamas. For three hours the throng swelled in front of the Wall, refusing to move and chanting, “Open the gate! Open the gate!” In all the years of communist oppression, the guards had received endlessly detailed instructions about what to do in case people tried to breach the Wall. But now the unthinkable had happened; they had no instructions for this eventuality. There were no directives about how to react in this situation, and so the guards were paralyzed. Were they to shoot, or were they to open the gates? In their confusion, they did the latter. Hundreds of thousands of East Berliners surged through, to be met on the other side by huge crowds of waiting West Berliners, who engulfed them with hugs and doused them with champagne and beer.

难以置信，西德总理赫尔穆特·科尔一年前还信誓旦旦地说这辈子都不会发生的事，如今竟然真的发生了。柏林墙实际上已经倒塌。东柏林人和西柏林人彻夜载歌载舞，欢庆胜利。现在，他们都是柏林人了。第二天，在东德共产党召开的紧急会议上，一位发言者沮丧地总结了这一新的现实：“党基本上完蛋了。”很快，东德就被历史的车轮碾过。至于柏林墙本身，它被拆除了，残骸将被当作逝去时代的纪念品出售。冷战结束了。它的结束既没有轰轰烈烈，也没有悄无声息，而是以一场盛大的派对告终。

It was unbelievable; what West German chancellor Helmut Kohl had only the year before said would not happen in his lifetime had just occurred. The Berlin Wall, for all practical purposes, had fallen. Together, East Berliners and West Berliners danced and sang the night through. Now they were all Berliners. The next day, at an emergency meeting of East Germany’s Communist Party, one speaker glumly summed up the new reality: “The party is basically kaput.” Soon enough, East Germany was swept away by history. As for the Wall itself, it was demolished, and chunks of it would be sold off as souvenirs of a bygone era. The cold war was over. It had ended with neither a bang nor a whimper but with a party.

柏林墙曾象征着东西方、共产主义与资本主义的分裂。它的倒塌也象征着对抗的结束和新时代的到来。同时消失的还有一道思想的壁垒，它打开了思想和知识的疆界，将曾经各自拥有数十亿人口的两个截然不同的世界，转变为共同的图景和共同的市场。由于共产主义是国家经济控制最极端的形式，它的消亡标志着一次巨大的转变——从国家控制转向市场共识。共产主义经济模式的表面成功及其带来的声望，曾是政府控制的最重要驱动力之一。而如今，马克思主义和共产主义制度的失败，无疑构成了塑造这个新时代的最重要力量之一。

The Wall had symbolized the division between East and West, between communism and capitalism. Its fall was a great symbol, too, of the end of the confrontation and the passage into a new era. What also disappeared was an intellectual wall, opening up the frontiers of ideas and knowledge and transforming what had been two different worlds, each with billions of people, into a common landscape—and a common market. As communism was the most extreme form of state economic control, its demise signaled an enormous shift—from state control to market consensus. The apparent success, and thus the prestige, of the communist economic model had been one of the most important drivers of government control. Now, certainly, the failure of Marxism and the communist system constituted one of the most important forces shaping this new era.

这是一个概念转变最终导致全球经济组织方式的思维和政策发生根本性变革的时代。尽管在各个地区和国家内部存在诸多差异，但总体而言，这一变革标志着国家主权问题得到解决，传统殖民主义和帝国主义的残余被扫入历史的垃圾堆，经济凌驾于政治之上。此外，一套共同的理念和视角将成为政府与市场关系的枢纽和转折点。而这一切又是如何开始的呢？源于人们对工业化世界混合经济模式的幻灭。1

It was an era in which conceptual shifts would culminate in a sharp revision in thinking and policy about the organization of economies around the world. Within regions and countries there were many variations. But taken as a whole, this change represented a process through which the issues of national sovereignty were resolved, the residue of classic colonialism and imperialism were relegated to the past, and economics won precedence over politics. Moreover, a common stock of ideas and perspectives would provide the pivot, the hinge, on which the relationship between government and marketplace would swing. And how did it begin? With disillusionment about the mixed economies of the industrial world.1

信任危机

Crisis of Confidence

经验是最好的老师，而20世纪70年代到80年代的经验教会我们的，是对当时已成为传统的混合经济模式的能力日益增长的怀疑。对一些人来说，这会导致他们彻底否定政府的能力。而对另一些人来说，则是不安，以及日益增长的担忧，即战后时代的经济结构已不再能实现其缔造者最初的目标。无论哪种情况，这种观念的转变都是随着时间的推移而发生的，因为过去三十年辉煌时期所带来的信心开始以各种形式消散。与其说这是一个顿悟，不如说是一个逐渐认识到政府在管理现代经济方面能力局限性的过程。

Experience is a teacher, and what experience taught in the 1970s and into the 1980s was an increasing skepticism about the capabilities of what had become the traditional mixed economy. For some, it would result in an outright rejection of government’s abilities. For others, there was unease and the growing sentiment that the economic structures of the postwar era no longer fulfilled the aims their founders had intended. In either case, the change of heart happened over time as, in one form or another, the confidence generated by the thirty glorious years began to dissipate. It was less a revelation than a process of learning about the limits of government’s ability to run a modern economy.

三十年来，人们普遍认为，实现经济增长、提高生活水平和人类福祉需要某种形式的中央管理。协调的程度如此之高，以至于只有国家才能提供这种协调。这种共识建立在信任之上。为了使之有效，公众和企业必须相信，政治领导层——当然，必须经过选举的考验和调整——能够掌握必要的知识，以应对高度不确定的未来，并运用经济工具来改善国家前景，使未来更加安全。混合经济体制下的政府通过结合使用五套工具来实现这一目标：监管、计划、国有制、产业政策和凯恩斯主义财政管理。这些工具还可以辅以第六套工具——货币政策。实际的工具组合因各国传统和历史而异。

For three decades the consensus held that achieving economic growth and improvements in the standard of life and human welfare required some form of central management. The extent of coordination was considered so great that only the state could provide it. This consensus rested upon trust. In order for it to work, the public and business enterprises would have to believe that political leadership—tested and recalibrated by elections, to be sure—could gather the knowledge required to look into the highly uncertain future and apply economic tools to improve a country’s prospects and make that future more secure. The governments of the mixed economy did so by using some combination of five sets of tools—regulation, planning, state ownership, industrial policy, and Keynesian fiscal management. These tools could be augmented by a sixth—monetary policy. The actual mix varied considerably among countries, depending upon their traditions and history.

政府发挥作用的基本理论依据是经济学家提出的“市场失灵”概念。某些预期结果需要一定程度的协调，而市场上的单个竞争者无法做到这一点。由于这种失灵，政府会介入并提供这种协调。时间跨度和回报通常是重要的考量因素。仅靠企业自身无法进行投资；投资要么需要太长时间才能见效，要么产生的收益会惠及整个社会，而非进行投资的单个企业。基础设施建设就是一个例子，它需要很长时间才能完成，基础研发支出也是如此——在这种情况下，收益可能相当分散，因此无法被投入资金的企业所获取。

The basic rationale for government’s role was the economists’concept of “market failure.” Some desired outcomes required a degree of coordination that individual competitors in the marketplace could not muster. As a result of this failure, government would step in and provide that coordination. Time horizons and returns were often important concerns. Business alone could not provide investment; it either would take too long to come to fruition or would generate benefits that went to society at large, rather than the individual firm that had made the investment. Infrastructure was an example of something that took too long to develop, as were expenditures on basic research and development—a case in which the benefits might be quite diffused and thus not capturable by the firm that spent the money.

市场失灵还有另一层含义——洞察力和知识的匮乏。“政府知识”——即政府所掌握并被认为有责任掌握的知识——与“商业知识”截然不同。后者是在不同的学院中培养的——在法学院和政策学院，而非商学院，更不是在“行业”中。人们认为，一项经济活动越是着眼于未来并影响广大民众，仅凭简单的商业知识就越不足以应对。干预手段便成了应对失灵的工具。运用政府知识。资源的分配和运用并非源于供求关系这一基本力量——而是由市场参与者的知识所塑造——而是由国家通过政治和官僚决策来指导和分配的。法国前总统瓦莱里·吉斯卡尔·德斯坦在20世纪50年代初是法国国家行政学院（法国政府知识的宝库）的优秀学生。回顾他的求学经历，他回忆说，他当时学习的是指导性计划和价格管制，“但完全没有提及市场，也没有讨论过市场本身。”

There was another sense to market failure as well—a failure of acumen, of knowledge. “Government knowledge”—what the government knew and was considered responsible for knowing—was different from “business knowledge.” The latter was cultivated in different academies—in schools of law and policy, not business, and certainly not in the “trades.” It was thought that the more an economic activity aimed toward the future and affected the broad population, the less sufficient was simple business knowledge to see it through. The instruments of intervention became the tools with which to apply government knowledge. Resources were directed and allocated by the state, by political and bureaucratic decision making, rather than by the elemental forces of supply and demand—forces shaped by the knowledge of those in the marketplace. Valéry Giscard d’Estaing, the former French president, was a star pupil at the École Nationale d’Administration, France’s great repository of government knowledge, in the early 1950s. Looking back on his education, he recalled that he was taught about indicative planning and price controls, “but there was no reference, no discussion whatsoever of the market or about the market.”

起初，政府承担经济活动风险似乎合情合理，也显得稳妥。毕竟，谁也不会忘记20世纪30年代的种种乱象。于是，政府俨然成了一家国家保险公司，既保障经济增长，又保护公众免受市场风险的冲击。如同庞大的保险公司一般，政府通过各种直接和间接税收收取保费，以支付各项支出。但与保险公司不同的是，政府还拥有公共权力——赤字支出，并且越来越多地动用这项权力。然而，随着政府作为保险机构的角色日益稳固，消费者、工人和企业的期望也随之增强。一旦确立，干预型政府只会不断壮大，而不会缩小。政府能够且将会保障经济增长和不断扩大的福利，这种预期逐渐成为政治文化的一部分。

At first, government’s assumption of the risks of economic activity seemed logical—and safe. No one could forget the 1930s. Thus government became a sort of national insurance company, guaranteeing growth while protecting the public from the risks of the market. Like vast insurers, governments collected premiums to pay for their outlays via direct and indirect taxes of all sorts. Unlike insurers, they also had at their disposal the prerogative of public authorities—deficit spending, on which they increasingly drew. But as government’s role as insurer became entrenched, so too did the expectations of consumers, workers, and businesses. Once established, an interventionist government could only grow larger, not shrink. The expectation that government could and would guarantee growth and expanding benefits became part of the political culture.

然而，谁又能否认这场实验的成功呢？从二战结束到20世纪70年代的石油危机，工业化世界经历了三十年的繁荣和收入增长，这激发了人们的抱负和梦想。这是一项非凡的成就。战时和战后物资配给制度下的孩子们，成长为经济复苏和增长的青少年，最终成为消费社会的父母。住房条件得到了极大的改善。许多家庭购买了第一辆、第二辆汽车；他们添置了家电和电视机。他们在超市和百货商店购物，他们度假、出国旅行，他们购买那些被广告打造成品牌和身份象征的产品。最重要的是，他们有了工作。社会评论家们哀叹消费主义和物质主义；他们指出了“私人富裕”与“公共贫困”之间的巨大鸿沟。但根本的事实是，一种在二战结束时人们根本无法想象的生活质量已经出现。毫不奇怪，在整个非共产主义工业化世界，选民们都授权政治家们使用这套标准工具来保障经济稳步增长，从而实现充分就业。这样做，体现了他们对政府在维护国家经济利益方面拥有更优越认知的信任。

Yet who could deny the success of the experiment? From the end of the Second World War until the oil crises of the 1970s, the industrial world enjoyed three decades of prosperity and rising incomes that sparked aspirations and dreams. It was an extraordinary achievement. The children of wartime and postwar rationing became the adolescents of economic recovery and growth and then the parents of the consumer society. Housing improved enormously. Families bought their first and then their second car; they acquired appliances and televisions. They shopped in supermarkets and department stores, they went on vacations and traveled to foreign countries, and they purchased products that had been turned into brand names and status symbols by advertising. And, most of all, they had jobs. Social critics bemoaned consumerism and materialism; they identified the gulf between “private affluence” and “public squalor.” But the fundamental fact was that a quality of life had emerged that could not have been dreamed of at the end of World War II. It is no wonder that throughout the noncommunist, industrialized world, voters gave politicians the go-ahead to use that standard set of tools to guarantee a steadily growing economy—and, hence, full employment. In so doing, they deferred to government’s superior knowledge of the national economic interest.

通货膨胀是预警信号。整个20世纪60年代，混合经济体的通胀趋势缓慢上升，但从未达到引发严重警报的程度。然而，到了70年代初，通胀压力变得越来越明显。各国政府过去用来勉强应对通胀的手段——维持消费需求、抑制通货膨胀——如今已不再奏效。工资增长——如今已不足以应对困境。凯恩斯主义的需求管理理论认为，低失业率和低且可控的通货膨胀率是可持续的组合。事实证明，这种假设是错误的。

The warning flag was inflation. Throughout the 1960s, inflationary tendencies crept upward in the mixed economies, but never to the point of causing serious alarm. However, by the early 1970s, inflationary pressures were becoming more pronounced and visible. The tools governments had used to muddle through—to sustain consumer demand, to match inflation with wage increases—were now inadequate. Keynesian demand management assumed that low unemployment and a low, managed rate of inflation was a sustainable combination. That proved wrong.

这一教训来之不易，因为它挑战了所有既定的认知。缺乏直面问题的政治意愿，只会让情况雪上加霜。通货膨胀在诸多方面根深蒂固：政府赤字不断增长、福利国家规模不断扩大、竞争壁垒重重、劳动力市场僵化、劳动成本中增加“社会费用”，以及劳资双方就工资及其在社会体系中的传递方式进行的谈判。通货膨胀很大程度上是国家保险体系为应对不确定性、波动性和竞争而提供的保护成本。工资和价格管制措施的实施，恰恰证明了通货膨胀的普遍存在。但这些管制措施不过是权宜之计。它们或许能暂时抑制通货膨胀，但却无法根除其根源。

The lesson took time to learn, for it challenged all that had been accepted as the received wisdom. The shortage of political will to tackle the problem head-on only gave conditions time to get worse. Inflation was becoming entrenched in many ways: by the growth of government deficits, by the expansion of the welfare state, by the barriers to competition, by the rigidities of the labor market, by the “social charges” added to the labor bill, and by the nature of the bargaining between labor and management over wages and the way they would be passed through the system. A good part of the inflation was a cost of the protection provided by the insurance state against uncertainties, volatilities, and competition. The adoption of wage and price controls became testament to the prevalence of the inflationary dynamics. But controls were no more than a stopgap. They could hold inflation at bay ever so briefly but could not disable its causes.

1973-74年石油危机爆发时，混合经济体系已不堪重负。油价暴涨之所以构成真正的“冲击”，在于它彻底颠覆了经济中原有的成本模式。石油危机后的经济衰退中，通货膨胀和失业率开始同步攀升，形成了一种前所未有的致命螺旋式上升。这种现象被称为滞胀。1974年至1980年间，左翼和右翼政府都认识到，试图通过赤字支出摆脱危机是徒劳且适得其反的。凯恩斯主义失去了其影响力。此前几十年人们习以为常的经济增长，如今却令人无比怀念。

When the oil crisis of 1973-74 hit, the mixed economy was already straining. What made the dramatic rise in the price of oil truly a “shock” was the extent to which it upset the familiar patterns of costs in the economy. In the slump that followed the oil crisis, inflation and unemployment began to rise together in a deadly and unprecedented spiral. The phenomenon was christened stagflation. And between 1974 and 1980 governments of the left and the right alike learned that attempts to buy one’s way out of the crisis by means of deficit spending would be futile and counterproductive. Keynesianism lost its cachet. The economic growth of the preceding decades, formerly much taken for granted, was now sorely missed.

糟糕的经济表现以及政府政策的混乱和迷茫导致人们对现有体制失去信心。政府的知识不再那么强大，政府也不再无所不知。到了动荡的20世纪70年代末，一种新的认识逐渐形成：不仅仅是日常管理，整个经济结构已经达到了极限。重新思考政府在市场中的角色势在必行。对于那些先驱者——那些在各国率先推行政府退出经济计划的经济学家、政治家和技术官僚来说，这项任务堪称革命性的。几十年来，各国政府首次寻求扭转局面——剥离资产，并至少正视放弃部分控制权的想法。到20世纪70年代末，工业化国家对混合经济的不满情绪已经显现，而这种不满很快就会在选举中产生影响。与此同时，当工业化世界重新评估其安排时，发展中国家即将面临自身的转型危机。

Poor economic performance and the muddling and confusions of government policy engendered a loss of confidence in existing arrangements. Government knowledge was less powerful; governments, less all-knowing. By the end of the troubled 1970s, a new realization had gained ground: More than daily management, it was the entire structure of the economy that had reached its limits. It was imperative to rethink government’s role in the marketplace. For the pioneers—the economists, politicians, and technocrats who shepherded the early programs of government withdrawal from the economy in various countries—the task was nothing short of revolutionary. For the first time in decades, governments would seek to reverse direction—to shed assets and to confront at least the idea of giving up some control. The dissatisfactions with the mixed economy were already evident in the industrial world by the end of the 1970s, and they would shortly make their impact felt at the ballot box. In the meantime, while the industrial world was reassessing its arrangements, the developing world was about to encounter its own transforming crisis.

债务危机与失去的十年

The Debt Crisis and the Lost Decade

赫苏斯·席尔瓦·赫尔佐格在墨西哥历史上享有盛名。1937年，他的父亲起草了一份具有历史意义的控诉外国石油公司的法案，这份法案为墨西哥石油工业国有化提供了理论依据——这是墨西哥现代史上最重要的事件之一。他本人也追随了新一代技术官僚的道路，并在耶鲁大学获得了经济学硕士学位。1982年4月，他出任墨西哥财政部长，当时墨西哥似乎正蓄势待发，准备在世界舞台上迈上新的台阶。新的大型石油发现使墨西哥成为主要的石油出口国，而当前和预计的收入激增意味着墨西哥将能够慷慨地进行新的公共投资。何塞·洛佩斯·波蒂略总统要求墨西哥在全球发挥领导作用。为此，他摆出了一副威严的姿态：他宣称，经济不应“吃得太多，消化不了”。

Jesús Silva Herzog carried a proud name in Mexican history. In 1937, his father had drawn up the historic bill of complaint against the foreign oil companies that provided the rationale for Mexico to nationalize the oil industry—one of the most important events in modern Mexican history. He himself had followed the path of the new technocrats, in his case getting a graduate degree in economics from Yale. He became his country’s minister of finance in April 1982, just as Mexico seemed poised to rise to a new rank in the world. Large new petroleum discoveries were turning the country into a major oil exporter, and the present and projected surge in earnings meant the country would be able to spend liberally on new public investments. President José López Portillo demanded a global leadership role for Mexico. In so doing, he struck a magisterial pose: The economy should not “eat more than it could digest,” he declared.

然而，到了1982年夏天，席尔瓦·赫尔佐格发现这一切都不过是摇摇欲坠的纸牌屋。墨西哥一直在疯狂举债，无人能够阻止——当然也包括总统洛佩斯·波蒂略，他身边围绕着一群阿谀奉承之徒，只为博取人们的赞誉。几个月前，一群官员鼓起勇气警告总统，麻烦即将到来。总统却因为他们的警告而将他们解雇。但现在真相大白了，至少对席尔瓦·赫尔佐格来说是这样。1982年8月12日，他得出结论：墨西哥无力偿还国际债务的利息。一切都结束了。墨西哥即将破产。

But then, in the summer of 1982, Silva Herzog discovered that it was all a house of cards. Mexico had been on a borrowing spree that nobody would or could stop—certainly not President López Portillo, who had surrounded himself with courtiers and sycophants in order to be told what a wonderful president he was. Some months earlier, a group of officials had screwed up their courage and actually warned the president that trouble was coming. He had rewarded them for their troubles by firing them. But now the truth was clear, at least to Silva Herzog. On August 12, 1982, he concluded that Mexico could not pay the interest on its international debt. The game was just about over. Mexico was about to go bankrupt.

“那真是太可怕了，”席尔瓦·赫尔佐格说道。“我们因为石油犯下了可怕的错误。但当时墨西哥一片欢腾，一片胜利的氛围。我们经历了墨西哥历史上规模最大的经济繁荣。在1978年至1982年那几年，我们第一次受到世界上最重要的国家的青睐。我们以为自己很富有，因为我们拥有石油。”

“It was horrible,” said Silva Herzog. “We had just committed terrible mistakes on the basis of oil. But there had been this great mood of victory in Mexico. We had been in the largest boom in Mexican history. And for the first time in our history, in those years 1978 through 1982, we were being courted by the most important people in the world. We thought we were rich. We had oil.”

席尔瓦·赫尔佐格匆匆赶往华盛顿，在那里，他与美国财政部和美联储进行了极其艰难的谈判，最终敲定了紧急救援方案的第一步。美国官员们毫不费力地意识到事态的严重性。面临风险的不仅仅是墨西哥，甚至不仅仅是整个拉丁美洲。由于对发展中国家的贷款规模如此庞大，以至于美国的大多数主要银行，乃至整个全球银行体系，都岌岌可危。

Silva Herzog hastened to Washington, where, after very tough negotiations-with the U.S. Treasury and the Federal Reserve Board, he worked out the first steps in an emergency rescue package. The American officials had no trouble recognizing the extreme danger. It was not just Mexico, or even the whole of Latin America, that was at risk. So heavy had been the lending to the developing world that most of America’s major banks, and indeed the entire global banking system, were in grave peril of collapse.

几周后，应美国当局的要求，席尔瓦·赫尔佐格飞往纽约，会见了数百家曾向墨西哥提供贷款的美国银行的负责人，向他们说明墨西哥面临的困境。陪同他的是另一位高级官员安赫尔·古里亚。席尔瓦·赫尔佐格阐述了严峻的形势，并介绍了迄今为止的救援计划。这些银行必须配合，同意允许墨西哥……推迟偿还债务。纽约联邦储备银行行长称这种推迟为“暂停”。美国官员不愿使用“违约”一词，担心会立即引发恐慌。没有人会怀疑局势的严重性。而且这不仅仅是墨西哥的问题。他们都清楚自身的风险敞口，现在他们清楚地认识到其中的关联——每个人都站在悬崖边上。这不是一次令人愉快的会议。在场的银行家们震惊不已，几乎提不出任何问题。为了找到一些安慰的话，赫苏斯·席尔瓦·赫尔佐格最终告诉银行家们，从长远来看，他们不必担心墨西哥的债务。毕竟，他指着他的同事安赫尔·古里亚和他自己补充道，赫苏斯和安赫尔都会为他们着想。这种安慰微不足道，但也只能如此了。20世纪80年代的大债务危机就此拉开序幕。

A few weeks later, at the behest of American authorities, Silva Herzog flew to New York City to meet with the heads of the several hundred U.S. banks that had lent to Mexico in order to tell them how much trouble they were really in. He was accompanied by another senior official, Ángel Gurría. Silva Herzog laid out the bleak picture and described the rescue plans thus far. The banks would have to cooperate by agreeing to allow Mexico to postpone its repayments. The president of the New York Federal Reserve Bank called the postponement a “standstill.” American officials did not want to use the word default, for fear that it would immediately induce a panic. No one could doubt the gravity of the situation. And this was not just a Mexican problem. They all knew their exposure, and now they clearly understood the interconnections—everyone was standing at the precipice together. It was not a cheerful meeting. So stunned were the assembled bankers that they could hardly muster any questions. Searching for something comforting to say, Jesús Silva Herzog finally told the bankers that over the long term they need not worry about their Mexican debt. After all, he added, pointing to his colleague Ángel Gurría and himself, both Jesús and Ángel would be looking out for them. The reassurance was meager, but it would have to do. The great debt crisis of the 1980s had begun.

正如20世纪70年代滞胀和僵化政策动摇了工业化世界的共识一样，20世纪80年代旷日持久的债务危机也削弱了发展中国家对不断扩张的国家的信心以及对第三世界主义的坚持。这场始于雄心勃勃和信心满满的借贷最终演变成被誉为“历史上最广泛的债务问题”。这场债务危机在20世纪70年代后半期以惊人的速度爆发。在那些年里，世界金融中心充斥着石油生产国带来的巨额财富。银行家们迅速将这些新近被称为“石油美元”的资金以贷款的形式循环利用——其中许多贷款流向了发展中国家，既包括政府也包括国有企业。一些人担心这些政府和国有企业是否有能力偿还随之而来的债务，但这种担忧被置之不理。事实上，人们深受 20 世纪 20 年代和 30 年代的影响，非常担心如果这些资金不能循环利用，可能会引发世界大萧条。

Just as stagflation and rigidity had toppled the consensus within the industrial world in the 1970s, so the protracted debt crisis in the 1980s undermined both the confidence placed in the expanding state in the developing world and the adherence to third worldism. The borrowing that began with high ambition and great assurance ended in what has been described as “the most widespread debt problem in history.” It had been generated with remarkable rapidity in the second half of the 1970s. In those years, the world’s money centers were flush with deposits from the oil producers’windfall. Bankers rapidly recycled these newly dubbed “petrodollars” in the form of loans—many of them to developing countries, both to governments and to government-owned companies. Some worried about the ability of these government and state companies to handle the consequent debt service, but the concern was brushed aside. In fact, with the 1920s and 1930s very much in mind, there was great fear that failure to recycle those funds could trigger a world depression.

与此同时，在当时的社会氛围下，贷款人和借款人都觉得这是在为未来放贷。毕竟，全球权力和影响力不是正在从发达国家向发展中国家转移吗？南方国家不是正在纠正对北方国家的不平衡，赎清殖民主义和帝国主义的罪孽吗？此外，还有一个因素：由于工业化国家的经济衰退，银行在本国市场的生意惨淡。美国的房地产市场刚刚崩溃。银行间竞争加剧，导致贷款条件越来越优惠，越来越诱人。事实上，向第三世界国家放贷成了当时的潮流，没有人愿意垫底。美联储主席保罗·沃尔克事后评论道：“对于第三世界国家的总统或财政部长来说，20世纪70年代的国际银行业务就像收到一张信用卡——只不过额度后面多了三四个零。”

At the same time, in the spirit of the day, it seemed to both lenders and borrowers that this was money being loaned to the future. After all, were not global power and influence shifting from developed to developing countries? Wasn’t the South redressing the balance against the North, expiating the sins of colonialism and imperialism? Add to it all one other factor: Because of the downturn in the industrial countries, business in the home markets of the banks was poor. Real estate in the United States had just gone bust. Intensified competition among banks led to ever sweeter and more enticing terms for would-be borrowers. In fact, the in thing was to lend to third world countries, and no one wanted to be at the bottom of the league tables. “To a Third World president or finance minister,” Federal Reserve chairman Paul Volcker observed afterward, “international banking in the 1970s” was “like receiving a credit card in the mail—with three or four more zeros on the size of the credit line.”

发展中国家的借贷规模在当时并未得到充分认识或重视的情况下急剧膨胀。总体而言，1972年至1981年间，发展中国家的外债增加了六倍。到1981年，债务总额达到5000亿美元。资金的注入至少在几年内刺激了经济增长。到20世纪80年代初，美国九大银行已将相当于其资本250%的资金用于向发展中国家提供贷款。那些质疑债务快速增长的人被斥为脾气暴躁的老顽固。毕竟，正如美国最大银行的行长所坚称的那样，政府不可能破产。

In ways that were not very well recognized or accounted for as it was happening, developing-country borrowing exploded. Overall, between 1972 and 1981, the external debts of developing countries increased sixfold, reaching $500 billion by 1981. The infusion of money stimulated, at least for a few years, higher economic growth. By the beginning of the 1980s, the nine largest U.S. banks had committed the equivalent of 250 percent of their capital to loans to developing countries. Those who questioned the rapid buildup of debt were dismissed as grumpy old men. After all, insisted the head of America’s largest bank, governments could not go bankrupt.

墨西哥凭借石油繁荣，在借贷大国排行榜上名列前茅。到20世纪80年代初，墨西哥的债务已超过800亿美元。各大银行争相向墨西哥放贷。在这场疯狂的放贷浪潮中，一位墨西哥官员甚至被人们盛赞为“年度最佳借款人”。然而，1982年8月之后，这个头衔就无人愿意接受了。

Right at the top of the borrowing league was Mexico, boosted by its oil boom. By the early 1980s, it owed over $80 billion. Banks fell all over themselves to lend to Mexico. Amidst the feverish lending, one Mexican official was even pronounced, with great admiration, “borrower of the year.” After August 1982, however, that was a title no one would want.

借贷是如何演变成债务危机的？事后看来，破产的根源其实很简单：债务不断增长、利率不断攀升、收入不断下降。债务的迅速累积在糟糕的时机达到了顶峰——正值发达国家经济衰退，导致大多数发展中国家赖以生存的初级产品需求疲软之际。这意味着商品价格下跌，收入也随之下降。与此同时，20世纪80年代初旨在抑制发达国家通货膨胀的高利率政策，提高了发展中国家浮动利率债务的成本，加重了偿还负担。诚然，借来的钱确实投入了投资，本应产生更多收益。然而不幸的是，这些钱也流入了收益甚微的领域——昂贵的进口商品、铺张浪费、通货膨胀、资源浪费、腐败以及大量空头支票。最终，所有贷款转化为的生产性资产远低于预期。

How did the borrowing turn into the debt crisis? In retrospect, the formula for bankruptcy was very simple: growing debt, rising interest rates, and falling revenues. The rapid buildup of debt reached its peak at a bad time—just at the moment when, owing to the recession in industrial countries, demand was weakening for the primary products that made up the livelihood of most developing countries. That meant lower prices for their goods, and thus lower income. At the same time, the high interest rates of the early 1980s, aimed at counteracting the inflation in the industrial countries, raised the cost of developing countries’floating debt, increasing the repayment burden. Yes, the borrowed money went into investment, which should have been generating more income. Unfortunately, it also went into things that did not generate much of a return—expensive imports, extravagance, inflation, waste, corruption, and numbered bank accounts. As a result, there was a lot less to show for all the loans in terms of productive assets than might have been anticipated.

20世纪20年代，当人们讨论德国的债务减免问题时，卡尔文·柯立芝总统曾说：“他们不是雇人拿的钱吗？” 这样的错误绝不会重蹈覆辙。这一次，人们投入了大量精力，试图通过债务重组、债务减免、债务豁免以及将现有债务转换为新型债券或股权等方式来“解决”债务危机。否则，经济将陷入长期的困境，并可能带来高度不确定但极其严重的政治后果。因此，20世纪80年代余下的时间都用于善后工作。对于部分发展中国家而言，20世纪80年代被称为“失去的十年”——经济增长极其缓慢甚至出现负增长，考虑到人口因素，人均实际收入急剧下降。与此同时，银行纷纷减记贷款，严重削弱了自身的资产负债表。所有这一切都是野心、傲慢和鲁莽的代价。

During the 1920s, when there was some discussion about debt relief for Germany, President Calvin Coolidge said, “They hired the money, didn’t they?” That mistake was not going to be made again. This time around, vast efforts would be expended to help “solve” the debt crisis through rescheduling and repackaging the debt, write-downs and forgiveness, and conversion of existing debt into new kinds of bonds or equity. The alternative was protracted economic misery, with highly uncertain but potentially very serious political consequences. Thus the rest of the 1980s was spent on the cleanup. For parts of the developing world, the 1980s became known as the “lost decade”—a period of either very modest or negative economic growth and, when taking population into account, sharply declining per capita real income. Banks, meanwhile, wrote down their loans, greatly weakening their own balance sheets. All this was the price of ambition and hubris—and imprudence.

债务危机的持久影响主要体现在发展中国家政府与市场之间的交界地带。作为救助方案的一部分，国际货币基金组织（IMF）成为负债累累的各国政府的合作伙伴，扮演着类似国际破产管理人的角色。IMF在债务重组协议中附加了苛刻的条件，迫使各国尽快偿还债务。财政整顿。这意味着取消消耗资源的贸易保护措施，将货币贬值至合理的汇率，并限制工资增长。至关重要的是，这意味着减少赤字和财政支出。各国政府必须削减开支，停止补贴亏损企业，并将国有资产出售或转让给私营部门。为了帮助这一转型提供资金并监督其实施，世界银行设计了“结构调整贷款”，只有在受助方满足特定政策条件时才会发放贷款。紧缩取代了挥霍。

The lasting impact of the debt crisis was to fall on the frontier between government and market in the developing world. As part of the rescue packages, the International Monetary Fund became partner to the debtridden governments, a sort of international bankruptcy receiver. Imposing tough conditions in its workout deals, the IMF pushed countries to get their fiscal houses in order. That meant removing trade protections that drained resources, devaluing currencies to realistic exchange rates, and restraining wage increases. And, crucially, it meant reducing deficits and fiscal drain. Governments would have to cut spending, stop subsidizing loss-making enterprises, and sell or transfer state-owned assets to the private sector. To help finance this transition and oversee its implementation, the World Bank devised “structural adjustment loans,” which it disbursed only when recipients met certain policy conditions. Austerity replaced profligacy.

债务危机是发展中国家的重大转折点。这场危机带来了深远的教训。各国陷入如此困境，部分原因是政府部门臃肿不堪，国有企业效率低下。各国不能指望国际资本市场为庞大且缺乏纪律的政府部门提供融资。正是当时以各种理念为依据的政府扩张，才将这些国家引向了实际上的破产之路。经济体制和源于发展经济学的指导思想都必须改变，因为它们已无法实现其所承诺的经济增长。几年前还被视为异想天开、政治上不可能实现的理念，如今却占据了主导地位，新的机遇也随之涌现。财政现实别无选择。2

The debt crisis was the great turning point for the developing world. Far-reaching lessons were drawn from the entire drama. Countries had gotten into these severe straits owing in part to bloated government sectors and inefficient state-owned companies. Nations could not expect the international capital markets to finance a huge, undisciplined government sector. And it was the very expansion of government, justified by the ideas of the times, that had led these nations down the road to what in reality was bankruptcy. Both economic arrangements and the guiding ideas derived from development economics would have to be changed, for they could no longer deliver the economic growth they had promised. Ideas that had been beyond the pale and politically impossible only a few years earlier now moved to the fore, and doors opened to new people who would apply those ideas. Fiscal reality simply would not allow otherwise.2

全国冠军

The National Champions

1995年，颇具学者风范的意大利石油公司埃尼集团首席执行官弗朗哥·贝尔纳贝来到美国，在休斯顿对一群人说：“我们必须私有化。”然后他简单地补充道：“别无选择。”

When Franco Bernabé, the somewhat scholarly chief executive of the Italian oil company ENI, came to the United States in 1995, he told a group in Houston, “We have to privatize.” Then he added simply, “There is no choice.”

这真是一段漫长的历程。意大利最大的公司埃尼集团，如果不是国有企业，二战后根本不可能存在。如果没有国家资金和国家冠军企业的魄力与使命感，它永远无法凭借自身实力跻身行业翘楚，取得技术上的卓越成就，并发展成为世界十大石油公司之一。然而，上世纪四五十年代的道理，到了九十年代就不再适用了。弗朗哥·贝尔纳贝对此深信不疑。

What a long arc it had been. ENI, Italy’s largest company, would never have come into existence after World War II had it not been state owned. Without state funding and the élan and mission of the national champion, it would never have been able to elbow itself successfully into prominence and technical excellence and grow to become one of the world’s ten largest oil companies. Yet what made sense in the 1940s and 1950s no longer held true by the 1990s. Of that Franco Bernabè was sure.

贝尔纳贝的信念源于亲身经历——在埃尼集团内部以及意大利政坛的艰苦斗争中，他常常处于守势。似乎每天，他都在反复领悟同一个道理：国有企业的理想与其困境的现实之间存在着巨大的鸿沟。贝尔纳贝的父亲是一名铁路工人，他接受过经济学方面的训练。1983年加入埃尼集团之前，他已经参与了意大利最大的私营企业菲亚特的重组工作。然而，他当时对埃尼集团内部的糟糕状况却一无所知。公司当时正处于亏损状态，并且不断受到意大利各政党的压力。该公司既将其视为资金来源，也将其视为赢得人脉的奖赏。因此，该公司无法作为一个整体正常运作。

Bernabè’s conviction arose from experience—bitter struggles within ENI and the Italian political arena, in which he often found himself on the defensive. Every day, it seemed, he learned and relearned the same lesson—that there was a huge gap between the ideal of the state company and the reality of its predicament. The son of a railway worker and trained as an economist, Bernabè had already played a role in the restructuring of Italy’s largest private company, Fiat, by the time he joined ENI in 1983. He had no idea of how bad the conditions inside ENI were. The company was losing money. It was also under constant pressure from Italy’s political parties, which regarded it both as a source of funds and as a prize in terms of patronage. The company was not able to function as a coherent business.

从一开始，贝尔纳贝就试图让公司摆脱政治影响。但当他着手重组这家亏损的化工企业时，却遭到各部委、议会委员会、部长和党内官员的猛烈攻击。这对他来说是一个转折点。“从那时起，”他说，“我对政治干预深恶痛绝，并开始思考如何让埃尼集团摆脱公共部门的束缚。”他悄悄地开始构思私有化方案。但随后，那些希望维持现状的政客和公司内部人士察觉到了他的努力。他们对他发动了新的攻击；他们想要他的命。意大利“清白之手”调查揭露了普遍存在的腐败，导致众多政府官员和商人锒铛入狱，贝尔纳贝才得以幸免。被投入监狱的人员中包括埃尼集团的20名高级管理人员，其中包括公司董事长，后者在狱中自杀身亡。“清白之手”运动在埃尼集团内部造成了权力真空。 1992年，贝尔纳贝被任命为总经理兼首席执行官，他很快意识到这家亏损公司已时日无多。当年，公司几乎无法支付员工工资。贝尔纳贝随即着手对公司进行大刀阔斧的重组，出售低效资产，更换管理层，并将公司重心从迎合政客利益转移到为股东创造价值——尽管当时唯一的股东是国家。他还启动了一项私有化计划。1995年末，在他访问美国几个月后，埃尼集团的股票首次在米兰、纽约和伦敦证券交易所上市。

From the outset, Bernabé tried to free the company from political influence. But when he began to work on the reorganization of the lossmaking chemical business, he found himself subjected to a vicious assault from ministries, parliamentary commissions, ministers, and party officials. That was the turning point for him. “From then on,” he said, “I felt a violent hatred for political interference, and I began to think of a way of liberating ENI from the public sector.” He quietly started to sketch out a concept for privatization. But then politicians and people in the company who wanted things to stay just the same got wind of his efforts. They unleashed a new war against him; they wanted his head. He was saved in part by the “Clean Hands” investigation into Italy’s pervasive corruption that led to the jailing of numerous government officials and businessmen. Among those thrown into prison were twenty senior managers from ENI, including the company’s chairman, who committed suicide while in jail. The Clean Hands campaign created a vacuum within ENI. Appointed managing director and CEO in 1992, Bernabé quickly realized that time was running out for the lossmaking company. That year, it nearly failed to meet its payroll. Bernabè now set about ferociously restructuring the company, selling off unproductive assets, changing the management, and focusing the company not on meeting the interests of politicians but on creating value for shareholders—although at that time the only shareholder was the state. He also initiated a plan for a privatization. Late in 1995, several months after his visit to the United States, ENI shares were offered, for the first time, on the Milan, New York, and London exchanges.

埃尼集团曾是世界上最著名的国有企业之一。尽管它深受意大利政治文化的影响，但其困境和转型仍然以一种尤为戏剧性的方式展现了此类企业地位的变迁。国有企业的诞生是为了实现崇高而重要的目标——确保国家目标的实现，维护国家主权并摆脱外国控制，促进经济增长，遏制私人垄断，并确保国家资源服务于人民的利益。它们还肩负着吸引投资和促进技术发展的重任。然而，国有企业面临的困境早在20世纪70年代就已开始显现，事实上，70年代危机的最大受害者之一便是人们对国有企业的信心。它们曾经的标志性特征——企业文化、运营模式、自豪感和使命感、吸引人才和技术的能力——如今都已黯然失色。协调变成了笨拙的控制；资源分配变成了扭曲；政府税收和收入变成了补贴，反而成了经济增长的障碍。政治干预成了顽疾。他们缺乏灵活性和效率；被迫错配资源；最终变成了对国家财政的消耗日益加剧。公共企业如今被视为各国面临整体经济危机的重要推手。

ENI had been one of the most famous state-owned companies in the world. Although it was uniquely shaped by Italy’s political culture, its travails and transformation nevertheless demonstrated in a particularly dramatic form how the position of such enterprises had changed. State companies had come into existence to meet worthy and important ambitions—to secure national objectives, to assert sovereignty and escape foreign domination, to fuel economic growth, to constrain private monopoly, and to ensure that the nation’s resources served the interests of the people. They were also to marshal investment and promote technical development. But the difficulties for state companies had already begun to emerge in the 1970s, and indeed, one of the great losers from the crisis of the 1970s was confidence in state-owned companies. The shine of their hallmarks—their corporate cultures, their modes of operation, their pride and sense of mission, their ability to attract skills and mobilize technology—now faded. Coordination had turned into unwieldy control; allocation had turned into distortion; government taxes and revenues had turned into subsidies and obstacles to growth.
