In the classic autarkic system, control of information was as important as control over licenses, currency, and investment.

但随着电话服务、传真机和计算机的普及（当然，还有旅行的增加），信息流动更加自由，整个经济体系也变得更加透明。信息技术发展迅猛，覆盖面广，各国政府已难以跟上。信息在全球范围内传播，人们可以进行比较和对比；可以即时交换知识；可以据此采取行动。无论身处何地，投资者都能做出更加明智的决策。只需访问路透社终端或彭博终端，就能获得十年前难以想象的广度和深度的信息——而且无需任何延迟。在那些曾经信息壁垒森严的国家，人们现在也能了解各种选择和方案。

But once information began to flow more freely with improved and less expensive phone service, fax machines, and computerization (and, of course, with increased travel), entire economic systems became more transparent. With the speed and reach of new information technology, governments can no longer keep up. As information flies around the world, people can compare and contrast; they can trade knowledge instantaneously; they can act upon it. Investors can make far more informed decisions no matter where they sit. Access to a Reuters terminal or a Bloomberg machine provides a range and depth of information hardly imaginable ten years ago—and without a moment’s delay. Inside countries where the walls had been high, people can now learn about alternatives and choices.

信息和通信革命的影响才刚刚开始显现。但当企业建立虚拟总部，硅谷和班加罗尔的软件设计师、西伯利亚和休斯顿的石油地质学家、底特律和科隆的汽车设计师通过计算机协同工作时，经济格局已截然不同。国家控制的有效性以及民族国家的边界​​正在被削弱。当市场走向全球时，各国经济管理者便会变得目光短浅。因此，政府知识的概念——几十年来规划者和监管者所构建的——正遭受挑战。政府可能并不像它自认为的那样了解一切，也可能无法有效地利用其已知的信息。其结果是政府权力受到更多限制。随着市场体系掌控商品供应、降低价格、抑制通货膨胀和提高全民生活水平，政治冲动如今必须服从于经济的必然性。但市场在智力上的胜利也赋予了市场一系列新的职责和义务，引发了关于市场究竟掌握多少信息、如何有效利用信息以及可能出现何种严重偏差的新问题。因为全球市场也意味着全球风险。正如旅行的激增意味着疾病传播速度加快一样，金融一体化也意味着传染病可以在市场间迅速蔓延。

The impact of the information and telecommunications revolution is only beginning to be felt. But it is a very different kind of economy when companies establish virtual headquarters and software designers in Silicon Valley and Bangalore, or oil geologists in Siberia and Houston, or auto designers in Detroit and Cologne, function via computer as one team. The effectiveness of state control and the very borders of the nation-state are being eroded. Nations’s economic managers become parochial when the market becomes universal. Thus the notion of government knowledge, as decades of planners and regulators had developed it, has come under siege. Government may not know as much as it thought it knew—and may not be able to act effectively on what it does know. The result is increased limits on governments. Political impulses are now subject to economic imperatives as market systems take control of delivering goods, lowering prices, decreasing inflation, and improving universal living standards. But the intellectual victory of the marketplace has also transferred a new set of duties and responsibilities to the market, leading to new questions about just what and how much the market knows and how effectively it will be used—and how badly awry things could go. For global markets also mean global risks. Just as vastly increased travel means that diseases can be transported more quickly, so financial integration means that contagion can pass rapidly among markets.

全球经济格局中角色剧变的余波尚未完全平息。然而，人们似乎对政府掌握的信息以及如何运用这些信息更加谦逊。对瓦莱里·吉斯卡尔·德斯坦而言，从国家控制到市场控制的转变可以用面包这样简单的东西来象征。20世纪60年代末，他担任法国财政部副部长，负责监督基本商品价格管制的实施。“我手下有一支庞大的公务员队伍，”他回忆道，“他们的任务是检查法国的每一家面包店，确保法棍的价格符合规定。”成千上万的官员奔赴各个城市，与每个城镇乡村的面包师争论不休。“这简直是胡闹，”吉斯卡尔总结道，“我意识到这套体系行不通了。”11

The dust has yet to clear from this very dramatic reversal of roles in what has become a global economy. Yet there appears to be greater modesty about government knowledge and what government ought to do with the knowledge it does have. For Valéry Giscard d’Estaing, the shift from state control to market control was symbolized by something as simple as bread. As France’s junior minister of finance in the late 1960s, he oversaw the implementation of price controls for basic goods. “I had an army of civil servants,” he recalled, “whose job was to inspect every bakery in France and make sure the price of a baguette followed the guidelines.” Thousands of officials fanned out across the cities to bicker and argue with the bakers in every town and village. “This was nonsense,” Giscard concluded. “I realized the system could not go on.”11

第六章

CHAPTER 6

东亚经济奇迹真的存在吗？马来西亚总理马哈蒂尔·穆罕默德对此应该很有发言权。毕竟，自上世纪80年代中期以来，他领导的马来西亚经济年增长率一直保持在6%或以上。在他准备讨论这个问题的当天，他略显拘谨地坐在吉隆坡办公室一张巨大的柚木办公桌后，迎接来访者。总理身着朴素的传统马来服饰，胸前佩戴着一枚小巧的正式胸牌，上面写着“马哈蒂尔”。他的所有助手也都佩戴着各自的胸牌。

IS THERE TRULY such a thing as the East Asia economic miracle? Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia would have an informed view. After all, since the mid-1980s, the country over which he presides had been growing at an annual rate of 6 percent or more. On the day he was to discuss this matter, he welcomed the visitors to his office in Kuala Lumpur a bit stiffly from behind an enormous desk of pristine teak. The prime minister was clothed simply, in traditional Malay dress. He also wore, at chest level, a small, formal tag that read MAHATHIR. All of his aides sported their own tags.

马哈蒂尔的人脉显然很广；在他身旁的一张桌子上摆放着四块屏幕，不时闪烁。第一块用于视频会议；第二块连接着互联网；第三块持续播放路透社的新闻；第四块则提供马来西亚各地最新动态。左侧的窗台上摆放着马来西亚人设计制造的飞机模型。

Mahathir was definitely well connected; on a separate table at his side sat four screens, which blinked intermittently. The first served for video conferencing; the second was linked to the Internet; the third displayed a continuous news feed from Reuters; and the fourth provided up-to-the-hour information on developments across Malaysia. To the left, models of airplanes designed and built by Malaysians were displayed on a windowsill.

吉隆坡市中心（在亚洲通常被称为KL）一片繁荣景象，到处都是巨大的起重机和建筑设备。在街头，身着牛仔裤和T恤的年轻人——马来人、华人、印度人——骑着摩托车穿梭在拥挤的街道上，街道上挤满了日本车、奔驰以及随处可见的马来西亚国民车宝腾。文化交融的景象在两旁形成鲜明对比：一边是穿着迷你裙和高跟鞋的女性，另一边是身着端庄伊斯兰服饰的女性。两座令人叹为观止的摩天大楼拔地而起，直插云霄。它们属于马来西亚国家石油公司（Petronas），是世界上最高的办公楼，超过了纽约的世界贸易中心和芝加哥的西尔斯大厦。它们也是亚洲经济增长的非凡建筑象征。这场持续而又惊人的变革，甚至连世界银行都称之为奇迹。这场奇迹席卷了整个地区，马来西亚也随之而来，彻底改变了这个曾经以种植园经济为主的国家。“直到1960年，”马哈蒂尔说，“我们才赶上海地的人均收入水平”——海地是西半球最贫穷的国家。到了20世纪90年代末，马来西亚已发展成为一个科技日新月异的社会，目标是在2020年之前，甚至更早，赶上西方工业化国家。仅仅用了三十年时间，这个曾经的橡胶殖民地就摇身一变，成为世界最大的半导体生产国之一。

Outside, downtown Kuala Lumpur—KL, as it is known in Asia—was a boom city, with a forest of gigantic cranes and construction equipment. At street level, youths—Malay, Chinese, and Indian—clad in jeans and T-shirts zoomed on motorbikes through streets jammed with Japanese cars, Mercédeses, and the ubiquitous Proton, Malaysia’s national car. The cultural mix was captured by the stark contrast of women in miniskirts and high heels next to women clad head to toe in demure Islamic dress. Twin office towers, astonishingly tall, tapered far up into the sky. Belonging to the state oil company, Petronas, they are the world’s tallest office buildings, surpassing the World Trade Center in New York and Chicago’s Sears Tower. They are also an extraordinary architectural symbol of an Asian economic growth so sustained and so dramatic that even the World Bank called it a miracle. Embracing Malaysia in its southward sweep through the region, this miracle had transformed what was a plantation economy. “It was only in 1960,” Mahathir said, “that we managed to catch up with the per capita income of Haiti”—the poorest nation in the Western Hemisphere. In the late 1990s, Malaysia is an increasingly technologically advanced society that aims to pull even with the industrial West by 2020, if not before. It took just thirty years to turn the former rubber colony into one of the world’s largest manufacturers of semiconductors.

当李光耀卸任新加坡的日常领导职务后，马哈蒂尔脱颖而出，成为亚洲经济增长领域最雄辩、最自信、最直言不讳的领导人。他驳斥了那些质疑亚洲经济持续发展的人，并大力宣扬“新亚洲”的崛起，这个新亚洲将“向东看”，不再追随西方。但与该地区的许多其他人一样，他并不喜欢“奇迹”这个词。他认为这个词似乎忽略了辛勤工作和牺牲，也掩盖了市场规模和结构、历史、文化以及——对马哈蒂尔而言至关重要的——民族主义方面的巨大差异。“亚洲没有奇迹，”他抗议道，“这只是一个理念的实现，一个关于如何管理经济体系的理念。它是做出正确的选择，是政治和经济手段的正确结合。”

When Lee Kuan Yew gave up day-to-day leadership of Singapore, Mahathir emerged as the most articulate, assertive, and outspoken leader of Asian economic growth. He disparaged those who expressed doubts about the sustainability of Asia’s economic march, and he forcefully proclaimed the emergence of a “new Asia” that will “look east” and no longer follow the West. But like many others in the region, he did not particularly like the word miracle. It seemed to dismiss hard work and sacrifice, and glossed over enormous differences of market size and structure, history, culture, and—what was very important to Mahathir—nationalism. “There is no Asian miracle,” he protested. “It is just the realization of an idea, an idea of how to manage an economic system. It is making the right choices, the right mixture of political and economic methods.”

在政府宫殿的专属区域，马哈蒂尔指定的继任者、副总理安瓦尔·易卜拉欣详细阐述道：“从某种意义上说，我们的成功是惊人的。各阶层人士获得收入和财富的机会以及开放程度的提高，在现代历史上是前所未有的。但我们不喜欢‘奇迹’这个词。它太夸张，太傲慢了。亚洲的成功归功于社会、健康、教育和文化。”

In his own wing of the government palace, Mahathir’s designated successor, Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim, elaborated. “Our success is spectacular in some way,” he said. “The increase in openness and the opportunity for income and wealth among all classes are unprecedented in modern history. But we do not like the word miracle. It is too grand—too arrogant. Success in Asia has happened because of the society, health, education, and culture.”

无论如何称呼，东亚都发生了一件非同寻常的事情——经济增长的强度和速度几乎在经济史上前所未有。正如世界银行所言，这一“奇迹的本质”在于亚洲实现了经济学中最接近“点石成金”的目标——“公平的快速增长”。正是这一点将亚洲推向了世界前沿，也正是因为如此，亚洲奇迹这颗冉冉升起的新星取代了马克思主义和中央计划经济这颗黯淡的明星，成为人们研究和效仿的典范。1997年下半年席卷亚洲的金融危机震惊了整个地区，并引发了人们对该地区未来前景的根本性质疑。然而，亚洲所取得的成就非同凡响，其内在的活力和适应能力表明，该地区正进入一个调整期，而非脱轨期。

Whatever it is called, something very remarkable has unfolded in East Asia—growth at an intensity and rapidity nearly unprecedented in economic history. The “essence of the miracle,” as the World Bank put it, was Asia’s attainment of the closest thing that economics has to the philosopher’s stone—“rapid growth with equity.” It is this that has pushed Asia to the forefront, and it is why the rising star of the Asia miracle has replaced the setting star of Marxism and central planning as the model to study—and to seek to emulate. The financial crisis that hit Asia in the second half of 1997 stunned the region and raised fundamental questions about the area’s future prospects. Yet what has been accomplished is extraordinary, and the underlying vibrancy and adaptability suggest that the region is entering a period of readjustment, not derailment.

这些国家是如何取得如今成就的？马哈蒂尔曾用一句话来形容马来西亚的案例，他称之为“制胜秘诀”。但这个秘诀究竟是什么？政府与市场是如何结合的？这些问题引发了激烈的辩论，有时甚至演变成尖锐的争论。有人认为，秘诀在于政府的指导——一种……一群精英官僚无休止地挑选赢家并发号施令。他们不断通过管理贸易壁垒、信贷、投资和竞争进行干预。他们在国际上推行激烈的竞争，在国内则奉行保护主义。另一些人则反驳说，更重要的是，政府奉行“市场友好型”政策，从而确保了宏观经济基本面的正确性：高储蓄率、低通货膨胀、强烈的出口导向以及对教育的高度重视——尤其是针​​对工业化所需不断变化的技术技能而制定的教育。此外，还有一种坚定不移的信念，即事关重大的不是财富分配，而是在面对激进共产主义的威胁时能否生存下去。

How have these countries achieved what they have? Mahathir offered a phrase to describe the case of Malaysia. He called it “the winning formula.” But exactly what was the formula? What was the mixture of government and marketplace? These questions are the subject of vigorous and sometimes acid debate. Some argue that the secret was the guiding hand of the government—an elite cadre of bureaucrats who endlessly engaged in picking winners and calling the shots. They continually intervened through the management of trade barriers, credit, investment, and competition. They promoted aggressive competition internationally and detailed protectionism at home. Others reply that far more important was the fact that governments were “market-friendly” and thus ensured that the macrofundamentals were right: high savings rates, low inflation, a strong orientation to exports, and high commitment to education—especially education geared to the changing technical skills required by industrialization. Add to all that consistency and persistence, supported by the deep conviction that what was at stake was not distribution but, in the starkest terms, survival in the face of militant communism.

是政府指导还是市场作用？答案显而易见，两者兼而有之。亚洲的成功源于政府干预与市场力量的平衡，尽管各地情况不尽相同，但二者依然各具特色。市场与国家——企业与政府——各自发挥着作用，在协调一致、目标明确的背景下，在一种被称为“进取精神”的驱动下，共同发展。这种平衡始于日本，并不断发展演变。其共同要素以不同的形式呈现，以适应不同国家的需求，这些国家涵盖了从工业城邦到农业巨头，从文化单一的社会到种族和宗教多元的社会。此外，还有一些国家从一开始就倾向于市场而非政府干预。

Was it government guidance or was it the market? The unambiguous answer is both. Asia’s success has been realized through a balance of government intervention and market forces that, for all their local varieties, remains both distinctive and different. Market and state—business and government—each played its role, against a backdrop of coordination and common purpose, motivated by a drive to work that has been called “a hungry spirit.” From its start in Japan, the balance evolved and adapted. Its common elements found separate expressions to fit the perceived needs of countries that ranged from industrial city-states to agricultural giants, from culturally homogeneous societies to those that are ethnically and religiously mixed. There were also some countries that from the beginning were less apt to use government intervention than to go with the market.

这些国家共同的特点之一是坚定地选择通过出口来发展国内经济，从而投身于激烈的国际竞争。然而，尽管该地区各国在竞争中“脱颖而出”，但也采取了“内护”措施，在不同程度上将国内经济与外国竞争隔离开来。整个体系在不同程度上建立在政治和经济生活的监管或强制之上。大多数亚洲成功案例都曾经历过独裁、威权主义，或者至少是受监管的政治和事实上的一党制。但与此同时，它们围绕着生存的必要性和增长带来的显著回报——也就是所谓的共享增长——达成了共识，从而促进了社会平等。大多数亚洲政府确实进行过干预——有时干预力度相当大。但它们的目的是影响市场走向，而不是取代或破坏市场。因此，亚洲的悖论在于，在许多方面，正是政府的知识，通过政治结构加以强化，才促成了“有利于市场的结果”。

Chief among the common threads was a resolute choice to grow the domestic economy by harnessing it to exports—and thus committing to the rigors of international competition. Yet while the countries of the region have “competed out,” they have also “protected in”—insulating their domestic economies, to one degree or another, from foreign competition. The entire edifice was built, to varying degrees, on regulation or coercion, in political as well as economic life. Most of the Asian success stories involved, at some point, dictatorship, authoritarianism, or at least regulated politics and a de facto one-party system. Yet at the same time, they built a consensus around the imperative of survival and the visible returns of growth—indeed, what has been called shared growth—which has resulted in growing equality. Most Asian governments did intervene—sometimes quite drastically. But they did so to influence the shape of market outcomes, not to replace or roll back markets. The paradox of Asia, then, was that in many ways it was government knowledge, enforced by political structures, that helped bring about “market-friendly outcomes.”

亚洲奇迹背后的政府与市场的故事，至今仍可概括为一个概念：“国家有限公司”。将国家比作一家公司——这一比喻常被该地区的领导人所采用——生动地展现了其对贸易的重视、对生产力的追求以及对严格组织结构的运用。但更重要的是，这些“国家有限公司”……享有极高的共同目标，这在业内是其他公司难以企及的：一种民族主义的驱动力，这种驱动力是由对殖民、征服、分裂、内战、颠覆或战争的切身记忆塑造而成的。

The story of government and market that underlies the Asia miracle could still be summed up in one concept: “Countries, Inc.” The analogy of the country as a firm—often employed by the region’s leaders—keenly evoked the orientation toward trade, the quest for productivity, and the recourse to regimented organization. But more, these Countries, Inc. have enjoyed a degree of common purpose few firms can match: a nationalistic drive, molded by living memories of colonization, conquest, secession, civil conflict, subversion, or war.

20世纪90年代末，随着经济发展，国家对市场的“治理”逐渐式微，市场作为管理和监管力量的重要性日益凸显。与此同时，人们也日益担忧，当这些国家的收入水平和开放程度达到一定程度后，快速经济增长的模式可能不再奏效。1997年的货币危机更是将这种担忧推到了风口浪尖。

In the late 1990s, as economic development proceeds, a shift is taking place away from the state’s “governance” of the market and toward greater reliance on the market as manager and regulator. At the same time, there is growing anxiety, even fear, that the formula for fast economic growth no longer works when these countries reach a certain level of income and openness. And indeed, the currency crisis of 1997 brought that apprehension to the fore.

各地文化和历史使每个“国家公司”都独具特色。但所有国家都以一个共同的模式为参照：日本，该地区第一个达到——甚至可以说超越——西方工业成就的国家。1

Local cultures and histories have made each Country, Inc. distinct. But all of the nations shared a reference to a common model: Japan, the first in the region to attain—and, arguably, surpass—the industrial achievements of the West.1

日本：“我要实现收入翻番”

Japan: “I’ll Go for Income Doubling”

1945年，日本满目疮痍，战败后颜面尽失。领导人被捕，声名狼藉；工业衰败；三分之一的城市房屋化为灰烬和瓦砾；整个国家仅能勉强维持生存。人民士气低落，茫然无措，生活支离破碎。食物匮乏，饥寒交迫。男孩们站在铁轨旁，蹦蹦跳跳，恳求美国士兵从驶过的火车上扔给他们糖果。

In 1945, Japan was a devastated nation, humiliated by absolute defeat. Its leaders under arrest and discredited, its industry in ruins, a third of its urban housing nothing more than ashes and rubble, the country existed at a bare subsistence level. Its people were demoralized and adrift, their lives torn apart. There was hardly anything to eat. Boys stood by railway lines jumping up and down, begging American soldiers to toss them candy bars from the passing trains.

与美国力量的对抗令日本人感到无比震撼。战争期间，B-29轰炸机成群结队地掠过日本上空，而最终结束战争的两颗原子弹更是带来了毁灭性的打击，这让他们深刻体会到美国在科技上的绝对优势。随后的占领让他们直面美国的生活水平。他们亲眼目睹了自己梦寐以求的生活。然而，现实似乎遥不可及。真的是这样吗？《来吧，来吧，大家》（Come, Come, Everybody）是日本广播电台英语对话节目的主题曲，这首曲子在街头巷尾回荡，仿佛在召唤着听众走向未来。

The confrontation with American power had overwhelmed the Japanese. The vast swarms of B-29’s overhead during the war and the total devastation of the two atomic bombs that ended it had driven home the fact of superior American technological prowess. The occupation that followed brought them face-to-face with the American standard of living. They could see with their own eyes what they might dream of attaining. Yet the reality seemed far beyond their grasp. Or was it? “Come, Come, Everybody” was the theme song of Japanese radio’s English-conversation program, and the tune, repeated in the streets, became a counterpoint, enticing listeners into the future.

战后最初几年极其艰难，社会动荡不安，物资长期短缺，通货膨胀居高不下。到了20世纪40年代末，受经济负担和冷战形势的双重压力，美国占领当局采取了所谓的“逆转策略”，开始致力于促进日本经济复苏。为此，美国实施了道奇计划，该计划在很大程度上抑制了通货膨胀。1950年爆发的朝鲜战争使日本成为驻韩美军的后勤基地，并刺激了出口繁荣。20世纪50年代初是日本经济复苏的开端。1952年畅销书《总经理》生动地描绘了这段历史，书中主人公在一家公司担任总经理，最终成功转型为日本的金融巨头。他用一辆战前生产的达特桑换了一辆福特，然后攒够了钱买了一辆林肯，开着它在明治神宫的外苑里兜风，一边喊着：“轻如鸿毛！轻如鸿毛！简直就像在云端飞翔！”当时谁也想不到，有一天，一辆日本汽车会比底特律的汽车更受欢迎，更能象征身份地位。

The first several years after the war were excruciatingly hard, dominated by vast dislocations, chronic shortages, and high inflation. By the end of the 1940s, the U.S. occupation—impelled by both the cost burden and the emerging cold war—made what was known as the “reverse course” and began to focus on promoting Japanese economic recovery. As part of that, it imposed the Dodge Plan, which did much to extinguish inflation. The Korean War, beginning in 1950, turned Japan into a supply base for the American forces on the Korean peninsula and stimulated an export boom. The early 1950s were the beginning of recovery. Those years were immortalized in the 1952 best-seller The General Manager, whose hero trades in his prewar Datsun for a Ford and then earns enough to buy a Lincoln, which he drives around the outer garden of the Meiji shrine, shouting, “Light as a feather! Light as a feather! It’s absolutely like flying above the clouds.” No one could possibly think at the time that a Japanese automobile would one day be more desired, and a greater status symbol, than a car from Detroit.

直到20世纪50年代中期，日本才从经济复苏走向持续增长，经济增长也成为国家的核心目标。1960年，池田勇人即将从通商产业大臣升任首相时，有人问他有什么打算。“这不都是经济政策的问题吗？”他回答说，“我要实现国民收入翻番。”而日本也确实朝着这个目标迈进。到了1964年，在东京奥运会开幕前夕，池田可以自豪地宣布：“经过战后19年的快速增长，日本的国民收入正在接近西欧水平；我们正努力在战后20年内完成战前80年都未能完成的事情。”这可以从生活水平的提高来衡量。在20世纪60年代，消费者开始拥有“三大家电”——电视、洗衣机和冰箱。到了 20 世纪 70 年代，他们又转向了“三 C”——汽车、彩色电视和空调。2

It was only in the mid-1950s that Japan rose from recovery into sustained economic growth, which became the central national objective. In 1960, when Hayato Ikeda was about to move from being minister of international trade and industry to prime minister, he was asked what he would do. “Isn’t it all a matter of economic policy?” he replied. “I’ll go for income doubling.” And that is what Japan was doing. By 1964, on the eve of welcoming the Olympics to Tokyo, Ikeda could proudly declare, “With the 19 postwar years of rapid growth, Japan’s national income is approaching the Western European level; we are attempting to do in 20 postwar years what we were unable to do in the 80 years before the war.” This could be measured in the standard of living. In the 1960s, consumers were acquiring the “three sacred treasures”—television, washing machine, and refrigerator. In the 1970s they moved on to the “three C’s”—car, color television, and air conditioner.2

20世纪70年代的能源危机爆发时，日本人一度担心一切都结束了。他们认为，依赖廉价石油的经济增长模式无法继续下去。然而，尽管当时一片悲观，但能源危机最终证明只是日本经济的暂时挫折。到了20世纪80年代初，凭借快速的技术转型——从能源密集型经济向“知识密集型经济”转型——以及对效率的重新重视，日本经济已经强劲反弹。日本一跃成为经济超级大国。到20世纪80年代末，东京证券交易所的市值与纽约证券交易所持平，全球十大银行中有八家是日本银行。据说，位于东京市中心皇宫附近的房地产价值甚至超过了整个美国西部地区。站在帝国酒店的大堂里，看着一群群西方和日本商人互相走近、鞠躬、交换名片，你会感觉自己置身于世界经济的集市，全球商业的枢纽。

When the energy disruptions of the 1970s hit, the Japanese feared that the game was over. Their growth, based on cheap oil, could not continue, they thought. Yet despite the pessimism at the time, the energy crises proved to be only a temporary setback for Japan. By the early 1980s, its economy was already rebounding strongly, on the basis of rapid technological adjustments—moving from an energy-intensive economy to a “knowledge-intensive economy”—and a new emphasis on efficiency. Japan was now an economic superpower. By the end of the 1980s, the capitalization of the Tokyo Stock Exchange was equal to that of the New York Stock Exchange, and of the world’s ten biggest banks, eight were Japanese. The real estate in the area of the Imperial Palace, in central Tokyo, was said to have a higher value than the entire western United States. To stand in the lobby of the Imperial Hotel and watch groups of Western and Japanese businessmen approach each other and bow and exchange business cards was to feel that one was in the agora of the world economy, the very pivot point of global commerce.

日元走强的推动下，日本掀起了一股疯狂的收购热潮，不仅收购了众多公司，还购入了各种各样的“战利品”——法国的葡萄园、一些世界名画、纽约的洛克菲勒中心和埃克森大厦，以及好莱坞五大电影制片厂中的两家。欧美企业和商业战略家们纷纷试图探寻日本商业成功的秘诀，以便复制其成功模式；仿佛预示着未来，墨西哥总统特意将自己的孩子送往墨西哥城的日本学校就读。

Buoyed by a strong yen, Japan went on an enormous shopping spree, buying not only companies but trophies of all sorts—vineyards in France, some of the world’s most famous paintings, Rockefeller Center and the Exxon building in New York, and two of the five major film studios in Hollywood. American and European companies and business strategists sought to divine the secret of Japanese commercial success in order to replicate it; and as if indicating the future, the president of Mexico made a point of sending his children to the Japanese school in Mexico City.

日本战后成功的因素有很多。二战前，日本已经是一个相对发达的国家。美国的占领也起到了作用。推行土地改革，瓦解了财阀——即大型产业/金融集团。财阀之后是财团，即银行和工业企业组成的集团，但集团之间的联系不如财阀紧密，这为像索尼联合创始人盛田昭夫这样的企业家提供了空间，使他们能够将自己的小型作坊发展成为充满活力的全球性公司。基本面有利：日本拥有庞大且受过良好教育的劳动力、低通货膨胀率和极高的储蓄率。美国的实力证明了技术的核心地位，日本企业开始加速从美国和欧洲获取和吸收技术。1956年，盛田昭夫在索尼的合伙人井深大在一次由美国国务院资助的考察访问中，在西屋公司发现了晶体管，索尼迅速获得了晶体管的专利权。各公司将持续改进产品质量作为竞争优势，并投资于规模化生产的不断扩大，以赢得市场份额。这一切都建立在以下价值观之上：令人难以置信的职业道德、对公司极其强烈的认同感、共同的民族认同感（以及对国家岌岌可危的处境的认同感）、渴望过上更好的生活——以及对战败、战后艰难岁月、占领和随之而来的屈辱的深刻记忆。

There were many elements in Japan’s postwar success. It was already a relatively developed country before World War II. The U.S. occupation implemented land reform and broke up the zaibatsu, the great industrial/ financial combinations. The zaibatsu were succeeded by keiretsu, groupings of banks and industrial companies, but the links were less tight, and there was room for entrepreneurs like Akio Morita, the cofounder of Sony, to turn their backroom workshops into dynamic global companies. The fundamentals were right: The country had a large and educated workforce, low inflation, and a very high savings rate. American power had demonstrated the centrality of technology, and Japanese companies set out on a forced-pace campaign to obtain and absorb technology from America and Europe. Masaru Ibuka, Morita’s partner at Sony, came across the transistor at Westinghouse in 1956 while on a State Department-sponsored tour, and Sony promptly acquired the rights. Firms sought continuing quality improvement as a competitive weapon and invested in ever-greater scale in mass production in order to win market share. All this was sustained on values that included an incredible work ethic, an extraordinarily intense identification with the firm, a shared sense of national identity (and of the country’s precarious position), a desire to live better—and the searing memory of the defeat, the harsh postwar years, with the occupation and the humiliation that went with it.

另一个至关重要的因素是日本致力于通过出口实现增长。20世纪50年代初，日本国内就应采取何种战略展开了激烈的辩论——国际贸易主义与内向型“发展主义”之争，自由主义与中央计划经济之争。最终，国际贸易主义胜出，日本对世界经济进行了大胆的押注，并获得了丰厚的回报。日本从日益开放的国际贸易体系中获益匪浅，而这一体系正是由美国主导塑造的。直到20世纪70年代初，日本的经济实力一直被忽视，这也对日本的发展起到了推波助澜的作用。在美国和欧洲，日本并非被视为竞争对手，而是被视为廉价低质商品的来源地。几乎没有人记得，在两次世界大战期间，日本是如何有效地从英国手中夺取亚洲出口市场的。此外，日本的贸易保护主义政策也被忽视了。作为出口国，日本逐步提升了产品链：从纺织品和简单的制造业产品，到船舶和钢铁，再到复杂的机械产品、电子产品和高科技产品。

One other factor was absolutely central, and that was Japan’s commitmentto exporting its way to growth. In the early 1950s, there was a vigorous debate in Japan over what kind of strategy to follow—what was called international tradism versus inward-looking “developmentalism”: liberalism versus central planning. International tradism won out, with the result that Japan made a huge bet on the world economy, and one that paid off handsomely. Japan benefited enormously—and very consciously—from the increasingly open international trading system that America took the lead in shaping. Japan was helped by its being ignored as an economic force until the early 1970s. In the United States and Europe, it was regarded not as a competitor but as a source of cheap, low-quality goods. Hardly anyone recalled how effectively it had captured export markets in Asia from the British in the interwar years. And its protectionist policies were also overlooked. As an exporter, Japan moved up the product chain: from textiles and simple manufactures to ships and steel to complex mechanical goods, electronics, and high technology.

铁三角：“1955 年体系”

The Iron Triangle: “The 1955 System”

这一切都根植于一个以政府与企业合作为特征的市场体系之中。该体系实现了经济增长和生活水平提升的目标，尽管日本企业之间竞争激烈，但最终却形成了一个被称为“日本公司”的体系。在这个体系中，政府官员常常通过监管以及某种更难以言喻但却同样强大的手段——“行政指导”——发挥主导作用。一些日本人最近将其描述为……1940年代体系——二战前夕建立的体系的延续，在这个体系中，官僚机构和企业紧密合作以维持战时经济的运转，但决定性权力仍然掌握在官僚机构手中。二战后，官僚机构的地位更加巩固。但更准确的说法应该是1955年体系。那一年标志着自民党开始崛起，官僚、商人和政客组成的“铁三角”也正式确立。

All of this was embedded in a market system that was characterized by a particular government-corporate collaboration. It achieved growth and standard of living objectives that, despite the often intense competition among Japanese firms, added up to a system that came to be known as Japan, Inc. It was one in which government bureaucrats often played a dominating role through regulation and something more ineffable but nevertheless potent: “administrative guidance.” Some Japanese have recently described this as the 1940s System—a continuation of the system that was established on the eve of World War II, in which bureaucracies and companies worked closely together in order to operate a war economy but in which decisive power lay with the bureaucracies. After World War II, the bureaucracies moved into an even more ascendant position. But it is more relevant to describe it as the 1955 System. That year marked the beginning of the Liberal Democratic Party’s ascendancy and the clear establishment of the “iron triangle” of bureaucrats, businessmen, and politicians.

在日本体制下，政府与企业之间这种紧密的协调被视为理所当然，而日本当时岌岌可危的地位更强化了这种协调。正如一位学者所言，官僚和许多企业领导人“将政府干预产业事务视为经济政策的自然组成部分”。产业监管具有战略意义；它“与促进产业发展密不可分”。企业必须在国内市场强大才能在海外竞争，而日本政府认为促进海外竞争与严格监管国内市场之间并不矛盾。

In the Japanese system, this tight coordination between government and business was accepted as the natural order and was reinforced by the precariousness of Japan’s position. In the words of one scholar, both bureaucrats and many business leaders “viewed government intervention in industrial affairs as a natural component of economic policy.” Regulation of industry was strategic; it was “not considered distinct from the promotion of industry.” Firms had to be strong at home in order to compete abroad, and the Japanese government saw no contradiction between promoting overseas competition and strongly regimenting the domestic market.

这套体系旨在扶持生产者而非消费者，因此消费价格居高不下。这是确保供应安全和企业持续健康发展所必须付出的代价。管理这套经济体系需要付出巨大的努力，并且依赖于一支技能娴熟且不受政治干预的官僚机构。整套经济管理机制被称为“供求调节” 。

This system was meant to support producers, not consumers, and consumer prices were high. Such was the cost of ensuring security of supply and the continued health of business. The efforts required to manage this economic system were complex, and depended on a skilled and politically insulated bureaucracy. The whole apparatus of economic management was known as jukyu chosei—“supply-and-demand adjustment.”

十久战略的核心是一个实体——一个统筹国内外产业战略的强大机构：通商产业省。在战后的大部分时期，它都是日本非计划经济的指挥中心。它更为人熟知的名称是其缩写——通商产业省（MITI）。正如一位日本前高级官员所说：“日语中有一个词可以表示‘制高点’，至少在20世纪70年代之前是这样，那就是通商产业省（MITI）。”

At the center of the jukyu chosei was one entity—a single, potent agency that coordinated both external and domestic industrial strategy: the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, which for most of the postwar era represented the command center for the noncommand Japanese economy. It was better known by its initials—MITI. As a former senior Japanese official observed: “There is a word for commanding heights in Japanese, at least up through the 1970s, and that is MITI.”

日本通产省（MITI）总部位于东京霞关区一栋建于20世纪50年代的灰褐色办公楼内，距离皇宫不远。该机构负责协调整个产业政策体系。其目标不仅在于帮助企业适应世界出口市场，更在于帮助它们最大限度地利用这些市场。它负责信息和知识的传播，并促进新技术的流动。为了实现目标，通产省运用了一系列工具：价格制定；进口配额和市场份额限制；许可证制度；质量标准；行业协会；“老男孩俱乐部”关系网；以及一种不具约束力但传递明确信息的方式：行政指导。通产省解读世界市场的变化，以此来塑造国内产业组织的规则，并通过地方办事处提供持续的咨询和本地干预。它力求确保“过度”的国内竞争不会削弱日本企业在海外竞争所需的实力。通产省组织并购和大型并购，协调投资以避免产能过剩，并鼓励中小企业专业化发展。日本通产省不仅控制着众多企业，还试图通过一系列手段和壁垒限制外国竞争对手在日本的生存。因此，国际贸易与国内产业紧密交织，通产省扮演着唯一协调者的角色。这堪称日本最伟大的创新之一。只有财务省在声望和影响力上能与通产省匹敌（甚至有人认为超过它），因为财务省掌握着信贷和外汇的控制权。但财务省的运作环境更为封闭，也远不如通产省那样引人注目。

From its headquarters in a gray-brown 1950s office block in the Kasumigaseki section in Tokyo, not far from the walls of the Imperial Palace, MITI coordinated the entire system of industrial policy. It aimed not only to help firms adapt to world export markets but also to help them take the greatest advantage of them. It channeled information and knowledge and facilitated the flow of new technologies. It utilized an array of tools to achieve its objectives: price setting; quotas for imports and market share; licenses; quality standards; industry associations; “old boy” networks; and a nonbinding but clear way of sending a message: administrative guidance. It interpreted changes in world markets to shape the rules of domestic industrial organization, providing continual advice and local interventions through local offices. It tried to ensure that “excessive” domestic competition did not erode the strength that Japanese firms needed in order to compete overseas. It organized mergers and megamergers, coordinated investment to avoid overcapacity, and encouraged the specialization of small and medium-sized companies. It also sought to restrict foreign competitors within Japan through a host of tools and barriers. International trade and domestic industry were thus closely intertwined, and MITI acted as the single coordinator. That was one of Japan’s greatest innovations. Only one ministry matched (and some would say exceeded) MITI in prestige and influence, and that was the Ministry of Finance, which wielded control over credit and foreign exchange. But the Ministry of Finance operated in a more rarefied world, and was much less visible.

执掌这两个部门的人都是顶尖大学的优秀毕业生，尤其是东京大学法学院的毕业生。他们被称为官僚——事实上，他们也毫不讽刺地这样称呼自己——但这个词在美国并没有贬义。它是一个儒家式的尊称，蕴含着责任、奉献和权力。而承担如此广泛的职责，对日本的官僚来说无疑是极其艰巨的。

The people who ran both ministries were the top graduates of the top universities, particularly the law school of Tokyo University. They were called bureaucrats—and indeed, with no irony, so described themselves—but the word had none of the pejorative implications found in the United States. It was a Confucian term of respect, connoting responsibility, dedication, and power. And carrying out such far-ranging responsibilities put very heavy demands on Japan’s bureaucrats.

随着日本私营经济的壮大，通产省的角色也随之演变。正如一位前官员所言，这套体系被证明是“一种非常有效的追赶模式”。通产省成为日本经济扩张乃至“日本公司”的核心，并围绕它形成了一种独特的文化。由于需要与通产省保持近乎持续的互动，各公司纷纷将总部设在通产省附近，也就是所谓的“步行可达”范围内。他们积极参与通产省的咨询委员会，这些委员会既是提供建议的渠道，也是接受建议的渠道。公司高管通常会格外注意对比自己年轻几十岁的通产省高级官员表示尊重，并恰当地鞠躬。

MITI’s role evolved over time as the Japanese private sector became stronger. The system proved to be, as one former official put it, “a very effective catch-up model.” MITI became the focal point of Japanese economic expansion, of Japan, Inc. An entire culture grew up around it. Companies, required to interact with MITI on a near-constant basis, located their headquarters near the ministry, within what was known as the short walk. They served on its advisory councils, which were as much vehicles for receiving advice as giving it. Senior company officials were often careful to show great respect, and bow appropriately, to high-flying MITI officials decades younger than themselves.

通产省与各行业协会密切合作，采纳他们的建议，力求促进整个行业的发展。然而，一些公司却因抵制通产省的政策、特立独行而闻名。为了应对汽车行业的国际竞争，通产省试图减少汽车企业的数量，以确保规模经济。为此，它曾试图说服本田公司继续专注于摩托车业务。但本田公司无视通产省的强烈建议，一意孤行。至关重要的消费电子产品行业在政府支持不足的情况下发展起来。录像机（VCR）就是一个典型的例子。三家日本公司成功地将一项价值五万美元的美国发明（当时只有电视台才能负担得起）转化为五百美元的消费品。通产省的作用充其量也只能说是微不足道。然而，无论存在哪些失误，这套体系都是日本经济日常生活的核心，而日本的非凡成就正是源于这套体系。总的来说，这套体系发挥了预期的作用。日本取得的成就如此显著，以至于到了20世纪80年代末，日本的霸权地位似乎注定要消除占领时期遗留的最后耻辱。那些曾经蹦蹦跳跳地试图从美国大兵手中接过糖果的男孩们，如今不仅掌管着一个经济超级大国，而且这个超级大国似乎即将超越美国。

MITI worked closely with industrial-sector associations, took their advice, and sought to promote the overall sector. However, some companies became famous for resisting MITI and going their own way. In preparation for international competition in automobiles, MITI tried to narrow down the number of companies to ensure economies of scale. As part of that, it tried to persuade Honda to stick with motorbikes. Ignoring MITI’s strong advice, Honda went ahead anyway. The crucial consumer-electrics business developed with little government support. The classic case was VCRs—videocassette recorders. Three Japanese companies succeeded in transforming a fifty-thousand-dollar American invention, which only television stations could afford, into a five-hundred-dollar consumer item. MITI’s role was modest at best. Yet whatever the missteps, this system was the nexus of daily life for the Japanese economy, and it was out of this nexus that Japan’s extraordinary achievement arose. For the most part, the system performed as intended. It delivered the goods to such a degree that by the end of the 1980s, Japanese preeminence seemed destined to remove the last humiliations of the occupation. The boys who had jumped up and down trying to catch candy bars from the American GIs were now running not only an economic superpower but one that seemed poised to overtake the United States.

然而，经济却被一场规模庞大、令人陶醉的投机热潮所主导，这场热潮在1990年开始破裂。1992年，日本陷入深度衰退，这是自高速增长时代开始以来最严重的经济危机。股市暴跌60%，房地产价格暴跌，背负大量不良房地产贷款的银行濒临破产。金融体系的脆弱性持续拖累着经济复苏。日本的竞争力正在下降。笼罩全国的悲观情绪弥漫开来。消费者和企业的信心不断削弱，与此同时，自民党分裂，其长达半个世纪的权力垄断也随之瓦解。

Instead, the economy was taken over by a huge and intoxicating speculative boom, which started to burst in 1990. In 1992, Japan went into a deep slump, the most severe economic crisis since the era of high growth had begun. The stock market fell 60 percent, real estate values plunged, and banks loaded up with bad real estate loans teetered on the edge of bankruptcy. The weakness of the financial system proved a persistent drag on recovery. Japan was losing its competitiveness. A glowering pessimism settled over the country. Confidence among consumers and business eroded, coinciding with a splintering of the Liberal Democratic Party and the breakup of the monopoly on power it had exercised for half a century.

这些困境引发了关于“日本株式会社”是否已经终结的激烈辩论。政府与市场之间的关系模式是否需要彻底改革，政府是否应该受到约束，经济是否应该放松管制？这场辩论至今仍在政治舞台和公共领域持续进行，其结果将决定日本的经济未来。3

These troubles led to turbulent debate as to whether Japan, Inc. was finished. Did the formula for the relationship between government and marketplace need radical revision, with government to be constrained and the economy deregulated? The outcome of this debate, still being fought in the political arena as well as in argument, will determine Japan’s economic future.3

官僚的“自杀法案”

A “Suicide Act” for Bureaucrats

这场斗争体现在通产省总干事兼产业政策局局长内藤正久的命运上，他后来成为日本放松管制的主要倡导者。与通产省的大多数领导一样，他毕业于东京大学法学院，于1961年进入通产省。在20世纪60年代初参与日本加入经济合作与发展组织（OECD）的相关谈判后，他开始对这一体系的长期有效性产生怀疑。“我认为，除非所有信息都集中到一个特定的中心，否则计划不可能如此有效，”他说。 “但这不太可能。所以次优方案就是市场机制。从上世纪60年代开始，我关注的重点一直是政府与企业之间应该建立怎样的关系。当时，许多贸工部人士认为只有贸工部的智慧才能引导经济发展。但我认为贸工部并非无所不能。我阅读过美国的反垄断和竞争理论。我一直觉得，在没有政府支持的情况下，消费电子产品发展得如此成功，实在令人惊叹。”

The battle was embodied in the fate of Masahisa Naitoh, a MITI director general and head of the industrial policy bureau within MITI, who was to become the foremost advocate of deregulation in Japan. Like most of the leadership in the ministry, he was a graduate of the law school of Tokyo University. He entered the ministry in 1961. After participating in negotiations related to Japan’s entry into the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) in the early 1960s, he began to harbor doubts about the long-term efficacy of the system. “I thought that planning could not work so well unless all information was directed to a specific center,” he said. “But that is very unlikely. So the second best was the market mechanism. From the 1960s onward, the main theme for me was what should be the relation between government and companies. At that time, many in MITI thought only the wisdom of MITI people could guide the economy. But I thought MITI was not almighty. I read American antimonopoly and competition theory. And I always thought how well consumer electronics had done without government support.”

随着奈藤在通商产业省（MITI）步步高升，他基本上将这些非传统的想法藏在心底。相反，他逐渐被视为通商产业省的“金童”之一。他在与美国至关重要的半导体谈判中扮演了关键角色，似乎很有可能一路高升。到了20世纪80年代末，他已身居要职，开始倡导更加自由的经济管制。他遭到了多方反对。“通商产业省的老家伙们认为放松管制会损害他们的地位，”他说。“公司总裁和政客们也反对。甚至有人散发传单，说我鼓吹‘摧毁’现有的经济体系。”系统。但所有这些批评反而更加坚定了我的信念。我认为这件事应该做。

As Naitoh rose through MITI, he kept such unconventional thoughts more or less to himself. Instead, he came to be seen as one of MITI’s “golden boys.” He played a key role in the all-important semiconductor negotiations with the United States, and seemed to have a good chance to go right to the top. By the late 1980s, he was in a prominent enough position to begin arguing the merits of a more deregulated economy. He was opposed on many fronts. “The MITI old boys felt that deregulation would hurt their positions,” he said. “The company presidents and politicians also opposed it. Brochures were circulated saying that I advocated the ‘destruction’ of the current system. But all of this criticism only strengthened my conviction. I thought it should be done.”

内藤忠雄与通产省内部的“国际主义”派系立场一致。他执掌着权力强大的产业政策局，极有可能晋升为公务员最高职位——副大臣。与此同时，他也变得更加直言不讳。他曾就日本经济的未来向由经团联（日本强大的雇主联合会）会长领导的平岩委员会作证。他坚持认为，放松管制对于恢复日本日渐衰落的竞争力至关重要。他是唯一一位持此立场的高级官员。“在政府内部，我的做法并不受欢迎，”他回忆道，“其他人认为政府官员应该只是执行法律。有人说我是在为官僚们制定‘自杀方案’。”

Naitoh was aligned with the “internationalist” faction within MITI. He was running the powerful Bureau of Industrial Policy and was a very likely candidate to rise to the highest post open to a civil servant, vice-minister. He also became more outspoken. He testified to the Hiraiwa Commission, headed by the chairman of the Keidanren (the powerful Japanese Federation of Employers), on the future of the Japanese economy. He insisted that deregulation was essential to restore waning Japanese competitiveness. He was the only senior official to take that position. “Within the government, what I did was not liked,” he recalled. “Others thought government officials should simply implement the laws. I was said to be envisioning a ‘suicide act’ for bureaucrats.”

1993年底，一件前所未闻的事情发生了。身为政治家的通产省大臣以一种史无前例的方式介入：他突然解雇了内藤，确保他永远无法担任至关重要的副大臣一职。这次解雇在日本引起了轩然大波，引发了一场激烈的辩论。内藤前往华盛顿——在那里教书，用他自己的话说，成为一名“政治难民”。他的政敌在日本媒体上散布文章，声称他与美国企业首席执行官秘密会面。

Then, at the end of 1993, the unheard-of happened. The MITI minister, a politician, intervened in an unprecedented way: he abruptly fired Naitoh, ensuring that he would never be able to occupy the critical post of viceminister. The firing became a cause célèbre in Japan, the crucible for an unfolding debate. Naitoh left for Washington—to teach and to become, in his words, a “political refugee.” His enemies circulated articles in the Japanese press alleging that he was holding secret rendezvous with American CEOs.

但为时已晚。那时，放松管制的趋势日益高涨。建立在股市和房地产价格螺旋式上涨之上的“泡沫”破裂，对日本造成了沉重打击。数年增长乏力甚至停滞，彻底颠覆了人们对1955年体制运作的预期。经济衰退暴露了高成本、受保护的、以生产为导向的经济模式的弊端。其金融影响巨大。由于工业界急需廉价资金，企业获得贷款并非基于其资产负债表，而是依赖于一套管理完善的体系，其中行政指导和人脉网络发挥了重要作用。这套体系阻碍了强弱企业之间的明显区分。储蓄被管理以维持体系运转。高消费价格刺激了人们储蓄而非消费。但家庭储蓄被引导至银行和人寿保险计划，收益微薄，而其持有者本应能够在更具活力——或风险更高——的市场中寻求更高的回报。在日益全球化的金融市场中，日本的共同基金行业规模却很小。层层监管将银行和金融机构的功能割裂开来，限制了日本或外国公司提供新型金融产品的机会。随着日本人口迅速老龄化，越来越多的人即将领取养老金，日本储蓄未能获得更高回报的问题，犹如一颗人口定时炸弹。

But it was too late. By that time, there was a growing movement toward deregulation. The bursting of the “bubble,” which had been built on spiraling stock market and property values, hit Japan very hard. Several years of sluggish, or even no, growth upset all expectations about the workings of the 1955 System. The slump showed up the problems with a highcost, protected, production-geared economy. The financial implications were great. The imperative of cheap money for industry had meant that firms received loans less on the basis of their balance sheets than as a result of a managed system in which administrative guidance and networks played a large part. This system prevented a clear differentiation between stronger and weaker companies. Savings were managed to support the system. High consumer prices provided an incentive to save, not spend. But household savings were channeled into the banks and life insurance schemes, where they earned low returns, whereas their owners should have been able to seek higher returns in more dynamic—or riskier—markets. In an increasingly global financial market, Japan had only a small mutual fund industry. Layers of regulations separated the functions of banks and financial institutions, limiting opportunities for Japanese or foreign firms to offer new financial products. With the population of Japan rapidly aging and increasing numbers of people soon to claim pension benefits, the failure of Japanese savings to achieve better returns took on the character of a demographic time bomb.

日元贬值虽然有利于出口商，但政府几轮基础设施建设支出都不足以解决问题。刺激经济复苏。随着经济衰退的持续，支持结构性改革的呼声日益高涨，希望摆脱对经济的严格监管，从而恢复其竞争力。

Neither the low value of the yen, which helped exporters, nor several waves of government spending on infrastructure projects were sufficient to jump-start the economy. As the recession continued, voices grew louder in favor of a structural change to unharness the economy from its tight regulation and thus to restore its competitive position.

在经济衰退的最初几年，由于多个联合政府的不稳定，协调一致的政治行动变得更加困难。但自1996年以来，在首相桥本龙太郎领导的改革后的自民党政府的领导下，监管改革的重点和动力显著增强。桥本龙太郎起初似乎不太可能成为结构性改革的倡导者。他一生中曾先后担任六个部门的负责人，事实上，他曾在1991年因财务大臣卷入金融丑闻而被勒令辞职。一度被认为政治生涯已过巅峰的他，在自民党内部动荡期间保持低调，最终在1996年成为自民党党首兼首相。

In the first few years of the recession, concerted political action was made more difficult by the instability of several coalition governments. But since 1996, there has been more focus and momentum for regulatory change under the reformed Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) government of Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto. Hashimoto appeared at first an unlikely proponent of structural reform. The head of six ministries at different times during his career, he had, in fact, been forced to resign as minister of finance in 1991, when the ministry’s role in a financial scandal became known. For a time considered a spent force, he kept a low profile during the internal turmoil of the LDP and emerged as its leader and prime minister in 1996.

桥本将放松管制置于其政治议程的核心。但实际上，推动日本放松管制的因素主要有两个。第一个因素相对简单。它涉及某些行业，这些行业与竞争对手之间的成本差异过大，部分原因是这些行业的组织原则已经过时。长期以来，国家安全要求日本所有石油都必须在日本的工厂提炼，而不是在其他地方以更低的成本提炼，但如今这一要求被认为已经过时或发生了转变。日本电力公司的传统垄断地位正受到独立发电企业的蚕食。航空运输业也将开放更多竞争。这些改革意义重大，但并非普遍适用。在成本差异不那么显著的行业，变革的压力要小得多，既得利益集团的力量加上僵化的劳动制度，仍然根深蒂固。

Hashimoto placed deregulation at the center of his political agenda. But it is in fact two forces toward deregulation that are at play in Japan. The first is relatively simple. It concerns certain sectors where the cost differential with competitors has become too extreme, partly because the principles on which the industries were organized are out of date. The imperative of national security, which had long required that all of Japan’s oil be refined in Japanese plants rather than more cheaply elsewhere, is now seen to be outdated or transformed. Japan’s electric utilities are seeing their traditional monopolies being eroded around the edges by independent power production. Air transport is also to be opened up to more competition. These reforms are significant but hardly universal. In sectors where the cost differential is less extreme, there is far less pressure to change, and the power of established interests, combined with the rigidity of the labor system, remains deeply entrenched.

更为复杂的力量来自日本金融领域，它对日本经济管理方式的影响虽然不那么直接，但却更为深远。其核心在于所谓的“金融大爆炸”——一系列以伦敦金融放松管制为蓝本的自由化改革，计划从1998年开始分阶段实施。从外汇市场放松管制开始，“金融大爆炸”将逐步扩展到银行、证券和保险业，改变东京金融市场的运作方式。它旨在重振东京作为金融中心的地位，并重新吸引许多已从东京证券交易所退市的外国公司。它还旨在切断金融与犯罪集团之间的一些联系，这些联系导致了多起臭名昭著的丑闻。但它对整体经济的影响更为深远，因为它将引入更激烈的储蓄和投资资本竞争。家庭将能够要求理财者提供更高的回报；日本企业将不得不彼此竞争，并与海外市场争夺投资资本。金融市场将对企业施加新的约束，从而增强它们的竞争力。这意味着，除其他事项外，市场将被允许表明哪些公司比其他公司更强大。

The more complex force is the one in Japanese finance, which will have a less direct but far more pervasive effect on the way Japan manages its economy. It hinges on what has come to be known as the Big Bang—a series of liberalizations modeled on financial deregulation in London and slated to occur in stages starting in 1998. Beginning with foreign-exchange deregulation and spreading to banking, securities, and insurance, the Big Bang will change the ways that the financial industry does business on the Tokyo market. It seeks to reenergize Tokyo as a financial center, and to re-attract many of the foreign companies that have delisted from the Tokyo stock exchange. It also aims to unravel some of the ties between finance and the criminal underworld that have led to several notorious scandals. But it will have a more pervasive effect in the economy at large, for it will introduce a far greater measure of competition for savings and investment capital. Households will be able to demand higher returns from those who manage their money; and Japanese firms will have to compete among themselves and with overseas markets for investment capital. The financial markets will apply a new discipline to companies, enhancing their competitiveness. The implication will be, among other things, that the market will be allowed to indicate which firms are stronger than others.

“经济大爆炸”是桥本政变的核心议程，他将自己的政治声誉押在了上面。但事实上，这一理念源于通产省和财务省内部的一些想法，而这些想法直到如今才因日本长期的经济衰退而变得足够紧迫，值得公开倡导。这两个部门仍然是官僚机构中的思想领袖，但它们的领导性质正在迅速变化。通产省不再是产业政策的首席设计师；在“经济大爆炸”推行之前，财务省也不再是日本资金管理的唯一机构。相反，它们越来越多地承担着引导政府其他部门走向自由化的重任。甚至有人提议修改政府结构，将通产省并入一个经济超级部门，这至少具有象征意义，可以废除战后经济史上最著名的缩写之一。

The Big Bang is the centerpiece of Hashimoto’s agenda, and he has staked much of his political reputation on it. But in fact, it draws on ideas that were nurtured in some quarters of MITI and the Ministry of Finance and which only now have become urgent enough to be advocated in public, owing to Japan’s long slump. The two ministries are still the intellectual leaders in the bureaucracy. But the nature of their leadership is changing fast. MITI is no longer the grand architect of industrial policy; nor is the Ministry of Finance, in the run-up to the Big Bang, the sole clearinghouse for the management of Japan’s money. Rather, they are increasingly charged with directing the rest of the government toward liberalization. There are even proposals on the table to modify the structure of the government to merge MITI into an economics superministry, which would at the very least have the highly symbolic effect of abolishing one of the most famous acronyms of postwar economic history.

显而易见，通产省（MITI）曾经凌驾于一切之上的时代早已远去。1955年的体制使日本成为强大的竞争对手。但未来国际竞争的要求表明，日本很可能像许多其他国家一样，转向比使其成为经济超级大国的体制更加自由开放的市场经济体系。4

What is clear is that the days in which MITI was synonymous with the commanding heights are already long over. The 1955 System made Japan a formidable competitor. But the future requirements of international competition suggest that Japan, like so many other nations, is likely to move to a market system that is freer and more open than the one that made it an economic superpower.4

韩国：挑选赢家

Korea: Picking Winners

1983年10月9日，阳光明媚的清晨，在缅甸仰光，韩国民众在烈士陵园内列队等候。他们正等待着韩国总统全斗焕的到来。全斗焕即将开启对缅甸的五国访问，并计划在陵园敬献花圈。韩国大使乘坐的豪华轿车上飘扬着韩国国旗，在摩托车的护送下疾驰而来，迅速进入陵园。一名缅甸士兵举起号角，还没吹响两个音符，一声巨响便撕裂了陵园，屋顶被炸飞，尸体被抛向空中，一英里外的建筑物都为之震动。五名韩国部长和三名副部长不幸遇难，其中包括一位名叫金载益的斯坦福大学经济学家，他当时正在主导韩国下一阶段的经济发展。但袭击者错失了他们的主要目标——当时还有几分钟路程的全斗焕总统。他们被车队和缅甸号手误导，把韩国大使误认为是全斗焕，过早地引爆了遥控炸弹。

In Rangoon, Burma, on the sunny morning of October 9, 1983, Korean members of the receiving line were taking their places inside the Martyrs Mausoleum. They were awaiting the imminent arrival of South Korea’s president, Chun Doo Hwan, who was beginning a five-nation tour in Burma and was due at the mausoleum for a wreath-laying ceremony. The South Korean ambassador, flags flying from his limousine, roared up with a motorcycle escort and hastened into the mausoleum. A Burmese soldier lifted his bugle to his lips. He managed barely two notes before a huge explosion ripped through the mausoleum, blowing its roof off, throwing bodies high into the air, and shaking buildings a mile away. Five South Korean ministers and three vice-ministers were among those killed, including a Stanford-educated economist named Kim Jae-Ik, who had been masterminding the next phase of economic development in his country. But the perpetrators missed their main target, President Chun, who was still a few minutes away. Misled by the motorcade and the Burmese bugler, they had mistaken the South Korean ambassador for Chun and had detonated the remote-controlled bomb too soon.

毫无疑问，爆炸案的组织者是：共产党人。朝鲜。其目标是破坏朝鲜半岛南部地区的稳定。韩国军队立即在分隔两国的非军事区进入最高警戒状态。这又是一场战争中的又一场战斗，而这场战争实际上从未真正结束。但自20世纪50年代初的全面战争以来，韩国无疑发生了变化：韩国正迅速崛起为经济强国，令极权主义的朝鲜相形见绌。而且，韩国的发展速度非常快。

There could be no doubt about who had organized the bombing: communist North Korea. The objective was to destabilize the southern half of the Korean peninsula. South Korean soldiers immediately went on the highest alert status along the demilitarized border zone that separated the two countries. It was yet another battle in a war that had never really ended. But what had surely changed since the all-out war in the early 1950s was that South Korea was well on its way to becoming an economic powerhouse, shaming totalitarian North Korea. And it was doing so very quickly.

1945年朝鲜半岛分裂时，韩国几乎一无所有。大部分现有工业——主要是日本在鸭绿江上建造的水电站以及附近的化工厂和化肥厂——最终都落入了朝鲜手中。1950年，13.5万朝鲜军队入侵韩国。共产主义中国参战支持朝鲜，随着朝鲜军队的推进，韩国一度似乎岌岌可危。其首都首尔四次易手。战争于1953年结束，但双方签署的是停战协定而非和平条约——这时刻提醒着韩国，其生存是多么岌岌可危，来自北方的威胁又是多么危险。朝鲜的独裁领导人金日成始终坚持其毫不妥协的敌对政策。因此，战后韩国迫切需要增强经济实力，尤其是在中国和朝鲜都开始以共产主义模式快速推进工业化的情况下。但韩国当时处境艰难，饱受战争摧残。7%的人口丧生，其中包括大量青年男性，而其原本就微薄的工业产能也有三分之二被摧毁。

In 1945, when the peninsula was partitioned, South Korea had been left with very little. Most of the existing industry—largely the Japanese-built hydroelectric stations on the Yalu River and the nearby chemical and fertilizer plants—had ended up in North Korea. In 1950, 135,000 North Korean troops invaded the south. Communist China entered the war in support of North Korea, and as the communist troops advanced, it had seemed for a time that South Korea might not survive at all. Seoul, its capital, changed hands four times. The war ended in 1953, with a truce, not a peace treaty—a constant reminder to South Korea of how precarious was its existence and how dangerous was the threat from the north. Kim Il Sung, North Korea’s megalomaniacal leader, never wavered in his relentlessly hostile policy. Thus, in the aftermath of the war, South Korea desperately needed to build up its economic strength, especially as both China and North Korea embarked on rapid industrialization, communist-style. But South Korea was in a terrible state, devastated by the war. Seven percent of its population had been killed, including a large proportion of young men, and two thirds of its meager industrial capacity had been destroyed.

这为李承晚总统的统治开了个不吉利的头。从二战结束到1960年，他一直主导着韩国政坛。朝鲜半岛自1895年起成为日本的殖民地，李承晚因其民族主义活动于1898年至1904年间被日本人监禁。之后他前往美国，并于1910年在普林斯顿大学伍德罗·威尔逊教授的指导下获得博士学位。他总共在国外生活了四十年，致力于争取韩国独立。掌权后，他更关注政治和处理与美国的关系，而非发展。民族主义而非经济才是他的强项。

This was the inauspicious beginning for the rule of President Syngman Rhee, who dominated the South Korean scene from the end of World War II until 1960. The Korean peninsula had been a colony of Japan since 1895, and the Japanese had jailed Rhee from 1898 until 1904 for nationalist activities. He had then made his way to the United States, where in 1910 he completed a Ph.D. at Princeton University, under Professor Woodrow Wilson. Altogether, he spent forty years outside the country, campaigning for Korean independence. Once in power, he was much more concerned with politics and with managing relations with the United States than with development. Nationalism, not economics, was his forte.

1961年军事政变后，韩国真正开始大力推进工业化进程。朴正熙将军崛起成为强人，从1962年到1979年统治韩国。他强硬专制，一心致力于经济发展，是“韩国公司”的创始人兼首席执行官，并以铁腕手段统治国家。他得到了充满活力的年轻军官、一支训练有素且日益经验丰富的官僚队伍、广大勤奋工作的民众以及全国上下对工业发展的坚定承诺的支持。来自北方的持续威胁推动着一切。

The real push to industrialization came in 1961, following a military coup. General Park Chung Hee emerged as the strongman, running the country from 1962 until 1979. Tough, autocratic, and absolutely committed to economic development, he was the founding CEO of “Korea, Inc.,” and he played the part, ruling with an iron fist. He was supported by energetic young military officers, a skilled and increasingly experienced bureaucracy, a broad base of citizens willing to work, and a national commitment to industrial development. The continuing danger from the North drove everything.

在所有亚洲国家中，韩国是最有意识地（尽管态度矛盾）采纳日本模式的国家。结果是：用经济学家德怀特·珀金斯的话来说，这套体系“高度干预主义，但又受到出口导向的约束”。韩国对日本的关注无疑具有讽刺意味。韩国不仅曾是日本的殖民地，而且有着悠久的反抗日本统治的历史。日本的占领残酷无情，即使在独立后，韩国人民仍然深感愤懑。他们决心建立自己的国家和民族认同。然而，由于日本的占领，许多韩国人接受了日语教育，深受通产省模式和日本文化的影响。此外，他们还能眺望日本海对岸，一个经济超级大国的崛起显而易见。曾就读于日本军校并在二战期间在满洲军队服役两年的朴槿惠总统，将加强日韩关系作为其发展战略的一部分。

Of all the Asian countries, South Korea proved to be the one that most consciously, if ambivalently, adopted the Japanese model. The result was a system that was, in the words of economist Dwight Perkins, “highly interventionist, but with the discipline of having to export.” Certainly, there was irony in Korea’s focus on Japan. Not only had it been a colony, but the Koreans had a long history of resisting Japanese domination. The Japanese occupation had been brutal and the Koreans were bitter long after independence. They were intent on building up their own nation and their own national identity. As a result of the Japanese occupation, however, many of them had been educated in Japanese-language schools, and they were strongly influenced both by the MITI model and by Japanese culture. Moreover, they could look across the Sea of Japan, where the rise of an economic superpower was all too evident. President Park, who had attended a Japanese military academy and had served two years as an officer in the Manchurian army during World War II, pursued closer Japanese-Korean relations as part of his development strategy.

通商产业省（MITI）的某种模式或许能满足韩国的迫切需求。当时的韩国非常贫穷，人均国民生产总值直到1963年才达到100美元。在军政府统治的第一个十年里，政府致力于发展出口，以弥补美国对外援助的减少。最初，出口导向型政策不加歧视，为所有企业提供保护以及各种补贴和支持。但很快，朴正熙政府的经济规划者们得出了一个影响深远的结论：他们坚信，韩国要想在国际市场上竞争并抵御外国进口，就必须拥有大型企业。为了实现这一目标，他们扶持了一系列被称为“财阀”的“国家冠军企业”——这些控股公司控制着多元化的产业集团。朴正熙及其团队挑选的都是在某一领域（例如碾米、房地产或建筑）已经取得成功的企业，这些企业通常由意志坚定、自信满满的企业家掌舵。这些公司随后获得了政府的低息贷款、税收优惠和其他扶持，发展成为规模庞大、实力雄厚且业务多元化的工业集团。由此诞生了如今享誉全球的现代、三星、乐记金星和大宇等公司。

A MITI variant could serve Korea’s urgent interests. The country was very poor; per capita GNP did not reach $100 until 1963. In the first decade of military rule, the government focused on building up exports to compensate for declining U.S. foreign aid. Initially, the export-push system was nondiscriminatory, providing protection and a wide variety of subsidies and support to all comers. But soon the economic planners in the Park government came to a conclusion with far-reaching implications: They were convinced that Korea needed big companies if it was to compete in international markets and withstand foreign imports. To achieve that goal, they promoted a series of national champions called chaebols—holding companies that controlled diversified industrial groups. Park and his team selected firms that were already successful in one field (for example, rice milling or real estate or construction), typically run by a strong-willed entrepreneur who was not lacking in self-confidence. These firms were then nurtured with low-interest government loans, tax incentives, and other advantages to enable them to become large, strong, and diversified industrial groups. Thus were born companies whose names are now globally known—Hyundai, Samsung, Lucky Goldstar, and Daewoo.

1973年，朴正熙政府的干预主义倾向进一步加剧，启动了所谓的“重化工业倡议”，这成为韩国未来全球地位的基石。此举主要出于安全考虑。朝鲜是一个军事机器，其目标毋庸置疑，因此，对韩国而言，问题至关重要——避免灭亡。随着越南战争中共产党胜利的阴影笼罩，朴正熙及其身边的人担心美国会撤回安全保障。而韩国自身也几乎无力独自应对。其仅有的二战时期火炮已无法使用；美国已停止生产相关零部件。韩国没有反坦克武器来对抗朝鲜的T-62坦克，其军需品也仅够维持三天的战争。1976年，美国总统吉米·卡特宣布其意图，这极大地加剧了韩国的不安全感。促使美国从朝鲜半岛撤军。卡特费了好一番功夫才让步，但他将美军驻扎与人权挂钩，进一步加剧了与朴槿惠独裁政权的裂痕。

In 1973, Park’s government became even more interventionist, launching what was known as the Heavy and Chemical Industries Initiative—the foundation upon which Korea’s global role would be built. It was done mainly for reasons of security. North Korea was a military machine, its objectives could not be doubted, and thus, for South Korea, the issue was basic—escaping extinction. With a Communist victory looming in Vietnam, Park and those around him feared the U.S. security shield would be withdrawn. And South Korea was hardly equipped to go it alone. Its only cannons, of World War II vintage, were not usable; the United States had stopped making the spare parts. It did not have antitank weapons to resist North Korea’s T-62 tanks, and its military stores were sufficient for no more than three days of warfare. South Korea’s renewed sense of insecurity was greatly stoked by President Jimmy Carter, who in 1976 announced his intention to withdraw U.S. forces from the Korean peninsula. It took some dissuading to get Carter to relent, but he tied the presence of U.S. troops to human rights, further widening the gap with the authoritarian Park regime.

在重化工业计划下，政府官员制定了基本的投资决策，并通过信贷控制来强制执行。其结果是形成了一个高度集中的经济体系，该体系建立在政府与少数几家大型工业企业之间牢固而紧密的关系之上。朴正熙本人就是一位亲力亲为的首席执行官，他亲自挑选企业，监督项目进展，克服企业或官僚机构的重重阻碍，甚​​至乘坐直升机飞遍全国各地，亲自考察各个项目地点。朴正熙还推行着一套他自己版本的“目标管理”。每年新年，他都会拜访所有部长，讨论他们的目标以及实现目标的方案。第二年新年，他会再次拜访部长们，逐条审查他们前一年的承诺。那些未能完成80%承诺的部长会被解雇。每个人都明白了朴正熙的意图，他们想要的是持续高速增长。

Government officials made the basic investment decisions under the Heavy and Chemical Industries Initiative, and then enforced them through control of credit. The result was a very concentrated economic system, based upon a strong and tight relationship between government and a limited number of large industrial companies. Park himself was the hands-on CEO, selecting companies, monitoring progress, bullying through corporate or bureaucratic impediments, traveling around the country by helicopter to swoop down on the different sites and see them for himself. Park also had his own demanding version of “management by objectives.” Each New Year he visited all of his ministers to discuss their goals and how they would be achieved. The following New Year he would return to the ministers and go through the previous year’s promises—“sentence by sentence.” Those who failed to hit 80 percent of what they had promised were fired. Everybody got the message, and they understood what Park wanted—high, sustained growth.

政府重点扶持了六大战略产业——钢铁、石油化工、有色金属、造船、电子和机械。政府敦促财阀全力追求最尖端的技术，并力求规模化生产。例如，为了达到效率，一家汽车制造厂的年产量必须达到30万辆，这远远超出了韩国当时的消化能力，因为当时韩国的乘用车保有量仅为16.5万辆。因此，韩国必须尽快开拓出口市场，同时也要发展国内市场。

The government targeted six strategic industries for support—steel, petrochemicals, nonferrous metals, shipbuilding, electronics, and machinery. It pushed the chaebols to pursue aggressively only the most advanced technology, and it pushed for scale. To be efficient, for instance, an automobile manufacturing plant had to produce 300,000 vehicles a year, which was far beyond South Korea’s ability to absorb given the fact that at the time, the country had a total of only 165,000 passenger cars. Thus it was imperative to develop an export market as soon as possible and at the same time create a domestic market.

财阀们拥有充足的信贷资源，并受到政府的支持，免受经济衰退的影响。它们不仅免受韩国市场上外国竞争对手的冲击，也免受国内竞争对手的冲击。这些公司获得了产品的独家销售权，在新兴产业的第一阶段，只允许一家财阀在国内市场销售产品。政府强制要求财阀们按照严格的时间表，在其各自领域内，在广泛的产品范围内，达到国际竞争力。如果达不到目标，它们将遭受经济和政治上的惩罚。这项计划的实施体现了非凡的奉献精神和强大的职业道德。正如一位经理所说，韩国人“凭借勤奋和自律克服了贫困”。在许多情况下，情况远不止于此。政府制定了非常严格的工作规则，员工受到高度的纪律约束，每周工作时间接近60小时。财阀们拥有诸多优势，其中之一便是集团内部的交叉补贴。财阀首脑们变得极其富有，但这并没有阻止他们继续努力拼搏。但谁才是老大，这一点毋庸置疑。他们会定期被召到总统府——青瓦台，朴槿惠总统会亲自接见他们。他们因未能维护国家利益而受到责备。他们必须服从命令。5

The chaebols had generous access to credit and were insulated from downturns by government support. They were protected from foreign competitors in the Korean market—and from domestic competitors as well. The companies received exclusive licenses for their products, and only one chaebol was allowed to sell in the domestic market during the first phase of a new industry. The government forced the chaebols to attain international competitiveness in their fields according to a strict timetable and across a broad range of their products. If they did not, they suffered economic and political penalties. The program was pursued with extraordinary dedication, embodied in a very powerful work ethic. As one manager was to put it, Koreans “overcame poverty with hard work and discipline.” In many cases, it went further than that. Government work rules were very tough, workers were highly regimented, and the workweek was close to sixty hours. The chaebols had many advantages, one of which was cross-subsidies within the groups. The heads of the chaebols became enormously rich, which did not prevent them from continuing to work hard and aggressively. But there was no question of who was the boss. They would regularly be called to the presidential palace, the Blue House, where President Park would take them to task for failing to act in the interest of the state. They were to do as they were told.5

20世纪70年代末，韩国政府开始逐步放弃大规模干预的重化工业计划。部分原因是国内反对派势力抬头，民众对朴正熙政权不满。政府认为，转向稳定政策能够通过控制通货膨胀和更广泛地惠及民众来安抚民心。1979年10月，朴正熙总统被韩国中央情报局局长刺杀，这无疑是政策走向转变的转折点。接任总统的全斗焕将军更加注重稳定，并且对大型财阀及其巨大的影响力抱有敌意。

At the end of the 1970s, the government began to back off from the massively interventionist Heavy and Chemical Industries Initiative program. Part of the reason was the rise of domestic opposition and discontent with the Park regime. A shift to stabilization was seen as a way to placate the population by controlling inflation and spreading the benefits of industrialization more widely. The obvious break came in October 1979, when President Park was assassinated by the head of the Korean CIA. The man who thereafter took power, General Chun Doo Hwan, was even more interested in stability. He was also somewhat hostile to the large chaebols and their considerable influence.

金载益这位强大的思想领袖也推动了韩国的转型。金载益生于1938年，毕业于首尔大学，后在斯坦福大学获得经济学博士学位。他最初在权力强大的经济企划委员会任职，崭露头角，随后于1979年成为韩国经济稳定和自由化的倡导者。他的目标是控制经济增长，减少政府干预，并创造一个更加公平的竞争环境，使中小企业能够蓬勃发展。

A strong intellectual force in the person of Kim Jae-Ik also drove Korea’s change of course. Born in 1938, Kim had attended Seoul National University and then completed a Ph.D. in economics at Stanford University. He first made his influence felt as a member of the powerful Economic Planning Board and then, in 1979, became the architect of stabilization and the promoter of liberalization. His objectives were to get growth under control, reduce government intervention, and create a more level playing field on which small and medium-size firms could flourish.

金正日成为了全斗焕总统的首席经济顾问，这让许多人感到匪夷所思——“一个严肃的军人，一个热情洋溢的美国经济学家”。但他们的关系却异常密切。正如一位同事所说，“他是向将军解释经济学的人”。金正日意识到工业化战略此前取得了巨大成功，但他同时也坚信必须做出改变；否则国家将陷入困境。许多财阀的效率低下令人担忧，如果没有政府持续的救助，它们几乎会破产。银行体系主要由政府所有，几乎不受任何人的监管。农业体系效率低下。金正日的方案是收紧国家对经济的干预，出售至少一部分国有企业，开放金融领域，并降低进口壁垒，使效率低下的产业暴露在外国竞争之下。他希望外国投资发挥更大的作用。他意识到，经济的复杂性已经超出了政府的管理能力。令他的同事们惊讶的是，他甚至在说服掌握最终权力的将军们削减国防开支方面取得了一些进展。

Kim became President Chun’s chief economic adviser, which many found odd—“the dour soldier and the exuberant U.S.-trained economist.” But they were unusually close. In the words of a colleague, “he was the man who explained economics to the general.” Kim recognized how successful the industrialization strategy had been until then, but he was also convinced that it had to be changed; otherwise the country would come to grief. Many of the chaebols were becoming woefully inefficient and would have been virtually insolvent without continuing government bailouts. The banking system, largely government owned, was accountable to virtually no one. The agricultural system was massively inefficient. Kim’s prescription was to pull back the economic frontiers of the state, sell off at least some statecontrolled enterprises, free up the financial sector, and reduce import barriers in order to expose inefficient industries to foreign competition. He wanted a bigger role for foreign investment. He recognized that the complexity of the economy had now grown beyond the government’s ability to manage it. And to the astonishment of his colleagues, he even made some headway in convincing the generals, who held ultimate power, to trim defense expenditures.

如果金在益没有在1983年10月加入访问仰光的高级官员代表团，以他谦逊的魅力，他的政治生涯又会走多远呢？烈士陵园的惨剧令人痛心地提醒着韩国当时面临的危险。金在益的死被认为是整个事件中“最大的损失”。尽管去世时年仅44岁，金在益在事后却被人们铭记为“传奇人物”。

How much farther would Kim, with his self-effacing charm, have gone had he not joined that delegation of senior officials visiting Rangoon in October 1983? The carnage at the Martyrs Mausoleum was a terrible reminder of the dangers South Korea faced. Kim’s death was described as “the biggest loss” of the entire event. Although only forty-four at the time of his death, Kim Jae-Ik was to be remembered, in the aftermath, as “legendary.”

韩国在金正恩的政治遗产基础上，此后奉行了一系列政策。其目标是减少干预性的指导性规划，扩大市场作用，并实现金融和进口自由化。然而，这些变革并非一帆风顺。它们遭到了强大的官僚机构和习惯于受到优待的韩国企业的强烈反对。正如一位公务员所言，上世纪90年代末期仍然存在许多“隐性法规”，这些法规是由那些不愿失去权力的官员制定的。

Building upon Kim’s legacy, South Korea thereafter pursued policies aimed at less intrusive indicative planning, an expanded role for the market, and financial and import liberalization. The changes did not come easily. They met considerable opposition both from the powerful bureaucracies and from Korean companies used to being taken care of. In the words of one civil servant, much “hidden regulation” remains in the late 1990s, promulgated by officials who do not want to lose their power.

韩国已不再是低工资社会。然而，其严苛的劳动制度却屡屡出现问题。紧张局势始于1979年光州罢工工人遭屠杀事件，该事件引发了推翻朴正熙将军的政变。此后，劳工动荡时有发生。许多韩国工人感到自己被排除在劳动成果的应有权益之外。但到了20世纪80年代，工资大幅上涨，工作保障得到保障；1987年后，工会摆脱了政府的压制和控制。然而，近年来，为了使韩国能够与新兴经济体竞争，并使其劳动法与国际惯例接轨（这是加入经合组织的条件），韩国面临着劳动力市场更加灵活的压力，这无疑加剧了问题的严重性。工会对此的回应往往是暴力罢工和示威游行。

Korea finds itself no longer a low-wage society. The regimented labor system has shown recurrent strains. The tension began with the massacre of striking workers at Kwangju in 1979, which precipitated the coup that brought down General Park. Periodic labor unrest has continued ever since. Many Korean workers had felt excluded from the benefits of their labor. But in the 1980s, wages went up substantially and job tenure was guaranteed, and after 1987, unions were freed of government repression and control. More recently, however, compounding the trouble, there has been the pressure to make labor markets more flexible, both to enable South Korea to compete with the new tigers and to bring labor laws in line with international practice, as a condition of having joined the OECD. The unions have responded with often-violent strikes and demonstrations.

韩国财阀担忧国内经济前景，正寻求通过海外投资来维持竞争力。仅前五大财阀就计划在未来十年内投入700亿美元用于海外投资。韩国经济持续受到用于扶持大型产业的不良贷款以及对上世纪70年代创建的产业进行合理化和重组的迫切需求的困扰。此外，韩国缺乏像日本那样支撑经济稳定的中小企业网络。而且，鉴于德国统一付出的沉重代价，韩国民众担忧一旦朝鲜突然崩溃，统一这一他们梦寐以求的目标最终实现，将会造成怎样的经济和社会损失。尽管历经种种波折，韩国依然保持着令人瞩目的增长势头。亚洲问题专家埃兹拉·沃格尔的深思熟虑的评价简洁明了地概括了韩国三十年来取得的成就：“韩国从几乎没有任何工业技术到跻身世界工业化国家之列的速度之快，即使是日本也无法匹敌。” 他补充道：“没有任何一个国家能够如此迅速地取得如此巨大的进步，从手工业到重工业，从贫困到繁荣，从缺乏经验的领导人到拥有现代化的规划者、管理者和工程师。”

Worried about prospects for the domestic economy, the chaebols are seeking to maintain competitiveness by investing abroad. The top five chaebols alone are planning to spend $70 billion over a decade on overseas investment. Korea’s economy continues to stagger under the weight of nonperforming loans used to build up big industries and the persisting need to rationalize and restructure the industries created in the 1970s. Moreover, South Korea does not have the networks of small and medium-sized companies that have been a source of stability for Japan. In addition, Koreans—observing the high price of German reunification—worry about the economic and social costs should North Korea suddenly collapse and the cherished goal of reunification become a reality. Yet with all the ups and downs, South Korea has continued on its enormously impressive growth. And the considered judgment of Asia expert Ezra Vogel stands as a concise view of what was accomplished over three decades: “South Korea was unrivaled, even by Japan, in the speed with which it went from having almost no industrial technology to taking its place among the world’s industrialized nations.” He adds, “No nation has come so far so quickly, from handicrafts to heavy industry, from poverty to prosperity, from inexperienced leaders to modern planners, managers, and engineers.”

韩国正为其经济成功付出沉重的政治代价。大规模的国家干预滋生了大量的腐败机会。韩式产业政策意味着国家向特定企业提供巨额补贴，而这些企业也必须为此付出代价。“如果你与政府关系不密切，就无法在韩国市场生存，”一位商人解释道。“那些渴望在韩国开展业务的企业都遵循着不成文的规则，以促进经济的正常运转。”资金用于创造商业机会”——换句话说，就是回扣、贿赂和政治回报。

Korea is paying a heavy political penalty for its economic success. Massive state intervention created massive opportunities for corruption. Industrial policy Korean-style meant that the state extended enormous largesse to favored companies and there was a price to be paid by those so favored. “If you were not close to the government, you could not survive in the Korean marketplace,” one businessman explained. “The Korean businesses that were eager to do business followed the informal rules for the flow of funds in the generation of business”—in other words, kickbacks, bribes, and political payoffs.

1987年总统选举中，由于反对派分裂，全斗焕钦点的接班人卢泰愚得以上台。但民众对专制和镇压日益愤怒，对不平等和腐败也深恶痛绝。韩国的“掌权者”——将军和政客——攫取了过多的利益，要求透明化的呼声再也无法被压制。1993年，新当选的总统金泳三发起了一场反腐运动，这场运动规模庞大，且广受民众欢迎。最终，前总统全斗焕和卢泰愚因参与1979年政变和1980年镇压民主示威者的事件而受审并被判有罪。与此同时，八家财阀的掌门人因向卢泰愚行贿而被判入狱。根据起诉书，流向卢武铉的“非正式”资金数额巨大，高达6.5亿美元。1996年8月，两位前总统手牵着手，戴着镣铐，耻辱地聆听着判决。卢武铉被判处22年监禁；全斗焕被判处死刑。据说，卢武铉在狱中的最初几个晚上都在阅读玛格丽特·撒切尔的回忆录，无疑是在思考她提出的自由市场理念以及反对国家干预的观点。

In the presidential elections of 1987, a divided opposition had allowed Chun’s handpicked successor, Roh Tae-Woo, to take over. But the public became increasingly angry with authoritarianism and repression, as well as resentful of inequality and corruption. The top “managers” of Korea, Inc.—the generals and politicians—had grabbed too much profit for themselves, and the calls for transparency could no longer be shut out. In 1993, newly elected President Kim Young-Sam launched an anticorruption drive that would prove comprehensive in its sweep—and politically popular. As a result, former presidents Chun and Roh were tried and found guilty for their roles in the 1979 coup and the 1980 massacre of pro-democracy demonstrators. At the same time, the heads of eight chaebols were given prison terms for paying bribes to Roh. The “informal” flow of funds to Roh had been very considerable—$650 million, according to the indictment. Ignominiously shackled together, clasping hands, the two former presidents listened to their sentences in August 1996. For Roh, it was twenty-two years in prison; for Chun, a sentence of death. It is said that Roh spent his first nights in jail reading Margaret Thatcher’s memoirs, no doubt reflecting on her free-market philosophy and the case against state intervention.

从某种意义上说，这一结果是对推动韩国跻身世界经济前沿的整个体制的控诉。“过去在韩国经济发展阶段被视为正常且必要的做法，如今却受到​​了质疑，”一位负责韩国经济改革的委员会重要成员指出。“一个更加成熟的经济体要进入下一个发展阶段，就需要对市场、政府和工业化进行重新调整。” 漫长的军事独裁统治给韩国留下了复杂而沉重的遗产。那些年使韩国成为经济强国，人民生活水平也远远超出了预期。它们也确保了韩国在面对来自北方的无情敌意和威胁时得以生存。然而，许多韩国人也反对军政府，认为它们是破坏民主、实行高度专制统治的非法政权。如何处理这段历史，是韩国至今仍在努力面对的问题。6

In its way, the outcome was an indictment of the entire system that had propelled Korea to the forefront of the world economy. “What has been normal and necessary in the past as part of a phase of economic development in Korea is now being questioned,” observed a key member of a commission charged with reforming Korea’s economy. “A more mature economy going into the next stage of development will require the realignment of market, government, and industrialization.” The long years of military dictatorship leave a complex and difficult legacy for the nation. Those years turned Korea into an economic powerhouse and raised living standards far beyond what might have been expected. They also ensured that the nation survived in the face of the implacable hostility and threats from the North. Yet many Koreans also opposed the military governments, regarding them as illegitimate regimes that destroyed democracy and ruled in a highly authoritarian manner. How to deal with that past is something with which the nation continues to struggle.6

台湾：儒家资本主义

Taiwan: Confucian Capitalism

日月潭位于台湾中部群山环抱之中，常年云雾缭绕，一直是台湾最受欢迎的蜜月胜地。它的名字来源于从附近山顶眺望时呈现出的奇特形状。潭边有一座宏伟的庙宇，供奉着孔子和两位武士神。1949年，蒋介石曾到访日月潭。他来到日月潭边，寻求片刻喘息。此前，他刚刚逃离中国大陆，以躲避毛泽东领导的共产党军队的追捕。就在这湖边，蒋介石收到了那份电报，电报的内容是他最不愿听到的消息——国民党军队在大陆的最终溃败。他顿时沉默不语，一动不动地坐了一个小时。之后，他起身和儿子一起去森林里散步。漫长的沉默之后，他百无聊赖，提议去钓鱼。儿子付钱请一位老渔夫用他的船带他们出海。蒋介石沉浸在沮丧之中，心不在焉地撒下渔网，却意外地捕获了一条大鱼。渔夫说，这是他见过的从日月潭里钓上来的最大的一条鱼。他还说，这是个好兆头。然而，这似乎不太可能。毕竟，台湾——蒋介石最后的堡垒——的陷落似乎已迫在眉睫。他的宿敌毛泽东即将取得全面胜利。蒋介石已经无路可走了。

Sun-Moon Lake, enfolded in the mountains of central Taiwan and often covered with mist, has long been Taiwan’s favorite honeymoon resort. It takes its name from its shapes as seen from various nearby hilltops. On one shore is a magnificent temple, dedicated to Confucius and two warrior deities. In 1949, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek made his way to Sun-Moon Lake in search of some respite. He had just fled mainland China to escape capture by Mao Zedong’s advancing communist forces. And it was there by the side of the lake that Chiang was handed the telegram telling him the news he had never wanted to hear—of the final collapse of his nationalist forces on the mainland. He turned stone-silent and, for an hour, sat motionless. Then he stood up and set out for a walk in the forest with his son. After a long silence, for want of anything else to do, he suggested that they go fishing. His son paid an old fisherman to take them out in his boat. Lost in depression and hardly paying attention, Chiang cast out a net and, to his surprise, caught a very large fish. The fisherman said it was the largest he had ever seen taken from the waters of Sun-Moon Lake. It was a good omen, he added. Yet that hardly seemed possible. After all, the fall of Taiwan, Chiang’s last redoubt, appeared imminent. His old nemesis, Mao Zedong, was on the verge of total victory. And Chiang had nowhere else to go.

蒋介石与毛泽东之间的竞争定义了现代中国。1949年，毛泽东的军队取得最终胜利，从越南边境控制了整个中国大陆，当时两人的实力对比似乎非常清晰。然而，四分之一世纪后，在他们去世之时，这种对比已截然不同。蒋介石和毛泽东都在20世纪70年代中期去世，相隔不到一年，享年分别为87岁和83岁。那时，蒋介石主导了台湾经济的奇迹，使其跻身工业化国家的前列；而毛泽东则成功地制造了一系列灾难，使中国大陆陷入经济困境。

The rivalry between Chiang and Mao had defined modern China. The balance between them had seemed very clear in 1949, when Mao’s forces won their final victory, taking control of all of mainland China, from the Vietnamese border. Yet a quarter century later, by the time of their deaths, the balance looked quite different. Chiang and Mao both died in the mid-1970s—within a year of each other—at the ages of eighty-seven and eighty-three, respectively. By then Chiang had presided over an extraordinary economic miracle that was catapulting Taiwan into the forefront of industrial nations while Mao had succeeded in creating a series of catastrophes that left mainland China an economic disaster.

与韩国一样，台湾也是冷战的产物，其战后历史正如一位经济缔造者所言，是一部“白手起家”的传奇故事。从1895年开始的五十年间，台湾一直是日本的殖民地——一个“粮仓”——二战后又短暂地成为中国的省份。直到1949年，国民党领袖蒋介石率领两百多万军民逃往台湾，台湾才成为一个独立运作的国家。尽管人数仅为台湾本地居民的三倍，但这些来自大陆的难民却掌控了台湾的社会生活。他们与台湾本地居民之间的分裂，在经济、政治和社会层面都产生了深远的影响。

Like South Korea, Taiwan was a creation of the cold war, and its postwar history was a “rags-to-riches story,” in the words of one of its economic architects. For fifty years, beginning in 1895, it had been a colony of Japan—a “rice bowl”—and then briefly a province again of China after World War II. It became a separately functioning country only in 1949, when Chiang, leader of the Nationalist Party, sought refuge there with upward of 2 million soldiers and civilians. Although outnumbered by the Taiwanese Chinese by three to one, the refugees from the mainland controlled Taiwanese life. The split between them and the native Taiwanese would be of lasting economic, political, and social significance.

对台湾而言，首要问题是生存。在大陆共产党看来，台湾仍然是一个省，征服台湾是内战未竟的事业。而蒋介石和国民党则拒绝承认台湾并非中国的一部分，多年来一直谈论着收复大陆。然而，随着时间的推移，蒋介石的野心从“坚定的决心”转变为“一种愿望，然后变成一种神话，最后变成一种仪式”。但生存仍然是最紧迫的任务。起初，台湾只需抵御来自大陆的进攻。后来，随着中华人民共和国在国际社会占据一席之地，切断了台湾的大部分外交关系，包括与美国的外交关系，台湾面临着孤立无援的困境。在国际体系中，台湾面临着持续不断的、几乎独一无二的合法性斗争。但正如约翰逊博士所说，台湾岌岌可危的处境如同绞刑一般，反而磨砺了国民意志，增强了民族团结，并促使他们集中精力构建生存所需的经济命脉。

For Taiwan, one issue was paramount: survival. As far as the Communists on the mainland were concerned, Taiwan was still a province, its conquest the uncompleted business of the civil war. For their part, Chiang and the nationalists refused to acknowledge that Taiwan was not China, and talked for many years about retaking the mainland. With the passing of the years, however, Chiang’s ambition shifted from “a fierce resolve” to “an aspiration, then a myth, then a liturgy.” But survival remained the most urgent imperative. At first, it was necessary simply to withstand an onslaught from the mainland. Later, it was to weather Taiwan’s isolation as the People’s Republic took its place in the international community, snapping most of Taiwan’s diplomatic links, including those with the United States. It faced a constant and almost unique struggle for legitimacy in the international system. But Taiwan’s precarious position—as Dr. Johnson said of hanging—concentrated the mind, strengthening national unity and focusing resolve on building the economic sinews required for survival.

20世纪40年代末50年代初，形势并不乐观。中国资源匮乏，企业家寥寥无几，储蓄更是少得可怜，而且在战争中遭受重创。此外，当时普遍认为中国人不适合现代资本主义。据说，他们无法在家庭之外开展业务，也不会储蓄。他们过于多疑，缺乏创新精神。就连伟大的社会学家马克斯·韦伯在其关于资本主义兴起的研究中也宣称，儒家思想与资本主义格格不入。1949年，一些人将国民党的失败归咎于他们深陷于传统的儒家体制之中。如今看来，这种观点显得十分古怪；毕竟，亚洲经济奇迹现在有时也被称为“儒家资本主义”。

Things hardly looked promising in the late 1940s and early 1950s. The country had few resources, few entrepreneurs, and no savings, and it had been heavily damaged during the war. Moreover, there was a strong view that the Chinese people were not suited to modern capitalism. They could not operate beyond the family, it was said; nor would they save. They were too suspicious; they were not innovative. No less an authority than the great sociologist Max Weber, in his study on the rise of capitalism, had declared that Confucianism was incompatible with capitalism. In 1949 some attributed the nationalists’ defeat to their being mired in a traditional Confucian system. This view sounds quaint today; after all, the Asian miracle is now sometimes called “Confucian capitalism.”

然而，台湾也拥有一些坚实的基础。长达五十年的日本殖民统治给台湾留下了重视教育的遗产；到1949年，台湾一半的人口识字。此外，在大陆的彻底失败反而转化为一种力量，因为国民党人对导致他们走向失败的原因进行了深刻而痛苦的反思。他们总结出诸多原因——恶性通货膨胀、腐败、不平等、缺乏土地改革、政府权力滥用以及未能接受现代科学技术。这些教训成为他们系统地在规模小得多的台湾进行实践的依据。国民政府早期就推行了土地改革，建立了强大的农业基础，并促进了平等。它在新成立的官僚机构中灌输了强有力的反腐败精神。几乎从一开始，国民党就坚信，政府的首要职责是创造一个有利于企业家发展的环境，然后逐步退出。计划经济将引导台湾走向市场经济。用一位高级规划师的话来说，目标是管理“经济体系逐步去政治化的过程”。
