Yet Taiwan did have a few strong foundations. A legacy of its fifty years of Japanese colonization was the heavy emphasis on education; by 1949, half of the population was literate. Also, the totality of defeat on the mainland turned into a strength, for the nationalists went through a deep and painful soul-searching about what had brought them to disaster. They identified a number of causes—hyperinflation, corruption, inequality, lack of agrarian reform, arbitrary government power, failure to embrace modern science and technology. These became the lessons they methodically sought to apply on a much smaller stage. Early on, the Nationalist government carried out a land reform that created a strong agricultural base and promoted equality. It inculcated a powerful anticorruption ethos in its new bureaucracies. Almost from the beginning, there was also the conviction that government’s prime role was to create an environment in which entrepreneurs could flourish, and then it would withdraw incrementally. Planning would guide Taiwan toward a market system. The objective, in the words of one of the senior planners, was to manage “a process of the gradual depoliticization of the economic system.”

用“渐进”来形容或许恰当。在20世纪50年代的大部分时间里，台湾都专注于常见的进口替代战略，大力投资基础设施建设，并着力发展劳动密集型生产，辅以保护性关税和税收优惠。台湾也积极拥抱国有企业。这部分原因在于，它必须处理日本遗留下来的国有企业。此外，台湾也认为这些企业对于整合稀缺的技能和资源至关重要。而且，欧洲国有企业蓬勃发展的趋势也对台湾产生了显著影响。

“Gradual” would prove a fair description. Through most of the 1950s, Taiwan concentrated on the familiar import-substitution strategy, with a heavy investment in infrastructure and a focus on labor-intensive production, backed up by protective tariffs and tax incentives. It also embraced stateowned enterprise. It did so in part because it had to do something with the state companies the Japanese had left behind. It also saw such companies as essential for aggregating the scarce skills and resources that were available. And it was influenced by the very evident rise of state-owned enterprise in Europe.

在这一时期，美国的对外援助至关重要，使台湾能够在支付进口费用的同时投资设备。但到了20世纪50年代末，台湾意识到美国的援助即将结束（正如1965年发生的那样），因此迫切需要赚取外汇。当时，当时最大的出口产品是糖，但这显然无法满足需求。因此，该国做出了决定性的转变，进入了一个新阶段——向世界市场出口制成品。这不仅意味着开放，也意味着（尽管不太明显）国内管制开始放松。政府通过低息贷款、降低用于出口的进口商品关税以及积极引进技术来支持这些新兴产业。政府还鼓励外国直接投资，以促进技能和技术的转移以及产品质量的提升。结果令人瞩目：出口额从1963年的1.23亿美元增长到1972年的30亿美元。1980年，该国进入了一个新阶段，重点转向技术和研发；从此，自由化的趋势变得更加明显。

U.S. foreign aid was very important in this period, enabling Taiwan to invest in equipment while still paying for its imports. But by the late 1950s, Taiwan could see that American aid would end (as it did in 1965) and thus there was an urgent need to be able to earn foreign exchange. At the time its number-one export was sugar, which would hardly do. Thus it made a decisive shift into a new phase—toward export of manufactured goods into the world market. This meant not only an opening up but also, although less obviously, the beginning of relaxation of domestic controls. The government supported these new would-be industries through low-cost loans, lower tariffs on imports that went into making exports, and aggressive scouring for technology. It also encouraged direct foreign investment, in order to facilitate the transfer of skills and technology and upgrading of quality. The results were spectacular: Exports rose from $123 million in 1963 to $3 billion in 1972. A new phase began in 1980, with an emphasis on technology and research and development; and from there on, the trend toward liberalization became more explicit.

政府一直致力于扶持企业家阶层的崛起。有时，政府甚至需要亲自“扶持”他们，四处寻找能够承担特定任务的商人。例如，政府需要找到一位私营企业家来接管一家最初由美国援助项目资助的政府聚氯乙烯（PVC）工厂。经过一番寻找，最终确定了一位台湾候选人——当时在日本做木材推销员的王永昌。在政府的劝说下，他回到台湾，将自己的台塑集团发展成为全球最大的PVC生产商，并最终跻身台湾最富有的两三位富豪之列。但与韩国截然不同的是，台湾的整体发展更多地依赖于中小企业，这些企业通常是家族企业，并且往往以网络形式运作。7

The government was consistently concerned with promoting the emergence of an entrepreneurial class. Sometimes it had to do the “emerging” itself, hunting down businessmen to whom it could entrust specific tasks. For instance, it needed to find a private businessman to take over a government polyvinyl chloride plant originally financed by the U.S. aid program. After much looking, it finally identified a Taiwanese candidate, Y. C. Wang, who was working as a lumber salesman in Japan. Persuaded to come back, he built his Formosa Plastics into the world’s largest manufacturer of PVC—and ended up one of the two or three richest men in Taiwan. But in striking contrast to Korea, Taiwan’s overall development rested much more upon small and medium-sized businesses, frequently family owned and often operating in networks.7

超级技术官僚

The Supertechnocrats

蒋介石最明智的举措之一，就是将经济政策制定权交给了后来被称为“超级技术官僚”的群体——这些能力卓越的官员，其中许多人是科学家和工程师，他们的工作几乎不受政治干预。他们能够调动海外华人资源，包括一些在美国的著名经济学家，最终还能利用几代赴海外求学的台湾人——将原本令人担忧的“人才流失”转变为“人才库”。在海外学习或工作的华人成为一项巨大的资源，他们不仅提供了极其高效的技术转移网络，还发挥了其他诸多作用。

One of the smartest things Chiang did was leave economic policy making to what became known as the Supertechnocrats—very able officials, many of them scientists and engineers, who operated without a great deal of political interference. They were able to call upon Chinese living abroad, including a number of prominent economists in the United States, and eventually on generations of Taiwanese who had gone abroad for their education—and turned what had been feared as a “brain drain” into a “brain bank.” Chinese studying or working overseas became a tremendous resource, among other things providing an exceedingly effective network for technology transfer.

从20世纪50年代初到80年代中期，仅有五位男性在经济政策制定中拥有绝对的话语权。他们融合了传统与现代。一位学者指出，他们扮演的角色“很像传统的儒家贤臣，但他们的风格和工作内容在中国历史上都是全新的。他们是世界科学与发展界的一员，他们信奉增长与进步。” 事实上，在长达四十年的时间里，这五位男性中的两位，在多个关键职位间辗转，主导了整个经济政策制定过程。

From the early 1950s until the mid-1980s, just five men had preponderant say over economic policy making. They combined old and new. They played, observed one scholar, “a role much like that of good traditional Confucian advisors, but both their style and the content of their work were new in Chinese history. They were part of the world scientific and development communities, and they believed in growth and progress.” Indeed, for forty years, two of these men, moving among a number of key positions, dominated the entire process.

第一个是尹凯，他策划了进军出口领域的举措。他被誉为“台湾工业发展之父”，并担任过电气工程师。二战前，他曾在中国大陆各地工作。战争期间，他曾是中国政府赴美采购代表团的成员。从1949年到20世纪60年代初，他担任台湾首席规划师。他思维方式如同工程师。“工程师是精通经济学的科学家，”他曾这样说道。他如饥似渴地阅读经济学著作。他能就亚当·斯密的理论细节和精妙之处展开辩论——没错，政府确实有提供国防的职责——也能对凯恩斯的理论提出修正。在规划台湾的未来时，他既采纳了沃尔特·罗斯托的经济起飞理论，也强调了阿瑟·刘易斯的出口导向型增长理念。此外，他还坚信应该推动经济体制向市场化转型。 1963年他去世后，人们说他留下的最伟大的纪念碑是“台湾制造”这几个简单的字，刻在可以销往发达工业国家的优质商品上。

The first was K. Y. Yin, who orchestrated the move into the export phase and who became known as the “father of Taiwan’s industrial development.” Trained as an electrical engineer, he had worked all over China before World War II. During the war, he had been a member of the Chinese government’s purchasing mission in the United States. And from 1949 through the early 1960s, he was Taiwan’s chief planner. He thought like an engineer. “An engineer is a scientist who is knowledgeable about economics,” he said. He became a voracious reader of economic texts. He could argue over the details and the finer points in Adam Smith—yes, government did have the role of providing for defense—and offer emendations on Keynes. In planning Taiwan’s future, he embraced both Walt Rostow’s concept of the economic takeoff and Arthur Lewis’s emphasis on export-led growth. He was also a believer in moving the system toward the market. After his death in 1963, people said that his towering monument was the simple phrase “Made in Taiwan,” inscribed on quality goods that could be sold in advanced industrial countries.

他的继任者是副手李国栋，李国栋一直掌权到20世纪80年代末，并被誉为“中国经济奇迹之父”。李国栋毕业于中国最负盛名的大学之一，获得物理学学位。20世纪30年代初，他获得奖学金，先前往苏格兰，后在剑桥大学学习核物理。日本侵略中国后，他回国投身战争，在军工企业工作。他也是一位技术型思考者。他解释说，“经济现代化是一个庞大的工程系统，需要极其谨慎和周密的规划。” 但随着时间的推移，他也致力于逐步减少国家对市场的干预——用“市场的自动调节机制”取代“政府的专断政治权力”。

His place was taken by his deputy, K. T. Li, who held sway until the end of the 1980s and who became known as “the father of the nation’s economic miracle drive.” Graduating with a degree in physics from one of China’s most prestigious universities, Li won a scholarship in the early 1930s and went first to Scotland and then to study nuclear physics at Cambridge. After Japan invaded China, he returned home to join the war effort, working in the military industries. He, too, thought in technical terms. “Economic modernization,” he explained, is a “huge engineering system that requires extremely careful and elaborate planning.” But as time passed, he was also intent on progressively withdrawing the state from the market—replacing “the arbitrary political power of the government” with “the automatic adjustment mechanism of the market.”

李致力于创造有利于创业蓬勃发展、企业能够超越家族单元之外的条件。这意味着政府必须着重完善基础设施，构建合理的制度和法律框架，并从企业家的角度出发看待问题。“由于没有现成的改善营商环境的教科书，”李说，“我会设身处地地站在投资者的角度思考，然后运用科学方法来寻找答案。”

Li was obsessed with creating conditions in which entrepreneurship could flourish and business could develop beyond the immediate family unit. This meant that the government had to focus on getting infrastructure in place, developing a rational institutional and legal framework—and looking at things from the entrepreneur’s point of view. “Since there is not a textbook on how to improve the climate of business,” Li said, “I put myself in the shoes of investors and then rely on scientific method to provide the answers.”

这些技术官僚反复仔细地研究了日本的经验。尹先生对始于1868年的明治维新尤为感兴趣，明治维新开启了日本的现代化进程，他试图从中汲取经验教训。李先生在二战后逃往台湾之前的第一份工作是调查日本人在中国东北建立的工业，这使他终生致力于研究日本的行事方式。在台湾，两人都借鉴了日本官僚机构的部分结构——类似于通产省的模式，但又摒弃了日本体制中那种僵化的氛围。他们也得出结论：台湾和日本一样，需要出口才能生存，这意味着要在保持价格竞争力的同时不断提高产品质量。而这反过来又需要持续高效的运作。技术吸收也意味着要充分保护国内市场，以保护新兴产业免受更先进的外国竞争对手的冲击。简而言之，他们采取了日本的做法——“通过竞争淘汰对手，同时保护国内市场”。但这种保护措施会逐步取消，因为台湾企业会被刻意地置于国内市场，接受国际竞争的严格考验。

The technocrats studied the Japanese experience repeatedly and with great care. Yin took a deep personal interest in the Meiji Restoration, which, beginning in 1868, initiated Japan’s modernization, and he sought to sort out its lessons. Li’s first job after World War II, before his flight to Taiwan, was to investigate the industry that the Japanese had built in northeast China, which made him a lifelong student of how the Japanese did things. In Taiwan, both men adapted aspects of Japan’s bureaucratic structure—MITI-style, yet without the sense of permanence that characterized the Japanese system. They also came to the conclusion that Taiwan, like Japan, would need to export to survive, which meant continually improving quality while remaining price-competitive. That, in turn, required the constant and efficient absorption of technology. It also meant protecting the domestic market sufficiently to safeguard infant industries from more advanced foreign competitors. In short, they adopted the Japanese approach—“competing out and protecting in.” But the protection would be allowed to phase out, as Taiwanese firms were deliberately subjected to the rigors and tests of international competition in their home market.

这些超级技术官僚们对国内企业施压，迫使其产品达到世界标准并降低价格，同时鼓励外商投资以提升出口能力，尤其是在他们认为国内企业无法胜任的情况下。然而，尹锡悦和李国栋在推行李国栋所谓的“开放导向”时遭遇了强烈的反对。他们二人被指控与个别商人勾结。许多人希望继续实行保护主义政策。李国栋回应道：“对于那些抱持着上世纪五十年代思维——崇尚公营企业、憎恶日本私人资本入侵——的人来说，八十年代的种种事件是一场创伤。所有这些政策创新都意味着放弃一些根深蒂固的、与民族主义略有关联的、但却无法经受住世界市场现实考验的根深蒂固的观念。”

The supertechnocrats bludgeoned domestic companies to get their products up to world standards and down to world prices, and encouraged foreign investment to promote new export capabilities when they felt domestic firms were not up to the task. But Yin and Li ran into powerful opposition in promoting what Li called the “openness orientation.” They were both accused of colluding with individual businessmen. Many wanted protection to continue. Li responded: “For those with the mentality of the 1950s—glorification of public enterprise and resentment of the intrusion of private [former imperialist] Japanese capital—the events of the 1980s have been traumatic. All these policy innovations amounted to the abandonment of some highly treasured vested ideas, which were vaguely associated with nationalism”—but which could not stand up to the realities of the world market.

上世纪90年代末，台湾面临着与第一代高增长但不再低工资的亚洲国家相同的困境。一方面，它们受到低工资新兴工业化国家（包括中国大陆）的冲击；另一方面，它们又受到老牌工业化国家高科技产品的冲击。台湾试图通过提升自身的高科技能力来应对这一挑战。此外，为了追求低工资，台湾企业家也加大了对外投资，其中在大陆的投资尤为显著。第二个挑战是，随着经济发展和中产阶级的壮大，台湾正持续从威权主义向更加民主的政体转型。国民党长期以来牢牢把持权力，通过任命而非选举的方式产生总统。蒋介石之子蒋经国曾担任总统十年。1988年，国民党任命了毕业于康奈尔大学的农业经济学家李登辉。虽然他是国民党成员，但他是台湾人，并非大陆人。1996年，他再次当选，这次是通过自由竞争的选举，尽管当时中国海军在福尔摩沙海峡进行军事演习，选举仍然如期举行。

In the late 1990s Taiwan faces the same squeeze as the others of the first generation of high-growth—but no longer low-wage—Asian countries. They are pressed on one side by the low-wage, newly industrializing countries (including mainland China) and on the other by high-technology products from the established industrial countries. Taiwan has tried to respond by augmenting its high-technology capabilities. Also, Taiwanese entrepreneurs have, in the quest for low wages, stepped up their foreign investment, including a great deal on the mainland. A second challenge is the continuing transition away from authoritarianism to a more democratic rule, which has gone hand in hand with economic development and the broadening of the middle class. The Kuomintang long kept a tight grip on power, appointing rather than electing the president. Chiang Ching-kuo, Chiang Kai-shek’s son, held that post for ten years. Then, in 1988, the party appointed Lee Teng-hui, a former agricultural economist who had graduated from Cornell University. Although a member of the Nationalist Party, he was also a native Taiwanese, not a mainlander. In 1996, he was renewed in his post, this time in free, contested elections that went on despite Chinese naval maneuvers in the Formosa Strait.

最大的挑战，也是迄今为止最复杂的挑战，的确是台湾与中华人民共和国的关系。经济因素将二者联系在一起。过去十年，台湾企业在大陆投资了数百亿美元，使其成为迄今为止最大的外国投资者。然而，毛泽东在大陆取得胜利五十年后，政治因素却使二者渐行渐远。中华人民共和国仍然视台湾为一个需要重新统一的“叛离省份”。在台湾的学校里，孩子们详细学习中国的地理，背诵历代朝代，并研究那些将台湾标示为“一个省份”的地图。中国。但中华人民共和国对此却无感。1997年香港回归后，台湾的地位问题成为关注焦点。香港在新形势下的发展状况，以及其独特地位能否得到充分尊重，都将受到台湾的密切关注。目前看来，双方的分歧短期内难以解决。然而，时间或许能给出答案。随着中国大陆人均收入的增长，以及其社会主义模式日益趋向资本主义，两岸之间的鸿沟或许会逐渐缩小。

The biggest and by far the most complex challenge is indeed Taiwan’s relation to the People’s Republic. Economics is drawing them together. Taiwanese firms have invested tens of billions of dollars on the mainland over the last decade, making it by far the biggest foreign investor. But fifty years after Mao’s victory on the mainland, politics keeps them apart. The People’s Republic still regards Taiwan as an errant province to be regathered. In Taiwan’s schools, children learn in detail about the geography of China, memorize its dynasties, and study maps that show Taiwan as a province of China. But there is no taste to be absorbed by the People’s Republic. In the aftermath of the return of Hong Kong in 1997, Taiwan’s status has moved front and center. How Hong Kong fares in its new situation—and how well its distinct status is respected—will be scrutinized closely in Taiwan. No near-term resolution of their differences is evident. Time, however, could provide the answer. As per capita income rises in China, and as its brand of socialism comes to look more and more like capitalism, then the gulf between the two could begin to look less significant.

台湾的白手起家故事堪称传奇。其人均收入从1949年的100美元增长到如今的近14000美元。多年来，台湾中央银行的外汇储备位居世界第一。如今，台湾生产全球30%的笔记本电脑，以及全球一半的电脑键盘、显示器、扫描仪和主板。然而，这一发展历程并非一帆风顺。

As rags-to-riches stories go, Taiwan’s is spectacular. Its per capita income rose from $100 in 1949 to almost $14,000 today. For several years, its central bank held the largest foreign reserves of any country in the world. Today it produces 30 percent of the world’s notebook computers and half of the world’s computer keyboards, monitors, scanners, and motherboards. Yet the progress was never smooth.

台湾独立之初，政府在经济中扮演着举足轻重的角色，几乎没有其他选择。随着时间的推移，政府的权力范围逐渐缩小​​，同时对宏观基本面问题的关注也持续增加：超级技术官僚们制定政策鼓励民众高储蓄。通货膨胀和大陆战败的阴影始终萦绕在他们心头，如同挥之不去的噩梦，因此他们坚持不懈地运用预算纪律和货币紧缩来对抗通货膨胀。他们持续重视教育以及科技和技能的发展。他们关注公平和收入分配。他们寻求深度融入世界经济。而且，他们愿意放弃政府最令人沉迷的诱惑——行使权力。

At the beginning of Taiwan’s independence, government played an overwhelming role in the economy. There was hardly an alternative. Time has seen a progressive withdrawal of the frontier of government, along with a continuing emphasis on the macrofundamental agenda: The supertechnocrats put policies in place to encourage very high savings. With inflation and the defeat on the mainland entwined as a permanent nightmare in their minds, they relentlessly fought inflation with budget discipline and monetary restraint. They put sustained emphasis on education and on the development of technology and skills. They paid attention to equity and income distribution. They sought deep engagement with the world economy. And they were willing to surrender that most addictive of all of government’s allures—the exercise of power.

“人们往往认为，具有中华文化传统的国家拥有根深蒂固、权力强大的官僚机构和中央政府，”李国栋曾这样指出。“这不仅在历史上如此，对台湾来说至今依然如此。然而，我们作为台湾的政策制定者所做的，是先帮助经济的各个部门站稳脚跟，然后逐步发展。之后，我们就放手了。”8

“Countries with a Chinese cultural tradition are often perceived as having entrenched, powerful bureaucracies and central governments,” K. T. Li was to observe. “This not only is historically true but is still true for Taiwan. Nevertheless, what we as policy makers did in Taiwan was to help various parts of the economy first to stand and then to walk. And then we let go.”8

新加坡：国家作为风险投资家

Singapore: The State as Venture Capitalist

当年近八旬、身体虚弱的吴庆瑞博士走进历史悠久的莱佛士酒店餐厅时，所有人都转头看向他。毕竟，他是一位德高望重的长者。如果说李光耀是现代新加坡的奠基人，那么吴博士就是接班人，他是新加坡的经济架构师，是他设计了新加坡经济奇迹的体系——在长达三十年的时间里，新加坡的经济几乎每年都保持着7%到9%的增长率。但是，吴博士坚持认为，人们对这一奇迹的根源存在着巨大的误解。“大学里的讲师们都错了，”他说，“关键因素是我们决定在学校里重视科学和数学课程，以及母亲们的坚持。”他们让孩子们学习科学和数学。这主要归功于母亲们。

When Dr. Goh Keng Swee, nearly eighty and frail, entered the restaurant of the venerable Raffles Hotel, everybody turned to look at him. After all, he was a father figure. If Lee Kuan Yew was the patriarch of modern Singapore, then Dr. Goh was next in line, its economic architect, the man who designed the system that delivered Singapore’s economic miracle—7 to 9 percent growth rates almost every year for three decades. But, Dr. Goh would insist, the source of that miracle is greatly misunderstood. “The lecturers in the universities are all wrong,” he said. “The critical factor was our decision to emphasize science and math courses in the schools, and the mothers’ insistence that their children take science and math. It was the mothers that were really responsible.”

当然，在莱佛士学校见到吴作栋博士可谓恰如其分。毕竟，正是托马斯·斯坦福·莱佛士爵士于1819年抵达新加坡，当时岛上只有一小群马来人，他便开始将新加坡建设成为英国殖民地以及该地区的贸易中心。20世纪30年代，年轻的吴作栋像当时新加坡本土有前途的年轻人一样，被选中进入以斯坦福·莱佛士命名的精英学校，接受培训，以便日后进入地方政府工作。之后，他被派往英国，在伦敦政治经济学院获得博士学位。直到回到新加坡并加入公务员队伍后，他才与李光耀共事。

It was, of course, fitting to see Dr. Goh at Raffles. After all, it was Sir Thomas Stamford Raffles who in 1819 arrived at the island and, finding only a small Malay community, began to build it into a British colony as well as an entrepôt for the region. In the 1930s, the young Goh was picked out, as was the custom with the promising young native Singaporeans, to attend the elite school named for Stamford Raffles in order to be trained to enter the local government. He was then sent to England, where he earned a Ph.D. at the London School of Economics. It was only after he returned to Singapore and joined the civil service that he teamed up with Lee Kuan Yew.

李光耀在前往剑桥大学深造之前，也曾在莱佛士学校就读。从英国返回新加坡后，他决心投身于反殖民运动。在斗争结束之前，李光耀不仅战胜了英国殖民者，还在一场争夺民族主义运动控制权的激烈斗争中击败了共产党。他的梦想是建立一个包含马来西亚和新加坡的统一国家，但1965年，仅仅两年之后，这个统一的尝试就宣告失败。李光耀在公众面前痛哭流涕。他所领导的，是一个人口不足300万的城邦国家——新加坡。他必须想方设法，从现有的资源中建立一个国家——这群人贫穷且教育水平低下，其中75%是华人，其余大部分是马来人和印度人，他们缺乏民族认同感。帮派、犯罪和共产党势力使新加坡的生活始终处于危机之中，其前景也十分黯淡。

Also educated at the school named for Raffles before going off to Cambridge University, Lee had come home from England determined to throw himself into the anticolonial movement. Before the struggle was over, Lee would not only overcome the British but would also best the Communists in a bitter battle for control over the nationalist movement. His dream was of a single country comprising both Malaysia and Singapore, but in 1965, after just two years of such a union, the experiment fell apart. Lee wept in public. He was left the leader of a much diminished nation, the city-state of Singapore, with fewer than 3 million people. Somehow he would have to make a nation out of what was there—a poor and poorly educated population, 75 percent of whom were Chinese, with most of the rest Malay and Indian, with no sense of national identity. Gangs, crime, and communists all made life in Singapore a permanent crisis, and its prospects were quite problematic.

新加坡若想拥有未来，显而易见的资源只有两点——人民和领导力。李光耀先生兼具多种非凡才能——他是一位魅力四射的领袖、一位技艺精湛的政治家、一位视野开阔的杰出技术官僚，以及一位富有远见的领导者。“建设一个国家，你需要激情，”他曾说过，“如果你只是计算——加减贷——你注定失败。”他充满激情，并且对自己判断和权威几乎毫不怀疑。正如他晚年所言，他还拥有令人叹服的说服力。

If Singapore was to find a future, there were only two obvious resources—the people and the leadership. In Lee Kuan Yew, Singapore had a man with an unusual combination of talents—he was a charismatic leader, a skilled and shrewd politician, a superb technocrat with a broad view, and a visionary. “To build a country, you need passion,” he once said. “If you just do your sums—pluses, minuses, credit, debit—you are a washout.” He had passion, and he evinced little doubt about his own judgment or authority. He also had, as he would note later in life, a formidable talent for persuasion.

在吴作栋博士身上，国家拥有了一位务实的经济学家。“如果我们是经济先驱，”吴作栋说，“那是出于简单的经济需要。成功的关键不在于计划，而在于适应不断变化的形势的能力。” 该国唯一一次尝试五年计划是在20世纪60年代。但吴作栋说，那只是“在一个长周末里仓促炮制出来的”，是为了安抚世界银行。然而，无论是否存在计划，李光耀和吴作栋创建的体制都赋予了国家在经济中强大的指导作用。其结果被赋予了许多不同的名称：“行政国家”、“国家作为风险资本家”，有时也被称为“具有社会主义特征的资本主义”。

In Dr. Goh, the country had a pragmatic economist. “If we were economic pioneers,” Goh said, “it was due to simple economic necessity. The key to success is not a matter of planning but rather the ability to adapt to changing situations.” The country’s one and only foray into five-year plans was in the 1960s. But, said Goh, it was “cooked up during a long weekend” as a sop to keep the World Bank happy. Yet whether there was a plan or not, the system that Lee and Goh created provided the state with a strong, guiding role in the economy. The results have been given many different names: “the administrative state,” “the state as venture capitalist,” and, occasionally, “capitalism with socialistic characteristics.”

这一切都是对当时形势的回应。新加坡建国初期，是一个四面楚歌的国家，它对自己能否成功并没有太大的信心。能否成功，甚至能否生存下去。由于资源匮乏，李光耀、吴作栋及其同事对当地企业家的能力并不十分有信心。他们也深受战后英国工党和战后国有化趋势的影响。事实上，他们最初是以坚定的社会主义者身份开启政治生涯的，但最终却信奉市场经济，尽管政府拥有强大的话语权。在很大程度上，这套体系是他们自主建立的。如果说有一个重要的外部影响，那就是一位名叫阿尔伯特·温塞米乌斯的荷兰经济学家，他最初是冰淇淋经济学的专家。温塞米乌斯是他们了解国际经济的向导，帮助他们决定扶持哪些产业，并在他们感到迷茫和绝望时给予鼓励。是的，他们能够做到；他们能够将一个以小型农场为支撑的港口，发展成一个可行的经济体。

All this was a response to the situation at hand. In its early years, Singapore was a country besieged. It had no great confidence that it could make it, or even survive. As there was so little to work with, Lee, Goh, and their colleagues were not very confident in the capabilities of local entrepreneurs. They were also much influenced by the postwar British Labour Party and the postwar trend toward state ownership. Indeed, they began their public careers as committed socialists, but they ended up professing their faith in the market, albeit with a strong government say. For the most part, they developed the system on their own. If there was one major external influence, it was a Dutch economist named Albert Winsemius, originally an expert in the economics of ice cream. Winsemius was their guide to the international economy, helping them decide which industries to encourage and providing pep talks during times of uncertainty and despair. Yes, they could do it; they could create a viable economy out of what was essentially a port backed up by small farms.

吴作栋和李光耀设立了经济发展局，旨在指导现代经济的建设。他们建立了国有企业，并竭尽所能地为这些企业配备最优秀的人才。他们要求公务员像商人一样思考，并将他们的晋升与他们所管理的国有企业的盈利能力挂钩。他们为社会服务——医疗保健和住房——提供资金，但始终谨慎地避免福利过于完善，以免剥夺新加坡人的个人和家庭责任感。正如一位现任政府部长所说，一个不完全的福利体系“有助于新加坡人民更清晰地展望未来”。他们利用中国人的储蓄倾向，提倡极高的储蓄率。事实上，他们通过中央公积金来实现这一目标，该基金鼎盛时期曾提取所有工资的50%。这些资金被用于基础设施、工业和住房建设。基础设施建设中最著名的例子是吴作栋主导的裕廊工业园区改造项目，该项目将一片名为裕廊的广袤沼泽地改造成了一个庞大的工业园区。许多人认为这个项目荒谬可笑，极有可能失败，因此被称为“吴作栋的愚行”。然而，如今它却成了新加坡经济成功的代名词。

Goh and Lee established the Economic Development Board to guide the creation of a modern economy. They put in place state-owned companies, which they went out of their way to staff with the best they could find. They forced civil servants to think like businessmen, tying their promotions to the profitability of the state-owned enterprises they ran. They financed social services—health care and housing—but were always careful not to make them so complete as to deprive Singaporeans of their sense of personal and family responsibility. As one of the current government ministers put it, a less-than-total welfare system “helps Singaporean people see the future more clearly.” And they built upon the Chinese propensity to save by promoting a very high savings rate. In fact, they implemented it through the Central Provident Fund, which at its height took 50 percent of all wages. The money was used to finance infrastructure, industry, and housing. The most famous example of the infrastructure development was the transformation—masterminded by Goh—of a wide expanse of swamp called Jurong into a vast industrial park. Many regarded the project as ridiculous and likely to fail, and it became known as Goh’s Folly. Today, however, it is synonymous with Singapore’s economic success.

他们对教育也投入了巨大的资源——但至少在大学层面，他们是要收费的。在新加坡，任何东西都不应该免费。1968年，新加坡没有培养出一名工程师；如今，它的目标是每年培养两万名工程师。在整个现代化进程中，政府扮演了非常积极的推动者角色。它是议程的制定者、长期规划者、独立的战略参与者以及资源的管理者。一小群精英官僚，通过精英选拔，掌控着整个体系。当时的紧迫感、国土面积小、不断取得的成功，以及李光耀作为动员者和执行者的卓越才能——所有这些因素共同促成了全国共识、共同目标和有效协调，使新加坡看起来像一个高度团结的公​​司。毕竟，就连工会理事会的秘书长也是内阁成员。

They also made an enormous commitment to education—but they charged, at least at the university level, something for it. Nothing in Singapore should be free. In 1968, the country produced no engineers; now it aims to turn out twenty thousand a year. Throughout the process of modernization, the government was a very active facilitator. It was the agenda keeper, the long-range planner, a strategic player in its own right, and the manager of resources. A small elite of bureaucrats, selected meritocratically, ran the whole system. The sense of immediate vulnerability, the small size of the country, the unfolding success, and Lee’s considerable talents as a mobilizer and implementer—all created a national consensus, a common purpose, and effective coordination that made Singapore look like a very cohesive company. After all, even the secretary-general of the trades union council was a member of the cabinet.

然而，国家统治只是故事的一部分。在同一时期，在进口替代和保护主义盛行的时代，新加坡做出了对国际贸易至关重要的承诺。李光耀和吴作栋都非常清楚新加坡的国土面积之小；在他们看来，新加坡太小，无法单打独斗。他们决心将新加坡牢牢地融入世界经济。“我们别无选择，只能生产出口产品，”吴作栋说，“我们的国内市场太小，而且当时本地企业的技术水平也太低。”

Yet state domination was only part of the story. For over the same period of time, Singapore made a crucial commitment to international commerce—in an era when import substitution and protection were the order of the day. Lee and Goh were all too conscious of Singapore’s diminutive size; it was, in their view, simply too small to go it alone. They would seek to anchor it firmly in the world economy. “There was no choice except to produce for export,” said Goh. “Our domestic market was too small, and the skills of local enterprise at the time were too low.”

首先，新加坡致力于营造有利于经济增长的环境——低通胀、稳定且可预测的“游戏规则”（供企业和外国投资者遵循）、高储蓄率、反腐败精神以及对商业友好的气候。正如一位经济学家所说，“在新加坡，企业发展良好。”其次，新加坡做出了一个非常不合时宜的决定，即积极吸引跨国公司，因为这些公司会带来至关重要的“嫁妆”——技术、技能、资本和市场准入。新加坡对这些公司进行了严格的筛选，考察它们带来的价值以及它们所代表的行业。新加坡寻找的是拥有强大技术实力且愿意进行长期投资的稳定企业。它希望开展能够提升新加坡“品牌”形象的高知名度项目——正如一位部长所说，这些项目将代表着质量、可靠性以及比其他地区更高的外国投资者信心。最早被新加坡吸引的公司之一是德州仪器公司，该公司于1968年进驻新加坡，开始生产晶体管。在那些年里，新加坡从毛泽东发动的文化大革命的动荡中获益匪浅。这场革命吸引了众多跨国公司离开香港和台湾，转而涌向新加坡——新加坡最大的优势在于其距离中国大陆较远。新加坡政府竭尽所能地为外国公司提供便利，从基础设施投资到调整教育项目以满足他们的需求，无所不包。

First, Singapore would create an environment conducive to economic growth—low inflation, stable and predictable “rules of the game” for business and foreigners to operate by, a high savings rate, an anticorruption ethos, and a climate friendly to business. As one economist put it, “In Singapore, companies are good.” Second, it made the very unfashionable decision to court multinational corporations, for these firms would move in with a crucial dowry—technology, skills, capital, and access to markets. The firms were vetted carefully for what they brought and what industries they represented. Singapore was looking for stable companies with strong technologies and a willingness to invest with a long-term perspective. It wanted high-visibility projects that would contribute to building, as one minister put it, the Singapore “brand name”—embodying quality, reliability, and a comfort level for foreign investors higher than available elsewhere. One of the very first companies to be so enticed was Texas Instruments, which arrived in 1968 to begin manufacturing transistors. In those years, Singapore benefited greatly from the upheavals of Mao’s Cultural Revolution, which lured multinationals away from Hong Kong and Taiwan and instead toward Singapore, which had the great virtue of being farther from China. The government went out of its way to facilitate the activities of foreign companies with everything from infrastructure investment to aligning its educational programs to their needs.

上世纪90年代末，新加坡担心会被新兴的低成本生产地区抢占先机，因此寻求通过向更高技术价值链转型，并开辟“外部经济”（即新的经济活动领域）来保护自身——例如，它在中国监管的“第二个新加坡”。新加坡早在上世纪70年代就开始了这一转型，但如今这种紧迫性与日俱增。“新加坡还是殖民地的时候，”吴作栋博士回忆道，“每家商店里的东西都标着‘英国制造’。现在，主要的标志是‘中国制造’。”9

In the late 1990s, Singapore worries about losing out to the newer low-cost production areas, and it has sought to protect itself by moving up the value chain to higher technologies and by carving out an “external economy,” new spheres of economic activity—as, for instance, in the “second Singapore” it is overseeing in China. It began this redefinition in the 1970s, but the urgency has grown. “When Singapore was a colony,” recalled Dr. Goh, “everything in every store were items that said ‘Made in Britain.’ Now the dominant insignia is ‘Made in China.’”9

马来西亚：这片土地的儿女

Malaysia: The Sons of the Soil

最初的四个“亚洲四小龙”中，有三个——台湾、新加坡和香港——都是华人聚居区。在随后的“亚洲四小龙”——印尼、马来西亚和泰国——华人也一直是当地经济的引擎。然而，就马来西亚而言，其发展的全部方向都明确指向解决其“华人问题”——即华人主导地位。尽管马来人大多居住在农村，生活贫困，但他们凭借悠久的商业传统和市场，在当地经济活动中发挥了重要作用。一位深入研究马来西亚经济的学者指出：“马来西亚后来的成功，很大程度上归功于其解决种族问题的努力。” 马来西亚的成功如此显著，以至于在短短二十年间，它就从一个橡胶和棕榈油出口国转型为世界最大的计算机芯片生产国之一。马来西亚人口仅有1900万，却是世界第十三大贸易国；其贸易额超过俄罗斯（人口1.47亿），是印度（人口9.35亿）的两倍。马来西亚还拥有世界第十三大股票市场，其出口产品83%为制成品。正如马哈蒂尔总理所说，对于一个曾被视为“历史的弃儿”的国家而言，这“相当不错”。

Three of the first four “tigers”—Taiwan, Singapore, and Hong Kong—were all Chinese communities. In the “tigers” that came next—Indonesia, Malaysia, and Thailand—the ethnic Chinese have been engines of the local economies. In the case of Malaysia, however, the entire thrust of development has been aimed specifically at solving its “Chinese problem”—dominance of economic activity by the local Chinese, with their long commercial tradition and markets, although the Malays, rural and poor, made up the majority of the population. “Malaysia’s subsequent success,” observed a close student of its economy, “results in large part from its effort to solve its racial problems.” And it was so successful that the country in two decades was transformed from an exporter of rubber and palm oil to one of the world’s largest manufacturer of computer chips. With just 19 million people, it is the thirteenth-largest trading nation in the world; it trades more than Russia (with a population of 147 million) and twice as much as India (with a population of 935 million). It also has the thirteenth-largest stock market in the world, and 83 percent of its exports are manufactures. “Not bad,” in the words of Prime Minister Mahathir, for a country that was considered “a primary candidate for the dustbin of history.”

转折点是1969年的反华骚乱——这场骚乱的导火索是华人在选举中表现出色。马来人——其中四分之三生活在贫困之中——眼睁睁地看着自己仅有的一点政治权力正逐渐落入华人手中。民主进程被中止，政府推出了一项“新经济政策”，旨在促进经济快速增长，但更重要的是，实现财富再分配。这是一项大规模的平权行动、配额制和偏袒政策，旨在帮助占人口多数的土著（即马来人）摆脱贫困，进入学校和大学，最终跻身中产阶级。这项政策的精妙之处不胜枚举。所有商业企业都必须至少有30%的马来人参与。政府为土著提供的抵押贷款利率低于非土著。诸如此类的政策不胜枚举。

The turning point was the 1969 anti-Chinese riots—sparked by a strong Chinese showing in elections. Malays—three quarters of whom lived in poverty—saw the little political power they had slipping away to the Chinese. Democracy was suspended, and a “New Economic Policy” was launched, intended to promote rapid growth but also, crucially, to bring about redistribution. It was a massive program of affirmative action, quotas, and favoritism that was meant to lift the majority bumiputras—the sons of the soil, that is, indigenous Malays—out of poverty and into schools and universities and then into the middle class. There was no end to the ingenuity of the program. All business enterprises were to have at least 30 percent Malay participation. The government offered bumiputras lower mortgage rates than non-bumiputras. And on and on.

然而与此同时，政府力图缓和社会摩擦，并为新经济政策争取广泛支持。为了维持这一政策，财富再分配的首要前提是创造财富，全体民众都开始受益——其中华人受益尤为显著。该计划涉及高度国有化、大量监管和庞大的官僚机构。它还包含对教育的巨额投资。1957年马来西亚独立时，国内没有一所马来语学校。“马来教育的目的，”一位著名的英国殖民时期教育家曾宣称，“是让他们成为更优秀的农民和渔民。”仿佛是为了回应这一论断，身为教师之子的马哈蒂尔总理后来自豪地指出：“稻农和渔民的儿子们如今拥有并成功经营着价值数十亿美元的公司。”政府鼓励外商投资。马来西亚由此走上了高速增长之路——20世纪70年代年均增长率高达7.8%。人均收入从1970年的390美元增长到1982年的1900美元。国家也实现了民族团结。经济增长惠及所有人。

Yet at the same time, the government sought to ease the social frictions and build broad support for the New Economic Policy. To be sustained, redistribution required wealth creation first and foremost, and the entire population began to benefit—including, very considerably, the Chinese. The program involved a high degree of state ownership, much regulation, and a large bureaucracy. It also entailed a massive investment in education. In 1957, when Malaysia became independent, it did not have a single Malaylanguage school. “The purpose of Malay education,” a noted British colonial educator had declared, “is to make them better farmers and fisherman.” As if in reply, Prime Minister Mahathir, himself the son of a teacher, would later proudly point out, “The sons of rice farmers and fishermen own and run billion-dollar companies successfully.” Foreign investment was encouraged. The country was launched on a high growth curve—7.8 percent per year in the 1970s. Per capita income rose from $390 in 1970 to $1,900 in 1982. The country also developed national unity. There was enough economic growth to go around.

但到了20世纪80年代初，新经济政策开始失败。政府扩大了国有企业规模，并在重工业领域投入巨资，但这些举措并未奏效。亏损和效率低下问题日益严重。国有企业的亏损占比显著上升。国民生产总值下降。经济增长停滞不前。此时，首相马哈蒂尔和财政部长达因·扎因丁主导了经济向市场化方向的急剧转变。

But by the early 1980s, the New Economic Policy floundered. The government had expanded public enterprise and made a very large investment in heavy industry, which was not working. Losses and inefficiency were mounting. The deficit of public enterprises grew markedly as a share of the GNP. Economic growth faltered. At that point, Prime Minister Mahathir and his finance minister, Daim Zainuddin, engineered a sharp shift to the market.

在推行这些变革的过程中，马哈蒂尔的动力与其说是经济理念，不如说是始终激励着他的民族主义。他的父亲是英属马来亚首位担任英语学校校长的马来人。二战期间，十几岁的马哈蒂尔曾是手推车小贩，但他刻意避免向占领马来亚的日本人出售水果。战争结束后，他甚至在前往新加坡爱德华七世国王医学院学习之前，就加入了反英殖民运动。21岁时，他已是反殖民主义政党马来民族统一机构（巫统）的成员，该党在1997年仍是执政党。1969年，他出版了《马来人的困境》一书。书中批评政府对马来人相对于华人的经济劣势缺乏应对，导致他被巫统开除，该书也被查禁。在反华暴乱三年后，在他书中提出的那些补救措施开始实施之后，他被邀请重返党内。他先后担任多个职务，直至1981年成为首相。直到那时，《马来人的困境》一书的禁令才被解除。

In instituting these changes, Mahathir was moved less by economic philosophy than by what had always been his motivating force—nationalism. His father was the first Malay head of an English school in British-controlled Malaya. As a teenager during World War II, Mahathir was a pushcart vendor, but he went out of his way to avoid selling fruit to the occupying Japanese. At the war’s end, he joined the anti-British colonial movement even before going off to study at the King Edward VII College of Medicine in Singapore. By age twenty-one, he was already a member of the anticolonial United Malay National Organization (UMNO), which in 1997 was still the ruling party. In 1969 he wrote a book, The Malay Dilemma. Its criticism of the lack of governmental response to the economic weakness of the Malays vis-à-vis the Chinese got him kicked out of the UMNO, and it was banned. Three years after the anti-Chinese riots, and after the kind of remedies he had proposed in his book were being implemented, he was invited back into the party. He held a succession of positions until becoming prime minister in 1981. It was only then that the ban on The Malay Dilemma was lifted.

作为首相，马哈蒂尔采取措施，明确表示将更加注重效率和现代化。为了象征这一变革，他要求所有政府雇员，包括国会议员，都必须打卡上班。他还着手将日本模式的相关部分应用于马来西亚经济。他曾秘密前往日本数周，探寻“日本的精神和根源”。当时，有关日本的书籍在马来西亚往往畅销，马哈蒂尔特意阅读这些书籍，并在关键段落下划线，同时要求他的助手们也认真研读。

As prime minister, Mahathir took steps to make it clear that there was now going to be a new emphasis on efficiency and modernization. To symbolize the change, he required that all government employees, including members of Parliament, punch in on a time clock. He also set out to apply relevant parts of the Japanese model to the Malaysian economy. At one point, he spent several weeks traveling incognito in Japan seeking to uncover “its spirit and roots.” Books about Japan were often best-sellers in Malaysia, and Mahathir made a point to read them, underlining key passages and insisting that his aides study them as well.

民族主义斗争持续影响着马哈蒂尔的世界观。尽管马来西亚与世界经济的融合日益加深，但他仍经常对任何他认为带有居高临下、评判或来自西方的未经请求的建议感到愤怒和愤慨。马哈蒂尔限制国内批评，并将来自国外的批评视为殖民主义的表现。他曾致信一位反对伐木的德国环保人士，写道：“别那么傲慢，以为决定世界各国人民的命运是白人的责任。”他查禁了多家西方出版物和记者，并抨击他所谓的“西方控制的自由媒体”。他的马来民族主义如今正演变为亚洲民族主义。“亚洲势不可挡，”他说。对于那些质疑高增长可持续性的人，他讽刺地回应道：“这种认为我们失败的能力无穷无尽，而成功的能力却有限的想法，真是令人感动。”

The nationalist struggle continues to define how Mahathir looks at the world. Despite Malaysia’s increasing integration with the world economy, he frequently rose up in anger and indignation at what he saw to be any instance of condescension, judgment, or unsolicited advice from Western sources. Mahathir restricted domestic criticism, and viewed criticism from outside the country as expressions of colonialism. To a German environmentalist campaigning against logging, he wrote, “Stop being arrogant and thinking that it is the white man’s burden to decide the fate of the peoples of the world.” He has banned a number of Western publications and reporters, and attacks what he calls the “so-called Western controlled free press.” His Malay nationalism is now becoming an Asian nationalism. “Asia cannot be stopped,” he said. To those who questioned the sustainability of high growth, he sarcastically replied, “This belief in our infinite ability to fail and in our limited ability to succeed is touching.”

但在 20 世纪 80 年代初，当他主导马来西亚经济转型时，是因为当时经济遭遇危机，也因为他判断经济已经足够强大，可以放松国家控制——这令人瞩目。对于这样一位民族主义者来说，进一步开放市场、吸引外资至关重要。马来西亚需要经济增长和不断提高的国民收入才能解决其经济困境。“到20世纪80年代初，马来西亚已经发展出向前发展的管理技能和专业知识，包括一批企业家阶层，”马哈蒂尔说。“这在20世纪60年代和70年代并不存在。因此，在那些年里，国家必须加强管控。然而，一旦这些条件具备，就可以放手让私营部门和市场发挥作用。”撒切尔主义的盛行也起到了推动作用。“从某种意义上说，我们利用了撒切尔及其所作所为来推进我们自身的工作，”马哈蒂尔说。“撒切尔成为了一个强化催化剂。真正令人担忧的是政府资源的消耗和局限性。这些项目对政府来说过于昂贵。用于这些项目的资金本可以更好地用于政府应该做的事情，例如教育、医疗和消除贫困。”

But in the early 1980s, when he directed the turn in the Malaysian economy, it was because of the crisis that had hit the economy and because of his judgment that it was now strong enough to relax state control and—striking for such a nationalist—to open up further to foreign investment. The country needed the growth and rising national income if it were to solve the Malay economic dilemma. “By the early 1980s, Malaysia had developed the managerial skills and expertise to go forward, including an entrepreneurial class,” said Mahathir. “That did not exist in the 1960s and 1970s. Thus, in those years, you had to have stronger state control. Once these were in place, however, you could pull back and leave it to the private sector and the markets to perform.” It helped that Thatcherism was in the air. “In a sense, we took advantage of Thatcher and what she was doing to promote our own work,” Mahathir said. “Thatcher became a reinforcing catalyst. The real concern was the drain and limitations of government resources. The projects were too expensive for the government to finance. The money used for these projects could be better used for what government would be doing, which is education, health, and removing poverty.”

1984年至1986年间，马哈蒂尔任命的国家委员会制定了私有化的理由。“我们认为政府不应该涉足商业，”马哈蒂尔解释道，“私营部门将成为经济增长的主要引擎。”然而，实际的私有化并非完全自由放任。政府仍然持有许多公司的大量股份，甚至控股权。资产出售往往缺乏透明度。批评人士指出，受益者是与执政党关系密切的马来族知名商人。政府则回应称，其所做的只是挑选“赢家”——那些能够让部分私有化公司取得成功的人。此外，政府还将广大马来民众纳入受益者之列，他们通过国家支持的养老基金和信托基金获得了这些公司的股份。这些基金促成了一种大众资本主义，使普通民众与内部人士一样拥有股份。

Between 1984 and 1986, a Mahathir-appointed national commission developed the rationale for privatization. “We said it was not the business of government to be in business,” explained Mahathir. “The private sector would be the primary engine of growth.” The actual privatization has not been laissez-faire, however. The government has continued to hold large, even controlling, stakes in many firms. Asset sales were often far from transparent. The beneficiaries, critics said, were prominent Malay businessmen with connections to the ruling party. The government replied that all it was doing was picking “winners”—people who would make a success of the partly privatized companies. And it included among the beneficiaries the broader Malay population, which acquired stakes in the firms through state-sponsored pension and trust funds. These funds mobilized a form of popular capitalism, giving ordinary people a stake alongside the insiders.

马哈蒂尔将政府战略的转变写入了一项新计划——《国家发展政策与2020年愿景》，该计划旨在实现7%的年增长率，这意味着国民生产总值每十年翻一番。在这个计划中，私营部门将与政府紧密合作。“我们对马来西亚的构想是‘马来西亚股份有限公司’，这与日本的模式非常相似，”马哈蒂尔说。“我们明确地采纳了这一理念，旨在形成社会共识，即市场是马来西亚发展的方向。我们希望政府、企业和社区之间能够紧密合作。毕竟，政府和企业一样，都依赖于企业的盈利能力。如果企业不盈利，政府也就无法盈利。如果企业盈利，政府就能以税收的形式获得其中30%的利润。这道理简单却意义深远。”

Mahathir codified the shift in government strategies in a new program, the National Development Policy and Vision 2020, which aimed at 7 percent annual growth, meaning that the GNP would double every ten years. In this enterprise, the private sector would operate in close “partnership” with the government. “Our idea of Malaysia is Malaysia, Inc., very much along the lines of Japan,” said Mahathir. “We have adopted this very explicitly in order to develop the social consensus that the market is the way for Malaysia to go. We want strong cooperation between government, companies, and the community. After all, government depends upon the profitability of companies as much as companies themselves do. If companies don’t make money, the government doesn’t make money. If companies make money, the government is guaranteed thirty percent of those profits in the form of taxes. It’s simple, but profound.”

正如马来西亚当年奋起直追第一代“亚洲四小龙”一样，它也将面临来自下一代国家的竞争挑战。与该地区其他国家一样，马来西亚也必须对其雄心勃勃的基础设施发展计划进行调整。然而与此同时，马来西亚也取得了非凡的成就——尤其是在通过普及……来控制种族紧张局势方面。增长带来的益处。“政治环境已经成熟，”副总理安华解释道，“印度人、华人和马来人现在比上世纪60年代更加包容。相互适应是体制的一部分。领导力可以影响文化价值观，改变发展路径。把所有这些因素放在一起，摇一摇。”安华用力地上下挥动双手，然后笑了。“结果就是成功。”10

Just as Malaysia came charging after the first generation of “tigers,” it will also face competitive challenges from the next generation. And like others in the region, it will have to temper its ambitious plans for infrastructure development. Yet in the meantime, the country has racked up an extraordinary record—not least, keeping ethnic tensions at bay by spreading the benefits of growth. “The political climate was ripe,” explained Deputy Prime Minister Anwar. “Indians, Chinese, and Malays are now more tolerant of each other than in the 1960s. Efforts to accommodate each other are part of the system. And leadership can influence the values in the culture, and alter the path of development. Put all these things together in a box and shake it up.” Anwar vigorously moved his hands up and down for a moment. Then he smiled. “The result is success.”10

新角色

The New Role

尽管各国历史文化背景以及反殖民斗争的性质各不相同，但政府与市场之间许多基本的互动模式在该地区其他国家也同样存在。在印度尼西亚，两派技术官僚长期冲突不断——“工程师”希望开展大型高调项目，而“经济学家”则希望减少政府的控制和干预。与台湾不同，印尼直到20世纪80年代末才得以解决这一冲突，当时该国转向国际市场并放松管制。印尼的这一转变无疑受到了该地区其他国家开放政策的影响。其主要目标是摆脱对石油和天然气出口的过度依赖。当时印尼著名经济学家阿里·瓦尔达纳（Ali Wardhana）表示：“官僚必须承担新的角色。他们不应干预私人经济活动以控制私人经济主体，而应避免干预，并为私人活动提供便利。”

Many of the same basic interactions between government and market have played out in the other countries of the region, although refracted through their histories and cultures and the defining nature of their anticolonial struggles. In Indonesia, there was a long clash between two groups of technocrats—the “engineers,” who wanted to undertake big high-visibility projects, and the “economists,” who wanted to reduce government control and intervention. Unlike Taiwan, Indonesia was unable to resolve that clash until the late 1980s, when the country made a major turn toward the international market and deregulation. It was certainly influenced by the opening up of other countries in the region. Its major objective was to free itself from excessive dependence on oil and gas exports. “Bureaucrats must take on a new role,” said Ali Wardhana, one of the leading Indonesian economists, at the time. “Instead of intervening to control private economic agents, bureaucrats need to avoid intervention and facilitate private activity.”

该计划总体上是成功的。印尼如今已成为一个高增长国家，成功转型为重要的多元化出口国，摆脱了对石油和天然气出口的过度依赖。然而，印尼拥有2.03亿人口，分布在1.7万个岛屿上，因此它不像一些较小的亚洲国家那样拥有集中发展的资源。印尼面临着诸多重大问题，例如区域发展、教育与经济发展之间的联系、中国企业家的突出地位、公平和收入分配以及腐败问题。其政治体制也成为国际人权活动家的新目标。所有这一切都笼罩在苏哈托将军下台之后的阴影之下。苏哈托将军于1965年在即将发生共产党政变的情况下夺取政权，此后一直通过实质上的一党制维持着统治。

The program has generally worked. Indonesia is now a high-growth country that has successfully moved toward being a significant diversified exporter and away from a heavy reliance on oil and natural gas exports. With 203 million people spread over seventeen thousand islands, however, it does not have the same kind of focus that the smaller Asian countries enjoy. It faces major questions about regional development, the link between education and economic advancement, the prominent role of the Chinese entrepreneurs, equity and income distribution, and corruption. Its political system has become a new target for international human rights activists. Hanging over all of this is the question of what will follow the departure of General Suharto, who took power in the face of an imminent Communist coup in 1965 and has maintained control through an essentially one-party system ever since.

自20世纪80年代中期以来，泰国的增长主要得益于以日本为首的外国投资。该国经历了一些艰难的政治斗争，其核心是各军事和文职团体之间的权力斗争。但泰国在该地区国家中独树一帜，因为它拥有一位统治长达半个世纪的国王——普密蓬·阿朱利耶德，他在各种危机中为国家带来了持续的稳定、合法性和道德良知。泰国的基础设施——道路、例如，污染控制方面的发展速度并没有跟上国民生产总值快速增长的速度。

Thailand’s growth since the mid-1980s was propelled by foreign investment, led by the Japanese. The country went through some tough political battles, centered on a struggle for power between various military and civilian groups. But Thailand is unique among the countries in the region in that it has had a king, Bhumibol Adjulyadej, who has ruled for half a century and provided continuing stability and legitimacy—and moral conscience—through the various crises. Thailand is a classic case in which the infrastructure—roads, and pollution control, for example—has not kept pace with the rapid rise in the GNP.

自上世纪90年代初以来，政府一直试图通过大规模私有化来减少其在经济中的作用。前总理阿南德·班雅拉春表示：“推行私有化政策有两个原因，一是必要性，二是审慎性。国有企业要想生存和发展，就需要注入更多国家资金。即使企业盈利，国家也无力承担这笔费用。公众要求政府精简，去除臃肿机构，不希望看到国有企业继续沦为国家就业机构，既没有提高生产力，也没有长远发展潜力。” 阿南德还谈到推动私有化的另一个因素：“共产主义制度的终结也是推动全球走向自由市场的重要因素。随着共产主义国家的崩溃以及政府控制的瓦解，我对资本主义失败的所有担忧以及我对国家主导地位的信念都烟消云散了。”

Since the early 1990s, the government has sought to reduce its role in the economy through large-scale privatization. “The policy of privatization was carried out for two reasons, necessity and prudence,” said former prime minister Anand Panyarachun. “State companies needed the injection of more state funds if they were to survive and grow. The state could not afford to do that even if companies were profitable. The public was demanding leaner government, getting rid of the fat, and did not want to see state-owned companies to be continued as state employment agencies without any productivity effect or long-term potential.” Anand spoke of another force behind the move toward privatization: “The timing of the end of the communist system was also a major factor in propelling the global trend toward the free market. All fears of capitalism’s failures and my belief in the dominance of the state were cast aside with the collapse of the communist state and, with it, of government control.”

越南是共产主义仍然占据核心地位的国家。其人口超过台湾、韩国、马来西亚和新加坡的总和，有望跻身快速增长国家之列。越南拥有受过良好教育的人口，在许多方面都具备促进增长的条件。然而，越南的转型之路可能比该地区其他国家更为艰难，因为其体制的合法性和意识形态根植于越南战争以及对资本主义和西方的敌视。拥抱市场就意味着质疑政权的根基，而这绝非现任领导层所愿。因此，目前越南正处于国家主导和私人企业主导的摇摆不定状态。虽然存在市场经济，但私营部门尚未获得充分的自由，国有企业的改革也尚未真正启动。

The country for which communism remains the central fact is Vietnam. With a population bigger than Taiwan’s, Korea’s, Malaysia’s, and Singapore’s combined, it is poised to enter the league of the fast growers. It has a well-educated population and, in many ways, the attributes to spur growth. Yet its transition is likely to be more difficult than that of the other countries in the region, for the system’s legitimacy and ideology are rooted in the Vietnam War and a hostility to capitalism and the West. To embrace the market would be to call into question the fundaments of the regime, which is hardly something that the current leadership wants to do. Thus, for the time being, Vietnam is suspended between state domination and private initiative. There is a market system, but the private sector has not been freed up, nor has reform of state enterprises begun in earnest.

或许，东亚经济增长是一个全面、区域性现象的最有力佐证来自菲律宾。几十年来，菲律宾的经济远未发挥其应有的潜力。社会不平等现象极其严重。政府是地主精英的独裁统治，臭名昭著、挥霍无度的费迪南德·马科斯执掌政权。与其他东亚地区的独裁领导人不同，马科斯很少将他非法所得的财富投入国内经济。相反，他和他的亲信将财富藏匿在瑞士银行，并在海外挥霍。他妻子伊梅尔达的数千双鞋子，成为了这个体制腐败的象征。

Perhaps the surest sign that East Asian growth is a comprehensive, regional phenomenon comes from the Philippines. For many decades, the country operated far beneath its economic potential. Social inequalities were extreme. The government was a dictatorship of the landed elite, with the notorious and profligate Ferdinand Marcos at the helm. Unlike other authoritarian leaders in the region, Marcos rarely channeled his ill-gotten wealth back into the local economy. Instead, he and his cronies stashed it in Swiss banks and spent it overseas. The thousands of pairs of shoes belonging to his wife, Imelda, came to symbolize the corruption of the system.

1986年，马科斯政权被科拉松·阿基诺领导的人民阵线推翻。她的丈夫贝尼尼奥·阿基诺是马科斯的公开反对者，三年前在马尼拉机场被马科斯的枪手暗杀。菲律宾长期以来饱受贸易和投资方面的质疑，其长期存在的腐败和混乱与该地区其他地区的快速增长形成鲜明对比。然而，在阿基诺夫人及其继任者菲德尔·拉莫斯的领导下，菲律宾实现了和平的政治转型，为菲律宾重新融入东南亚其他地区奠定了基础。阿基诺和拉莫斯该国调整了经济政策，使其与区域伙伴保持一致。得益于自由化的货币市场和贸易壁垒的降低，黑市活动有所减少。首都马尼拉仍然以高犯罪率、污染和贫困而闻名。然而，自1994年以来，该国经济持续保持4%或更高的增长率，并在解决长期电力短缺问题上取得了进展，已成为一个极具吸引力的新兴市场——一个名副其实的“亚洲四小龙”——并且正在缩小与邻国之间的差距。11

Marcos fell in 1986, overthrown by the popular front led by Corazón Aquino. Her husband, Benigno, an outspoken opponent of Marcos, had been assassinated three years earlier by Marcos gunmen when he landed at Manila’s airport. The Philippines remained a suspect destination for trade and investment, its chronic corruption and disorder contrasting with fast growth elsewhere in the region. Yet the peaceful political evolution under Mrs. Aquino and her successor, Fidel Ramos, set the stage for the Philippines to claim its connection to the rest of Southeast Asia. Aquino and Ramos brought economic policy into line with their regional partners. Thanks to freed currency markets and the lowering of trade barriers, the black market has become less pervasive. Manila, the capital, is still known for high crime, pollution, and poverty. Yet with sustained growth rates of 4 percent or higher since 1994, and having made progress toward ending its chronic electricity shortages, the country has become a newly attractive emerging market—a full-fledged “tiger”—and is narrowing the gap with its neighbors.11

亚洲公司？

Asia, Inc.?

整个东南亚地区的经济模式正在发生转变，各国政府在不同程度上减少了对经济的干预。其原因与其他地区有所不同——并非如其他地区那样源于幻灭感、失败感或严峻的经济现实。尽管不时遭遇挫折，但亚洲的变革在很大程度上是成功的必然结果。日益壮大的中产阶级渴望拥有更多参与权和更大的话语权。他们希望经济体系能够积极影响他们的日常生活；他们希望自身的增长和收入水平能够转化为生活质量的提升。经济的日益复杂化使得政府管理更加困难。竞争所需的创新、速度、灵活性和适应性都可能因官僚干预而受阻。

All across Southeast Asia, the economic model is changing as governments, to one degree or another, pull back from an interventionist role in the economy. The reasons for this are not the same as those to be found in other parts of the world—disillusionment, a sense of failure, harsh economic realities. Despite periodic setbacks, change in Asia is in large measure a consequence of success. The growing middle class wants more participation and a bigger say. Its members want the economic system to affect their daily lives positively; they want their growth and income levels to translate into an improving quality of life. The growing complexity of economies makes government management more difficult. The requirements of competition—innovation, speed, flexibility, and adaptability—can all be impeded by bureaucratic intervention.

许多国家日益担忧“空心化”（即工业实力的丧失），因为它们担心国内出口产业会因工资上涨和后方国家的崛起而失去竞争力。事实上，整个地区普遍弥漫着一种焦虑：曾经推动其发展的那些优势——低工资、技术娴熟且纪律严明的劳动力——可能会反过来成为它们的劣势，被其他国家抢占先机。这种担忧加剧了对投资的竞争，也加大了各国减少政府监管以降低成本、提高灵活性的压力。消费者和投资者都渴望在海外寻求更优的性价比。

A growing fear of “hollowing out”—losing their industrial strength—is gripping many of these nations as they worry that their domestic export industries will lose competitiveness, owing to rising wages and to the countries moving up behind them. Indeed, one finds a pervasive anxiety throughout the region that the same set of attributes that propelled their growth—low wages, a skilled and disciplined workforce—could work against them as other nations capture them in turn. That fear spurs the competition for investment, adding to the pressures to reduce government regulation in order to lower costs and increase flexibility. Consumers—and investors—are eager to look outside for better values.

具有讽刺意味的是，国家集团（Countries, Inc.）正受到亚洲集团（Asia, Inc.）——这个新兴的一体化区域经济体——的冲击，而亚洲集团将成为21世纪的核心特征。这一经济体在20世纪80年代中期开始形成，当时日本为寻求更低的成本，在亚洲的投资不断增加。在日本大规模涌入美国和欧洲的采购活动遭遇挫折后，这股投资热潮加速发展。这使得亚洲成为日本企业的出口平台，同时也成为其市场。“日本投资是变革的催化剂，”泰国前总理阿南·班雅拉春（Anand Panyarachun）表示，“泰国决定制定具有竞争力的条件来吸引日本投资，而不是眼睁睁地看着它们流向马来西亚、印度尼西亚或其他东南亚国家。这是一项果断的政策，旨在吸引投资日元，并创建一个更加开放的外国投资环境。这代表着……”这是泰国有意为之，旨在帮助建立区域市场并参与其中。

Ironically, Countries, Inc. is being undermined by the growth of Asia, Inc., the new integrated regional economy, which will be a central fact of the twenty-first century. This economy began to take shape in the middle 1980s, as Japanese investment in Asia mounted, seeking lower costs. The flow accelerated after Japan’s huge shopping spree in the United States and Europe came to grief. It has made Asia into an export platform—as well as a market—for Japanese companies. “Japanese investment was a catalyst for change,” said Anand Panyarachun, Thailand’s former prime minister. “Thailand decided to establish competitive terms to attract Japanese investment in our country rather than see it go to Malaysia, Indonesia, or elsewhere in Southeast Asia. It was a decisive policy to seek that investment yen and to create a more open economy for foreign investment. It represented a conscious move on Thailand’s part to try to help establish a regional market and to be part of it.”

日本的资本输出极大地促进了亚洲经济体的融合，但韩国、台湾和香港也已成为该地区的重要投资者，它们和日本一样，都在寻求更低的成本。随着这些国家彼此成为重要的市场，区域内贸易迅速增长。企业和企业家不断增加跨境投资，而本土跨国公司的崛起也进一步加强了区域联系。与此同时，经济的快速增长使数千万人成为消费者。人们对选择和生活质量日益增长的需求，正促使社会的经济逻辑从生产逻辑转向消费逻辑。许多“国家公司”（Countrystals, Inc.）的人口相对较少，因此，亚洲区域经济使它们能够进入更大的市场，而它们本身也是该市场的一部分，这有助于它们实现规模化发展。

Japan’s capital exports did much to tie the Asian economies together, but Korea, Taiwan, and Hong Kong have also become big investors throughout the region, seeking, like the Japanese, lower costs. Trade within the region has grown quickly as these countries become important markets for each other. Companies and entrepreneurs have been increasing their own cross-border stakes, while the rise of locally based multinationals is also tying the region together. Meanwhile, rapid economic growth has turned tens of millions of people into consumers. The growing demands for choice and quality of life are shifting the economic rationale of societies from a producer logic to a consumer logic. Many of the Countries, Inc. have relatively small populations, so the regional Asian economy gives them access to a larger market, of which they are part, which helps them get to scale.

还有一种独特的因素为区域经济提供了活力——那就是“桥对岸的华人”（ hua ch'ia）之间的联系。这些华人居住在东南亚各地，从事贸易、投资和合作。他们已成为一股重要的经济力量，不仅将各地经济紧密联系在一起，也削弱了政府的控制。据估计，东南亚约有2500万华人。他们在马来西亚占总人口的32%，在泰国占15%，在印度尼西亚占4%，在菲律宾占1%。华人在商业和创业领域扮演着举足轻重的角色；他们拥有12个身价超过50亿美元的家族，据估计，他们掌控的资产至少有2万亿美元。他们以无需合同、律师、银行家和顾问就能完成交易而闻名——即便交易金额高达数十亿美元。基于亲缘关系的规则取代了合同法在其他地方的作用，促进了贸易、投资和资本流动。他们的国民生产总值（GNP）——这是一个有点比喻性的概念——估计为 4500 亿美元，这将使他们作为一个独立的国家成为世界第九大经济体。

Something else provides unique sinews for the regional economy—the connections among the hua ch’ia (“the Chinese across the bridge”), the ethnic Chinese who live, trade, invest, and collaborate across the region. They have proved to be a major force, tying economies together as well as lessening government control. An estimated 25 million Chinese live in Southeast Asia. They make up 32 percent of the population in Malaysia, 15 percent in Thailand, 4 percent in Indonesia, and 1 percent in the Philippines. The ethnic Chinese have an inordinately large entrepreneurial and commercial role; they boast twelve families worth $5 billion or more and are estimated to control at least $2 trillion. They are famous for doing their deals without contracts, lawyers, bankers, and consultants—even when values run into the billions of dollars. Kinship-based rules of the game assume the role that contract law performs elsewhere, facilitating trade, investment, and the movement of capital. Their collective GNP—a somewhat metaphorical concept—has been estimated at $450 billion, which would make them, as a separate country, the world’s ninth-largest economy.

区域发展固然证明了“国家公司”的成功，但也削弱了各国继续以“国家公司”模式运作的能力。由于经济活动的范围——投资、联盟、贸易、市场发展——已超越国家主权的边界，政府的管理和干预能力也随之下降，因此，运用政府知识和发挥指导作用变得更加困难。其结果是出现了一种新的混合体，其特征是私有化和放松管制程度更高、规则更少、控制力更弱、保护力度降低。与此同时，各国政府面临着承担协调区域内各国经济关系的新角色的压力。目前的合作框架是东盟（东南亚国家联盟），它于上世纪七八十年代发展起来，最初是作为对抗中国（尤其是越南）共产主义的政治堡垒。如今，它的使命已不再局限于政治层面。事实上，具有讽刺意味的是，越南也是近期才加入东盟的。

While the regional development is testament to the success of Countries, Inc., it also reduces the ability of nations to continue to run themselves as Countries, Inc. It becomes more difficult to deploy government knowledge and to exert the guiding hand, for the span of economic activity—investment, alliances, trade, market development—extends beyond the borders of national sovereignty, and thus beyond the ability of governments to manage and intervene as they did in earlier and, by comparison, simpler times. The result is a new mixture, featuring greater privatization and deregulation, fewer rules, less control, and reduced protection. At the same time, governments are facing pressure to take on the new role of coordinator of economic relations among the nations of the region. The current framework for cooperation is ASEAN, the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, which grew up during the 1970s and 1980s as a political bulwark against communism in China and, more so, in Vietnam. Its vocation is no longer exclusively political. Indeed, ironically, Vietnam is a recent admittee.

区域一体化带来风险。随着亚洲各经济体的融合，要保持其和谐共存，需要更加复杂的协调机制。爆炸式增长以及贸易和投资壁垒的消除，带来了新的区域性风险——经济过热和过度放贷、对外部资本流动的依赖、人为支撑的金融体系、货币高估以及投机行为。1997年下半年，东南亚爆发了一场严重的货币危机，这些风险都显露无疑。危机始于泰国，其根源在于房地产泡沫破裂、银行业疲软、外债高企以及鼓励过度借贷的固定汇率制度。危机迅速导致马来西亚林吉特、印尼盾和菲律宾比索遭受重创，并引发区域股市暴跌。这场危机的背后，是人们更深层次的担忧：面对不断上涨的工资和日益激烈的竞争，这些国家的竞争力正在削弱，它们最终可能会陷入“中等技术”的尴尬境地。金融危机引发了诸多指责，其中最激烈的莫过于马来西亚总理马哈蒂尔·穆罕默德的抨击。他指责国际投机者犯下了“卑鄙的破坏行为”和“国际犯罪的巅峰”。尽管马哈蒂尔的言辞尖锐，但他确实道出了该地区许多人的震惊：他们不仅意识到自身面临的风险，更意识到自身在一体化的全球金融体系中，面对资金波动和有时剧烈的流动时，是多么脆弱。在他们看来，货币攻击抹去了他们几十年来辛辛苦苦积累的20%到30%的国家财富。

Regional integration brings risk. It will take even more complex coordination to keep the dynamic economies of Asia, Inc., in harmony as they integrate. Explosive growth and the removal of barriers to trade and investment have brought new regional dangers—overheating and overlending, dependence on external capital flows, artificially propped up financial systems, overvalued currencies, and speculation. This was all too evident in the second half of 1997, when a severe currency crisis swept over Southeast Asia. It began in Thailand, brought on by the bursting of a real estate bubble, a weak banking sector, high foreign debt, and a fixed currency that encouraged expansive borrowing and lending. It quickly led to attacks on the Malaysian ringgit, the Indonesian rupiah, and the Philippine peso—and dramatic collapse in regional stock markets. Underlying the crisis was the deeper apprehension that the competitive strengths of these nations were eroding in the face of rising wages and a new intensified competition, and that they might end up caught in a sort of no-man’s-land of “middle technology.” The financial crisis generated many recriminations. By far the most vocal came from Mahathir Mohamad. The prime minister of Malaysia blamed international speculators for “villainous acts of sabotage” and “the height of international criminality.” Despite the acerbity of his comments, Mahathir did capture the shock that many in the region felt on discovering not only their exposure but their vulnerability to the volatile and sometimes drastic movements of money in an integrated global financial system. As they saw it, the currency attacks wiped out 20 or 30 percent of the national wealth that had been laboriously built over several decades.

但国际金融体系的制度性力量也伸出了援手。亚洲各国政府发起了一项区域性干预行动——由日本牵头，包括中国在内的其他亚洲国家也参与其中，总额达172亿美元的救助计划——以稳定泰铢汇率，遏制这场现代意义上的“多米诺骨牌”危机。国际货币基金组织不得不介入，帮助恢复金融平衡。随后，印尼获得了230亿美元的救助。为了改善国际收支状况和提升金融信誉，许多国家政府迅速宣布削减耗资巨大且引人注目的投资项目。与此同时，货币贬值也增强了它们在世界市场上的竞争力。至少在一些人看来，这场危机也为过热的经济降温。“律师、会计师和工程师纷纷辞职，涌入股市，”一位马来西亚商人观察到，“从长远来看，6%的增长率或许比8%更好。它更容易掌控。”

But the institutional side of the international financial system also came to their rescue. Asian governments mounted a regional intervention—a $17.2 billion bailout led by Japan, in which the other countries of the region, including China, participated—to stabilize the Thai baht and contain a “domino” crisis of a modern type. The International Monetary Fund had to be called in to help restore financial equilibrium. A $23 billion bailout of Indonesia followed. In order to improve their balance of payments and financial credibility, many governments quickly announced cutbacks in expensive and visible investment projects. At the same time, the devaluation of currencies renewed their competitive position in world markets. And at least as some saw it, the crisis also cooled off overheated economies. “Lawyers, accountants, and engineers were resigning their positions to go into the stock market,” observed a Malay businessman. “We may be better off in the long run with 6 rather than 8 percent growth. It’s more manageable.”

该地区各国过去曾经历过一系列货币和资本市场危机。具有讽刺意味的是，最近这次危机的影响恰恰表明了它们取得了多大的进步，因为此前的危机都没有像这次一样引起如此广泛的关注，也没有像这次一样产生如此区域性和国际性的影响。一些人认为1997年的危机与日本“泡沫经济”的破裂有相似之处。他们担心，薄弱的金融部门、过度建设的房地产和过剩的工业产能意味着，即使奇迹发生，未来仍将面临艰难的经济时期。然而，其中一个显著特征是……这些国家多年来的优势在于它们的灵活性和适应性，而现在的形势为它们提供了再次重组经济并恢复持续增长的机会。

The countries in the region have gone through a series of currency and capital-markets crises in the past. Ironically, the impact of the latest is a sign of how far they have come, for none before had either the visibility or the regional and international repercussions. Some see in the 1997 crisis similarities to the bursting of the Japanese “bubble.” They fear that weak financial sectors, overbuilt real estate, and industrial overcapacity will mean that difficult economic times lie beyond the miracle. Yet one ofthe hallmarks of these countries over the years has been their flexibility and adaptability, and necessity now provides the opportunity for them to once again restructure their economies and return to sustained growth.

在亚洲各地，人们经常听到这样一句话——该地区各国需要找到一种“新的模式”。这是一个令人沮丧、难以捉摸且抽象的术语，但它反映了一种信念：政府与市场之间必须达成新的平衡，这种平衡不仅要考虑到国家自身的需求，还要兼顾新的区域经济环境的必然要求。这些国家已经证明自己是竞争高手，但新的竞争压力正在推动变革。尤其值得一提的是，中国和印度这两个主导该地区的巨头即将带来的竞争，极有可能对各国未来的发展格局产生巨大影响。12

Throughout Asia, one encounters a recurrent phrase—the countries of the region, it is said, need to find a “new modality.” It is a frustratingly elusive and abstract term, but it reflects a conviction that a new balance has to be struck between government and marketplace that takes into account not only national needs but also the imperatives of the new regional economic context. These countries have proved to be expert competitors, but new competitive pressures are driving a change. In particular, it is highly likely that the future of Countries, Inc. will be dramatically affected by the coming competition from the two giants that bestride the region: China and India.12

第七章

CHAPTER 7

1920年12月，当法国邮轮停靠马赛港时，船上的大多数中国留学生茫然不知所措，茫然地站在那里。然而，其中一位却立刻忙碌起来，整理行李，安排下船事宜。这位年仅十六岁的年轻人正是邓小平，他当时已展现出卓越的领导才能，而这种才能将在六十年后使他成为中国举足轻重的人物。在二十世纪的最后二十年里，他引领中国走上了在共产主义政治体制下建立资本主义经济的道路，并使中国成为全球经济的重要力量。令人瞩目的是，当他最终成为最高领导人并开启中国改革开放时代时，他已七十四岁高龄。同样令人钦佩的是，在他最终掌权之前，他面对着巨大的挫折、挑战、匮乏和失宠，所展现出的非凡韧性。

WHEN THE FRENCH LINER docked in Marseilles in December 1920, most of the group of Chinese students on board stood about dazed, confused, not knowing what to do. One, however, was immediately busy, organizing their luggage, arranging their disembarkation. The young man, just sixteen, was Deng Xiaoping, and he was already demonstrating the take-charge organizational skills that would make him the dominating figure in China sixty years later. In the last two decades of the twentieth century, he would set his country on a course to create a capitalist economy within a communist political system and turn it into a major force in the global economy. This was remarkable in that he was seventy-four when he finally became the paramount leader and launched China on its era of reform. No less remarkable was the extraordinary resilience he displayed in the face of the enormous setbacks, challenges, deprivations, and falls from favor that preceded his final rise to power.

邓小平出生于四川省，一个富裕的地主家庭，后来成为地方官员。四川是人口稠密的内陆省份。邓小平幼时就读于传统的儒家学校，但随着1911年辛亥革命后社会动荡，他转学到一所课程更为现代且与法国联系紧密的学校。也正因如此，他被送往法国深造。他在法国的学业断断续续，做过许多工作，包括在雷诺汽车厂、钢铁厂和橡胶厂工作，也当过厨房帮工和火车司炉。在法国，他培养了两大爱好——一是羊角面包，二是共产主义。这两者并非毫无关联：正是后来成为北越领导人的胡志明告诉他，巴黎哪里能买到最好的羊角面包。

Deng was the son of a prosperous landowner-turned-local-government-official in the populous inland province of Sichuan. As a boy, he started in a traditional Confucian school, but then, amid the tumult and fragmentation that followed the Chinese Revolution of 1911, switched into a school equipped with both a more modern curriculum and links to France. That is how he came to be sent to France for further study. His education there proved to be spotty, and he held a number of jobs, working in a Renault plant and steel and rubber factories, and also doing time as a kitchen hand and as a fireman on a locomotive. He developed two lasting passions in France—one was for croissants; the other was for communism. The two were not totally unconnected: It was Ho Chi Minh, later the leader of North Vietnam, who would tell him where in Paris to get the best croissants.

在欧洲少数中国留学生中传播共产主义思想，其灵感源于1919年5月4日在北京天安门广场爆发的五四运动。这场运动旨在抗议凡尔赛条约后中国遭受的外国统治带来的屈辱。共产主义成为中国民族主义的有力载体，对邓小平而言更成为一种毕生追求。他的主要赞助人和导师之一是周恩来。周恩来在日本求学期间深受马克思主义思想的影响，之后移居法国，成为欧洲规模很小的中国共产主义运动的领导人之一。多年后，邓小平称周恩来为“我的兄长”。周恩来也像一位慈兄，在20世纪60年代的文化大革命中竭力保护邓小平免受最残酷的迫害。在法国求学期间，周恩来让邓小平负责制作共产主义通讯，这让他被戏称为“油印学博士”。 1926年2月，法国人突袭了邓小平居住的房屋，但为时已晚。他前一天已经前往莫斯科。

The spread of communism among the handful of Chinese students in Europe was inspired by the May 4 Movement in Beijing, which had erupted in Tiananmen Square on May 4, 1919, to protest the humiliation of foreign domination of China in the aftermath of the Versailles treaty. Communism became a powerful vehicle for Chinese nationalism. For Deng it became a vocation. One of his chief sponsors and mentors was Zhou Enlai, who had imbibed Marxism while a student in Japan, before moving to France and becoming a leader of the tiny Chinese communist movement in Europe. Years later Deng was to call Zhou “my elder brother,” and Zhou, as a good older brother, would shield Deng from the worst excesses of the Cultural Revolution of the 1960s. During their French student days, Zhou put Deng in charge of producing the communist newsletter, which led to his being jokingly granted a Ph.D. in mimeographing. In February 1926, the French raided the house where Deng lived, but they were too late. He had left for Moscow the day before.

在莫斯科，邓小平先后就读于东方劳动大学和中山大学。那时，中国的民族主义者和共产党人还是合作伙伴，而非敌人。他们的共同目标是中国的现代化和复兴。斯大林的国际机构——共产国际——正在指导民族主义者如何建立革命政党，而中国共产党的成员也积极参与民族主义活动。富有的民族主义者资助在莫斯科培养年轻的革命者，以期重振中国的尊严。邓小平的同学中就有蒋经国，他是国民党领袖蒋介石的儿子。多年以后，在20世纪80年代，蒋经国接替其父，成为台湾地区领导人。

In Moscow, Deng studied at the University of the Toilers of the East and Sun Yat-sen University. These were the days when China’s nationalists and communists were collaborators and not yet enemies. Their shared objective was China’s modernization and renewal. The Comintern, Stalin’s international apparatus, was teaching the nationalists how to construct a revolutionary party, and members of the Chinese Communist Party were also active nationalists. Wealthy nationalists were financing the training of young revolutionaries in Moscow who would restore China’s dignity. Among Deng’s fellow students was Chiang Ching-kuo, son of the Nationalist Party leader Chiang Kai-shek. Much later, in the 1980s, the younger Chiang would succeed his father as president of Taiwan.

邓小平回到中国时，已成为一名坚定的共产主义者，准备将毕生奉献给革命。他的组织能力很快使他步步高升。23岁时，他已是中共中央总书记，之后又深入农村从事组织工作。当时的中国正处于动荡不安的混乱之中。军阀混战，争夺各地控制权，国民党与共产党的联盟也因权力斗争而破裂。共产党内部派系林立，冲突不断，甚至演变成流血冲突。邓小平追随周恩来，加入了毛泽东领导的派系。后来，毛泽东在共产党内部的敌人一度将邓小平监禁审讯，很可能对他施以酷刑，并多次试图逼迫他承认所谓的政治“罪行”。

Deng returned to China a convinced communist, prepared to dedicate his life to the revolution. His organizational skills quickly carried him forward. By the age of twenty-three he was chief secretary of the Central Committee of the Communist Party and then became an organizer in the countryside. China was in violent disarray. Warlords were battling for control of various regions, and the nationalists’ alliance with the communists broke down as they competed for power. The Communist Party itself was riven by deep factional splits that spilled over into bloodshed. Deng, following Zhou, allied himself with the faction led by Mao Zedong. At one point, Mao’s enemies within the communist movement imprisoned and interrogated Deng, probably tortured him, and repeatedly tried to force him to recant political “crimes.”

邓小平曾参与1934-35年的长征，这是毛泽东领导的为躲避国民党军队而进行的六千英里长途跋涉。在这段艰辛的征程中，共产党军队遭受了毁灭性的打击。长征开始时，共产党军队有九万人，最终只剩下五千人。然而，正是这段经历，为共产党提供了神话和凝聚力，并在之后的十五年里，帮助共产党取得了胜利，统治了整个中国。

Deng was part of the Long March of 1934-35, the six-thousand-mile trek that Mao led to escape the nationalists. Over its harrowing course, the communists were decimated. The march began with ninety thousand communist soldiers and ended with a paltry five thousand. Yet that experience was to provide the myths and cohesion that, within a decade and a half, would help to carry the communists to victory and rule over all of China.

1937年日本侵华战争为……创造了条件。这场战争标志着共产党政权的复兴，也使邓小平成为一名军人。他的组织才能再次让他脱颖而出，先是抗击日本侵略者，后又在1945年后对抗国民党。他成为最杰出的军事领导人之一；事实上，他在淮海战役中发挥了关键作用，这场战役在1949年彻底击溃了国民党的军队。淮海战役歼灭了五十万国民党军队，被认为是二十世纪最重要的陆战之一。邓小平在战争中的角色提升了他的领导威望，并建立了一个关系网，这不仅巩固了他的政治地位，还在关键时刻保护了他。

The Japanese invasion of China in 1937 created the circumstances for the renewal of communist power vis-à-vis the nationalists. That war also turned Deng into a soldier. Once again his organizational talents brought him to the fore, first against the Japanese and then against the nationalists after 1945. He became one of the most prominent military leaders; indeed, he played a key role in the Huai-Hai campaign, which broke the back of the nationalists in 1949. This battle, which destroyed a nationalist army of five hundred thousand, is considered one of the most important land battles of the twentieth century. Deng’s wartime role enhanced his credibility as a leader and established a network of relationships and connections that would bolster his political position and—at crucial times—protect him.

在战时执掌位于中国西北太行地区的邓小平时期，他也提出了一系列务实的经济方针，这些方针预示了他20世纪80年代和90年代的政策。他认为经济激励是必要的。“有些同志说这太过分了，但我不同意，”他在战时对高级干部说，“如果他们是通过自己的劳动而不是贪污获得的，那就完全合适。那些懒惰、不积极的人就应该受到惩罚。”经济变革应该循序渐进；人民应该直接感受到经济利益。而且——至关重要的是——社会主义依赖于正确的组织和经济实力，必须建立在“资本主义生产”的基础上。换句话说，资本主义并非社会主义的绝对敌人。但邓小平始终坚持的是，他认为党是实现现代化的必要工具。1

During his wartime administration of the Taihang region, in northwest China, Deng also laid out a set of pragmatic economic precepts that would prefigure his policies of the 1980s and the 1990s. Economic incentives were appropriate. “Some comrades say this is too much, but I don’t agree,” he told senior cadres during the war. “If they’ve acquired it through their own labor and not corruption it’s entirely appropriate. Those who are lazy and unenthusiastic should suffer.” Economic change should come gradually; people should feel the benefits directly. And—of critical importance—socialism depends upon proper organization and economic strength, and must be built upon “capitalist production.” In other words, capitalism was not the total enemy of socialism. But where Deng did not waver was in seeing the party as the necessary instrument of modernization.1

捉老鼠

Catching Mice

1949年战胜国民党、中华人民共和国成立后，邓小平成为中共最高领导人之一。他担任总书记，位列党内第四。1957年毛泽东率团访问莫斯科时，他指着邓小平对苏联领导人赫鲁晓夫说：“看到那个小个子了吗？他非常聪明，将来必成大器。”

After the victory over the nationalists in 1949 and the establishment of the People’s Republic of China, Deng emerged as one of the most senior leaders of the Communist Party. He became secretary-general and number four in the hierarchy. When Mao led a delegation to Moscow in 1957, he pointed Deng out to Nikita Khrushchev, the Soviet leader, and said, “See that little man there? He’s highly intelligent and has a great future ahead of him.”

邓小平虽然对毛泽东忠心耿耿，但在毛泽东发起大跃进时却选择了袖手旁观。大跃进的目的是为了引导“群众”的热情，使中国在十五年内完成资本主义国家用了150年才完成的事情，并实现对农村的完全控制。全国各地的农民被集中到管理严格的公社中，家庭作坊式的炼铁炉成为了大跃进的象征。然而，事实证明，大跃进却是一场灾难。由于完全无视基本的经济规律，大跃进非但没有促进中国经济发展，反而导致数千万人死于饥荒，农业、工业生产和国内贸易——所有这些都彻底崩溃了——急剧下降。

Deng, for his part, remained deeply loyal to Mao, though he stood aside when Mao launched the Great Leap Forward. It was supposed to channel the enthusiasm of the “masses” so that China could do in fifteen years what the capitalist nations had taken 150 years to accomplish—and to secure complete control over the countryside. Farmers throughout the country were herded into regimented communes, and backyard pig iron furnaces became the symbols of the Great Leap. As it turned out, however, it proved to be a great leap into disaster. Undertaken without any regard for fundamental economics, it did nothing to advance China’s economy On the contrary, tens of millions of people died of starvation as agricultural and industrial production and internal trade—all totally disrupted—plummeted.

邓小平是负责收拾残局的主要人物之一。逐步投资将取代大规模动员；教育和专业知识也至关重要。再次受到尊重。正是在这个时候，并不以格言著称的邓小平发表了他最著名的言论：“猫是黑的还是白的，只要能抓老鼠就行。”尽管他后来表示自己并不确定这句话的确切含义，但这显然是在大跃进狂热之后，对经济政策务实主义的一种肯定。这句话也引起了全世界的共鸣。

Deng was one of the chief figures who had to pick up the pieces. Gradual investment was to replace mass mobilization; education and expertise were again to be respected. It was at this time that Deng, not known for his aphorisms, made his most famous statement: “It doesn’t matter whether a cat is black or white so long as it catches mice.” Although he himself would later say he was not sure exactly what he had meant, it was very clearly an affirmation of pragmatism in economic policy in the aftermath of the fanaticism of the Great Leap. It was also a phrase that would find resonance around the world.

这种务实精神在20世纪60年代中期毛泽东发动文化大革命时，成了邓小平的攻击目标。毛泽东对国内缺乏意识形态热情深感不满，而且显然对自己作为最高领导人不再受到应有的尊崇感到非常愤怒。毛泽东抱怨邓小平及其同僚“把我当成葬礼上的亡父”。为了报复，毛泽东动员青年对既有秩序​​发起猛烈攻击。文化大革命的首要目标是党。这在邓小平看来是异端邪说。在他看来，团结的共产党是中国复兴的基石。文化大革命的混乱威胁着他自20世纪20年代初以来毕生致力于的一切。有人曾递给他一本毛主席语录——文化大革命的“圣经”，邓小平断然拒绝。而他本人则被攻击为“走资派”，遭受了残酷的迫害；他被单独监禁了两年。他和妻子都被安排到一家拖拉机修理厂工作。他的儿子因红卫兵的殴打而瘫痪。邓小平之所以没有遭遇更糟糕的境遇，是因为他在军队中建立的人脉关系以及与“兄长”周恩来的私人情谊。

This pragmatism was held against him in the mid-1960s, when Mao launched the Cultural Revolution. Mao was deeply dissatisfied with the lack of ideological zeal in the country, and apparently very angry that he was no longer receiving the veneration due him as the paramount leader. Mao complained that Deng and his colleagues “had treated me like I was their dead parent at a funeral.” In revenge, Mao mobilized young people in a savage assault on the established order. The number-one target of the Cultural Revolution was the party. This was heresy to Deng. For him, the united Communist Party was the foundation of China’s regeneration. The chaos of the Cultural Revolution threatened everything he had devoted his life to since the early 1920s. Once offered a copy of Mao’s Little Red Book, the bible of the Cultural Revolution, Deng unceremoniously turned it away. For his part, Deng was attacked as a “capitalist roader” and subjected to intense abuse; he spent two years in solitary confinement. He and his wife were both put to work in a tractor repair plant. His son was paralyzed as a result of a physical assault by Red Guards. What saved Deng from even worse was the network he had established through the army and his personal camaraderie with his “elder brother,” Zhou Enlai.

20世纪70年代初，文化大革命结束后，邓小平重返领导岗位。在被软禁期间，他曾无数次在院子里踱步，思考现代化失败的原因以及如何才能重振现代化。如今，他终于可以将自己苦心钻研的结论付诸实践，指导经济复苏。他回归了自己之前所推崇的原则——教育和经济激励，而非意识形态和说教。然而，邓小平因向资本主义低头而饱受批评，毛泽东再次反对他，导致他被剥夺了权力。周恩来去世后，邓小平的处境岌岌可危，他被迫签署了又一份自我批评声明。他被描绘成各种邪恶的化身——从反革命分子到试图破坏光荣革命的“毒草”。但他的老战友们再次出手相助。

In the early 1970s, after the Cultural Revolution had run its course, he came back into the leadership. During his time in confinement, he had spent many hours pacing the courtyard, asking himself how modernization had failed and how it could be restored. Now he could put his hard-earned conclusions to work as he helped direct the economic recovery. He returned to the principles he had favored before—education and economic incentives rather than ideology and exhortation. But criticism mounted against Deng for bowing to capitalism, and once again, with Mao against him, he was stripped of power. The death of Zhou made Deng’s position very precarious, and he was forced to sign yet another self-criticism. He was portrayed as everything evil—from a counterrevolutionary to a “poisonous weed” who was trying to undermine the glorious revolution. But again his old comrades from the army shielded him.

1976年毛泽东的逝世使邓小平重获自由。策划文化大革命的“四人帮”（包括毛泽东的妻子）被捕，邓小平重返权力中心。他随即投身于毛泽东逝世后随之而来的激烈斗争。华国锋是毛泽东指定的接班人。“有你掌权，我就放心了。”毛泽东曾这样对华国锋说。然而，邓小平却挑战了以“什么都行”著称的华国锋。（“毛主席的任何决定，我们都坚决支持。”）华春莹说：“毛主席的任何指示，我们都将坚定不移地执行。”邓小平意识到，如果他注定要迎来属于自己的时刻，那就是现在。他动用一切可用资源与华春莹展开斗争。到1978年底，华春莹被赶下台，邓小平成为中国最高领导人。然而，他又一次面临着收拾残局的重任。他将以此为基础，为中国真正的大跃进奠定基础。

The death of Mao in 1976 liberated Deng. The “Gang of Four” (including Mao’s wife), who had masterminded the Cultural Revolution, were arrested; and Deng returned to the center of power. He immediately became engaged in the bitter struggles that followed Mao’s death. Hua Guofeng was Mao’s designated successor. “With you in charge, I’m at ease,” Mao had told Hua. Deng, however, challenged Hua, who was known as the “chief whateverist.” (“Whatever decisions Chairman Mao made, we resolutely support,” said Hua. “Whatever instructions Chairman Mao made, we will stead-fastly abide by.”) If he was to have his moment, Deng realized, this was it. He carried out the battle against Hua with every resource available to him. By the end of 1978, Hua was out, and Deng emerged as China’s paramount leader. Yet again he was in the position of picking up the pieces. Out of them he would lay the foundations for China’s real great leap forward.

在后来的历史中，1978年12月与1911年中国革命和1949年共产党胜利一样，成为20世纪中国历史上的重大转折点之一。中共十一大三中全会于当月召开。尽管在全会前后几个月也做出了一系列重大决定，但此次全会最根本的决定是：中国经济转向市场经济。
