India developed a very large cadre of highly talented scientists and engineers, but, as in the Soviet Union, there were major obstacles to deploying new technologies in the marketplace. The hostility toward foreign investment, the severe limits on international trade, and the constraints on competition all closed down the avenues by which innovation moves into nations. India fell behind technologically. Often, technology was frozen at the level at which it had been in the 1950s or 1960s.

王朝

The Dynasty

英迪拉·甘地几乎没有对她父亲制定的经济政策路线进行任何调整。事实上，她从小就学会了如何运用权力。她十八岁时母亲去世，因此，英迪拉成为了尼赫鲁的知己、女主人和出访时的随行伙伴。作为总理，她展现出了老练和精明，但也目光短浅。她魅力四射却又傲慢自大，凭借印度在对巴基斯坦的军事胜利以及1974年印度成功引爆核装置，她赢得了极高的个人声望。然而，在国内，她将政治权力集中于自己手中，挑战了印度民主的底线。她削弱了各邦的权力，增强了联邦政府（或“中央政府”）的权力。她还边缘化了国大党内的异见人士，导致许多人叛党并组建了其他政党。1975年，法院指控她在家乡选区存在轻微的选举违规行为。她勃然大怒，宣布全国进入紧急状态，暂停公民自由，并实施审查制度——这是印度唯一一次尝试威权统治。但公众的强烈抗议迫使她在1977年做出让步，举行大选，结果惨败。然而，取代她的乌合之众组成的联合政府几乎从一开始就失去了方向。其经济政策混乱不堪，正是在这段时期，许多国际公司……由于担心被国有化，她决定离开印度。联合政府因无休止的争吵而垮台。到了1980年，她的声誉受损，但个人魅力依旧，“G夫人”再次掌权。

Indira Gandhi did little to adjust the lines of economic policy that her father had established.1Indeed, she had learned power from an early age. Her mother had died when she was eighteen, and as a result it was Indira who became Nehru’s confidante, hostess, and travel companion on official visits. As prime minister, she would prove crafty and masterful—and also short-sighted. Charismatic but haughty, she earned considerable personal prestige from India’s military successes against Pakistan and from her country’s successful explosion of a nuclear device in 1974. At home, however, she centralized political power around herself, straining the limits of India’s democracy. She eroded the powers of the states in favor of the federal (or “central”) government. And she marginalized dissidents in the Congress Party, causing many to defect and form rival parties. In 1975, the courts accused her of minor voting irregularities in her home district. Enraged, she declared a nationwide state of emergency, suspended civil liberties, and imposed censorship—India’s only experiment with authoritarian rule. But the public outcry was too great, and in 1977 she was forced to relent and call general elections, in which she was trounced. But the ragtag coalition that replaced her lost its bearings almost from the start. Its economic policies proved incoherent, and it was during this time that many international companies, fearing nationalization, decided to leave India. The coalition foundered on its endless squabbles. By 1980, her reputation tarnished but her charisma intact, “Mrs. G.” swept back into power.

但政治格局已然改变。国大党不再是不可战胜、绝对正确的，它在各邦的势力范围正在被地方利益集团蚕食。甘地夫人固执己见、毫不妥协的态度只会加剧紧张局势，助长部分地区的分裂主义，尤其是在北部旁遮普邦的锡克教社群中。1984年6月，她下令军队强攻锡克教最神圣的圣地——金庙，当时极端分子藏身于此。这成了她致命的错误。同年10月，她的锡克教保镖们展开报复；当她在总理府花园散步时，他们向她开枪，将她击毙。

But politics had changed. No longer invincible and infallible, the Congress Party was losing ground in the states—to regional interests. Mrs. Gandhi’s stubborn, uncompromising response only exacerbated tensions, fueling separatism in some areas, notably among the Sikh community in the northern state of Punjab. In June 1984, she ordered the army to storm the Golden Temple, the holiest of Sikh shrines, where extremists had taken refuge. It was her fatal mistake. The following October, her bodyguards, who were Sikhs, took revenge; they opened fire on her while she strolled in the prime ministerial garden, killing her.

甘地夫人显然期望她的幼子兼最亲密的顾问桑杰接任——尽管在紧急状态时期，桑杰的声誉受损，因为他被发现曾推行一项计划，该计划将村民集中起来，强迫他们接受绝育手术，以此换取晶体管收音机。然而，1980年，桑杰在驾驶轻型飞机时意外身亡。甘地夫人随后将重任交给了她的长子拉吉夫。拉吉夫先是接替了桑杰的位置，然后在母亲去世后，又接替了母亲的位置，成为国大党领袖。之后，凭借着民众的广泛同情，他当选为总理。拉吉夫性格内敛，为人谦逊，娶了一位意大利妻子，他对飞行的热情远胜于政治。他曾是印度航空公司（国内航空公司）的飞行员。在机上例行寒暄时，他会通过广播系统自称“拉吉夫机长”。

It had been very clear that Mrs. Gandhi expected Sanjay, her younger son and closest adviser, to succeed her—despite damage to his reputation during the emergency years, when he was found to have promoted a program that rounded up villagers and forced them to undergo medical sterilizations in exchange for transistor radios. But Sanjay was accidentally killed in 1980 while flying a light plane. Mrs. Gandhi had then turned to her older son, Rajiv. He stepped first into Sanjay’s place, and then, after his mother’s death, into hers, becoming leader of the Congress Party. Then, riding on a great wave of sympathy, he became prime minister. Rajiv was the quiet son, unassuming, married to an Italian, and much more passionate about flying than about politics. He had been a pilot for Indian Airlines, the domestic carrier. In the course of the normal in-flight pleasantries, he would simply announce himself over the PA system as Captain Rajiv.

在他担任总理期间，国有企业不断增加的亏损已演变为持续攀升的政府赤字。随着公共债务飙升，政府试图通过国内外借贷来弥补缺口。拉吉夫·甘地承诺改革许可证制度。他和他的相对年轻的顾问团队，被称为“电脑小子”，探讨了创新和自由市场的重要性。甘地也敏锐地意识到印度需要变革。为什么？毕竟，他是费边主义的后裔。有人认为，原因在于他是“第一位在政治之外从事过正直工作的总理。因此，他亲眼目睹，并通过他的朋友们了解了他理智上深恶痛绝并决心改变的体制。”

By the time he became prime minister, mounting losses by state-owned enterprises turned into steadily increasing government deficits. As public debt soared, the government tried to catch up by borrowing, both domestically and internationally. Rajiv Gandhi pledged to reform the Permit Raj. He and his relatively young advisers, known as the “computer kids,” talked about the importance of innovation and freer markets. Gandhi also had an intuitive feel that India needed to change. Why? After all, he was the grandson of Fabianism. The reason, it has been suggested, was that he was “the first prime minister to have done honest work outside politics. He thus had seen for himself, and through his friends, the system that he sensibly deplored and would seek to change.”

但当时并没有形成广泛的改革共识。各种改革方案遭到嘲讽和抨击，被指责为“损害普通民众利益”。甘地本人在最初的热情过后，似乎也失去了信念，尤其是在他的政府深陷与瑞典军火制造商有关的武器采购丑闻之后。改革的动力逐渐消退，甘地在1989年被选民赶下台。但他的政府留下了两个直接影响改革的后果——一个积极的，一个非常消极的。第一个后果是，一系列改革理念，无论多么温和，都得以浮出水面并被讨论。第二个后果，也是更严重的后果，是……重要的是，面对不断飙升的赤字，政府转向借贷，而这最终导致了危机。随着20世纪80年代末的临近，政府赤字不断攀升，偿债难度也越来越大。与此同时，由于债务负担日益加重，政府不得不削减投资，这意味着减少基础设施支出，这反过来又进一步抑制了经济增长。5

But there was no broad consensus to support reform. The various proposed measures were scorned and attacked as “against the common man.” And after his initial burst of enthusiasm, Gandhi himself seemed to lose conviction, especially as his government became immersed in a weapons-purchase scandal involving a Swedish arms maker. The drive to reform dissipated and Gandhi was turned out by the voters in 1989. But there were two consequences of his government that would directly affect reform—one positive, one very negative. The first was the surfacing and discussion of a set of reform ideas, however mild. The second, and more important, was the turn—in the face of soaring deficits—toward borrowing, which was what ultimately led to the crisis. As the end of the 1980s approached, the government’s deficit was mounting and it was harder and harder to service the debt. Meanwhile, because of the growing debt burden, it had to cut investment, which meant reducing spending on infrastructure, which, in turn, further choked back growth.5

甘地的继任者们因宗教和种姓问题引发的政治冲突而四分五裂，无力维持政权。拉吉夫发起了一场复出运动。但在1991年5月，他也遭到暗杀——在一次乡村竞选活动中，一名泰米尔自杀式炸弹袭击者为报复印度干预斯里兰卡内战而发动了袭击。

Gandhi’s successors, riven by political conflicts over religion and caste, were unable to keep their grip on power. Rajiv launched a comeback campaign. But in May 1991, he too was assassinated—at a village campaign stop, by a Tamil suicide bomber seeking revenge for Indian intervention in the Sri Lankan civil war.

国大党内一些人再次本能地将目光投向了尼赫鲁-甘地家族。但拉吉夫和桑贾伊都已去世，拉吉夫的孩子们还太小，而他的意大利妻子索尼娅虽然现在是印度公民，却立即退出了竞选。就这样，年迈的纳拉辛哈·拉奥当选为震惊的国大党主席。

Some in the Congress Party once again looked instinctively to the Nehru-Gandhi dynasty. But both Rajiv and Sanjay were now dead, Rajiv’s children were too young, and his Italian wife, Sonia, although now an Indian citizen, promptly ruled herself out of the race. Thus the elderly P. V Narasimha Rao was elected president of a shocked Congress Party.

危机

The Crisis

拉奥充其量只是个看守人。多年来，他一直是这个王朝的忠实仆人。作为国大党的一名干部，他曾担任过演讲稿撰写人，并担任过从外交部长到内政部长等一系列高级职务。他总是尽职尽责地完成自己的工作。即使在他的几个孩子居住在美国期间，他仍然会按照甘地夫人的要求，例行公事般地抨击美国。然而，他不仅是一位精明的政治家，也是一位成就斐然的人。他精通十几种语言，同时也是一名翻译家和诗人。他出身于安得拉邦一个婆罗门的小种姓。这个种姓的成员以其生存能力和卓越的学术成就而闻名，其中许多人居住在美国。

Rao looked to be at best a caretaker. For many years he had been a faithful servant of the dynasty. A Congress Party functionary and a sometime speechwriter, he had held a host of senior positions—from foreign minister to home secretary. He had always done what he was supposed to do. Even at a time when several of his children were living in America, he would deliver the ritualistic attacks on the United States that Mrs. Gandhi demanded of him. Yet he was not only a shrewd politician but also a man of considerable personal accomplishments. He knew a dozen languages and was also a translator and a poet. He came from a small Brahmin subcaste from the state of Andhra Pradesh. The members of the caste were known both for their talent for survival and for their intellectual achievements, and many of them lived in the United States.

拉吉夫遇刺时，拉奥已年届七十，正准备退休。由于他整个政治生涯都生活在甘地家族的阴影之下，他带着复杂的心情离开，或许是因为他觉得自己没有得到应有的认可。如果说他有什么怨恨的话，那就是对甘地夫人，她像对待身边许多人一样，对他百般辱骂和贬低。相比之下，拉吉夫却对他彬彬有礼、彬彬有礼。后来，拉奥私人住所的墙上挂满了拉吉夫的非正式照片，却没有一张他母亲的照片。

At the time of Rajiv’s assassination, Rao was seventy and had been preparing for retirement. As he had lived his entire political career in the shadow of the dynasty, he was going with certain mixed feelings, perhaps because he had not received the recognition that he felt he deserved. If he had bitterness, it was toward Mrs. Gandhi, who had abused and belittled him, as was her habit with many around her. Rajiv, by contrast, had treated him with respect and civility. Later, the walls of Rao’s private quarters would be adorned with informal photographs of Rajiv but with none of Rajiv’s mother.

由于拉吉夫遇刺身亡，拉奥推迟了原定的退休计划。尽管他从未当选过任何国家级公职，但他还是被选为国大党的领导人——这并非因为他是一位大胆而富有魅力的领导人（事实上他并非如此），而是因为他是一位调解者。他是一位平衡者，一位妥协人选，似乎不太可能挑战其他党内大佬。当他作为新任总理公布内阁名单时，却被斥为“陈年旧酒”。人们说，他的政府不会长久。鉴于这是一个少数派政府，这种预期似乎合情合理。然而，事与愿违，他的政府执政了整整五年。在上任的头一百天里，拉奥就对国有经济发起了全面攻击——这仅仅是这场旷日持久战争的第一击。6

Owing to Rajiv’s assassination, Rao postponed his planned retirement. Although he had never been elected to a national office, he was chosen to lead the Congress Party in the elections—not because he was a bold and charismatic leader, which he certainly was not, but because he was a conciliator, a balancer, a compromise candidate, who did not seem likely to challenge the other party barons. When, as the newly designated prime minister, he unveiled his cabinet, it was dismissed as “old wine in old bottles.” His government, it was said, would not last long. That seemed a reasonable expectation, since it was a minority government. As events turned out, however, it stayed the full five years. In the first hundred days of his term Rao would launch a full-scale attack on the state-controlled economy—the first assault in what would prove to be a protracted war.6

形势所迫。拉奥和他的同事们没有时间辩论或拖延，因为印度当时正处于严重的经济困境。1990年8月2日，萨达姆·侯赛因入侵科威特。油价飙升，令印度本已脆弱的国际收支雪上加霜。此外，在波斯湾国家工作的印度工人停止汇款，进一步恶化了国际收支平衡。印度濒临金融危机，实际上已经破产。

Circumstances drove it. Rao and his colleagues did not have the luxury of debating or dallying, for India was in severe economic straits. On August 2, 1990, Saddam Hussein had invaded Kuwait. The sharp increase in the price of oil hit India’s already fragile balance of payments very hard. In addition, Indian workers in the Persian Gulf states stopped sending their earnings home, further weakening the balance of payments. On the edge of a financial crisis, India was virtually bankrupt.

尽管印度的动荡是由海湾危机引发的，但其根源却在于自身。深陷“许可证制度”的泥潭，印度始终未能充分发挥其潜力。

Although the country’s turmoil was triggered by the Gulf crisis, it was fundamentally homegrown. Entangled in the Permit Raj, India was prevented from reaching anything close to its potential.

“对数字一窍不通”

“No Head for Figures”

1991年夏天，短短几周内，一小群人就通过改变印度的发展方向来应对危机。事实上，拉奥总理最重要的决策都集中在部长人事任命上。但并非所有任命都沿袭旧习。除了那些熟悉的面孔，他还特意挑选了一些愿意打破传统的人。其中一位关键决策者正是拉奥本人，这位资深的国大党成员和老谋深算的政治家。他无意成为玛格丽特·撒切尔，或者李光耀。他把自己视为一名社会民主主义者。“我不相信涓滴经济学，”他斩钉截铁地宣称。作为一名政治家，他行事谨慎，做事深思熟虑，甚至到了令人沮丧的地步，他会事无巨细地进行思考。他也意识到国大党这些年来是如何衰弱和分裂的。他曾把国大党比作“一个火车站台，形形色色的人来来往往，随心所欲”。尽管他接任时看起来虚弱疲惫——他之前已经在休斯顿做过心脏手术——但他的表现却比预期的更加精力充沛，也更有掌控力。他的一位助手略带讽刺地说道，这是因为他吸收了最重要的维生素——权力维生素P。

Over a matter of weeks in the summer of 1991, a small group responded to the crisis by changing India’s direction. Indeed, the most important decisions that Prime Minister Rao made were in the ministerial portfolios. Not all, in fact, were old wine. Along with all the familiar figures, he deliberately selected some men who would break with the past. One of the key decision makers was Rao himself, the old Congress Party hand and the wily politician. He had no intention of trying to be a Margaret Thatcher—or, for that matter, a Lee Kuan Yew. He saw himself very much as a social democrat. “I do not believe in trickle-down economics,” he emphatically declared. As a politician, he would not be rushed; he would think things through deliberately, carefully, and, to the frustration of some, exhaustively. He also recognized how the Congress Party had weakened and fragmented over the years. Once, he compared the party to “a railway platform where all sorts of people come and go as they like.” And although he had looked weak and tired when he took over—he had already had open-heart surgery in Houston—he turned out to be more vigorous, and much more in command, than had been expected. It was the consequence, one of his aides wryly remarked, of his absorbing the most important vitamin of all—vitamin P, as in power.

第二位人物是财政部长曼莫汉·辛格。辛格是一名锡克教徒，出生于旁遮普地区（现属巴基斯坦）一个干旱贫困村庄。凭借天赋和奖学金，他一路走来。秉承印度杰出经济学家的传统，他在剑桥大学获得经济学学士学位，随后又在……获得博士学位。牛津大学毕业后，他在印度担任经济官员，事业蒸蒸日上；他曾在至关重要的计划委员会担任要职。尽管没有人怀疑他的经济才能——毕竟，他曾获得剑桥大学的亚当·斯密奖——但他为人谦逊低调；当他想回避某个问题时，他会略显牵强地低声说道：“我对数字一窍不通。”7

The second figure was the finance minister, Manmohan Singh. A Sikh, Singh had been born into a poor family in a drought-prone village in the Punjab region that is now part of Pakistan. Talent and scholarships had carried him far. In the tradition of India’s brilliant economists, he had earned his undergraduate economics degree at Cambridge and then his Ph.D. at Oxford. Subsequently, he had made a considerable career in India as an economic bureaucrat; he held a senior post on the all-important planning commission. Although no one doubted his economic acuity—after all, he had won the Adam Smith Prize at Cambridge—he was modest and understated; when he wanted to avoid a question, he would somewhat implausibly murmur, “I have no head for figures.”7

第三位关键人物是商务部长奇丹巴拉姆，他出身于马德拉斯一个著名的工业家族，拥有哈佛大学的工商管理硕士学位。辛格负责宏观经济，而奇丹巴拉姆则深入贸易政策的细节，直面许可证和许可制度这个如同卡夫卡小说般荒诞的世界。他性格内敛，作风略显严肃，但他目标明确，那就是瓦解许可证制度。他的反应比辛格更加强烈，这源于他十五年来从事行政法工作，并日复一日地与体制抗争的经历：“我清楚地看到，公共部门和私营部门都受到了保护主义环境的过度保护。商品和服务的质量低劣显而易见。我看到政府变得多么干涉、压迫和低效，扼杀了创业精神，扼杀了所有创意，却没有带来任何实际成果。”

The third key figure was P. Chidambaram, the commerce minister, a member of a leading industrial family from Madras, with an MBA from Harvard. Singh would deal with macroeconomics, while Chidambaram would battle down in the nitty-gritty of trade policy, the Kafkaesque world of licenses and permits. Reserved and rather austere in style, he knew exactly what he intended to do, which was to deconstruct the Permit Raj. His reaction was more visceral than Singh’s, the response to fifteen years spent practicing administrative law and grappling with the system on a daily basis: “It became clear to me that both the public sector and the private sector were being mollycoddled by a protectionist environment. The poor quality of goods and services was so apparent. I saw how intrusive, oppressive, and inefficient government had become, stifling entrepreneurial spirit, killing every idea, and not delivering anything in turn.”

面对迫在眉睫的经济崩溃，这些人都意识到，过去四十年的政策制定已经严重误导了国家。然而，他们只是少数派。在占主导地位的国大党内部，仍然没有广泛的支持变革的声音。但有一套清晰的理念，既是对旧政策的批判，也是新政策的指导。当他和改革派同仁审视经济运行状况时，他们发现经济并未实现增长。生产力低下，政府支出失控，高瞻远瞩的计划经济已经沦为盲目的控制。所有这些弊病都可以追溯到政府过度干预。“左派一直被市场失灵的理念所主导，”经济学家兼公务员维杰·凯尔卡尔说道，“然而，政府失灵的问题也随着时间的推移得到了充分的证实。我们看到了大量的数据。我们根据经验做出了回应。”8

Each of these men, confronting the impending economic wreck, recognized that four decades of policy making had steered the country badly wrong. They were, however, in a minority. Within the dominant Congress Party, there was still no broad support for change. But there was a clear set of ideas that served as a critique of the old policies and guided the new. And when he and the other reformers examined the workings of the economy, they saw it had not delivered growth. Productivity was low, government spending was uncontrolled, and high-minded planning had degenerated into mindless control. All these ailments could be traced back to overwhelming government intervention. “The left had been dominated by the idea of market failure,” said the economist and civil servant Vijay Kelkar. “Yet government failure had over time become very well documented. We could see all the data that was piling up. We responded to experience.”8

醒来

Waking Up

数据也来自国外。苏联共产主义的崩溃对印度的转型产生了决定性的影响。中央计划经济凭借其理性的外在形象，早已俘获了知识分子和官员的心。早在独立之前，尼赫鲁就曾写道，“共产党人和社会主义者自信地指向社会主义道路”，因为“他们拥有科学和逻辑”。印度人渴望效仿苏联的经济体制（正如俄罗斯人去印度时渴望购物一样）。“我们试图将苏联的经济模式移植到西方议会制度下的印度社会中。”“这套体系，”印度新一代技术官僚贾伊拉姆·拉梅什说道，“简直是一杯令人陶醉的鸡尾酒。” 这也带来了巨大的后遗症。苏联经济模式的失败摧毁了人们对政府管理经济能力的信心。苏联的耻辱性解体不仅意味着印度最大贸易伙伴的消失，也动摇了人们对中央计划经济体制的信心。印度精英们最终意识到，他们把自己的未来寄托在了错误的星辰上。

Data were also coming from outside the country. The collapse of Soviet communism had a decisive impact on India’s redirection. Central planning, with its appearance of rationality, had long ago captured the imagination of intellectuals and officials. Even before independence Nehru had written that “communists and socialists point with confidence to the way of socialism” because “they have science and logic on their side.” Indians wanted to emulate the Soviet economic system (even as Russians craved, when they went to India, the opportunity to go shopping). “We tried to implant a Soviet economic model on a Western parliamentary system on an Indian social system,” said Jairam Ramesh, one of India’s new technocrats. “It was a heady cocktail.” It also created a massive hangover. The failure of the Soviet economic model destroyed conviction in the ability of government to manage the economy. The ignominious end of the USSR meant not only the extinction of India’s leading trading partner; it also undermined confidence in the system of central planning. India, the elite came to realize, had hitched its future to the wrong star.

更糟糕的是，印度人几乎同时才意识到东亚和东南亚正在发生的事情。几十年来，他们一直忽视了正在崛起的“亚洲经济奇迹”，先是日本，然后是亚洲四小龙，这些国家都比印度小得多，而且其中许多还是美国的盟友。“我们往往把这些国家视为美国的走狗，美国帝国主义的走狗，”一位经济学家说道，“我们对它们的成就视而不见，也看不到它们在短短一代人的时间里所取得的成就是多么惊人。”

To make matters worse, Indians awoke at the same time to what was happening in East and Southeast Asia. For decades they had ignored the emerging “Asian economic miracles,” first Japan and then the tigers, all of which were much smaller than India and many of which were allied with the United States. “We tended to dismiss those countries as lackeys of the United States, running dogs of American imperialism,” said one economist, “and closed our ideas to their performance, to how amazing it was what they had done in one generation.”

到了20世纪80年代末，现实已不容否认。这些国家的经济增长速度持续远超印度，而印度似乎注定要经历一段较为缓慢的“印度式增长”。年增长率的差异如今已累积成巨大的鸿沟，曼莫汉·辛格访问远东时对此有了更深刻的体会。辛格拥有相当不错的社会主义背景，这使他在1991年被国大党接受为财政部长。（他此前曾担任南方委员会秘书，该委员会是第三世界国家干预主义的拥护者聚集地。事实上，南方委员会主席正是朱利叶斯·尼雷尔，他对利他主义社会主义的执着最终给坦桑尼亚——他曾带领其走向独立的国家——的经济带来了毁灭性的打击。）但在1987年，辛格访问了东亚。他震惊了。那里的对比令人瞠目结舌。 1960年，韩国和印度的经济水平相当。如今，韩国的人均收入是印度的十倍，并且正在申请加入经合组织。

By the end of the 1980s, the reality could no longer be denied. These countries, on a consistent basis, were growing much more rapidly than India, which, it was said apologetically, seemed consigned to a lower “Hindu rate of growth.” The annual differences in growth rates had now added up to a huge gap, a fact that was vividly demonstrated for Manmohan Singh when he made a trip to the Far East. Singh had reasonable socialist credentials, which had made him acceptable to the Congress Party as finance minister in 1991. (He had previously served as the secretary of the South Commission, very much a repository for believers in third world state intervention. Indeed, the chairman of the South Commission was Julius Nyerere, whose commitment to altruistic socialism had been ruinous for the economy of Tanzania, the country he had led to independence.) But in 1987, Singh made his trip to East Asia. He was stunned. The comparisons were astounding. South Korea and India had been at the same economic level in 1960. Now South Korea’s per capita income was ten times that of India, and it was applying for membership to the OECD.

辛格努力理解究竟是什么造成了这种差异。诚然，许可证制度的所有附属品——各种管制和许可证——都阻碍了经济发展。但有两件事真正让辛格印象深刻。在东亚，各国政府开展了他所谓的“促进活动”来支持商业发展，而印度则更注重监管。但或许最显著的差异在于，东亚国家在多大程度上积极拥抱国际贸易并从中获益，而印度却坚持走内向型路线。数据足以说明一切。1990年，经合组织国家从印度进口的制成品仅90亿美元，而从人口只有印度二十分之一的韩国进口的制成品却高达410亿美元。东亚并非唯一的国际影响来源。“撒切尔夫人执政时期发生的事情令人大开眼界，恍然大悟，”奇丹巴拉姆说道，“毕竟，我们的费边社会主义是从英国学来的。”

Singh struggled to understand what had made the difference. Certainly, all the accouterments of the Permit Raj—the controls and licenses—had held back the economy. But two things really struck Singh. In East Asia, the governments engaged in what he called “promotional activities” supporting business, whereas in India the emphasis was on regulation. But perhaps the most striking difference of all was the degree to which the East Asian countries had oriented themselves toward international trade and captured its benefits, while India had insisted upon turning inward. The numbers spoke for themselves. In 1990, the OECD countries imported just $9 billion of manufactures from India—and $41 billion from South Korea, whose population was one twentieth the size of India’s. East Asia was not the only international influence. “What happened under Mrs. Thatcher was an eye-opener, a revelation,” said Chidambaram. “After all, we had gotten our Fabian socialism from Britain.”

另一个因素更加坚定了印度走错路的信念。上世纪六七十年代，许多印度人移居北美和西欧。第一批移民或许起步贫寒，但他们勤奋努力，到了八十年代末，他们及其子女已在移居国站稳脚跟，成为成功的商人和专业人士。印度人拥有美国46%的经济型汽车旅馆客房。他们在英国零售业占据了重要地位。他们还在海外建立了大型工商业公司。这些被称为“非居民印度人”（NRI）的人，如今纷纷回国探亲，寻根溯源。他们的影响力巨大，也引出了一个引人入胜的社会学问题：为什么印度人在海外如此成功？这不可能是因为印度的水质。一定是NRI赖以生存的经济体系造就了他们的成功。他们在海外取得的成就，再次有力地驳斥了印度国内的“许可证制度”（Permit Raj）。9

One more factor reinforced the conviction that India was on the wrong track. Many Indians had emigrated, moving to North America and Western Europe in the 1960s and 1970s. The first wave may have started off poor, but they worked very hard, and by the late 1980s, they—and their children—had established themselves as successful businesspeople and professionals in their adopted countries. Indians owned 46 percent of the budget-motel rooms in the United States. They were responsible for much of retail trade in Britain. They had also built large industrial and commercial firms overseas. Known as NRIs—nonresident Indians—they were now coming back to visit their families and rediscover their roots. Their impact was considerable, and raised an endlessly fascinating sociological question: Why are Indians such a success outside India? It couldn’t be the drinking water. It had to be the economic systems under which the NRIs flourished. Their achievements outside the country became another indictment of the Permit Raj within.9

“无功能的资本主义”

“A Functionless Capitalism”

1991年6月21日，拉奥宣誓就任总理。第二天，他的新任财政部长曼莫汉·辛格向他汇报了经济状况，详细列举了各项数据。中央政府的财政赤字占国内生产总值的8%，而国内公共债务高达55%。仅国内债务的利息支出就占4%，外债利息支出更是高达23%。听完这番令人沮丧的汇报后，拉奥说道：“我意识到形势严峻，但没想到会如此糟糕。”当时，国家仅剩下几亿美元的外汇储备，仅够支付两周的进口费用。海外印度侨民惊慌失措，纷纷提取存款。甚至有人绝望地讨论出售印度驻东京和北京大使馆以快速筹集资金。拉奥和辛格深知，他们最终不得不向国际货币基金组织寻求贷款。但事实证明，国际货币基金组织的条件非但没有定义，反而强化了随后的改革议程。实际上，拉奥政府最终采取的措施远远超出了国际货币基金组织的要求。

Rao was sworn in as prime minister on June 21, 1991. The next day, his new finance minister, Manmohan Singh, briefed him on the state of the economy, going through all the numbers. The central government’s deficit was 8 percent of the GDP, while its internal public debt amounted to 55 percent. Interest payments on just the domestic debt consumed another 4 percent, while interest payments on foreign debt amounted to 23 percent. At the conclusion of this dismal recitation, Rao said, “I realized the position was bad but I did not realize that it was this bad.” The nation had just a few hundred million dollars’ foreign-exchange reserves left, enough to pay for imports for only two weeks. The nonresident Indians, panicking, were pulling out their deposits. There was even desperate discussion about selling off the Indian embassies in Tokyo and Beijing to raise quick money. Rao and Singh knew they would have to go to the International Monetary Fund for loans; but as it turned out, the IMF’s conditions would reinforce rather than define the ensuing agenda for reform. Indeed, the Rao government ended up going far beyond the terms the IMF would have required.

这场危机给了辛格和奇丹巴拉姆一个契机，让他们能够推动变革，从而根除经济的根本弊病——监管过度、控制不足以及竞争不足。辛格曾说，印度深受他所谓的“无功能的资本主义”之苦；也就是说，“人们可以赚很多钱，却丝毫不关心技术进步、质量和成本降低。” 这场变革最重要的意义在于理念的转变。辛格在就职后不久便表示：“印度需要在许多方面进行全新的思考。旧的思维方式已经无法带领我们走向任何方向。” 他补充道：“你们绝不能低估思想的力量。”

The crisis gave Singh and Chidambaram the opportunity to force a change that would cure the fundamental ailments of the economy—too much regulation and control and not enough competition. India suffered, Singh would say, from what he called a “functionless capitalism”; that is, “people can make a lot of money without any concern for technical progress, quality, and cost reduction.” As much as anything else, the change would mean a change in ideas. “India needs to think afresh on many fronts,” Singh said just after his appointment. “The old methods of thinking have not taken us anywhere.” He added, “You must not underestimate the force of ideas.”

辛格和奇丹巴拉姆意识到，他们的听众只有一个人。他们必须说服这位谨慎的总理尽快推进尽可能多的改革。拉奥承认，他对经济学的了解远称不上博学，他的世界观也形成于国大党狭小的体制内，而国大党长期以来一直标榜公共部门的至高无上。奇丹巴拉姆明白自己面临的挑战。“过去二三十年，”他告诉总理，“你一直被各种管制和监管所包围，你认为这些是正确的。突然说我们要放松管制、取消许可证制度，这可能会让人感到非常不安。”

Singh and Chidambaram realized that they had an audience of one. They would have to convince the cautious prime minister to push as much reform as possible as quickly as possible. Rao would admit that his knowledge of economics was less than encyclopedic, and his view of the world had been shaped within the confining walls of the Congress Party, which had for so long heralded the preeminence of the public sector. Chidambaram understood what he was up against. “For 20 or 30 years,” he told the prime minister, “you were raised on a diet of controls and regulations which you thought was the right thing. To suddenly say that we want to decontrol and delicense can be quite traumatic.”

“是的，”拉奥回答说，“对我们中的一些人来说，这很困难，因为要放弃我们认为正确的道路并不容易。”

“Yes,” replied Rao, “for some of us it is difficult because it is not an easy thing to make a break with what we thought was the right course.”

改革推进过程中，拉奥也曾有过疑虑。辛格做出了一个颇具争议的决定，即不降低对农民至关重要的煤油价格。对此，拉奥双手抱头，哀叹道：“我该拿这些技术官僚怎么办？” 但最终，拉奥还是与过去决裂了。他在全国广播中表示，他的政府致力于“清除阻碍快速工业化的障碍”。10

Rao had continuing moments of doubt as reforms got under way. After Singh made a controversial decision not to reduce the price of kerosene, a fuel of critical importance to farmers, Rao put his head in his hands and moaned, “What am I to do with these technocrats?” But finally Rao made the break with the past. His government, he said in a nationwide radio broadcast, was committed “to removing the cobwebs that come in the way of rapid industrialization.”10

改革决策似乎由一小群官员做出，他们几乎昼夜不停地工作。1991年7月下旬，辛格在向议会提交紧急预算时，不禁提到他的妻子对他长时间工作非常不满。“议会都会同意，”他说，“如果国家财政部长与国内的财政部长关系紧张，这对我国经济的健康发展是不利的。”他借此机会提议降低厨房用具的税收。

The decisions for reform were made by a small circle of officials working, it seemed, almost around the clock. In presenting the emergency budget in late July 1991 in a speech to Parliament, Singh could not help but note that his wife was very unhappy with his long hours. “The House will agree,” he said, “that it is not good for the health of our economy if the finance minister of the country has strained relations with his own finance minister at home.” He took that occasion to propose lower taxes on kitchen utensils.

辛格的预算演讲非同寻常，它不仅阐述了新的政策，更深刻而透彻地诊断了问题所在。演讲传递的核心信息是：印度正处于水深火热之中，唯一的希望在于大规模的改革。辛格在议会表示，国家“正处于悬崖边缘”。“时不我待……我们已经没有回旋余地，没有再靠借来的钱或时间苟延残喘。” 在演讲中，他反复指出，印度的财政表现远未达到理想和预期。印度拥有世界第三多的科学家和工程师，但这在国家科技发展中却鲜有体现。他重提了1987年东亚危机给他带来的冲击——印度必须成为“具有国际竞争力的经济体”。他援引了尼赫鲁、英迪拉·甘地和拉吉夫·甘地等几位印度王朝的先贤，为改革的努力祈福。但毫无疑问，他是在利用这场危机试图与过去决裂。

Singh’s budget speech was an extraordinary document, not only as a definition of new policies, but also as a penetrating and incisive diagnosis of what had gone wrong. Its overall message was that India was in dire straits and that its only hope was massive reform. The country was “at the edge of a precipice,” Singh told Parliament. “There is no time to lose …. The room to maneuver, to live on borrowed money or time, does not exist anymore.” Again and again in the speech, he showed how performance had fallen very far short of ideal and expectation. India had the third-largest number of scientists and engineers in the world, but that was hardly reflected in the country’s technology. He came back to what had hit him in 1987 in East Asia—it was imperative that India become “an internationally competitive economy.” He invoked the dynastic pantheon—Nehru and Indira and Rajiv Gandhi—to bless the efforts. But there was no question that he was using the crisis to try to break with the past.

官僚和国大党成员不断抨击改革派，警告他们走得太快太远，背离了党的传统和核心信仰。“我们致力于变革，”辛格对一群官员说，“任何有异议的人都应该说出来。” 当他受到批评时针对有人轻视尼赫鲁的政治遗产，辛格援引了圣雄甘地的“斯瓦德西”（自力更生）理念，反驳道：“不，不，这源于自力更生。自力更生意味着贸易，而不是援助。”

Both bureaucrats and Congress Party members kept sniping away at the reformers, warning them that they were going too far too fast, that they were denying the heritage, the beliefs, that were at the heart of the party. “We’re in the business of making changes,” Singh told one group of officials. “Anyone who has reservations should speak up.” When he was criticized for spurning Nehru’s legacy, Singh invoked Mahatma Gandhi’s vision of swadeshi—self-reliance—and shot back, “No, no, it follows from self-reliance. Self-reliance means trade and not aid.”

短短几周内，拉奥政府就成功扭转了局面：它让卢比贬值；削减了对国内产品和出口的补贴；降低了关税和贸易壁垒；取消了80%行业的许可证制度；并废除了大型企业扩张或多元化经营前必须获得批准的规定。它甚至大胆地重新开放了外国投资的大门。此外，它还启动了撤资进程——即出售部分政府持有的公司股份。

In a matter of weeks, the Rao government did succeed in changing course: It devalued the rupee. It cut subsidies for domestic products and for exports. It reduced tariffs and trade barriers, eliminated licenses for 80 percent of industry, and did away with the requirement that larger firms get advance approval to expand or diversify. It even dared to reopen the door to foreign investment. And it began a process of disinvestment—that is, selling off some of the government shares in companies.

如此迅猛的改革冲击了长达四十年的政府政策，人们原本预期会遭到强烈的反对。但危机的特殊情况以及改革者清晰的立场在一定程度上缓解了反对声浪。危机赋予了他们比预期更大的行动自由，他们遇到的最严重的阻力也只是因削减化肥补贴而引发的抗议。与此同时，他们启动的改革进程逐渐积蓄力量，并最终展现出惊人的持久性。11

With such rapid-fire reforms pressing so hard against four decades of government policy, a firestorm of strong opposition might have been expected. But the circumstances of the crisis and the clarity of the reformers somewhat mitigated the opposition. The crisis gave them a freer hand than they had any reason to anticipate, and the worst they got were protests over reductions in subsidies for fertilizers. In the meantime, they started a process that would gather momentum and prove surprisingly durable.11

“截然不同的角色”

“A Vastly Different Role”

正如两位印度学者所言，“自1991年中期以来的经济改革标志着政府在印度经济中扮演的角色发生了巨大变化。” 但此后也出现了诸多动荡和争议。1996年，国大党在大选中落败，最终由卡纳塔克邦前首席部长H·D·德韦·高达领导的少数派联合政府取而代之。国大党支持该联合政府。然而仅仅一年后，1997年5月，国大党暂时撤回了对该联合政府的支持；由此引发的政治危机导致资深外交官英德尔·库马尔·古杰拉尔被任命为新总理。他的政府面临着维持内部团结的挑战。然而，在政治动荡中，印度始终坚持改革路线，这既得益于该国思想的巨大转变，也得益于德韦·高达和古杰拉尔的财政部长都是P·奇丹巴拉姆，而奇丹巴拉姆曾担任商务部长，是拉奥的两名主要改革者之一。

“The economic reforms since mid-1991 have,” in the words of two Indian scholars, “signaled a vastly different role for the government in the Indian economy.” But there have been many upsets and controversies since. In 1996, the Congress Party lost the elections and was eventually replaced by a minority coalition government led by H. D. Deve Gowda, the former chief minister of the state of Karnataka. The Congress Party supported the coalition. But barely a year later, in May 1997, Congress temporarily withdrew its support; the ensuing political crisis resulted in the appointment of a new prime minister, the veteran diplomat Inder Kumar Gujral. His government faced the challenge of maintaining cohesion. Yet throughout the political tumult, India stayed on the course of reform, reinforced both by the vast shift in thinking in the country and also, specifically, by the fact that both Deve Gowda’s and Gujral’s finance minister was none other than P. Chidambaram, who as commerce minister had been one of Rao’s two key reformers.

综合所有变化来看，影响相当显著。许可证制度下的审批流程基本被取消，对外贸易开放，外国投资也随之开放，其中包括被誉为“革命性举措”的允许国内外私人投资进入电力、港口和电信等基础设施领域的举措。这类投资似乎挑战了旧体制下“制高点”的本质。但如今，迫切需要确保充足的电力供应，以支持经济增长，并避免频繁发生的电力短缺和停电。此外，现在人们认识到，基础设施建设所需的投资规模如此之大，以至于至少有一部分资金必须来自国外——否则，所需的基础设施将无法及时建成，而代价将体现在较低的增长率上。12

When all the changes are added up, they have been quite considerable. The licensing and approvals of the Permit Raj were mostly eliminated. Foreign trade was opened up. So was foreign investment, including what has been described as “the revolutionary step” of allowing foreign and domestic private investment into such infrastructure areas as electric power, ports, and telecommunications. That kind of investment would seem to have challenged the very essence of the commanding heights, at least as it was under the old system. But now there was an urgent necessity to ensure, for instance, that there would be adequate electricity to support economic growth and to avoid the brownouts and blackouts that had become habitual. Moreover, it was now recognized that the investment required for infrastructure would be so large that at least part of it had to be met with funds originating outside the country—otherwise, what was needed would not be built in time, and the costs would be measured in lower growth rates.12

诚然，外国直接投资确实引发了一些引人注目的争议。卡纳塔克邦的一家肯德基餐厅遭到反对者的围攻，其中包括一个以饮食为由攻击该餐厅的宗教团体。更重要的是，统治马哈拉施特拉邦（包括孟买）的印度教民族主义者试图推翻与安然公司牵头的国际财团签署的一项价值20亿美元的发电厂建设合同。安然公司是一家美国天然气和电力公司。经过二十五次以上的诉讼，印度独立的司法和法律体系最终维护了该合同的有效性，经过一些重新谈判，该项目得以继续推进。“这一经验表明，印度拥有完善的法律体系，能够维护具有约束力的合同，”安然公司首席执行官肯尼斯·莱表示，“我们相信印度将继续保持显著增长，并成为一个更加自由化的经济体，我们计划在印度长期发展。”尽管如此，在印度电力行业，几乎所有潜在的外国投资者都对繁琐复杂的审批流程以及由此带来的长期挫败感深有体会。该流程涉及多个联邦和州政府机构，并伴随着频繁的法律纠纷。总体而言，尽管外国对印度的投资有所增长，但考虑到其庞大的经济规模，这一数字仍然很小——1996年为56亿美元，而同年流入中国的外国投资则高达420亿美元。

Foreign direct investment did, to be sure, ignite some visible controversies.A Kentucky Fried Chicken restaurant in Karnataka was besieged by opponents, who included a religious faction that attacked it on dietary grounds. Of larger importance was the effort by the Hindu nationalists who ruled the state of Maharashtra (which includes Bombay) to overturn a contract signed with an international consortium led by Enron, the U.S. natural gas and electric power company, to build a $2 billion power plant. Through more than twenty-five court challenges, India’s independent judiciary and legal system upheld the contract, and after some renegotiation, the project progressed. “The experience demonstrated that India has a good legal system that upholds binding contracts,” said Kenneth Lay, Enron’s CEO. “We believe that India will continue to grow at a significant rate, and that it will become a more liberalized economy, and we’re planning to be in India for the long term.” With that said, it was still hard to find a potential foreign investor in the electric power sector that could not recite the prolonged frustrations caused by what has remained a highly complex and somewhat mysterious approval process, involving multiple federal and state agencies and frequent legal wrangles. Overall, while growing, foreign investment in India is still small given the size of its economy—$5.6 billion in 1996, in contrast to the $42 billion that went into China in the same year.

在印度，公共财政和国有企业是改革难度最大的两个领域。政府一直避免使用“私有化”一词，而是采取“撤资”策略，通常旨在出售部分股权，但保留多数控制权。对于效率低下、亏损严重且雇佣了大量员工的国有企业，政府在如何处理这些问题上遇到了重重困难，这也不难理解。

The two areas that have proved the most difficult to reform in India are public finances and state-owned enterprises. Government has avoided the word privatization and instead has adopted a program of “disinvestment,” generally intending to sell off partial ownership but retain majority control. And it has had an understandably very difficult time in figuring out what to do with highly inefficient, loss-making state-owned enterprises, which employ many people.

尽管1997年印度大部分工业仍为国有或国有控股，但私营企业规模庞大，其中最引人注目的是自殖民时代以来由传奇企业家及其继承人建立起来的实力雄厚的私营企业集团。这些企业集团——例如塔塔集团和比尔拉集团——之所以能够保留其资产，是因为尼赫鲁希望建立新的国有企业，而不是将现有的私营企业国有化。许可证制度保护了印度的实业家免受外部竞争，但他们很快就对此感到不满并予以反对，因为它扼杀了他们的活力。随着限制的解除，他们开始重整旗鼓。他们雄厚的实力——塔塔集团在钢铁、电气设备、重型机械、茶叶种植园甚至出版业等领域均位列印度领先企业之列——意味着他们不太可能被竞争和新的投资所淘汰。

Although the bulk of industry remained state owned or state controlled in 1997, there is a considerable private sector in India, most notably the powerful private conglomerates built up since colonial days by legendary entrepreneurs and their heirs. These houses—such as the Tatas and the Birlas—had retained their assets because Nehru wanted to set up new state-owned firms, not nationalize existing private industry. The Permit Raj protected India’s industrialists from outside competition, but they soon came to resent and oppose it, because it stifled their energies. As restrictions were lifted, they began to dust themselves off. Their formidable scope—the Tata group ranks among India’s leaders in iron and steel, electrical equipment, heavy machinery, tea plantations, and even publishing—meant that it was unlikely they would be swept away by competition and new investment.

在老牌企业集团周围，一个新的私营部门也在崛起，尤其是在科技和服务领域——这些市场正是尼赫鲁的规划者们所关注的。20世纪50年代的人们无法预料到这一切。所有这些新老私营企业每天都与国有企业进行贸易往来，签订合同。尽管效率低下且人员臃肿，但公共部门也拥有一些运作尚可的企业，其中一些企业表现尤为出色。印度的公共企业深陷于复杂的工业经济体系之中，日益受到国内外竞争对手的影响，因此它们无法置身于改革之外。

Around the old conglomerates, a new private sector is also on the rise, particularly in technology and services—markets that Nehru’s planners of the 1950s could not have anticipated. And all of these private firms, old and new, trade and make contracts daily with the state-owned enterprises. Although inefficient and overstaffed, the public sector possesses some firms that function reasonably well—and some that have performed remarkably. Embedded as they are in a complex industrial economy, increasingly subject to domestic and international competitors, Indian public enterprises cannot be cordoned off from reform.

从下方更改

Changefrom Below

变革的迹象比比皆是。海外印度人纷纷回国投资贸易，许多跨国公司也加入了这一行列。南部城市班加罗尔已成为第二个硅谷，一个世界信息技术发展中心。“在印度班加罗尔购买编程服务，价格只有美国的一半，”信息技术巨头甲骨文公司董事长兼首席执行官拉里·埃里森说道。“我们在班加罗尔设有一个大型研发中心，质量非常出色。我们之所以在那里设立并扩张，并非因为能节省大量资金，而是因为那里的工作质量实在太好。”与此同时，印度政界人士和官员们越来越重视政府应将资金用于医疗和教育等必需领域，而不是补贴国有企业的亏损。他们认为经济增长是消除贫困的先决条件。尽管印度的贫困人口高达数亿，但其中产阶级人数通常估计高达3亿——比美国总人口还要多，与西欧人口相当。无论作为消费市场还是经济活动来源，这都是一个庞大的数字。然而，正如西方消费品公司所发现的那样，印度中产阶级的收入和购买力远不及欧美中产阶级。

There have been many signs of change. The nonresident Indians are going back to invest and trade, and so are many multinational companies. The southern city of Bangalore has become a second Silicon Valley, a world center for information-technology development. “You can buy programming services in Bangalore, India, for half the cost you can buy it in the United States,” said Larry Ellison, chairman and CEO of Oracle, the information-technology gigant. “We have a big research center in Bangalore and the quality is fantastic. The reason we’re there and expanding is not because we’re saving so much money; it’s because the quality of the work is so good.” Meanwhile, Indian politicians and officials talk more and more about the importance of the government spending its money on such needs as health and education, rather than on subsidizing losses for government-owned businesses. They talk about economic growth as the precondition for healing poverty. While the number of the country’s poor is measured in the many hundreds of millions, the Indian middle class is often estimated at up to 300 million—bigger than in the entire population of the United States and the same as Western Europe’s. That is a huge number, both as a consumer market and as a source of economic activity. However, as Western consumer-goods companies have discovered, the Indian middle class does not have anything approaching the income or purchasing power of the European or American middle class.

记忆中，变革首次自下而上地发生——来自各邦首府，而不再仅仅来自“中央”新德里。中央政府放松管制，加剧了经济权力向各邦的转移。与此同时，那些为抵制英迪拉·甘地集权倾向而兴起的地区性政党已经发展成熟，并在许多邦执政。他们致力于为各自的选民群体（严格意义上的地方选民）争取改革带来的最大利益。起初，地方领导人依靠个人魅力和腐败——其中几位是昔日热门电影明星，一位甚至因其纵容贪污而被戏称为“百分之十夫人”。在选民的推动下，他们变得越来越精明，也越来越清楚如何吸引投资。长期以来被视为落后落后地区的奥里萨邦，如今正经历着电力系统的彻底自由化和重组。自1977年以来一直执政的印度共产党（马克思主义）在西孟加拉邦公开欢迎外国私人投资。安得拉邦一位热衷于科技的首席部长在1997年就促成了世界银行首次向印度各邦提供直接贷款，用于全面的经济改革。或许，自下而上活力的最确凿标志是地方政党在联邦政治中扮演的新角色。1996年执政的联盟伙伴大多来自地方。这些根植于地方政治、以区域发展为导向的权力掮客的崛起，反映了印度政府正在发生重大转变，即更加重视各邦的实践和成果。这些成果也更贴近民众。

For the first time in memory, change is coming from below—from the state capitals, and no longer just from “the center,” New Delhi. The loosening of the central government’s controls is accentuating a shift of economic power to the states. At the same time, the regional parties that emerged to resist Indira Gandhi’s centralizing tendencies have matured and assumed power in many states. They are concerned with getting the best deal out of reform for their constituencies, which are strictly local. At first, regional leaders relied on charisma and corruption—several of them were former stars in popular movies, and one became known as Madam Ten Per Cent, for the extent of graft she encouraged. Prodded by voters, they have become increasingly canny and aware of what it takes to attract investment. The state of Orissa, long considered a desperate backwater, is today the site of a radical liberalization and restructuring of the electric power system. In West Bengal, the Communist Party of India (Marxist), in power since 1977, openly invites foreign private investment. The technology-inclined chief minister of Andhra Pradesh was negotiating in 1997 the first-ever direct World Bank loan to an Indian state for comprehensive economic reform. Perhaps the surest sign of vitality from below is the new role of regional parties in federal politics. The coalition partners who took control in 1996 were largely based in the regions. The rise of power brokers steeped in regional politics and guided by a concern for regional development reflects a powerful change in Indian government toward giving more voice to state-level experiments and results. The benefits move one step closer to the people.

自独立以来，印度最令人费解的现象之一，便是政府僵化的管控与民众强大的商业传统之间存在的经济脱节。“印度的创业精神根深蒂固，”维杰·凯尔卡尔指出，“这并非问题所在。问题在于糟糕的政策。” 但这些政策正在改变。随着限制的消除和印度融入世界经济，一个高增长国家的轮廓正逐渐显现。人们并不指望它会像巨龙或猛虎那样势不可挡。相反，一些印度人认为，用大象来比喻更为贴切——起步缓慢，但一旦启动，便迅捷稳健，勇往直前，穿梭于层层丛林之间。

One of the oddest things about India since independence has been the economic disconnection between rigid government controls and the powerful commercial traditions of the people. “The springs of entrepreneurialism run very deep in India,” observed Vijay Kelkar. “That’s not the problem. Bad policies are the problem.” But those policies are being changed. As the constraints are eliminated and India integrates with the world economy, the outlines of a high-growth country are beginning to emerge. It is not expected to be a dragon or a tiger. Instead, some Indians suggest the appropriate zoological analogy is the elephant—slow to rise and get up to speed, but, once in motion, fast and steady, moving through thicket after thicket.

“我们的使命非常简单，”奇丹巴拉姆说，“到2020年，维持7%的经济增长，实现8%的增长，并彻底消除我们所知的贫困。市场必须发挥作用。但这并不意味着国家会萎缩。相反，国家必须在教育和医疗等领域采取果断行动，帮助穷人，并在真正重要的地方运用其权力进行干预。但国家必须避免生产商品和服务。如果以1到10分来衡量国家角色的转变，我们最初的起点接近于零。我认为我们现在处于2到3分。但我们终将达到目标。最大的风险在于我们过于迷恋市场的神奇力量，而忽视了穷人的基本需求。如果我们不解决他们的需求，就会引发反弹。”

“Our mission is very simple,” said Chidambaram. “Sustain seven percent-growth, allow eight percent growth, and abolish poverty as we know it by the year 2020. Markets must work. That does not mean that the state will wither away. Rather, it will have to act decisively in favor of the poor in such areas as education and health and use its power to intervene where there is a palpable importance. But the state must keep away from producing goods and services. On a scale of one to ten, in terms of changing the role of the state, we started close to zero. I’d say we’re now at two or three. But we will get there in time. The biggest risk is that we get too enamored of the wonders of the market and do not pay enough attention to the basic human needs of the poor. If we do not solve their needs, there will be a reaction.”

世界最大民主国家的政治复杂性很可能会延缓改革进程。随着各地区权力的增强，冲突和僵局的风险也随之增加。宗教宗派主义日益抬头。而以种姓制度为基础的社会结构，也引发了人们对机会获取的争夺。然而，迄今为止的变革表明，印度未来在全球经济中将扮演更加重要的角色——既是一个市场，也日益成为一个强大的竞争对手。“转型已在人们的思想中形成，”奇丹巴拉姆说道，“人们已经接受了这一转变。难点始终在于如何应对那些阻碍变革的游说集团和既得利益集团。此时此刻，我们更不应失去勇气和方向。”他顿了顿，继续说道：“改革的最后阶段的确最为艰难。”

The complexity of politics in the world’s largest democracy could well slow things down. As the regions become more empowered, the risk of conflict and stalemates increases. Religious sectarianism has been on the rise. And the social structure, built around the caste system, is creating conflict over access to opportunity. Yet the changes to date suggest that India will become much more important to the world economy in the future—as a market and, increasingly, as a competitor. “The transition is here in thought,” said Chidambaram. “People accept it. The difficult part is always to deal with the lobbies and the established interests that are blocking the process of change. This is the time when we should not lose nerve or direction.” He paused. “The last mile of reform is indeed the most difficult.”

在 1991 年引发改革的危机期间，曼莫汉·辛格引用了维克多·雨果的话：“世界上没有任何力量能够阻止一个时机成熟的思想。”他接着说：“印度崛起成为世界主要经济体之一，正是这样一种理念。”在1991年经济低迷时期，这听起来或许像是一种夸张的修辞，甚至是一个遥不可及的梦想。但在20世纪90年代末，这却是一个切实可行的前景。13

During the 1991 crisis that began the reforms, Manmohan Singh quoted Victor Hugo: “No power on earth can stop an idea whose time has come.” He went on to say, “The emergence of India as a major economic power in the world happens to be one such idea.” During the dismal days of 1991, that might have sounded like a rhetorical flourish or even a dream. At the end of the 1990s, it is a realistic prospect.13

1英迪拉·甘地是尼赫鲁唯一的女儿，她曾短暂地嫁给了费罗兹·甘地——与圣雄甘地没有任何关系。

1Indira Gandhi, Nehru’s only daughter, was briefly married to Feroze Gandhi—no relation to the mahatma.

第九章

CHAPTER 9

贡萨洛·桑切斯·德洛萨达（Gonzalo Sánchez de Lózada），昵称戈尼（Goni），1993年至1997年担任玻利维亚总统，一直对美国银行劫匪布奇·卡西迪和圣丹斯小子（Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid）着迷。这与他出生于玻利维亚，却在美国长大有关——这是他父亲在军事政变后流亡的结果。在玻利维亚，政变司空见惯——独立后的172年间发生了189次政变。在流亡美国期间，每逢新年，戈尼一家都会举杯祝酒：“愿来年一切改变，我们能够回家。”然而，那一年似乎永远不会到来。但最终，在戈尼从芝加哥大学哲学系毕业后，政治局势发生了实质性的变化，他于1952年回到了家乡。

GONZALO SÁNCHEZ DE LOZADA—known by the nickname Goni and president of Bolivia from 1993 to 1997—was always fascinated by the American bank robbers Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid. It had to do with his having been born Bolivian but then growing up in the United States—a consequence of his father’s exile after a military coup. In Bolivia, coups were commonplace—189 took place in the 172 years after independence. At every New Year during their exile in the United States, Goni’s family would make a toast: “Next year, may things change and we will go home.” That year never seemed to arrive. But finally, after Goni had completed a degree in philosophy at the University of Chicago, the political situation did change sufficiently and in 1952 he went home.

这并不容易。就连身体上的适应都十分困难。首都拉巴斯位于安第斯山脉，海拔一万一千英尺，即使只是在陡峭的鹅卵石街道上走一两个街区，也会让人气喘吁吁。戈尼曾尝试以电影制作人的身份起步，但在这样一个经济规模很小的地方，这最终证明只是个异想天开的爱好。为了谋生，他开始为石油勘探公司拍摄航拍照片，寻找有前景的油田，后来又开始为丛林中的勘探营地运送物资。

It was not easy. Even the physical adjustment was difficult. La Paz, the capital, is eleven thousand feet high in the Andes, and walking just a block or two up one of its steep cobbled streets leaves one badly winded. Goni tried to get himself started as a filmmaker, which proved to be a whimsical pursuit in such a small economy. To make a living, he took up aerial photography for oil exploration companies looking for promising terrain and then went into the business of delivering supplies to exploration camps in the jungle.

但布奇·卡西迪和圣丹斯小子那惊心动魄的故事始终萦绕在他的脑海中。这对著名的亡命之徒逃到了玻利维亚，躲过了法律的追捕，最终在那里被追杀致死。“美国西部，”戈尼喜欢说，“死在了玻利维亚的山区。”他研究了他们的故事，并写了一个电影剧本，米高梅公司以几千美元的价格买下了改编权；但这部电影最终未能拍摄。很久以后，由罗伯特·雷德福和保罗·纽曼主演的版本上映了，该版本是根据某人的真实故事改编的。他曾考虑过以抄袭为由起诉他人，但一位律师劝说他，诉讼费用会非常高昂。失望之余，戈尼放弃了剧本创作——反正这只是他的副业——转而创办了一家成功的矿业公司，并积极投身于民主运动。他还迎娶了1959年的玻利维亚小姐。

But the dramatic story of Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid maintained its hold on his imagination. The famous desperadoes had escaped to Bolivia one step ahead of the law, and there, still pursued, they perished. “America’s Old West,” Goni liked to say, “died in the mountains of Bolivia.” He researched their story and wrote a film script, which MGM optioned for a few thousand dollars; but it never got made. When the version starring Robert Redford and Paul Newman came out much later, based on somebody else’s script, he considered suing for plagiarism, but a lawyer persuaded him that the costs of fighting the case would be prohibitive. Disappointed, Goni gave up scriptwriting—it had been a sideline anyway—and instead went on to become a founder of a successful mining enterprise, as well as a campaigner for democracy. He also married Miss Bolivia of 1959.

休克疗法：第21060号法令

Shock Therapy: Decree 21060

多年后，到了20世纪80年代中期，戈尼又创作了另一个剧本——名为“休克疗法”。这并非一部电影，而是一个旨在迅速而大规模地——几乎是一夜之间——将经济从政府主导型经济转变为市场经济的方案。尽管这个方案如今已在全球范围内实施，但它起源于拉丁美洲，戈尼作为最初的作者理应获得赞誉。此外，他以创纪录的速度完成了这部剧本，而他所面临的期限并非来自制片厂，而是迫在眉睫的灾难。

Years later, in the mid-1980s, Goni came to write another script—one called “shock therapy.” It was not a movie but a program for a rapid and massive—indeed almost overnight—economic shift from a government-dominated economy to a market economy. Although the script has now been played out around the world, it began in Latin America, and Goni deserves credit as the original author. Moreover, he wrote it in record time, with a deadline imposed not by a studio but by looming disaster.

20世纪80年代中期，玻利维亚陷入了严重的危机，经济被恶性通货膨胀所吞噬，一片混乱。当时，戈尼是一名参议员，后来在1985年上台的新政府中担任计划部长。玻利维亚的经济体系是典型的拉丁美洲模式：以发展、民族主义和反美主义的名义，前几届政府直接控制了大部分经济活动。对于国家不拥有的领域，则实行严格的监管。然而，无论政府的雄心壮志如何，它都无法胜任。政府机构效率低下、能力不足，腐败和裙带关系盛行。政府肆意挥霍，大幅提高工资以吸引工人，但随后却因普遍存在的通货膨胀而血本无归。税收几乎为零，政府收入中只有3%来自税收，其余全部来自中央银行。国家不堪重负，背负着沉重的国际债务。贫困和不平等现象日益加剧。 1982年开始的债务危机雪上加霜，恶性通货膨胀率达到了24000%，人们担心它很快就会飙升至100万%。留给采取行动的时间已经不多了。

In the mid-1980s, Bolivia was in terrible crisis, its economy gripped by hyperinflation and in total disarray. At the time, Goni was a senator, and then he became minister of planning in a new government that came to power in 1985. Bolivia had a classic Latin American economic system: In the name of development, nationalism, and anti-Americanism, preceding governments had taken direct ownership of much of the economy. What the state did not own, it heavily regulated. But whatever the ambitions, government was not up to the task. The governmental machinery was incompetent and inefficient, blatantly open to corruption and favoritism. The spigots of spending were wide open. Workers were courted with large salary hikes and then lost their money through inflation, which was endemic. Almost no taxes were collected. Only 3 percent of government revenues came from taxes: The rest were from the central bank. The country groaned under its burden of international debt. Both poverty and inequality were increasing. With the added blow of the debt crisis, which had begun in 1982, hyperinflation had reached the rate of 24,000 percent, and there was fear that it could soon multiply to 1 million percent. Very little time was left to act.

然而，对于该如何应对，人们几乎没有达成共识。对大多数人来说，经济基本组织的大规模变革是不可想象的。戈尼却不这么认为。“恶性通货膨胀令人恐惧，”他解释说，“恶性通货膨胀和债务危机让许多原本难以想象的事情变得触手可及。如果没有这些措施，再多的理论说服也无法让政府和民众采取他们最终采取的行动。但真正影响我的是我作为一名商人的经历。我曾身处体制之中，亲眼目睹了它的弊端。私营部门试图从公共部门的运作中牟利，而公共部门却在削弱私营部门。这段经历，加上争取民主的长期斗争，让我确信旧体制已经行不通了。”

Yet there was little agreement on what to do. Large-scale change in the basic organization of the economy was, for most people, unthinkable. Goni thought otherwise. “The hyperinflation was frightening,” he explained. “A lot that seemed unimaginable became imaginable with hyperinflation and the debt crisis. No amount of intellectual persuasion could have gotten governments and people to take the steps they did without them. But what really influenced me was my experience as a businessman. I had been inside the system, and I saw that it didn’t work. The private sector tried to profit from the public sector’s workings, and the public sector was undermining the private sector. That experience, plus the long struggle for democracy, convinced me that the old system just couldn’t work anymore.”

但还有其他选择吗？戈尼认为自己是“中间偏左”的。他解释说：“我一直都意识到自己生活在一个贫穷的国家，必须想办法解决贫困问题。”尽管如此，他还是把德国的路德维希·艾哈德视为某种意义上的知识分子榜样。戈尼经常阅读《经济学人》，并从中了解世界其他地方正在发生的事情，包括撒切尔夫人领导下的英国和亚洲的经济奇迹。有两件事对他影响尤为深刻。“第一件事，”他说，“是新西兰。为了国家发展，工党政府不得不拆除多年前保守党政府建立的指令型经济体制。第二件事是中国。毛泽东一直被描绘成先锋人物。但邓小平掌权并推行改革时，我印象深刻。他那句‘只要能抓到老鼠，什么猫都无所谓’的话尤其让我印象深刻。”

But what were the alternatives? Goni saw himself as “left of center.” He explained, “I always recognized that I live in a poor country and that you have to figure out how to address poverty.” Still, he found something of an intellectual role model in Germany’s Ludwig Erhard. Goni was a regular reader of The Economist and from its pages followed what was happening elsewhere in the world, including Mrs. Thatcher’s Britain and the Asian economic miracles. Two things had a particular impact on him. “The first,” he said, “was New Zealand, where, in order that the country could grow, a labor government had to dismantle the command-and-control economy that had been created many years earlier by a conservative government. The second was China. Mao had always been portrayed as the cutting edge. But I was impressed when Deng came to power and initiated changes. I was particularly impressed by his statement that he didn’t care what kind of cat it was so long as the cat caught mice.”

戈尼开始引用邓小平关于猫的言论。这些例子更加坚定了他的信念：恢复玻利维亚经济健康的唯一途径是消除国家主义——采取激进措施。他的“休克疗法”方案初稿是1985年8月颁布的第21060号法令。该法令取消了价格管制，大幅削减预算，降低关税以引入竞争性定价，并开始对公共部门进行彻底重组和削减开支。戈尼和他的同事们冒着巨大的风险，仅凭中央银行150万美元的资金——几乎是零——就采取了所有这些措施。他们敢于冒险的原因是信息系统极其落后；戈尼说：“我们当时并不知道我们只有这些。”

Goni took to quoting Deng on the subject of cats. And these examples reinforced his conviction that the only way to restore Bolivia’s economic health was by eliminating statism—by taking dramatic steps. The first draft of his shock-therapy script was Decree 21060, in August 1985. It eliminated price controls, instituted drastic budget reductions, slashed tariffs to introduce competitive pricing into the economy, and began a radical restructuring of the public sector and a reduction in its spending. Goni and his colleagues took a huge risk in doing all this backed by only $1.5 million in the central bank—almost nothing. The reason they dared to take the risk was that the information system was so poor; he said, “We didn’t know that was all we had.”

在接下来的几个月里，戈尼和他的团队继续推进休克疗法计划的实施。他们需要建议，但这并非当时世界银行所能提供的帮助。然而，几个月前，在马萨诸塞州剑桥市，哈佛大学经济学教授杰弗里·萨克斯收到了一份关于玻利维亚研讨会的通知。他对恶性通货膨胀这种奇异现象非常感兴趣，而玻利维亚的案例是四十年来首例。他走进了会议室，立刻被深深吸引。由于他是经济学系唯一一位到场的教授，他自然而然地融入了讨论，并像一位优秀的教授一样，最终走到了黑板前。过了一会儿，从教室后排传来一个类似谚语的问题：“如果你这么聪明，为什么不来玻利维亚看看呢？” 他去了。

Over the next several months of 1985, Goni and his team put the rest of the plan for shock therapy in place. They needed advice, but this was not the sort of help the World Bank was providing at that time. Some months earlier, however, in Cambridge, Massachusetts, Harvard economics professor Jeffrey Sachs had received a notice about a seminar on Bolivia. He was deeply interested in the bizarre phenomenon of hyperinflation, and Bolivia’s was the first case in forty years. He wandered into the meeting and was mesmerized. Since he was also the only member of the economics faculty who had bothered to show up, he was drawn into the discussion and, like a good professor, ended up at the blackboard. After a while, from the back of the room, came a variant of a proverbial question: “If you’re so smart, why don’t you come to Bolivia?” He went.

在拉巴斯的一次鸡尾酒会上，萨克斯遇到了戈尼。戈尼意识到，这位教授正是他苦苦寻觅的人选。萨克斯提供了他们所需的大量分析工作和专家指导。他们的目标很明确——迅速遏制通货膨胀。玻利维亚当时有450种不同的税种，其中大部分从未被征收。萨克斯帮助戈尼和他的团队将税种减少到7种易于征收的税种。他还就如何管理中央银行以及需要哪些类型的金融控制措施提出了建议。此外，他还帮助他们树立了坚持信念的信心。

At a cocktail party in La Paz, Sachs met Goni, who realized that the professor was just the man he was looking for. Sachs provided a good deal of the analytical work and expert guidance they needed. The objective was clear—to end inflation very quickly. Bolivia had 450 different taxes, most of which were never collected. Sachs helped Goni and his team reduce the number to 7 easily collectible taxes. He provided input about how to manage the central bank and what kind of financial controls were necessary. And he helped give them the confidence to stand by their convictions.

1985年至1987年间玻利维亚发生的事件给玻利维亚带来了稳定。该国通货膨胀率从24000%降至9%。政府削减开支，取消补贴，实行物价和贸易自由化，征收税款并改革税制，同时启动了紧急社会保障计划。1987年，玻利维亚在国际货币基金组织（IMF）的主持下实施了首个债务削减计划。总而言之，玻利维亚人完成了在拉丁美洲前所未有的壮举。“我们一夜之间建立了市场经济，”戈尼说道。“问题在于采取冲击式改革还是渐进式改革。但渐进式改革行不通；原有体系已经崩溃。我们只有很短的时间采取行动。那些看似不可能的事情最终变成了可能。”

What unfolded in Bolivia between 1985 and 1987 brought stability to the country. The inflation rate was reduced from 24,000 percent to 9 percent. Government spending was reduced, subsidies were cut, prices and trade were liberalized, taxes were collected and the tax system reformed, and an emergency social safety net program was put in place. In 1987, Bolivia was able to implement the first debt-reduction program under IMF auspices. Altogether, the Bolivians had done something that was unthinkable in Latin America. “We created a market economy overnight,” said Goni. “The issue was shock versus gradualism. But there was no gradualist solution; the system had broken down. There was only a brief time to act. Things that seemed impossible to do became possible.”

戈尼不仅要应对玻利维亚的危机，还要推动拉丁美洲彻底摒弃传统的国家与市场模式。几十年来，这些国家的政府对本国经济拥有绝对的控制权。尽管各国之间存在着明显的差异，但一些共同特征将该地区联系在一起：军国主义、马克思主义、反马克思主义、民粹主义和反美主义以各种方式交织在一起。一些军事独裁者身着准法西斯式的制服招摇过市；另一些则高喊社会主义口号。无论其装束如何，国家都通过直接所有权、庇护主义和恩庇制来控制经济生活；政府被视为经济增长的核心引擎。

Goni was not only taking on Bolivia’s crisis but also helping initiate a radical turn away from what had been the traditional Latin American approach to state and marketplace. For decades, these governments had thoroughly dominated their national economies. Despite the obvious differences among countries, common features tied the region together: Militarism, Marxism, anti-Marxism, populism, and anti-Americanism were all intertwined in various ways. Some military dictators strutted around in quasi-fascist uniforms; others mouthed the slogans of socialism. Whatever the garb, the state controlled economic life through direct ownership, clientelism, and patronage; government was deemed the central engine of economic growth.

上世纪90年代末，这种模式正在被打破。虽然尚未出现能够完全取代它的单一体系，但总体方向已经明确——走向市场自由化，通过私有化减少并重新定义国家角色，使其退出生产领域；通过限制政府支出抑制通货膨胀；降低贸易壁垒；以及将传统经济活动从国家手中转移出去。在很大程度上，这一进程与该地区民主的显著复兴齐头并进，而该地区过去常常是军人独裁统治的常态。1

In the late 1990s, that model is being broken. No single system has emerged to take its place, but the general direction is clear—toward freeing markets, reducing and redefining the role of the state and removing it from production through privatization, taming inflation by constraining government spending, lowering trade barriers, and shifting traditional activities out of the state’s hands. For the most part, this process has gone hand in hand with a remarkable rebirth of democracy in a region where military dictatorship too often seemed the norm in the past.1

附属规则

Dependencia Rules

拉丁美洲传统的国家主义模式深受依附理论（或称“依附论”）的影响。该理论为国家主导地位辩护，其手段包括高进口壁垒、封闭经济以及对市场的普遍压制。从20世纪40年代末到80年代，依附理论一直占据主导地位。其起源可追溯至20世纪20年代末30年代的大萧条时期，当时大宗商品价格暴跌重创了拉丁美洲以出口为导向的经济体。与此同时，在当时的社会氛围下，“国家安全”成为政府接管经济“战略部门”以满足国家而非国际投资者需求的借口。这尤其导致了多个国家国有石油公司的成立。二战后，对国家依赖程度的进一步加深，是由……推动的。西方福利国家和凯恩斯主义干预主义的兴起，以及马克思主义和苏联的声望，都对拉丁美洲经济学家及其政府产生了影响。此外，还有一个因素促使他们采取这种行动：反美主义——既惧怕北方的庞然大物，又反感那些被视为在拉丁美洲剥削性的美国公司。

The traditional statist approach in Latin America was greatly influenced by what was known as dependencia, or dependency theory. It rationalized state dominance—high import barriers, a closed economy, and a general demotion of the market. And from the end of the 1940s right up to the 1980s, dependencia ruled. Its origins were in the late 1920s and 1930s and the Great Depression, when the collapse of commodity prices devastated the export-oriented economies of Latin America. Meanwhile, in line with the tenor of those times, “national security” became a justification for governments to take over “strategic sectors” of the economy to meet the needs of the nation, not those of international investors. This led, notably, to the founding of state oil companies in a number of countries. After World War II, the shift toward a much greater reliance on the state was propelled by the emergence in the West of both the welfare state and Keynesian interventionism and by the prestige of Marxism and the Soviet Union. One other thing motivated both Latin American economists and their governments: anti-Americanism—fear of the colossus to the north, and antipathy to what were seen as exploitative American corporations operating in the Latin arena.

依附理论家们否定了世界贸易的益处。到20世纪40年代末，他们的思想核心要素已被联合国拉丁美洲经济委员会（ECLA）阐明并推广——尤其值得一提的是阿根廷经济学家劳尔·普雷维什，他于1948年至1962年担任该委员会主席。用他自己的话说，他职业生涯之初是“新古典主义理论的坚定信徒”。但“资本主义的第一次重大危机——大萧条——让我对这些信念产生了严重的怀疑”。普雷维什和他在拉丁美洲经济委员会的同僚们提出了一种国际化的阶级斗争必然论。他们认为，世界经济被划分为工业“中心”（美国和西欧）和商品生产“边缘”。贸易条件总是对边缘不利，这意味着中心将持续剥削边缘。富者愈富，贫者愈贫。在这种论述下，国际贸易并非提高生活水平的途径，而是工业化国家及其跨国公司实施的一种剥削和掠夺。受害者是发展中国家的人民。这种观点逐渐成为拉丁美洲各大学普遍接受的共识。

The dependencia theorists rejected the benefits of world trade. By the end of the 1940s, the essential elements of their thinking were already articulated and promoted by the United Nations Economic Commission on Latin America (ECLA)—and most notably by an Argentinean economist named Raúl Prebisch, who headed the commission from 1948 until 1962. He began his career, in his words, as “a firm believer in neoclassical theories.” But “the first great crisis of capitalism—the Great Depression—prompted in me serious doubts regarding those beliefs.” Prebisch and those who joined him at ECLA propounded an international version of the inevitability of class warfare. They argued that the world economy was divided into the industrial “center”—the United States and Western Europe—and the commodity-producing “periphery.” The terms of trade would always work against the periphery, meaning that the center would consistently exploit the periphery. The rich would get richer and the poor would get poorer. International trade, in this formulation, was not a method to raise standards of living but rather a form of exploitation and robbery, committed by the industrial nations and their multinational corporations. The victims were the peoples of the developing world. This belief became the received wisdom in universities across Latin America.

因此，边缘国家选择了一条独立发展的道路。它们不再出口大宗商品、进口成品，而是尽可能快速地转向所谓的“进口替代”工业化（ISI）。为了实现这一目标，它们通过高关税和其他形式的保护主义切断了与世界贸易的联系。幼稚产业的逻辑演变成了全产业的逻辑。货币被高估，从而降低了工业化所需设备的进口成本；所有其他进口商品都通过许可证和执照进行严格配给。高估的货币还推高了农产品和其他商品的价格，使其失去竞争力，从而抑制了出口。国内价格受到控制和操纵，补贴现象普遍存在。许多行业和活动被国有化。整个经济体系中充斥着错综复杂的管制和监管。赚钱的途径不是开发和服务市场，而是设法穿过行政和官僚迷宫。总而言之，主导经济的是官僚和政治决策，而不是来自市场的信号和反馈。

So instead, the periphery would go its own way. Rather than exporting commodities and importing finished goods, these countries would move as rapidly as possible toward what was called “import-substituting” industrialization (ISI). This would be achieved by breaking the links to world trade through high tariffs and other forms of protectionism. The infant-industry logic became the all-industry logic. Currencies were overvalued, which cheapened equipment imports needed for industrialization; all other imports were tightly rationed through permits and licenses. Overvalued currencies also discouraged agricultural and other commodity exports by raising their prices and thus making them uncompetitive. Domestic prices were controlled and manipulated, and subsidies were widespread. Many industries and activities were nationalized. A jungle of controls and regulations grew throughout the economy. The way to make money was by making one’s way through the administrative and bureaucratic maze rather than by developing and serving markets. Overall, what guided the economy were bureaucratic and political decisions, not signals and feedback from the market.

直到20世纪70年代，这种做法似乎行之有效。1950年至1970年间，实际人均收入几乎翻了一番。同期，国家的作用不断扩大，国有企业也随之发展壮大。关税和其他贸易壁垒不断提高。当时最大的批评是，政府做得不够，应该更加贴近民众。苏联和东欧实行的是中央计划经济模式。这种体制的深层缺陷大多被掩盖了——直到20世纪80年代初。2

Until the 1970s, the approach seemed to work. Real per capita income nearly doubled between 1950 and 1970. Over the same period, the role of the state continued to expand, as did state-owned enterprise. Tariffs and other trade barriers were raised. The biggest criticism at the time was that governments were not doing enough and that they should move closer to the centrally planned model of the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. The deep weaknesses of this system were mostly hidden—until the beginning of the 1980s.2

失去的十年

The Lost Decade

债务危机对拉丁美洲造成了沉重打击。借贷规模已达惊人的程度。1975年至1982年间，拉丁美洲的长期债务几乎翻了两番，从452亿美元增至1764亿美元。加上短期贷款和国际货币基金组织的信贷，1982年的总债务负担高达3330亿美元。然而，直到1982年8月墨西哥濒临违约之前，几乎没有人注意到这一不祥的增长。随之而来的是双重破产——金融和思想的双重崩溃。塑造拉丁美洲经济体系的理念和概念已经失效；它们再也无法获得资金支持。“依赖性”导致了它们的破产。此后几年，拉丁美洲努力重塑经济，这段时期被称为“失去的十年”。这并非没有道理。因为到1990年，也就是十年的末期，人均收入甚至低于十年前的水平。

The debt crisis hit Latin America very hard. The buildup in borrowing had been enormous. Between 1975 and 1982, Latin America’s long-term debt almost quadrupled, from $45.2 billion to $176.4 billion. Adding in shortterm loans and IMF credits, the total debt burden in 1982 was $333 billion. Yet no one was paying much attention to that ominous increase until August 1982, when Mexico teetered on default. What ensued was a double bankruptcy—financial and intellectual. The ideas and concepts that had shaped Latin American economic systems had failed; they could no longer be funded. Dependencia had caused them to go broke. The years that followed, in which Latin America struggled to reshape its economies, became known as the “lost decade.” And with good reason. For at its end, in 1990, per capita income was lower than it had been at the beginning of the decade.

多年来，旧体制的全部代价逐渐显现。它扶持的工业企业——无论是私营的还是国有的——由于保护主义、缺乏竞争以及与技术创新脱节，效率低下。这些企业大多忽视服务质量和规模。农业遭受重创。财政赤字激增。通货膨胀普遍且根深蒂固，家庭储蓄被蚕食殆尽。结果，人们无法安享晚年。在赤字和宽松货币政策的推动下，通货膨胀飙升至惊人的水平。国内经济无法享受国际贸易带来的益处，社会不平等问题也未得到任何改善。3

Over those years, the full costs of the old system came to be reckoned. The industrial enterprises—both private and state owned—that it had fostered were inefficient, owing to protectionism, lack of competition, and isolation from technological innovation. For the most part, they put little emphasis on quality and scale of service. Agriculture was seriously damaged. Budget deficits swelled. With inflation pervasive and deeply entrenched, family savings were devastated. As a result, people could not retire. Inflation rose to astounding levels, driven by the deficits and loose monetary policy. The domestic economies were denied the benefits of international trade, and there was no improvement in fundamental social inequality.3

新的共识：“我们要求太多了𔄥

The New Consensus: “We Asked Too Much𔄥

在债务危机爆发的最初几年，当务之急是帮助各国摆脱破产困境，稳定经济。各国的国际收支必须得到恢复，而这在很大程度上是在紧缩政策和国际货币基金组织（IMF）的“附加条件”框架下实现的。IMF牵头实施紧急贷款、信贷和债务重组计划，前提是各国必须采取措施减轻债务负担、减少赤字、抑制通货膨胀，并使汇率更加合理。

In the first few years of the debt crisis, the urgent need was to pull the countries back from bankruptcy and stabilize their economies. Their balance of payments had to be restored, much of which was accomplished under the aegis of austerity and the “conditionality” of the International Monetary Fund. The IMF took the lead in implementing emergency programs of loans, credits, and debt reschedulings if the countries, in turn, would take steps to shrink their burden of debt, reduce their deficits, temper inflation, and make their exchange rates more realistic.

但在20世纪80年代末和90年代，拉丁美洲开始出现一种更为根本性的变革——国家在经济中扮演的角色发生了根本性的重新调整。重点从政府转向市场，市场成为资源配置的基本主体。经济方面，一位新思潮的领军分析家将其描述为“发展和利用市场，而不是谴责、压制和扭曲市场”。政府的退缩意味着大规模私有化，总体而言，意味着更少的管制。这也意味着降低贸易和外国投资壁垒，以弥补债务危机导致的信贷枯竭。各国政府致力于减少赤字和通货膨胀，并改革税收制度。公共支出将尽可能更多地受经济回报而非政治需要驱动。汇率将更具竞争力和可预测性。产权将得到加强。在整个经济领域，应鼓励竞争，而非垄断和控制。

But in the late 1980s and into the 1990s, something more fundamental began to unfold throughout Latin America—a drastic reordering of the basic principles regarding the role of the state in the economy. The emphasis shifted from government to the market as the basic allocator of resources in the economy. One of the leading analysts of the new thinking described it as nothing less than a move toward “developing and using the market, rather than denouncing, repressing, and distorting markets.” The retreat of government meant large-scale privatization and, in general, fewer controls. It also meant lowering the barriers to both trade and foreign investment, in order to replace the lending that had dried up with the debt crisis. Governments focused on reducing deficits and inflation, and reforming their tax systems. To the degree possible, public expenditures would be driven more by economic returns than by political exigencies. Exchange rates would be competitive and more predictable. Property rights were to be strengthened. And throughout the economy, competition, rather than monopoly and control, was to be encouraged.

或许只有在旧体制下成长起来的人才能完全理解这种变化的程度。恩里克·伊格莱西亚斯多年来一直与拉丁美洲经济委员会（ECLA）保持密切联系，与劳尔·普雷维什共事。如今，他是美洲开发银行行长。“我从未想过会发生如此巨大的变化，”他说。“在大萧条和第二次世界大战后的四十年里，我们一直指望政府承担起振兴经济的重任。我们要求国家提供一切所需。我们对政府的要求太高，时间也太长了。我们必须做出选择。现在，我们已经迅速回归市场经济。四十年前，我根本无法想象这一切。”

Perhaps only those who had grown up in the old system could fully grasp the extent of the change. For many years, Enrique Iglesias was associated with ECLA, working closely with Raúl Prebisch. He is now the head of the Inter-American Development Bank. “I would never have imagined this much change,” he said. “For forty years following the Great Depression and the Second World War, we looked to government to take on the task of reviving our economies. We asked the state to deliver the goods. We asked too much of government, for too long. We had to make a choice. Now we have taken a sharp turn back to the market economy. I could not have imagined this forty years ago.”

总而言之，这一系列新思想将在20世纪90年代塑造拉丁美洲的经济格局。如同任何此类思想体系一样，它也拥有了一个专属名称——“华盛顿共识”。然而，它的倡导者，经济学家约翰·威廉姆森，却一直对这个术语感到后悔。他指出，为了推动“拉丁美洲的政策改革”，他不得不使用“一个不那么外交辞令的标签”。这个标签重新激起了人们的旧情绪，并再次唤起了人们对美国主导地位的担忧。正如一位对“华盛顿共识”持批评态度的人士用他那老派的热情所言，这个术语“直白地揭示了20世纪后期政策的制定者——不是各国政府，而是华盛顿。‘华盛顿’……不仅指国际货币基金组织和世界银行，还包括它们那并非完全隐秘的幕后主使——美国政府，以及在其背后那些隐秘的幕后主使——美国经济学界和西方商业利益集团。”

Altogether, this new stock of ideas would shape the economies of Latin America in the 1990s. And like any such group of ideas, it acquired a moniker—in this case, the Washington Consensus. It is a term that its promulgator, the economist John Williamson, has regretted ever since. In the interest of promoting “policy reform in Latin America,” he observed, “it is difficult to think of a less diplomatic label.” It refueled all the old emotions and revived the specter of Yankee domination. As one critic of the Washington Consensus put it with good old-fashioned gusto, the term “was coming clean about who made policy in the late twentieth century—not governments, but Washington. ‘Washington’ … embraced not only the IMF and the World Bank but also their less than shadowy master—the U.S. government—and behind it, its shadowy masters, the American economics profession and Western business interests.”

这或许是阴谋论或电影的绝佳素材。但这种长篇大论完全忽略了其中的讽刺意味。“华盛顿共识”是由拉丁美洲人在拉丁美洲制定的，旨在应对该地区内外正在发生的事情。摆在人们面前的是政府失灵，而非市场失灵。旧体制已无法带来经济增长。人们在恶性通货膨胀和基本公共服务严重不足的困境中挣扎求生。

Good stuff for a conspiracy theory or a film. But such a diatribe missed the whole irony. The Washington Consensus was developed in Latin America, by Latin Americans, in response to what was happening both within and outside the region. Government failure was what now loomed before people’s eyes, not market failure. The old system could no longer deliver economic growth. People struggled to live with hyperinflation and woefully inadequate basic services.

外部因素也产生了重大影响。与世界许多其他地区一样，共产主义的崩溃动摇了拉丁美洲对社会主义和中央计划的信念。卡斯特罗领导下的古巴不再像以往那样是……的先锋。它既不是革命的先锋，也不是任何事物的先锋，而更像是一件仅靠苏联补贴勉强维持的古老遗迹。即便苏联模式的失败已昭然若揭，拉丁美洲经济学家也开始关注亚洲的经济成功。这实际上是一个发现的过程，因为在此之前，他们几乎完全忽视了该地区。亚洲经济监管较少，通货膨胀率也低得多，汇率更具竞争力，波动性也更小。与拉丁美洲不同，亚洲经济迅速从债务危机中复苏。与依附关系的种种限制形成鲜明对比的是，亚洲经济已明显融入世界经济。到了20世纪80年代末，曾经站在依附关系前沿的拉丁美洲经济委员会（ECLA）开始彻底转变思路，开始谈论“外向型”经济的必要性以及摆脱政府控制的必要性。

External factors also loomed large. As in many other parts of the world, the collapse of communism undermined Latin America’s faith in socialism and central planning. Castro’s Cuba no longer looked like the vanguard of revolution, or indeed the vanguard of anything, but rather like an archaic relic that had managed to stay afloat only on a sea of Soviet subsidies. Even as the failures of the Soviet model became completely apparent, Latin American economists began to focus on the economic success of Asia. It was really a process of discovery, for they had mostly ignored the region until then. The Asian economies were less regulated and much less inflationary, and their exchange rates were competitive and less volatile. Unlike the Latins, the Asians had rebounded quickly from their debt crisis. And in striking contrast to the strictures of dependencia, the Asians had manifestly anchored themselves in the world economy. By the late 1980s ECLA, formerly at the forefront of dependencia, began, in what was nothing less than a complete turnaround in thought, to talk about the necessity of “outward oriented” economies and a shift away from government control.

技术政客

The Technopols

这一概念重构的过程得益于该地区涌现出的一批市场导向型经济学家。他们中的许多人前往北方，在哈佛大学、麻省理工学院、耶鲁大学、斯坦福大学和芝加哥大学等顶尖学府攻读博士学位。他们的前辈在很大程度上深受大萧条时期市场失灵的影响。但对他们以及年轻的教员而言，当时的经济问题是政府失灵。例如，在20世纪70年代中期，墨西哥未来的财政部长佩德罗·阿斯佩正在麻省理工学院攻读博士学位，而智利未来的财政部长亚历杭德罗·福克斯利当时是麻省理工学院的客座教授；阿根廷未来的财政部长多明戈·卡瓦略则在哈佛大学撰写博士论文。他们经常交流、一起慢跑，并结识了像劳伦斯·萨默斯（现任美国财政部副部长）和杰弗里·萨克斯这样的人，他们当时都在哈佛大学攻读博士学位。他们会见了麻省理工学院的鲁迪格·多恩布施和斯坦利·费舍尔（现任国际货币基金组织副总裁）；以及哈佛大学的本杰明·弗里德曼（财政政策专家）和马丁·费尔德斯坦（他们展示了高税收如何起到抑制作用）。

The process of reconceptualization was made possible by the emergence of a group of market-oriented economists throughout the region. Many of them had gone north to earn their Ph.D.’s at institutions such as Harvard, MIT, Yale, Stanford, and Chicago. Their senior teachers had been shaped, to a large degree, by the market failure of the Great Depression. But the economic problem of the day for them, and for the younger faculty members, was government failure. In the mid-1970s, for instance, Pedro Aspe, Mexico’s future finance minister, was doing his Ph.D. at MIT, where the future finance minister of Chile, Alejandro Foxley, was a visiting professor, while Domingo Cavallo, the future finance minister of Argentina, was writing his Ph.D. thesis at Harvard. They talked together and jogged together, and became friends of people like Lawrence Summers, now U.S. deputy Treasury secretary, and Jeffrey Sachs, both of whom were doing Ph.D.’s at Harvard at the time. They met MIT faculty members Rudiger Dornbusch and Stanley Fischer, now deputy managing director at the International Monetary Fund; and Harvard professors Benjamin Friedman, an expert on fiscal policy, and Martin Feldstein, who showed how high taxes function as disincentives.

这些拉丁美洲经济学家回国后，许多人不仅从事教职工作，还创办了自己的研究机构，进入政府部门，并致力于落实新的共识。他们被称为“技术政治家”，与早年的“技术官僚”形成鲜明对比。他们不仅致力于改善政府机器的运作，而​​且要想取得成功，他们本身也必须是优秀的政治家。毕竟，他们试图对本国经济的运行机制进行大规模改革，而众多机构和利益集团都牵涉其中，这显然是一项政治任务。

When these Latin American economists went home, many of them not only took teaching jobs but also established research institutes of their own, went into government, and generally set about trying to implement the new consensus. They became known as the “technopols,” in contrast to the “technocrats” of earlier years. They were not only making the machine of government work better; they also, if they were to be successful, had to be good politicians. After all, they were seeking to make massive changes in the workings of their economies, and with so many institutions and interests having so much at stake, that was a manifestly political task.

福克斯利说：“要想在经济管理方面做好技术工作，你必须成为一名政治家。如果你没有清晰表达的能力……”“要想说服反对者，想让人们接受某些不受欢迎的措施，你只会一败涂地。”他补充道，“经济学家不仅要了解他们的经济模型，还要了解政治、利益、冲突和激情。”福克斯利在这方面颇具权威。作为一名训练有素的经济学家，他也是皮诺切特独裁统治时期最主要的批评者之一，之后在智利首届民主政府中担任财政部长，并展现出卓越的才能。5

“To do a good technical job in managing the economy, you have to be a politician,” said Foxley. “If you do not have the capacity to articulate your vision, to persuade antagonists, to bring people around on some unpopular measure, then you are going to be a total failure.” He added, “Economists must not only know their economic models but also understand politics, interests, conflicts, passions.” Foxley could speak with some authority on this subject. A highly trained economist, he was also one of the foremost critics of the Pinochet government during the years of dictatorship, and then he proved to be a very effective finance minister in the first democratic Chilean government that followed.5

智利：模棱两可的榜样

Chile: The Ambiguous Role Model

智利成为了一个试验场，检验一种与二战后拉丁美洲经验截然不同的模式。但由于其实施与镇压和独裁紧密相连，这种模式最初备受争议，甚至遭到怀疑和彻底拒绝。然而，随着时间的推移，它却成为了该地区其他国家的榜样。

Chile became a laboratory for an approach that was wholly at odds with the Latin American experience since World War II. But it was regarded with great ambiguity—and, indeed, suspicion and outright rejection—because its implementation was so entwined with repression and dictatorship. Yet over time, it became a role model for the rest of the region.

1970年，萨尔瓦多·阿连德领导的社会主义政府上台，推行大规模国有化和征用政策，并实施价格管制，其目的似乎是为了在智利建立东欧式的经济模式。结果却导致经济混乱。阿连德政府最终被奥古斯托·皮诺切特将军发动的政变推翻，皮诺切特随后建立了独裁统治。皮诺切特极度恐惧共产主义和各种内部敌人，实行残酷统治，镇压工会成员、记者、学生以及其他被视为颠覆分子的人士。

In 1970, the socialist government of Salvador Allende came to power and embarked on a program of massive nationalization and expropriation, along with price controls, that seemed aimed at creating an Eastern European-style economy in Chile. The result was economic chaos. The Allende government was toppled in a coup led by General Augusto Pinochet, who in turn established a repressive dictatorship. Obsessed with the fear of communism and internal enemies of all sorts, Pinochet enforced a harsh reign, suppressing trade unionists, journalists, students, and others deemed subversive.

皮诺切特和他的军方同僚对经济学知之甚少。除了“国家安全”和镇压左翼之外，他们几乎没有任何纲领。但他们必须有所作为。一份与阿连德的纲领截然相反的文件名为《砖头》（El Ladrillo），这是一份篇幅巨大的手稿，最初由智利天主教大学经济系为1970年的基督教民主党总统候选人撰写。它倡导强有力的自由市场经济。其主要作者后来表示，《砖头》的撰写是为了“安抚我们的神经，一种疗愈……我们当时并不认为它有任何未来。”

Pinochet and his military colleagues knew little about economics. Beyond “national security” and repression of the left, they had hardly any program at all. But they had to do something. A program diametrically opposed to Allende’s existed in a document called El Ladrillo—The Brick—a massive manuscript originally prepared by the economics faculty of the Catholic University of Chile for the Christian Democratic presidential candidate in 1970. It advocated a strong free-market approach. Its chief author later said The Brick had been composed as “something for our nerves, a kind of therapy…. We didn’t see that it had any future.”

但皮诺切特政府采纳了《砖块》中的方案。随之而来的是“芝加哥学派”——一群市场导向的经济学家，他们中的许多人曾通过芝加哥大学与天主教大学的交换项目在芝加哥大学接受教育。这群人的思想导师是两位芝加哥大学的教授——米尔顿·弗里德曼，以及更重要的阿诺德·哈伯格。“芝加哥学派”着手将《砖块》中的方案付诸实践。但即使对于一个权力高度集中的政权来说，这项任务也绝非易事。一位经济部长曾说，他90%的时间都花在了“向将军们和全国人民解释什么是自由市场上。这是一个全新的实验，而且……”阻力巨大。”皮诺切特被冗长的经济学讲座弄得疲惫不堪，恼怒不已，他厉声提醒经济学家们，智利的“锅柄”掌握在他手中，于是打断了讨论。一位芝加哥学派的领军人物反驳道，如果经济继续衰退，皮诺切特最终只会“只剩下锅柄”。将军勃然大怒。谁都不该这样跟他说话。然而，讲座还是继续进行着。6

But The Brick’s program was what the Pinochet government adopted. And along with it came “the Chicago Boys”—market-oriented economists, many of whom had been educated at the University of Chicago under an exchange program with the Catholic University.
