The intellectual mentors of this group were two Chicago professors—Milton Friedman and, even more so, Arnold Harberger. The Chicago Boys set about to turn the program in The Brick into reality. But the task was hardly easy even for a regime that had centralized power in its hands. One economics minister said that he spent 90 percent of his time “trying to explain to the generals and the country what a free market was. This was a totally new experiment, and there was huge resistance.” Tired and irritated by one long economics tutorial, Pinochet cut off the discussion by sternly reminding the economists that he was the one who held Chile’s “pot by the handle.” One of the leading Chicago Boys replied that if the economy continued to suffer, Pinochet would be left “holding just the handle.” The general was furious. No one was supposed to talk to him like that. Nevertheless, the lectures continued.6

芝加哥学派迅速推行了一系列根本性改革。他们放开物价，开放贸易，并放松金融管制。他们大规模私有化，将国有企业数量从1973年的500家锐减至1980年的25家。他们力求以最快的速度完成所有改革。他们的目标是瓦解自20世纪20年代末以来一直主导智利经济、并在各大利益集团间斡旋的“发展型国家”。具有讽刺意味的是，他们利用军事独裁政权的权力，试图建立一个在经济上极简主义的国家。

The Chicago Boys rapidly instituted a host of fundamental reforms. They freed prices, liberalized trade, and deregulated the financial sector. They privatized massively, reducing the number of state-owned companies from five hundred in 1973 to just twenty-five by 1980. They wanted to do everything as fast as they could. Their aim was to dismantle the “developmental state” that had run the Chilean economy since the end of the 1920s and mediated among the various strong interest groups. It was ironic that they used the power of a military dictatorship to try to impose what would be, in economic terms, a minimalist state.

改革取得了成效，尽管皮诺切特政权仍然是国际社会的弃儿，但也赢得了勉强的尊重。然而，1982年，由于整体债务危机、货币管理失误以及金融部门监管不力（该部门丑闻不断，破产频发），智利陷入了严重的经济衰退。“芝加哥男孩”的整个改革方案似乎都失去了信誉。军政府迷失了方向，其调整努力也收效甚微。由于不得不接管大量银行，这一时期被戏称为“通往社会主义的芝加哥之路”。1985年，第二代改革者掌权。他们不像最初的“芝加哥男孩”那样“血统纯正”——事实上，来自芝加哥大学的人更少，来自哈佛大学的人更多——他们的政策也更加宽松。他们成功地纠正了许多错误。在接下来的几年里，智利成为拉丁美洲市场改革的杰出典范。经济增长率高，通货膨胀率低，出口增长并更加多元化。优质智利葡萄酒在世界市场上占据了一席之地。

The reforms produced results, and even though the Pinochet regime continued to be an international pariah, it won grudging respect. In 1982, however, the country went into a severe economic tailspin, owing to the overall debt crisis, errors in currency management, and inadequate supervision of the financial sector, which was shaken by scandals and failures. The entire program of the Chicago Boys appeared to be discredited. The military government was disoriented, and its efforts to adjust were not very successful. It had to take over so many banks that the period became known jokingly as the “Chicago road to socialism.” A second generation of reformers took charge in 1985. They were less pure-bred than the original Chicago Boys—indeed, fewer came from Chicago and more from Harvard—and less austere in their policies. They succeeded in correcting many of the mistakes. And over the next several years Chile became the outstanding Latin American example of market reform. Growth rates were high, inflation was low, and exports grew and became more diversified. Quality Chilean wines found their place on the shelves of the world market.

最终，在20世纪80年代末，军方在全民公投中落败，被迫下台。1989年总统竞选最重要的意义——除了民主的到来之外——在于所有三位候选人，包括两位公开反对独裁统治的候选人，都支持改革。新政府的经济部长是亚历杭德罗·福克斯利，他曾在天主教大学创建了一个智库，该智库后来成为批评军政府的主要力量之一，尽管其批评披着经济学的外衣。在20世纪80年代初，他仍然主张国家应发挥重要的干预作用，包括“挑选赢家”。他后来坦言：“说实话，我对自由市场的信心不如对国家的信心。”十年后，作为经济部长，他致力于解决长期被忽视的贫困和不平等社会问题。但他的根本目标是巩固支持市场经济的共识，使新政府更加……他发现，自己必须捍卫市场改革，对抗新近获胜的民主党人，后者想要彻底摧毁独裁政权的一切成果。与此同时，为了应对“芝加哥男孩”试图解构干预主义国家的努力，他力图建立他所谓的“高效国家”。他解释说，他的目标是将“进步的社会政策与严苛的，有些人甚至会说是保守的财政政策”结合起来。

Finally, at the end of the 1980s, the military, defeated in a plebiscite, stepped aside. What was most decisive about the presidential campaign of 1989—beyond the advent of democracy—was that all three candidates, including two who were outright opponents of the dictatorship, endorsed the reforms. The economics minister in the new government was Alejandro Foxley, who had created a think tank at the Catholic University that had become one of the leading sources of criticism of the military government, though garbed in the language of economics. In the early 1980s, he had still argued for the state to play a large interventionist role, including, among other things, “picking winners.” “Truthfully,” he later said, “I had less confidence in the free market and more confidence in the state.” A decade later, as economics minister, he was intent on addressing the neglected social problems of poverty and inequality. But his fundamental objectives were to strengthen the consensus in favor of a market economy, make the new system work better, and consolidate and continue reform. He found that he had to defend the market reforms against newly victorious democrats, who wanted to dismantle any and all handiwork of the dictatorship. Simultaneously, in response to the Chicago Boys’ efforts to deconstruct the interventionist state, he sought to build what he called “the competent state.” His goal, he explained, was to combine a “progressive social policy with an austere, some would say conservative, fiscal policy.”

在爱德华多·弗雷政府的领导下，这一路线得以延续。“要了解智利，你需要一个广阔的视野，”能源部长亚历杭德罗·雅德雷西奇指出，“这并不容易。许多人反对最初的改革，因为这些改革出自一个不合法的军政府。如何既保留那些合理的改革，又能进一步推进改革？这正是像我这样的人投身政治的原因之一。我们担心这些改革会被推翻。民主政府对改革进行了重要的调整。现在，改革更加注重公平，强调社会需求、住房、医疗体系、教育和环境。但要让市场体系创造财富，让市场自由发展。”

That course has continued under the government of Eduardo Frei. “To understand Chile, you need a broad view,” observed Energy Minister Alejandro Jadresic. “It is not easy. Many people were against the original reforms because they came from an illegitimate military government. How to preserve the reforms that were rational, and go further with more reforms? That was one of the reasons why people like me got involved in politics. We were afraid that the reforms would be undone. The democratic governments have made important modifications to the reforms. There is now a strong equity consideration, stressing social needs, housing, the health system, education, the environment. But let the market system create the wealth. Let markets develop.”

1989年智利总统选举意义重大。尽管此前二十年饱受战乱和苦难，尽管激情澎湃、代价高昂，但几乎没有人愿意让市场经济倒退。这一点，连同经济成就本身，向拉丁美洲其他国家传递了一个强有力的信息，尤其是在它们亟需榜样之时。市场经济再也不能被视为独裁统治的遗物。智利孕育了新自由主义，并从那里传播到拉丁美洲其他地区——最直接的途径是越过安第斯山脉，到达阿根廷。7

The 1989 presidential election in Chile proved decisive. Despite the bitter strife and deep pain of the previous two decades, notwithstanding the passions and costs, few wanted to roll the market back. That—along with the economic achievement itself—sent a powerful message to the rest of the region, particularly at a time when it needed a role model. No longer could the market economy be dismissed as an artifact of dictatorship. Chile was where the new liberalism was nurtured and from whence it spread to the rest of Latin America—most immediately, across the Andes to Argentina.7

阿根廷悖论

The Paradox of Argentina

阿根廷长期以来都是一个经济悖论。这个在20世纪初曾是世界上最富裕的国家之一，为何最终陷入如此严重的经济混乱？胡安·庇隆对此负有不可推卸的责任。如今，人们记住他，当然是因为他与艾薇塔的婚姻，但在二战后的几年里，他却是民粹主义的化身，甚至带有一丝法西斯色彩。庇隆利用战前法西斯思想的流行，将阿根廷变成了一个社团主义国家，强大的利益集团——大企业、工会、军队、农民——为了权力和资源，与国家以及彼此之间进行着利益交换。他煽动民族主义情绪，鼓吹宏伟的野心，并推行强硬的反美政策。他将经济的很大一部分国有化，并设置贸易壁垒来捍卫这些国有资产。他切断了阿根廷与世界经济的联系——而世界经济曾是阿根廷财富的重要来源之一——使通货膨胀深入社会，并摧毁了稳健经济增长的基础。他他也曾广受欢迎——直到 1952 年艾薇塔去世。然而，此后经济变得如此混乱，以至于他明智地选择流亡。

Argentina had long been an economic paradox. How did a country that was one of the world’s richest in the first decades of the twentieth century end up in such economic disorder? A good part of the answer rested with Juan Perón. He is now best remembered, of course, as the husband of Evita, but in the years after World War II he was the embodiment of populism with an almost fascist tinge. Building on the prewar popularity of fascist ideas, Perón turned Argentina into a corporatist country, with powerful organized interest groups—big business, labor unions, military, farmers—that negotiated with the state and with each other for position and resources. He incited nationalist passions, stoked pretensions of grandeur, and pursued stridently anti-American policies. He nationalized large parts of the economy and put up trade barriers to defend them. He cut Argentina’s links to the world economy—which had been one of its great sources of wealth—embedded inflation in the society, and destroyed the foundations of sound economic growth. He was also wildly popular—until Evita’s death in 1952. Thereafter, however, the economy became so chaotic that he prudently went into exile.

随后的几年里，阿根廷总统和军政府频繁更迭。1973年，贝隆结束流亡生涯返回阿根廷，再次当选总统。不久后他便去世，留下他的新婚妻子伊莎贝尔担任总统。伊莎贝尔此前曾在巴拿马的夜总会当舞女，对总统之职并不胜任。阿根廷陷入更深的混乱。新的军政府上台，对左翼和其他人士发动了残酷的“肮脏战争”，成千上万的人像智利人一样被“强迫失踪”——有些人甚至被直接扔下飞机，抛入大西洋。军方在经济管理方面毫无能力，阿根廷深陷持续通货膨胀和严重衰退的泥潭。1982年，为了重振权威和民意，军方孤注一掷，进攻了英国的福克兰群岛（阿根廷称之为马尔维纳斯群岛）。正是这场战争，让玛格丽特·撒切尔获得了在英国推行大规模私有化的政治影响力。阿根廷军政府的失败削弱了他们的权威。在他们自认为最擅长的领域——战争——他们却表现得十分无能。1983年，他们向民选总统劳尔·阿方辛交出了政权。

The years that followed were characterized by a revolving door of elected presidents and military juntas. Perón returned from exile to become president again in 1973. He died shortly thereafter, leaving as president his new wife, Isabel, who was not really prepared for the job, having previously been a nightclub dancer in Panama. The country descended into further chaos. A new military junta took power, and it waged a vicious “dirty war” against the left and others, many thousands of whom were “disappeared” à la Chile—some simply thrown out of airplanes over the Atlantic. The military showed no competence in running the economy, which was mired in persistent inflation and a deep recession. In 1982, in a desperate gamble to restore its authority and popularity, the military attacked the British-owned Falkland Islands (known to the Argentines as the Malvinas). It was the same war that gave Margaret Thatcher the political clout to undertake large-scale privatization in Britain. The defeat of the Argentine military dictators undermined their authority. In the one thing at which they were supposed to be expert—warfare—they had proved quite incompetent. In 1983 they surrendered office to a democratically elected president, Raúl Alfonsín.

阿方辛的竞选口号是“民主还是反民主”。阿根廷曾饱受民主和反民主之苦。从1930年到他1983年当选总统，阿根廷经历了24位总统、26次成功的军事政变和数百次失败的政变。阿方辛最大的贡献在于恢复了民主和公民制度。但随着债务危机的爆发，他为稳定经济所做的临时努力失败了。国家深陷经济危机，他的政府也陷入混乱。他的一位经济部长，在阿方辛执政的第一年曾受到民众的拥戴，到了任期末期，却因为胆敢出门而被邻居们唾弃。

Alfonsín had campaigned on the slogan DEMOCRACY OR ANTIDEMOCRACY. Argentina had had an abundance of both. Between 1930 and his election in 1983, the country had gone through twenty-four presidents and twenty-six successful military coups and several hundred unsuccessful ones. Alfonsín’s great contribution was the restoration of democracy and civic institutions. But with the beginning of the debt crisis, his improvised efforts to stabilize the economy failed. The country remained in a deep economic crisis, and his administration was in disarray. One of his economics ministers, who had ridden on the shoulders of the crowd in the first year of Alfonsín’s government, was by the end of his term spit upon by his own neighbors when he dared to venture outside his home.

阿方辛之后，一位作风张扬、近乎异类的身着白西装的省长卡洛斯·梅内姆接任。梅内姆曾被形容为“精神分析学家的噩梦”，但他同时也是一位务实之人，能够迅速适应环境，并且几乎不拘泥于任何既定的理念。事实上，他的政策最初被描述为“一些被误解的观念的拼凑，有些来自墨索里尼，有些来自梅纳德·凯恩斯”。他以庇隆主义者的身份参选——有人形容他“留着鬓角的庇隆”——其竞选纲领是民粹主义、政府补贴和大手笔支出。他嘲讽他的对手，后者主张私有化和经济自由化。然而，当选后，梅内姆迅速采纳了对手的理念，并启动了拉丁美洲最激进、最迅速、最全面的市场改革计划之一。

Alfonsín was succeeded by a flamboyant, almost improbable, white-suited provincial governor, Carlos Menem. Once described as “a psychoanalyst’s nightmare,” Menem was also pragmatic, quick to adjust to circumstances, and hardly wedded to any set of ideas. Indeed, his policies were initially described as “a mismatch of misunderstood notions, some from Mussolini, some from Maynard Keynes.” He ran as a Peronist—he was described as “Perón with sideburns”—with a platform of populism, handouts, and spending. He derided his opponent, who advocated privatization and a freeing up of the economy. Once elected, Menem promptly adopted his opponent’s ideas and launched one of the most radical, speedy, and all-encompassing market reform programs in Latin America.

阿根廷别无选择。它已经走到了绝境。恶性通货膨胀率高达20000%，经济萎缩，街头爆发了粮食骚乱。债务负担高达580亿美元。梅内姆上任时，并没有明显的解决办法。再也不能像庇隆主义时期那样，通过通货膨胀式的工资上涨来解决问题了。“我们已经看过那套把戏了，”梅内姆曾这样解​​释道。与此同时，邻国智利证明了另一种选择。即使在阿根廷国内，也存在着另一种选择。20世纪70年代末，一家糖果制造商和一家建筑承包商共同出资成立了阿根廷和拉丁美洲现实经济研究所（IEERAL），这是一个位于内陆城市科尔多瓦的经济研究机构。该研究所的成员厌倦了社团主义，厌倦了各大利益集团之间的勾心斗角。他们认为，小型创业企业就像是被体制忽视和扼杀的穷亲戚。该研究所的研究人员研究了世界其他地区的市场改革，并将这些经验与阿根廷的实际情况联系起来。梅内姆上台时，他们已经阐述并实际上认可了一系列经济改革方案。当时梅内姆正处于政治风口浪尖，只要他认为这些建议有助于解决阿根廷的问题，他都愿意接受。但他却缺少一样东西——他自己的想法。他需要一个有想法的人。而他在科尔多瓦的研究所找到了这样一个人。8

There was really no choice. Argentina had run into a wall. Hyperinflationhad reached 20,000 percent, the economy was contracting, and food riots were taking place in the streets. The debt burden stood at $58 billion when Menem took office, and there was no obvious way to pay it off. It was no longer possible to play the old Peronist game of inflationary wage hikes. “We have already seen that movie,” Menem once explained. Meanwhile, next door, Chile demonstrated that there was an alternative. Yet even within Argentina an alternative could be found. In the late 1970s, a candy manufacturer and a building contractor had gotten together and endowed the Instituto de Estudios Económicos sobre la Realidad Argentina y Latinoamericana (IEERAL), an economic research institute in the inland city of Córdoba. Its members were sick of corporatism, with its wheeling and dealing among major interest groups. Smaller entrepreneurial businesses, they believed, were the poor relations, simultaneously ignored and smothered by the system. Researchers at this institute studied market reforms in the rest of the world and then, in their own work, related them to Argentina’s experience. By the time Menem came to power, they had articulated and indeed legitimized a host of ideas for reforming the economy. Menem, who had the political momentum, was ready to accept any suggestions if he thought they would help solve Argentina’s problems. But he lacked one thing—ideas of his own. He needed someone with ideas. And he found such a person at the institute in Córdoba.8

扫帚匠的儿子

The Broom-maker’s Son

该研究所的负责人，也是其议程的制定者，是经济学家多明戈·卡瓦洛，他后来成为重塑拉丁美洲国家与市场关系的最具影响力的人物之一。他出生于1946年，同年胡安·庇隆上台执政。如果说他一生中有什么宿敌，那就是庇隆，因为他的许多学术和政治努力都旨在驳斥和否定庇隆主义。卡瓦洛在内陆省份科尔多瓦长大，他后来表示，正是那里的生活经历让他对庇隆主义习以为常。“在远离布宜诺斯艾利斯的省份，人们最容易感受到过度扩张和专断的经济体系所带来的恶劣影响。”他自己的出身非常卑微；他的父亲拥有一家与自家相连的小型扫帚作坊。

The head of the institute, and the one who shaped its agenda, was the economist Domingo Cavallo, who would prove to be one of the most influential figures in recasting the relationship of state and marketplace in Latin America. He was born in 1946, the same year that Juan Perón took power. If he had one nemesis in his career, it was Perón, for many of his intellectual and political efforts were aimed at refuting and rejecting Peronism. Cavallo grew up in the interior province of Córdoba, which he would later say had inured him to Peronism. “It is in the provinces, away from Buenos Aires, where one most easily noticed the pernicious effects of an overexpanded and arbitrary economic system.” His own origins were very modest; his father owned a small broom-making shop that was connected to the family house.

卡瓦洛在科尔多瓦完成了本科学习，之后进入州政府工作。在那里，他越来越对自己在大学里学到的东西感到不满。“当时，人们非常强调市场失灵和计划经济的作用，”他回忆道，“我对市场经济缺乏了解。”于是，他开始自学。法国经济学教授、后来的法国总理雷蒙·巴尔的《经济学原理》对他影响颇深。巴尔着重阐述了“游戏规则”——经济是如何组织的，参与者是谁，以及他们的行为方式。“游戏规则”后来成为卡瓦洛长期关注的焦点，也是他经常挂在嘴边的一句话。他还深入研究了19世纪阿根廷关于市场经济宪政基础的思想。“我无法将这些思想与我在大学里学到的东西联系起来。”卡瓦洛说：“我决定去美国，以便更好地了解市场经济。”

Cavallo did his undergraduate studies in Córdoba and then worked in the state government, where he found himself increasingly dissatisfied with what he had learned in university. “At the time, there was a lot of emphasis on market failure and the role of planning,” he recalled. “I didn’t have the feeling of the market economy.” He began to educate himself. He was much influenced by The Principles of Economics by Raymond Barre, a French economics professor and later prime minister of France. Barre focused explicitly on “the rules of the game”—how an economy is organized, who the players are, how they behave. The rules of the game would turn into a lasting preoccupation—and an oft-repeated phrase—for Cavallo. He also plunged into nineteenth-century Argentinian thought on the constitutional basis for a market economy. “I could not relate those ideas to what I was taught in university,” said Cavallo. “I decided to go to the United States to understand the market economy better.”

卡瓦洛最终在20世纪70年代于哈佛大学攻读博士学位。他专注于阿根廷持续的通货膨胀和货币主义问题，由此产生了影响他日后政策的思想。阿根廷的通货膨胀是由政治领导人的财政不负责任造成的，他们不计代价地挥霍和干预经济——部分原因是出于不切实际的幻想。卡瓦洛认为，控制通货膨胀的方法是约束政治家，而不是控制货币供应。他对依赖论者嗤之以鼻。他认为，阿根廷的长期衰落并非外部因素（例如贸易条件）造成的，而是其内部政治文化的结果。阿根廷不应该抱怨国际贸易，而应该扩大和多元化其经济结构。

Cavallo ended up doing his Ph.D. at Harvard in the 1970s. He focused on Argentina’s persistent inflation and monetarism, out of which came the ideas that would shape his subsequent policies. Argentina’s inflation had been created by the fiscal irresponsibility of political leaders, who would spend and intervene no matter what the cost—motivated in part by grandiose illusions. Cavallo believed that the way to check inflation was to rein in the politicians, not the money supply. He was contemptuous of the dependencia theorists. Argentina’s long decline, he argued, was the result not of external forces—the terms of trade—but of the internal political culture. Instead of complaining about international trade, Argentina ought to have been expanding and diversifying it.

回到科尔多瓦后，卡瓦洛创建了IEERAL；担任这家新研究机构的主席为他提供了一个平台，让他得以阐述自己的理念，并培养一批志同道合的研究者。他的目标是弄清阿根廷经济为何会陷入如此严重的困境。“在19世纪下半叶英国建立的贸易体系中，阿根廷曾是世界上最成功的新兴经济体，”他说道，“究竟发生了什么？” 试图找出其中的规律，成为了IEERAL所有研究项目的永恒起点。

Returning to Córdoba, Cavallo organized IEERAL; the presidency of this new research institute gave him the platform from which to propound his ideas and develop a cohort of like-minded researchers. His objective was to understand why the Argentinean economy had gone so badly wrong. “Argentina had been the most successful emerging economy in the world in the trade system that Britain created in the second half of the nineteenth century,” he said. “What happened?” The attempt to identify the rules of the game became the perennial starting point for any research project at IEERAL.

20世纪80年代中期，卡瓦洛出版了《危机中的经济》一书。尽管这本书基于他十年的思考和分析，但他只用了四周时间就完成了写作。该书畅销一时，使他成为阿根廷的全国性人物。他对阿根廷经济弊病的诊断广为人知；他宣称，阿根廷的根本问题是“没有计划的社会主义和没有市场的资本主义”并存。他成功当选国会议员。尽管存在分歧，他和卡洛斯·梅内姆却成为了好友。梅内姆意识到卡瓦洛对他大有裨益。

In the mid-1980s, Cavallo published a book entitled Economy in Crisis. He wrote it in four weeks, although it was based on a decade of thought and analysis. The book was a best-seller and made him a national figure in Argentina. His diagnosis of Argentina’s ailment became famous; the nation’s essential problem, he announced, was the coexistence of “a socialism without plans and a capitalism without markets.” He got himself elected to Congress. Despite their differences, he and Carlos Menem became good friends. Menem recognized that Cavallo could be very useful to him.

梅内姆当选时，卡瓦洛是财政部长的最佳人选，但他的任命遭到了强大的商业利益集团的强烈反对，这些集团希望保住自己的地位，并担心竞争和放松管制。因此，梅内姆转而任命卡瓦洛为外交部长。毕竟，他的英语说得很好。与此同时，经济危机持续恶化。在上任的头十九个月里，梅内姆更换了三位经济部长，最终他选择了显而易见的候选人多明戈·卡瓦洛，并将经济大权交给了他。

Cavallo was the logical choice for finance minister when Menem won, but his appointment was strenuously opposed by powerful business interests, which wanted to preserve their position and feared competition and deregulation. And so instead, Menem made Cavallo foreign minister. After all, he did speak English very well. Meanwhile, the economy continued to sink further into crisis. Having gone through three economics ministers in his first nineteen months in office, Menem finally turned to the obvious choice, Domingo Cavallo, and handed the economy over to him.

卡瓦洛说话常常直率、尖锐、好辩，而且缺乏圆滑。有时他忍不住打电话到广播脱口秀节目中，纠正主持人或听众的错误。但他同时也展现出非凡的政治手腕——明确目标、有效沟通、整合各方力量、建立并巩固支持改革的广泛共识，以及与国际机构和金融界建立关系，这些机构和金融界的信任至关重要。当然，他的这种能力也得益于他敏锐的洞察力。绝望。没有人会怀疑这个国家正处于严重的危机之中。失败的代价显而易见——恶性通货膨胀。

Cavallo was often blunt, abrasive, argumentative, and tactless. Sometimes he could not resist calling in to radio talk shows to set the speakers and listeners straight. But he also demonstrated a remarkable skill at the required politics—identifying goals, communicating, folding groups in, creating and shaping a broad consensus in favor of reform, and building up relationships with the international institutions and financial community whose confidence would be essential. Of course, he was aided by a sense of desperation. No one could doubt that the country was in a severe crisis. The cost of failure was evident—hyperinflation.

卡瓦洛决心实施休克疗法，迅速在多个方面展开行动。首先，他快速降低贸易壁垒，并推行改革以鼓励竞争和新的出口导向型政策。其次，他将阿根廷货币比索与美元挂钩。根据《货币兑换法》，中央银行有义务按固定汇率将比索兑换成美元。这一举措彻底消除了一种传统的货币主权形式；政客和中央银行再也不能通过操纵汇率和肆意扩张国内信贷来推高通货膨胀。强制货币兑换对于降低通货膨胀至关重要。正如卡瓦洛所解释的：“我们需要改变阿根廷人的观念。这对于培养经济纪律至关重要。在此之前，政客和经济参与者根本没有预算约束的概念。”9

Determined to implement shock therapy, Cavallo moved quickly on several broad fronts. First, he rapidly reduced trade barriers and introduced reforms to encourage competition and a new export orientation. Second, he pegged the peso, the Argentinian currency, to the dollar. According to the Convertibility Law, the central bank was obliged to convert the austral into dollars at a fixed rate. This step decisively removed a classic form of sovereignty; no longer could politicians and the central bank feed inflation by manipulating the exchange rate and wantonly expanding domestic credit. The mandatory convertibility was of overwhelming importance in bringing down inflation. As Cavallo explained, “We needed to change the minds of Argentinians. That became very important in contributing to discipline. Before that, politicians and participants in the economy did not have any idea of a budget constraint.”9

私有化

Privatization

第三个要素是私有化。政府拥有庞大的企业资产组合，涵盖从传统公用事业到国有石油公司，甚至包括马戏团。这些企业大多组织架构陈旧，劳动法规繁琐，年复一年地累积巨额亏损，消耗着国家财政的大量资金。因此，它们是通货膨胀的主要来源之一。私有化旨在实现多个目标。它可以止损，使企业摆脱对公共财政的依赖。它有助于减轻阿根廷的债务负担。它还可以缩小政府规模，下放决策权，使政府不再扮演不合适的经济角色。它还可以改善电话和交通等领域糟糕的服务质量。最后，如果不进行私有化，从长远来看，控制通货膨胀是无望的。

The third element was privatization. The government owned an enormous portfolio of companies, ranging from the traditional utilities to the state oil company and a circus. Most of them, burdened with antique organizations and onerous labor regulations, racked up huge losses year after year, draining vast sums out of the national treasury. As such, they were one of the main sources of inflation. Privatization was intended to achieve several objectives. It would stanch such losses and get business off the public dole. It would help reduce Argentina’s debt burden. It would also reduce the size of the state, decentralize decision making, and take government out of an economic role that was inappropriate. It would provide a way to improve the quality of woefully poor services in such areas as telephones and transportation. And finally, there was no hope in the long term of taming inflation without privatization.

事实上，阿根廷将推行拉丁美洲各国中最广泛、最彻底的私有化计划之一。卡瓦洛和他的同事们在实践中不断学习。“最初的私有化给我们带来了大量资金，但却没有带来任何竞争带来的好处，”卡瓦洛说道，“我们从最初的经验中学到的最重要的一点是，必须最大限度地提高效率，并为消费者带来更多利益。我们需要提高服务的质量和数量，并降低成本。所有这些都将提高整个经济的生产力和竞争力。” 因此，卡瓦洛开始将放松管制视为私有化的必要前提。

Argentina would in fact carry out one of the most far-reaching and radical privatization programs of any country in Latin America. Cavallo and his colleagues learned as they went along. “The first privatizations brought us a lot of money but none of the benefits of competition,” said Cavallo. “The most important thing we learned from the initial experiences was the need to maximize efficiency and benefits to consumers. We needed to improve the quality and quantity of services and to lower costs. All this would increase the productivity and competitiveness of the entire economy.” Thus, Cavallo came to focus on deregulation as the necessary precedent to privatization.

规模最大的私有化项目是YPF的私有化，YPF是国家石油公司，也是庇隆主义国有企业的典型代表。梅内姆和卡瓦洛选择了何塞·埃斯滕索罗来负责私有化工作，埃斯滕索罗是一位在国际石油服务行业拥有三十年经验的温文尔雅的管理者。埃斯滕索罗提出了两种方案：要么拆分公司并出售各个业务部门，要么将公司规模“调整”至其战略核心。最终选择了后者。第一阶段，公司剥离了非核心资产，其中包括超市、电影院、俱乐部、飞机，甚至教堂。第二阶段是重组——引入全新的管理组织架构和一系列新的系统来支持这一架构。核心问题是就业。员工人数减少了近90%，从52,500人锐减至5,800人。如此大幅度的裁员表明了公司效率低下。除非解决就业问题，否则公司将永远无法摆脱亏损。“裁员是最痛苦的决定，”埃斯滕索罗说，“但整个过程没有发生罢工、社会动荡或停工。”事实上，公司处理此事非常谨慎——采取了多种措施，包括提前退休方案（其中一年为再培训期），以及丰厚的遣散费，同时还将部分员工的资产出售，并将他们转移出去。

The biggest privatization was that of YPF, the national oil company and the very embodiment of the Peronist state-owned enterprise. Menem and Cavallo selected José Estenssoro, an urbane executive with three decades of experience in the international oil service industry, to run the privatization. Estenssoro presented two alternatives: Either dismantle the company and sell off the parts, or “rightsize” the company to its strategic core. The latter approach was chosen. As a first stage, noncore assets were shed, among them supermarkets, movie theaters, clubs, airplanes, and even churches. The second stage was restructuring—introducing an entirely new management organization and a host of new systems to support that structure. The central issue was employment. It was reduced by almost 90 percent, from 52,500 employees to 5,800. The extent of the reduction was evidence of how inefficient the company was. Unless it addressed employment, it could never cease being a loss maker. “The reduction in the labor force was the most painful decision,” said Estenssoro, “but it took place without strikes, social unrest, or work stoppages.” Indeed, it was handled with extreme care—with a mixture of early-retirement packages that included a year of retraining followed by generous severance packages, along with the transfer of employees with assets that were sold off.

重组使YPF摇身一变，成为一家现代化企业，而非臃肿的政府机构。唯有如此，它才具备了私有化的条件。1993年，YPF成功上市，募资30亿美元，创下当时纽约证券交易所历史上规模最大的首次公开募股纪录。一家曾经臃肿低效、目光短浅、依赖保护主义的公司，一跃成为一家充满活力的国际竞争者，业务遍及拉丁美洲，之后又拓展至美国和亚洲。

The restructuring turned YPF into a firm that looked like a modern company, not a sprawling branch of government administration. Only then was it ready for privatization. The result was a stock offering in 1993—at $3 billion, the largest initial public offering up to that time in the history of the New York Stock Exchange. A lumbering, inefficient, inward-looking company dependent on protection had been transformed into a dynamic international competitor, operating throughout Latin America and, later, in the United States and Asia.

国家退出直接所有权并不意味着它就此退出市场。相反，它扮演了一个新的角色——卡瓦洛和他的同事们为此投入了大量精力——而这个角色与他关注的“游戏规则”非常契合。这个新角色就是建立监管规则和机构，以确保如今已私有化的垄断企业不会滥用其地位。这项努力后来引发了争议。此外，梅内姆在1995年连任后，他与卡瓦洛的关系急剧恶化，卡瓦洛于1996年辞职。不久之后，他便成为梅内姆政府的直言不讳的批评者；他提出了一系列耸人听闻的指控，包括腐败、司法操纵和黑手党控制。然而，他们之间的激烈分歧并没有动摇卡瓦洛的基本判断：“梅内姆是当时形势下最合适的人选。没有人能够如此迅速地实施如此多的改革。他是胜任这项工作的最佳人选。”

The retreat of the state from direct ownership did not mean that it was out of business. Rather, it held a new role—to which Cavallo and his colleagues had to devote considerable effort—and one that very much fit in with his preoccupation with the “rules of the game.” It was the creation of regulatory rules and bodies to ensure that the now-privatized monopolies did not take advantage of their position. That effort would become controversial. Moreover, relations between Menem and Cavallo deteriorated badly after Menem’s reelection in 1995, and in 1996 Cavallo resigned. It did not take long for him to become a very outspoken critic of Menem’s administration; he made dramatic charges of corruption, judicial manipulation, and mafia control. Yet their bitter differences have not disrupted Cavallo’s basic judgment: “Menem was the man for the circumstances. No one else could have implemented so many changes so fast. He was the man for the job.”

梅内姆和卡瓦略上任时，正如何塞·埃斯滕索罗所说，阿根廷“很难展望未来”，但他们成功地将阿根廷从过去的泥潭中拯救出来。几十年来，阿根廷一直是一个封闭的国家，这与其强烈的民族主义情绪相符。因此，向世界开放是一次巨大的转变。“那些年压力非常大，”卡瓦略说，“我们每周、每天都在战斗。但我在街上或商店里遇到的年轻人给了我很大的帮助，他们祝愿我能够创建一个新的阿根廷。我们取得的成就远远超出了预期。”阿根廷曾遭受重创。通货膨胀使国家陷入困境。它无法征收税款，无法批准预算，有钱人拼命想方设法将钱转移出境，公共服务每况愈下。新生的民主政体岌岌可危。国家被一段危险而令人窒息的过去所束缚。但在短短五年内，它重获新生。10

Menem and Cavallo came to office in a country where, in the words of José Estenssoro, it was very difficult “to think about the future,” and they succeeded in rescuing Argentina from its past. For decades, Argentina had been an inward-looking country, which fit its strongly nationalistic temper. Thus, opening up to the world was a dramatic turnaround. “Those years were very stressful,” said Cavallo. “We went into battle every week, every day. But I was helped a lot by the young people I would meet in the street or in the stores, who would wish me well in creating a new Argentina. We did accomplish much more than we expected.” Argentina had been decimated by inflation. It could not collect its taxes, it could not approve its budget, people with money desperately finagled to get it out of the country, and services were in a downward spiral. The credibility of the new democracy was at stake. The country was trapped by a dangerous and suffocating past. But in the short period of half a decade, it regained a future.10

秘鲁：农学家和作家

Peru: The Agronomist and the Book Writer

在20世纪80年代的“失落十年”里，秘鲁经历了西半球最令人震惊的经济衰退之一。从1968年到1980年，秘鲁一直处于左翼军事独裁政权的统治之下。该政权受菲德尔·卡斯特罗的影响，宣称致力于社会改革，并以民族主义为幌子，控制了大部分经济，扼杀了私营企业，将国内外企业国有化，使国家陷入了巨大的倒退。一个简单的例子是：到20世纪60年代末，秘鲁已经建立起庞大的渔业，提供了大量就业机会；事实上，其船队规模甚至超过了日本。军政府将渔业国有化后，渔业最终崩溃。然而，尽管渔业经营惨淡，却仍然继续获得巨额国家补贴。搁浅在沙滩上腐烂的渔船船体就是最好的证明。

During the “lost decade” of the 1980s, Peru experienced one of the most stunning descents into economic darkness of all the countries in the Western Hemisphere. From 1968 to 1980, it had been ruled by a left-wing military dictatorship. Influenced by Fidel Castro, proclaiming its commitment to social reform, and wrapping itself in nationalism, the regime took over much of the economy, strangled private enterprise, nationalized domestic and foreign businesses, and set the country back enormously. One simple example: By the end of the 1960s, Peru had built up a substantial fishing business, which provided many jobs; its fleet, in fact, was larger than Japan’s. The military government nationalized the business and in due course it simply collapsed. Yet despite its nonperformance, the fishing business still continued to draw huge state subsidies. The beached rotting hulls of the fishing boats told all.

20世纪80年代初的第一届后军政府并没有对经济体制的运作方式做出多少改变。第二届政府则使情况变得更糟。这届政府是由一位名叫阿兰·加西亚的年轻政治家领导的左翼政府。加西亚是一位极具魅力、口才出众的演说家，他被广场上的阳台所吸引——但更被阳台所带来的权力所吸引。加西亚和他的亲信利用职权散布私利，并在此过程中中饱私囊。他们的经济政策注定会走向经济崩溃。他们实施物价管制，切断秘鲁与国际金融体系的联系，推行大幅加薪，削减税收，并大肆挥霍政府开支。在加西亚总统任期的后期，他甚至不遗余力地与朝鲜建立外交关系，因为朝鲜是秘鲁的资金和武器来源地。与此同时，秘鲁正处于严重的经济危机之中：军队和政府雇员的实际工资下降了三分之二，1988年至1990年间经济萎缩了25%，到1990年初，通货膨胀率高达3000%。国家已经破产。

The first postmilitary government in the early 1980s did not change much in the way the economic system operated. The second made things worse. It was the leftist government led by a young politician named Alan García. A charismatic and captivating orator, he was drawn to the balcony overlooking the square—but even more by the power that came with the balcony. García and his cronies used their positions to hand out favors and, in the process, to enormously enrich themselves. Their economic policy was a recipe for economic collapse. They slapped on price controls, severed Peru from the international financial community, promoted generous wage increases, cut taxes, and opened the floodgates for government spending. Toward the end of his presidency, García went out of his way to establish diplomatic relations with North Korea, a source of funds and weapons. Meanwhile, Peru was in deep economic crisis: Real wages of the army and government employees had declined by two-thirds, the economy contracted 25 percent between 1988 and 1990, and by early 1990 inflation had reached 3,000 percent. The country was broke.

当时，安第斯山脉也正深陷一场由“光辉道路”（Sendero Luminoso）领导的内战引发的激烈政治危机之中。尽管“光辉道路”常被描述为毛主义，但其意识形态几乎难以理解，而它试图强加自身的方式却昭然若揭——通过暴力、野蛮、肆意流血和破坏。在安第斯山脉城市阿亚库乔的哲学教授阿比马埃尔·古斯曼的领导下，“光辉道路”凭借恐怖手段将控制范围扩展到了高原的大部分地区，并发动了战争。在首都利马，他们通过谋杀、爆炸、绑架和停电等手段控制了这座城市。据估计，当时该国一半的地区都处于他们的控制之下。

It was also in the grip of an intense political crisis, instigated by a civil war led by Sendero Luminoso, the Shining Path. Although often described as Maoist, the ideology of the Shining Path was almost impenetrable, but the way in which it sought to impose itself was all too clear—through violence, savagery, wanton bloodshed, and havoc. Led by Abimael Guzmán, a philosophy professor in the Andean city of Ayacucho, it had spread its control through sheer terror over much of the highlands and was waging war on the capital, Lima, through murder, bombings, kidnappings, and blackouts. By some estimates, half of the country was under its sway.

然而，到了20世纪80年代，秘鲁迎来了另一条道路。事实上，《另一条道路》（El Otro Sendero）——一本为秘鲁提出自由主义替代方案的书籍——就以此为题。该书由经济学家埃尔南多·德·索托撰写，其出版反映了改革思想在一些知识分子和商界人士中的渗透。弗里德里希·冯·哈耶克和米尔顿·弗里德曼都曾参与在利马举行的研讨会，这些研讨会为该书的写作奠定了基础。《另一条道路》的研究人员得出结论，当时有超过五十万条法律和行政命令适用于经济活动。为了探究在这样一个高度管制且复杂的体系中创办一家小型企业究竟有多么困难，他们进行了一项不同寻常的实验。他们在利马设立了一个小型作坊，配备了两台缝纫机，然后尝试将其注册为一家企业。他们报告说：“注册这家作坊耗时289天，需要负责这项工作的四人小组全职投入，还要花费1231美元……在当时，这相当于32个月的最低工资。这意味着，对于任何经济条件一般的人来说，合法注册一家小型企业的成本都太高了。”这种制度抑制了经济创新，或者迫使潜在的创业者走上非法道路，进入黑市——也就是后来所谓的“非正规经济”。

Yet in the 1980s, the country was afforded another path. Indeed, El Otro Sendero—The Other Path—was the title of a book that put forth a liberal alternative for Peru. The appearance of the book, written by the economist Hernando de Soto, reflected the percolation of reformist ideas among some intellectuals and businesspeople. Indeed, both Friedrich von Hayek and Milton Friedman were among those participating in the symposia in Lima that had laid the basis for the book. The researchers associated with El Otro Sendero concluded that there were over five hundred thousand laws and executive orders that applied to economic activity. They conducted an unusual experiment to discover how difficult it was to start a small business in such a highly regimented and complex system. They set up a small workshop in Lima with two sewing machines and then tried to register it as a business. “To register the workshop,” they reported, “took 289 days and required the full-time labor of the group of four assigned to the task, as well as $1,231 …. At the time, that was the equivalent of 32 monthly minimum wages. This means that the process of legally registering a small industry is much too expensive for any person of modest means.” The system discouraged economic initiative or forced would-be entrepreneurs into illegality and the black market—what became known as the “informal economy.”

但对另一条道路的兴趣仅限于一小撮人。这一切在1987年7月28日中午发生了改变，加西亚发表讲话，宣布他将把所有银行和金融机构国有化。作家马里奥·巴尔加斯·略萨当时正与家人在秘鲁最北端一个偏僻的海滩度假，他用一台老旧的便携式收音机听到了这场讲话。他怒不可遏。结果只会是更多的腐败、更多的贫困、更多的独裁。“秘鲁历史上又一次倒退了一步，走向了野蛮，”他愤愤不平地对妻子说。他在一篇题为《走向极权主义的秘鲁》的文章中也表达了类似的观点。随后，一份宣言发表，接着是一场示威游行。这场游行没有像预期的那样吸引几千名专业人士，而是吸引了至少十万人参加——这让正在电视机前观看的阿兰·加西亚愤怒地砸碎了屏幕。马里奥·巴尔加斯·略萨成为了“自由运动”的领导人，该运动旨在削弱国家权力。

But interest in the other path was restricted to little more than a small circle. That all changed at midday, July 28, 1987, when García delivered a speech announcing that he would nationalize all banks and financial institutions. The writer Mario Vargas Llosa, vacationing with his family at an isolated beach in the very north of Peru, heard the speech over an ancient portable radio. He was infuriated. The results would be more corruption, more poverty, more dictatorship. “Once again in its history, Peru has taken yet another step backward toward barbarism,” he said bitterly to his wife. He said much the same in an article entitled “Toward a Totalitarian Peru.” A manifesto followed, and then a demonstration that, instead of attracting a few thousand professionals, drew at least a hundred thousand—and caused Alan García, watching it on television, to smash the screen in rage. Mario Vargas Llosa became the leader of the Libertad movement, which intended to roll back the state.

巴尔加斯·略萨是秘鲁最杰出的文学家。他是一位技艺精湛的文学评论家，曾在马德里大学撰写关于哥伦比亚小说家加西亚·马尔克斯的博士论文。然而，真正使他成为国际文坛巨匠的，是他自己的小说——从《英雄时代》到《胡莉娅姨妈与编剧》和《世界尽头的战争》等作品，无论在伦敦、马德里、巴黎还是利马，他都同样游刃有余。如同许多拉丁美洲知识分子一样，他自学生时代起就对政治抱有浓厚的兴趣，但他的转变比大多数人都要彻底得多。他最初是一名学生时代的共产主义者，并坚定地捍卫古巴共产党。革命。但当他胆敢批评卡斯特罗监禁作家时，卡斯特罗及其遍布全球的知识分子拥护者对巴尔加斯·略萨进行了猛烈的抨击。他越来越意识到，共产主义意味着镇压，同时又未能兑现其夸耀的承诺。他最终成为了一名社会民主主义者。11

Vargas Llosa was Peru’s most distinguished man of letters. A very adept literary critic, he had written his dissertation at Madrid University on the Colombian novelist Gabriel García Márquez. But it was his own novels—beginning with The Time ofthe Heroes and continuing with the likes of Aunt Julia and the Scriptwriter and The War at the End of the World—that had made him an international literary figure, equally at home in London, Madrid, and Paris as in Lima. In the way of so many Latin American intellectuals, he had flirted continually with politics since his student days, but he had gone through a much more thoroughgoing transformation than most. He had begun as a student communist and had staunchly defended the Cuban revolution. But when he dared to criticize Castro for imprisoning writers, a hail of invective from Castro and his intellectual defenders around the world fell upon Vargas Llosa. Increasingly, he came to see that communism meant repression and, at the same time, failed to deliver on its vaunted promises. He became a social democrat.11

巴尔加斯·略萨仍不满足，转而研究经济学，最终认定自由主义经济学是实现经济增长和捍卫自由的最佳途径。左翼知识分子对他进行铺天盖地的诽谤，他也予以回击。他谴责那些“廉价知识分子”，这些人追逐潮流，却对经济学一窍不通。“你不可能既是现代人又是马克思主义者，”他宣称。他反复思考，为什么知识分子如此痴迷于国家控制和马克思主义。部分原因是庇护，部分原因是时尚，还有部分原因是“他们缺乏经济学知识”。他尤其鄙视那些拉丁美洲知识分子，在他看来，这些人一边谴责“帝国主义”的美国，一边却从美国的大学获得教职和基金会的资助。或许没有什么比一天晚上在墨西哥城的一家剧院偶遇老朋友加西亚·马尔克斯更能让他意识到自己走过的路有多远了。加西亚·马尔克斯从未背弃过菲德尔·卡斯特罗，并且强烈批评巴尔加斯·略萨对左翼的否定。两人发生了争执，最终巴尔加斯·略萨一拳打倒了加西亚·马尔克斯——这可是你几乎不可能在博士论文研究对象身上做的事。

Still unsatisfied, Vargas Llosa turned to the study of economics, and ended up settling on liberal economics as the best bet for both delivering economic growth and protecting freedom. Leftist intellectuals heaped calumny on him, and he returned it in kind. He denounced “cut-rate intellectuals,” who went with the fashions and were profoundly ignorant of economics. “You cannot be a modern man and a Marxist,” he declared. He mused endlessly on why intellectuals were so fascinated with state control and Marxism. Part of it was patronage, part of it was fashion, and part “their lack of economic knowledge.” He reserved some of his greatest contempt for Latin American intellectuals who made a career, in his view, of denouncing the “imperialist” United States while at the same time finding much succor from professorships at its universities and grants from its foundations. Perhaps nothing so much brought home the distance he had traveled as when he encountered his old friend Gabriel García Márquez one evening at a theater in Mexico City. García Márquez had never abandoned Fidel Castro, and he was strongly critical of Vargas Llosa’s repudiation of the left. They got into an argument, and Vargas Llosa ended up knocking García Márquez out, which is something that one hardly ever gets to do to the subject of one’s doctoral dissertation.

在阿兰·加西亚宣布国有化之后，巴尔加斯·略萨成为自由党（Libertad）的领袖，该党将已在美洲大陆其他地区传播的改革理念引入秘鲁政坛。党内较为有学识的成员就应该采取“市场经济”还是“社会市场经济”展开辩论，并探讨路德维希·艾哈德会支持哪条道路。更直接的是，自由党的领导人花了三年时间，有条不紊地制定了一份“白皮书”，其中包含了彻底改革秘鲁经济的理念和计划。政治话语的重塑几乎是难以想象的。“我看到了，但我不敢相信，”著名工程师费利佩·桑代克对巴尔加斯·略萨说，“你谈论私有财产和大众资本主义，他们非但没有把你打死，反而为你鼓掌。秘鲁到底发生了什么？”

Now, in the aftermath of Alan García’s nationalization announcement, Vargas Llosa emerged as the leader of a political movement, Libertad, which became the vehicle that brought into Peruvian politics the reform ideas that had spread elsewhere on the continent. The more learned members argued about whether they should adopt the “market economy” or the “social market economy” and debated which path Ludwig Erhard would have endorsed. More immediately, Libertad’s leaders methodically developed over three years a “white book” of ideas and plans for radically reforming Peru’s economy. The reshaping of political discourse was almost unimaginable. “I see it but I don’t believe it,” Felipe Thorndike, a prominent engineer, said to Vargas Llosa. “You talk about private property and popular capitalism, and instead of lynching you they applaud you. What’s happening in Peru?”

到1990年，巴尔加斯·略萨已成为总统候选人的领跑者。但他必须在巨大的压力下开展竞选活动。他面临着诸多挑战，例如每天都会接到威胁要杀害他家人的电话，以及人身攻击。除了可能遭到加西亚支持者的暗杀外，他还时刻受到“光辉道路”的威胁，尤其是在安第斯山脉地区，他的竞选工作人员在那里遭到枪击。在长达数月的竞选期间，巴尔加斯·略萨努力保持对知识的兴趣。竞选期间的每个早晨，当他……在利马，他把自己关在书房里，阅读并思考卡尔·波普尔和开放社会理论。晚上，为了寻求慰藉，他会读西班牙诗人贡戈拉的诗。

By 1990, Vargas Llosa was the front-running candidate for president. But he had to conduct his campaign under enormous pressure. There were simple things—like the daily phone calls threatening to kill his family. There were physical attacks. In addition to the risk of assassination by Garcia’s supporters, there was also the constant threat of the Shining Path, particularly in the Andes, where his campaign workers were gunned down. During all the months of campaigning, Vargas Llosa struggled to keep in touch with his intellectual interests. Every morning during the campaign, when he was in Lima, he withdrew to his study to read and reflect on Karl Popper and the open society. At night, for solace, he read the Spanish poet Góngora.

为了展现另一条道路——他称之为“经济自由、市场和国际化”，巴尔加斯·略萨进行了一次备受瞩目的亚洲之行。他指出，左派人士将台湾描绘成美国的“半殖民地工厂”。20世纪50年代中期，秘鲁的经济状况优于台湾；两国的人均收入均低于1000美元。然而，到他访问台湾时，秘鲁的人均收入已下降了一半，而台湾的人均收入则上升至7530美元。他还拜访了玛格丽特·撒切尔，撒切尔告诉他应该继续努力。但这将付出代价。“如果你继续下去，”她对他说，“你将不得不忍受巨大的孤独。”12

Vargas Llosa took a highly publicized trip to Asia in order to demonstrate the other path—what he described as “economic freedom, the market, and internationalization.” Leftists, he noted, depicted Taiwan as “a semicolonial factory” of the United States. In the middle 1950s, Peru’s economy had been superior to Taiwan’s; both countries had per capita incomes under $1,000. Yet by the time of his visit, per capita income in Peru had slipped by half, while Taiwan’s had risen to $7,530. He also visited Margaret Thatcher, who told him that he should press on. But there would be a cost. “If you continue,” she said to him, “you will have to endure a great deal of loneliness.”12

这一切都建立在巴尔加斯·略萨会胜选的前提之上。然而，阿尔贝托·藤森——一位农业工程师兼大学校长——却被忽略了。至少在最初，人们很难认真看待藤森这位候选人；他甚至比小说家候选人更难让人信服。他没有任何政治支持者，也不属于任何政党。人们对他所知甚少，仅限于他主持的一档探讨农业和社会经济问题的电视谈话节目。他也是个局外人，是秘鲁日裔社区的一员，他的家人在20世纪30年代中期移民到秘鲁。他与那些被秘鲁社会排斥的人——穷人和印第安人——感同身受。他对祖国在他眼中所经历的崩溃、绝望和掠夺充满了愤怒。

All this assumed that Vargas Llosa would win. What was not factored in was Alberto Fujimori, an agricultural engineer and university rector. It was very hard, at least at first, to take Fujimori seriously as a candidate; he was even harder to take seriously than a novelist candidate. He had no political following and belonged to no party. Insofar as he was known at all, it was as host of a television talk show that dealt with farming and socioeconomic issues. He was also an outsider, a member of Peru’s small Japanese community, his family having immigrated to Peru in the mid-1930s. He identified with those excluded from Peruvian society—the poor and the Indians. And he was filled with anger at what he saw as the collapse, despair, and looting of his country.

起初，他几乎无人问津，甚至与以色列新约教会的先知以西结一起垫底。就连他的家人都说他参选简直是疯了。但藤森决心已定。据说，他卖掉了自己的拖拉机和皮卡，以资助这场单人竞选。他联合了一群福音传教士和无家可归者，在贫民窟挨家挨户地为他拉票。他通过批评巴尔加斯·略萨的休克疗法、私有化和大幅削减政府雇员的言论来争取支持。他没有详细说明具体措施；他的口号是“诚实、科技和工作”。电视观众可以看到他驾驶拖拉机驰骋在安第斯山脉高地的画面。

Initially, he was hardly noticed, left vying for last place with the prophet Ezequiel of the Israelite Church of the New Covenant. Even his family told him that he was crazy to run. But Fujimori was determined. It is said that he sold his tractor and pickup truck to help finance his one-man campaign. He put together a coalition of evangelists and the dispossessed, who campaigned door to door for him in the shantytowns. He built support by criticizing Vargas Llosa’s talk of shock therapy, privatization, and the slashing of government employment. He did not get into specifics; his slogan was “Honesty, technology, and work.” Television viewers were treated to footage of him driving tractors over the Andean highlands.

藤森遭到攻击，原因在于他是日本人，他的母亲不会说西班牙语，而且他的亲属中没有一人葬在秘鲁。他以儿子领圣餐的照片进行反击，并指出如果秘鲁要效仿亚洲国家，那么他比任何欧洲血统的人都更有能力落实这一政策。藤森将巴尔加斯·略萨描绘成秘鲁小精英阶层的代表——白人、富裕、享有特权，与广大穷人和社会现实脱节。面相也成为一个争论点——巴尔加斯·略萨引人注目的欧洲面孔让人联想起四个世纪前的西班牙征服，而藤森的面部特征则更接近安第斯印第安人。

Fujimori was attacked because he was Japanese, because his mother did not speak Spanish, and because none of his relatives was buried on Peruvian soil. He counterattacked with pictures of his son taking communion, and by observing that if Peru was going to emulate the Asian countries, then he was better prepared to implement it than was someone of European descent. Fujimori portrayed Vargas Llosa as the candidate of the small Peruvian elite—white, well off, privileged, and separated from the mass of the poor and the reality of society. Physiognomy became an issue—Vargas Llosa’s striking European looks, evoking the Spanish conquest four centuries earlier, in contrast to Fujimori, whose facial features were closer to those of the Andean Indians.

在第一轮选举中，巴尔加斯·略萨和藤森分别位列第一和第二。经过一番深思熟虑，巴尔加斯·略萨提出，如果藤森接受他的改革方案，他愿意退出竞选。但藤森拒绝了这一提议。在第二轮选举中，藤森轻松获胜。第二天，巴尔加斯·略萨带着对政治的厌倦和痛苦，飞往巴黎，渴望重拾写作。但他留下的，却是那份详尽的改革方案。

In the initial round of the elections, Vargas Llosa and Fujimori came out first and second, respectively. After much soul-searching, Vargas Llosa offered to step aside if Fujimori would adopt his reform program. The offer was spurned. In the second round, Fujimori won handily, and the next day Vargas Llosa flew off to Paris, bitter and sick of politics, eager to return to his writing. But what he left behind was the detailed script for reform.

藤震

Fujishock

藤森就任总统不到两周，这位以民粹主义者身份竞选并呼吁逐步改革的领导人，便推出了一项比巴尔加斯·略萨提出的任何方案都更为激进的“休克疗法”，因此被称为“藤森休克”。公共开支大幅削减，货币实际上贬值，这标志着一项迅速而彻底的改革计划的开始。藤森的执政风格也体现出一种不重视组建联盟和制度建设的特点。他坚持己见，不愿与人分享决策。

Within two weeks of taking office, Fujimori, who had run as a populist and had called for gradual reform, unleashed a program of shock therapy so much more far-reaching than anything Vargas Llosa had proposed that it became known as Fujishock. Public spending was slashed and the currency effectively devalued, the beginning of a very rapid and thoroughgoing reform program. Fujimori also demonstrated a style of governing that put little emphasis on coalition creation and institution building. He took his own counsel and kept decisions to himself.

然而，藤森决心同时推进两件事——打击恐怖主义和落实“自由党”白皮书中制定的改革方案。“打击暴力和进行经济改革是一个非常棘手的问题，”一天，他在利马巴洛克风格的总统府里说道。他笔直地坐在长桌的首位，轻声细语，目光时常低垂，偶尔侧目看向来访者，嘴角偶尔会露出一丝微笑。“同时推进这两件事风险很大，因为任何经济改革都会在短期内带来一些不稳定。但我们冒险一试。这成为了我们经济计划走向成功的转折点。”

Yet Fujimori was determined to do two things simultaneously—combat terrorism and implement the kind of reforms that had been laid out in Libertad’s white book. “It was a very difficult problem to fight violence and at the same time to make economic reforms,” he said one day in the baroque presidential palace in Lima. Sitting very straight at the head of a long table, he talked quietly, often gazing down at the table, sometimes looking sideways at his visitors, occasionally with a little smile at the corner of his lips. “It was very risky to do both of them at the same time, because any economic reform would bring some instability in the short term. But we ran the risk. It was the turning point for success in our economic program.

“即便在光辉道路时期，我的思维也像工程师一样运转，”他继续说道。“人们，甚至包括利马大主教，都在谈论先消除贫困再打击暴力。这完全是谬论。我们必须先打击暴力，然后才是消除贫困。”他伸出手臂。“我曾在这间屋子里与一些商界领袖交谈过。他们毫无希望。但我却截然不同。我坚信我们制定的战略一定会成功。我并不孤单。我充满信心。从这个意义上说，我拥有东方人的耐心。我等待结果。我非常坚定，甚至可以说是固执。”

“My mind worked as an engineer’s even on the Shining Path,” he continued. “People, even the archbishop of Lima, were talking about fighting poverty before violence. That was a fallacy. We had to fight violence, and then poverty.” He stretched out his arm. “I had a conversation in this room with some of the leaders of the business community. They had no hope. But I saw things completely differently. I was convinced that the strategy we established would be a success. I was not lonely. I was sure. In that sense, I have the Oriental patience. I wait for the result. I was very firm. Even stubborn.”

针对光辉道路的行动进行了重组和加强；藤森亲自参与其中。现在，他们不再局限于边缘地带，而是直击运动的核心。这场行动持续了两年。警方开始关注利马的一处住宅。他们发现，这栋房子每天产生的垃圾远远超过居住在那里的两个人所能产生的量。1992年9月，警方发动突袭，在随后的行动中，他们发现这确实是光辉道路成员秘密居住的安全屋。其中就包括头号目标——领导人阿比马埃尔·古斯曼。他被捕后……在电视上亮相后，古兹曼不再是那个令人畏惧的哲学家游击队员；他恳求他的同事们放下武器。

The campaign against the Shining Path was reorganized and intensified; Fujimori involved himself directly. Now, instead of fighting on the periphery, they would go after the heart of the movement. It took two years. The police came to focus on a house in Lima. They observed that it was turning out garbage on a daily basis considerably in excess of what might have been expected to be generated by the two people living there. In September 1992, they mounted a raid, and in the ensuing attack, they found that it was indeed a safe house where Shining Path members were living secretly. Among them was the number-one quarry—Abimael Guzmán, the leader. Captured and paraded on television, Guzmán was no longer the fearsome philosopherguerrilla; he implored his colleagues to lay down their arms.

暴力活动的逐渐平息为藤森实施“藤森冲击”的下一阶段提供了契机。劳动力市场和金融市场放松管制，关税降低并简化，私有化进程启动，税基扩大，同时税收本身也得到降低。秘鲁重新向外国投资开放，并彻底推翻了阿兰·加西亚的政策，重新融入国际金融体系。秘鲁开始经历显著的经济增长，与快速发展的亚洲国家相比，它不再被视为“老虎”，而是“美洲狮”。“我试图加快步伐，”藤森解释道，“我的经济专家们并不理解我们想要在市场经济方面走多远。我想要的是一个真正意义上的市场经济。” 事实上，他解雇了最初的顾问，最终组建了一个完全由最初不支持他的人组成的内阁。

The winding down of violence provided the context in which Fujimori could carry out the next phases of Fujishock. Labor and financial markets were deregulated, tariffs were reduced and simplified, privatization was initiated, and the tax base was broadened, while taxes themselves were reduced. Peru was reopened to foreign investment and, in complete reversal of Alan García’s policies, reintegrated into the international financial community. Peru started to experience substantial economic growth, and in contrast to the fast-growing Asian countries, it began to be talked of not as a tiger but as a puma. “I tried to make a very fast pace,” Fujimori explained. “My economic experts did not understand how far we wanted to go to the market economy. I wanted a real authentic market economy.” Indeed, he jettisoned his original advisers and ended up with a cabinet composed entirely of people who had originally not supported him.

“这里的情况一团糟，各种管制措施都对贫困消费者不利，却有利于强大的政治势力，”他说。“国家的作用体现在教育、医疗、安全和司法等领域，”他说道。“我之所以会有这些想法，是因为我是一名全职工程师，而且我独立思考。我会做出自己的评估。这对我来说至关重要。我的思维方式与政客截然不同。我的思维方式逻辑严谨、客观公正。我以工程师的视角看待问题。一旦工程师发现问题，就会想方设法找到解决方案，即使只是一个有限的方案。”

“The situation here was such a mess, with many kinds of controls that were against the poor consumer and favoring big political power,” he said. “The role of the state is in fields like education, health, security, and the judiciary,” he said. “I had this thinking, these ideas, because I was a full-time engineer and because I was independent. I make my own evaluation. That is critical for me. The way I think is not the way a politician thinks. My way of thinking is logical and objective. I see a problem as an engineer. Once an engineer sees a problem, he wants to find a solution, even if it is a limited solution.”

改革伴随着诸多创伤。1992年4月，藤森解散了国会，中止了宪法，并解雇了大部分司法人员。批评人士称之为政变，并指责藤森试图把自己塑造成一个强人。然而，在一项针对44位拉丁美洲总统的绩效调查中，他因任人唯贤而非任人唯亲而获得最高分。他的妻子与他展开了一场激烈的公开争吵，最终她加入了包括前联合国秘书长哈维尔·佩雷斯·德奎利亚尔在内的十几位候选人的行列，竞选总统，与他竞争。尽管如此，藤森还是在第一轮投票中以超过60%的得票率赢得了连任。

The reforms were accompanied by many traumas. In April 1992, Fuji-mori dissolved the Congress, suspended the constitution, and dismissed much of the judiciary. Critics called it a coup and charged that Fujimori was making himself into a strongman. Yet in a survey about the performance of forty-four Latin American presidents, he received the highest score for making appointments on the basis of merit rather than patronage. His wife unleashed a furious public feud with him, which culminated in her joining a dozen other candidates, including former U.N. secretary-general Javier Pérez de Cuéllar, in running against him for president. Nevertheless, Fujimori won a second term on the first ballot, with over 60 percent of the vote.

1996年12月，隶属于卡斯特罗主义小革命组织图帕克·阿马鲁的游击队员伪装成服务员，在庆祝日本天皇生日的大型年度宴会期间占领了日本大使官邸。最初六百名人质（包括藤森的母亲）被扣押，后减少到七十一人（包括藤森的兄弟和外交部长）。谈判毫无进展。图帕克·阿马鲁游击队员坚持要求释放所有被囚禁的同伴。他们不肯妥协。藤森也不肯妥协。释放人质将破坏为恢复秩序和安全所做的一切努力。在人质被扣押的第125天，秘鲁士兵执行了一次精心策划的营救行动。只有一名人质死亡——显然是心脏骤停。袭击发生后，藤森的支持率一度飙升，但随后由于民众对其被视为专制的统治方式不满以及一系列政治丑闻，支持率再次回落。与此同时，经济持续增长。

In December 1996, guerrillas belonging to the small Castroite Tupac Amarú revolutionary group, disguised as waiters, seized the residence of the Japanese ambassador during the huge annual party celebrating the Japanese emperor’s birthday. The initial lot of six hundred hostages (including Fujimori’s mother) was reduced to seventy-one (including both Fujimori’s brother and his foreign minister). Negotiations got nowhere. The Tupac Amarú guerrillas insisted on the release of all their imprisoned brethren. They would not compromise. Nor would Fujimori. Release of the prisoners would undermine everything that had been done to restore order and security. On day 125 of the hostage taking, Peruvian soldiers carried out an expertly executed rescue. Only one hostage died—apparently, of a heart attack. Immediately after the raid, Fujimori’s popularity soared, but then fell again owing to discontent with what was seen as his authoritarian style of rule and a wave ofpolitical scandals. In the meantime the economy continues to grow.

藤森依然能唤起最初促使他参选的那份愤怒。“我当时既愤怒于经济，也愤怒于治安，”他说。“大多数享受经济发展成果的上层社会人士，甚至都不知道贫民窟里发生了什么。他们害怕贫民窟会蔓延到利马的其他地区。”他回忆起一件激起他愤怒的往事，正是这件事促使他走上了看似异想天开的总统竞选之路。“1988年的某一天，由于服务糟糕，我无法从万卡约飞往利马。秘鲁航空公司的乘客不得不在航站楼里等上十二个小时。最后，我只好开车。因为路上的石头，也因为光辉道路的危险——他们会拦车——我不得不开得很慢。我花了十四个小时才到。”他笑了笑。“现在五个小时就能到了。”13

Fujimori still summons the rage that initially prompted him to run. “I was angry both about the economy and the security,” he said. “Most of the first society, the people who enjoyed the results of the economy, did not even know what was happening in the shantytowns. They were afraid of those shantytowns coming down to invade the rest of Lima.” He recalled an incident that had fueled the anger that had led him on what had seemed an overwhelmingly quixotic presidential bid. “One day in 1988 I couldn’t fly from Huancayo to Lima because of bad service. Aero Peru passengers would have to wait twelve hours in the terminal. Finally, I drove a car. I had to go very slowly because of rocks on the road, and because of the risks and dangers of the Shining Path, who would stop cars. It took me fourteen hours.” He smiled. “Now you can do it in five.”13

墨西哥：权力的扩散

Mexico: The Diffusion of Power

墨西哥似乎总是与众不同。自1910年革命以来，它成功地避免了其他拉美国家经历的大部分政治动荡——民粹主义、军事镇压以及最严重的压迫和暴力。这种相对的和平很大程度上归功于墨西哥独特的政治制度，使其在近一个世纪的时间里与该地区其他国家截然不同。革命后的权力巩固将政府牢牢掌握在一个占主导地位的单一政党手中。甚至其不同寻常的名称——制度革命党（PRI）——也暗示了其使命、身份和目标的模糊性。但其历任领导人设法制定并运用了能够为墨西哥带来相对政治秩序和稳定的政治手段。

It always seemed that Mexico was different. Since the revolution of 1910, it had managed to avoid most of the political upheavals that the other Latin American countries had experienced—the populism, the military crackdowns, and the worst of the repression and violence. This relative peace came largely thanks to Mexico’s unique political system, which set it apart from the rest of the region for most of the century. The consolidation of power that followed the revolution put government firmly into the hands of a single, dominant political party. Even its unusual name—the Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI—signaled the ambiguity of its mission, identity, and purpose. But its successive leaders managed to devise and apply the political tools that would grant Mexico relative political order and stability.

墨西哥总统权力牢牢把控，对异议的容忍度极低。革命制度党（PRI）并非唯一的合法政党，但它通过收买潜在反对者、拉拢派系领导人，以及在所有其他手段失效时控制选举结果，来确保自身地位。它竭力维护广泛的民众支持，以赋予政治进程合法性。例如，一个统一的工会联合会负责在工人、私营企业领导人和政府之间进行调解。工会领导人因其努力而获得丰厚回报，并帮助缓和了劳资关系中的紧张局势。与此同时，革命制度党内部的各个派系不断形成和重组，彼此谈判，瓜分权力。革命制度党制定了一套“游戏规则”，以确保在其一党制逻辑框架内尽可能地保持公平。国家宪法规定，总统只能连任一届，任期六年。而且，任何在过去六个月内担任过内阁级职务的人都不得再次当选总统。为了符合这些要求，PRI 制定了一项不成文但不可动摇的做法，称为dedazo（指指点点），即将卸任的总统通过此举指定其继任者，并通过不太透明的全国选举予以认可。

Mexico’s presidents had a firm grip and did not tolerate dissension beyond a point. PRI was not the sole legal party, but it guaranteed its role by buying off potential opponents, coopting faction leaders, and, when all else failed, controlling the outcome of elections. It took care to preserve, at base, a broad measure of bedrock popular support to give legitimacy to the process. A single trade union confederation, for example, mediated among workers, private business leaders, and the government. Its leaders, who were well rewarded for their efforts, helped take the rough edge out of industrial relations. Meanwhile, factions formed and re-formed within PRI, negotiating among themselves and dividing up positions of influence. PRI devised “rules of the game” to ensure something close to fairness within the confines of its one-party logic. The national constitution stipulated that the country’s president could serve only one six-year term. And nobody could become president who had held a cabinet-level post within the previous six months. To conform with these requirements, PRI developed an unwritten but unshakable practice known as the dedazo—the pointing of the finger—by which the outgoing president would designate his successor, to be rubber-stamped by less-than-transparent national elections.

并非所有的一切都是操纵、贿赂和障眼法。普里斯特时期的总统​​们也采取措施，提升人民的福祉，改善生活水平，并赋予人民掌控国家经济命运的权力。其中最引人注目的是拉萨罗·卡德纳斯于1938年将石油工业国有化，卡德纳斯被大多数人认为是本世纪最受欢迎、最受尊敬的墨西哥总统。二战后，墨西哥的经济增长和社会秩序与拉丁美洲其他地区普遍存在的恶性通货膨胀、经济衰退，尤其是内战和军事独裁形成了鲜明对比。

Not all was manipulation, payoff, and sleight of hand. Priista presidents also took measures to give the people a sense of welfare, improved living standards, and control over their country’s economic destiny. Most notable was the nationalization of the oil industry in 1938 by Lázaro Cardenas, by most accounts the most popular and revered Mexican president of the century. And in the post-World War II era, Mexico’s record of economic growth and social order stood in contrast to the hyperinflation, the recessions, and especially the civil strife and military dictatorships spreading in the rest of Latin America.

到了20世纪80年代初，这一切都受到了严重威胁。尽管墨西哥拥有诸多优势和政治稳定，但它也曾奉行进口替代的经济逻辑，并同样感受到了这一体系带来的压力。大宗商品市场崩溃、债务累积和外汇储备锐减都给墨西哥带来了沉重打击。而革命制度党（PRI）沿用已久的权力巩固手段也无济于事。毕竟，与工会达成的协议是以庞大的庇护体系为代价的；而与墨西哥北部富有的私人实业家达成的协议则建立在保护其市场免受竞争的基础之上。如今我们熟知的庞大国有企业造成了巨额开支，而20世纪70年代末的墨西哥总统何塞·洛佩斯·波蒂略更是以其臭名昭著的挥霍无度的习惯雪上加霜。

All this came under severe threat by the beginning of the 1980s. Despite its advantages and political stability, Mexico too had operated on the economic logic of import substitution, and it too felt the strain of that system. The collapse of commodity markets and the accumulation of debt and dwindling foreign reserves hit hard. And the time-honored ways in which PRI retained its grip did not help. After all, the bargain with organized labor came at the cost of a vast patronage system; and the bargain with the wealthy private industrialists of northern Mexico was based on protecting their markets from competition. The now-familiar array of massive state enterprises bred heavy expenses, and the Mexican president of the late 1970s, José López Portillo, made matters worse with his notoriously profligate spending habits.

1982年8月债务危机爆发时，墨西哥的处境正是如此。救助计划代价沉重。墨西哥的信用评级一落千丈，不得不在极其严格的限制下，在经济深度衰退的背景下，一步步重建声誉。控制赤字支出和公共债务势在必行。由于许多问题都源于结构性因素，根植于革命制度党（PRI）的执政方式，因此，这种执政方式也必须受到质疑。政治影响令人望而生畏，革命制度党内部的老牌势力——后来被称为“恐龙”——形成了一个颇具影响力的派系，旨在抵御这些危险。与他们对抗的是一小群改革派，他们深受债务危机的冲击。随着时间的推移，他们逐渐改变了政治格局，彻底改变了墨西哥经济，使其从进口替代国转变为大陆自由贸易的参与者。但转型之路远非一帆风顺，期间经历了数次戏剧性的停滞和逆转。

Such was the situation when the debt crisis hit in August 1982. The bailout came with a heavy cost. Mexico’s credit was shot, and it had to rebuild its reputation step by step within very tight constraints and during a deep economic slump. It was imperative that deficit spending and the public debt be reined in. And since much of the trouble was structural, inherent to PRI’s way of running the country, that too would have to be questioned. The political implications were daunting, and an influential faction formed within the old guard of PRI—they would later be called the “dinosaurs”—to ward off such dangers. Against them was a small set of reformers scalded by the shock of the debt crisis. Over time, they would come to transform the political landscape and turn the Mexican economy inside out, from import substituter to participant in continental free trade. But the transition was to be far from simple, and punctuated by several dramatic pauses and reversals.

这需要几位领路人。其中第一位是米格尔·德拉马德里，他按照既定程序和“十人制”规则，于1982年12月在金融危机的重压下就任总统。尽管他曾担任洛佩斯·波蒂略的预算部长，但他很快就试图与前任划清界限。他有充分的机会证明自己，因为他必须负责棘手的债务重组谈判。在这些谈判中，他成功地让银行家们意识到……有些事情发生了变化。他在政治上也做出了前所未有的举动：上任第一年，他就允许反对党赢得一系列地方选举。然而，这被认为做得太过火了，在接下来的地方选举中，革命制度党又恢复了以往的做法。

It would take several shepherds as well. First among them was Miguel de la Madrid, who became president, according to schedule and the rule of the dedazo, in December 1982, amid all the financial torment. Although he had once been López Portillo’s budget minister, he sought very rapidly to distance himself from his predecessor. He had ample opportunity to prove himself, as he had to assume responsibility for very tricky debt renegotiations. In these, he succeeded in conveying to the bankers the sense that something had changed. He also did the unheard-of politically: Within his first year in office, he allowed the opposition to win a series of local elections. This, however, was felt to be too much, and in the next set of local elections PRI returned to its old ways.

德拉马德里在两位关键部长的协助下着手工作。他的财政部长是赫苏斯·席尔瓦·赫尔佐格，出身政治世家，其父在1938年的石油国有化运动中扮演了核心角色。计划和预算部长是卡洛斯·萨利纳斯，一位年轻瘦削的经济学家，曾在哈佛大学肯尼迪政府学院学习。两人之中，席尔瓦·赫尔佐格无疑更为谨慎，而萨利纳斯则更具冒险精神。但他们都明白必须做出改变。“很难找到另一个像我们这样赤字如此之高的国家，”席尔瓦·赫尔佐格回忆道，“我们需要降低赤字，摆脱债务负担。”正如萨利纳斯所解释的那样，他们的任务是“驯服预算这头恐龙”。他们严厉削减开支，将预算赤字从占GDP的7.3%转变为盈余4.2%。他们竭尽所能地偿还债务。最重要的是，他们开始梳理错综复杂的国有企业网络。“到1982年底，国有企业超过1100家，”席尔瓦·赫尔佐格说。“有些是重中之重，比如电力和铁路。但我们也拥有酒店、餐馆、自行车厂和牛仔裤厂。我们甚至在墨西哥城拥有一家夜总会。它可能是世界上唯一一家亏损的夜总会。”

De la Madrid set to work with the help of two key ministers. His finance minister was Jesús Silva Herzog, the scion of a political family, whose father had played a central role in the oil nationalization of 1938. The planning and budget minister was Carlos Salinas, a young, slight economist who had studied at Harvard’s Kennedy School of Government. Of the two, Silva Herzog was certainly the more cautious and Salinas the more adventurous. But both knew something had to change. “It was not easy to find another country with as high a deficit as ours,” Silva Herzog recalled. “We needed to bring it down and to get rid of debt service.” Their job, as Salinas explained it, was “the taming of the budget dinosaur.” They clamped down on spending with ferocity, moving the budget from a deficit of 7.3 percent of GDP to a surplus of 4.2 percent. They devoted every possible resource to repaying the debt. And most of all, they began to unravel the tangled web of public enterprises. “At the end of 1982, there were over eleven hundred public companies,” said Silva Herzog. “Some were top priority, like electricity or the railroads. But we also owned hotels, restaurants, a bicycle factory, and a blue jeans factory. We even owned a nightclub in Mexico City. It was probably the only nightclub in the world losing money.”

着手处理这个复杂的问题堪称革命性的举措。尽管他们有勇气采取强硬措施，但运气却并不眷顾他们。1985年墨西哥城发生的毁灭性地震造成的损失估计相当于国内生产总值的2%，紧接着石油价格暴跌，而石油出口占墨西哥出口总收入的一半以上。这些障碍，加上难以控制国内反对派，意味着到1988年德拉马德里下台时，通货膨胀率仍然居高不下（年增长率超过100%），普通民众的实际收入大幅下降。财政赤字再次攀升。早期对私有化的重视也存在弊端。“一夜暴富”的亿万富翁如雨后春笋般涌现。“大多数人都确信存在大量腐败案件，”席尔瓦·赫尔佐格说道，“这是一个道德信誉问题。”与此同时，墨西哥加入了《关税及贸易总协定》（GATT），这意味着一些特权行业的保护措施将被取消。所有这一切都预示着未知的未来，并威胁着劳动人民的信心。

To take on this complex was nothing short of revolutionary. If they had the courage to take tough measures, they were not, however, helped by luck. A devastating earthquake in Mexico City in 1985 caused damage estimated at 2 percent of GDP, and was followed soon after by a fall in the price of oil, which generated more than half of Mexico’s total export revenues. These obstacles, combined with the difficulties of keeping internal opposition at bay, meant that by 1988, when de la Madrid stepped down, inflation remained very high (upward of 100 percent per year), and the real incomes of ordinary people had plummeted. The budget deficit had crept up again. And the early emphasis on privatization had its pitfalls, too. “Overnight billionaires” had sprung up. “Most people were convinced there were many cases of corruption,” said Silva Herzog. “It was a question of moral credibility.” At the same time, Mexico had joined GATT, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which meant removing the protections on a number of privileged sectors. All this portended the unknown and threatened the confidence of working people.

或许正因如此，1988年接替德拉马德里总统的选举比以往任何一次都更具竞争性。一位实力强劲的替代候选人横空出世，与革命制度党（PRI）抗衡。他就是库奥特莫克·卡德纳斯，从左翼角度抨击革命制度党的经济政策。他的名字就足以说明一切。他是传奇总统拉萨罗·卡德纳斯的儿子；他的名字源自一位阿兹特克皇帝。他是一位才华横溢的演说家，作为民主革命党（PRD）的候选人，他走遍全国，猛烈抨击……腐败问题引发了人们对另一种选择的希望。指定革命制度党候选人是德拉马德里的职责。席尔瓦·赫尔佐格是主要竞争者，但德拉马德里却选择了萨利纳斯。这似乎是一个不太可能的选择：萨利纳斯年轻，不受民众欢迎，被认为过于技术官僚，而且与外国人关系密切。1988年7月的选举结果在一周的疑点重重的沉默后公布，萨利纳斯获得了50.4%的选票——这是墨西哥现代史上最低的胜选优势，如此之低甚至引发了卡德纳斯被窃取胜利果实的指控。

Perhaps for this reason, the election to succeed President de la Madrid in 1988 looked to be more contested than most. A powerful alternate candidate had sprung up to rival PRI. He was Cuauhtémoc Cardenas, who attacked the PRI’s economic policies from the left. His name said it all. He was the son of the legendary President Lázaro Cardenas; his first name was that of an Aztec emperor. A gifted orator, he toured the country as the candidate of the Party of the Democratic Revolution (PRD), lambasting corruption and raising hopes that there was an alternative. It was up to de la Madrid to designate the PRI candidate. Silva Herzog was the leading contender, but de la Madrid instead picked Salinas. This seemed an unlikely choice: Salinas was young and unpopular with the public, seen as technocratic and close to foreigners. When the results of the July 1988 election were announced after a week of suspicious silence, Salinas had 50.4 percent of the votes—winning by the lowest margin in Mexico’s modern history, so low as to lead to charges that Cardenas had been robbed of victory.

无论萨利纳斯当选的理由如何，他迅速赢得墨西哥民众的支持着实令人惊讶。他率领一支军队，以迅雷不及掩耳之势击败了石油工人联合会的独裁领导人，赢得了民众的尊重，人们不仅把他看作技术官僚，更把他视为一位强硬的领导人。他推进私有化进程，出售了电信等主要行业的多数股权。他还出售了洛佩斯·波蒂略在1982年临别之际国有化的银行。所得款项用于偿还债务。此外，他还实现了预算平衡，从而将通货膨胀率降至完全合理的水平，并大幅提高了工资的实际价值。推动这一经济发展的幕后功臣是他的财政部长佩德罗·阿斯佩，他领导的专家团队曾被誉为“任何国家历史上经济素养最高的政府团队”。阿斯佩是第一批技术官僚中的一员，他最初就读于墨西哥技术大学，这是一所私立大学，旨在与公立大学——墨西哥国立大学——相抗衡。他后来进入麻省理工学院深造，并于1978年获得博士学位。回到墨西哥后，他加入了一个“卡马里拉”（camarilla），这是一个由效忠于中心人物的公务员组成的团体，这是晋升的先决条件。通常， “卡马里拉”发挥着庇护作用。阿斯佩的“卡马里拉”与众不同之处在于，其中心人物是萨利纳斯，而且其成员全部由年轻气盛的经济学家组成，他们都对墨西哥近期的经济状况感到震惊。后来，阿斯佩也组建了自己的拥护者团队。一旦他成为财政部长，他便能够将这些人分散到各个部委，极大地促进了协调工作。他还展现出卓越的政治才能，设计了一项关于工资和物价的“社会契约”，有效抑制了通货膨胀。

Whatever the merits of his election, Salinas surprised Mexicans by soon winning them over. In a lightning strike with a military squadron, he defeated the dictatorial boss of the oil workers’ union, gaining respect as a tough leader, not just a technocrat. He moved privatization forward, selling off majority stakes in major industries such as telecommunications. He sold off the banks, which López Portillo had nationalized in 1982 as a parting shot. The receipts went to pay off the debt. He also balanced the budget, and in this way helped bring inflation down to wholly respectable levels, considerably increasing the real value of wages. The motor of this economic drive was his finance minister, Pedro Aspe, who led a team of experts once called “the most economically literate group that has ever governed any country anywhere.” A member of the original crop of technopols, Aspe studied first at the Technical University in Mexico, a privately funded institution set up to rival the public National University. He went on to MIT, where he earned his doctorate in 1978. Returning to Mexico, he joined a camarilla, a group of civil servants loyal to a central figure, which was a prerequisite for advancement. Usually camarillas served patronage functions. The difference with Aspe’s was that its central figure was Salinas and that its membership was exclusively comprised of brash young economists, all of them appalled at Mexico’s recent economic history. In time, Aspe would form his own group of loyalists, and once he became finance minister, he was able to disseminate them among the various ministries, greatly facilitating coordination. He also showed his political skills by designing a “social pact” on wages and prices that helped drive down inflation.

到1993年中期，萨利纳斯政府似乎完成了不可能的任务——彻底扭转了墨西哥的局面。几十年来，公共财政首次实现了根本性的稳健，政治格局也似乎正在真正开放，中右翼的国家行动党（PAN）在北部工业中心地带的一些州执政。萨利纳斯的一项重大成就是与美国谈判达成了北美自由贸易协定。接受自由贸易标志着墨西哥曾经极度封闭的经济模式发生了彻底的转变。它也具有深远的心理意义，至少在一些人看来，它使墨西哥与北方邻国站在了同一起跑线上。

By mid-1993, the Salinas government seemed to have achieved the impossible—turned Mexico around—for good, it appeared. Public finances were fundamentally sound for the first time in decades, and a real political opening seemed to be under way, with the center-right National Action Party (PAN) in power in some states in the industrial heartland of the north. In a major achievement, Salinas negotiated the North American Free Trade Agreement with the United States. The acceptance of free trade represented a turning inside out of Mexico’s once desperately inward-looking economy. It also carried profound psychological weight, setting Mexico, at least in the minds of some, on an equal footing with its northern neighbor.

然而，一系列非同寻常的事件使整个过程受到质疑。1994年元旦，蒙面叛军占领了位于贫困的南部恰帕斯州的圣克里斯托瓦尔-德拉斯卡萨斯镇中心。恰帕斯州地处偏远，印第安人聚居区，改革进程几乎毫无成效。在那里，他们向墨西哥政府“宣战”。这戏剧性地提醒人们，改革之路漫长而艰辛，各方利益也错综复杂。这也标志着中美洲各地持续数十年的农民战争的卷土重来。尽管恰帕斯冲突局限于局部地区，但此后却时有爆发，最终以土地权属和基础设施服务改善等勉强妥协的方式得以平息。1994年3月，在下加利福尼亚州的蒂华纳，前预算部长路易斯·多纳尔多·科洛西奥（萨利纳斯指定的继任者）在一次竞选集会上遇刺身亡。这是墨西哥六十年来最令人震惊的政治谋杀案。尽管嫌疑人很快被锁定并接受审判，但大多数墨西哥人都觉得这起案件远不止表面那么简单。随着时间的推移，调查逐渐与其他调查交织在一起，形成错综复杂的政治和金融丑闻，这些丑闻似乎牵涉到萨利纳斯的盟友和亲属，以及腐败和毒品交易。（后来，萨利纳斯明智地移居爱尔兰，因为墨西哥与爱尔兰没有引渡条约。）

Yet extraordinary events were to call the entire process into question. On New Year’s Day 1994, masked rebels took over the town center of San Cristóbal de las Casas in the impoverished southern state of Chiapas, which was remote, heavily populated by Indians, and had little to show for the reform process. There they “declared war” on the Mexican state. It was a dramatic reminder of the distance to be traveled and the range of interests to be considered in reform. It was also a reversion to the debilitating peasant wars that had festered in previous decades all over Central America. Although localized, the Chiapas conflict was to flare up and down, and to be placated by uneasy compromises over land rights and improved infrastructure and services. Then, in March 1994, in Tijuana in Baja California, former budget minister Luis Donaldo Colosio, Salinas’s designated successor, was assassinated as he addressed an electoral rally. It was Mexico’s most shocking political murder in sixty years. Although a suspect was identified and rapidly tried, most Mexicans felt there was more, much more, to the story. In due course the investigation would become enmeshed with other inquiries in a complex weaving of political and financial scandals that appeared to involve Salinas allies and relatives and corruption and drugs. (Later, Salinas would prudently remove himself to Ireland, with which Mexico had no extradition pact.)

为了取代被谋杀的科洛西奥，萨利纳斯选择了另一位出人意料的黑马——埃内斯托·塞迪略·庞塞·德莱昂。他在看似毫无悬念的选举中获胜后就职，尽管他后来被称为“意外总统”。他出生于墨西哥城一个普通的家庭，但主要在美墨边境的墨西卡利长大。墨西卡利是一个混乱的城市，位于工业、移民和各种不法交易的交汇点。他天资聪颖，学习经济学，后来成为墨西哥新一代技术官僚的代表人物之一，但也因此落得个沉闷悲观的名声。1981年，他在耶鲁大学完成了博士论文，极具前瞻性地指出，墨西哥的债务困境应该归咎于政府，而不是提供贷款的银行。债务危机爆发后，他凭借这一观点进入了中央银行工作，而央行行长也与他持有相同的观点。这也确立了他的经济立场，他在德拉马德里和萨利纳斯领导下担任各种技术官僚职务期间，始终坚定不移地奉行这一立场，尽管他本人并未公开表态。

To replace the murdered Colosio, Salinas selected yet another unlikely dark horse, Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de León, who assumed office after an apparently clear election victory, although he became known in the process as the accidental president. He was born to a modest family in Mexico City but grew up primarily in Mexicali, on the United States border, a rough town at the crossroads of industry, immigration, and shady dealings. A gifted student, he studied economics and went on to become another of Mexico’s new generation of technocrats, in the process earning the reputation of being dull and gloomy. He wrote his Ph.D. thesis at Yale in 1981, presciently arguing that Mexico’s debt predicament should be blamed on the government and not on the banks that had provided the loans. That earned him a job, after the debt crisis began, at the central bank, whose head shared his views. It also set out an economic stance that he pursued unwaveringly, if quietly, in various technocratic positions under de la Madrid and Salinas.

然而，塞迪略新总统上任后的第一个经济决策却代价惨重。比索估值过高已有一段时间，但萨利纳斯出于政治和维护自身威望的考虑，拒绝调整比索汇率。塞迪略的财政部长宣布比索贬值。不幸的是，他低估了此举对措手不及的金融市场的影响。墨西哥股市暴跌，引发了拉丁美洲的连锁反应。这场被称为“龙舌兰酒效应”的事件，再次损害了墨西哥的金融声誉。不过，与债务危机相比，这次事件的影响要小得多，而且随着时间的推移，投资界逐渐将其解读为一种修正或警示，而非彻底崩溃的理由。此外，美国迅速提供200亿美元的救助也起到了一定的缓和作用。

Yet the first economic decision of the new Zedillo presidency was to prove costly. The peso had been overvalued for some time, but Salinas refused to adjust it for reasons of politics and prestige. Zedillo’s finance minister announced a devaluation. Unfortunately, it turned out that he had miscalculated the effect on the unexpecting financial markets. Mexico’s stock exchange took a dramatic dip, which set off a domino reaction around Latin America. Dubbed the “tequila effect,” it was another unfortunate sully to Mexico’s financial reputation. It was less grave, however, than the debt crisis, and over time was reinterpreted in investment circles as a correction or caution rather than grounds for a full stop. It helped as well that the United States mounted a $20 billion bailout in short order.

塞迪略最显著的成就体现在政治领域。尽管可能牵涉到政治纷争，但他决心推进对科洛西奥之死的调查，这为他赢得了一定的尊重。至少就相对而言，他是一位正义准则的捍卫者。最引人注目的是，他大幅开放了政治舞台。他将选举权委托给一个独立的委员会，有效地将选举运作与革命制度党（PRI）的旧势力隔离开来。1997年的中期选举结果——令人惊讶地——证实了民意调查的预测。革命制度党失去了在国民议会以及几个州的绝对多数席位。库奥特莫克·卡德纳斯当选为墨西哥城市长，这是一个新设立的民选职位，并且由于墨西哥城拥有2000万人口，市长实际上成为了该国第二大权力机构。在现代历史上，墨西哥首次出现了超越革命制度党的联合政治，而不是内部派系之间的妥协和利益交换。短期内对经济的影响尚不明朗。然而，尽管自1982年的创伤以来，改革进程坎坷，但经济已经发生了巨大的变化。公共财政和宏观经济管理方面的表现仍然不稳定。但随着私有化和加入国际贸易体系，经济力量向出口导向型产业转移，并越来越多地向私营部门和证券交易所转移，经济结构已经发生了变化。

Zedillo’s most notable achievements have come in the political realm. His determination to push forward the investigations of Colosio’s death, despite the possible political entanglements, has earned him some respect as a champion, in at least relative terms, of the norms of justice. Most strikingly, he has allowed the political arena to open up substantially. He entrusted elections to an independent commission, effectively distancing the operations from the PRI old guard. In the midterm elections of 1997, the results—remarkably—confirmed the opinion polls. PRI lost its absolute majority in the National Assembly, as well as in several states. Cuauhtémoc Cardenas became mayor of Mexico City, a newly created elective post and, by virtue of the city’s size—it has 20 million inhabitants—the country’s de facto second-most-powerful position. For the first time in modern history, Mexico has coalition politics beyond PRI rather than factional accommodations and horse trading within it. The implications for the economy in the near term are uncertain. Yet despite the rocky progression of reform since the trauma of 1982, the economy has been transformed in no small measure. The record of public finance and macroeconomic management is still shaky. But the structure has changed, as privatization and accession to the international trading system have moved economic power toward export-oriented industries and more and more to the private sector and the stock exchange.

墨西哥面临着巨大的社会诉求。“我们存在严重的收入分配问题，”席尔瓦·赫尔佐格警告说，“富者愈富，贫者愈贫。” 新的产业格局并不均衡，导致一些工作比其他工作更稳定、更有收入。“我们的出口行业在世界上极具竞争力，”他说，“但我们的非出口行业却非常落后。” 墨西哥面临的挑战是如何利用政治变革和经济管理来实现这些诉求，同时避免重蹈覆辙。对于在萨利纳斯执政时期推动改革的佩德罗·阿斯佩来说，政治体制的开放是通往未来的关键。“这一切都始于德拉马德里，”他说，“他知道，开放经济将引发政治变革。” 尽管经历了诸多波折，但这一进程在1997年仍在继续。“开放经济的力量是巨大的，”阿斯佩继续说道。 “没有任何政党、政府或官员能够阻止这种情况。人们正在达成交易——与美国、与加拿大。没有人能够阻止它。”14

There are gigantic social aspirations to be fulfilled. “We have serious problems of income distribution,” cautioned Silva Herzog. “The rich got richer and the poor have become poorer.” The new patterns of industry are uneven, which makes some jobs more stable and lucrative than others. “Our export sector is as competitive as any in the world,” he said. “But our nonexport sector is very backward.” Mexico’s challenge is to harness political change and economic management to meet these aspirations, while avoiding the mistakes of the past. For Pedro Aspe, who drove the reforms under Salinas, the openness of the political system is the key to the future. “It all started with de la Madrid,” he said. “He knew that when he opened up the economy it would foment political change.” Despite numerous accidents, that process is still in motion in 1997. “When we open up, it has a tremendous force,” Aspe continued. “No party, no government, no bureaucrats can stop that. People are doing deals—with the U.S., with Canada. No one can stop it.”14

巴西：从依附者转变为通胀杀手

Brazil: Dependentista Turned Inflation Slayer

在巴西，改革受到该国自身特性的阻碍——其幅员辽阔、文化多元、问题根深蒂固、人口结构复杂、联邦制结构以及利益交织，还有根深蒂固的腐败。在经历了21年的军政府统治后，巴西于1985年恢复民主，但同时也继承了严重的经济问题。债务危机爆发时，巴西负债高达870亿美元，成为当时世界上最大的债务国。通货膨胀席卷全国。到1990年，通货膨胀率飙升至1500%。物价指数化成为一种生活方式。几乎所有商品的价格都与当时公布的众多指数之一挂钩。报纸价格每日变动；就连银行账户也与通货膨胀挂钩。穷人受苦最深。腐败威胁着新生民主制度的合法性；首位直接选举产生的民主总统于1992年辞职，以避免因腐败指控而被弹劾。

In Brazil, reform has been hampered by the very character of the country—its size, its diversity, the depths of its problems, its demographics, the federal structure and the multiplicity of interests, and the entrenchment of corruption. Democracy returned to the country in 1985 after twenty-one years of military rule, but Brazil inherited considerable economic problems. At the time the debt crisis broke, Brazil owed $87 billion, making it the world’s largest debtor. A culture of inflation engulfed the nation. Inflation hit 1,500 percent by 1990. Indexation became a way of life. The price of virtually everything was linked to one of the many indices that were published in the newspapers. Prices changed every day; even bank accounts were indexed. The poor suffered the most. And corruption threatened to undermine the legitimacy of the new democracy; the first directly elected democratic president resigned in 1992 to avoid impeachment on corruption charges.

尽管如此，巴西还是朝着开放市场经济的方向迈进，尽管速度比大多数邻国都要慢。而推动这一进程的，莫过于现任总统费尔南多·恩里克·卡多佐。这其中颇具讽刺意味，因为卡多佐自称属于拉丁美洲思想的“激进传统”，而且他确实是依附理论及其对资本主义和“中心”批判的主要倡导者之一。他是拉丁美洲左翼的知识英雄，也是对资本主义和“帝国主义”最尖锐的批判者之一。他个人的转变比他所在的国家更为彻底，也戏剧性地展现了思想格局的巨变。

Yet despite all this, Brazil moved toward an open market economy, although more slowly than most of its neighbors. More than anybody else, the architect was the current president, Fernando Henrique Cardoso. There was more than a little irony in this, for Cardoso described himself as belonging to the “radical tradition” of Latin American thought and, indeed, was one of the premier architects of the dependencia theory and its critique of capitalism and the “center.” He was an intellectual hero of the Latin American left and one of the most trenchant critics of capitalism and “imperialism.” His personal transformation was more thoroughgoing than that of his country and dramatized how far the weight of ideas shifted.

卡多佐在圣保罗大学求学期间深受马克思主义影响，1964年军事政变后被迫流亡。他最终来到智利，在“依附理论之父”劳尔·普雷维什手下工作。作为一名社会学家，卡多佐运营着一家隶属于拉丁美洲和加勒比国家经济委员会（ECLA）的研究机构，并与人合著了一部关于依附理论的经典著作。他还在其他大学任教，包括巴黎大学激进的楠泰尔校区，1968年的学生运动就爆发于此。1969年，卡多佐返回巴西。他随即被独裁政权剥夺了大学教职，但他仍然设法建立了一个研究机构，该机构致力于批判军政府及其政策。他逐渐转向政治，在民主回归后，他成为新成立的社会民主党的领导人，并当选为参议员。1992年，他出任外交部长，次年又出任财政部长。

Cardoso, strongly influenced by Marxism while a student at the University of Sao Paulo, was forced to go into exile after the 1964 military coup.
