He ended up in Chile, working under Raúl Prebisch, the father of dependencia. A sociologist, Cardoso ran a research institute affiliated with ECLA and coauthored a classic text on dependencia. He taught at other universities, including the radical Nanterre campus of the University of Paris, where the student uprisings of 1968 began. Cardoso returned to Brazil in 1969. He was promptly stripped of his university professorship by the dictatorship, but nevertheless managed to establish a research institute that turned out criticism of the military regime and its policies. He gravitated toward politics and, after the return of democracy, emerged as a leader of a new social-democratic party and won election as a senator. In 1992, he became foreign minister and then, the following year, finance minister.

卡多佐担任财政部长期间，采取了稳定巴西经济的关键措施。他大幅削减政府开支，并改善税收征管。他还减少了联邦政府对州和地方政府的转移支付。当时通货膨胀率高达7000%，他果断采取行动。其机制是他的雷亚尔计划，该计划与阿根廷的计划类似，将雷亚尔与美元挂钩。该计划奏效了。一个月内，通货膨胀率骤降至10%以下。该计划缓解了通货膨胀的主要受害者——穷人和工人阶级的困境。它为创纪录的外国投资奠定了基础，并刺激了贸易的快速增长。卡多佐成为稳定经济的英雄。在竞选巡回演讲中，他像足球明星一样受到民众的热烈欢迎。1994年，他当选为总统。

It was as finance minister that Cardoso took the key steps to stabilizing the Brazilian economy. He slashed government expenditures and improved tax collection. He also reduced the transfer payments from the federal government to the state and local governments. And with inflation running at 7,000 percent, he acted decisively. The mechanism was his Real Plan, which, like that in Argentina, tied the currency to the dollar. It worked. Within a month, inflation plummeted to less than 10 percent. The plan brought respite to the main victims of inflation: the poor and the working class. It laid the basis for record foreign investment and spurred a rapid growth in trade. Cardoso became the hero of stabilization. On campaign tours, he found himself mobbed like a soccer star. In 1994, he was elected president.

他担任总统的头几年并不顺利。期间经历了银行危机和货币贬值失败。无论如何，在一个1988年才通过宪法，宪法明确规定政府必须拥有部分工业所有权，且国会更多地受利益集团而非政党控制的国家，改革并非易事。尽管如此，巴西的私有化进程仍在继续，其中一些规模庞大，许多私有化项目发生在州一级。到1997年底，钢铁、电力等关键行业的股权出售规模不断扩大。电信业已筹集了290亿美元。而公务员制度、税收制度、社会保障和教育领域的改革进展则较为缓慢。

His first few years as president did not go smoothly. There were banking crises and a botched devaluation. In any event, reform was not easy in a country in which the constitution, adopted as late as 1988, explicitly mandated government ownership of part of industry and in which the Congress is dominated less by parties than by interest groups. Nevertheless privatizations, some of them large, continued in Brazil, many of them at the state level. By late 1997, equity sales in such key sectors as steel, electricity, and telecommunications had raised $29 billion. Reforms of the civil service, the tax system, social security, and education have been slower.

卡多佐的行为或许像极了拉丁美洲新一代的新自由主义者，但他的言辞却并非如此。他的语言依然带有社会民主主义色彩，关注贫困和公平问题。然而，他如今却以“受监管的自由市场”和西欧的混合经济模式为蓝本。依附论的信条已被世界经济的变化、技术进步和竞争所取代。专横跋扈、效率低下、干预过多的国家机器，反而成了经济问题的根源，而非解决之道。

Cardoso may have acted like one of the new breed of Latin American neoliberals, but he did not talk that way. His language was still that of a social democrat, with the focus on poverty and equity. But now he had a “regulated free market” and Western Europe’s mixed economy as his model. The tenets of dependencia were overtaken by changes in the world economy, technological advance, and competition. The overweening, inefficient, intrusive state was a cause of economic problems, not a solution to them.

卡多佐说：“在全世界，以变革为导向的、带有社会主义色彩的乌托邦式思潮已经失去了吸引力。”传统的左翼思想已经落后了。他问道：“如今，左翼究竟是什么？左翼已经迷失了方向。如果左翼认同历史上已经形成的左翼模式，那就完了。尤其是在拉丁美洲，左翼的思想过于基于发展至上的理念，认为国家是发展的核心机构，集体行动优先于个人行动……它必须更加理性。”但他同时也驳斥了“国家越小越好”的观点。“要正确解决社会福利问题，仅仅空谈智利并对其私有化模式大加赞赏是不够的……我们不能把私营部门当作万能的灵丹妙药，因为它并非如此。市场无法解决贫困问题。贫困问题必须通过国家协调一致的行动来解决。”

“In the whole world,” Cardoso said, “the force of change-oriented utopia, of a socialist hue, has lost attraction.” The traditional left has been left behind. Today, he asked, “what is the left? The left has lost its bearings. If the left identifies with what in history has materialized as the left, it is finished. Especially here in Latin America, the thinking of the left had been based too much on the idea that development was fundamental, that the state was the central agency for such development, and that collective instruments of action had precedence over individual ones…. It has to be more rational.” But he also rejected the view that “the smaller the state, the better…. For a correct solution to the problems of social welfare, it is not enough to make idle references to Chile and bless it on the altar of privatization…. One cannot make the private sector the universal salvation, because it is not. The market does not solve the problem of misery. The problem of poverty has to be solved along the lines of coordinated actions by the state.”

然而，这位“依赖论”之父，曾经是拉丁美洲左翼的领军人物之一，如今却发现他的主要政治对手正站在他曾经抛弃的左翼阵营中。他毫不怀疑左翼曾帮助巴西恢复了“法治”。但即便没有社会主义目标，“以强权国家作为发展主要工具的观念依然存在，”卡多佐说道，“改革势在必行。”15

Yet this father of dependencia, formerly one of the leading intellectuals on the Latin American left, now finds that his main political opponents are on the very ramparts of the left that he abandoned. He has no doubt that the left helped restore “the rule of law” in Brazil. But even without the socialist goal, “the notion of a strong state as the main instrument of development is still alive,” Cardoso said. “Reforms are needed.”15

重新发现国家

Rediscovering the State

在拉丁美洲，国家的性质和责任是首要议题。随着整个大陆经济规则的趋同，以及依赖、进口替代和军事独裁的阴影逐渐消散，政策制定者开始思考未来的挑战。他们的国家仍然饱受基础设施、民生福祉和教育水平不足的困扰。在所有这些领域，他们的表现都远逊于亚洲四小龙。在拉丁美洲，经济不平等程度，即贫富差距，位居世界最高之列——而且从某些指标来看，这种情况已经持续了几个世纪。

The character and responsibilities of the state are at the top of the agenda in Latin America. With the economic rules converging across the continent and the ghosts of dependencia, import substitution, and military dictatorship laid to rest, policy makers are starting to consider the challenges ahead. Their countries remain plagued by deficiencies in infrastructure, human welfare, and the standard of education. In all of these areas they fare far worse than do the Asian tigers. In Latin America, the rates of economic inequality, the gap between rich and poor, are among the world’s highest—and have been, by some measures, for centuries.

在国有化数十年之后，曾经占据主导地位的核心工业部门发生了巨大变化，但这种变化并不彻底。通过航空公司、电话系统和电力公司的私有化，各国政府已经止住了财政亏损，减轻了国家一项牵涉重大政治利益的负担。然而，这些私有化公司后续的表现参差不齐，在一些国家甚至可以说是喜忧参半。随着私有化在非洲大陆的蔓延，其形式也日趋多样化。在这一切之中，各国政府面临着一项新的挑战：如何监管这些提供政治敏感服务（有时甚至是垄断服务）的新兴私营企业。由于摒弃了原有的国有企业，各国政府如今有时缺乏必要的技能、人员、信息和经验，来确保私营企业主和承包商维持高标准的服务，并防止他们串通抬高价格或降低服务质量。

After decades of state ownership of the core industrial sectors that for so long made up the commanding heights, the change has been great but incomplete. By privatizing airlines, telephone systems, and electric utilities, governments have stopped the financial hemorrhage and relieved the state of a considerable burden that carried high political stakes. The subsequent record of these privatized companies has, however, been uneven, and in some countries it is quite mixed. As privatization spreads across the continent, it also takes on different forms. In all of this, governments face a new challenge: regulating the new private firms that provide politically sensitive services, in some cases on a monopoly basis. Having repudiated the old state-owned firms, governments now sometimes lack the skills, the staff, the information, and the experience to ensure that private owners and contractors maintain high standards of service and are not allowed to collude to keep prices high or service inadequate.

技术精英的“技术能力”——融合了教育背景、资历、专业精神、进取心以及一定的运气和机遇——并未深入官僚机构。官僚机构的资源已被大幅削减，公务员薪酬过低，士气低落。省级政府和负责基层医疗、教育等分散服务的机构，无法享有中央财政部那样的权力和效率。税收征管力度不足。地方政府饱受腐败和收买之苦。

The “technicity” of the technopols—a blend of education and credentials, professionalism and motivation, and a measure of luck and opportunity—does not spread deep in bureaucracies. These have been stripped of much of their means, and civil servants are underpaid and often demoralized. Provincial administrations and the agencies responsible for decentralized services such as primary health care and education do not enjoy the clout and efficiency of the central Finance Ministry. Tax collection is anemic. Local authorities are subject to corruption and cooption.

委内瑞拉经济学家、前部长莫伊塞斯·奈恩表示：“市场的发现很快将迫使拉丁美洲国家重新认识国家”，因为市场无法在一个运转失灵的国家中发挥作用。在国家本身信誉受损的当下，如何将政府的重心重新放在减贫和监管私营企业上，是拉丁美洲正在进行经济改革的国家面临的特殊挑战。其中的先行者在向外界开放其“战略”部门方面走得比其他任何国家都更远。他们现在经常尝试使用市场经济中最先进的技术工具。但与此同时，无法保证电力和其他关键基础设施服务，更不用说改善医疗保健和教育，能够惠及大量被排除在外的人群。如果不能改善现状，只会加剧拉丁美洲本已巨大的贫富差距，并使这片大陆走上与亚洲竞争对手截然不同的道路。这还会引发政治动荡，并唤起人们对民主程度较低时代的记忆。16

“The discovery of the market,” said Moisés Nairn, a Venezuelan economist-and former minister, “will soon force Latin American countries to rediscover the state,” for the market cannot work with a malfunctioning state. Just how to refocus government toward alleviating poverty and regulating private enterprise, at a time when the state itself is discredited, is the special challenge of Latin America’s reforming economies. The pioneers among them have gone further than anyone else in opening their “strategic” sectors to the outside world. They now routinely experiment with the most sophisticated technical tools of the market economy. But at the same time, there is no guarantee that electricity and other crucial infrastructure services, not to mention improved health care and education, will be delivered to the large numbers of people who are excluded. Failure to improve conditions will only redouble Latin America’s already gaping contrast between rich and poor, and set the continent on a drastically different course from its rivals in Asia. It will also stir political jitters and memories of less democratic times.16

玻利维亚，这个十多年前“休克疗法”的发源地，最近为巩固民众对市场化改革的支持提供了一种创新方法。在1993年至1997年担任玻利维亚总统期间，冈萨洛·桑切斯·德·洛萨达及其改革团队观察了其他国家的私有化模式，并决定玻利维亚应该采取略有不同的方法，以自己的方式诠释这一普遍模式。他们计划出售主要的国有企业，包括能源和电信企业，但方式却很特别。戈尼（戈尼的昵称）想到了安第斯山脉高处的印第安人将收成分配给田地所有者和耕种者的做法。他借鉴了这种方法来实施他的改革方案。每出售一家国有企业，政府将通过招标程序选定战略合作伙伴——通常是由经验丰富的外国公司组成的联合体。该合作伙伴将持有50%的股权，并拥有独家管理控制权。

Bolivia, the country where shock therapy was born more than a decade ago, has recently provided an innovative approach to consolidating popular commitment to the move to the market. During his term as president of Bolivia from 1993 to 1997, Gonzalo Sánchez de Lozada and his reform team observed the ways that other countries privatized and decided that Bolivia should have a somewhat different approach, its own variation on the common theme. They would sell off the chief public enterprises, including those in energy and telecommunications, but in a particular way. Goni had in mind what happened high up in the Andes, where the Indians divided the harvest between those who owned the fields and those who worked them. He borrowed that approach for his program. For each sale of a state company, the government would select by a bidding process a strategic partner—typically, a consortium of foreign firms experienced at the job. The partner would own 50 percent of equity and wield exclusive management control.

玻利维亚的创新之处在于对剩余50%的资产的处理，这部分资产被移交给国家养老基金——而这些养老基金的管理权也很快被私有化。每年年底，养老基金将利用私有化企业的收入，向所有65岁以上的玻利维亚公民发放股息。股息金额最初不高，每位玻利维亚老年人250美元。但由于这超过了人均年收入的10%，因此数额相当可观。戈尼拒绝将这项计划称为“私有化”。在他看来，这个词含义过于模糊，且带有负面的政治色彩。相反，他找到了一个令玛格丽特·撒切尔和世界各地许多其他私有化推手都难以启齿的词。他称之为“资本化” ——这个词试图表明，市场开放和切实改善社会福利可以齐头并进。养老基金的使用实现了两个基本目标。首先是应用亚洲共享增长原则——让民众参与企业经营并直接分享企业业绩。其次是合法性，因为企业的大部分股份仍然掌握在“人民”手中。

Where Bolivia innovated was with the remaining 50 percent, which it handed over to national pension funds—whose management it soon privatized as well. At the end of each year, the pension funds, using the revenue of the privatized firms, are to pay out a dividend to every Bolivian above the age of sixty-five. The dividend has started off small—$250 per elderly Bolivian. But because it is more than 10 percent of annual per capita income, the amount is quite significant. Goni refused to call the plan privatization. In his mind, the word was too heavily loaded with ambiguity and negative political connotations. Instead, he found a word that had eluded Margaret Thatcher and so many other privatizers around the world. He called it capitalization—a term which tried to say that market opening and tangible welfare improvement can go hand in hand. The use of the pension funds accomplishes two fundamental objectives. The first is the application of the Asian principle of shared growth—giving the population a stake in the enterprise and direct benefits of its performance. The second is legitimacy, for a good part of the enterprise remains in the hands of the “people.”

当前拉丁美洲的经验表明，新规则的实施仅仅是开始，而非结束。随着市场机制的恢复，人们的注意力将重新集中到国家角色的重新构建上。国家不再是控制一切、令人窒息的官僚机构，也不再是企业管理者，而是能够扮演公正监管者角色、并妥善处理人类需求这一重大遗留问题的称职国家。这出戏码，仍有待书写。

The current Latin American experience demonstrates that implementation of the new rules of the game is the beginning, not the end. With the market restored, attention returns to the rediscovery of the state. It is no longer to be the controlling, suffocating state, nor the state as business manager, but the competent state that can play an appropriate role of fair regulator—and address the heavy legacy of human needs. That script is still to be written.

第十章

CHAPTER 10

在美国，至今仍有一些人对这个形象记忆犹新——无论是来自那个时代本身，还是来自某部电影。英俊的年轻人迈着大步穿越美国，他的手在空中挥舞，带着浓重的波士顿口音——他铿锵有力地宣告：“我们必须让这个国家重新运转起来。”

THERE ARE STILL those in America for whom the image is embedded in memory—either from the era itself or from some piece of film. The handsome young man stumping across the country, his hand slicing through the air, his Boston twang—and his ringing declaration: “We must get this country moving again.”

约翰·肯尼迪在1960年总统竞选期间反复强调国家必须重新振作起来，但人们却不太记得他当时的真正原因。仅仅三年前，也就是1957年，苏联发射了第一颗人造卫星“斯普特尼克”，这令美国的自信心遭受重创。随后，在1959年，苏联领导人尼基塔·赫鲁晓夫在洛杉矶的一次午餐会上发出挑战，咆哮道：“我们会把你们埋葬。”苏联的意识形态和实力似乎正在强势扩张。

Less well remembered than John Kennedy’s refrain during the 1960 presidential campaign is why he said the country had to get moving again. Just three years before, in 1957, the Soviets had lofted the first Sputnik into orbit, shocking American self-confidence. And then, in 1959, Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev had thrown down the gauntlet at a luncheon in Los Angeles, growling: “We will bury you.” Soviet ideology and power appeared to be militantly on the march.

这一切都得益于苏联看似极高的经济增长率，远高于美国。如果美国不重新振作起来，资本主义和西方将在争夺世界领导权的竞赛中失败，并失去各国对共产主义和苏联的效忠。肯尼迪认为未来可能属于西方，但他所表达的信心远非根深蒂固。

All of this was made possible by apparently high Soviet growth rates, much higher than American rates. If the United States did not get moving again, then capitalism and the West were going to fail in the race for world leadership and lose the allegiance of nations to communism and the Soviet Union. Kennedy argued that the future could belong to the West, but the confidence he expressed was not at all deeply entrenched.

仅仅三十年后，到了20世纪90年代初，这场竞赛就结束了。结果显而易见。实行极端国家控制的共产主义已经失败，破产；苏联分崩离析；其主要继承国俄罗斯正在向某种市场经济社会转型。那颗曾赢得无数人想象和支持的红星，从天而降。这一切在1960年的约翰·肯尼迪看来，简直是天方夜谭。

Just three decades later, by the beginning of the 1990s, the race was over. The outcome was decisive. Communism, with its extreme state control, was defunct, bankrupt; the Soviet Union was fragmented; and Russia, its main successor state, was moving to turn itself into some kind of market society. The red star, which had captured the imagination and support of so many people, had dropped from the sky. All of this would have seemed quite improbable to John Kennedy in 1960.

共产主义的崩溃和苏联帝国的终结构成了正如俄国革命和第一次世界大战定义了二十世纪的开端一样，二十世纪末的标志性事件也同样意义重大。在其他任何地方，国家与市场关系的重塑都未曾像在前共产主义世界那样剧烈，因为这场剧变引发了一场在那些市场曾长期被摒弃的国家中建立市场体系的激烈斗争。共产主义制度曾自诩为未来的先锋，但它最终在自身内部衰败的压力下崩溃了。中央计划和国有制的机制未能促进创新，也未能分配经济增长的成果——最终，它甚至未能带来任何增长。

The collapse of communism and the end of the Soviet empire constitute the defining events of the end of the twentieth century, just as the revolutions in Russia, along with World War I, defined its beginning. Nowhere else has the recasting of the relationship between state and market been so extreme as in the former communist world, for the upheaval has set off a turbulent struggle to establish market systems in the very countries where markets had for so long been banished. The communist system claimed to be the vanguard of the future, but it buckled under the pressure of its inner decay. The machinery of central planning and state ownership failed to foster innovation and distribute the benefits of economic growth—and then it failed to deliver any growth at all.

共产主义经济的全面失败引发了始于1989年的政治革命，这场革命席卷了东欧和苏联。崩溃来得如此之快，以至于根本没有时间进行深思熟虑的调整。苏联帝国的继承国没有办法用资本主义取代共产主义经济机器，在建国初期，它们不得不面对前所未有的困境，这些困境几乎超乎想象。许多国家的人民感觉自己仿佛被带到了月球背面。旧的中央计划和控制机制消失了，所有曾经支配经济组织和日常生活的规则都荡然无存，而且没有任何替代方案。取而代之的是恶性通货膨胀、极度的不安全感、对国有资产控制权的激烈争夺，以及似乎无处不在的混乱。从共产主义的废墟中重建市场体系的进程至今仍远未完成。然而，尽管“转型”这一略显抽象的概念带来了诸多痛苦，尽管转型过程充满不平衡，但原苏联帝国的大部分地区进入市场经济的速度却比预期更快。这种转型——以及塑造转型的思想斗争——其重要性不亚于共产主义国家自身的崩溃及其意识形态在全球范围内的消亡。

The pervasive economic failure of communism brought about the political revolution that, beginning in 1989, swept across Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. When the collapse came, it happened so quickly that there was no time for considered adjustment. The successor states to the Soviet empire had no recipe for replacing the communist economic machine with capitalism, and in their first years of existence, they wrestled with travails that had never been anticipated and that were indeed almost beyond imagination. Many of the people in those countries felt as though they had been transported to the other side of the moon. The old apparatus of central planning and control disappeared, and all the rules that had governed economic organization and daily life were gone, with nothing at hand to replace them. Instead, people confronted hyperinflation, massive insecurity, a fierce battle for control of state assets, and what seemed to be pervasive chaos. The construction of market systems out of the rubble of communism is still very much unfinished. Yet for all the human pain of what is somewhat abstractly called “transition” and for all the unevenness of the process, most of the old Soviet empire has been brought into a market economy faster than was anticipated. That transformation—and the struggle of ideas that shaped it—is as compelling as the collapse of the communist states themselves and the demise, around the world, of their ideology.

波兰危机：终结的开始

Poland’s Crisis: The Beginning of the End

共产主义的终结并非始于中心——苏联，而是始于边陲——波罗的海沿岸。位于波罗的海港口城市格但斯克的列宁造船厂原本是波兰共产主义国家的标志性建筑之一。然而，事实上，工人们的不满情绪十分高涨。1979年12月的一天，许多工人聚集在绿灰色的大门前举行纪念活动，悼念九年前在同一地点被警察和士兵屠杀的抗议工人。一位身材矮壮、留着下垂胡须的电工走到人群前面。“我呼吁你们组织起来，成立独立的团体，自卫，”莱赫·瓦文萨恳求道。他曾因政治活动而被造船厂解雇。他还说，如果政府不建纪念碑……为了纪念被杀害的工人，所有在那里的人都应该在一年后回来，每人带一块石头，然后他们自己一块一块地建造纪念碑。1

The end of communism did not begin at the center, in the Soviet Union, but on the frontier, along the coast of the Baltic Sea. The huge Lenin Shipyards in the Baltic port of Gdansk were meant to be one of the showpieces of the Polish communist state. In fact, discontent was rife among its workers. On a December day in 1979, many of them gathered in front of the green-gray gates for a memorial—to mark the massacre of protesting workers on the same spot by police and soldiers some nine years earlier. A stocky electrician with a droopy mustache worked his way to the front of the group. “I appeal to you to organize yourself in independent groups for your own self-defense,” implored Lech Walesa, who had been fired by the shipyard for political activism. And, he said, if the government would not build a memorial to the slain workers, then all those there should return in a year, each bearing a stone, and they themselves would build the monument, stone by stone.1

他们建立的，却是团结工会运动的开端。这场运动在共产主义国家几乎做到了不可思议的事情：挑战政府。次年八月，同一造船厂的工人们，有的甚至从半成品船上爬下来，举行了罢工。很快，数千名工人占领了造船厂，其他罢工企业的代表也加入了他们的行列。近三周后，政府被迫屈服于他们的要求，包括允许工人组建独立工会和举行罢工。此前，从未有任何一个共产主义政府如此大张旗鼓地赋予公民自由。团结工会取得了胜利，至少是暂时的。

What they built instead was the beginning of a movement, Solidarity, that would do the almost inconceivable in a communist country: challenge the government. The following August, workers in the same shipyard, some of them clambering down from half-completed ships, went on strike. Soon, thousands of workers were occupying the shipyard and representatives from other striking enterprises joined them. After almost three weeks, the government capitulated to their demands, including the right to form independent unions and to strike. Never had a communist government gone so far as to grant liberties to its citizens. Solidarity had won, at least temporarily.

波兰反对派之所以能够崛起，部分原因在于其他任何共产主义国家都无法提供的——天主教会强大的支持，无论公开还是秘密。然而，若非两年前梵蒂冈城发生的一件事——新任教宗若望保禄一世的意外逝世——这种支持的全部力量恐怕无法发挥出来。继任者是波兰籍枢机主教、克拉科夫总主教卡罗尔·沃伊蒂瓦，他为了纪念前任教宗，取名若望保禄二世。1979年7月，若望保禄二世在波兰进行了一次凯旋之旅；他曾向两百万民众发表演讲。波兰教宗的到访点燃了波兰人民新的信仰、信心和民族团结；同时也鼓舞了反对派。若望保禄二世在二战期间曾在地下神学院接受教育，他始终反对共产党政权。在他担任枢机主教期间，他冒着巨大的风险，帮助培育了后来发展成为民主运动的雏形。如今身为教皇的他，为异议人士创建了庇护所，并将罗马天主教会动员起来，使其成为对抗共产主义的强大力量。1980年8月列宁造船厂罢工期间，工人们聚集的大门上悬挂着教皇的画像。他的出现似乎给了他们力量。共产主义世界的势力意识到，他们面对的是一位多么危险的对手——这位波兰教皇。

The Polish opposition was made possible in part by something not available in any other communist country—the powerful support, both open and covert, of the Catholic Church. And yet the full weight of that support would not have been brought to bear were it not for an event in Vatican City two years earlier—the unexpected death of the newly anointed pope, John Paul I. He was succeeded by a Polish cardinal, Karol Wojtyla, the archbishop of Krakow, who took the name John Paul II in honor of his predecessor. In July 1979, John Paul II made a triumphant tour across Poland; one group he spoke to numbered two million. The visit of the Polish pope kindled a new sense of faith, confidence, and national unity; it also inspired the opposition. Educated in an underground seminary during World II, John Paul II had consistently stood against Communist Party power. During his years as cardinal, he helped nurture—at great risk—what became the democratic movement. Now as pope, he created a sanctuary for dissidence and mobilized the Roman Catholic Church as a powerful opponent of communism. During the August 1980 strike in the Lenin Shipyards, a portrait of the pope decorated the gates behind which the workers rallied. His presence seemed to give them strength. The powers in the communist world recognized what a dangerous antagonist they faced in the Polish pope.

团结工会运动的兴起，是对日益恶化的生活状况——生活水平下降和物资短缺加剧——的抗议。事实上，“短缺经济”后来成了中央计划经济体制下共产主义经济的代名词。自20世纪60年代末以来，波兰经济饱受衰退之苦，在共产主义框架内根本无法进行改革。匈牙利曾尝试推行更为灵活的“市场社会主义”（也被称为“炖牛肉社会主义”），试图在中央计划经济中引入市场经济的元素。然而，除了波兰幸存下来的私营农业之外，波兰共产党领导层对此置若罔闻，坚持己见。

Solidarity had emerged as a protest against deteriorating conditions—sinking standards of living and growing shortages. Indeed, the “shortage economy” would become the alternative name for the centrally planned communist economies. Since the late 1960s, the Polish economy had suffered from economic decline and an absolute inability to reform within a communist framework. Hungary had tried to implement reform by experimenting with a more flexible “market socialism,” otherwise known as “goulash socialism.” It introduced elements of a market system into the centrally planned economy. But, except for the private agriculture that survived in Poland, the Polish Communist Party leadership would have none of it. They stuck to orthodoxy.

然而，劳工动荡意味着领导层必须采取行动。但波兰政府在20世纪70年代初并没有尝试进行重大改革，而是转向西方，认为可以通过借贷摆脱困境。波兰陷入困境。它背负了巨额贷款，以为可以利用这些资金降低食品价格、引进西方技术，从而在不改变体制的前提下改善经济状况。事实证明，这是一个致命的假设。宽松的融资环境使波兰陷入了无法自拔的困境。通过向西方借贷，波兰背负了巨额债务，既无力偿还，也无力偿还。到20世纪70年代末，波兰的债务负担已高达250亿美元。

Yet labor unrest meant that the leadership had to do something. Rather than try major reform, however, the Polish government in the early 1970s turned to the West, on the assumption that it could borrow its way out of its troubles. It contracted enormous loans, thinking it could use that money to keep food prices down, import Western technology, and thus improve its economic performance without tampering with the system. That turned out to be the fatal assumption. Easy finance led the country into a situation from which it would not be able to extract itself. By borrowing from the West, it took on huge loans that it could neither service nor repay. By the end of the 1970s, Poland’s debt burden had reached $25 billion.

波兰人基本上浪费了借来的资金。经济非但没有复苏，反而因结构性问题和无力偿还的债务而雪上加霜。波兰很快面临严重的国际收支危机。它曾是粮食进口大国，如今却严重缺乏支付进口粮食的能力。物资短缺随处可见。在列宁造船厂被占领后，波兰团结工会迅速发展壮大。短短几个月内，其成员就接近1000万。

The Poles largely wasted the borrowed funds. Instead of bouncing back, the economy was doubly burdened by its structural problems and by the repayment obligations, which it could not meet. Poland soon faced a massive balance-of-payments crisis. It had turned into an enormous food importer, and yet it was now severely constrained in its ability to pay for food imports. Shortages were everywhere. In these stringent circumstances, following the occupation of the Lenin Shipyards, Solidarity grew. In a matter of months, its membership approached 10 million.

莫斯科对这种前所未有的共产主义政权威胁日益感到震惊，苏联对波兰政府的压力也与日俱增。一些人甚至认为，1981年5月发生在圣彼得广场的教皇约翰·保罗二世遇刺事件是苏联幕后策划的。最终，在经历了长达一年半的罢工和抗议活动后，波兰政府于1981年12月展开反击。坦克开进华沙市中心，路障封锁了全国，电话线也被切断。政府宣布实施戒严。“团结工会”被取缔，其领导人被捕。然而，这一切并未改善波兰的处境。整个20世纪80年代，波兰的经济形势进一步恶化。“团结工会”被迫转入地下，瓦文萨则被软禁在家。最后，在 1989 年，为了挽救仍在下沉的经济，共产党人孤注一掷地召开了一次全国性的“圆桌会议”，与会者包括团结工会和天主教会的领导人，目的是讨论波兰黯淡的未来，并开启更加开放的对话。

Moscow was progressively more alarmed by this unprecedented threat to communist power, and Soviet pressure on the Polish government became enormous. Some maintained that the Soviets were behind the May 1981 assassination attempt on Pope John Paul II in St. Peter’s Square. Finally, in December 1981, after a year and a half of strikes and agitation, the government counterattacked. Tanks moved into the center of Warsaw, roadblocks sectioned off the country, and telephone lines were cut. The government declared martial law. Solidarity was banned; its leaders, arrested. Yet all that did nothing to improve Poland’s prospects. Over the 1980s, the economic situation deteriorated further. Solidarity struggled to survive underground, and Walesa was under house arrest. Finally, in 1989, in a desperate effort to bolster the still-sinking economy, the Communists convened a national “roundtable,” which included both Solidarity and Catholic Church leaders, to discuss the Poland’s bleak future and initiate a more open dialogue.

电话

The Phone Call

此时，苏联正忙于应对自身问题，开始从东欧撤军。它开始撤出军队。克里姆林宫的专家们开始论证，在东欧建立帝国的代价远大于收益，他们的观点得到了重视。在波兰，1989年圆桌会议之后，团结工会重新获得合法地位。下一步是举行自由选举。选举结果对共产主义来说是灾难性的。在新组建的上议院中，团结工会赢得了100个席位中的99个。在下议院，35名共产党候选人无人竞争。然而，为了当选，他们必须获得超过50%的选票。波兰选民——其中许多人带着孩子到投票站，亲眼见证他们的反抗行为——仔细地划掉了共产党候选人的名字。35名共产党候选人中，除两人外，其余全部落选。

At this point, the Soviet Union, preoccupied with its own problems, was beginning to disengage from Eastern Europe. It started withdrawing its troops. Experts close to the Kremlin had begun to argue that the costs of empire in Eastern Europe outweighed the benefits, and they were heard. In Poland, in the aftermath of the 1989 roundtable, Solidarity was relegalized. The next step was free elections. The results were cataclysmic for communism. In the newly reconstituted Upper House, Solidarity won ninety-nine out of a hundred seats. In the Lower House, thirty-five Communist Party candidates were running unopposed. Still, in order to be elected, they had to gain over 50 percent of the vote. Polish voters—many of them bringing their children to the polling booths to witness their acts of defiance—carefully crossed out the names of the Communist candidates. All but two of the thirty-five Communists were defeated.

如同以往无数次一样，波兰政权再次向莫斯科寻求指示。但这一次，答案却截然不同。米哈伊尔·戈尔巴乔夫与波兰共产党领导人通了电话。戈尔巴乔夫的讲话令人震惊。他说，苏联将接受自由选举的结果——在这种情况下，将组建一个由共产党少数派领导、非共产党总理领导的政府。正是这通电话结束了冷战。

As so often in the past, the Polish regime turned to Moscow for directions. But this time the answer was different. Mikhail Gorbachev talked by phone with the head of the Polish Communist Party. Gorbachev’s message was stunning. The Soviet Union, he said, would accept the outcome of a free election—in this case, a government with a Communist minority and a non-Communist prime minister. That phone call ended the cold war.

团结工会几乎没有做好掌权的准备。它是一个广泛的政治联盟，一场抗议运动，而非一个政党。由于团结工会在下议院仅占三分之一的席位，其领导人担心他们是否应该——甚至是否能够——掌权。他们的新经济顾问是杰弗里·萨克斯，这位哈佛大学教授在拉丁美洲的贡献已为他赢得了国际声誉。一位团结工会的领导人告诉萨克斯，该运动在议会中没有足够的席位来做任何事情，而且波兰的经济一团糟。萨克斯回答说，波兰看起来确实像一团糟，但眼见未必为实。波兰与德国接壤，位于欧洲中心——而且波兰人并不缺乏经济技能。简而言之，结果可能会出乎所有人的意料。这就是萨克斯在拉丁美洲学到的。经过数小时的激烈讨论，他最终提出了一个简单的建议：行动起来，夺取政权。那位团结工会的领导人长叹一声。 “我对这次谈话很不满意，”他说，“因为我认为你是对的。”

Solidarity hardly felt itself prepared to take power. It was a broad political coalition, a protest movement, not a party. With Solidarity holding only one third of the Lower House, its leaders worried about whether they should—or even could—take power. Their new economic adviser was Jeffrey Sachs, the Harvard professor whose role in Latin America had already earned him international recognition. One Solidarity leader told Sachs that the movement did not have enough votes in the Parliament to do anything and that Poland was an economic basket case. It certainly looked like a basket case, Sachs replied, but looks could be deceiving. Poland shared a border with Germany, it was in the center of Europe—and the Poles were not lacking in economic skills. In short, the results could surprise everyone. That was what Sachs had learned in Latin America. After hours of impassioned discussion, he finally offered a simple message: Do it; take power. The Solidarity leader sighed a very long sigh. “I’m very unhappy with this conversation,” he said, “because I think you’re right.”

团结工会的领导人要求萨克斯和他的同事大卫·利普顿拟定一份经济纲要，以实现快速而全面的变革。“而且，”他们被告知，“请务必在纲要开头写上‘通过这项纲要，波兰将跃升至市场经济’。我们希望迅速行动；这是唯一可行的方法。”萨克斯表示，他和利普顿会返回美国撰写一份计划。但他们被告知，没有时间了。第二天早上就需要。这两位美国人熬夜撰写了一份计划，然后第二天前往格但斯克，与团结工会的成员会面并解释该计划。2

The Solidarity leaders asked Sachs and his colleague David Lipton to prepare the outline for an economic program for rapid and comprehensive change. “And, please,” they were told, “start the outline with the words ‘With this program, Poland will jump to the market economy.’ We want to move quickly; that is the only way that this will make sense.” Sachs said that he and Lipton would go back to the United States and write a plan. No, they were told, there was no time for that. It was needed the next morning. The two Americans stayed up all night, wrote a plan, and then went to Gdansk the next day to meet with Solidarity members to explain it.2

“我的路德维希·艾哈德”

“My Ludwig Erhard”

1989年8月，塔德乌什·马佐维茨基成为波兰首位非共产党总理。他当时并不清楚自己想要什么样的经济方案，但他知道自己需要迅速行动，并且需要一位能够执行萨克斯和利普顿所起草的方案的人。他说，他当时在寻找“我的路德维希·艾哈德”。

Tadeusz Mazowiecki became Poland’s first nonCommunist prime minister in August 1989. He did not know exactly what sort of economic program he wanted, but he knew he wanted rapid action—and that he wanted someone who could implement the kind of program Sachs and Lipton had drafted. He was looking, he said, “for my Ludwig Erhard.”

马佐维茨基在一位名叫莱谢克·巴尔采罗维奇的波兰经济学家身上找到了他的埃尔哈德。巴尔采罗维奇是经济纲领的制定者，该纲领最终不仅将波兰，而且将东欧大部分地区，甚至苏联，都带入了市场经济。就在这一年，共产主义像多米诺骨牌一样在东欧崩溃。正如人们常开玩笑说的那样，波兰用了十年才摆脱共产主义；匈牙利用了十个月；捷克斯洛伐克用了十天；而罗马尼亚只用了十个小时，最终以处决告终。在独裁者尼古拉·齐奥塞斯库的统治下，波兰经历了动荡不安的时期。尽管如此，波兰在经济改革方面仍走在前列，这要归功于巴尔采罗维奇。

Mazowiecki found his Erhard in a Polish economist named Leszek Balcerowicz, who was the author of the economic program that would end up carrying not only Poland but also much of Eastern Europe, and even the Soviet Union, into the market economy. This was the year that communism collapsed, dominolike, throughout Eastern Europe. As the joke went, Poland took ten years to throw off communism; Hungary, ten months; Czechoslovakia, ten days; and Romania, just ten hours, which culminated in the execution of its dictator, Nicolae Ceausescu. Through all of this upheaval, Poland led the way in terms of economic reform, and that was the work of Balcerowicz.

巴尔塞罗维奇为这一刻准备了二十年。他曾在纽约圣约翰大学学习了两年商业。随后，他深入研究了韩国和台湾的经济增长动力。他甚至一度前往西德考察路德维希·艾哈德1948年的改革，事实证明这是一个明智之举；当他被选中担任马佐维茨基的“路德维希·艾哈德”时，他确实了解艾哈德的改革措施。此外，他还孜孜不倦地研究了拉丁美洲各项稳定计划的成功与失败之处。

Balcerowicz had been preparing for this moment for two decades. He had spent two years studying business at St. John’s University in New York City. Subsequently, he had investigated the dynamics of Korean and Taiwanese growth. At one point he went to West Germany to study Ludwig Erhard’s reforms of 1948, which turned out to be a brilliant decision; when he was picked to be Mazowiecki’s “Ludwig Erhard,” he actually knew what Erhard had done. He had also assiduously examined what had worked and not worked in the various Latin American stabilization programs.

自1978年起，他在华沙领导着后来被称为“巴尔采罗维奇小组”的研究团队。该小组长期致力于分析社会主义的“问题”以及如何改革波兰经济。研究重点包括产权、国家在经济中的恰当角色、通货膨胀，以及日益成为社会主义真正标志的物资短缺等基本问题。所有这些都使巴尔采罗维奇确信，“渐进主义”注定失败。除非将足够多的变革结合起来并迅速实施，否则就无法达到必要的“临界规模”。与许多经济学家不同，他还涉猎社会心理学。他对认知失调理论印象尤为深刻。正如巴尔采罗维奇总结该理论对经济改革的意义时所说：“如果人们面临环境的根本性变化，并且他们认为这些变化是不可逆转的，那么他们更有可能改变自己的态度和行为，而不是面对渐进式的变化。”3

In Warsaw, from 1978 onward, he had directed what became known as “the Balcerowicz group,” a long-running study group that was devoted to analyzing the “problems” of socialism and the question of how to reform the Polish economy. It focused on such basic questions as property rights, the proper role of the state in the economy, inflation, and what was increasingly becoming the true hallmark of socialism—shortages. All of this convinced Balcerowicz that “gradualism” was doomed to failure. Unless enough changes were combined and applied rapidly, the necessary “critical mass” would not be reached. Unlike many economists, he also dabbled in social psychology. He was particularly impressed by the theory of cognitive dissonance. As Balcerowicz summed up its significance for economic reform: “People are more likely to change their attitudes and their behavior if they are faced with radical changes in their environment, which they consider irreversible, than if those changes are only gradual.”3

市场革命

Market Revolution

巴尔采罗维奇在新成立的团结党政府中出任财政部长兼副总理，条件是他唯一要推行的转型必须是极其迅速且大规模的。这一转型被冠以一个早已在拉丁美洲流行起来的词汇——休克疗法。但巴尔采罗维奇更倾向于“市场革命”这个说法。无论叫什么，他都清楚这项政策风险极大，势必会遭到强烈反对。但他确信一点：渐进主义绝对行不通。接下来的几个月里，巴尔采罗维奇和他的团队夜以继日地制定计划，并起草所有必要的法律。而这一切都发生在经济形势日益恶化的背景下。当时的通货膨胀率高达年增长率17000%，使波兰成为历史上第十四个出现恶性通货膨胀的国家。此时，波兰已拖欠410亿美元的债务，许多企业管理者正在进行一种被委婉地称为“自发私有化”的活动——尽可能快地窃取他们所管理企业的资产。

Balcerowicz became finance minister and deputy prime minister in the new Solidarity government on the condition that the only transition he would implement would be a very rapid and massive one. It became known by the term already popularized from Latin America—shock therapy. But Balcerowicz preferred the term market revolution. Whatever the name, he knew the policy would be very risky and would meet much opposition. But of one thing he was sure: Gradualism would certainly not succeed. Over the next few months, Balcerowicz and his team worked feverishly to devise a plan and write all the laws that would be necessary. They did so amid an ever-worsening economic situation. Inflation was now running at an annual rate of 17,000 percent, making Poland the fourteenth case of hyperinflation in history. By this time, the country was in default on a debt of $41 billion, and many enterprise managers were engaged in what was euphemistically called “spontaneous privatization”—stealing as quickly as they could the assets of the enterprises they managed.

1990年1月1日是“大爆炸”之日，巴尔采罗维奇的休克疗法正式颁布，这是市场革命的关键一击。而这的确是一次冲击——与共产主义时代的决裂。大多数价格都发生了翻天覆地的变化。解放了经济。货币兹罗提贬值并实行自由兑换。政府实施了管制措施，以防止工资激增。政府赤字占GDP的比重从7%降至1%。税制进行了改革，并实施了紧缩的货币政策。

January 1, 1990, was the day of the “big bang,” the promulgation of Balcerowicz’s shock therapy, the critical salvo in the market revolution. And it was a shock—a decisive break with the communist past. Most prices were freed. The currency, the zloty, was devalued and made convertible. Controls were imposed to forestall an explosion in wage increases. The government deficit was to be reduced from 7 to 1 percent of the GDP. Taxes were reformed and a restrictive monetary policy put in place.

巴尔采罗维奇和他的同事们忐忑不安地等待着事态发展。他们知道物价会上涨，但估计涨幅在45%左右。然而，短短几天内，物价就飙升了78%。粮食、肉类和其他食品的储备告急，短缺状况持续恶化。他们屏住了呼吸。粮食骚乱、街头示威——这些都可能破坏整个改革计划，让波兰重回威权主义的深渊。但到了1月底，情况开始有所好转。起初只是零星几户，后来人数越来越多，农民们开始从农村开车进城，绕过国家分销系统，直接在汽车、卡车上或人行道上售卖农产品。工业产品也以同样的方式涌入市场。波兰一夜之间迎来的不是示威者和暴徒，而是商贩。随着短缺的缓解和供应的增加，物价开始回落。巴尔采罗维奇的助手们试图安抚这位焦虑的老板，让他把注意力放在鸡蛋上。没错，鸡蛋将是衡量改革成败的关键指标。月底，结果证实：鸡蛋价格趋于稳定，在一些地区甚至有所下降。巴尔采罗维奇长舒了一口气。鸡蛋市场的成功是一次巨大的胜利。市场运转良好。4

Balcerowicz and his colleagues waited nervously to see what would happen. They knew prices would go up, but they estimated a 45 percent rise. Instead, prices jumped 78 percent in a matter of days. Reserves of grain, meat, and other foods were low and the shortages continued. They held their breath. Food riots, demonstrations in the street—these could undermine the entire reform program and send Poland spinning back to authoritarianism. But by the end of January, something began to happen. First in a trickle, then in growing numbers, farmers started to drive into the cities from the countryside, bypassing the state distribution system and selling their produce from cars and trucks or on the sidewalk. Industrial wares showed up in the same way. Instead of demonstrators and rioters, Poland had acquired merchants overnight. As shortages disappeared and supplies increased, prices started to come down. Balcerowicz’s aides tried to reassure their tense boss by telling him to focus on eggs. Yes, eggs would be the critical indicator of success or failure. By the end of the month, it was confirmed: The price of eggs had leveled off, and in some parts of the country, it had actually declined. Balcerowicz heaved a great sigh of relief. The eggs constituted a great victory. Markets were working.4

然而，休克疗法确实令人震惊，批评和反对之声迅速高涨。许多人认为，渐进主义才是更好的选择。这场辩论的背后，存在着一种根本性的思维分歧——一方即便在共产主义之后，仍然指望国家作为仲裁者；另一方则对市场的运作机制充满信心。报刊上充斥着关于生活水平和GDP下降的文章。但这些论断忽略了一个事实：官方的GDP数据并不能反映新兴的、仍处于“非正式”状态的市场中正在发生的事情。人们不断呼吁扶持和振兴庞大的国有工业企业。在巴尔采罗维奇看来，这无异于把钱扔进无底洞，因为许多企业已经失去了存在的意义、市场和未来，而且效率低下、浪费严重。在很多情况下，它们之所以能维持目前的规模，仅仅是因为斯大林主义的经济教条规定它们必须存在。

Yet shock therapy was a shock, and criticism and opposition rose very quickly. Gradualism, many argued, was the better way to go. Underlying the debate was a fundamental difference of mind—between those who looked, even after communism, to the state to be the arbiter and those who had confidence in the dynamics of markets. The press was filled with articles about the decline in the standard of living and the GDP. But the assertions failed to take into account the fact that official GDP numbers did not capture what was happening in the new, still “informal,” market. There were constant calls for propping up and reviving the huge state industrial concerns. To Balcerowicz, this would be throwing good money after bad, for so many of the firms no longer had a purpose, a market, or a future, and were extremely inefficient and wasteful. In too many cases, they existed in their current dimensions only because Stalinist economic dogma had ordained that they should exist.

“别再仰望顶峰”

“Stop Looking to the Top”

巴尔采罗维奇不得不应对来自四面八方的攻击。在格但斯克举行的团结工会成员大会上，他愤怒地宣称：“我们必须摆脱旧习和旧观念。尤其重要的是，我们必须停止仰望‘上层’，停止仰望国家，因为那是旧思维的遗物。”他不得不反复提醒1990年12月当选总统的瓦文萨，经济失败将意味着耻辱。在梵蒂冈觐见教皇约翰·保罗二世时，巴尔采罗维奇被迫回答教皇严厉的问题：波兰是否有可能建立“公正的市场经济”。他遭受了各种各样的辱骂；甚至不得不亲自应对那些闯入财政部、要求见他的愤怒人士。他庆幸自己的政府安全官员恰好也拥有心理咨询学位。

Balcerowicz had to fight off attacks from many quarters. To an angry convention of Solidarity members in Gdansk, he declared, “We have to break away from old habits and attitudes. In particular, we have to stop looking to ‘the top,’ to the state, because it is a relic of the old way of thinking.” Again and again he had to remind Walesa, who was elected president in December 1990, that economic failure would mean disgrace. Meeting John Paul II at the Vatican, Balcerowicz was forced to answer the pope’s stern question as to whether it was possible to create a “just market economy in Poland.” He endured all sorts of abuse; he even had to deal personally with angry individuals who managed to get into the Ministry of Finance, demanding to see him. He was thankful that his government security officers also happened to have degrees in counseling.

大型国有企业的私有化进程缓慢。首先，尽管巴尔采罗维奇将私有化视为“制度重组的关键部分”，但他认为在经济稳定和建立起所谓的市场社会之前进行私有化毫无意义。否则，在“恶性通货膨胀的混乱局面”下，私有化将变得毫无意义。后来，当波兰设计出一套大型企业私有化体系时，却发现它既繁琐又缓慢。

The privatization of the large state concerns proceeded slowly. To begin with, while Balcerowicz regarded privatization as “the key part of the institutional restructuring,” he saw no point in trying to privatize before stabilization and the creation of what might be called a market society. Otherwise, privatization would become meaningless in the “chaos of hyperinflation.” Subsequently, when a Polish system was devised for privatizing large firms, it proved to be cumbersome and ponderous.

如果说改革方案的这一部分令人失望，那么其他部分则远远超出了预期。没有什么比小企业的蓬勃发展更能戏剧性地展现新经济的诞生——或者说，没有什么比小企业蓬勃发展更能使新经济成为可能。1989年底至1992年中期，新增注册公司超过70万家。到1997年中期，这一数字已超过200万。“短缺经济”随着以消费者为导向的经济体系的出现而消失。1989年底至1992年6月，实际工资增长了七倍。到1992年，新兴的私营部门创造了超过一半的GDP。由于新兴私营企业在两年内创造了200万个新的就业岗位，预期的大规模失业并未出现。波兰的进口量有所增加，但现在有能力支付进口款项。1989年至1993年间，波兰的进口额和外汇出口额均翻了一番，而且许多出口商品是家用电器等产品——这是任何人始料未及的。地理位置——波兰毗邻德国和欧洲其他国家——以及自由贸易的优势，最终证明远比预期更有价值。而最令人瞩目的成果莫过于波兰的整体经济表现——自1994年以来，波兰经济年均增长率达到6%。人们开始不再将波兰视为一个“问题国家”，而是将其视为欧洲的“新老虎”。

If that part of the reform program was disappointing, other parts greatly exceeded expectations. Nothing so dramatized the birth of the new economy—or made it possible—as the explosion of small business. Between the end of 1989 and mid-1992, over seven hundred thousand new companies were registered. In mid-1997 the number was over 2 million. The “shortage economy” disappeared as a consumer-oriented system emerged. Real wages rose sevenfold between the end of 1989 and June 1992. By 1992, the new private sector was generating over half of the entire GDP. The predicted mass unemployment did not occur because the new private firms created 2 million new jobs within two years. Poland was importing more, but now it could be paid for. Its imports and hard currency exports doubled between 1989 and 1993, and many of the exports were items such as consumer appliances—something that no one had predicted. Geography—Poland’s being close to Germany and the rest of Europe—and freedom to trade turned out to be much more valuable assets than had been anticipated. The most extraordinary outcome of all was Poland’s overall performance—economic growth averaging 6 percent a year since 1994. People started to talk about Poland not as a basket case but as Europe’s “new tiger.”

到那时，团结工会已失去了往日的光辉，这既是由于内部激烈的权力斗争，也是由于休克疗法带来的社会不满。尽管如此，当昔日的共产党人亚历山大·克瓦希涅夫斯基在1995年击败瓦文萨当选波兰总统时，克瓦希涅夫斯基明确表示，他无意改变波兰的经济路线。瓦文萨因在自由选举中落败而愤懑离任。然而，他也应该感到由衷的欣慰。他的勇气和信念起到了决定性的作用。在如此短的时间内，他取得了如此巨大的成就。在1997年的议会选举中，团结工会成为联合政府的领导者。新任财政部长是莱谢克·巴尔采罗维奇，他曾为波兰的市场革命撰写剧本。5

By that time, Solidarity had lost much of its luster, owing both to acrimonious infighting and the social discontent that came with shock therapy. Still, when the former Communist Alexsander Kwasniewski defeated Walesa for president of Poland in 1995, Kwasniewski made clear that he had no intention of diverting Poland from its economic course. Walesa departed from office embittered by his defeat in a free election. Yet he also owed himself a great measure of satisfaction. His courage and conviction had been decisive. And so much had been achieved in so little time. In the 1997 parliamentary election, Solidarity emerged the leader of a coalition government. The new finance minister was Leszek Balcerowicz, who had written the script for Poland’s market revolution.5

两个瓦茨拉夫

The Two Václavs

捷克斯洛伐克被认为是威尔逊民族决心在第一次世界大战后凡尔赛会议的版图构建中取得的最伟大成就之一。它将奥匈帝国境内两个语言相近但文化迥异的斯拉夫民族——捷克人和斯洛伐克人——融合为一个新国家。尽管人们曾寄予厚望，但其历史却充满坎坷。1938年慕尼黑会议后，捷克斯洛伐克被肢解；二战期间，它又遭到纳粹的残酷占领；在1948年再次落入共产党之手前，它仅维持了三年的独立。1968年，苏联坦克粉碎了亚历山大·杜布切克领导的建立“人道社会主义”的努力。最终，在共产党夺取政权四十年后的1989年，持不同政见者成功地实现了相对平稳的民主过渡。这场革命是在作家瓦茨拉夫·哈维尔的指导下进行的——哈维尔在共产主义统治下被监禁——他为后来被称为天鹅绒革命的运动提供了道德权威和愿景。

Czechoslovakia was considered one of the greatest achievements of Wilsonian national determination to emerge from the mapmaking at the Versailles conference after World War I. It fused two linguistically similar but culturally different Slavic populations of the Austro-Hungarian Empire—the Czechs and the Slovaks—into a new state. Despite the high hopes, its history proved mostly unhappy. Dismembered at Munich in 1938 and then brutally occupied by the Nazis during World War II, it managed only three years of independence before falling under communist control in 1948. In 1968, Soviet tanks crushed the effort led by Alexander Dubcek to create a “socialism with a human face.” Finally, in 1989, four decades after the communists seized control, dissidents succeeded in implementing a relatively smooth transition to democracy. It was carried out under the tutelage of the writer Václav Havel—imprisoned under communism—who provided the moral authority and vision for what became known as the Velvet Revolution.

然而，事实证明，捷克人和斯洛伐克人并不热衷于维持凡尔赛缔结的婚姻。在尝试了不受欢迎的“双重家庭”模式后，1992年天鹅绒革命后，两国友好分手，史称“天鹅绒离婚”。斯洛伐克由于充斥着效率低下的军事导向型国有企业，变革步伐缓慢。但捷克共和国，作为原斯洛伐克共和国中地理位置更西、经济更发达的地区，在两位瓦茨拉夫——总统哈维尔和总理克劳斯——的领导下，迅速转向市场经济。如果说哈维尔是原则和民主价值观的化身，那么克劳斯则是经济变革的幕后推手。他领导的改革使捷克共和国迅速成为经济成功的典范。然而，他也因此有时受到哈维尔的批评，认为他没有充分考虑休克疗法带来的社会成本。

As it turned out, however, the Czechs and Slovaks had no great desire to maintain the marriage made at Versailles. After experimenting with an unpopular “dual household,” they followed the Velvet Revolution in 1992 with the amiable separation of a Velvet Divorce. Slovakia, with its preponderance of inefficient military-oriented state enterprises, would prove slow to change. But the Czech Republic, the geographically more western and economically more advanced part of the former nation, turned swiftly to the market under the aegis of the two Václavs—President Havel and Prime Minister Klaus. If Havel was the embodiment of principle and democratic values, Klaus was the man responsible for what happened economically. He led the reforms that rapidly turned the Czech Republic into an economic success story. He also found himself sometimes criticized by Havel for not giving enough consideration to the social costs of shock therapy.

套用一句老话，瓦茨拉夫·克劳斯就像是从守林人变成了偷猎者。作为最强硬的共产主义政权之一的经济学家，他受命于上司，肩负着“知己知彼”的重任——阅读、分析并掌握哈耶克和弗里德曼等市场自由主义的危险倡导者的思想。问题在于，他越是研究他们的著作，就越觉得他们的观点极具说服力。在思想的交锋中，他经历了一场“战场式”的转变。“我为自己感到骄傲，”他曾说过，“即使在共产主义的黑暗时期，我也被指责为弗里德曼主义者和芝加哥大学主义者。”他甚至写了一篇题为《芝加哥大学与我》的文章。1991年1月，在波兰实施休克疗法整整一年后，他推出了捷克版的休克疗法，而自由主义思想正是他政策的指导原则。在克劳斯看来，别无选择。在转型现实面前，关于休克疗法和渐进主义的争论既不相关也不现实。“这种选择并不存在，因为政府对转型的控制力不如以往。”“他们会仔细考虑速度，”他解释说。“我们知道的是，他们越是放慢转型的脚步，代价就越高，过程就越痛苦。”6

Václav Klaus was, to turn around an old phrase, gamekeeper turned poacher. As an economist in one of the hardest of hard-line communist regimes, he had been entrusted by his bosses with the critical responsibility to “know the enemy”—to read, analyze, and master such dangerous advocates of market liberalism as Hayek and Friedman. The problem was that the more he studied their work, the more persuasive and convincing he found them. Amid the war of ideas, he underwent a battlefield conversion. “I am proud,” he once said, “of having been … accused of being a Friedmanite and a Chicagoan, even in the dark days of communism.” He even wrote an essay entitled “The University of Chicago and I.” Liberal ideas governed his policies when he launched the Czech version of shock therapy in January 1991, exactly one year after Poland’s. As far as Klaus was concerned, there was no alternative. The debate between shock therapy and gradualism was irrelevant and unrealistic when it came to the realities of transition. “Such a choice doesn’t exist, because governments don’t have as much control as they think over the speed,” he explained. “What we do know is that the more they put brakes on the transformation, the more costly and painful it will be.”6

捷克的方案与波兰的方案类似：立即放开大部分物价，实行货币自由兑换和贬值（捷克还同时征收进口附加费以提供一定程度的保护），并实施紧缩的货币政策。其效果与波兰大致相同——起初通货膨胀剧烈波动，随后迅速稳定下来，之后经济强劲增长。然而，两国之间存在一个显著差异。捷克采取了快速而大规模的私有化政策，其前提是与其等待结构调整或完善的法律和制度框架，不如将财产转移到私人手中。早在1990年，一些财产就已归还给那些在20世纪40年代末共产党掌权时被没收的民众。政府尝试了多种私有化措施，其中最著名的是代金券制度。政府向所有年满18岁的公民出售代金券。这些凭证既可以用于直接购买公司股票，也可以通过凭证基金进行间接购买。

The Czech program followed along the lines of Poland’s: immediate freeing of most prices, currency convertibility and devaluation (combined, in this case, with import surcharges to provide some protection), and tight monetary policies. The effects were much the same as in Poland—a great burst of inflation to begin with, and then a quick settling down, followed by strong economic growth. There was, however, one outstanding difference between the two countries. The Czech Republic went for quick and massive privatization, on the premise that it was better to get property into private hands than wait for restructuring or a fully developed legal and institutional framework. As early as 1990, some property was returned to the people from whom it had been confiscated when the Communists came to power in the late 1940s. The government experimented with a variety of privatization measures. The best known was a voucher system. Books of vouchers were sold to all citizens over the age of eighteen who wanted them. These vouchers, in turn, could be used either for direct purchase of shares in companies or for indirect purchases through voucher funds.

诚然，捷克共和国在进入“市场革命”时拥有一些显著优势。尽管曾经历过共产主义时期，但它仍然是一个拥有深厚商业传统和西方历史渊源的国家。有人认为，在二战前夕，捷克的技术水平甚至高于德国。因此，它重返市场经济的过程相对顺利。

To be sure, the Czech Republic went into its “market revolution” with certain decided strengths. Its experience under communism notwithstanding, it was a country with a strong mercantile tradition and a historic orientation to the West. Some argue that on the eve of World War II it was more technologically advanced than Germany. It had relatively little trouble returning to the market.

苏联计划经济

The Soviet Command Economy

在苏联体制下，政府与市场之间不存在明显的冲突，原因很简单——因为至少在官方层面上，根本不存在市场。20世纪20年代，共产党曾尝试实行混合经济，允许农业和小企业私有，但前提是国家必须掌握绝对的控制权（列宁的格言）。然而，这种做法失败了。物资短缺蔓延，托洛茨基的追随者与斯大林和布哈林的追随者之间也爆发了激烈的相互指责。随着斯大林权力的崛起，他对经济和政治生活都进行了严厉的管控。他将生产国有化，并在20世纪20年代末，随着第一个五年计划的启动，“计划经济”由此诞生。

In the Soviet system, there was no obvious battle between government and market for a very simple reason—because there was, at least officially, no market. In the 1920s the communists had tried to run a mixed economy, permitting private ownership in agriculture and small business so long as the state held the commanding heights (Lenin’s dictum). It did not work. Shortages spread, as did recriminations between the followers of Trotsky and those of Stalin and Bukharin. As Stalin rose to power, he clamped down on both economic and political life. He nationalized production, and by the end of the 1920s, with the initiation of the first five-year plan, the “command economy” was born.

在计划经济体制下，供求关系无关紧要，甚至被弃之不顾。资源分配并非基于数千万个体的选择（而这些选择恰恰构成了供求关系），而是由官僚机构的决策决定。真正重要的是政治领导人的偏好和目标，并通过中央计划机制加以实施。中央是一系列政府机构，它们共同制定了整个经济体系。系统运作。这些机构的名称都以“gos”开头，这是俄语中“政府”一词的缩写。国家计划委员会（Gosplan）负责制定计划，国家价格委员会（Gosten）负责定价，国家物资分配委员会（Gossnab）负责分配物资。劳动和工资政策则由国家统计局（Gostrud）负责。在共产党的协调下，莫斯科各部委负责所有关键决策——企业生产什么产品、原材料从哪里采购、原材料成本是多少、客户是谁以及产品售价是多少。他们还决定企业雇佣多少员工、员工工资是多少以及进行哪些投资。实际上，计划制定过程还涉及与企业管理者以及地方党政官员的大量谈判。

In the command economy, supply and demand were irrelevant; they were exiled. Resources were allocated by bureaucratic decision rather than by the tens of millions of individual choices that add up to supply and demand. What mattered were the preferences and goals of the political leaders, which were implemented through the mechanisms of central planning. At the center was a series of government agencies that made the whole system work. Their names all began with gos, which is an abbreviation of the Russian word for government. Gosplan determined the plan, while Gosten set prices and Gossnab allocated supplies. Labor and wage policies belonged to Gostrud. With the coordination of the Communist Party, the ministries in Moscow were responsible for all the critical decisions—what a firm would produce, where its supplies would come from, what those supplies would cost, who the customers would be, and what the price to the customers would be. They also decided the number of people who would work in the enterprise, what they would be paid, and what kind of investments would be made. In practice, the process of planning also involved a lot of negotiations with enterprise managers and local party and government officials.

盈利能力和效率等经济指标并非苏联体制的考量因素。真正重要的是“完成计划”——或者至少要让外界认为完成了计划。石油钻探者并非以经济合理的价格发现石油来评判，而是以钻井深度来衡量。从20世纪30年代到70年代，这套体制在世界范围内享有极高的声望，因为它被认为在快速工业化和高增长率方面取得了显著成效。资源的高度集中确实带来了高速增长，使苏联从农业转向工业化——尤其是在军工复合体领域，其扩张和技术实力曾令约翰·F·肯尼迪那一代人感到震惊。但这种集中也导致了农业、服务业和消费品行业的忽视。它还使体制变得极其僵化，滋生了各种低效现象。这套体制变得更加复杂和非理性。它在 20 世纪 50 年代和 60 年代取得的表面成功的关键，从长远来看，也成为了它走向衰落的根源。

The economic tests of profitability and efficiency were not part of the Soviet system. What really mattered was “fulfilling the plan”—or at least being seen as fulfilling the plan. Oil drillers were not judged on whether they found oil at some economically sensible price; they were judged by how many feet they drilled. From the 1930s into the 1970s, this system enjoyed immense prestige around the world, for it was seen to be delivering the goods in terms of rapid industrialization and high growth rates. The draconian concentration of resources did deliver high growth as it moved the Soviet Union from agriculture to industrialization—most spectacularly in the military-industrial complex, whose expansion and technical prowess had so alarmed John F. Kennedy’s generation. But that concentration spelled neglect for agriculture, services, and consumer goods. It also imposed extreme rigidity on the system, breeding inefficiency of all sorts. The system became even more complicated and irrational. The key to its apparent success in the 1950s and 1960s also proved, over the long term, to be the source of its downfall.

某些市场确实存在于体制边缘，隐于幕后，但它们在润滑整个体系、使其运转方面发挥着至关重要的作用。只有极少一部分可耕种的农地可供私人耕种。尽管国家不情愿，但最终还是正式批准了这些私人农地——而且这的确是一件好事。虽然与国营农场和集体农场相比，这些私人农地面积小得可怜，但它们却至关重要，生产了超过25%的肉类和高达50%的土豆。黑市则没有得到这样的官方认可。黑市经营者被斥为“社会寄生虫”，有时甚至被投入监狱。然而，黑市对城市生活同样不可或缺。商店里买不到鸡。但如果你想吃鸡，只要认识“街角那个人”，就可以在黑市上买到——而很多人都认识这个人。

Certain markets did exist on the fringes of the system, in the shadows, but they had a crucial role in lubricating the entire system and actually enabling it to work. A tiny proportion of arable agricultural land was available for private farming plots. However reluctantly, the state officially sanctioned these private plots—and a good thing, too. Although postage stamp-size by comparison to the state and collective farms, they proved essential, producing over 25 percent of the meat and up to 50 percent of the potatoes. No such official sanction existed for the black market. Its operators were denounced as “social parasites,” and were sometimes imprisoned. Yet it, too, was essential to urban life. There were no chickens in the stores. But if you wanted a chicken for dinner, you could buy it on the black market if you knew “the man on the corner”—and many people did.

斯大林时期发展起来并由其继任者推行的计划经济体制确实有其目的。尽管口口声声说着要改善人民的福祉和生活水平，但事实并非如此；它的存在是为了促进快速工业化，从而为军工复合体提供养分。国家国民生产总值的很大一部分都集中在这一领域。整体经济都屈从于其自身需求。当苏联卫星绕地球运行，核潜艇在海洋中巡游时，这套体系所提供的生活水平远低于大多数人的想象——在20世纪80年代，其水平甚至只有西方的十分之一。

The command economy, as developed under Stalin and operated by his successors, did have a purpose. It was not, despite all the rhetoric, about the well-being and standard of living of the people; rather, it existed to promote rapid industrialization with which to feed the military-industrial complex. An enormous part of the country’s GNP was concentrated in that sector, and the overall economy was subordinated to its needs. While Soviet satellites circled the earth and the country’s nuclear submarines prowled the seas, the system delivered a standard of living much lower than most people understood—in the 1980s, a level as low as one tenth the West’s.

早在20世纪70年代初，苏联体制的一个致命缺陷就已显露：它基本上无法创新。创新没有回报，也没有动力去做任何新的事情。事实上，苏联社会强烈倾向于避免任何形式的变革，因为变革会带来巨大的官僚主义麻烦。最好的办法就是墨守成规。在更发达的经济体中，创新是促进经济增长的关键。但在苏联体制下，创新的主要特征就是缺乏创新。这种情况适用于所有领域——无论是改进流程的小改动，还是推出新产品。唯一的例外是部分军事领域。投资的整体分配也存在僵化。年复一年，巨额资金投入灌溉工程——是通信工程投入的二十倍。 “二十年来，这个巨大的灌溉工程并没有给收成带来明显的改善，”俄罗斯经济学家叶戈尔·盖达尔说，“但是，哪怕是小幅削减这项投资也是完全不可能的，因为一年前、两年前、五年前、十年前都是这么做的。”

Already by the early 1970s, a fatal weakness was becoming clear in the system: It could not, for the most part, innovate. There was no reward, no reason to do anything new. In fact, there was a strong predisposition to avoid change of any kind, for change caused enormous bureaucratic headaches. The best thing was to keep doing what had been done before. In more advanced economies, innovation was essential to the promotion of economic growth. But in the Soviet system innovation was characterized mainly by its absence. And that applied to everything—whether it was small changes to make processes work better or the introduction of new products. The only exception was in parts of the military sector. Rigidity also applied to the overall distribution of investment. Year after year, vast amounts of money went into irrigation projects—twenty times as much as went into communications. “For twenty years there was no visible improvement in the harvest as a result of this huge irrigation project,” said the Russian economist Yegor Gaidar, “but it was completely out of the question to reduce, even by a small amount, this investment because this was how it had been done a year ago, two years ago, five years ago, and ten years ago.”

经济增长率骤降。这套体系曾经凭借蛮力促进经济增长，但如今其僵化却阻碍了增长。西方技术被引进，但正如在波兰一样，无法得到有效应用。很大一部分技术最终锈蚀殆尽。曾经推动经济增长的体系如今正走向自我毁灭。然而就在此时，如同希腊悲剧中的“天降神兵”一般，一位救世主出现了——但事实证明，这只是暂时的。这位救世主是西伯利亚蕴藏的丰富石油资源，这些资源在20世纪60年代末被发现并开始开发。1973-74年，第一次石油危机导致石油价格翻了四倍，这些石油的价值也随之大幅提升。作为世界主要石油出口国之一的苏联从中获益匪浅。石油和天然气出口带来的巨额外汇收入，为维持这套摇摇欲坠的体系运转提供了至关重要的财政资源，而无需进行改革或挪用军工复合体的资源。 “这使得人们有长达十五年的时间不必去想这场危机，”叶戈尔·盖达尔说。7

The growth rate plummeted. The system had been able to promote growth by brute force, but now its rigidity was preventing growth. Western technology was being imported, but as in Poland, it could not be applied very effectively. A good part of it simply rusted away. The system that had driven economic growth was now in the process of destroying itself. Yet just then, like the deus ex machina in a Greek tragedy, a savior appeared—but as it turned out, it was only on temporary assignment. It took the form of the vast oil resources in west Siberia, which were discovered and initially developed in the late 1960s. This oil became much more valuable in 1973-74, when the first oil crisis led to a quadrupling of petroleum prices. The Soviet Union, as one of the world’s major petroleum exporters, benefited mightily. The enormous increase in hard currency earnings, from oil and then gas exports, provided the critical financial resources to keep the failing system going without forcing reforms or diversion of resources from the military-industrial complex. “It created the ability not to think about the crisis for a decade and a half,” said Yegor Gaidar.7

刺猬与蛇的婚姻

The Marriage of the Hedgehog and the Snake

20世纪80年代初，苏联领导人——勃列日涅夫、安德罗波夫和契尔年科——相继上台，这些年迈的领导人恰如其分地象征着苏联经济体系的衰落。直到1985年，一位更年轻、更有活力的领导人——戈尔巴乔夫——上台执政，苏联经济才开始出现转机。领导层愿意认真思考这场危机。戈尔巴乔夫上任后决心推进改革。正如他自己所说，他深受赫鲁晓夫1956年在苏共二十大上发表的秘密讲话的影响，赫鲁晓夫的讲话谴责了斯大林和斯大林主义。他希望实现亚历山大·杜布切克近二十年前在捷克斯洛伐克尝试的：一种有人情味的社会主义。戈尔巴乔夫启动了改革（perestroika） ——即结构调整——以及后来被称为“公开性”（glasnost）的政策。后者包括对斯大林主义历史的公开，而随后的揭露进一步削弱了该体制的合法性和公信力。戈尔巴乔夫想要改革社会主义，使其运转起来，尽管他和他的团队对于如何将中央计划经济与市场经济、多党民主制与共产党相结合并没有清晰的思路。他的死敌鲍里斯·叶利钦后来将戈尔巴乔夫的错误描述为想要“将不能结合的东西结合起来——就像让刺猬和草蛇结婚一样”。

The succession of geriatric Soviet leaders in the early 1980s—Leonid Brezhnev, Yuri Andropov, and Konstantin Chernenko—was a fitting symbol for an economic system in advanced decline. It was only in 1985, when a younger, dynamic leader—Mikhail Gorbachev—assumed power that the leadership was willing to think about the crisis. Gorbachev came in intent on promoting reform. He was a child, as he described himself, of Nikita Khrushchev’s 1956 secret speech to the 20th Party Congress denouncing Stalin and Stalinism, and he wanted to implement what Alexander Dubcek had attempted almost two decades earlier in Czechoslovakia: socialism with a human face. Gorbachev initiated perestroika—restructuring—and what became known as glasnost—openness. That latter included an openness about the Stalinist past, and the subsequent revelations helped undermine the legitimacy and credibility of the system. Gorbachev wanted to reform socialism, to make it work, although he and those around him had no clear idea about how to merge central planning with the market economy or multiparty democracy with the Communist Party. His nemesis, Boris Yeltsin, would later describe Gorbachev’s error as wanting “to combine things that cannot be combined—to marry a hedgehog and a grass snake.”

戈尔巴乔夫上台后不久，严重的经济危机变得更加严峻。1986年，油价暴跌，切断了德国硬通货的重要生命线，而此时，德国与美国之间代价高昂的军事技术竞争也愈演愈烈。戈尔巴乔夫意识到危机，采取了一系列重要措施，为市场经济奠定了基础。他赋予工厂和其他企业的管理者更大的自主权，此前他们一直受到计划的束缚。他还对私营企业给予了一定的认可，特别是1988年的一项法律，该法律将拥有三个或三个以上所有者的公司合法化，并将其视为“合作社”。这为许多人打开了一扇门，许多类型的企业——从举重器材制造商到餐馆再到银行——都是基于这项法律建立起来的。“合作社”实际上只是掩盖其私营企业的幌子。

The severe economic crisis became much more acute just after Gorbachev-took over. Oil prices collapsed in 1986, severing a major part of the hard-currency lifeline at a time when the costly military-technical competition with the United States had intensified. Recognizing the crisis, Gorbachev took important steps that helped create a foundation for a market economy. He gave much more independence to directors of factories and other enterprises, who had previously been straitjacketed by the plan. And he gave some sanction to private firms, particularly with a 1988 law that legalized any company with three or more owners, counting it as a “cooperative.” That was a door through which many people passed, and it was on the basis of this law that many types of enterprises—from manufacturers of weight-lifting equipment to restaurants to banks—were first built. “Cooperatives” proved to be a fig leaf for what were, in reality, private businesses.

然而，总体而言，戈尔巴乔夫改革旧经济体制的努力失败了。他拆除了中央计划的机器，包括曾经协调这一复杂体系的共产党的主导地位。但他没有用任何东西来取代它。没有任何东西能够维系各个部门的正常运转。他发起了一场声势浩大的禁酒运动，试图遏制当时社会普遍存在的酗酒问题。但酒精和其他酒类的税收是国家的主要财政收入来源之一，这场运动最终导致国家损失了大量资金，却并未对国民的节制饮酒做出显著贡献。消费品进口的减少降低了人们的工作积极性，而增加的设备进口要么利用率低下，要么根本就没用上。通货膨胀和物资短缺现象十分明显；就连洗涤剂和勺子这类简单的生活用品都出现了短缺。商店里的货架越来越空；店外的队伍越来越长。在炎热的夏日，甚至连冰淇淋都买不到。

Overall, however, Gorbachev’s efforts to reform the old economic system failed. He dismantled the machinery of central planning, including the dominating position of the Communist Party, which had coordinated the complex system. But he did not replace it with anything. There was nothing left to keep the parts working together. He launched a vigorous anti-alcohol campaign to try to stem the endemic alcoholism that crippled the society. But the tax on alcohol and other liquors was one of the state’s major sources of revenue, and the campaign ended up depriving the state of a great deal of money without contributing notably to national sobriety. The reduction in imports of consumer goods reduced work incentives, while the increased imports of equipment were either poorly used or not put to work at all. Inflation and shortages were much evident; there were now shortages even of simple things like detergent and spoons. The shelves in the shops became more and more empty; the lines outside them grew longer and longer. On warm days in the summer, there was no ice cream.

与此同时，经济的工业部门仍然极度不合理、效率低下、浪费严重且污染环境——其程度几乎令人难以置信。苏联造纸业花费的时间是其他行业的七倍。生产一吨纸张所需的木材比芬兰造纸业消耗的木材还要多。当时的定价体系简直荒谬至极。瑞典经济学家安德斯·阿斯隆德列举了一些最令人震惊的例子：由于价格管制，一吨石油——在国际市场上价值约150美元——换算成卢布的价格，几乎只相当于一包万宝路香烟的自由市场价格。从符拉迪沃斯托克到莫斯科——距离四千英里，跨越六个时区——的机票管制价格是七美元。但从莫斯科机场打车到红场附近的酒店却要花十美元。8

Meanwhile, the industrial sector of the economy continued to be enormously irrational, inefficient, wasteful, and polluting—to an extent that was almost incomprehensible. It took the Soviet paper industry seven times more timber to make a ton of paper than it took the Finnish industry. The price system was truly lunatic. The Swedish economist Anders Aslund catalogued some of the most stunning examples: Because of price controls, a ton of oil—worth about $150 on the world market—was worth about as much in rubles as the free-market price of exactly one pack of Marlboro cigarettes. The regulated cost of an airfare from Vladivostok to Moscow—a distance of four thousand miles, over six time zones—was seven dollars. But it cost ten dollars to take a taxi from Moscow’s airport to a hotel near Red Square.8

做市

Market Making

现在的核心问题只有一个：如何从一个没有市场的体系过渡到一个市场体系。这种转型没有现成的方案，没有现成的指南，只有波兰和捷克等国仍在摸索中积累的经验教训。但各国之间存在差异。波兰有4000万人口；捷克有1000万人口。而苏联拥有近3亿人口，是一个核超级大国。此前从未有人面临过苏联局势的规模和紧迫性。

There was one central question now: how to move from a system in which there was no market to a market system. There were no recipes, no cookbooks for this transition, only the lessons and experience still being accumulated—very much on the run—in countries like Poland and the Czech Republic. But there were differences. Poland had 40 million people; the Czech Republic, 10 million. The Soviet Union, almost 300 million people strong, was a nuclear superpower. No one had ever faced the scale and the urgency of the Soviet situation.

这就是马克思主义和斯大林主义的遗毒：直到20世纪90年代初，苏联及其直接继承者俄罗斯联邦都未具备市场经济体系的任何基本条件。既没有价格机制来传递供求信息，也没有任何规则——无论是规范还是法律——来指导市场行为。当然，更没有合同制度或私有财产权。所有这一切都必须从零开始——而且几乎是在一夜之间——建立起来。在当时，这似乎是一项几乎不可能完成的任务——而且没有任何可以借鉴的先例。

Such was the legacy of Marxism and Stalinism that right up to the beginning of the 1990s, not one of the fundamental conditions for a market system existed in the Soviet Union or its immediate successor, the Russian Federation. There was no price mechanism to convey information about supply and demand. Nor were there any of the rules of the game—neither norms nor laws—to guide behavior in the marketplace. And there certainly was no system of contracts or private property rights. All this had to be built from scratch—and almost overnight. At the time, it seemed an almost impossible job—and there was no laboratory in which to practice.

还能向谁求助？戈尔巴乔夫时代的经济学家们陷入了进退两难的境地：一边是计划经济体制的糟糕遗产，另一边是某种形式的市场经济。然而，年轻的经济学家们却准备进行更为激进的思考，尤其是那些聚集在莫斯科系统分析研究所和中央数理经济研究所，以及列宁格勒（今圣彼得堡）一个规模较小、更为非正式的网络中的经济学家们。他们曾前往西方考察；他们能够接触到图书馆“特殊许可区”（spetskhran）中收藏的西方经济文献。他们的外语水平足以阅读西方作家的作品。同时，他们也对自己的体制抱有极大的怀疑。

To whom to turn? The Gorbachev-era economists were trapped in a no-man’s-land between the dismal inheritance of a command economy on the one side and some kind of market economy on the other. Younger economists, however, were prepared to think more radically, in particular those grouped around the Institute for System Analysis and the Central Mathematical Economics Institute, both in Moscow, and a smaller, more informal network in Leningrad (now St. Petersburg). They had traveled to the West; they had been able to gain access to Western economic literature held in the spetskhran, the classified area in libraries that required special permission. They knew foreign languages well enough to read the Western writers. They had also become very cynical about their own system.

其中一位名叫安德烈·科诺普利亚尼克的人，人生的转折点出现在他的博士论文中。他曾是一名非常优秀且充满活力的少先队员和青年共产主义者。20世纪70年代末，他撰写了一篇关于北海石油经济学的博士论文。他的导师坚持要求他以一段引自马克思和恩格斯的经典论述作为论文的开篇，并展开论述。与北海石油相关。可惜的是，马克思和恩格斯去世时，北海石油尚未被发现，他们早已作古。尽管如此，科诺普利亚尼克意识到这是迫不得已的事，便找到了一句引语。但这还不够。他的导师在阅读了他的论文终稿后，告诉他犯了一个非常严重的错误——一个不可接受的错误。他竟然没有引用当时备受尊敬的领导人勃列日涅夫的话。但科诺普利亚尼克坚持认为，勃列日涅夫肯定从未说过任何与北海石油相关的有价值的话。导师没有与他争论，而是迅速抽出笔，在论文草稿中写下了勃列日涅夫那部杰出理论著作中的一段引文，作为整篇论文的理论基础。从此以后，科诺普利亚尼克再也无法认真对待马克思列宁主义。他成为了所谓“体制内异议者”群体的一员。

The turning point for one of them, Andrey Konoplyanik, came with his dissertation. He had been a very good and energetic Young Pioneer and Young Communist. In the late 1970s, he wrote a doctoral dissertation on the economics of North Sea oil. His adviser insisted that he begin the thesis with a learned quote and disquisition of Marx and Engel’s views that would be relevant to North Sea oil. Alas, Marx and Engels had died many, many decades before the discovery of North Sea oil. Nevertheless, realizing that necessity was necessity, Konoplyanik found a quote. That was not enough. His adviser, reading the final draft of his dissertation, told him that he had made a very major mistake—an unacceptable mistake. He had failed to quote the then-glorious leader Leonid Brezhnev. But, insisted Konoplyanik, Brezhnev most assuredly had never said anything of value and relevance to North Sea oil. Instead of arguing, the adviser whipped out his pen and wrote into the draft dissertation a citation from the brilliant theoretical work of Leonid Brezhnev, meant to serve as the intellectual underpinning of the entire thesis. Thereafter, Konoplyanik could never take Marxism-Leninism seriously. He became part of a cohort of what might be called establishment dissenters.

在这一代新一代经济学家中，叶戈尔·盖达尔最为杰出，他为推动俄罗斯走向市场经济做出了巨大贡献。但从某种意义上说，他也是过去的一部分。“我们家族的命运就是与二十世纪俄罗斯的悲剧如此紧密地交织在一起，”一天下午，他坐在莫斯科郊外公寓里那间铺着木板的长书房里说道。盖达尔出身于十月革命的先驱家族之一，因此，他最终参与推翻祖父曾参与创建、祖父又在其中占据着传奇地位的体制，这本身就极具讽刺意味。“我的祖父阿尔卡季·盖达尔是社会主义时代共产主义最伟大的英雄之一，”他说，“他是我们历史上最著名的人物之一。”

Among the most prominent of this new generation of economists was Yegor Gaidar, who would do as much as anybody to move Russia toward a market economy. But he was also very much part of the past, in a peculiar way. “It’s our family’s fate to be so completely intertwined in the tragedy of Russia in the twentieth century,” he said one afternoon, sitting in the long, wood-paneled study of his apartment on the edge of Moscow. Gaidar belonged to one of the first families of the October Revolution, and thus it was a special irony that he would help bring down the very system that his grandfather had helped create—and in which his grandfather held a mythic place. “My grandfather Arkady Gaidar was one of the biggest heroes of communism of the socialist era,” he said. “He was one of the most famous people in our history.”

阿尔卡季·盖达尔十四岁就投身革命。十七岁时，他已是内战中一支红军团的指挥官。随着时间的推移，他被奉为楷模，其勇气和胆识广受赞誉。在两次世界大战之间的年代，他作为全国最受爱戴的儿童文学作家之一，声名鹊起。他是共产主义思想的典范。他于1941年去世，比叶戈尔·盖达尔出生早十五年。但叶戈尔在祖父的影响和光环下长大。“我努力学习，争取在学校赢得金牌，就是为了不听到别人说我没能像祖父阿尔卡季·盖达尔那样出色。”

Arkady Gaidar joined the revolution at the age of fourteen. By the time he was seventeen, he was commander of a Red regiment in the civil war. In time, he was held up as a role model and much celebrated for his courage and bravery. In the interwar years, he achieved even more fame as one of the nation’s most beloved writers of children’s books. He was a paragon of communist ideology. He died in 1941, fifteen years before Yegor Gaidar was born. But Yegor grew up under his grandfather’s influence and shadow. “I worked hard to win gold medals at school just so I would not have to hear that I was not living up to my grandfather Arkady Gaidar.”

叶戈尔·盖达尔出身于这样的家庭，他本人也很快成为了一名优秀的共产主义者。他的父亲是一名记者，卡斯特罗革命初期，他们一家住在哈瓦那。“那仍然是一场令人欣喜的革命，对一个男孩来说，那是一件非常棒的事情，”他回忆道，“切·格瓦拉会来我们家，我亲眼目睹了我们的国家在保卫全世界善良的人们，对抗美国帝国主义。” 1968年苏联入侵捷克斯洛伐克，让他开始对共产主义产生怀疑。“我有很多捷克朋友，我和他们交谈过，但官方对事件的解释简直令人难以置信。” 他的父亲在某种程度上算是自由主义者，至少在共产主义的框架下是如此。在家人围坐在餐桌旁时，年轻的盖达尔经常听父亲和父亲的朋友们谈论这件事。关于匈牙利改革、关于炖牛肉社会主义，以及关于赫鲁晓夫在 1956 年秘密讲话中揭露的斯大林的罪行。

With such a pedigree, Yegor Gaidar started out to be a very good communist himself. His father was a journalist, and the family was living in Havana during the first years of Castro’s revolution. “It was still a very happy revolution, and it was a splendid thing for a boy,” he said. “Che Guevara would come to our house, and I saw our country defending all good people in the world against American imperialism.” His first doubts came with the Soviet Union’s invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968. “I had a lot of Czech friends, and I talked with them, and the official explanation of what had happened was impossible to believe.” His father was something of a liberal, at least within communist terms, and around the family’s kitchen table, the young Gaidar listened to his father and his father’s friends talk about the Hungarian reforms, about goulash socialism, and about what Khrushchev had revealed about Stalin’s crimes in his 1956 secret speech.

但盖达尔人生的关键转折点或许出现在他全家搬到贝尔格莱德之后，当时贝尔格莱德是统一的南斯拉夫的首都。共产党领导人铁托元帅领导着一个在辩论和与西方接触方面相对开放的社会。盖达尔对市场社会主义的讨论尤为感兴趣，当时南斯拉夫和匈牙利都在以各种形式推行市场社会主义。回到莫斯科后，他加入了一群学生和年轻教授的行列，他们至少在20世纪70年代末和80年代初认为，市场社会主义是解决之道，苏联可以变得更加开放，就像匈牙利那样——一种将国家控制和所有制与私人决策和部分私有财产相结合的经济体制。然而，即使是这种观点也被认为是非常激进的。1986年，一位老一辈的苏联经济学家请一位西方访客离开他的办公室，走到街上，以便他可以告诉他一个秘密，而不用担心被窃听器窃听。这个秘密是什么呢？苏联比匈牙利大得多，匈牙利的经济模式不能应用于苏联，甚至考虑将两者进行比较都是冒犯性的。

But perhaps the key turning point for Gaidar came when his family moved to Belgrade, then the capital of united Yugoslavia. The Communist leader, Marshal Tito, presided over a somewhat more open society in terms of debate and contacts with the West. Gaidar was particularly interested in the discussions about market socialism, which was then being applied in various forms in both Yugoslavia and Hungary. Returning to Moscow, he became part of a group of students and young professors who, at least in the late 1970s and early 1980s, thought that market socialism was the answer, that the Soviet Union could become more open, like the Hungarian system—an economy that mixed state control and ownership with private decision making and some private property. Yet even that was considered very radical. In 1986, a Soviet economist of the older generation asked a Western visitor to leave his office and walk down the street so that he could tell him a secret without the risk of being overhead by bugs. The secret? That the Soviet Union was much bigger than Hungary, that the Hungarian economic model could not be applied to the Soviet Union, and that it was offensive even to consider making the comparison.

然而，此时年轻一代的经济学家却得出了一个更为惊人的结论——即使是市场社会主义也行不通。这样的制度既无法解决工资、失业和资本流动等实际问题，也不允许私有财产的产生。

By this time, however, the younger generation of economists was coming to an even more startling conclusion—that even market socialism could not work. Such a system could not deal with the meat-and-potatoes issues of wages, unemployment, and capital movements. Nor did it permit the creation of private property.

在所有这些问题上，他们都深受一位作家的影响，他就是匈牙利经济学家亚诺什·科尔奈，曾在布达佩斯和哈佛大学兼职任教。在世的经济学家中，只有科尔奈可以说影响了整整一代生活在共产主义制度下的人的思想。他细致入微地剖析了中央计划经济体制，揭示了其非理性和自我毁灭的本质。他还指出了其潜在变体——市场社会主义——的种种不足。“在20世纪80年代，他对我们所有人的影响最大，”盖达尔说道，“他专注于社会主义的实际运作机制。他在20世纪80年代初对短缺经济的分析对我们所有人都产生了深远的影响。他关注的正是我们面临的问题。他的著作我们都耳熟能详。”

On all these questions, they were tremendously influenced by one author, János Kornai, a Hungarian economist who taught part-time in Budapest and part-time at Harvard. The one living economist who could claim to have influenced the minds of a whole generation living under communism was Kornai. He meticulously dissected the centrally planned system and demonstrated its irrationality and self-destructiveness. He also demonstrated the inadequacies of its would-be variant, market socialism. “He was the most influential on all of us in the 1980s,” said Gaidar. “He focused on the practical mechanisms of socialism. His analysis of the economy of shortage, in the early 1980s, had a great impact on all of us. He was addressing our problems. We knew all his books.”

西方作家中还有哪些人有影响力？“当然还有哈耶克，”盖达尔回答说。“他对世界的描绘非常清晰且令人印象深刻，在某种程度上与马克思一样令人印象深刻。”9

Which among the Western writers were also influential? “Of course, Hayek,” Gaidar replied. “He gave a very clear and impressive picture of the world, as impressive as Marx in his way.”9

有序过渡？

An Orderly Transition?

这些年轻的经济学家开始思考比市场社会主义更大胆的方案：向市场经济转型，有序转型。但有序转型是否可能？这个问题永远不得而知，因为到了20世纪80年代末，经济体系已经陷入极度混乱，根本无法实施任何改革。经济正走向混乱和恶性通货膨胀。

These young economists began to think about something more daring than market socialism: a transition, an orderly transition, to a market economy. But was an orderly transition possible? That will never be known because by the very late 1980s, the system was in such distress that there was no way to implement one. The economy was headed toward chaos and hyperinflation.

从1989年底到1991年夏季，苏联推出了大约十五项重大经济计划，其中大部分都得到了采纳，但并未产生任何积极影响。最著名、影响最大的当属格里戈里·亚夫林斯基和其他经济学家制定的激进方案。该方案做到了当时其他方案都未曾做到的：它没有改革苏联的经济体制，而是主张以强制的速度将该体制转型为市场经济。它是苏联共产主义和资本主义之间的思想桥梁，并且深受当时波兰局势的影响。

Between the end of 1989 and the summer of 1991, some fifteen major economic programs were introduced, and most of them adopted, without any positive effect. The most famous and influential was the radical program developed by Grigori Yavlinsky and other economists. It did what no other plan did at that time: Instead of reforming the Soviet economic system, it advocated the system’s transformation, at forced pace, into a market economy. It was the intellectual bridge between communism and capitalism in the Soviet Union. And it was much influenced by what was already unfolding in Poland.

在所有东欧国家中，波兰及其变化对苏联的命运影响最为深远。波兰在苏联势力范围内具有特殊意义。它是东欧最大的国家，也是战略地位最为重要的国家。二战结束后，斯大林因企图控制波兰并将其纳入帝国版图而与盟友决裂。此后，波兰问题一直牵动着苏联军事策划者的心；它被视为潜在的入侵路线。正因如此，戈尔巴乔夫在1990年8月的电话——接受一个非共产主义政府——才显得意义重大。也正因如此，波兰的经济改革对苏联此后的发展产生了深远的影响。格里戈里·亚夫林斯基正是传递这一信息，并将其翻译成俄语的人。

Of all the countries in Eastern Europe, it was Poland—and the changes there—that would matter the most for what transpired in the Soviet Union. Poland was of special significance in the Soviet sphere. It was the largest of the Eastern European countries, and also the most strategically important. Stalin broke with his allies at the end of World War II over his bid to gain control of Poland and incorporate it into his empire. Poland preoccupied Soviet military planners thereafter; it was the potential invasion route. That was why Gorbachev’s phone call in August 1990—accepting a non-Communist government—was so significant. And that was why economic reforms in Poland were to have so great an impact on shaping what came soon after in the Soviet Union. Grigori Yavlinsky was the man who transported the message and, so to speak, translated it into Russian.

亚夫林斯基多年前就放弃了中央计划经济。在他看来，这种经济体制毫无意义，也无法改革。为了避免花费过多时间研读马克思和列宁的著作，他转行成为了一名劳动经济学家。然而，当他撰写了一份关于煤矿状况的批评性报告后，克格勃开始对他进行审讯和施压。他被威胁要开除出共产党——但这其实只是虚张声势，因为他根本就不是党员。之后，他被强行送进医院，接受了许多他根本没有的疾病的治疗。直到戈尔巴乔夫上台，这些治疗和迫害才停止。亚夫林斯基重操旧业，再次从事经济学家的工作。他最终在部长会议从事经济研究，并于1990年被派往波兰，正好赶上巴尔采罗维奇改革的实施。“那真是太神奇了。我永远不会忘记物价下跌的情景。对于经济学家来说，亲眼目睹物价的‘活’是极其罕见的。”他写了一份非常积极的报告——积极到令震惊的苏联大使拒绝寄出。亚夫林斯基设法将报告交给了戈尔巴乔夫的一位高级顾问，这位顾问又将报告转交给了戈尔巴乔夫，戈尔巴乔夫随后将报告分发给了中央委员会。

Yavlinsky had given up on the centrally planned economy years earlier. In his view, it was senseless and could not be fixed. In order to avoid spending inordinate time reading Marx and Lenin, he had become a labor economist. But when he did a critical report on conditions in coal mines, the KGB began to interrogate and pressure him. He was threatened with expulsion from the Communist Party—a rather hollow threat as he was not, in fact, a member. He then found himself hospitalized by force and subjected to many treatments for an ailment he did not have. The treatments and persecution stopped only when Gorbachev came to power. Yavlinsky was then back in business as an economist. He ended up doing economic research for the Council of Ministers and was dispatched to Poland in 1990, just in time to see the Balcerowicz reforms go into effect. “It was so amazing. I will never forget seeing how prices were moving down. It’s very rare for an economist to see prices come alive.” He wrote a very positive report—so positive that the appalled Soviet ambassador refused to send it. Yavlinsky managed to slip it into the hands of one of Gorbachev’s senior advisers, who in turn sent it to Gorbachev, who distributed it to the Central Committee.

回到莫斯科后，亚夫林斯基告诉政府高官，他们修修补补经济是在浪费时间。他说，是时候“停止撒谎”了。于是，他开始着手制定一项计划，彻底将经济体制改造为市场经济。他还深受一份按月编制的预算报告的影响。他分析了1945年至1951年间日本经济的状况。他得出结论，日本的经验非常具有借鉴意义。“日本也经历过一场灾难。如果日本能做到，我们为什么不能？当然，日本的经济受益于朝鲜战争。这对我们来说是一个非常痛苦的想法。我一直在思考我们能做些什么。最终，我得出结论，我们可以用自然资源来取代朝鲜战争，从而实现经济复苏。”

Back in Moscow, Yavlinsky told senior government officials that they were wasting their time tinkering with the economy. It was time, he said, to “stop lying.” Instead, he began to develop a plan to radically transform it into a market system. He was also much influenced by a month-by-month analysis he had conducted of what had happened to the Japanese economy between 1945 and 1951. The Japanese experience, he concluded, was very relevant. “Japan, too, had experienced a catastrophe. If Japan could do it, why couldn’t we? Japan’s economy, of course, had benefited from the Korean War. That was a very painful thought for us. I kept thinking what could we do.
