I came to the conclusion that we could replace the Korean War in our recovery with natural resources.”

亚夫林斯基和他的团队制定了一项苏联在四百天内（后改为五百天）向市场经济转型的计划。该计划是在苏联总统戈尔巴乔夫和俄罗斯联邦总统叶利钦的共同授权下撰写的，而当时的俄罗斯联邦权力非常有限。（在此期间，亚夫林斯基曾略显不妥地对叶利钦说：“你领导的是一个尚未存在的国家。你没有银行，没有货币，没有任何行动工具，除了一个独立的洗衣店之外什么都没有。”这种不愉快的感觉一直持续至今。）亚夫林斯基的计划最终形成了一份题为《向市场转型》的报告，可谓恰如其分。该报告主张快速改革——迅速改革经济的各个方面。这份报告具有里程碑意义；它没有屈从于马克思主义。它摒弃了社会主义，拥抱市场经济，包括迅速实现价格自由化和私有化。但这些理念也遭到了巨大的反对。这些改革措施最终未能实施，因为没有一位高层政治家愿意采纳。戈尔巴乔夫曾对这些措施犹豫不决，最终为了保住自己的地位，放弃了改革，转而向右翼、向老共产党人靠拢。但这对他毫无益处。

Yavlinsky and his team laid out a plan for the Soviet Union to move to a market economy in four hundred days, subsequently amended to five hundred days. It was written under a joint mandate from Gorbachev, president of the Soviet Union, and Boris Yeltsin, president of the Russian Federation, which, at the time, had very little power. (During this period, Yavlinsky said to Yeltsin, somewhat undiplomatically, “You are president of a country that does not yet exist. You have no banks, no currency, no tools to do anything, nothing except an independent laundry.” A bad feeling would persist.) Yavlinsky’s plan eventually took shape as a report entitled, aptly enough, “Transition to the Market.” It advocated speed—rapid reform of every part of the economy. The report was a landmark; it did not genuflect to Marxism. It rejected socialism and embraced the market, including swift price liberalization and privatization. But there was also enormous opposition to such ideas. They were not implemented, because no senior politicians wanted them. Gorbachev flirted and danced with them before finally veering away from reform and turning back to the right, to the old Communists, in order to hold on to his position. It would do him no good.

危机日益恶化。戈尔巴乔夫考虑私有化。与此同时，民族主义在苏联境内死灰复燃，而戈尔巴乔夫还启动了一项与传统共产主义等级制度格格不入的举措：他开始与15个不安分的苏联加盟共和国谈判，计划建立一个由他担任总统的自愿联盟。危机在1991年8月达到顶峰，强硬派共产党人发动政变，将戈尔巴乔夫软禁在克里米亚。尽管政变初期取得了一些成功，但他们遭遇了顽强抵抗——鲍里斯·叶利钦骑在坦克上的照片成为了永恒的象征。一些政变策划者沉溺于酒精之中。政变在几天后便宣告失败。戈尔巴乔夫重掌政权，但接下来的四个月却屈辱无比，他的权力逐渐衰落，最终导致苏联解体。在此期间，波兰改革家莱谢克·巴尔采罗维奇在莫斯科会见了戈尔巴乔夫。“苏联有兴趣了解波兰的经济改革之路，”戈尔巴乔夫告诉他。但对苏联——或者说对戈尔巴乔夫本人——来说，一切都为时已晚。1991年底，苏联解体。十五个苏联加盟共和国变成了十五个独立国家，其中俄罗斯是迄今为止最大、最重要的国家。戈尔巴乔夫将权力——以及核武器密码——移交给俄罗斯联邦总统鲍里斯·叶利钦，自己也成为了历史的一部分。

The crisis was worsening. Gorbachev considered privatization. At the same time, ethnic nationalism was being reborn within the borders of the Soviet Union, and Gorbachev initiated something else that was anathema to the traditional Communist hierarchy: He began negotiating a treaty with the fifteen restive Soviet republics on creating a voluntary union—with him as president. The crisis reached a climax in August 1991, when hard-line Communists mounted a coup. They put Gorbachev under house arrest in the Crimea. Despite their initial success, they met determined resistance—immortalized in the photograph of Boris Yeltsin astride a tank. Some of the plotters sank into an alcoholic stupor. The coup fizzled after a few days. Gorbachev returned to power for what proved to be four humiliating months, during which his power ebbed away and he found himself presiding over the dissolution of the Soviet Union. During this period, the Polish reformer Leszek Balcerowicz met Gorbachev in Moscow. “The Soviet Union is interested in discovering the Polish path to economic reform,” Gorbachev told him. But it was much too late for the Soviet Union—or Gorbachev—to discover anything. As 1991 ended, the Soviet Union disintegrated. The fifteen Soviet republics had become fifteen independent nations, of which Russia was by far the largest and most important. Gorbachev handed over power—and the nuclear codes—to Boris Yeltsin, president of the Russian Federation, and became part of history.

在之前的几个月里，叶利钦一直在为俄罗斯的主权和自己上台做准备。八月政变后不久，他邀请了五个相互竞争的经济学家团队制定经济战略，这些团队在莫斯科周边的政府别墅里开始着手制定各自的方案。这些方案五花八门，从支持军工复合体到改革中央计划经济体制，不一而足。叶戈尔·盖达尔是主张激进改革的团队的领导人。他和他的团队坚信，休克疗法是唯一的出路。

Over the preceding few months, Yeltsin had been preparing for Russia’s sovereignty and his assumption of authority. Shortly after the August coup, he had invited five competing groups of economists to come up with an economic strategy, and they set to work, in government dachas around Moscow, developing their competing programs. The various plans ranged from support for the military-industrial complex to a reform of central planning. Yegor Gaidar was the leader of the group calling for radical reform. He and his team were convinced that shock therapy was the only way to go.

盖达尔的理论与叶利钦的直觉不谋而合。这位俄罗斯总统既然决定推进改革，就不想拖延，他希望尽快行动。“既然我们已经下定决心，就必须行动起来！”他后来说道。然而，他仍在犹豫是否要将希望寄托在年轻的盖达尔身上，甚至将自己的未来押注于他。但后来，他想起盖达尔出身于一个特殊的家庭——革命家阿尔卡季·盖达尔的家族，而阿尔卡季·盖达尔恰好是叶利钦的英雄之一。这最终促使他下定决心。他选择了盖达尔和他的团队。10

Gaidar’s theories coincided with Yeltsin’s instincts. Having decided to move toward reform, the Russian president did not want to draw things out; he wanted to move forward as quickly as possible. “If our minds were made up, we had to get going!” he later said. Yet he was still wavering about whether to place his bets on—and risk his future on—the young Gaidar. But then he was reminded that Gaidar came from a special family—that of the revolutionary Arkady Gaidar, who happened to be one of Yeltsin’s great heroes. That pushed him over. He chose Gaidar and his team.10

革命——或激进改革

Revolution—Or Radical Reform

盖达尔说：“直到1990年夏天，我仍然相信我们可以实现有序的、国家组织的过渡。但到了1990年秋天，很明显一场灾难即将到来；体制正在崩溃，我们正经历着公开的通货膨胀。一场革命即将爆发，就像布尔什维克革命或法国大革命那样。在这种情况下，任何有序的改革都不可能实现，只能进行危机管理。所有这些，对于我们这些了解革命的人来说，都是非常清楚的。”盖达尔停顿了一下，然后补充道：“我唯一没有预料到的是，我竟然会负责管理这场危机。”

“As late as the summer of 1990,” said Gaidar, “I still believed we could make an orderly, state-organized transition. But by the fall of 1990, it was evident that a blowup lay ahead; the system was falling apart and we were living through open inflation. A revolution was coming, like the Bolshevik or the French Revolution. In that kind of setting, no orderly reform would be possible, only crisis management. All of this was very well known to those of us who knew about revolutions.” Gaidar paused for a moment, then added, “The only thing I could not foresee was that I would be in charge of managing that crisis.”

1991年11月，盖达尔被任命为副总理兼财政经济部长。甚至在他上任之前，他就完成了一件非常重要的事情：他起草了叶利钦1991年10月的讲话，阐述了迅速而大规模经济改革的基本理由。“小步前进的时代已经结束，”叶利钦说，“必须进行一次重大的改革突破。”他回顾了8月未遂政变：“我们捍卫了政治自由。现在我们必须给予经济自由，消除企业和创业自由的一切障碍，让人民摆脱官僚主义的压力，能够工作并获得与其收入相符的报酬。”

In November 1991, Gaidar was made deputy prime minister and ministerfor finance and the economy. Even before taking office, he had done one very important thing: He drafted Yeltsin’s October 1991 speech laying out the basic case for swift and massive economic reform. “The period of small steps is over,” said Yeltsin. “A big reformist breakthrough is necessary.” He summoned up the failed August coup: “We have defended political freedom. Now we have to give economic [freedom], to remove all the barriers to the freedom of enterprises and entrepreneurship, to give the people possibilities to work and receive as much as they earn, after having thrown off bureaucratic pressures.”

然而，尽管言辞自信，现实却异常艰难。“世界上绝大多数人并不了解1991年11月的危险，”盖达尔说道。“一个核超级大国陷入了无政府状态。军队不向任何人汇报。没有人知道发生了什么。我再怎么强调其中的危险都不为过。”经济上也一片混乱，十五个独立的共和国，十五家中央银行。“一切都处于一种可怕的、难以置信的混乱之中。”“一团糟，”盖达尔说。“我们没钱，没黄金，也没粮食撑到下一次收成，根本找不到解决办法。这就像你坐喷气式飞机，走进驾驶舱却发现没人操控。”公共财政濒临崩溃。政府赤字占GDP的20%甚至更多。旧经济陷入深度衰退，随着坦克和其他军事装备订单的消失，产出暴跌。通货膨胀飙升，养老金日渐缩水。煤炭供应中断，莫斯科和圣彼得堡很可能在冬天没有暖气。11

However confident the words, the reality was very tough. “The vast majority of people in the world do not understand the dangers of November 1991,” said Gaidar. “A nuclear superpower was in anarchy. The army was not reporting to anyone. No one knew what was happening. I can’t overemphasize the dangers.” Economically, it was chaotic too, with fifteen central banks in fifteen independent republics. “Everything was in a terrible, unbelievable mess,” said Gaidar. “We had no money, no gold, and no grain to last through the next harvest, and there was no way to generate a solution. It was like traveling in a jet and you go into the cockpit and you discover that there’s no one at the controls.” Public finances were falling apart. The government deficit was 20 percent or more of the GDP. The old economy was plunging into a deep depression, with the output plummeting as the orders for tanks and other military equipment disappeared. Inflation was soaring, shrinking pensions day by day. Coal supplies were disrupted, and there was a good chance that Moscow and St. Petersburg would have no heat in the winter.11

一切——尽可能快

Everything—As Rapidly as You Can

“显然，我们之前关于改革措施合理顺序的所有理论设想都是无稽之谈，”盖达尔说道。“当时的情况是，你必须竭尽所能，而且要尽可能快地完成所有事情。根本没有时间去思考。”盖达尔和他的同事们清楚他们必须做什么：为价格自由化（即取消价格管制）做好准备，开始开放经济，并为卢布可兑换和私有化做好准备。叶利钦政府迅速行动——比他们预想的还要快——以实现价格自由化，并减少那些对危机产生巨大影响的扭曲因素。

“Clearly, all our theoretical ideas about the proper sequencing of reform measures were nonsense,” said Gaidar. “It was a time when you do everything you can do, and as rapidly as you can. There was no time for reflection.” Gaidar and his colleagues knew what they had to do: prepare for price liberalization (i.e., freeing prices from controls), begin opening up the economy, and get ready for convertibility of the ruble and for privatization. The Yeltsin government moved quickly—more quickly than it wanted—to free prices and reduce the huge distortions that were doing so much to contribute to the crisis.

最紧迫的问题是粮食：城市里的面包快要断货了。盖达尔和他的同事们深知粮食短缺在俄国历史上的重要性——它曾是1917年革命的导火索之一，并在20世纪20年代末促成了斯大林经济的建立。“我当时真不知道我们能不能熬过1992年的春天，”盖达尔说。他担心粮食短缺、骚乱和恶性通货膨胀。国家征粮机构已经不复存在——这些机构是斯大林代理人的遗留产物，他们在20世纪30年代初曾从农民手中征用粮食。和波兰一样，政府所能做的只有寄希望于价格自由化带来的刺激来解决问题，然后等待。1992年6月，第一批收成开始运抵城市。

The most immediate problem was grain: The cities were running out of bread. And Gaidar and his colleagues well knew how important grain shortages had been in Russian history—helping to provoke the revolution in 1917 and leading in the late 1920s to the creation of the Stalinist economy. “I wasn’t sure we would make it through the spring of 1992,” said Gaidar. He feared food shortages, riots, and hyperinflation. There were no longer state procurement agencies—the legatees of Stalin’s agents, who had requisitioned grain from the peasants in the early 1930s. As in Poland, all the government could do was count on the incentive of newly freed prices to solve the problem, and wait. In June 1992 the first harvest began to reach the cities.

其他一些颇具争议的改革也相继启动并部分实施。许多商品和服务的价格不再受管制，俄罗斯开始走上恢复公共财政和降低通货膨胀的艰难道路。对外贸易自由化，经济活动也更加开放。军费采购削减了70%。对企业的补贴大幅减少，并试图减少那些使工厂得以继续维持原有生产模式的廉价信贷。

Other controversial reforms were initiated and partly implemented. Many prices were decontrolled, and Russia started down the hard road of restoring public finances and reducing inflation. Foreign trade was liberalized and economic activity was freed. Military procurement was cut by 70 percent. Subsidies to enterprises were slashed, and attempts were made to reduce the cheap credits that enabled factories to continue to do what they had always done.

但反对改革的声音日益高涨，导致改革实施进程延缓，有时甚至几乎使整个进程功亏一篑。企业管理者和工业官僚们对市场考验感到极度恐惧。军队的资源也逐渐枯竭。老年人则掌握着……改革者们应对高通胀负责，高通胀正蚕食着他们的养老金，他们却不明白，真正推高通胀的，是中央银行（其行长反对改革）的廉价信贷政策。地方政客眼睁睁地看着支撑整个城镇的企业倒闭。社会保障体系早已千疮百孔；这些企业曾为员工提供大部分社会服务——住房、托儿、医疗、娱乐。或许这些企业不再承担军工产业的角色，但如果它们萎缩或倒闭，谁来提供这些服务？那些靠国家工资生活的人——无论是教师、医生还是科研人员——眼睁睁地看着自己的工资缩水到每月不足五十美元。

But opposition to the reformers intensified, delaying implementation, sometimes very nearly derailing the entire process. The enterprise managers and industrial bureaucrats had an enormous amount to fear from the test of the market. The military saw its resources disappear. The elderly held the reformers responsible for the high inflation that was devouring their pensions, not understanding that it was the cheap-credits policy of the central bank (whose head was opposed to reform) that was fueling inflation. Local politicians saw the enterprises that supported whole towns collapse. The social safety net was much frayed; the enterprises had provided their workers with the bulk of their social services—housing, child care, medical care, recreation. Perhaps the firms no longer had their military-industrial role, but if they shrank or collapsed, who would provide these services? Those who lived on state salaries—whether they were teachers or doctors or researchers in the institutes—saw the value of their wages decrease to the equivalent of less than fifty dollars a month.

双方的观念存在根本性的差异。对于老一辈的管理者、工人和退休人员来说，“市场”是巨大的压力来源，实际上就像一个入侵他们生活的异类，它攻击着社会肌体，扰乱着他们熟悉的一切，贬低着他们的经验，质疑着那些曾经支配他们生活、为他们苦难辩护的根本理由。老一辈经济学家也是如此，即使是那些在勃列日涅夫和戈尔巴乔夫时期信奉自由主义的人也不例外。简而言之，他们认为市场意味着无政府状态。他们认为要么应该恢复中央计划经济，要么至少国家应该继续发挥主导作用，控制物价和工资。市场不可信赖。它与俄罗斯的特殊情况格格不入。从根本上讲，他们眼前发生的一切似乎是不道德的；它违背了他们最深层的本能。在市场上赚到的钱自然而然地受到怀疑。“投机”一词成了贬义词和侮辱的代名词。任何带有商业色彩的东西都被视为黑手党。他们早已习惯了旧政权时期的黑色吉尔和柴卡豪华轿车，这些车拉着窗帘，在莫斯科林荫大道上专用的中央车道上轰鸣而过，这在当时是司空见惯的景象。对此，他们还能接受。但他们对越来越多奔驰车里的乘客感到反感，这些乘客个个傲慢而强悍，手里拿着手机，还有浓妆艳抹的年轻女子。

And there was a fundamental difference in ideas. For managers, workers, and pensioners in the older generation, the “market” was a source of great stress, indeed some alien creature that had invaded their lives, attacking the body of society, disrupting all they knew, and devaluing their experience, throwing into question the very rationales that had governed their lives and justified their sufferings. This was also true of the older economists, even those who had been liberals under Brezhnev and Gorbachev. In short, they took the market to mean anarchy. They thought that either there should be a return to central planning or at least the state should still play the dominant role, controlling prices and wages. The market could not be trusted. It did not accord with Russia’s unique situation. Fundamentally, what seemed to be unfolding before their eyes was immoral; it ran against their deepest instincts. Money made in the market was automatically suspect. Speculation was the all-purpose term of opprobrium and insult. Anything that smacked of trade was considered mafia. They had been accustomed, as part of the natural order, to the black Zil and Chaika limousines of the old regime roaring down the specially reserved central lanes on Moscow boulevards with their curtains drawn. That, they could accept. But they were repulsed by the growing number of Mercédeses filled with arrogant and toughlooking young men, holding cellular phones, and heavily made-up young women.

针对激进改革派，一种被形容为“冷酷无情的民粹主义”正在兴起。这些改革派对旧体制，对曾经抵抗希特勒并将第一颗人造卫星送入太空的体制，毫不尊重。叶利钦的副总统——后来的对手——亚历山大·鲁茨科伊抨击盖达尔及其团队是“穿着粉色短裤和黄色靴子的小男孩”。为了稳定政治局势，叶利钦于1992年12月任命维克托·切尔诺梅尔金为总理。切尔诺梅尔金曾是俄罗斯最成功的实业家，担任俄罗斯天然气工业股份公司（Gazprom）的总裁，该公司后来发展成为世界上最大的能源公司。他在工业界的管理者中备受尊敬，拥有巨大的影响力。没有人敢说他只是个穿着短裤的小男孩。此外，他还有一个很大的优点：他并非直接来自军工复合体。12

What has been described as a “ruthless populism” built up against the radical reformers, who showed no deference to the old system, to the apparatus that had resisted Hitler and put the first Sputnik into space. Yeltsin’s vice-president—and later opponent—Aleksandr Rutskoi attacked Gaidar and his team as “small boys in pink shorts and yellow boots.” In an effort to stabilize the political situation, Yeltsin made Viktor Chernomyrdin prime minister in December 1992. He had been the most successful industrialist in the country as the head of Gazprom, the state gas monopoly, which has since become the largest energy company in the world. He was widely respected and had enormous authority among the industrial managers. No one would dare say that he was a small boy in shorts. He also had the great virtue of not coming directly from the military-industrial complex.12

实际的改革进程有所推进，但进展并不顺利——有时……改革步伐放缓，有时甚至倒退，但始终没有停止。叶利钦本人并没有深刻的经济见解，而且他不断面临着放弃改革的压力。然而，改革和必要性自有其不可抗拒的逻辑。每当他听从那些劝他放慢脚步或倒退的建议时，结果往往是灾难性的。通货膨胀会急剧上升，卢布会大幅贬值，而这些事态发展又会迫使叶利钦重回改革之路。

The actual reform process moved ahead, but in an uncertain way—sometimes slowed down, sometimes reversed. But it continued to move. Yeltsin himself had no deep economic views, and he was under constant pressure to back away from reforms. But reform and necessity had their own inescapable logic. Whenever he heeded the advice of those who said to slow down or go into reverse, the results were disastrous. Inflation would rise dramatically or the ruble would collapse in value, and such developments would push Yeltsin back onto the path of reform.

到1993年9月，叶利钦与议会在改革问题上陷入僵局。社会不满情绪高涨。叶利钦解散了议会，但议会拒绝解散。议员们占领了议会大楼“白宫”；叶利钦则派遣军队包围了白宫，实际上是对议会进行了围攻。当议员的武装支持者试图占领市长办公室和电视塔时，叶利钦派遣坦克驶入莫斯科街头，并下令使用大炮，放火焚烧白宫，迫使占领者全部投降。而就在26个月前，这位叶利钦还曾站在坦克上，以示对抗。

By September 1993, Yeltsin and the parliament were deadlocked over reform. Social discontent was very high. Yeltsin dissolved parliament, but parliament refused to be dissolved. Its members occupied the “White House,” the parliamentary building; Yeltsin replied by throwing troops around it—in effect, a siege. When armed supporters of the deputies tried to seize the mayor’s office and the television tower, Yeltsin dispatched tanks through the streets of Moscow and ordered the use of cannons, setting the White House on fire and forcing the total surrender of the occupants. This was the same Yeltsin who twenty-six months earlier had stood on a tank in defiance.

12月，叶利钦的反对派利用社会动荡，在议会选举中取得重大胜利。一个月后，1994年1月，受到冲击的叶利钦接受了盖达尔辞去副总理职务的请求。维克托·切尔诺梅尔金从此直接负责经济事务。为了安抚反对派，政府放弃了财政紧缩政策，重新打开了信贷闸门。结果导致卢布大幅贬值。切尔诺梅尔金别无选择，只能重拾改革之路。他已经接受了稳健货币和低通胀的理念。

In December, Yeltsin’s opponents, capitalizing on the social distress, scored big gains in parliamentary elections. One month later, in January 1994, a shaken Yeltsin accepted Gaidar’s resignation from the post of deputy prime minister. Viktor Chernomyrdin now took direct responsibility for the economy. In order to placate the opposition, the government retreated from financial austerity and opened the flood gates of credit again. The result was an astonishing collapse in the value of the ruble. Chernomyrdin had no choice but to resume the reform path. He had become converted to sound money and low inflation.

那时，俄罗斯已经呈现出两种经济体制：一种是旧的、由国家控制的苏联军工体系——致力于盲目生产，士气低落，步履维艰——另一种是充满活力、雄心勃勃的新兴市场经济，致力于满足消费者的需求和愿望。后者在很大程度上是由年轻人，即后共产主义一代，所主导的。

By then Russia was already a country of two economies: the old statecontrolled Soviet military-industrial system—dedicated to mindless production, and despondent and demoralized and spiraling downward in decline—and a raw, ambitious new market-based society, responsive to consumers’ needs and desires. The lead role in the latter was being taken, to a considerable degree, by younger people, the postcommunist generation.

关键要素：私有财产的建立

The Essential Element: Creating Private Property

然而，没有私有财产，市场体系几乎不可能存在。叶利钦在1991年10月的改革演说中阐述了这一原则：“我们讨论私有财产是否必要已经太久了，这是不可接受的。与此同时，党国精英却积极地进行着他们自己的私有化。其规模、力度和虚伪程度令人震惊。俄罗斯的私有化一直在进行，但却是疯狂的、自发的，而且往往是建立在犯罪基础之上的。今天，我们必须掌握主动权，而且我们决心这样做。”

Yet there could hardly be a market system without private property. Yeltsin laid out the principle in his reform speech of October 1991: “For impermissibly long, we have discussed whether private property is necessary. In the meantime, the party-state elite has actively been engaged in their own personal privatization. The scale, the enterprise, and the hypocrisy are staggering. The privatization of Russia has gone on, but wildly, spontaneously, and often on a criminal basis. Today we have to seize the initiative, and we are intent on doing so.”

叶利钦将私有化实施工作委托给了一个小组。一群年轻的经济学家组成了国家国有资产管理委员会的核心，该委员会以其俄语缩写GKI为人所知。委员会主席是一位名叫阿纳托利·丘拜斯的经济学家，他于1977年毕业于列宁格勒工程经济学院，之后在该学院任教。尽管他曾是该学院的共产党委员会成员，但他同时也领导着一个由年轻经济学家组成的半地下小组，该小组研究和讨论改革。他被任命为列宁格勒市首席经济学家，当时列宁格勒正在一位改革派市长的领导下恢复其旧名圣彼得堡，这位市长希望吸引西方资本，并将列宁格勒打造成为一个市场展示中心。作为其职责的一部分，丘拜斯负责监督商店和小企业的私有化。之后，他被选中前往莫斯科，成为盖达尔团队的高级成员。他不仅在经济分析和政策制定方面展现出非凡的才能，而且在官僚机构内部斗争和纯粹的政治手腕上也颇有建树，最终在1996年成为鲍里斯·叶利钦的竞选经理和总统办公厅主任。然而，真正让他大放异彩的，是在推行私有化的过程中，克服了几乎不可能克服的重重困难。

Yeltsin entrusted the implementation of privatization to a group of young economists, who formed the nucleus of the State Committee on the Management of State Property, which became known by its Russian initials as the GKI. Its head was an economist named Anatolii Chubais, who had graduated from the Leningrad Institute of Engineering Economics in 1977 and subsequently taught there. Although he had been a member of the Communist Party committee at his institute, he also became the leader of a semi-underground local group of young economists who studied and debated reform. He was appointed chief economist for the city of Leningrad, which was returning to its old name of St. Petersburg under a reformist mayor, who wanted to attract Western capital and make the city a market showcase. As part of his responsibility, Chubais oversaw the privatization of shops and small businesses. Then he was tapped to go to Moscow as a senior member of Gaidar’s team. He was to demonstrate considerable talents not only for economic analysis and policy making but also for bureaucratic infighting and sheer politics, and would eventually become Boris Yeltsin’s campaign manager in 1996 and the presidential chief of staff. But it was in implementing privatization, against odds that could only be called insurmountable, that he was to truly hone his skills.

对盖达尔、楚拜斯以及他们周围的人来说，私有化有一个核心目标。楚拜斯将其描述为建立“一个庞大的私有制阶层”。或者，正如他所说，要使改革和共产主义的终结“不可逆转”。简而言之，他们的目标是建立一个庞大的财产所有者群体，使他们在市场经济中拥有利益，从而制衡管理者、官僚、党政干部、愤怒的民族主义者、军人和怀旧情绪。这一目标贯穿了整个过程，并赋予了改革者克服反对和障碍所需的毅力。13

For Gaidar, Chubais, and those around them, privatization had one central objective. Chubais described it as the creation of “a broad stratum of private owners.” Or, as he said, to make reform and the end of communism “irreversible.” In short, they set out to create a large property-owning population that would have a stake in the market economy and that therefore could counterbalance the managers, bureaucrats, party apparatchiks, angry nationalists, soldiers, and nostalgies. This objective shaped the entire process and provided the reformers with the tenacity required to overcome the opposition and the obstacles.13

这就是目标。但如何实现呢？用丘拜斯一些主要顾问的话来说，私有化进程的指导和实现“得益于一些关键的经济理念”。首先，他们坚信俄罗斯人与世界其他地区的人一样，属于“经济人”（homo economicus）这一物种，会对经济激励做出反应。然而，在20世纪90年代初期，无论是俄罗斯政界人士、老一辈俄罗斯经济学家，还是传统的西方苏联问题专家，当时的主流观点都截然不同。俄罗斯曾被布尔什维克统治了75年之久，这对市场经济中的人们来说是灾难性的。人们说——而且无疑是对的——统治之后留下的土壤并非那种能够轻易孕育企业家的沃土。反对私有化的民族主义者声称，俄罗斯的情况特殊，俄罗斯人与其他国家的人不同。批评家说，俄罗斯人懒惰、酗酒，他们对工作的态度可以用共产主义时期的一句格言来概括：“他们假装付钱给我们，我们也假装工作。”但在丘拜斯看来，这一切与其说是基因问题，不如说是经济组织体系的问题。如果激励机制……他相信，只要制度到位，人们就会按规矩行事。他根本不认同“俄罗斯人不一样”这种说法。

That was the goal. But how to attain it? The privatization process was, in the words of some of Chubais’s chief advisers, guided and made possible “by the power of some key economic ideas.” The first was a conviction that Russians belonged, like the rest of the world, to the species homo economicus—economic man—and would respond to economic incentives. In the early 1990s, the dominant view was quite different, whether it emanated from Russian politicians or older Russian economists, or traditional Western Sovietologists. Russia had been ruled by Bolsheviks for three quarters of a century, and the results had been catastrophic for people in the market economy. The soil left behind, it was said—and no doubt rightly—was not exactly the fertile sort from which entrepreneurs could be expected to spring easily. Nationalistic opponents of privatization claimed that Russia was different, a special case, that Russians were not like other people. Critics said that Russians were lazy, given to alcoholism, and that their attitude toward work was summed up by an epigram under communism: “They pretend to pay us, and we pretend to work.” But to Chubais, all this had less to do with DNA than with the system of economic organization. If the incentives and institutions were there, he believed, people would act accordingly. He simply did not buy the “Russians are different” thesis.

第二个观点认为，俄罗斯经济的核心弊病在于政治控制和支配，而解决之道在于尽可能地将经济活动从官僚和各部委手中剥离。这样做还能减少腐败，因为人们无需再向官僚机构请示。所有这些都促使俄罗斯致力于大规模私有化。俄罗斯没有时间进行西方式那种谨慎的私有化——逐案进行，在仔细评估和重组之后再做决定。如果拖延下去，到了22世纪，俄罗斯可能还在进行私有化，官僚机构仍然掌控着一切，经济仍然停滞不前——而且极有可能出现试图重返共产主义的极端情况。

The second idea was that Russia’s central economic ailment was political control and domination and that the cure was to take economic activity out of the hands of bureaucrats and ministries to the greatest degree possible. That would also reduce corruption by decreasing the necessity to ask bureaucrats for permission to do things. All this led to a commitment to mass privatization. Russia did not have time for careful Western-style privatization—on a case-by-case basis, after careful evaluation and restructuring. If it took its time, by the twenty-second century it would still be privatizing, the bureaucrats would still be in control, the economy would still be stagnating—and there would be plenty of potential for attempted U-turns back to communism.

第三个想法源于对财产权的理解。法律认可的财产权并非不可更改，而是一系列权利的集合。政府本身并不真正拥有那些即将私有化的资产；这些资产在不同程度上不仅属于国家，也属于管理者、雇员和地方当局。他们各自拥有特定的权利，而管理者、雇员和地方当局构成了“利益相关者”。因此，丘拜斯团队得出结论：如果私有化要取得成功，所有利益相关者都必须参与其中，成为交易的一部分。联盟越强大，对抗根深蒂固的官僚机构的成功几率就越大。这意味着还需要一个利益相关者群体——一个此前尚未被视为利益相关者的群体：公众。

The third idea was one that grew out of a view of property. Legally recognized property was not immutable; rather, it amounted to a collection of rights. Government by itself did not really own the assets that were to be privatized; they belonged, in varying measures, not only to the state but also to the managers, employees, and local authorities. Each of them had certain rights, and the managers, employees, and local authorities constituted the “stakeholders.” Thus, concluded the Chubais team, if privatization was to succeed, all the stakeholders had to get a piece of the action, to be part of the deal. The stronger the coalition, the better the chances of success against the entrenched bureaucracies. That meant that one more group of stakeholders was essential—a group that did not yet exist as stakeholders: the general public.

然而，形势似乎极其不利。议会试图阻止私有化；各部委试图重新掌控权力；企业管理者则竭力攫取一切能够到手的资产。在这一切的背景下，丘拜斯领导的GKI着手制定其方案。第一步是将国有企业“公司化”，重新注册为股份制公司，最初由国家持有全部股份。董事来自政府——但并非来自传统的部委，而是来自GKI。这又造成了另一个瓶颈。私有财产只能存在于合同和法律的框架之内，而GKI遇到的问题即使在美国这样的国家也会令人震惊——律师严重短缺。14

Yet circumstances seemed most unpromising. The parliament tried to block privatization; the ministries attempted to reassert their control; and enterprise managers stole whatever assets they could get their hands on. Amid all of this, Chubais’s GKI set out to design its program. The first step was to “corporative” state-owned companies, rechartering them as joint-stock companies, with the state initially holding all the shares. The directors came from the government—but from the GKI, not from the traditional ministries. That created another bottleneck. Private property can exist only within a framework of contracts and laws, and the GKI ran up against a problem that would astonish people in a country like the United States—an acute shortage of lawyers.14

通往自由经济的门票

A Ticket to the Free Economy

改革者们得出结论，波兰的私有化模式，即逐案出售和共同基金模式，效果并不理想。但捷克的模式，即大规模发放代金券的模式，则更有前景。而且，捷克模式有可能减少腐败，因为它消除了……通过幕后谈判达成交易，并尽可能使私有化过程透明化。

The reformers concluded that the Polish model of privatization, with its case-by-case sales and mutual funds, had not worked very well. But the Czech model, which handed out vouchers on a mass basis, was more promising. And it had the potential to reduce corruption insofar as it eliminated back room-negotiated deals and made privatization as transparent as possible.

俄罗斯政府向所有俄罗斯公民，包括儿童，发放了每张价值一万卢布的代金券。公民可以前往当地国家银行网点领取，只需支付象征性的手续费。最终，1.47亿俄罗斯人中约有1.44亿人收到了代金券。这些代金券看起来像货币，在某种程度上也像货币。它们可以通过拍卖机制兑换成公司股份。对叶利钦来说，这些代金券成为了私有化的象征。“我们需要数百万的所有者，而不是少数的百万富翁，”他宣称，“私有化代金券是我们每个人通往自由经济的门票。”

The Russian government issued vouchers, worth ten thousand rubles each, to every Russian citizen, children included. They could be picked up at local offices of the state bank for a nominal transaction fee. Eventually some 144 million out of 147 million Russians received their vouchers. They looked like currency and were like currency—up to a point. They could be exchanged for shares in companies through the mechanism of auctions. For Yeltsin, the vouchers became the symbol of privatization. “We need millions of owners rather than a handful of millionaires,” he declared. “The privatization voucher is a ticket for each of us to a free economy.”

在现代俄罗斯，代金券成为第一种流动性证券。人们可以持有代金券，并获得特定公司（或自己所在公司）的股份，也可以将其兑换成共同基金份额，或者直接出售。代金券的买卖市场应运而生，甚至可以在当地集市上买到。在西西伯利亚，妇女们在摊位上出售代金券，“就像卖胡萝卜或卷心菜一样”。价格在4美元到20美元之间波动。该计划的设计者们曾苦苦思索一个关键问题——现有管理层和员工可以获得多少公司股份，公众和外部投资者又能获得多少股份。

Vouchers became the first liquid security in modem Russia. People could hold on to them and acquire shares in specific companies (or the company in which they worked), exchange them for shares in mutual funds, or sell them. Markets grew up for the buying and selling of vouchers, which could even be bought in local bazaars. In west Siberia, women sold vouchers from stalls, “just like carrots or cabbages.” The price fluctuated between four dollars and twenty dollars. The designers of the program had struggled over the critical question—what share of a company the current managers and employees could obtain and how much the public and outside investors could acquire.

第一次大规模私有化是1992年的布尔什维克饼干厂。（工人们在那次交易中获得了控制权，但最终又将控股权出售给了法国达能公司，该公司是美国达能酸奶的母公司。）此后，尽管议会、各部委和政客不断攻击，试图阻止或控制这一进程，但私有化计划仍然稳步推进。反对者诉诸民族主义、国家安全和俄罗斯独特的民族特性。出版部长声称所有出版社都应该由政府掌控，因为“出版是我们的意识形态”。交通部长则认为所有卡车都必须归国家所有，因为战争时期需要它们进行动员。但联合政府的策略奏效了，私有化势头得以保持。每月约有90万工人通过代金券私有化从国有部门转移到私营部门。代金券很受欢迎；事实上，歌曲《哇哇代金券》甚至登上了莫斯科流行歌曲排行榜的第五名。

The first major privatization was the Bolshevik Biscuit Factory, in 1992. (The workers won control in that transaction and then ended up selling a controlling interest to France’s Danone, parent of American Dannon Yogurt.) Thereafter, the program moved ahead despite constant attack by the parliament and by the ministries and politicians who sought to stop the process or gain control over it. The opponents appealed to nationalism, national security, and the unique Russian character. The minister of publishing said that all publishing houses should remain in government hands because “publishing is our ideology.” The transportation minister argued that all trucks must belong to the state because they would be needed for mobilization in war. But the coalition strategy worked and the momentum was maintained. Some nine hundred thousand workers a month moved from the state sector to the private sector via voucher privatization. Vouchers were popular; indeed, the song “Wow Wow Voucher” reached number five on the Moscow hit parade.

凭证私有化计划实施时间不到两年，始于1992年10月，止于1994年7月。在此期间，俄罗斯大部分工业企业被私有化，一个私有化阶层确实形成。许多工人被骗走凭证，以及管理层操纵股份的案例层出不穷。尽管如此，该计划最终使约4000万人成为股东，他们或直接持有公司股份，或通过共同基金持有股份。无论是内部人士（管理层和工人），还是外部人士（公众），都与这些私营企业有着利益关系。私有化本身绝非解决重组问题的根本之道，而是一个前提条件。但它确实为企业重组提供了动力。企业努力做得更好，改进产品，寻找市场并适应市场，以及控制成本。15

The voucher privatization program ran for less than two years. It began in October 1992 and was over by July 1994. During that time, the greater part of Russian industry was privatized. A property-owning stratum had, indeed, been created. There were many stories of workers bilked out of their vouchers—and of managers manipulating the shares. Still, as a result of the program, some 40 million people were shareholders, either directly in companies or as members of mutual funds. Both insiders—the managers and workers—and outsiders—the public—had a stake in these private firms. Privatization in itself did not, by any means, answer the problem of restructuring. Rather, it was a precondition. But it did provide the incentive for companies to do better, to improve their products, to find markets and adapt to them, and to manage costs.15

中大型企业的私有化只是整个过程的一部分。国家还拥有住房，对大多数人来说，这意味着公寓。然而，在许多情况下，居住在这些公寓里的人实际上拥有准所有权。公寓作为遗产代代相传。住户可以以极低的价格购买自己的单元，到1994年10月，约有1050万套公寓落入私人手中。

The privatization of the medium- and larger-size firms was only part of the process. The state also owned housing, which for most people meant apartments. Yet in many cases, those who lived in the apartments had quasi ownership. Apartments were passed down as inheritances, from generation to generation. The occupants could buy their units at very low cost, and by October 1994, some 10.5 million apartments were in private hands.

商店和小企业都交由当地政府管理。节目一开始，就在下诺夫哥罗德市拍卖了几家店铺。在全国电视观众的注视下，一群坚强的女性先是想到自己即将“失去”工作多年的面包店而感到无比沮丧，随后得知自己成功竞标后欣喜若狂。很快，人们就发现，被拍卖的店铺的服务质量远高于那些直接交给“集体”成员经营的店铺。

Shops and small enterprises were left to their localities. Here the program began with the auctioning off of a few shops in the city of Nizhni Novgorod. Under the watchful eye of television viewers across the country, a group of sturdy women went from total despondency at the thought that they were about to “lose” the bakery in which they had worked for so many years to uncontrollable glee at learning that they had just won the bidding for the store. It became quickly evident that the quality of service in stores that had been auctioned was higher than the service in the stores that had merely been given away to the members of the “collective” who had worked there.

私有化进程存在一些重要的局限性。“战略性”企业和某些来自军工联合体的国防企业因其重要的国家使命不容冒险而被排除在私有化进程之外。改革者意识到，这些政治敏感且关系密切的企业所面临的阻力将远大于其他企业，因此，与其冒着输掉整场斗争的风险，不如尽力而为。在私有化的后期阶段，银行通过向财政拮据的政府提供贷款，得以收购大量仍由政府持有的股份。一些观察人士认为，这是一种隐晦的手段，旨在加强与银行关系密切的内部人士的权力，或是让银行集团以低价收购股份。另一些人则认为，如此强大的外部股东将促进重组。

There were important limitations on the privatization effort. “Strategic” and certain defense companies from the military-industrial complex were spared the privatization process on the grounds that their important national mission could not be risked. The reformers realized that opposition would be much stronger for these politically sensitive and well-connected companies than for others, and the better part of valor was to get done what they could get done rather than risk losing the entire battle. In a later stage of privatization, banks were able to acquire a substantial number of shares still in government hands by loaning money to the revenue-starved government. Some observers saw this as an ill-concealed method to strengthen the hands of insiders, with whom the banks were closely allied, or for banking groups to acquire shares on the cheap. Others argued that such strong outside shareholders would promote restructuring.

丘拜斯的“凭证私有化”政策有一个非常大的例外。莫斯科颇受欢迎的市长、叶利钦的主要盟友尤里·卢日科夫设法将莫斯科的大部分国有资产排除在国家计划之外。相反，莫斯科市政府以自己的条件出售或出租了这些资产，从而极大地充实了财政收入。在卢日科夫的领导下（他在1996年以90%的得票率再次当选市长），莫斯科正在进行大规模的改造，用色彩缤纷、建设如火如荼的新面貌取代苏联时代的破败景象。所有这一切——再加上莫斯科的发展速度远远超过其他地区——导致了斯大林在20世纪30年代提出的“一国建成社会主义”理念的重新诠释。莫斯科已经变成了“一座城市里的资本主义”——或者，正如一位俄罗斯政治家借用共产主义理论家的话说，“莫斯科和俄罗斯其他地区就像邓小平的理论——一国两制”。

There was one very large exception to Chubais’s voucher privatization. Yuri Luzhkov, the popular mayor of Moscow and a principal ally of Yeltsin, managed to get much of the state assets in Moscow excluded from the national program. Instead, the city sold them or leased them out on its own terms—to the great benefit of its coffers. Under Luzhkov, who was reelected mayor with 90 percent of the vote in 1996, Moscow is undergoing a vast refurbishment, replacing the shabbiness of Soviet days with color and frenetic construction. All this—combined with the speed with which Moscow has raced ahead of the provinces—has led to a reformulation of Stalin’s 1930s dictum about “socialism in one country.” Moscow has become “capitalism in one city”—or, as one Russian politician put it, switching communist theoreticians, “Moscow and the rest of the country are like Deng Xiaoping’s theory—one country, two systems.”

自1992年担任市长以来，卢日科夫不仅成为了……卢日科夫不仅是这座城市的领导人，也是俄罗斯最重要的政治人物之一。尽管他与叶利钦保持着密切关系，但他却公开批评叶利钦政府中的改革派，称他们为“青年团”，并抨击他们的改革和私有化政策“只有脱离日常生活的理论家才会想到”。他乐于描述自己给改革派带来的“痛苦”。卢日科夫支持干预主义、国家资本主义和强硬手段。“俄罗斯人一直以来都依赖政府，”他解释说，“打破这一传统意味着强加给人民的不是改革，而是背叛。”从克里姆林宫附近新建地下购物中心的决策，到推广他创立的快餐连锁店“俄罗斯小酒馆”（Russkoye Bistro），卢日科夫的影响力无处不在。这家连锁店旨在与麦当劳正面竞争。卢日科夫很可能以成为叶利钦的总统继任者为目标。在外交事务上，卢日科夫的民族主义立场比叶利钦更为强硬。他深知媒体的重要性，因此让莫斯科建立了自己的国家电视台。市政府控制着全国性报纸的办公室和服务部门，这些报纸对市长的报道也比其他政治人物更为谨慎。此外，凭借莫斯科雄厚的财政实力，卢日科夫正与其他地区的城市建立联盟。卢日科夫毫不掩饰自己在莫斯科的权威。鉴于莫斯科取得的显著成效，他的改革方案无疑受到了那些饱受俄罗斯现代革命动荡和混乱之苦的人们的热烈欢迎。

Since becoming mayor in 1992, Luzhkov has emerged not only as the city’s boss but also as one of the country’s most important politicians. While maintaining close relations with Yeltsin, he has become an outspoken critic of the reformers in the Yeltsin administration—dismissing them as the “youth squad”—and castigated their reform and privatization policies as something that “could only occur to theoreticians far removed from everyday life.” He delights in describing the “heartburn” he causes them. Luzhkov favors intervention, state capitalism, and a strong hand. “The Russian being has always counted on the government,” he explained. “To break that tradition would mean to force upon the people not reform but betrayal.” Luzhkov makes his presence felt in everything from decisions about the construction of the new underground shopping mall near the Kremlin to the promotion of Russkoye Bistro, a fast-food chain he set up to compete head-on against McDonald’s. Luzhkov may well aim to be Yeltsin’s successor as president. On foreign affairs, he strikes a more aggressively nationalistic posture than Yeltsin. Recognizing the importance of the media, Luzhkov has had Moscow establish its own national television network. The city controls the offices and services of the national newspapers, and their coverage of the mayor is more cautious than that of other politicians. And, with the city holding hefty financial resources, Luzhkov is building alliances with cities in other regions. Luzhkov leaves no doubt as to who calls the shots in Moscow. Given the results evident in the city, his brand of reform certainly gets a very receptive reaction from those who have been whipsawed by the turbulence and disorder of Russia’s modern revolution.

综上所述，迄今为止，俄罗斯私有化进程的总体评价如何？答案不出所料，并不简单。该计划令人印象深刻，尤其考虑到它所面临的几乎不可能克服的挑战，然而，仍有大量工作要做。其规模令人叹为观止。到1996年，约有18000家工业企业完成私有化——其中包括超过四分之三的大中型工业企业，以及近90%的工业产值，使私营部门的产业工人比例达到80%。超过五分之四的小商店和零售店也已实现私有化，其中包括俄罗斯企业家创办的90万家新企业。此外，70%的GDP来自私营部门。

When everything is added up, what is the overall judgment on Russian privatization so far? The answer, not surprisingly, is hardly simple. The program is impressive, all the more so because of the almost impossible challenges it faced, and yet there is an enormous amount still to be done. The scale is awesome. By 1996, some 18,000 industrial enterprises had been privatized—including more than three quarters of all large and midsize industrial firms and something close to 90 percent of industrial production, bringing the proportion of industrial workers employed in the private sector to 80 percent. Over four fifths of small shops and retail stores are also now privatized, including 900,000 new ventures established by Russian entrepreneurs. And 70 percent of GDP is generated in the private sector.

但私有化已不再是热门之选。它失去民心的原因有很多，其中最主要的是重组带来的裁员。在民众心目中，私有化还与其他一些弊病联系在一起，例如高通胀、社会保障体系的崩溃以及普遍存在的社会困境，尤其是老年人的困境。残酷的现实是，腐败和内幕交易是私有化过程中的顽疾，再加上公众对整个过程的怀疑，最终导致私有化失败。一些人通过垄断资产和孜孜不倦地积累股份券而暴富。而另一些人则将私有化视为对“苏联人民”劳动成果的窃取——无论他们认为罪魁祸首是官僚阶层（老一代的共产党官僚和经理人），还是黑手党。是投机取巧的投机者，还是新俄罗斯的银行和金融机构？批评之声不绝于耳，从老牌共产党人到新民主党人，无一幸免。“私有化行不通，因为他们没有创造私有财产，”格里戈里·亚夫林斯基说，“他们只是在制造卡特尔。”

But privatization is no longer at the top of the hit parade. It has lost its popularity for many reasons—not the least of which are the job cuts that go with restructuring. It is also associated in the popular mind with other afflictions—high inflation, the disappearance of the social safety net, and widespread social distress, especially for the elderly. The blunt fact is that corruption and inside dealing were features of the privatization process—which, combined with suspicion of the whole process, soured the public. Some people, by cornering assets and assiduously aggregating coupons, have gotten very rich. Many others see privatization as theft of the labors of the “Soviet people”—whether they believe the perpetrators are the nomenklatura (the old Communist bureaucrats and managers) or the mafia and shady speculators or the banks and financial institutions of the new Russia. Criticism ranges across the spectrum, from the old communists to the new democrats. “Privatization is not working because they are not creating private property,” said Grigori Yavlinsky. “They are creating cartelization.”

根据俄美联合开展的全国俄罗斯调查项目，私有化从未达到人们最初的高期望，也远没有目前的批评声那么糟糕。据估计，约四分之三的俄罗斯私有化企业需要进行彻底的重组，而其中相当一部分企业实际上已经破产。许多管理者根本缺乏重组的能力、经验、资质或意愿。唯有外部所有权才能促成变革。

According to the National Russian Survey, a comprehensive joint Russian-U.S. project, privatization was never as good as the high hopes for it—or anywhere near as bad as the current criticism. Something on the order of three-quarters of the privatized Russian firms are thought to be in need of radical restructuring, and a good part of those in turn are actually bankrupt. Many of the managers simply do not have the capacity, experience, competence, or desire to restructure. It takes outside ownership to force change.

其中大部分可能来自新兴的金融产业集团，它们已成为强大的政治和经济力量。在转型时期，巨额财富已被积累起来——通过积累私有化凭证、利用补贴信贷以及以世界价格出售以低价在国内购入的商品。但是，银行和其他金融机构日益增长的影响力究竟会促进现代化，还是仅仅意味着经济和政治权力向批评者所称的卡特尔和“金融寡头”的新集中？私有化的最终后果只有在这个问题得到解答后才能知晓。

Much of that could come through the new financial-industrial groups that have emerged as potent political and economic forces. Great fortunes have been made out of the transition years—by accumulating privatization vouchers, taking advantage of subsidized credits, and selling at world prices commodities acquired at low domestic prices. But will the growing impact of banks and other financial institutions promote modernization, or will it simply mean a new concentration of economic and political power in what critics call cartels and “financial oligarchies”? The ultimate consequences of privatization will be known only when that question is answered.

当然，私有化进程还有很多工作要做。与此同时，相当一部分所有权已经去政治化。然而，尽管涌现出大量新财富，俄罗斯仍然是一个“没有资本的资本主义”国家。重组的成功需要发展金融市场，使其能够高效地提供产业所需的资本，同时支持市场经济所需的技能和能力的培养。而这一切，最终又回到了根本问题：游戏规则是什么？16

Certainly, there is a lot more to do on privatization. In the meantime, a substantial amount of ownership has been depoliticized. Yet despite the newly created fortunes, Russia remains a country of “capitalism without capital.” The success of restructuring will require the development of financial markets, which can efficiently provide the capital that industry needs—and at the same time support the development of skills and competencies that a market economy requires. That, in turn, goes back to the basic question: the rules of the game.16

“政府的大规模撤退”

“The Massive Retreat of Government”

尽管私有化推进了俄罗斯经济生活去政治化的目标，但联邦、省和地方各级政府仍然通过任意征税、监管和直接干预等手段，对经济施加着强大的政治控制。然而，如今，与政府权力抗衡的是私有财产这股力量。私有财产已成为经济活动和市场制度的基础。事实上，随着价格自由化的推进，私有化也启动了推动俄罗斯迈向市场经济世界的进程，无论未来发生怎样的政治事件，这股进程都难以阻挡。私有化进程在1994年后停滞不前。从1995年开始，政府最大的经济成就体现在宏观经济领域。面对巨大的质疑，政府在降低通货膨胀和稳定卢布方面取得了卓越的成就。政府也开始控制国家预算。这一切都归功于维克托·切尔诺梅尔金，一位皈依经济正统观念的思想家。这些努力为经济复苏奠定了基础。但在其他方面，改革在这一时期却步履维艰。政府在补贴和向工业提供廉价信贷方面浪费了巨额资金。车臣战争这场灾难性的战争夺去了数万人的生命，并浪费了数十亿美元。

While privatization has advanced the objective of the depoliticization of Russian economic life, government—at the federal, provincial, and local levels—continues to exert heavy political control over the economy through arbitrary taxes, regulations, and direct intervention. But now, against government power, stands the countervailing force of private property. And private property has become the basis for economic activity and market institutions. Indeed, along with the freeing of prices, privatization has set in motion forces that will carry Russia forward into the world of market economies and that will be very hard to retard, whatever the political events ahead. Privatization stalled after 1994. From 1995 onward, the government’s biggest economic achievement was on the macroeconomic front. In the face of great skepticism, it did an outstanding job in bringing down inflation and stabilizing the ruble. It also began reining in the state budget. The leader in all this was a convert to economic orthodoxy, Viktor Chernomyrdin. These efforts laid the basis for economic recovery. But in other ways, reform faltered during this period. The government wasted huge amounts of money in subsidies and cheap credit to industry. The disastrous war in Chechnya claimed tens of thousands of lives and wasted billions of dollars.

1996年的总统选举预示着未来的种种困难。叶利钦实现了非凡的政治复兴。他的支持率从最初的5%飙升至几个月后的胜利——在第一轮投票中击败了包括直言不讳的格里戈里·亚夫林斯基在内的多位候选人，然后在第二轮投票中战胜了共产党候选人根纳季·齐加诺夫。叶利钦的竞选活动得到了新贵们的大力资助，他们担心如果共产党获胜，他们将蒙受巨大损失。在第二轮投票的混乱中，叶利钦的顾问们忘记提及他在选举前夕突发心脏病。然而，他的胜利重申了国家的改革路线——以及自1993年以来，在一系列选举和全民公投中，始终有60%的选民支持改革这一事实。与此同时，许多叶利钦支持者的冷淡态度（“两害相权取其轻”）以及共产党的强劲表现，表明许多俄罗斯人对市场体系的出现感到疏离，甚至抱有敌意。

The presidential election of 1996 demonstrated the difficulties ahead. Yeltsin managed an extraordinary political resurrection. He went from popular approval ofjust 5 percent to victory several months later—over a number of candidates in the first round, including an outspoken Grigori Yavlinsky and then, in the runoff, over Gennadi Zyganov, the Communist candidate. Yeltsin’s campaign was well funded by the new rich, who feared that they would lose a great deal were the Communists to win. In the hurly-burly of the runoff, Yeltsin’s advisers forgot to mention that he had suffered a heart attack on the eve of the election. Nevertheless, his victory reaffirmed the nation’s reform course—and the fact that a steady 60 percent of voters has supported reform in a series of elections and referendums since 1993. At the same time, the tepidness of many Yeltsin voters (“the lesser of two evils”) and the strong showing by the Communists demonstrated the estrangement and outright hostility of many Russians to the emergence of the market system.

这并非没有道理。即便新经济蓬勃发展，旧经济却持续衰落。俄罗斯饱受严重的环境问题之苦——这是共产主义遗留下来的顽疾——却缺乏足够的资金进行治理。俄罗斯的婴儿死亡率是欧盟国家的三倍。俄罗斯男性的预期寿命已降至57岁，而美国男性为72岁，中国男性为67岁。退休人员数月领不到养老金；工人领不到工资的时间更长。共产主义时代那种可预测性和人身安全感（对普通民众而言）已荡然无存；低水平但覆盖面广的社会保障体系也已支离破碎。拖欠账单已成为经济中的普遍现象——首先是政府，它根本无法征收税款。

And for good reason. Even as the new economy grows, the old one continues its decline. The nation suffers severe environmental problems—a lasting inheritance from communism—for which it has few funds for remediation. Russia’s infant mortality rate is three times that of the European Union countries. Life expectancy for Russian males has fallen to fifty-seven years, compared to seventy-two for males in the United States and sixtyseven in China. Pensioners go for months without receiving their pensions; workers, even longer without receiving their wages. The predictability and physical security (for the average citizen) of the communist era are gone; the low-level but universal social safety net is in tatters. Nonpayment of bills is endemic in the economy—beginning with the government, which cannot collect taxes.

腐败和犯罪的普遍存在威胁着新体制的合法性，并削弱了其有效运作所必需的共识。腐败的程度并不令人意外。数千亿美元的国有资产唾手可得；争夺其中一部分的斗争必然是疯狂而残酷的。改革缺乏透明度和进展缓慢进一步助长了腐败，这两点都为权钱交易和私下交易提供了大量机会。外国投资者的处境并不稳固；俄罗斯合作伙伴仍然可以卷款潜逃，而法院几乎无法提供任何追索途径。有组织犯罪——俄罗斯黑手党——已经将其触角伸入新经济的各个角落。保护费勒索盛行，富有的、装备精良的犯罪分子完全可以与士气低落、薪酬微薄（有时甚至没有薪酬）的警察部队抗衡。

The pervasive problems of corruption and crime threaten the legitimacy of the new system and undercut the consensus necessary to its effective functioning. The extent of corruption is not surprising. Hundreds of billions of dollars of state property were up for grabs; the scramble to get a share was bound to be frenetic and rough. Corruption has been further promoted by the lack of clarity and uncertain speed of reform, both of which have provided plenty of opportunity for favors and private deals. Foreign investors are not on secure grounds; Russian partners can still abscond with a joint venture, and courts hardly provide a recourse. Organized crime—the Russian mafia—has managed to extend its tentacles deep into the new economy. Protection rackets are endemic, and the rich, well-armed criminals are more than a match for a demoralized and underpaid (and sometimes unpaid) police force.

1996年的选举之后，俄罗斯陷入了长达八个月的沉寂。叶利钦胜选后的主要议题是他的心脏手术。术后，他因双侧肺炎而休养，这使得他的盟友和反对者都异常关注他的身体状况。国家杜马（议会）继续被反改革势力把持，其中包括共产党人和民族主义者。俄罗斯的政治体制已经演变成俄罗斯分析家莉莉娅·舍夫佐娃所描述的“混合政体”，它由“看似不相容的民主、威权主义、民粹主义、寡头政治、裙带关系，甚至无政府主义”等原则构成。自叶利钦连任以来，最引人注目的发展是集中在七大银行的新兴商业精英的政治权力日益增长，这些银行控制着媒体，并正在掌控着重要的工业领域。就在几年前，这些银行的掌门人还是收入微薄的工程师、科学家和学者。如今他们已是亿万富翁，被称为寡头集团。“他们是寡头，”一位知名政治家说道，“因为他们拥有金钱、权力和媒体。”他们毫不掩饰地在持续不断的国有资产所有权争夺战中运用着自己的权力。

The 1996 election was followed by eight months of lassitude. The main item on the agenda after Yeltsin’s victory was his open-heart surgery. His recovery was marred by double pneumonia,which left both his allies and his opponents focused, to an unusual degree, on his physical fragility. The Duma (parliament) continued to be dominated by antireform forces, both Communists and nationalists. The political system had become what has been described by Russian analyst Lilia Shevtsova as a “hybrid regime,” made up of “seemingly incompatible principles of democracy, authoritarianism, populism, oligarchy, nepotism, and even anarchy.” The most striking development since Yeltsin’s réélection has been the growing political power of the new business elite concentrated in the seven big banks, which dominate the media and are gaining control of significant parts of industry. Just a few years ago, the heads of these banks were poorly paid engineers, scientists, and academics. Now they are billionaires, and known as the oligarchy. “They are oligarchs,” said one prominent politician, “because they have money, power, and the media.” And they unabashedly wield their power in the continuing struggle over ownership of state assets.

直到1997年初叶利钦康复后，改革的决心才得以重燃。这位“沙皇鲍里斯”重振旗鼓的第一个迹象，便是叶利钦再次进行内阁整顿，并在1997年3月任命阿纳托利·丘拜斯为第一副总理。一份发给丘拜斯的备忘录警告他，如果不着手解决预算、税收、养老金和腐败等紧迫问题，将会面临巨大风险。税收问题尤其棘手，税率高得离谱、令人费解，而实际税收却低得离谱。备忘录的作者指出，总体而言，政府正面临“极度缺乏信任”的局面，如果这些问题得不到解决，将会“彻底摧毁整个改革努力的信誉”。备忘录还敦促他孤立政府中的“反对改革的‘可憎分子’”。

It was only after Yeltsin’s recovery early in 1997 that the commitment to reform renewed. The first sign that “Boris the czar” had bounced back was another housecleaning by Yeltsin and the appointment in March 1997 of Anatoly Chubais as first deputy prime minister. A memo for Chubais warned him of the risks of not coming to grips with the urgent problems of the budget, taxation, pensions, and corruption. Taxation was particularly difficult, as the rates were ridiculously high and confusing and the actual collections ridiculously low. Overall, the authors of the memo declared, the government was facing an “extreme lack of trust,” and failure to make progress on these issues would “destroy the credibility of the entire reform effort.” The memo also urged him to isolate the “odiousniks”—the antireform “odious ones”—in the government.

不久之后，叶利钦任命了另一位第一副总理——鲍里斯·涅姆佐夫，一位从物理学家转型为政治家的人物。作为深受民众爱戴的下诺夫哥罗德省省长，涅姆佐夫在那里推行的改革步伐比其他任何地区都快。他自豪地称自己是“从外省来到莫斯科的”。叶利钦在争取他时，涅姆佐夫问他：“鲍里斯·尼古拉耶维奇，你想以怎样的形象载入史册？成为一位贤明伟大的沙皇……还是另有所图？”叶利钦回答说：“我不想生活在一个匪帮横行的国家。”基于此，涅姆佐夫接受了第一副总理的职位。正如他所说，他认为自己的工作很大一部分在于执行“通俗易懂、清晰明了、人人平等的规则”。他解释说，“资本最初积累的时期——即使在美国，也总是伴随着匪患、腐败、游说等等……这个时期在俄罗斯正在结束。”

Shortly thereafter, Yeltsin appointed another first deputy prime minister—Boris Nemtsov, a physicist-turned-politician. As the popular governor of the province of Nizhni Novgorod, Nemtsov had pushed the pace of reform faster there than in any other region. He proudly styled himself a “provincial” who had come to Moscow. When Yeltsin was courting him, Nemtsov asked him, “Boris Nikolaevich, how do you want to go down in history. As a good and great tsar … or do you want the contrary?” Yeltsin replied, “I do not want to live in a bandit state.” On the basis of that, Nemtsov took the post of first deputy prime minister. He saw a good part of his job, as he put it, in implementing “understandable, clear rules, which are identical for everyone.” For, he explained, “the period of initial accumulation of capital—which always, even in America, was accompanied by banditry, corruption, lobbyism, and so forth … that period is ending in Russia.”

叶利钦的新团队正寻求重振改革——从持续推进预算和税收改革，到监管和控制垄断企业，再到构建新的社会保障体系。政府还必须找到一种方法……解决拖欠工人和老年人工资及养老金这一极具政治敏感性的问题。与此同时，叶利钦及其团队试图使政府与寡头——银行家——保持距离，并约束他们。“国家绝不容忍来自企业和银行代表的任何施压企图，”叶利钦在1997年秋季向俄罗斯议会坚定地表示。他还宣布政府的退让已经结束：“我们将从不干预政策坚定地转向对经济过程进行先发制人的监管政策……市场本身并非万能药。在任何文明国家，市场机制和国家监管都是和谐运作的。”如今，根本任务已经改变。不再是解散苏联体制，而是建立一个现代政府。 “俄罗斯人正在建设一个新国家，”俄罗斯新资本主义专家塞恩·古斯塔夫森说，“不是那种拥有和直接管理一切的苏联国家，而是一个监管国家，充当着比赛场上的裁判。”

Yeltsin’s new team is seeking to reinvigorate reform—from continued budgetary and tax reform to regulation and control of monopolies to the construction of a new safety net. The government also has to find a way to solve the politically explosive problem of getting workers and the elderly their unpaid wages and pensions. At the same time, Yeltsin and his team have sought to distance the government from the oligarchy—the bankers—and rein them in. “The state will not put up with any attempt at pressure from the representatives of business and banks,” Yeltsin firmly told the Russian parliament in the autumn of 1997. And he declared that the retreat of government was over: “From the policy of nonintervention, we are going resolutely going over to a policy of preemptive regulation of economic processes…. In itself, the market is not a cure-all. In any civilized state, the market mechanism and state regulation work in harmony.” The fundamental mandate has now changed. It is no longer to dismantle the Soviet system but rather to create a modern government. “The Russians are building a new state,” said Thane Gustafson, an expert on Russia’s new capitalism, “not a Soviet state that is owner and direct manager, but rather a regulatory state that is the referee over the playing field.”

这意味着要制定相应的规则，使人们能够更有信心、更可预测地做出决策。在银行和证券监管方面，无论是在规则制定还是运营方面，都取得了显著进展。1993年，莫斯科还没有真正意义上的股票市场。1996年以及1997年的大部分时间里，在叶利钦政治和经济复苏的推动下，俄罗斯股市成为全球表现最佳的新兴市场。来自西方的投资不断涌入，官方公布的投资额已从1996年的每天500万美元增至1997年的每天1亿美元以上（直至动荡时期）。据估计，至少有300家公司符合西方股权投资的条件。

This means getting the rules in place so that people can make decisions with greater confidence and predictability. On banking and securities regulation, considerable progress has been made on both rules and operations. In 1993, there was no real stock market in Moscow. In 1996 and through most of 1997—spurred by Yeltsin’s political and physical recovery—the Russian stock market was the best-performing emerging market in the world. Increasing investment is flowing in from the West, and the officially reported volumes have risen from $5 million a day in 1996 to upward of $100 million a day in 1997 (until the turmoil). By one estimate, at least three hundred companies could qualify for Western equity investment.

最大的失败——也是改革的最大威胁——依然是法律程序，尤其是在产权方面，而产权仍然是市场体系的基石。法律体系运转不畅；法院资金不足，且受制于地方政治势力。“私人投资的主要障碍在于所有权仍然不明确，法律体系无法保护产权，”叶利钦的首席经济顾问之一谢尔盖·瓦西里耶夫指出。这对新企业，无论规模大小，都是一个特别大的威胁。数十万家新企业如雨后春笋般涌现。这些企业家特别容易受到腐败和税收不确定性、地方和州政客的“干预”、保护费勒索以及令人沮丧的暴力威胁（甚至更糟的暴力）的侵害。正如瓦西里耶夫所指出的，“暴力对市场的危害远大于腐败。你可以通过放松管制来打击腐败，但你无法通过放松管制来打击暴力。”然而，这些新兴公司带来了创新和活力，带来了新的人才和新的思维方式，它们将在塑造新经济和创造新经济所需就业机会方面发挥重要作用——其作用远超许多人的预期。它们是必须加以培育的创新者。正如塞恩·古斯塔夫森所观察到的，“俄罗斯未来繁荣发展的最大隐患在于小企业发展缓慢。”

The biggest failure—and biggest threat to reform—continues to be the legal process, particularly as it relates to property rights, which are still the fundament of a market system. The legal system functions poorly; courts are underfinanced and beholden to local political forces. “The major impediment to private investment is that ownership is still not clear and the legal system does not protect property rights,” observed Sergei Vasiliev, one of Yeltsin’s chief economic advisers. This is a particular threat to new businesses, whether small or not. Several hundred thousand new firms have appeared. These entrepreneurs are particularly vulnerable to corruption and uncertain taxes, the unwanted “management hand” of local and state politicians, protection rackets, and the demoralizing threats—or worse—of violence. As Vasiliev noted, “Violence is much more dangerous to the market than corruption. You can fight corruption by deregulation, but you cannot fight violence by deregulation.” Yet those new companies bring innovation and dynamism, new people and new ways of thinking, and they will have a major role—bigger than many anticipate—in shaping the new economy and creating the jobs it requires. They are the innovators that must be nurtured. As Thane Gustafson observed, “The most serious shortcoming for the future of a prosperous Russia is the slowness with which small business is developing.”

尽管如此，俄罗斯的变革速度仍然惊人。“转型期”已经过去。正如叶戈尔·盖达尔所说，“俄罗斯是一个市场经济体，一个年轻、不成熟的市场经济体，但仍然是一个市场经济体。”它的前景可能比人们通常预期的要好。或许，尽管存在诸多差异，但日本的经济奇迹可以作为类比。事实上，到下一个十年初，俄罗斯经济奇迹——“中道”——的基础可能已经在奠定之中。俄罗斯拥有受过高等教育、技能精湛的人口。七十年来，其强大的科技实力首次与市场紧密结合——这在以前是无法想象的。后共产主义时代的一代人已经崛起，他们渴望参与建设一个现代化的工业国家。七十年来积累的巨大商品和服务需求正等待着被满足。如今，俄罗斯已向国际贸易开放，并通过计算机、互联网、电话和传真等技术与全球社会紧密相连。的确，在经历了75年的与世隔绝之后，重新融入世界经济的影响可能是巨大的。而且，这个国家拥有丰富的自然资源。它现在需要的只是游戏规则。17

With all that said, the speed of change in Russia has nevertheless been enormous. The “transition” is past. “Russia is a market economy,” as Yegor Gaidar put it, “a young, immature market economy, but still a market economy.” Its prospects could turn out to be better than is conventionally expected. Perhaps the analogy—for all of the differences—of Japan’s economic miracle is relevant. Indeed, the basis may already be in the process of being laid for a Russian economic miracle—a chudo—by the beginning of the next decade. The country possesses a highly educated population with considerable skills. For the first time in seven decades, its great scientific and technical capabilities are linked to the marketplace—something heretofore impossible. A postcommunist generation has already emerged, eager to partake in the building of a modern industrial country. An enormous pent-up demand for goods and services, built up over seven decades, waits to be satisfied. The nation, now open to international trade and commerce, is tied into the global community by the enabling technologies of computers, Internet, telephone, and fax. Indeed, the impact of being plugged into the world economy after three quarters of a century of isolation could prove enormous. And the country possesses a huge abundance of natural resources. What it still needs are the rules of the game.17

伏特加制造商

The Vodka Maker

历史中处处可见延续性。一个多世纪前，在托尔斯泰的杰作《安娜·卡列尼娜》中，画家戈列尼谢夫就曾抱怨“新俄罗斯人”。他告诉安娜和弗龙斯基伯爵，这些人都是唯利是图的商人，衣着俗艳，缺乏文化修养，一心追求财富。这几乎与今天一些俄罗斯知识分子对现代“新俄罗斯人”的批评如出一辙。然而，正是这些新俄罗斯人将缔造后共产主义经济。

Continuities wind through history. More than a century ago, in Tolstoy’s masterpiece Anna Karenina, the painter Golenishchev complained about “the new Russians.” They were commercial people, he told Anna and Count Vronsky, garish, devoid of culture, and focused on wealth. That is almost exactly the same critique that some members of the Russian intelligentsia make today when they talk about the modern “new Russians.” And yet it is the new Russians who will create this postcommunist economy.

如今俄罗斯最知名的面孔之一并非政客或媒体明星，而是一位33岁的工程师出身的企业家，他的照片被印在俄罗斯最畅销的伏特加酒之一的瓶身上。这位名叫弗拉基米尔·多夫甘的男子身材魁梧，黑发浓密，留着浓密的黑色胡须。他拥有企业家们普遍具备的专注力、意志力、信念和说服力，无论他们来自哪个国家。作为俄罗斯新一代企业家的典型代表，他在莫斯科河畔一座现代化的办公大楼里办公。为了提醒人们新俄罗斯面临的风险，这座大楼的安保措施十分严密。在大楼外，人们要穿过一群保安，然后经过两道厚重的安全门，进入大楼后，还要面对更多的保安，他们会仔细盘问每一位访客。

One of the most famous faces in Russia today belongs not to a politician or a media star but to a thirty-three-year-old engineer-turned-entrepreneur, whose photograph adorns what is now one of the best-selling vodkas in Russia. The visage belongs to Vladimir Dovgan. Husky, with black hair and a thick black mustache, he has the focus and willpower, along with the conviction and persuasive skills, that often animate entrepreneurs, whatever their country. A vivid example of Russia’s new entrepreneurs, he operates out of a modern office building on the bank of the Moskva River. As a reminder of the risks of the new Russia, security at the building is tight. Outside, one runs through a cluster of guards, then passes through two sets of thick security doors, only to be met inside by more guards, who carefully scrutinize visitors.

多夫根的经历凸显了新业务在增长和创新源泉中的作用——尽管重点在于重组现有企业。对他个人而言，这实际上是重新连接一条纽带。几十年前，布尔什维克主义似乎就已将他与家人彻底割裂。他成长于远东针叶林区的一个小村庄。他的父亲十一岁时，全家被共产党杀害，成了孤儿，之后一路向东流浪，最终落脚西伯利亚。他外祖父曾是一名企业家。

Dovgan’s experience underlines the role—despite the focus on restructuring existing enterprises—of new business as a source of growth and innovation. For him personally, it is really a case of reconnecting a cord that had appeared to be irreparably severed by bolshevism decades earlier. He grew up in a small village in the taiga of the Far East. His father, orphaned at the age of eleven when the rest of his family was killed by communists, wandered eastward until he ended up in Siberia. His mother’s father had been an entrepreneur.

泰加林地区前途渺茫，为了让多夫甘接受良好的教育，他的父母决定搬回俄罗斯欧洲部分。莫斯科不现实——他们没有在莫斯科居住的许可，而且即便有，租房也要等二十年。于是，他们去了伏尔加河畔的陶里亚蒂，位于莫斯科以南六百英里处。那里正在建设一家与菲亚特合资的巨型汽车工厂。这家工厂计划每年生产数十万辆汽车，急需工人。在那里，一家人可以拥有自己的房子，儿子也能接受教育。多夫甘在工程学院学习后，进入汽车装配线工作。他是一位运动健将，在20世纪80年代末写了一本关于空手道的小册子，销量达六十万册。这笔钱加上他那永不满足的精力，促使他在戈尔巴乔夫将合作社合法化后，创办了一家小型食品机械制造企业。然而，随着20世纪90年代初俄罗斯经济的衰退，他的生意也陷入了困境。他创办了一家连锁披萨店，但由于加盟商不重视质量，最终以失败告终。

There were few prospects in the taiga, and in order to get Dovgan a decent education, his parents decided to move back to European Russia. Moscow was impossible—they did not have a permit to live in the city, and in any event the waiting time for apartments was twenty years. Instead, they went to Togliatti, on the Volga River, six hundred miles south of Moscow, where a giant joint-venture auto factory was being built with Fiat. The plant was slated to produce hundreds of thousands of cars a year, and workers were needed. There, the family could get an apartment, and their son, an education. After studying at an engineering institute, Dovgan went to work on an auto assembly line. A talented athlete, he wrote a small book on karate in the late 1980s. It sold six hundred thousand copies. That provided the capital which, along with his restless energy, led him, after Gorbachev had legalized cooperatives, to start a small machine-making venture for the food business. However, as the Russian economy plummeted in the early 1990s, the business ran into trouble. He started a franchise pizza company that flopped because the franchisees did not pay attention to quality.

但有一天晚上，他做了一个梦——真的是梦——梦见了伏特加。“我梦见一瓶伏特加，上面贴着‘DOVGAN伏特加’的标签，”他说。每年有成千上万人因饮用不纯的伏特加而丧命，他回想起这个梦，觉得可以以一种全新的方式发展这项业务。他让团队放弃机器制造，转而学习所有关于伏特加酿造的知识。几周之内，他们就开始生产自己的伏特加；没过多久，他们就成为了市场领导者，生产数十种不同类型的伏特加。多夫甘始终坚持那些在苏联经济中从未被重视的要素——始终如一的品质，以及快速开发但精心构思的设计，并将其融入市场营销（这在苏联是不存在的）。每一瓶伏特加都贴着一张精美的标签，上面印着弗拉基米尔·多夫甘本人身着燕尾服的肖像。他想传达的信息是：他对自己的产品充满信心。标签的另一面是另一张照片，是一位革命前的俄罗斯人——他的祖父。莫斯科到处都是他产品的广告牌。如今，多夫甘生产数十种其他食品——从沙丁鱼到通心粉——所有产品都印着同样的两张照片。每一瓶伏特加，每一罐食品，都附带一个多夫甘彩票号码。每周，多夫甘的电视节目都会开奖；幸运儿将获得一辆汽车或一次巴黎之旅。收视率非常高。

But then one night he had a dream—literally—about vodka. “I saw a bottle of vodka with the label DOVGAN VODKA on it,” he said. Tens of thousands of people were dying every year from impure vodka, and, reflecting on his dream, he thought that he could develop the business in a new way. He switched his team from machine building to learning everything they could about vodka making. Within a few weeks they were producing their own vodka; and it was not all that long before they were the market leader, producing dozens of different types of vodka. Dovgan has kept a relentless focus on things that had never mattered in the Soviet economy—consistent quality and quickly developed but carefully conceived design work that is integrated into marketing (which did not exist in the Soviet Union). Each bottle comes with an exquisite label that includes the portrait of none other than Vladimir Dovgan, in a tuxedo. His message is that he stands behind his product. On the other side of the label is another picture, of a prerevolutionary Russian—his grandfather. Billboards for his products are all over Moscow. Dovgan is now producing dozens of other food products—from sardines to macaroni—all emblazoned with the same two photographs. Every bottle of vodka, each can of food, comes with a Dovgan lottery number. Every week the numbers are drawn on a Dovgan television show; the lucky winners get a car or a trip to Paris. The viewership is immense.

多夫根总是努力向前看。“我会删除不需要的信息，”他说，“我的一部分永远都在未来。”他为员工创办了一所管理学校，员工们利用周末时间去上课。“这些人不应该被限制。我们需要为新企业打造一个孵化平台。如果有人有了好点子，我们会在一年内将其付诸实践。”他还引入了一些新事物：头脑风暴会议和高强度、高效率的会议，这种会议在俄语中被称为“日本式高强度工作制”。过去几年里，多夫甘总共创办了大约30家公司，业务范围涵盖食品饮料、化工产品分销、建筑、印刷出版等。他并不直接收购食品工厂，而是与工厂签订服务合同——例如，他指导一家老式的苏联沙丁鱼罐头公司，如何在设备陈旧的情况下，适应新的市场。“上周，”他说，“我去了阿斯特拉罕地区。几年前，如果我们提出要让那里的工厂重获新生，人们会把我们当成疯子。但现在，他们主动来找我们，寻求帮助重启工厂。”

Dovgan is always trying to move on. “I erase information I don’t need,” he said. “A part of me is always in the future.” He has established a management school for his employees, which they attend on weekends. “These are people who should not know limits. We need to create a launching pad for new businesses. If somebody has a good idea, we are in the business within a year.” He has also introduced other things that are new: brainstorming sessions and highly intense, concentrated meetings that are known, translated from the Russian, as the “Japanese sweat-squeezing working system.” Altogether, over the last few years Dovgan has established about thirty companies, which range from foods and beverages to chemical distribution to construction to printing and publishing. Rather than buying up food factories, he contracts for their services—teaching, for example, an old-style Soviet sardine company how, despite its antiquated equipment, to interface with the new marketplace. “Last week,” he said, “I was in the Astrakhan region. Several years ago, if we had discussed the idea of bringing the plants there back to life, we would have been looked at like a crazy person. But now they come to us and ask for help to restart the plants.

“在俄罗斯，就像交通堵塞一样，似乎没有规则。但人们开始意识到规则的重要性。例如，陶里亚蒂的出租车总站一度倒闭。但我最近回去的时候，发现整个城市到处都是出租车，服务周到，配备手机，价格低廉。我相信我见证了一个真正的奇迹。虽然不是什么惊天动地的奇迹，但的确是一个奇迹。” 这正是俄罗斯所期盼的奇迹。18

“It may seem that in Russia, as in a traffic jam, there are no rules. But people are beginning to understand that they need rules. For example, taxi terminals died out in Togliatti. They went bankrupt. But when I went back recently, I found that the whole city is full of taxis with great service, mobile phones, and low prices. I believe that I saw a real miracle. Not a big miracle, but a miracle.” Those are the kinds of miracles that Russia awaits.18

第十一章

CHAPTER 11

1941年，在意大利那不勒斯附近海岸的文托泰内岛上，阿尔蒂埃罗·斯皮内利和两位狱友开始着手撰写一份关于新欧洲、统一欧洲的宣言。若非当时的绝望境况，这或许会被视为一项不切实际的计划。希特勒已经征服了西欧，他的军队横扫苏联，恐慌笼罩着苏联的领导层和民众。美国尚未参战，而英国几乎是欧洲抵御法西斯全面控制的最后一道防线。没错，欧洲似乎即将统一——但这并非通过民主的自决，而是通过希特勒的帝国。在这样的背景下，斯皮内利在狱中写下的这份宣言与其说是愿景，不如说是幻觉，是一个垂死之人​​对美好世界的狂热幻想。

IN 1941, on the island of Ventotene, off the coast of Italy near Naples, Altiero Spinelli and two fellow prisoners set about to write a manifesto for a new Europe, a united Europe. Were it not for the desperation of the time, it would have seemed a quixotic undertaking. Hitler had conquered Western Europe, his troops were rolling across the Soviet Union, and panic had gripped the Soviet leadership and population alike. The United States had not yet entered the war, and Britain was virtually the last point of resistance to total fascist control of Europe. Yes, Europe seemed about to be united—but by Hitler’s Reich, not by democratic self-determination. In such circumstances, Spinelli’s manifesto, composed in prison, seemed less like a vision than a hallucination, a dying man’s feverish dream of a better world.

然而，此时的斯皮内利已是一位身经百战的幸存者。他已被监禁了十四年。1924年，他加入了刚刚成立的意大利共产党，与刚刚夺取政权的独裁者贝尼托·墨索里尼及其法西斯分子作斗争。1927年，年仅二十岁的斯皮内利因组织反对派而被判入狱。如果他当时在法庭上说了些合适的话，或许可以免于牢狱之灾，但他拒绝了。1937年，在狱中了解到斯大林的种种行径后，他感到无比厌恶，于是放弃了共产主义，转而成为一名民主社会主义者。

By this time, however, Spinelli was a hardened survivor. He was in the fourteenth year of his incarceration. He had joined the nascent Italian Communist Party in 1924 to fight the dictator Benito Mussolini and his Fascists, who had just seized power. In 1927, at the age of twenty, Spinelli was sentenced to prison for organizing opposition. Had he said the right words to the court, he might have been spared jail, but he refused. In 1937, repulsed by what he had managed to learn in prison about Stalin, he renounced communism and instead became a democratic socialist.

不久之后，他被转移到文托泰内，那里曾是近两千年前尼禄皇帝的流放地，也是法西斯分子关押许多政治犯的地方。在那里，他开始阅读走私来的书籍、小册子和文章——其中许多出自英国思想家之手，他们认为欧洲应该效仿美国革命的模式，建立一个联邦。斯皮内利也深受《联邦党人文集》以及美国开国元勋们思想的影响。

Not long after, he was transferred to Ventotene, where the emperor Nero had been exiled almost two thousand years before and where the Fascists kept many of their political prisoners. There he began to read smuggled books, pamphlets, and articles—many by British thinkers who argued that Europe should follow the model of the American Revolution and create a federal union. Spinelli was also much impressed by what he read of the Federalist Papers and by the thinking of the American founding fathers.

在这些“盎格鲁-撒克逊”小册子中，他找到了解决席卷全球的灾难的办法。他与另外两名囚犯尤金尼奥·科洛尼和埃内斯托·罗西合作，将这一方案阐述在后来被称为《文托泰内宣言》的文件中。宣言认为，民族国家本质上是自我毁灭的，因为它们滋生民族主义，而民族主义一旦滋生，就会变得极端，最终导致独裁、经济危机和战争。避免此类灾难的唯一途径是建立一个联邦制的欧洲，让各个国家更像美国各州。该计划的经济部分是混合经济的社会主义版本。科洛尼的妻子将宣言偷偷带出了文托泰内监狱，她甚至还设法出版了地下报纸《欧洲团结》的第一期。但很难相信当时有人会对此给予足够的重视。人们当时更关心的是生存问题。

Here, in these “Anglo-Saxon” tracts, he found the solution to the cataclysm that had engulfed the world. And in collaboration with two other prisoners, Eugenio Colorni and Ernesto Rossi, he set out the solution in what became known as the Ventotene Manifesto. It argued that nation-states were inherently self-destructive, for they bred nationalism, which became virulent, leading to dictatorship, economic crisis, and war. The only way to avoid such catastrophes was through the creation of a federal Europe, in which individual countries would become more like the American states. The economic component of this plan was a socialist version of the mixed economy. The manifesto was smuggled off Ventotene by Colorni’s wife, who even managed to get published the first issue of an underground newspaper, European Unity. But it is hard to believe that anybody paid much attention at the time. There were more immediate things to worry about, such as survival.

两年后，1943年，战争的局势发生了逆转。苏联军队守住了东线，开始将纳粹击退。盟军登陆意大利海岸，墨索里尼倒台。获释后，斯皮内利带着宣言回到意大利本土，脑海中浮现出一些想法，身边也聚集了一些仰仗他领导的人。他的前狱友兼合著者欧金尼奥·科洛尼在罗马街头被法西斯暴徒殴打致死。斯皮内利后来娶了科洛尼的遗孀，她曾将科洛尼的作品偷运出文托泰内监狱。他还前往瑞士，在那里结识了一些志同道合的欧洲人，并发起了后来成为欧洲一体化运动的事业。《文托泰内宣言》成为了他们的战斗口号。然而，在战争的最后几个月以及战后初期，人们对欧洲一体化并没有太大的兴趣。重建的巨大难题和冷战的阴影笼罩着所有人。但斯皮内利长达十五年的政治囚禁生涯，在他心中深深烙下了两样东西——决心和耐心。1947年，随着马歇尔计划的实施，欧洲一体化的最初基础开始奠定。

Two years later, in 1943, the tide of war turned. The Soviets had held on the eastern front and were beginning to push the Nazis back. The Allies had landed on Italy’s coast, and Mussolini had fallen. Released, Spinelli returned to the Italian mainland with the manifesto in his pocket, a few ideas in his head, and a handful of people who would look to him for leadership. His former fellow prisoner and coauthor Eugenio Colorni died from a beating that fascist thugs gave him on a street in Rome. Spinelli later married Colorni’s widow, who had smuggled his work out of Ventotene. He also made his way to Switzerland, where he established contact with a few like-minded Europeans and launched what became the movement for European unity. The Ventotene Manifesto would be their rallying cry. Yet in the last months of the war, and then in the immediate postwar years, there was not much interest in European unity. The immense problems of reconstruction and the emerging cold war dominated thinking. But Spinelli’s decade and a half as a political prisoner had engrained two things deeply into him—determination and patience. And in 1947, with the Marshall Plan, the first foundations of European unity began to be laid.

四十年后，到了20世纪80年代，欧洲经济共同体已成为现实。欧洲的收入和繁荣程度达到了二战结束时难以想象的水平，尽管冷战持续，欧洲大陆依然保持着和平。然而，各个民族国家仍然各自掌控着自己的经济。被誉为“欧洲之父”的让·莫内已经去世，阿尔蒂埃罗·斯皮内利如今成了欧洲的元老。他也日益感到失望和幻灭。尽管取得了诸多成就，但欧洲一体化进程多年来一直停滞不前；它只不过是一个名义上的关税同盟而已。他脑海中不断浮现出欧内斯特·海明威的《老人与海》。 “你们一定都读过海明威的短篇小说，”他在1983年对欧洲议会说，“讲的是一个老渔夫钓到他一生中最大的一条鱼后，试图把它带回岸边。但鲨鱼一点一点地啃食着它，等老人回到岸边时，只剩下一副骨架了。”他担心，这也会是……的命运。联邦制的欧洲。他已准备好进行最后一次努力。当时他已年近八旬，却依然带头发起争取欧洲联盟条约的斗争。他的努力催生了欧洲一体化的新阶段，使其更接近他在文托泰内岛的梦想——一个联邦制的欧洲。1

Four decades later, by the 1980s, the European Economic Community was a reality. Europe had achieved a level of income and prosperity inconceivable at the end of World War II, and despite the cold war, the peace had held on the Continent. Still, nation-states continued to control their own economies. Jean Monnet, the “Father of Europe,” was dead, and Altiero Spinelli was now the grand old man of Europe. He was also becoming increasingly disappointed and disillusioned. For all that had been achieved, the European project had been stagnating for years; it was not much more than a glorified customs union. What kept coming to his mind was The Old Man and the Sea, by Ernest Hemingway. “You must all know the short story by Hemingway,” he told the European Parliament in 1983, “about an old fisherman who, after catching the biggest fish of his life, tries to get it back to shore. But bit by bit the sharks eat it, so that when the old man returns to shore, all that remains is a skeleton.” That, he feared, would be the fate of federal Europe. He was ready for one last campaign. Already in his late seventies, he took the lead in launching the battle for a treaty for European union. His campaign was the catalyst for a new stage in European integration, much closer to the dream he had had on Ventotene—the dream of a federal Europe.1

双重撤退

The Double Retreat

在20世纪末的欧洲，混合经济和现代​​福利国家诞生于此，但事实上，国家的经济作用正从两个方面显著减弱。一方面，随着如今的欧盟权力不断扩大、单一市场实施以及共同货币的筹备工作，民族国家管理经济的能力正受到极大限制。另一方面，国家正通过私有化、放松管制和减少干预来逐步退出市场。竞争领域正在扩大。与此同时，要求控制和缩减规模庞大的福利国家的呼声也越来越高。随着欧洲一体化，企业和工人正融入一个日益扁平化——甚至超越——国界的体系。企业不再依赖国家监管机构，而是必须重新调整自身定位，与其他能够调动整个欧洲大陆资源的企业展开竞争。否则，就可能意味着彻底失败，因为传统的国家救助保障机制已不复存在。

At the end of the twentieth century in Europe, where the mixed economy and the modern welfare state were born, the economic role of the state is in fact being significantly reduced—from two directions. On one side, the nation-state’s capacity to manage its economy is being sharply restricted by the broadening of the powers of what has now become the European Union, the implementation of the “single market,” and preparations for a common currency.1 On the other side, the state is retreating by means of privatization, deregulation, and reduced intervention. The realm of competition is expanding. At the same time, there are increased pressures to rein in and reduce the expansive welfare state. As Europe unites, companies and workers are becoming part of a system that flattens—and indeed transcends—borders. Instead of looking to a national regulator, firms must reorient themselves to compete against other firms that can muster Continent-wide resources. Failure to do so can mean outright failure, since the traditional safety net of the national bailout no longer exists.

当各国经济参与者正匆忙为更加激烈的竞争做准备时，欧元——这个统一欧洲的货币——在20世纪90年代末的引入，将会带来全面的影响。纸币上印有君主、总统、总理、财政部长、将军和英雄的肖像，体现着国家认同。货币控制权是主权的重要组成部分。将这种控制权移交给超国家机构，实际上意味着国家主权的削弱。

While the players in national economies are hastily preparing themselves for far more intense competition, the full impact awaits the introduction of the euro, the currency of a united Europe, at the end of the 1990s. Paper money—with its images of monarchs, presidents, prime ministers, finance ministers, generals, and heroes—embodies national identity. Control of currency is one of the essences of sovereignty. Handing over that control to supranational institutions truly represents a diminution of national sovereignty.

这一趋势始于20世纪80年代中期，当时斯皮内利等人发起了一场复兴欧洲一体化的运动。但在此之前，人们对国家在市场经济中的角色进行了彻底的重新思考，并涌现出一种新型的社会主义者——不信奉社会主义的社会主义者。在整个欧洲大陆，没有哪个地方比法国更能体现这一点，因为法国是科尔伯特主义（以路易十四专横跋扈的财政大臣命名）和指挥主义（法国人称之为其传统政策）的发源地。（中央集权和国家经济控制体系）。法国的变革为欧洲的变革奠定了基础。

Movement in this direction started in the mid-1980s, with the campaign by Spinelli and others to revive the European project. But it was preceded by a dramatic reconceptualization of the role of the state in the marketplace and the wholesale emergence of a new kind of socialist—socialists without socialism. And nowhere on the Continent did this occur more vividly than in France, for it is the country of Colbertism (named for Louis XIV’s domineering finance minister) and dirigisme (as the French call their traditional system of centralization and state economic control). The changes in France set the stage for the changes in Europe.

法国：“与资本主义决裂”

France: “The Break with Capitalism”

巴黎是一座在关键时刻上演国家政治的城市，1981年5月10日正是这样一个时刻。当晚，整座城市洋溢着昔日的热情，街头巷尾都洋溢着欢乐的气氛。这一切都是为了庆祝弗朗索瓦·密特朗当选为法兰西第五共和国首位社会党总统。这是一场势均力敌的选举，但最终密特朗胜出。选举几天后，他前往拉丁区的先贤祠，向逝者致敬；他在让·饶勒斯的陵墓前驻足良久。饶勒斯是世纪之交伟大的法国社会党领袖，此后一直是无共产主义左翼的守护神。密特朗显然是在宣称自己是饶勒斯的继承人，而且他完全有理由这样做。他上任时就致力于建立一个社会主义法国，向“金钱之墙”宣战，并兑现了长期以来承诺的“与资本主义决裂”。

Paris is a city on whose streets national politics, at critical moments, are acted out. And May 10, 1981, was such a time. That evening, the city exploded with old-fashioned fervor and joyous street parties. All this was to celebrate the election of François Mitterrand as the first Socialist president under the Fifth Republic. It was a very close race, but Mitterrand had done it. A few days after the election, he visited the Pantheon in the Latin Quarter to pay respects to the dead; he paused an especially long time by the mausoleum of Jean Jaurès, the great French socialist leader of the turn of the century and patron saint of the noncommunist left ever since. Mitterrand was clearly laying claim to being his heir, and with very good justification. He was coming to office committed to creating a socialist France, declaring war against the “wall of money,” and delivering the decisive and longpromised “break with capitalism.”

密特朗和他在新政府中的社会主义同志们决心，政府将以人民的名义，巩固并扩展法国传统的国家干预主义，并通过国有化和其他形式的控制，对经济施加更大的指导作用。这正是所有支持者所期待的，而密特朗也确实做到了——至少在一段时间内是这样。法国社会党人发起了近几十年来工业化世界中最激进的“加强国家干预”运动——尤其引人注目的是，这与撒切尔夫人和里根试图朝相反方向发展的努力几乎同时发生。密特朗的纲领融合了凯恩斯主义的经济管理、国有化和国家控制。然而，意识形态终究无法抵挡冷酷的经济现实。

Mitterrand and his Socialist comrades in the new government were determined that the government would, in the name of the people, build upon and expand France’s traditional dirigisme and exert much greater direction over the economy through both nationalization and other kinds of control. That was what all those celebrating supporters expected, and that was what Mitterrand delivered—for a time. The French Socialists began with the boldest drive in recent decades to implement “more state” in the industrial world—all the more striking as it took place contemporaneously with Margaret Thatcher and Ronald Reagan’s efforts to move in the opposite direction. Mitterrand’s program was an amalgam of Keynesian economic management, nationalization, and state control. But ideology would not be able to resist cold economic realities.

米特朗是法国政坛的生存大师。这位后来担任法国总统直至1995年的人，早在二战结束的1946年，年仅30岁的他就已在拉马迪埃政府中担任内阁部长。在法兰西第四共和国时期，他属于中左翼激进派。和戴高乐一样，他深谙角色扮演和自我塑造的重要性，多年来，他把自己塑造成一位思想家和文人——考虑到他的文学天赋，这并非毫无道理。他似乎也是一位永不言败的挑战者——1965年，他先是败给了戴高乐，1974年又以微弱劣势输给了瓦莱里·吉斯卡尔·德斯坦。1981年，他再次挑战吉斯卡尔，这一次，他赢了。

Mitterrand was a master survivor in French politics. The man who would be France’s president until 1995 was already a cabinet minister at age thirty in the 1946 Ramadier government, at the end of World War II. In the days of the Fourth Republic, he was on the center-left, a Radical. Like Charles de Gaulle, he knew the importance of playacting and selfcreation, and over the years he cast himself as a thinker and man of letters—though not without reason, considering his literary gifts. He also seemed the perennial challenger—losing the presidency first to de Gaulle in 1965 and then, by the slimmest of margins, to Valéry Giscard d’Estaing in 1974. In 1981, he went back for a return bout against Giscard. And that time he won.

1981 年的胜利是密特朗及其盟友十年来重组（实际上是彻底改变）法国左翼的结果。从1971年到1981年的十年间，他们建立了一个组织强大的社会党，取代了第四共和国时期软弱且妥协的左翼残余势力。此外，他们还与共产党缔结了团结协议，预示着阶级斗争的爆发以及国家对经济更严格的控制，包括大规模的国有化。

The 1981 victory was the result of a decade of work by Mitterrand and his allies to recompose—indeed, dramatically transform—the left in France. In the ten years from 1971 to 1981, they built an organizationally strong Socialist Party to replace the weak and compromised remnants of the left from the Fourth Republic. In addition, they forged a unity pact with the Communist Party that portended class warfare and much greater state control of the economy, including extensive nationalization.
