事实上，没有共产党，社会党就无法取得进展。即使到了20世纪70年代末，法国共产党仍然是一支强大的政治力量，经常在选举中赢得20%的选票。这个阴郁的法国共产党仍然带有宗派主义的斯大林式阴郁色彩，它回避了内部改革和辩论，而正是这些改革和辩论使意大利和西班牙共产党走向了后来被称为欧洲共产主义的道路。在新政府中，密特朗只给了共产党四个部长职位——总共44个。而且都是次要职位。与此同时，他小心翼翼地向世界其他国家发出信号，让他们不必担心。就在共产党人进入政府担任部长的当天，他特意接见了副总统乔治·布什，并把他当作贵宾。

Indeed, the Socialists could not advance without the Communists. Even at the end of the 1970s, the French Communist Party was a potent political force, frequently winning 20 percent of the vote in elections. Still characterized by a sectarian Stalinist gloom, the dour French party had eschewed the internal reforms and debates that had moderated the Italian and Spanish Communist parties into what became known as Eurocommunism. In the new government, Mitterrand gave the Communists just four ministerial places—out of a total of forty-four. All were secondary posts. At the same time, he took care to signal the rest of the world not to worry. On the very day that the Communists entered the government as ministers, he made a point of receiving as his guest of honor Vice-Président George Bush.

密特朗及其同僚决心确立政府对经济的主导地位。他们推出了一系列旨在刺激经济摆脱低迷状态的广泛措施。按照经典的凯恩斯主义传统，政府将大规模支出以启动经济。与此同时，国家加强了对主要行业的控制和协调，以确保它们以“正确的方式”运作。政府将银行（96%的存款）和许多大型工业企业收归国有，其中包括20家最大的工业公司中的13家，并控股了许多其他公司。政府大幅增加了社会支出，每周减少一小时工作时间而不减薪，将带薪假期从四周增加到五周，并新增了10万名政府雇员。这项公共支出和国有化计划，加上对高收入人群增税，被称为“重启”（ la relance）。

Mitterrand and his associates were determined to assert government sway over the economy. They launched a broad set of measures intended to stimulate the economy out of its sluggishness. In the classic Keynesian tradition, the government would spend on a vast scale in order to jump-start the economy. At the same time, the state increased its control and coordination of the major industries to ensure that they acted in the “right way.” It nationalized banks (96 percent of deposits) and many large industrial companies, including thirteen of the twenty largest industrial corporations, and took controlling shares in many other companies. It vastly increased social spending, cut an hour from the workweek with no loss of pay, increased paid vacations from four to five weeks, and hired another hundred thousand government workers. This program of public spending and nationalization, along with increased taxes on high incomes, became known as la relance—or “the relaunching.”

但“重启经济”立即引发了资本市场的广泛恐慌，导致法郎持续贬值。它非但没有刺激经济增长，反而滋生了通货膨胀，刺激了资本外逃，并掏空了国库。失业率急剧上升。新近国有化的产业亏损巨大，极大地加剧了财政赤字。法国濒临破产，社会党也岌岌可危。密特朗和他的同僚们必须被拯救于水火之中。2

But la relance immediately set off widespread panic in the capital markets, leading to continuing assaults on the value of the French currency. Instead of stimulating growth, la relance bred inflation, stimulated capital flight, and drained money out of the treasury. Unemployment increased dramatically. The newly nationalized industries were losing enormous amounts of money, contributing mightily to the swelling budget deficit. France was heading for bankruptcy, and the Socialists, for disaster. Mitterrand and his colleagues had to be saved from themselves.2

德洛尔先生和第二左派

M. Delors and the Second Left

这项任务落到了雅克·德洛尔身上，他曾被誉为“他那一代最成功的欧洲社会主义者”。德洛尔的父亲是法国银行的一名信使，他无疑成长于一个较为优渥的工人阶级家庭。他的资历甚至超过了那些精英名校的毕业生。 1940年德军攻入巴黎时，年轻的德洛尔和母亲辗转火车、卡车、徒步逃离，最终在乡下祖父母家找到了避难所。战争及其后的种种困境使德洛尔失去了上大学的机会。于是，他在法兰西银行找到了一份低级工作，利用晚上时间自学，凭借着过人的才智和勤奋努力一步步晋升。他是一位自学成才的人，从未停止过学习。他的早期导师之一，政治家皮埃尔·孟戴斯-弗朗斯曾评价他：“德洛尔是个勤奋的人——他的优势在于自学成才，因此他的知识非常扎实。”他痴迷于美国爵士乐和电影，甚至还创办了自己的电影俱乐部。

That task fell to Jacques Delors, who was once described as the “most successful European Socialist of his generation.” The son of a messenger at the Bank of France, Delors certainly grew up with better working-class credentials than the graduates of the elitist grandes écoles. When the Germans marched into Paris in 1940, young Delors and his mother fled by train, truck, and foot, finally finding refuge with his grandparents in the countryside. The conditions of the war and its aftermath denied Delors the opportunity to go to university. Instead, he found a low-level job at the Bank of France, took courses at night, and proceeded to rise by dint of intellect and hard work. He was an autodidact; he never stopped studying. One of his early mentors, the politician Pierre Mendès-France, once said of him that “Delors is a good workhorse—his asset is to be self-taught and therefore concrete.” He was obsessed with American jazz and film and even established his own film club.

他也成为了一名社会主义者，尽管并非马克思主义者。他曾自称是“法国左翼中唯一一个从未对共产主义和马克思主义着迷的人”。相反，他被天主教左翼所吸引，尤其推崇埃马纽埃尔·穆尼埃的哲学思想。穆尼埃于1950年去世，享年45岁。他提出的个人主义主张强调团结、社群、内在精神复兴以及政治革新。个人主义反对的不仅是自由资本主义的个人主义，还有马克思主义和极权主义。多年来，德洛尔反复研读穆尼埃的著作，穆尼埃的思想成为他政治理念和对欧洲社会福利国家模式的坚定信念的基石。

He also became a socialist, although not a Marxist. He once described himself as “the only man on the French left” who had “never been fascinated by communism and Marxism.” Instead, he was drawn to the Catholic left, and in particular to the philosophy of Emmanuel Mounier, who died in 1950 at age forty-five. Mounier propounded what became known as personalism, which advocated solidarity, community, and an internal spiritual renewal as well as a political renewal. It set itself as much against the individualism of liberal capitalism as against Marxism and totalitarianism. Over the years, Delors would read and reread Mounier, whose ideas would provide the underpinnings of his politics and his commitment to the European model for the social welfare state.

在法国银行工作期间，德洛尔积极参与天主教工会活动，并很快成为工会研究部门的负责人。他善于用简单易懂的方式解释复杂问题，这使他迅速晋升。多年后，密特朗在谈到德洛尔的清晰表达能力时问道：“你是怎么做到的？”

While still working at the Bank of France, Delors became active in the Catholic trade union, and soon emerged as head of the union’s research department. His gift for offering simple, understandable explanations of complex matters helped thrust him forward. Many years later Mitterrand, commenting on Delors’s clarity, asked, “How do you manage it?”

“如果我表达得清楚的话，那是因为我受的教育不多，”德洛尔回答说。“由于我不聪明，所以在理解某些事情之前，我必须付出巨大的努力。”3

“If I’m clear, it’s because I have had little education,” Delors replied. “As I’m not clever, before understanding something I have to make a huge effort.”3

20世纪60年代初，德洛尔进入法国计划总委员会工作。该委员会由让·莫内于二战后创立，旨在指导法国的重建工作。他的工作引起了包括戴高乐在内的高级官员的注意，德洛尔开始在官僚机构中步步高升。与此同时，他积极参与政治活动，投身于“第二左翼”运动。该运动摒弃了传统所谓雅各宾左翼的马克思主义教条，并对国家主义和官僚主义持批判态度。60年代末，德洛尔成为一位改革派戴高乐主义总理的经济顾问，这引起了其他社会党人的极大怀疑。他们认为他已经倒戈了。然而，随着社会党在20世纪70年代进行重组，更关注政治而非经济的弗朗索瓦·密特朗意识到自己需要帮助，于是将德洛尔从政治边缘拉了出来，任命他为社会党国际经济部门负责人。1981年社会党赢得大选后，德洛尔成为密特朗的财政部长。

In the early 1960s, Delors went to work for the Commissariat Général du Plan, which had been founded by Jean Monnet after World War II to guide France’s reconstruction. His work caught the eye of senior officials, including Charles de Gaulle, and Delors began to advance up through the bureaucracy. At the same time, he was active in politics, in the “Second Left,” which rejected Marxist dogmas of the traditional so-called Jacobin left and was critical of statism and bureaucracy. At the end of the 1960s, Delors became economic adviser to a reformist Gaullist prime minister, which engendered great suspicions among other Socialists. He had, they thought, gone over to the other side. Nevertheless, as the Socialists reorganized themselves in the 1970s, François Mitterrand, who cared much more about politics than economics, recognized that he needed help, and he brought Delors in from political purgatory to be head of the international economics department of the Socialist Party. With the Socialist victory in 1981, Delors became Mitterrand’s finance minister.

“现金流焚烧炉”

“Cash-Flow Incinerators”

德洛尔并没有像他的社会主义同僚那样被狂热的情绪所裹挟。毕竟，他是他们当中唯一一位拥有政府实践经验的人。上任伊始，他就试图平息资本市场对社会主义纲领的恐慌。他曾试图将国有化运动的影响降到最低，但未能成功。然而，他的回旋余地十分有限。在许多人眼中，他的社会主义背景颇具争议；尽管他是财政部长，但在礼仪顺序中却仅排在第十六位，预算职能被剥离出来，交给了年轻的密特朗门生洛朗·法比尤斯，后者正热情地推行社会主义议程。德洛尔无力阻止法比尤斯大幅增加社会支出。他不得不批准这些支出，以及支付给被国有化公司被征用股份的股东的数十亿法郎补偿金。之后，他又不得不筹集数十亿法郎来弥补这些公司的损失。正如一位商人所言，国有化企业简直就是“现金流焚烧机”，政府的损失持续攀升。整体经济形势迅速恶化，1981年和1982年，法郎持续承受贬值压力。

Delors was not swept up in the same euphoria that engulfed his Socialist colleagues. After all, he was the only one among them with practical experience in government. Immediately upon taking office, he tried to calm the panic in the capital markets over the Socialist program. He sought, unsuccessfully, to minimize the nationalization campaign. But his room for maneuvering was slim. His Socialist credentials were problematic in the eyes of many; although he was the finance minister, he was only sixteenth in the order of protocol, and the budget function was hived off and handed to a young Mitterrand protégé, Laurent Fabius, who was enthusiastically promoting the Socialist agenda. Delors was not able to prevent Fabius from driving vast increases in social spending. He had to sign off on those expenditures, as well as on the billions of francs in compensation to the expropriated shareholders of the now-nationalized companies. He then had to find still billions more to cover the companies’ losses. The nationalized companies proved to be, in the words of one businessman, “cash-flow incinerators,” and the government’s losses continued to mount. The overall economic situation deteriorated rapidly, and throughout 1981 and 1982, the franc was under constant pressure.

一场旨在彻底改变密特朗政府路线的斗争就此展开。这场斗争由德洛尔领导。“在这辆火车上，是我要求减少燃料消耗，”他曾这样解释道。最终，他找到了总理皮埃尔·莫鲁瓦作为盟友。莫鲁瓦也意识到，疯狂的支出并没有带来预期的效果。他和德洛尔联手推行纪律和紧缩政策，并与主导政府的左翼“雅各宾派”作斗争。他们有时白天能赢得密特朗的同意，但到了晚上，一些有影响力的“夜访者”（取自一部著名法国电影的片名）会悄悄潜入爱丽舍宫，觐见密特朗并游说他采取相反的立场。这些“夜访者”力主保护主义，并告诉密特朗法国应该使其货币与其他欧洲货币脱钩，尤其是与德国马克脱钩。密特朗相信政治意志可以克服经济问题，因此他最终会改变立场，支持这些“夜访者”的观点。

Now began a battle to alter radically the course of the Mitterrand government. It was led by Delors. “On board this locomotive, I was the one demanding that we put less coal in the engine,” he once explained. He eventually found an ally in prime minister Pierre Mauroy, who had come to see that the spending frenzy was not bringing the promised results. He and Delors conspired to impose discipline and austerity and to combat the leftist “Jacobins” who dominated the government. They would sometimes win Mitterrand’s assent by day, but by night, influential “evening visitors”—nicknamed after the title of a famous French film—would slip into the Elysée Palace to see Mitterrand and lobby otherwise. The evening visitors urged protectionism and told Mitterrand that France should delink its currency from the other European currencies, particularly the deutsche mark. Mitterrand, who believed that political will could overcome economic problems, would backtrack and endorse the positions of the evening visitors.

内阁内部也上演了这场斗争。“除了增长别无选择，”德洛尔的一位反对者在一次内阁会议上宣称，“我们必须调动储蓄，开展大规模借贷活动。”

The struggles were played out in the cabinet as well. “There is no option but growth,” one of Delors’s opponents declared in a cabinet meeting. “We have to mobilize savings, launch major borrowing campaigns.”

“你们满脑子想的都是借钱，”德洛尔反驳道，“等到我们被国际货币基金组织接管的时候，你们肯定会怪我。我们没钱了，根本借不到钱！”

“All you talk about is borrowing,” Delors retorted. “And when we come under International Monetary Fund receivership, you’ll blame me. There is no money left. We cannot borrow!”

“我们必须减少消费，降低购买力，”德洛尔的盟友、总理皮埃尔·莫鲁瓦补充道。

“We have to reduce consumption, cut back on purchasing power,” added Delors’s ally, Prime Minister Pierre Mauroy.

一直沉默不语的密特朗突然插话道：“我任命你来这里不是为了推行撒切尔夫人的政策。”4

Silent up to this point, Mitterrand abruptly interjected, “I did not appoint you here in order to pursue Mrs. Thatcher’s policies.”4

然而，面对严峻的经济现实，政治意愿的作用终究有限。国际收支状况糟糕透顶，而且还在不断恶化。针对法郎的投机性攻击持续不断。法国甚至不得不屈辱地向沙特阿拉伯寻求紧急贷款，以试图遏制法郎的投机行为。

Yet political will could do only so much in the face of economic reality. The balance of payments was in awful shape, and getting worse. The speculative assault against the franc was relentless. France even had to resort, however humiliatingly, to an emergency loan from Saudi Arabia to try to stem the speculation against the franc.

大转弯

The Great U-Turn

1983年3月对法国乃至某种意义上的欧洲来说都是一个关键时刻。社会党在地方选举中惨败，紧张局势加剧。如何摆脱通货膨胀的恶性循环？如何保住法郎？究竟该怎么办？正是在这令人沮丧的时刻，德洛尔与莫鲁瓦联手策划了后来被称为“大转弯”的政策调整。

March 1983 proved to be the critical moment for France, and in a certain sense for Europe. The Socialists did terribly in local elections. Tensions worsened. How to break out of the inflationary cycle? How to protect the franc? What was, after all, to be done? It was at this dismal moment that Delors, with Mauroy, engineered what became known as the Great U-Turn.

关键问题在于货币。1978年，瓦莱里·吉斯卡尔·德斯坦和德国总理赫尔穆特·施密特谈判达成了欧洲货币体系（EMS），该体系将法郎和其他几种货币与德国马克挂钩，并规定它们的波动范围不得超过约定的限度。如今，法郎汇率持续逼近该体系的下限，一些人——包括“夜间访客”——主张将其退出该体系。然而，德洛尔坚信，欧洲货币体系的崩溃将对欧洲一体化造成毁灭性打击。他成功说服了持怀疑态度的密特朗，指出退出欧洲货币体系将导致法郎贬值20%，进而引发利率大幅上升，这将进一步损害经济并削弱国际收支平衡。随后，在布鲁塞尔举行的周末会谈中，德洛尔咄咄逼人，威胁德国人同意一项妥协方案：马克升值将与法郎贬值同时进行，而法国将留在现有体系内。密特朗为了表彰德洛尔，任命他为经济、财政和预算部部长，使其在礼宾等级中从第十六位跃升至第二位。

The critical issue was money. In 1978, Valéry Giscard d’Estaing and German chancellor Helmut Schmidt had negotiated the European Monetary System (EMS), which tied the franc and several other currencies to the deutsche mark, allowing them to fluctuate only within agreed limits. Now the franc was persistently straining the lower bounds of the system, and some—including the “evening visitors”—argued it should simply be taken out. Delors, however, was convinced that a breakdown of the EMS would be devastating for European unity. He persuaded a skeptical Mitterrand that exiting the EMS would reduce the franc’s value by 20 percent, resulting in an enormous increase in interest rates, which would further hurt the economy and weaken the balance of payments. Then, in a weekend of talks in Brussels, Delors blustered and threatened the Germans into agreeing to a compromise: A revaluation of the mark would accompany the devaluation of the franc, and France would stay in the system. Mitterrand rewarded Delors by making him head of a superministry of economics, finance, and budget, moving him from sixteenth to second in the order of protocol.

德洛尔的成功终结了法郎贬值。从此以后，法国法郎将与德国马克紧密挂钩。由于德国马克强势，法郎也必然强势。这就是所谓“强势法郎” （francfort ）政策理念及其强有力的象征。而强势法郎的要求意味着经济增长不能再依靠人为抬高的出口、贸易保护主义或不受控制的公共支出，而只能依靠提高生产率。通过重新加入欧洲货币体系（EMS），社会党将关注点从需求侧转向了供给侧。法国也更加牢固地融入了欧洲经济共同体的市场和机构，再也不能以传统的民族视角来思考问题了。

Delors’s success brought an end to the devaluations. From here on, France would keep its currency closely linked to the D-mark. Because the D-mark was strong, the franc would be strong too. Thus was bom the policy idea and powerful symbol of the so-calledfrancfort, or “strong franc.” And the requirement of a strong franc meant that growth could not come from artificially high exports, protectionism, or uncontrolled public spending. Instead, it could come only from increased productivity. By recommitting to the EMS, the Socialists were shifting their focus from the demand side to the supply side. France was also now lodged much more firmly in the market and institutions of the European Economic Community. It could no longer think in the traditional national perspective.

通过欧洲货币体系稳定法郎标志着大逆转的开始。欧洲货币体系的重建意味着最初的社会主义纲领已成空谈。由于与货币的迫切需求相悖，它无法继续推行。国际金融市场已经获得了……对国家经济政策拥有重大否决权。重新加入欧洲货币合作也意味着经济必须现代化，效率必须提高。阻碍生产力的，是法国经济中一些根深蒂固、陈旧过时的结构，其中许多结构扼杀了银行业和股市。在短短十五个月的紧张工作中，德洛尔开始了这项伟大的现代化任务，他的继任者们将继续推进这项工作。德洛尔还对传统的救助困境企业政策采取了非常强硬的态度。1984年，曾经是法国工业瑰宝的钢铁和工程集团克勒索-卢瓦尔(Creusot-Loire)濒临破产，国际经济格局的变化和新兴竞争对手的崛起使其举步维艰。管理层认为两万五千个工作岗位岌岌可危，要求政府提供救助方案。德洛尔断然拒绝。“这已经是我们第三次救助克勒索-卢瓦尔了，”他说。 “我反对这项计划，因为它又一次意味着将收益私​​有化，将损失社会化。这就是我拒绝他们以破产和失业为由进行敲诈勒索的原因。”5

The stabilization of the franc through the EMS was the beginning of the Great U-Turn. The reestablishment of the EMS meant that the original Socialist program was out the window. Inconsistent with the currency imperative, it could not be pursued. International financial markets had gained a major veto over national economic policy. Recommitment to European monetary cooperation also meant that the economy had to be modernized and made more efficient. Holding back productivity were a number of profoundly archaic, antiquated structures in the French economy, including many that were strangling banking and the stock market. In fifteen frenetic months, Delors began the great task of modernization that his successors would carry on. Delors also took a very hard line against the traditional policy of bailing out troubled companies. In 1984, the steel and engineering group Creusot-Loire, once a crown jewel of French industry, stood on the verge of bankruptcy, felled by international economic change and the rise of new competitors. Arguing that twenty-five thousand jobs were at stake, management demanded a state rescue package. Delors said no. “This was our third time helping Creusot-Loire,” he said. “I opposed the plan because once again, it would have meant privatizing the gains and socializing the losses. That’s why I refused their blackmail over bankruptcy and the loss of jobs.”5

社会主义者“抹杀国家”

Socialists “Efface the State”

在经历大转弯后，社会主义者坚持推行市场改革的新路线。他们控制开支，并继续推进金融部门现代化，使国有企业能够从资本市场而非仅仅依靠政府融资。这与出售国有企业子公司相结合，构成了一种“变相”私有化的开端。他们的言辞不再是“与资本主义决裂”，而是充斥着现代化、产业活力、效率和竞争性技术等词汇。这种变化甚至在密特朗的言论中也显而易见。他宣称：“国家必须懂得如何自我消亡。”

After the Great U-Turn, the Socialists maintained their new course of market reform. They controlled spending and continued to modernize the financial sector so that nationalized companies could turn to capital markets and not just the government for funding. This, combined with the sell-off of subsidiaries belonging to state-owned companies, constituted the first steps in what was a sort of “backdoor” privatization. Instead of the “break with capitalism,” their rhetoric was now peppered with words like modernization, industrial dynamics, efficiency, and competitive technology. The change was evident even in Mitterrand’s language. “The state,” he declared, “must know how to efface itself.”

然而，从1983年起，德洛尔作为法国财政部长的地位开始下滑。尽管事实证明他的判断是正确的，而且与其他社会党人相比，他的个人声望仍然相对较高，但这都无济于事。密特朗是一位老谋深算的政客。他喜欢阴谋诡计，喜欢权谋，而且与德洛尔格格不入。德洛尔是一位天主教社会主义者，崇尚个人主义，并且工作热情极高。事实上，密特朗曾抱怨说：“德洛尔身上散发着圣器室的味道。”他害怕被德洛尔的光芒所掩盖。在向德洛尔解释为何1983年没有任命他为总理时，密特朗援引十世纪的一个王朝的例子说：“你会成为大维齐尔，而我会成为懒惰的国王。”

Yet from 1983 onward, Delors’s position as French finance minister deteriorated. It didn’t help at all that he had been proved right or that his personal popularity had remained relatively strong compared to the other Socialists’. Mitterrand was a crafty, cunning politician. He liked intrigue and maneuvering, and he was not at all comfortable with Delors, who was a Catholic socialist and a devotee of personalism and had a huge appetite for work. Indeed, at one point Mitterrand complained, “Delors smells of the sacristy.” He feared being outshone by Delors. Explaining to Delors why he had not made him prime minister in 1983, Mitterrand—recalling a tenthcentury dynasty—said, “You would have been the grand vizier, and I would have been the roifainéant [the “lazy king”].”

1984年7月，莫鲁瓦辞去总理职务后，密特朗再次告诉德洛尔，他不会成为总理。更糟糕的是，密特朗随后任命了德洛尔的死对头，年仅39岁的洛朗·法比尤斯为下一任总理。这是德洛尔最感兴趣的职位之一。欧盟委员会主席一职，作为欧洲经济共同体的执行和行政机构，正向公众开放。德洛尔深信，真正的竞技场并不局限于国界，而是整个欧洲。

When Mauroy resigned as prime minister in July 1984, Mitterrand told Delors once again that he would not become prime minister. To make matters worse, Mitterrand then proceeded to appoint Delors’s nemesis, the thirty-nine-year-old Laurent Fabius, as the next prime minister. But there was one position in which Delors was most interested. The presidency of the European Commission, the executive and administrative arm of the European Economic Community, was opening up. Delors had become convinced that the real playing field was not bounded by national borders. It was Europe.

欧盟委员会新任主席的遴选很大程度上取决于构成欧洲经济共同体核心的两大国——法国和德国。德国当时并没有合适的候选人。总理赫尔穆特·科尔对德洛尔印象深刻，他向密特朗表示，如果一定要选一位法国主席，那非德洛尔莫属。而这样的任命对密特朗来说也有一个明确的目标——让德洛尔离开法国。1984年7月18日，欧共体各国政府选举德洛尔为下一任欧盟委员会主席。当他最后一次离开装饰华丽的财政部前厅时，在工作人员的掌声中，德洛尔给密特朗留下了一份非常重要的遗产：他已经为法国开启了经济现代化和对市场的依赖的进程，即使他卸任，这一进程也将继续下去。正如他在社会党的一位竞争对手所说，德洛尔“在法国社会民主主义中重新确立市场经济理念方面发挥了至关重要的作用”。他的政策最终促成了社会党和共产党之间的彻底决裂。密特朗不再需要他们了。1984年，共产党退出政府，并发表声明称其“不再是总统多数派的一部分”。但这并没有给该党带来任何好处。它从一支重要力量沦为了边缘力量。6

The selection of the Commission’s new president depended very much on the two countries that formed the inner core of the European Economic Community, France and Germany. The Germans did not have a candidate. Chancellor Helmut Kohl, impressed by what he had seen of Delors, conveyed to Mitterrand that if there was going to be a French president, it would be Delors and no one else. And such an appointment would serve one clear purpose for Mitterrand—it would get Delors out of town. On July 18, 1984, the governments of the EEC chose Delors to be the next president of the Commission. As he departed the ornate front hall of the Ministry of Finance for the last time, to the applause of the staff, Delors left Mitterrand a very important bequest: He had set France on a drive for economic modernization and increased reliance on markets that would carry on without him. In the words of one of his rivals in the Socialist Party, Delors “played a fundamental role in reinserting a vision of the market economy in French social democracy.” His policies had helped finalize the divorce between the Socialists and the Communists. Mitterrand did not need them anymore. In 1984, the Communist Party exited the government with a blast that it was “no longer part of the presidential majority.” That did the party no good. It was reduced from being a force to being on the fringe.6

停滞与欧洲悲观主义

Stagnation and Euro-pessimism

德洛尔抵达布鲁塞尔，就任欧洲共同体主席一职。此前，欧洲共同体已停滞近二十年。共同体的起源可以追溯到马歇尔计划。当时，面对迫在眉睫的经济崩溃，美国向欧洲提供了数十亿美元的援助，以促进二战后的重建。作为贷款的条件，美国政府坚持要求欧洲各国在经济重建方面开展合作，从欧洲视角看待问题，并制定共同计划。该计划也为欧洲一体化运动的启动提供了动力。正如阿尔蒂埃罗·斯皮内利所说，“关于马歇尔计划的讨论重新开启了欧洲一体化的理念。”反过来，马歇尔计划也为欧洲经济共同体（EEC）的前身——欧洲煤钢共同体——奠定了基础。该共同体由法国和德国共同管理。让·莫内正是这一共同体的构想者。他与法国外交部长罗伯特·舒曼和德国总理康拉德·阿登纳一起，一手缔造了这一条约。

Delors arrived in Brussels to take up his position in a European Community that had been largely stagnant for almost two decades. The Community’s origins went back to the Marshall Plan, when the United States provided billions of dollars of aid to Europe, in the face of its imminent economic collapse, to promote reconstruction after World War IL As a condition for loaning its money, the U.S. government had insisted that the Europeans cooperate on economic reconstruction, look at problems in a European context, and draw up common plans. It also provided the impetus for launching the unification movement. As Altiero Spinelli put it, “The discussions about the Marshall Plan reopened the idea of European unification.” In turn, the Marshall Plan helped lay the foundations for the predecessor organization to the EEC: the European Coal and Steel Community, which exercised common management of those resources between France and Germany. Jean Monnet was the man who envisioned this community; and he—along with French foreign minister Robert Schuman and German chancellor Konrad Adenauer—hammered it into existence.

随后在1957年，六个欧洲国家——德国、法国、意大利、比利时、荷兰和卢森堡签署了《罗马条约》，该条约促成了欧洲经济共同体的成立，并将煤钢共同体巧妙地纳入其中。这是欧洲的第一次“重启”。事实上，煤钢共同体的各个机构成为了新成立的欧洲经济共同体的核心机构。但它究竟应该是一个怎样的共同体呢？由此引发了一场直击问题核心的激烈争论。戴高乐主张建立一个由各国组成的欧洲，各国在合作的同时保留各自的主权。他希望作为共同体执行机构的欧盟委员会服从于各国政府，而不是凌驾于各国政府之上。多数票不足以解决问题；必须获得绝对一致通过。否则，一个国家的主权可能会受到损害——尤其是法国的主权。

Then in 1957, six European countries—Germany, France, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands, and Luxembourg—signed the Treaty of Rome, which brought the European Economic Community into existence, neatly enveloping the Coal and Steel Community in the process. This was the first “relaunching of Europe.” Indeed, the various institutions of the Coal and Steel Community became the core institutions of the new EEC. But what type of community was it to be? Here ensued a bitter battle that went right to the heart of the matter. Charles de Gaulle advocated a Europe of nations, cooperating but retaining their sovereignty. He wanted the European Commission, the executive arm of the Community, to be subordinate to the national governments, not to have authority over them. Majority votes were insufficient; there had to be absolute unanimity. Otherwise, a nation’s sovereignty might be impaired—in particular, France’s sovereignty.

莫内和斯皮内利想要的远不止于此：他们想要的是一个联邦制的欧洲。诞生于欧洲的民族国家将服从于一个拥有最终决定权的超国家。欧洲那些历史悠久的国家将不再像主权国家，而更像美国的各个州。这种转变不会一蹴而就，而是通过建立拥有特定权力的机构来实现。现实将会改变，尽管这一过程是渐进的。但戴高乐行使了否决权，说了“不”，并取得了胜利。结果，从20世纪60年代末开始，迈向联邦制欧洲的进程停滞不前。尽管共同体新增了成员——英国、丹麦和爱尔兰于1973年加入——但能源危机和经济危机加剧了这种停滞。主要的进展是20世纪70年代末欧洲货币体系的建立——并非所有成员国都加入了该体系。除此之外，欧共体内部围绕其权力、预算以及——由于它不直接征税——成员国政府应缴纳多少资金的争论也持续不断。英国首相玛格丽特·撒切尔曾因欧共体花费巨资补贴那些经济效益低下但政治上举足轻重的农民而怒不可遏，她宣称：“我要我的钱回来。” 当时的欧洲似乎注定要衰落，患上了“欧洲硬化症”，无法与美国平起平坐，并受到来自日本和其他亚洲国家的竞争威胁。让·莫内曾经的乐观主义，尽管有时显得过于务实，但如今已被盛行的、弥漫的欧洲悲观主义所取代，而这正是20世纪70年代和80年代初的标志。7

Monnet and Spinelli wanted something much more: a federal Europe. The nation-state, which had been born in Europe, would be subordinated to a supranational state, which would have the final say. The venerable countries of Europe would become less like sovereign nations and more like the individual states of the United States. Such a transformation would not happen all at once but would be accomplished by building institutions that had specific authorities. Reality would be changed, though gradually. But de Gaulle wielded his veto, said “Non” and won. As a result, from the late 1960s onward, movement toward a federal Europe stalled. Although the Community gained new members—Britain, Denmark, and Ireland joined in 1973—the energy and economic crises only added to the stagnation. The principal new evolution was the establishment of the European Monetary System—which not every member joined—in the late 1970s. Aside from that, the EEC continued to be stalemated by battles over its authority, its budgets, and—since it did not tax directly—how much its member governments would contribute. In one memorable moment, British prime minister Margaret Thatcher, angry over the huge amounts the Community spent to subsidize uneconomic but politically critical farmers, declared, “I want my money back.” Europe, it seemed, was destined to decline, afflicted by “Eurosclerosis,” unable to engage the United States as an equal, and threatened by competition from Japan and other Asian countries. Jean Monnet’s optimism, however hardheaded it had been, had given way to rampant and pervasive Euro-pessimism, which was the hallmark of the 1970s and the early 1980s.7

单一市场：重振欧洲

The Single Market: Relaunching Europe

正是在这样的背景下，德洛尔前往布鲁塞尔，出任欧盟委员会主席。在他任职期间，办公室墙上只挂着一幅画像——从干邑推销员转型为政治家和人脉高手的让·莫内。莫内致力于结束欧洲内战，在欧洲的背景下解决德国问题，这些使命感也塑造了德洛尔。他的父亲曾身负重伤。德洛尔曾参加过第一次世界大战的凡尔登战役，他对德国人的憎恶从未消散。纳粹占领巴黎期间，他和母亲逃往乡下，在那里结识了一位为抵抗组织传递信息的挚友。这位朋友被纳粹俘虏，最终死于奥斯维辛集中营。德洛尔决心确保那段往事永远不会重现。

It was under these circumstances that Delors moved to Brussels to become president of the European Commission. During his tenure, just one portrait decorated his office wall—that of cognac-salesman-turned-statesman and expert networker Jean Monnet. The imperatives that drove Monnet—to put an end to European civil war, to solve the German problem in the context of Europe—had also shaped Delors. His father had been grievously wounded at the Battle of Verdun in the First World War and had never buried his antipathy to the Germans. When Delors fled with his mother to the countryside during the Nazi occupation of Paris, he made a best friend who carried messages for the Resistance. The friend was captured by the Nazis and died at Auschwitz. That was the past that Delors wanted to be sure would never return.

最终，德洛尔成为了“新”欧洲——单一市场欧洲——的化身。他被誉为富有远见的工程师，孜孜不倦地寻找看似棘手问题的解决之道，引领欧洲走向统一的、真正开放的市场。然而，他也因傲慢自大、目空一切以及逐渐将自身与整个欧洲混淆而饱受诟病。他被抨击为典型的法国官僚，不必要地将法国人惯用的指令主义、繁文缛节、僵化作风和官僚作风强加于整个欧洲大陆，而欧洲大陆真正需要的不是更多的控制，而是更多的经济自由。

In due course, Delors would become the incarnation of the “new” Europe—the Europe of the single market. He would be celebrated as a visionary engineer, who tirelessly found solutions to seemingly intractable problems and who was leading Europe toward a unified, truly open market. He would also be criticized for hubris and arrogance, for pomposity, and for progressively confusing himself with Europe as a whole. He would be attacked as the French bureaucrat par excellence, who needlessly applied the French propensity for dirigisme, regulations, rigidity, and paperwork to an entire continent, which needed more economic freedom, not more control.

德洛尔决心主持欧洲的复兴。为此，他需要一个宏大的构想，一个能够产生深远影响的构想。否则，这项工作还有什么意义呢？前一年秋天，他走遍欧洲各地寻找这样的构想，最终在“单一市场”的概念中找到了答案。与此同时，他还将推动单一货币的建立。这两项举措将共同构成他的贡献。如果成功实施，联邦制的欧洲几乎将不可避免，并创建一个一体化的欧洲大陆经济。

Delors was determined to preside over a new relaunching of Europe. To do so, he needed a big idea, one that would have far-reaching impact. Otherwise, what was the point of doing the job? He had spent the previous autumn canvassing Europe for such an idea, and he had found it in the concept of the “single market.” Along with that, he would also promote a single currency. Together, they would add up to his contribution. And if successfully implemented, they would make a federal Europe almost inevitable and create an integrated Continental economy.

德洛尔毫不拖延。1985年1月14日，就任欧盟委员会主席仅两周后，他就前往欧洲议会，呼吁在1992年底前消除所有“内部壁垒”，建立单一市场。1957年的《罗马条约》已经取消了传统的关税。如今，德洛尔决心更进一步，消除一切阻碍单一开放内部市场的壁垒。到6月，欧盟委员会已经提出了297项消除壁垒的提案。边境的实体壁垒将被取消。成员国之间将不再征收关税。技术壁垒也将被取消。每个国家都将接受其他国家制定的商品或服务标准。这就是“相互承认”的关键原则，该原则也适用于银行业、股票经纪业、共同基金和保险业。如果一家公司被授权在一个国家从事这些业务，那么它就可以在所有其他国家从事这些业务。各国政府不能再偏袒本国企业；竞争环境本应公平。为了进一步限制民族国家的特权，各国政府必须允许任何欧洲公司参与大型合同的竞标，而不是将合同保留给受优待的本国公司。

Delors wasted no time. On January 14, 1985, just two weeks after taking over as president of the Commission, he went before the European Parliament to call for the removal of all “internal frontiers” to a single market by the end of 1992. The 1957 Treaty of Rome had eliminated traditional customs duties. Now Delors was determined to go much further, to do away with every kind of barrier that stood in the way of a single open internal market. By June, the Commission had come up with 297 proposals to flatten the barriers. Physical barriers at frontiers were to go. No longer would there be customs between members. Technical barriers were also to go. Each country would accept standards on goods or services imposed by another country. This was the key principle of “mutual recognition,” which was also applied to banking, stockbroking, mutual funds, and insurance. If a firm was authorized to ply any of these trades in one country, then it could do so in all the others. Governments could no longer play favorites with their national champions; the playing field was meant to be level. Further circumscribing the prerogatives of the nation-state, governments would have to permit any European firm to bid on major contracts rather than reserve them for favored national companies.

德洛尔得到了共同体三个最新成员国——希腊、西班牙和葡萄牙的支持，这三个国家于1986年1月1日正式加入。对这三个国家而言，成为正式成员标志着它们现代化进程中的一个历史性分水岭——它们从欧洲的穷亲戚，从受独裁统治的国家，一跃成为共同体的一员。这三个国家长期以来都是农产品和廉价移民劳动力的来源地，后来发展成为民主国家，并全面参与经济一体化进程。此外，当时这三个国家都由深受法国经验影响的“新”社会主义者执政——其中最引人注目的代表人物是西班牙年轻而富有魅力的首相费利佩·冈萨雷斯。

Delors enjoyed the support of the Community’s three newest members—Greece, Spain, and Portugal, which formally joined on January 1, 1986. For all three, full membership marked a historic watershed in their modernization—they went from being Europe’s poor cousins, ruled by dictatorships and long the source of agricultural products and cheap migrant labor, to becoming democracies and full-fledged participants in economic integration. In addition, all three were ruled at this time by “new” socialists much influenced by the French experience—most compellingly symbolized in the figure of Spain’s young and charismatic prime minister, Felipe González.

创建内部市场所需的机制体现在《单一欧洲法案》中，该法案于1987年7月1日获得欧洲共同体所有十二个成员国的批准。到1992年底，所有内部市场壁垒都将被消除。为了便于实施该法案，戴高乐奉为圭臬的“一致同意”原则在许多方面被推翻。各国政府只需多数票即可确保新举措获得通过。这将是一项至关重要的变革。十二个成员国还承诺制定共同的欧洲外交政策。

The mechanisms needed to create the internal market were embodied in the. Single European Act, which was approved by all twelve members of the European Community on July 1, 1987. By the end of 1992, all barriers to the internal market were to be eliminated. To facilitate implementation of the act, the principle of unanimity—so sacred to de Gaulle—was overturned for many purposes. Majority votes among the governments would be enough to ensure approval of new initiatives. This would be a very key change. The twelve members also committed themselves to develop a common European foreign policy.

然而，《单一欧洲法案》并未获得预期的关注。它被视为又一个欧洲故事，即使是严肃报纸的读者也只是匆匆一瞥。阿尔蒂埃罗·斯皮内利（Altiero Spinelli）的一生恰好见证了它的成形。尽管他几乎毕生致力于欧洲一体化，但他对这场他曾在20世纪80年代参与发起的“重启”运动最终的结局毫不掩饰自己的失望。1986年去世前不久，他轻蔑地称这项计划无关紧要——不过是“一只可笑的小老鼠”。人们需要时间才能意识到，《单一欧洲法案》将权力从各国首都转移到布鲁塞尔，转移到欧盟，尤其是转移到拥有立法专属权的欧盟委员会。

Yet the Single European Act did not command anywhere near the attention that might have been expected. It was treated as another of those European stories and received only glancing attention, even from readers of serious newspapers. Altiero Spinelli lived just long enough to see it take shape. But even after spending almost a lifetime of struggle for European unity, he did not bother to hide his disappointment at this outcome of the “relaunching” campaign he had helped initiate in the 1980s. Shortly before his death in 1986, he dismissed the plan as insignificant—nothing more than a “ridiculous mouse.” It would take time to realize how much the Single European Act would shift power away from national capitals to Brussels and toward the Community and, in particular, to the Commission, which had the exclusive right to initiate laws.

要将这项法案付诸实践，需要在欧洲范围内进行大量的立法工作。仅在1988年上半年，欧洲共同体做出的决定就超过了1974年至1984年这十年间的总和。各种商品和服务都要进行“欧洲化”，并制定关于成分、安全和标签的共同规则。有时，障碍实在太大，例如啤酒。一些国家销售不含酒精的无醇啤酒，而另一些国家销售的无醇啤酒酒精含量却高达1%。与此同时，德国有着数百年前制定的啤酒“纯净法”，而其他国家的啤酒并不符合这一标准。如果啤酒要成为自由贸易商品，就必须实现趋同。在这种情况下，规则制定者不得不做出妥协。他们所能做的最多就是要求每个成员国遵守其他成员国关于啤酒定义的标准。

To turn the act into reality required an enormous amount of lawmaking, on the European scale. In the first half of 1988 alone, the European Community made more decisions than it had in the ten years between 1974 and 1984. All sorts of goods and services were to be “Europeanized” and to have common rules about content, safety, and labeling. Sometimes the obstacles were too great, as in the case of beer. Some countries sold nonalcoholic beer that contained no alcohol. Others sold nonalcoholic beer that had up to 1 percent of alcohol. Germany, meanwhile, had a “purity law” for beer that dated back several centuries, which the beer of other countries did not meet. If beer was to be a freely traded good, then convergence was required. In this case, the rule makers had to compromise. The most they could do was oblige each country to honor other member countries’ standards about what constituted beer.

糖果制造商与欧盟之间关于如何建立巧克力单一市场的斗争同样激烈。英国和爱尔兰的糖果制造商经常在巧克力中大量添加牛奶，他们可能被要求将巧克力棒重新贴上“高牛奶含量牛奶巧克力”或“家用牛奶巧克力”的标签。英国糖果制造商对此反应强烈，他们坚持认为这个问题事关重大。民族特性。“英国人一直喜欢在巧克力里多加点牛奶，”一位专家坚持说，“就像我们喜欢在茶里加牛奶一样。”这场斗争留下的不愉快经历清楚地表明，协调并非一帆风顺。8

No less bitter has been the battle between candy makers and the European Union over how to create a single market in chocolate. British and Irish confectioners, who liberally mix milk in with their chocolate, may be ordered to relabel their candy bars as “milk chocolate with a high milk content” or “household milk chocolate.” There has been no sweet talk in the response of British candy makers, who insist that the issue goes to the heart of national character. “The British have always preferred more milk in their chocolate,” insisted one expert, “just as we like milk in our tea.” The bad taste left by this struggle makes clear that harmonization is not a smooth process.8

这是在无视历史吗？

Flying in the Face of History?

迈向单一市场的进程引发了一场激烈的辩论。只要单一市场被视为一种超级自由贸易区，像玛格丽特·撒切尔这样的领导人就完全可以接受；她和其他欧洲领导人一起在1987年签署了该文件。但批评者们越来越意识到，这实际上是将主权从各国首都——民选议会所在地——转移到了布鲁塞尔以及庞大而自成体系的欧盟委员会官僚机构。该机构不遗余力地维护自身权威，并且不受各国政府和直接民主监督的约束。德洛尔被冠以“布鲁塞尔沙皇”的称号，更是火上浇油。

The march toward the single market ignited an acrimonious debate. The single market was more than acceptable to the likes of Margaret Thatcher as long as it was viewed as nothing more than a sort of super-duper free-trade zone; and she, along with the other European leaders, put her signature to the document in 1987. But what the critics now increasingly saw was the transfer of sovereignty from national capitals, the homes of elected parliaments, to Brussels and the large, self-referential bureaucracy of the European Commission, implacable in its efforts to assert its authority and insulated from both national governments and direct democratic controls. It did not help when Delors was dubbed the Czar of Brussels.

事实上，对撒切尔而言，欧盟委员会权力的扩张威胁到她为英国设定的目标。“欧盟正在违背历史，”她后来说道，“它行不通，绝对行不通。”在她看来，一个统一的欧洲意味着将过多的权力赋予布鲁塞尔一个官僚主义的指令型委员会，该委员会试图将触角伸向所有它不该涉足的领域。这也与撒切尔革命背道而驰。她当时宣称：“我们在英国成功地缩小了国家边界，却眼睁睁地看着这些边界在欧洲层面重新出现，一个欧洲超级国家从布鲁塞尔行使着新的统治权，这绝非易事。”在她看来，德洛尔正是掌管欧盟的“新一代不负责任的政客”的典型代表——正如她所说，他们“在古老民族、不同语言和多元经济的不稳固基础上，建造了他们的巴别塔”。9

Indeed, for Thatcher, the expansion of the Commission’s power threatened to undo what she had enunciated as her goal for Britain. “The European Union is flying in the face of history,” she later said. “It will not work. It will not work.” In her eyes, a unified Europe meant vesting too much power in a bureaucratic dirigiste commission in Brussels that sought to get its tentacles into all sorts of activities where it did not belong. It also ran counter to the Thatcher revolution. She declared at the time, “We have not successfully rolled back the frontiers of the state in Britain only to see them reimposed at a European level with a European superstate exercising a new dominance from Brussels.” And as far as she was concerned, Delors was the epitome of the “new breed of unaccountable politicians” running the Community—building, as she put it, “their Tower of Babel on the uneven foundations of ancient nations, different languages, and diverse economies.”9

但撒切尔夫人不久便下台，而涉及约三百项独立立法和监管规定的单一市场计划的实施，也按计划于1992年底基本完成。竞争格局发生了翻天覆地的变化。每个国家都更加开放。《单一欧洲法案》削弱了各国政府对关键领域的控制力。然而，有一个领域仍然是主权的堡垒：资金。

But Thatcher was shortly to fall from power, and the implementation of the Single Market Program—involving about three hundred separate pieces of legislation and regulation—was virtually completed by the end of 1992, on its appointed timetable. The competitive landscape was transformed. Each country was open. The Single European Act had removed the sway of governments over large parts of the commanding heights. One area, however, remained a bastion of sovereignty: money.

Buba 最懂？

Buba Knows Best?

随着单一市场的建立，欧洲已做好进一步一体化的准备。事实上，早在1988年，德洛尔就已领导一个委员会，负责研究如何创建单一货币。这显然是合乎逻辑的必然要求。一个一体化的市场。气氛乐观，一个统一的欧洲似乎即将到来。

With the single market, Europe was ready for more unity. In fact, in 1988, Delors had already headed a committee that was charged with figuring out how to create a single currency. That was clearly a logical requirement for an integrated market. The mood was upbeat, and a united Europe appeared to be on the way.

随后，1989年这个充满奇迹的年份到来了，欧洲的统一进程再次受阻。然而，与欧洲既定的时间表不同，这次的统一是出乎意料的，毫无计划。1988年，赫尔穆特·科尔曾预言，德国统一在他有生之年不会实现。1989年1月，统治东德的共产党官僚埃里希·昂纳克更是将预言推向了更远的境地，他预测柏林墙将屹立五十年甚至一百年。但那时，一系列戏剧性且出乎意料地推翻所有这些预言的事件已经开始发生。那一年，波兰、匈牙利、捷克斯洛伐克、东德、保加利亚和罗马尼亚的共产党政权相继垮台——柏林墙也随之倒塌。10

Then came the annus mirabilis of 1989, and another unification got in the way of Europe’s. This one, however, in contrast to the European timetables, was unplanned and unexpected. In 1988, Helmut Kohl had prophesied that German unification would not occur in his lifetime. In January 1989, Erich Honecker, the Communist apparatchik who ran East Germany, stretched the horizon even farther, predicting that the Berlin Wall would last fifty or even a hundred years. But by then, events that would dramatically and unexpectedly negate all such predictions were already in motion. That year would bring the collapse of the Communist governments of Poland, Hungary, Czechoslovakia, East Germany, Bulgaria, and Romania—and the fall of the Berlin Wall.10

冷战时代结束，不可避免地打乱了原有的基本格局。欧洲一体化的主要动力之一原本是为了遏制东方的共产主义势力。但如今，西欧人不再担忧华沙条约组织的坦克西进，而是害怕经济难民的涌入。他们不再团结起来抵抗共产主义，而是不得不制定共同的经济政策来应对来自东方的挑战。更紧迫的是，这些前共产主义国家很快就会蜂拥而至，寻求加入共同体。但他们如何才能融入单一市场呢？他们甚至还没有建立起市场经济体系。所有这一切都使得制定共同外交政策变得更加迫切。

The era of the cold war was over, inevitably upsetting fundamental calculations. One of the main impetuses for European integration had been to offset communist power in the East. But now, instead of the specter of Warsaw Pact tanks heading west, the Western Europeans feared a flood of economic refugees. Rather than uniting to resist communism, Western Europeans had to devise common economic policies to meet the challenge from the east. To make matters even more pressing, these former communist countries would soon be banging at the Community’s door, seeking association and membership. But how could they join in the single market? They did not yet even have market systems. All of this provided new urgency to develop a common foreign policy.

第二个根本性的考量涉及德国的角色——始终存在的德国问题。共产主义的崩溃彻底改变了这个问题。战后的基本方案可以追溯到让·莫内和欧洲煤钢共同体：德国只有融入民主的欧洲，才能最大程度地实现自身及其邻国的利益。德国的实力将与法国相抗衡，而加入欧洲后，又将与英国相抗衡。但共产主义的崩溃使战后德国政策中一直被视为终极目标的统一触手可及。这将使德国成为欧洲的主导力量，从而给整个欧洲大陆带来巨大的挑战。

A second fundamental calculation concerned the role of Germany—the ever-present German question. The collapse of communism drastically rewrote that question. The basic postwar formula went back to Jean Monnet and the European Coal and Steel Community: Germany would best flourish, in both its own interests and those of its neighbors, when integrated into a democratic Europe. Germany’s might would be balanced off against France’s and, after its entry, against Britain’s. But the collapse of communism put within reach what had been the rhetorical holy grail of postwar German policies—reunification. This would make Germany the preponderant power in Europe, thus creating an enormous challenge for the entire continent.

德国自身也面临着巨大的挑战。东德经济曾一度被吹捧为世界第十大工业经济体（按人均计算）。人们常说，如果说谁能让共产主义成功，那非德国人莫属。然而，东德的崩溃暴露了其锈迹斑斑的内在本质。事实证明，东德经济是一个摇摇欲坠、运转失灵、效率低下且浪费严重的体系，依靠西德的援助和信贷勉强维持运转。如何整合两国经济？如何帮助“奥西人”（东德人）实现其宏伟目标，并使其生活水平达到“西德人”的水平？答案，无论如何，都将归结于金钱。路德维希·艾哈德的货币1948年的改革为德国经济奇迹和随后四十年的增长奠定了基础。如何处理西德货币和东德货币之间的关系，对未来的经济发展至关重要。

Germany itself faced a huge challenge. The East German economy had once been trumpeted as the tenth-largest industrial economy in the world, on a per capita basis. If anybody could make communism work, so it was said, it was the Germans. But the collapse of East Germany revealed its rusted innards. It turned out that the East German economy was a ramshackle, broken-down, highly inefficient, wasteful system, kept afloat by aid and credits from West Germany. How to integrate the two economies? How to help the “Ossies”—the East Germans—achieve their great objective and bring them up to the standard of living of the “Wessies”? The answer, in one way or another, would come down to money. Ludwig Erhard’s currency reform of 1948 had created the foundations for the German economic miracle and four decades of growth. How the relationship between the West German and East German currencies was handled would be central to future economic development.

掌管德国货币的卡尔-奥托·珀尔，即德国联邦银行行长，坚信正确的做法是谨慎行事。德国联邦银行堪称欧洲经济正统的守护者。由于它是德国的中央银行，又因其宪法规定，德国联邦银行——货币交易员通常称之为“Buba”——成为欧洲最具主导地位的中央银行。其权力仅次于美国联邦储备委员会。德国联邦银行不仅决定德国的利率，也决定整个欧洲的利率，因为其他中央银行必须根据德国的利率来调整自身的利率，以维持汇率稳定。德国联邦银行在成立之初就被赋予了相当大的自主权，以避免受到短期政治干预。其宪法义务在1957年颁布的设立法案中明确规定：抑制通货膨胀。由于权力过于强大，位于法兰克福郊外黑色现代城堡内的布巴政权经常被批评为“国中之国”——过度关注通货膨胀，不惜牺牲就业和社会稳定。布巴政权则回应说，通货膨胀才是最大的不稳定因素，是瘟疫；如果不加以控制，最终会摧毁生产性经济，在此过程中，就业和社会稳定都将遭受重创。

The man who was in charge of Germany’s money, Karl-Otto Pöhl, the president of the Bundesbank, was convinced that the right answer was to move with great caution. The Bundesbank was truly the keeper of Europe’s economic orthodoxy. Because it was Germany’s central bank and because of its constitution, the Buba—as the Bundesbank is known to currency traders—was the dominant central bank in Europe. Its power was rivaled only by that of the U.S. Federal Reserve. The Buba determined interest rates not just for Germany but for all of Europe, because the other central banks had to calibrate their interest rates in relation to Germany’s, to maintain stability in exchange rates. The Bundesbank had been established with considerable autonomy, to protect it from short-term political interference. Its constitutional obligation was expressed in the 1957 act that had established it: to fight inflation. Because its power was so great, the Buba, ensconced in its black, modernistic castle on the outskirts of Frankfurt, was often criticized as a “state within a state”—overly obsessed with inflation, at the expense of employment and social peace. Its reply was that inflation was the great destabilizer, the plague; if not checked, it would ultimately destroy the productive economy, shredding both jobs and social peace in the process.

德国联邦银行的正统观念深深植根于德国历史。其中两段与通货膨胀相关的历史记忆至关重要。第一段是20世纪20年代初的恶性通货膨胀，当时人们用手推车运送几乎一文不值的纸币，这一景象至今仍为人津津乐道。这场通货膨胀摧毁了中产阶级的储蓄和稳定生活，并为魏玛共和国的崩溃和希特勒的崛起埋下了伏笔。第二段是二战后严重的通货膨胀，路德维希·艾哈德通过1948年的货币改革一夜之间消除了通货膨胀，为德国经济奇迹的诞生创造了条件。其教训显而易见：通货膨胀会摧毁社会的根基。

The Bundesbank’s orthodoxy was deeply rooted in the German past. Two historic memories—both about inflation—were fundamental. The first was the hyperinflation of the early 1920s, memorialized by photographs of wheelbarrows filled with almost-worthless paper currency. It had wiped out the savings and stability of the middle class and helped set the stage for the collapse of the Weimar Republic and the rise of Hitler. The second was that of the massive post-World War II inflation that Ludwig Erhard had eliminated overnight with the 1948 currency reform, creating the conditions for the German economic miracle. The moral was straightforward: Inflation destroys the foundations of society.

尽管他信奉正统犹太教，但珀尔进入德国联邦银行的经历却非同寻常。1945年，他十五岁，正等待被征召入伍，成为最后一批炮灰。二战结束时，他和许多战后的人一样，在满目疮痍的德国茫然无措。他对埃尔哈德货币改革前几年的记忆十分模糊。“我们的问题非常紧迫，”他说，“我们连饭都吃不上。”十八岁时，他开始为一家社会主义报纸工作。尽管他的思想立场有所转变，但他对社会主义者的情感忠诚却从未动摇。“我敬佩那些人，”他回忆道，“他们从集中营回来，从流亡中归来。除了共产党人之外，他们是唯一敢于反抗纳粹的人。而且，由于我们都知道东德正在发生什么，所以没有人愿意成为共产党人。我当时……”1948年我加入社会民主党时18岁。他们帮了我很多，资助我上了大学。我对此负有一定的道义责任。

Despite his orthodoxy, Pöhl came to the Bundesbank by an unusual route. He was fifteen in 1945, waiting to be drafted for the last wave of cannon fodder, when World War II ended, and like so many after the war, he was adrift in a nation of ruins. His memory of the years leading up to Erhard’s currency reform was basic. “Our problems were very immediate,” he said. “We didn’t have anything to eat.” At the age of eighteen, he went to work for a socialist newspaper, and even if his intellectual allegiances would shift, he never lost his emotional allegiance to the socialists. “I admired those people,” he recalled. “They came back from the concentration camps, from emigration. They were the only people who had stood up against the Nazis, except for the communists, and because of what we knew was happening in eastern Germany, no one wanted to be a communist. I was eighteen years old when I joined the Social Democrats in 1948. They did a lot for me. They helped me go to university. I have a certain moral obligation.”

在大学期间，珀尔主修经济学，师从杰出的经济学家卡尔·席勒。（后来，席勒成为战后德国首位社会主义财政部长，并宣布他的目标是将凯恩斯主义与秩序自由主义的经济哲学相结合，后者在德国重建时期塑造了社会市场经济。）20世纪70年代初，珀尔进入政府，担任时任财政部长赫尔穆特·施密特的顾问。1974年，来自社会民主党右翼的施密特接替维利·勃兰特出任总理。1977年，施密特任命珀尔为德国联邦银行董事会成员，到1980年，珀尔已成为该银行行长。

At university Pöhl concentrated on economics, studying under Karl Schiller, an outstanding economist. (Later, upon becoming Germany’s first socialist finance minister in the postwar era, Schiller announced that his ambition was to merge Keynesianism with the economic philosophy of Ordoliberalism, which had shaped Germany’s social market economy in the years of reconstruction.) Pöhl came into the government in the early 1970s as an adviser to Helmut Schmidt, then the finance minister. In 1974, Schmidt, who came from the right wing of the Social Democratic Party, replaced Willy Brandt as chancellor. In 1977, Schmidt appointed Pöhl to the Bundesbank board, and by 1980 he was the bank’s president.

1982年，由基督教民主联盟领导的联合政府在德国上台执政，该党领袖赫尔穆特·科尔出任总理。在接下来的十五年里，他逐渐成为欧洲最具影响力的政治人物——被誉为“欧洲巨人”，这不仅是因为他身材魁梧，也因为德国的经济实力雄厚。科尔出生于莱茵兰地区，父亲是一名税务官员，他从小就对政治充满热情。1946年，年仅十六岁的他加入了基督教民主联盟。尽管当时人们并不确定他能否最终成为总理，但他的雄心壮志却毋庸置疑。1979年，随着党内反对声浪高涨，他经历了一段他称之为“屈辱之谷”的时期。但他并未就此放弃，四年后，他成功当选总理。他与联邦德国首任总理康拉德·阿登纳（同样来自莱茵兰的天主教徒）有着强烈的认同感，甚至自称“阿登纳的孙子”。科尔的对手认为他沉闷迟钝，因此一直低估他，而这最终却成了他的巨大优势，他的对手们在败北后才意识到这一点。他对当时的政治形势有着敏锐的洞察力。但东西德统一似乎遥不可及，因此，作为一名务实的政治家，他起初并未过多关注此事——直到1989年柏林墙倒塌事件发生。

In 1982, a coalition led by the Christian Democrats took power in Germany and Helmut Kohl, the party’s leader, became the new chancellor. Over the next decade and a half, he was to become Europe’s dominant politician—known as the “big man of Europe” not only because of his considerable size but also because of Germany’s economic preponderance. The son of a tax official from the Rhineland, Kohl grew up with a gargantuan appetite for politics. He joined the Christian Democrats in 1946, at age sixteen. No one could doubt his consuming ambition, though it was not at all clear that he would achieve the chancellorship. In 1979, as opposition to him mounted in his party, he went through what he was to call his “valley of humiliation.” But he was not to be outmaneuvered, and four years later he was chancellor. He so identified with the Federal Republic’s first chancellor, Konrad Adenauer, also a Catholic from the Rhineland, that he would describe himself as “Adenauer’s grandson.” Thinking him dull and plodding, Kohl’s opponents continually underestimated him, which turned out to be a great advantage for him, as his rivals discovered as they fell by the wayside. He also had a tremendous sense of the political moment. But the reunification of West and East Germany appeared a distant objective, and thus, as a practical politician, it did not much engage him—until the events of 1989, which culminated in the fall of the Berlin Wall.

突然间，核心问题不再是何时统一，而是更为实际和紧迫的统一方式。这使得汇率问题成为首要议题。卡尔-奥托·珀尔意识到，东西德之间的汇率对未来的经济发展至关重要。有人提议将1个东德马克兑换成1个西德马克。珀尔认为这简直荒谬。德国联邦银行估计，汇率应该在4比1左右——也就是说，4个东德马克大致相当于1个西德马克。东德工人的生产力充其量只有西德的40%。1比1的汇率，再加上西德社会和劳动制度的强加，将使东德完全丧失竞争力，其工业也将破产。其结果将是……将东德变成一个依赖福利的庞大实体。珀尔认为，波兰的经验为正确的做法提供了借鉴。波兰的工资远低于德国，这反映了其较低的生产率。但这并非坏事，而是好事，因为它使波兰商品在世界市场上更具竞争力——这意味着就业机会、更多投资和现代化，以及更广阔的发展机遇。

Suddenly, the central question was not when reunification would take place but the much more practical and immediate how. That pushed the matter of exchange rates right to the front. Karl-Otto Pöhl recognized that the exchange rate between East and West Germany would be crucial to future economic development. Some were talking about exchanging one East German mark for one West German deutsche mark. This, Pöhl thought, would be ludicrous. The Bundesbank estimated that it must be about four to one—that is, four East German marks were more or less equivalent to one deutsche mark. The productivity of East German workers was, at best, only 40 percent of West Germany’s. A one-to-one exchange rate, and the imposition of the West German social and labor system, would make East Germany totally uncompetitive. Its industry would be bankrupt. The result would be to turn East Germany into a giant welfare-dependent entity. The right approach, according to Pöhl, was suggested by Poland’s experience. Wages there were much lower than in Germany, reflecting the lower productivity. And that was good, not bad, because it made Polish goods competitive on world markets—which meant jobs, more investment and modernization, and expanding opportunity.

波尔意识到了这一切。他甚至不确定迅速实现政治统一是否明智。在他看来，作为一种民族理想，统一被过分夸大了，而且在某种程度上也不符合历史。他认为，或许更好的做法是让东德暂时保持一个独立的民主德国国家的地位，让它解决自身的经济、社会和政治问题——包括秘密警察“斯塔西”遗留下的种种问题。正是斯塔西将东德变成了一个高度依赖告密者的国家。之后，东德和西德才能重新融入欧洲共同体的更大框架之中。

Pöhl recognized all this. He was not even sure that rapid political unification was a good idea. To his mind, it was overrated—and somewhat unhistoric—as a national ideal. Perhaps it would be better, he thought, to allow East Germany to remain a separate democratic German state for a time. Let it sort out its economic, social, and political problems—including the legacy of the Stasi, the secret police, which had turned East Germany into an extraordinary informer state. East Germany and West Germany could then be reintegrated within the larger framework of the European Community.

“D标记来了”

“The D-mark Comes”

政客们却另有打算。四十年的分裂之后，人们的情绪如潮水般涌来，欣喜若狂。与此同时，总理赫尔穆特·科尔却越来越担心另一种浪潮——东德工人如潮水般涌入西德，追寻遍地黄金的街道。波尔辩称：“一段时间后，当人们意识到无法谋生时，他们自然会回去。”但科尔​​眼见人数已然激增，东德民众开始走上街头示威——他们并非反对共产党政府，而是支持德国马克。“如果德国马克来了，我们就留在这里，”他们高喊，“如果没来，我们就去用德国马克。”这番口号令科尔感到恐慌，他确信东德即将崩溃。他预见到1990年将有五十万难民涌入西德，引发巨大的社会动荡。没有人能向他保证，除了货币统一之外，还有什么办法能够阻止这股浪潮。还有另一个因素。科尔认为，货币联盟将完成统一的进程，正如1948-49年的货币改革促成了西方三个占领区的融合，最终形成了西德。如果科尔能够成就一番伟业，完成这项国家使命，他必将在历史上留下浓墨重彩的一笔。如果成功，他将成为一位堪比阿登纳，甚至俾斯麦的总理。

The politicians were thinking otherwise. The wave of emotion—the exultation after forty years of division—was overwhelming. At the same time, Chancellor Helmut Kohl was increasingly fearful of another kind of wave—a tidal wave of East German workers flooding into West Germany, seeking streets paved with gold. Pöhl argued, “After a certain time, when people realized that they couldn’t make a living, they would have gone back.” But Kohl could see the numbers swelling already, and East Germans were now demonstrating in the streets—not against the Communist government but in favor of the deutsche mark. “If the deutsche mark comes, we stay here,” they chanted. “If it doesn’t come, we’ll go to the deutsche mark.” The refrain alarmed Kohl, who was convinced that East Germany was about to implode. He could envision half a million refugees moving west in 1990, creating vast social tumult. No one could assure him that anything short of currency unification could hold back the flood. There was another factor as well. Kohl thought that monetary union would complete the job of reunification, just as the currency reform of 1948-49 had led to the fusing of the three Western occupation zones to create West Germany. Kohl would certainly earn himself a unique place in history by doing something great and carrying out this national mission. If successful, he would indeed be a chancellor on the level of an Adenauer—even a Bismarck.

1990年2月5日晚，在前往会见东德中央银行行长的途中，波尔在波恩停留，拜访了财政部长特奥·魏格尔。波尔回顾了反对仓促调整货币政策的论点。魏格尔委婉地暗示，事情可能会朝着不同的方向发展，德国联邦银行或许很快就不得不接管东德的货币政策。他引用了一句广为流传的话来佐证这一点。那是电视剧《碟中谍》德语配音版里的一句台词： “眼镜蛇，接管控制权。” 他想说的是，波尔应该继续关注。但波尔没听懂。毕竟，韦格尔喜欢开玩笑。

On the evening of February 5, 1990, on his way to meet the head of the East German central bank, Pöhl stopped in Bonn to see Theo Waigel, the finance minister. Pöhl reviewed the arguments against hasty action on the currencies. Waigel suggested, in an oblique way, that things might work out differently and that the Bundesbank might very soon have to take over monetary responsibility for East Germany. He did so by quoting a popular line from the German-dubbed version of the television series Mission: Impossible: “Cobra, take over control.” Pöhl, he was saying, should stay tuned. But Pöhl missed the cue. After all, Waigel liked to make jokes.

波尔随即前往柏林会见东德领导人。1990年2月6日，他在东柏林公开宣称货币联盟绝对不可能实现，那只是个幻想。但就在同一天的几个小时前，在波恩，包括魏格尔和经济部长奥托·冯·兰布斯多夫伯爵在内的一小群人与科尔在其办公室会面。他们决定将德国马克推广至东德。这项意义重大的决定，如同许多决策一样，是在仓促之下做出的。在当时形势的巨大压力下，所有决策者都没有预料到即将面临的巨大经济损失。当天下午，在波尔得知这一决定之前，波恩方面就宣布了这一决定。

Pöhl immediately went on to Berlin to meet with his East German counterpart. In East Berlin, on February 6, 1990, he publicly declared that monetary union was absolutely not on. It was a fantasy. But a few hours earlier on the same day, in Bonn, a small group met with Kohl in his office, including Waigel and economics minister Graf Otto von Lambsdorff. There they decided to expand the deutsche mark into East Germany. This momentously important decision was made, as decisions so often are, in an improvised manner. Under the intense pressure of events, none of the decision makers anticipated the enormous economic toll ahead. The decision was announced in Bonn that same afternoon, before Pöhl could be informed.

大多数人最初的反应是欣喜若狂。科尔和他的同事们坚信，货币统一正是东德所需要的，东德很快就能走上经济快速发展的道路。他们根本无法想象这将会带来怎样的后果。此时，或许只有波尔敢于公开表达自己的担忧：这项决定对东德来说将是一场经济灾难，它将扼杀东德的工业，并给整个德国带来巨大的损失。不久之后的一次内阁会议上，波尔明确表明了自己的立场。“我们没有咨询过联邦银行，”他说，“但这的确是一项政治决定。”他非常清楚外界对联邦银行权力的批评。联邦银行并非第二个政府，而是负责货币政策的机构，它将作为政府的一部分履行职责。“我们可以管理货币，”他最后说道，语气中却丝毫没有热情。11

For the most part, the immediate reaction was euphoric. Kohl and his colleagues had convinced themselves that currency unification was exactly what the doctor had ordered and that East Germany would soon be on an economic fast track. They simply could not conceive what the consequences would be. By this point, Pöhl was perhaps the only senior official who was willing to speak aloud the fear that the decision would be an economic disaster for East Germany, that it would kill off its industries and would prove immensely costly for Germany as a whole. At a cabinet meeting shortly afterward, Pöhl made his position clear. “The Bundesbank had not been consulted,” he said. “But it was a political decision.” He was very mindful of the criticism of the Bundesbank’s power. The bank was not a second government. It was an agency in charge of monetary policy, and it would do its job as part of the government. “We can manage the currency,” he finally said, although hardly with enthusiasm.11

然而，正如科尔所希望的那样，货币统一确实服务于一个总体性的国家目标：推动政治统一。1990年10月，柏林墙倒塌不到一年，货币统一三个月后，德国重新统一为一个国家。德国成为欧洲的主要强国，德国联邦银行在整个欧洲大陆的影响力也进一步增强。但对于西德而言，统一的过程也远比几乎所有人预想的要艰难、痛苦且代价高昂得多。

Currency unification did, however, serve an overarching national objective,as Kohl had hoped. It drove political reunification. In October 1990, less than a year after the fall of the Wall and three months after currency unification, Germany was reunited as one country. Germany became the major power in Europe, and the Bundesbank would become even more dominant across the Continent. But unification also turned out to be far more difficult and painful—and costly—for West Germany than almost anyone had anticipated.

不久之后，精疲力竭、沮丧不已的珀尔辞职了。统一带来的经济后果正如他所预料的那样。东德经济崩溃了。“我们知道如何进行心脏移植、肾脏移植、肝脏移植，”当时一位著名的西德经济学家解释说，“但在这里，我们却要一次性更换所有器官。”东德的工资水平逐渐接近西德。东德的大部分工业企业破产倒闭，因为它们无法与西德竞争。德国政府不得不补贴东德——在1990年至1997年间，补贴金额高达约7000亿美元，其中很大一部分用于支付失业救济金。其他社会效益。西德企业确实从中受益，因为它们得以更换破旧的基础设施，而东德人则掀起了一股抢购热潮。但很快，1991年柏林墙两侧的非凡喜悦就被弥漫的苦涩所取代。12

Not long after, Pöhl, exhausted and frustrated, resigned. The economic consequences of unification were as he had foreseen. The East German economy disintegrated. “We know how to carry out heart transplants, kidney transplants, liver transplants,” explained a prominent West German economist at the time. “But here, we are changing all the organs at once.” East German wages rose toward the level of West Germany’s. Much of East German industry went bankrupt; it could not compete. The German government had to subsidize the east—to the tune, between 1990 and 1997, of about $700 billion, a good part of which went to pay unemployment and other social benefits. West German companies did benefit, because they got to replace the decrepit infrastructure and because the East Germans went on a buying spree. But soon the extraordinary exultation of 1991, on both sides of the former Wall, gave way to pervasive bitterness.12

自1990年起，德国联邦银行为防范货币一体化带来的通胀风险，维持了严格的利率政策。这一举措的影响远超德国本土。由于严格的货币政策，整个西欧的经济增长停滞，失业率飙升至战后前所未有的高度。德国的局势对欧洲一体化的进程产生了决定性的影响。

From 1990 onward, the Bundesbank sought to forestall the inflationary risks of monetary unification by holding to tight interest rates. This had consequences far beyond Germany. As a result of the stringent monetary policy, economic growth throughout Western Europe stalled and unemployment rose to levels never seen in the postwar years. What happened in Germany would have a decisive impact on the course of European unity.

王国的货币

The Coin of the Realm

1991年12月，欧洲各国领导人齐聚荷兰马斯特里赫特，缔结了关于单一货币以及建立共同外交、安全和内政政策的条约。当时，共产主义崩溃和德国统一带来的经济后果并非全部显而易见，但足以影响会议进程。各国领导人意识到，他们身处一个全新的世界。他们在马斯特里赫特通过的决议将决定欧洲一体化的走向，并影响到21世纪。在政治上，他们同意在外交和安全政策方面开展更加紧密的合作。但他们最重要的决定是创建一种共同货币——欧元——以及一家负责管理欧元的欧洲中央银行。根据计划，欧元将于1999年1月正式成为官方货币。各国政府、中央银行和企业将以欧元进行交易、开具账目和发票。人们熟悉的各国硬币和纸币将继续在日常生活中使用，但由于欧元与各国货币之间存在固定联系，它们只能作为欧元的“象征”。因此，发票和银行账户将以欧元计价，而人们走进商店，仍会用他们熟悉的纸币和硬币购买羊角面包和香肠。流通货币的实际转换预计将在2002年1月至7月之间完成。届时，欧元将以纸币和硬币的形式正式进入人们的口袋，而各国货币将退出流通。

In December 1991, the European summit leaders met in the Dutch market town of Maastricht to conclude a treaty on the single currency and on establishing common foreign, security, and internal policies. Not all the economic consequences of the collapse of communism and German unification were yet clear, but enough was evident to affect the proceedings. The leaders recognized that they were in a new world. The decisions they approved at Maastricht would define the course of European unity well into the twenty-first century. Politically, they agreed to much tighter cooperation on foreign and security policies. But their most important decision was to create a common currency—the euro—and a European central bank to manage it. According to the plan, the euro will come into existence as the official currency in January 1999. Governments, central banks, and corporations will conduct their business and write their accounts and invoices in the euro. The familiar national coins and bills will continue to be used in everyday life but, owing to the fixed link, only as an “expression” of the euro. Thus, invoices and bank accounts will be denominated in the euro, while individuals will walk into shops and pay for their croissants and sausages with the familiar physical bills and coins they know. The actual changeover in circulating currency is slated to occur between January and July 2002. At that point, the euro will come into physical existence in the form of coins and bills in people’s pockets, and the national currencies will be withdrawn from circulation.

随着欧元的诞生，欧洲中央银行（ECB）也随之成立，负责管理欧元。目前，欧洲央行尚处于萌芽阶段，名为欧洲货币研究所，其模式仿照德国联邦银行。考虑到德国联邦银行在欧洲的主导地位，以及卡尔-奥托·珀尔曾担任欧洲央行章程起草委员会主席，这一点并不令人意外。事实上，欧洲央行在宪法中明确承诺要抑制通货膨胀，其力度甚至超过了德国联邦银行。如果欧洲央行按计划成立，它将大幅削弱各国政府的货币权力。关于利率和货币的根本性决策将在银行的超国家层面构思和实施，这标志着一种全新的局面——用波尔的话来说，就是“货币的非国家化”。

With the euro comes the European Central Bank (ECB) to manage it. Currently in nascent form as the European Monetary Institute, the ECB is modeled on the Bundesbank. This is not exactly surprising, given both the Bundesbank’s predominant role in Europe and the fact that it was Karl-Otto Pöhl who chaired the committee that drafted the ECB’s statutes. In fact, its explicit constitutional commitment to fight inflation is even stronger than that of the Bundesbank. If it comes into existence as designed, the ECB will drastically reduce the monetary power of national governments, for fundamental decisions about interest rates and currency will be conceived and implemented at the supranational level of the bank, marking something altogether new—in Pohl’s words, “the denationalization of money.”

然而，这一切是否能够实现，至少能否按计划时间表实现，目前尚不完全明朗。统一货币需要经济趋同，这意味着各国经济体在债务、赤字和通货膨胀等因素上必须步调一致。为了实现这一目标，《马斯特里赫特条约》包含一系列极其严格的“基准标准”，任何国家若想加入欧元区，都必须满足这些标准。关键标准包括：通货膨胀率不超过三个最低通胀率国家平均水平的1.5个百分点；国家预算赤字低于GDP的3%；国家债务低于GDP的60%（或接近该水平）；以及本国货币在过去两年内不得贬值。预计一些国家能够并且愿意满足这些要求；而另一些国家则无法满足。其结果将是欧洲出现两极分化，至少在未来几年内如此。

Yet it is not absolutely clear that all this will happen, at least on the timetable planned. A common currency requires economic convergence, and this means that economies must march to the same drummer when it comes to such factors as debt, deficits, and inflation. To achieve that, the Maastricht treaty contains a series of extremely tough “benchmark criteria,” which must be met if a country is going to climb aboard the euro wagon. The key criteria include: inflation at no more than 1.5 percentage points above the average rate of the three countries with the lowest rates; a national budget deficit that is less than 3 percent of GDP; a national debt below 60 percent of GDP (or headed there); and a national currency that cannot have been devalued within the previous two years. It is expected that some countries will be able—and willing—to meet these requirements; others will not. The result will be a two-tier Europe, at least for some years.

尽管这些标准被抨击为不切实际且武断，但该条约在解释和应用这些标准方面确实留有一定的灵活性。在欧元诞生之前，德国一直坚持对这些标准进行非常字面化和僵化的解释。一些人认为，马斯特里赫特条约标准的严苛反映了德国人担心其“硬通货”的德国马克会被一种更软的欧洲货币所取代，而这种货币太容易受到政客通胀诱惑的影响。德国方面则极力推动一项协议，以惩罚任何加入欧元区后偏离这些标准的国家。1997年6月，在阿姆斯特丹举行的欧洲峰会正式通过了这样一项“稳定与增长公约”。罚款最高可达国内生产总值的0.5%，这可能是一笔巨款。例如，试想一下，如果欧洲中央银行在法兰克福对法国处以约80亿美元的罚款——毫无疑问，这正值法国失业工人走上街头示威之际——将会是怎样一番景象。事实上，负责货币事务的欧盟委员伊夫·蒂博·德·西尔吉曾将《稳定与增长公约》描述为“货币核武器”——威力太大，无法使用。13

While the criteria have been attacked as unrealistic and arbitrary, the treaty does have some flexibility in how these criteria are interpreted and applied. In the run-up to the euro, it is Germany that has insisted on a very literal and inflexible interpretation. Some see reflected in the toughness of the Maastricht criteria Germans’ fears that their “hard” deutsche mark will be replaced by a softer European currency, too vulnerable to the inflationary temptations of politicians. For its part, Germany pushed hard for a pact to punish any country that strayed from these criteria after opting into the euro. The European summit in Amsterdam formally adopted, in June 1997, such a “Stability and Growth Pact.” Penalties could reach as much as one half of 1 percent of gross domestic product, which could become a very big number. Imagine, for instance, the spectacle of a European Central Bank in Frankfurt fining France some $8 billion—no doubt at the very time when unemployed French workers are demonstrating in the streets. Indeed, Yves-Thibault de Silguy, the European commissioner responsible for currency matters, has described the Stability and Growth Pact as a “monetary nuclear weapon”—too powerful to use.13

当然，如果高失业率和低增长持续存在，而马斯特里赫特条约的严格标准又未能得到落实，那么公众对单一货币的抵制情绪必将加剧。目前，人们对统一的欧洲已抱有日益增长的敌意，因为许多人认为它与经济停滞而非复苏和繁荣息息相关。他们还认为，解除限制措施对资本的益处远大于对劳动者的益处。为了应对这些焦虑情绪（这些情绪在1997年法国大选中有所体现），阿姆斯特丹峰会将解决失业问题列为首要任务。政治因素和选民的需求正迫使人们重新评估这一问题，因为如果欧元体系出现问题，“统一的欧洲”也将受到质疑。

Certainly, if high unemployment and low growth persist against the backdrop of the tough Maastricht criteria, public resistance to a common currency will grow. There is already growing hostility toward a united Europe, for many people see it as linked to stagnation, not renewed growth and prosperity. They also see the lifting of restrictions as benefiting capital much faster than it benefits labor. In response to these anxieties, manifested in the 1997 French elections, the Amsterdam summit established the fight against unemployment as a high priority. Politics and the demands of electorates are forcing such a reassessment, for if the euro is derailed, then “United Europe” will be put into question.

颇具讽刺意味的是，尽管德国人担心德国马克“社会化”会导致他们失去对自身经济命运的控制，但他们自己却对此感到不安。——也就是说，德国马克被欧元吸收——其他国家的一些人担心，欧元和欧洲央行的成立意味着德国联邦银行及其规则将凌驾于整个欧洲之上。然而，并非所有人都这么认为。例如，在法国人看来，德国联邦银行目前是欧洲事实上的中央银行，法国和其他任何国家都没有投票权。他们认为，通过加入欧洲中央银行体系，自身将获得更大的权力，该体系将对新的欧洲中央银行拥有管辖权。即使欧洲中央银行的成立不意味着马克的公有化，至少也意味着德国联邦银行的权力将被削弱。然而，无论如何，法兰克福——无论是作为德国联邦银行的所在地，还是作为未来欧洲中央银行的所在地——都将对欧洲的货币体系拥有最终决定权。

In a considerable irony, while Germans worry that they will lose control over their economic fate through the “socialization” of the deutsche mark—that is, its absorption into the euro—some in the other countries fear that the euro and the ECB will mean that the Bundesbank and its rules will prevail over all of Europe. That is not the way that everybody sees it, however. In the French view, for instance, the Bundesbank is Europe’s de facto central bank right now, and neither France nor any other nation gets to have a vote. They see themselves gaining more power through their membership in the European System of Central Banks, which will have authority over the new European Central Bank. If it does not mean the socialization of the mark, the creation of a European Central Bank will at least mean the dilution of the Bundesbank. One way or the other, however, Frankfurt—whether as the Buba’s home or as the future home of the putative European Central Bank—will be calling the shots on Europe’s money.

私有化

Privatization

根据《马斯特里赫特条约》，削减赤字的需求正在加速欧洲的私有化进程。目前正在发生的一切，标志着混合经济体制传统优势地位的全面瓦解。其规模非常庞大。自1985年以来，欧洲已出售超过1000亿美元的资产。从大众汽车、汉莎航空和雷诺，到法国的埃尔夫-阿基坦石油公司和意大利的埃尼集团，许多历史悠久的工业巨头都经历了重组，随后被部分或全部出售。国有电信运营商的股权出售也已开始，德国电信26%股份的130亿美元公开发行——欧洲有史以来规模最大的私有化交易——为这一进程奠定了基础。到2000年，可能还会有3000亿美元的政府资产被出售。财政部长们热衷于私有化的原因有很多。它能带来巨额收入，有助于减少赤字（尽管销售收入本身并不计入《马斯特里赫特条约》的赤字标准）。它减少了补贴支出，并创造了增加税收的潜力。此外，它还能将未注资养老金的责任从国家转移出去，随着人口结构老龄化，这一点变得越来越重要。但这并非全部原因。

The need to reduce deficits, in accordance with Maastricht, is helping to accelerate the process of privatization in Europe. What is unfolding represents a wholesale retreat from the classic commanding heights of the mixed economies. The numbers are very large. Since 1985, over $100 billion in assets have been sold off in Europe. Venerable national champions in industry—from Volkswagen, Lufthansa, and Renault to the oil companies Elf-Aquitaine of France and ENI of Italy—have been subject to reorganizations followed by partial or complete sales. The sale of stakes in governmentowned telecommunications providers has begun, its pace set by the $13 billion public offering of 26 percent of Deutsche Telekom—Europe’s largest privatization on record. Before the year 2000, another $300 billion in government assets could be sold off. Finance ministers are attracted to privatization for several reasons. It brings in big money, which helps reduce deficits (although the sales revenues themselves do not count against the Maastricht deficit criteria). It cuts the outflow of subsidies and creates the potential for greater tax revenues. And it also shifts unfunded-pension responsibilities away from the state, which is of increasing importance as demographics tilt toward the elderly. But those are not the only reasons.

人们的观念也正在发生根本性的转变。在许多情况下（但并非所有情况），国有企业的神秘感已经消散。国有企业曾被视为现代化的推动者、捍卫者、进步的引擎、技术进步的手段以及国家目标的化身。多年来，国有企业也确实扮演了这样的角色。但如今，国有所有权越来越被视为一种实际或潜在的负担，它会导致效率低下，限制企业的灵活性和应对日益激烈的国际竞争的能力，并阻碍技术创新。由于国有性质，国有企业最终会做出受政治压力影响的决​​策，而政客们也很难抵挡住干预的诱惑。“国有企业确实存在一个谜团，”有人沉思道。法国前总统瓦莱里·吉斯卡尔·德斯坦说：“他们的管理层都是优秀的人——精英中的精英。然而，他们却无法高效运作。相反，他们抗拒变革，凌驾于一切之上。这真是令人费解。”

A fundamental change in outlook is also taking place. In many, but not all, cases, the mystique of the state-owned company has dissipated. Once it was seen as the modernizer, the champion, the engine ofprogress, the means for technological advance, the embodiment of national purpose. And for many years state companies did play such a role. But state ownership has increasingly come to be seen as a liability, actual or potential, which promotes inefficiency, limits a firm’s flexibility and ability to cope with increased international competition, and hinders technological innovation. Because it is state owned, it ends up making decisions that respond to political pressures, and politicians find it mighty hard to resist the temptation to intervene. “There is a mystery about state-owned companies,” mused former French president Valéry Giscard d’Estaing. “They are managed by good people—the best names of the elite. And yet they are unable to operate efficiently. Instead, they resist change, they are above events. It is mysterious.”

单一市场的动态也在发生变化。欧盟委员会对企业的公有制或私有制持中立态度，但它坚持消除竞争和市场准入的障碍。这一原则明确挑战了公共垄断；曾经被视为自然垄断的行业，例如电力行业，如今正受到边缘市场竞争的侵蚀。当不再存在受保护的“国家市场”时，国有企业就可能成为一种明显的阻碍。公共垄断企业可能会发现自己被排除在更广阔的机遇之外。“如果我们的企业想要为未来做好准备，就必须让它们接触竞争和真正的增长市场，”意大利前工业部长阿尔贝托·克洛说道。 “来自这些市场的企业应该在意大利参与竞争。意大利电力公司（ENEL）——意大利的主要电力公司——是世界上最大的公用事业公司之一，但它所在的国家电力使用量年增长率仅为1%。电力行业的未来在于亚洲、中欧和拉丁美洲。ENEL必须能够在这些市场竞争。为此，我们需要向外国投资开放意大利市场。”

The dynamics of the single market force change as well. The European Commission is agnostic on the issue of public or private ownership of firms, but it insists on the lifting of obstacles to competition and market entry. This doctrine explicitly challenges public monopolies; and sectors once considered natural monopolies, such as electric power, are now being eroded by competition on their fringes. When there is no longer a protected “national market,” state ownership can become a definite hindrance. And public monopolies might find themselves excluded from opportunities further afield. “If our companies are to be ready for the future, they must be exposed to competition and the real growth markets,” said Alberto Clô, Italy’s former minister of industry. “And people from those markets should compete in Italy. ENEL—Italy’s main electric company—is one of the largest public utilities in the world, but it operates in a country where electricity use grows at only 1 percent a year. The future of power is Asia, Central Europe, and Latin America. ENEL must be able to compete in those markets. To do so, we need to open the Italian market to foreign investment.”

推动私有化的另一个因素是技术。“1973年我刚加入工党时，花了一周时间学习马克思主义，了解生产力的变化如何改变社会结构，”挪威前财政大臣延斯·斯托尔滕贝格回忆道。“当时的动力是技术。我们被教导说，技术创造社会主义只是时间问题。如今，技术确实在带来变革，但它并没有创造社会主义。它促进了资本主义的发展，带来了更多的竞争。直到20世纪80年代末，我们只有一个电视频道。当时禁止设立第二个频道。在1985年的选举中，这是一个重要议题。我们党反对私有化；我们认为这对挪威人民不利，而且过于商业化。但后来出现了卫星电视，政策变得荒谬可笑。我们不得不让步——不得不改变——因为技术。”

Another factor is driving privatization as well—technology. “When I started in the Labor Party in 1973, I spent a week learning about Marxism, how changes in the forces of production change the structure of society,” recalled Jens Stoltenberg, recently finance minister of Norway. “The force was technology. It was only a question of time, we were taught, before technology would create socialism. Today technology is creating change, but it’s not creating socialism. It’s encouraging capitalism. It’s creating more competition. We had only one television channel until the end of the 1980s. It was forbidden to establish another. In the 1985 election, this was a big issue. Our party was against it; we said it was bad for Norway’s population, it was too commercial. But then came satellite dishes, and the policies became ridiculous. We had to give in—to change—because of technology.”

尽管这波“私有化浪潮”表明各国之间存在诸多趋同之处，但各国推行私有化的方式却存在关键差异。在法国，大多数大型交易都涉及将控股权股份转让给所谓的“核心股东”（ noyaux durs） ——即政府信任的战略投资者，他们能够长期稳定地支撑公司发展。在意大利，私有化意味着拆分中央控股公司工业复兴研究所（IRI）。在此过程中，意大利企业和政府之间错综复杂的法律和财务往来也暴露无遗。而在德国，尽管地方政府有时会反对那些会导致工厂关闭和失业的私有化项目，但联邦层面的私有化动力强劲，这得益于德国在原东德时期对工业和贸易进行私有化的独特经验。短短五年内，一个名为“工业和贸易私有化办公室”（The Institute of Industrial Estate Management Office）的特别机构就取得了显著成效。信托局出售了13700家东德企业，总价值约250亿美元。在其最后的举措中，在彻底清空了所有库存后，它进行了私有化。

For all the convergence among countries that this “wave of privatization” implies, there are key differences in the ways each country goes about it. In France, most big sales have involved the transfer of a controlling packet of shares to so-called noyaux durs—“hard cores” of strategic investors whom government trusted to anchor the firm for the long term. In Italy, privatization has meant unbundling the central holding company Istituto per la Ricostruzione Industriale (IRI). In the process, it has brought to light many of the tangled legal and financial dealings of Italian business and government. And in Germany, although local governments sometimes oppose privatizations that would lead to plant closures and job losses in their region, the drive to privatize at the federal level is strong, and it benefits from the country’s unique experience of having privatized industry and trade in the former East Germany. Over just five years, a special office called the Treuhandanstalt sold off 13,700 East German firms for a total of approximately $25 billion. In its final act, after it had completely cleared its shelf of its inventory, it privatized itself.

私有化正在欧洲催生一个重要的新兴产业：监管。过去，政府拥有企业，因此无需独立监管。政府部门负责制定电话、水、天然气和电力等服务的价格。但如今，新近私有化的企业掌握了主动权，它们制定价格和运营条款。因此，政府的角色发生了变化。政府的职责是保护消费者，确保价格竞争力、安全性和质量标准。为此，需要建立新的机构来监管价格和行为。英国率先启动了私有化进程，率先建立了监管体系，该体系至今仍在不断调整完善，而且规模远超预期。各种类型的自治监管机构在欧洲各地如雨后春笋般涌现。

Privatization is leading to a major new growth industry in Europe: regulation. When governments owned companies, there was no need for independent regulation. The ministry set the prices for such services as telephone, water, natural gas, and electricity. But the newly privatized companies are now in charge, and they set prices and the terms of operation. Government’s role has, therefore, changed. Its job is to protect consumers by ensuring competitive prices, safety, and standards of quality. To do this requires designing new institutions to regulate prices and practices. Having gotten the early start in privatization, Britain was first to set up a regulatory system, which it is still adjusting and which is also proving to be much bigger than originally anticipated. Autonomous regulatory boards of various kinds have sprung up all across Europe.

私有化仍然需要与工会进行艰难的谈判，以及欧盟成员国之间就各行业未来竞争规则达成复杂的妥协。然而，曾经几乎不可想象的事情如今已成为欧洲政府的常规且被广泛接受的工具。摆在眼前的是一场更为复杂和艰难的斗争——一场直指欧洲社会契约核心的斗争：福利国家的未来。14

Privatization still involves tough negotiations with unions, as well as complicated compromises among European Union members about the rules of future competition in each industry. Yet what was once almost unthinkable has become a standard and accepted tool of government in Europe. What looms ahead is a far more complex and difficult battle—one that goes to the very heart of the European social contract: the future of the welfare state.14

福利国家的代价

The Costs of the Welfare State

除了产业结构调整，《马斯特里赫特条约》还强制控制社会支出。多年来，西欧的社会支出飙升，平均占GDP的42%。二战后，欧洲的首次趋同——远早于《马斯特里赫特条约》——是将混合经济与福利国家相结合。人们认为，混合经济能够实现充分就业和经济增长。而经济增长的很大一部分将通过社会支出进行再分配，以确保社会安全与稳定。福利国家也一直是欧洲领先的增长产业之一——至少在最近一段时间内是如此。

In addition to industrial restructuring, Maastricht forces a reining in of social spending, which has soared over the years to reach an average of 42 percent of GDP in Western Europe. Europe’s first convergence after World War II—long before Maastricht—was on the mixed economy combined with the welfare state. The mixed economy, it was felt, would deliver full employment and growth. A significant part of that growth would, in turn, be redistributed through social spending that would ensure security and social peace. The welfare state has also proved to be one of Europe’s leading growth industries—at least until recently.

欧洲社会体系出现问题的信号是失业。20世纪90年代中期，失业取代通货膨胀，成为头条新闻、警钟和选举中的主导议题。工厂倒闭、裁员、重组以及来自国外的竞争导致旧工作岗位消失。政府越来越不愿意补贴亏损企业以保住就业。20世纪70年代，法国的失业人数从26.2万人飙升至100多万人。1982年，法国社会党担心失业人数会突破200万。1997年，这一数字超过了300万。辍学学生的失业率高达29%。西欧工业化国家的平均失业率在10%到15%之间。南欧的情况更糟。充分就业原本这应该是混合经济的主要保障之一。但实际上，越来越多的人仅仅受雇于发放失业救济金的政府机构。

The signal that Europe’s social systems have gone wrong is unemployment. In the mid-1990s, it has replaced inflation as the headline, the alarm bell, and the dominant issue in elections. Old jobs are being eliminated by plant closings, downsizing, restructuring—and competition from outside national borders. Governments are much less prone to subsidize loss-making firms in order to preserve employment. During the 1970s, unemployment in France rose from 262,000 to over 1 million. In 1982, the French Socialists feared crossing the threshold of 2 million unemployed. In 1997, the number is over 3 million. Among school dropouts the rate of unemployment is 29 percent. On average in industrial Western Europe, unemployment hovers between 10 and 15 percent. In southern Europe it is worse. Full employment was to be one of the main guarantees of the mixed economy. But increasing numbers of people are, in effect, employed only by the government agencies that disburse unemployment benefits.

失业率上升预示着更广泛的挑战——整个福利体系、各项权利、社会支出以及劳动力市场保障体系都面临着严峻考验。这是养老金和补偿制度的危机，该制度已被人口结构的变化所超越，无法自给自足。“欧洲的福利制度最初建立时非常完善且公平，”瓦莱里·吉斯卡尔·德斯坦回忆道，“但如今人们的预期寿命远远超过了最初方案的预期。”人口结构的变化只会更加严峻。到2030年，法国和英国64岁以上人口与15至64岁人口的比例将达到40%，德国则接近50%。

Rising unemployment signals a broader challenge—to the entire edifice of welfare, entitlements, social spending, and protections in the labor market. It is the crisis of a system of pensions and compensations that has been overtaken by demographics and can no longer pay for itself. “When Europe’s welfare systems were originally set up, they were very good and fair,” recalled Valéry Giscard d’Estaing. “But the current life span now greatly exceeds the anticipated life expectancy of the original schemes.” The demographics are only going to get more difficult. By the year 2030, the proportion of people over sixty-four to those between fifteen and sixty-four will be 40 percent in France and Britain, and nearly 50 percent in Germany.

在欧洲大陆国家中，荷兰在应对福利国家问题方面比邻国做得更多。20世纪80年代，荷兰经济表现不佳。这种被称为“荷兰病”的现象源于荷兰的特殊情况——天然气产量的快速增长及其带来的巨额财富。正如前首相鲁德·吕贝尔斯所言，“由于政治上的盲目以及天然气储量带来的国民收入快速增长的诱惑，福利国家已经‘过度成熟’。”不断增长的福利被轻易发放。失业救济金几乎与工资水平持平，这降低了人们的工作积极性。很快，近三分之一的劳动力都领取了失业救济金、残疾补助或其他社会福利。

Among the Continental countries, the Netherlands has done more than its neighbors to come to grips with the problems of the welfare state.
