In the 1980s, the Netherlands found itself suffering from poor economic performance. The “Dutch disease,” as it was dubbed, had its origin in Holland’s particular circumstances—the rapid growth of natural-gas production and the great wealth that came with it. In the words of former prime minister Ruud Lubbers, “The welfare state had ‘overmatured,’ through a combination of political blindnesss and the easy temptation of rapidly increasing national income due to natural-gas reserves.” Ever-growing benefits were handed out with ease. Unemployment assistance was so close to wage levels as to decrease the incentive to work. Soon almost one third of the workforce was on unemployment, disability, or other social benefits.

面对经济困境，政府被迫摒弃了传统的凯恩斯主义政策，开始调整经济结构——削减预算赤字、减税、推行“工资适度增长”，并简化雇佣和解雇流程，允许企业雇用兼职员工。失业救济金也被削减。自这些改革以来，荷兰经济迅速复苏，失业率低于邻国，并被视为福利国家温和改革的典范。然而，批评人士认为，实际失业率远高于官方数据。当然，没有人会否认荷兰的福利制度依然十分慷慨。

Forced to confront the illness, the government discarded the orthodox Keynesian prescription and began to redirect the economy—reducing the budget deficit, cutting taxes, promoting “wage moderation,” and making it easier to hire and fire and to employ part-time workers. Unemployment benefits were reduced. Since these reforms, the Netherlands has bounded back with lower unemployment than its neighbors and is discussed as a model for a moderate redesign of the welfare state. Critics, however, argue that the real unemployment rate is much higher than the official numbers. And certainly, no one would say that the welfare state in the Netherlands remains anything but generous.

“Fango in the Morning”

“Fango in the Morning”

美国和欧洲在态度上的差异十分显著。在美国，“福利”一词几乎成了贬义词。相比之下，欧洲人将福利国家视为欧洲大陆最伟大的成就之一，是文明社会不可或缺的组成部分，也是社会共识的基石。即使对福利国家提出批评，也是因为其过度干预，而不是因为其……这是一个理念。无论左翼还是右翼政府都致力于此。例如，德国人记得，正是铁血宰相俾斯麦——他绝非社会主义者——在19世纪80年代创建了第一个现代养老金制度。正如一位西班牙著名实业家所说：“在欧洲，福利国家备受尊重。根据欧洲社会契约，政府保障社会安全，而且这安全网相当完善。”现代福利国家是民族认同的一部分，当欧洲人谈到“团结”时，他们指的不仅是克服阶级和意识形态斗争，也包括福利国家的整体运作。

The contrast in attitudes between the United States and Europe is striking. In America, the term welfare is almost a dirty word. By comparison, the welfare state is seen by Europeans as one of the Continent’s greatest achievements, an essential element of a civilized society and the foundation of social consensus. When it is criticized, it is for its excesses, not for its concept. Governments of both the right and the left are committed to it. The Germans, for instance, recollect that it was the Iron Chancellor, Bismarck—hardly a socialist—who created the first modern pension system, beginning in the 1880s. In the words of a prominent Spanish industrialist, “In Europe, the welfare state is highly respected. According to the European social contract, the government guarantees the safety net, and it is quite a high safety net.” The modern welfare state is part of national identity, and when Europeans speak of “solidarity,” they mean not only the overcoming of class and ideological battles but also the sum of the welfare state.

但福利制度也因其自身的慷慨而走向极端。在德国，典型的带薪假期只有六周。失业救济金占工资的很大一部分，而养老金与工作无关。“如今德国的现状令人匪夷所思，”一位商人评论道，“在我们这个社会，一个工作了三十年、富有生产力的人退休后，领取的养老金竟然和一个失业了三十年的人——一个一辈子都没工作过的人——一样。这简直太离谱了。”这种慷慨还体现在福利制度涵盖的各种治疗和服务上。许多德国人秉承歌德诗歌的伟大传统，喜欢去温泉疗养，他们的医生也鼓励他们这样做。而这些费用都由社会福利制度承担。其中一种广受欢迎的疗法是泥敷，也被称为“fango” ，人们甚至用一句俏皮话来形容这种由纳税人买单的疗养带来的“快乐”：“早上敷fango，晚上跳探戈。”

But the welfare system has also been overtaken by its own generosity. In Germany, the typical paid vacation time is six weeks. Unemployment benefits are a high proportion of wages, and pensions are unrelated to work. “It is an amazing situation in Germany today,” observed one businessman. “Ours is a society in which a person who worked for thirty years of productive life and then retires gets paid the same pension as someone who for thirty years was unemployed—someone who did not work his entire life. Something has gotten out of hand.” The generosity extends to the range of treatments and services that the system will cover. Many Germans, in the grand tradition of Goethe’s poetry, like to go to spas to take a “cure,” and they are encouraged to do so by their doctors. The social welfare system pays. One much-favored therapy is the mud pack, otherwise known as the fango, which has given rise to a little epithet for the joys of such taxpayerpaid cures: “Fango in the morning and tango in the evening.”

为了满足过度扩张的社会福利体系的各项义务，不断膨胀的支出推高了“社会成本”——即纳税人和雇主为维持该体系运转而必须缴纳的资金。对雇主而言，这些成本已高到令人望而却步，以至于抑制了他们雇佣新员工的积极性。旨在保护劳动者的大量劳动法规如今却使该体系不堪重负，迫使雇主承担超出其掌控范围的问题成本，并阻碍了他们创造新的就业机会。与此同时，高额的失业救济金也可能导致人们不愿工作。此外，工会的法律和制度权力也阻碍了变革和创新，这同样是造成僵化局面的原因之一。一家德国大型企业的管理层花了三年时间才说服工会允许引入语音信箱。这些成本和监管对初创企业和创业型企业的影响尤为沉重。然而，事实证明，这类企业是美国创造就业的最重要引擎之一。最终结果可以从就业数据中体现出来。 1993年至1997年间，美国的净就业人数增长了8%，而欧洲的净就业人数则保持不变。

Mushrooming expenses to meet the commitments of an overextended social welfare system drive up “social charges”—the amount of money that taxpayers and employers must contribute to keep the system running. For employers, those charges have reached levels so high that they discourage the hiring of new workers. Reams of labor legislation, meant to help protect workers, now bog down the system, forcing employers to carry the costs of a problem that lies beyond their grasp—and discouraging them from creating new jobs. At the same time, the level of unemployment benefits is so high that it can create a disincentive to work. The rigidities also include the legal and institutional power of unions to impede change and innovation. It took the management of a major German company three years to get its unions to permit the introduction of voice mail. These costs and regulations fall particularly hard on start-up and entrepreneurial businesses. Yet such businesses have proved to be among the most important engines of job creation in the United States. The overall results can be measured in employment figures. Between 1993 and 1997 net employment in the United States grew by 8 percent, while in Europe it remained flat.

然而，如今在许多欧洲人的心中，人们越来越意识到社会模式亟需重大改革。人们普遍认为，福利国家的规模已经扩张过度，必须在福利和监管两方面进行调整和重塑。“我们目前面临的问题是……”“西欧标志着传统福利国家的终结，”卡尔-奥托·珀尔指出。“这无法完全逆转。你不可能抹去过去一百年的发展。但必须进行重组。”

Yet today, in the minds of many Europeans, the realization has grown that the social model is in need of significant repair. There is a sense that the welfare state has expanded too far and must be rolled back and reshaped, in terms of both its benefits and regulation. “What we are confronting in Western Europe is the end of the welfare state in its classical form,” observed Karl-Otto Pöhl. “It cannot be reversed completely. You can’t undo developments of the last hundred years. But there has to be a restructuring.”

挑战在于构思并实施社会领域的结构性变革，重组福利国家，使其服务以更低的成本和更高的效率提供——并且这一切都必须获得民众的认可。所有这一切都不能忽视团结的基本价值观。这正是欧洲政治家们，无论左右，在努力适应彼得·萨瑟兰（前欧盟委员会委员、世界贸易组织首任总干事）所说的“低通胀和稳健公共财政的新共识”时所面临的问题。这种适应对社会民主党人来说尤其困难。他们已经放弃了大规模国家控制的主张，如今的主要任务是保护、改革和振兴福利国家。而就业仍将是检验一切的试金石。“上世纪70年代社会民主党的失败之处在于他们无法保障就业，”挪威的延斯·斯托尔滕贝格说道，“如果这些市场导向的政策也不能提供就业机会，那么人们就会另谋出路。”15

The challenge is to conceive and carry out structural changes in the social sector and to reorganize the welfare state so that its services are carried out at lower cost and with greater efficiency—and to do so with popular consent. And all this without losing sight of the basic values of solidarity. That is the issue facing Europe’s politicians, both left and right of center, as they try to adapt to what Peter Sutherland, the former European commissioner and first head of the World Trade Organization, called “the new consensus of low inflation and sound public finance.” This adaptation is particularly hard for social democrats. Having given up the case for massive state control, their main missions today are the protection, reform, and revitalization of the welfare state. And employment will remain the acid test. “It was the failure of the social-democratic parties in the 1970s that they couldn’t deliver job security,” said Norway’s Jens Stoltenberg. “If these market-oriented policies don’t provide jobs either, then people will look for something else.”15

“困境”

“A Predicament”

“我相信欧洲充满活力，”曾于1974年至1982年担任西德总理八年的赫尔穆特·施密特说道。此前，他曾任国防部长和财政部长。他对当前的困境有着非凡的权威性和历史感。二战结束时，他是一名英国战俘。战后，他投身社会主义政治，并在汉堡市政府步步高升。他是社会民主党右翼成员，亲西方，也是北约的支持者。许多人认为他是他那个时代最杰出的政治家，对政治和经济都有着非凡的理解。然而，他为人诟病的一点是缺乏耐心，因为他觉得那些理解力跟不上他的人。

“I do believe that there is enough vitality in Europe,” observed Helmut Schmidt, who was chancellor of West Germany for eight years, from 1974 to 1982. Before that, he was defense minister and finance minister. He brings an unusual authority and historical sense to the current dilemmas. A British prisoner of war when World War II ended, he threw himself into socialist politics after the war and rose up through the Hamburg city government. He was on the right wing of the Social Democratic Party, a man of the West, and a partisan of NATO. He is considered by many to have been the most able statesman of his time, with an unusual grasp of both politics and economics. One quality he famously lacked was patience for those whose understanding, he thought, did not keep pace.

他在《时代周报》（Die Zeit）的办公室里思考着欧洲的现状。《时代周报》是德国著名的周刊，他是该报的出版人。汉堡外面寒风凛冽，但透过窗户射进来的阳光却明亮刺眼。谈话间，他时不时地拿出一个塑料盒，深深地吸了一口鼻烟。“是的，”他说，“欧洲各国有能力摆脱当前的结构性困境。但公众并不总是意识到问题的存在，意识到困境。一旦欧洲公众意识到这一点，就需要减轻社会服务的负担，降低税收，寻找生产新产品的新方法，才能在全球经济中保持竞争力。上世纪70年代，我曾对欧洲共同体的自由化充满信心。但我没有预见到中国正在发生的巨大变革。”1978年及之后，我曾认为世界杯会取得巨大成功。我当时并不看好日本或亚洲四小龙。如今，亚洲国家已成为世界杯的领头羊，欧洲则失去了许多优势。

He was reflecting on Europe’s condition in his office at Die Zeit, the prestigious German weekly of which he is the publisher. The day in Hamburg outside was very cold, but the light coming in through the window was bright and knife sharp. Occasionally during the conversation, he took out a plastic box and inhaled snuff with deep breaths. “Yes,” he said, “the European nations are capable of getting out of the present-day structural difficulties. But the public does not always understand that there is a problem, a predicament. Once the European public does understand, there will be the need to reduce the burden of social services, reduce taxation, find new ways to produce new goods in order to be competitive in the global economy. In the 1970s, I had every confidence that liberalization in the European Community would work. I did not see the great changes taking place in China in 1978 and after, and the enormous success it would have. I did not really believe in the success of Japan or the tigers. Now the Asians have become the lead players. Europe has lost great points of advantage.

“欧洲衰落的一个关键因素是福利国家的过度扩张，”他继续说道。“福利国家本身是个好主意，但瑞典、法国、德国以及所有欧洲国家都将其推向了极端。随着各国人口老龄化加剧，预期寿命也越来越长。为了提供更长时间的养老金保障，各国的财政状况将持续恶化。这导致每个欧洲国家都面临过高的税收和巨额的财政赤字。长期以来，每个人都认为自己的财务状况很安全。现在我们知道并非如此。”他停顿了一下。“至少，我们中的一些人明白这一点。”

“A critical factor in the decline of Europe is the overexploitation of the welfare state,” he continued. “The welfare state is such a good idea, but it has been driven to extremes by Sweden, by France, by Germany, by all the European countries. As the nations’ societies are getting older and older, the age of death gets higher. The necessity to provide pension cover for much longer times will create financial situations that will continue to deteriorate. This leads to too-high taxation, too-big budgetary deficits in every European state. For far too long, everyone believed that they were safe financially. Now we know that they are not.” He paused. “At least, some of us know.”

施密特认为，欧洲目前的困境正是欧洲成功地将过去抛诸脑后的结果。 “欧洲经济增长放缓的原因之一，”他说道，“在于英国、法国、意大利、德国，乃至欧洲其他任何地方，如今掌权的几代人——无论是在政界、商界、工会还是官僚机构——几乎没有经历过希特勒的暴行、二战的苦难以及占领的阴影。他们的前辈们怀着重建社会的决心，力图避免重蹈百年来的覆辙。而现在的领导人成长于截然不同的环境，他们的父母每隔三五年就能过上更好的生活。他们把生活水平的提高视为理所当然。这是一种理性的、社会的、政治的思维模式。他们缺乏建设和重建的动力。如今，市场的变化速度远超政治领导人的应对能力。欧洲的政治领导层已经落后于市场思维。政客们仍然固守着错误的经济观念；他们固守着自己熟悉的过去。”16

Indeed, as Schmidt sees matters, Europe’s current difficulties are the consequences of Europe’s success in putting the past behind it. “One of the reasons for the slowing of growth in Europe,” he said, “is the fact that in Britain, France, Italy, or Germany, or wherever in Europe, the generations who are now in power—in politics, business, unions, the bureaucracies—are people who hardly suffered from Hitler, from World War II, and the occupation. Their predecessors were driven by the will to rebuild society, so that the catastrophes of the preceding hundred years would not be repeated. The current leaders grew up in different circumstances, in which their parents were better off every three or five years. They have taken improving standards of living for granted. It is an intellectual feeling, a social feeling, a political feeling. There is no motivation to drive to build and rebuild. Now the market is moving faster than political leaders can keep up with. The political leadership in Europe is lagging behind the thinking in the marketplace. Politicians still deal with misplaced economic perceptions; they have hung on to the past they know.”16

但那段过去已成往事。改革福利国家，重新界定政府与公民之间的责任，如今已成为欧洲的核心使命之一。欧洲不会放弃福利国家，而是会寻求通过重新定义“团结”来更新其社会契约，在以往以权利和应享权益为主导的原则中加入个人责任的概念——也就是说，公民将承担一部分社会服务成本，并承担更多养老保障责任。这场辩论将涉及“公共利益”的新旧理念。不可避免地，它也将质疑未来的工作模式——工作时长、灵活性、规则——以及代际平衡。

But that past is gone. Reforming the welfare state, and redefining responsibilities between governments and citizens, now emerges as one of Europe’s central missions. Rather than retreating from the welfare state, Europe will seek to renew its social contract by redefining “solidarity,” adding a concept of personal responsibility to what has been the overriding principle of rights and entitlements—that is, citizens would bear some share of the costs of social services and would take greater responsibility for funding their retirement. The debate will confront old and new ideas of the “public interest.” Inevitably, it will also question the future of work—its length, its flexibility, its rules—and the balance among generations.

这一切都引发了相当程度的不安和焦虑。高水平的生活和高度的安全保障是欧洲混合经济的巨大成就。然而，欧洲人不再觉得他们“从未如此幸福”。过度扩张的福利体系削弱了创造财富以支付其开支的能力。现行体系体现了国家对公民根深蒂固的义务。如今，随着欧洲联邦制的实施，人们更加担忧国家本身会逐渐衰落，这加剧了人们的焦虑。这是阿尔蒂埃罗·斯皮内利在二战时期绝望的日子里于文托泰内河畔构想的愿景。现有的秩序必将受到单一欧洲市场和全球经济一体化带来的竞争压力，以及尚不明朗的新治理规则的影响而发生改变。其最终的回报将是能够巩固欧洲在21世纪团结的复兴。

All this is provoking a good deal of consternation and anxiety. The high standard of living and high degree of security stand as great achievements of Europe’s mixed economies. Yet Europeans no longer feel that they “never had it so good.” The overextended welfare system undermines the ability to create the wealth required to pay for it. The current system reflects the deep-seated obligation of the state to its citizens. Adding now to the anxiety is the sense that the state itself will erode as Europe implements the federal vision that Altiero Spinelli dreamed about on Ventotene during those hopeless days of World War II. The existing arrangements will certainly be transformed by competitive pressures from both a single European market and the integration of global economies, and by still-unclear new rules of governance. The payoff will be the renewal that can undergird solidarity in Europe’s twenty-first century.

1欧洲经济共同体或“共同市场”成立于 1957 年，1987 年更名为欧洲共同体，1992 年又更名为欧盟，即其目前的名称。

1The European Economic Community or “Common Market,” founded in 1957, became in 1987 the European Community, which in turn in 1992 became the European Union, its current nomenclature.

第十二章

CHAPTER 12

地球上最后一个超级大国于1995年12月16日关闭了国门。美国政府资金短缺。由于比尔·克林顿领导的民主党政府与纽特·金里奇和鲍勃·多尔领导的共和党控制的国会之间陷入僵局，政府无力支付各项账单。

THE LAST SUPERPOWER on earth shut its doors on December 16, 1995. The United States government was running out of money. Owing to a deadlock between the Democratic administration of Bill Clinton and the Republicancontrolled Congress led by Newt Gingrich and Bob Dole, funds were not available to pay the government’s bills.

数十万联邦雇员被遣散回家。另有数十万人只领到部分工资，甚至根本没有工资。国防部获得了资金，因此得以继续运转，但许多其他政府机构却无法运作。由于气象局对安全至关重要，所以仍在运行，但却无力支付员工工资。在一些机构，只有“必要”员工才需要到办公室上班。然而，由于同事缺席，他们能做的事情寥寥无几，于是被建议带上填字游戏。就连参议院餐厅也关闭了。由于员工无法上班，华盛顿的街道空空荡荡，如同节假日一般。华盛顿纪念碑关闭了，林肯纪念堂也关闭了。大多数博物馆也关门歇业。一个展出荷兰大师维米尔35幅已知画作中21幅的独特展览，在筹集到私人资金支付保安人员工资后才得以继续开放。

Several hundred thousand federal workers were sent home. Hundreds of thousands more received partial paychecks or no paychecks at all. The Defense Department was funded and thus kept working, but many other government agencies were not. Because it was essential to safety, the Weather Bureau was running, but there was no way to pay its employees. In some agencies, only “essential” workers came to the office. Since there was very little that they could do in the absence of their colleagues, however, they were advised to bring crossword puzzles. Even the Senate cafeteria closed. With workers not coming to work, Washington’s streets were as empty as on a major holiday. The Washington Monument was closed. So was the memorial to Abraham Lincoln. Most of the museums were shuttered as well. A unique exhibit of twenty-one of the thirty-five known paintings of the Dutch master Vermeer was kept open only after private funds were scrounged up to pay the security guards.

全国各地的联邦政府都关闭了，包括大约397个国家公园。在佛罗里达州，大沼泽地国家公园的入口被路障封锁，并挂着一块牌子，上面写着“因预算僵局关闭”。愤怒的游客们收到公园负责人的一封信，信中解释了国家的预算问题，但他们仍然无法平静下来。“他们这是在拿人们的生命玩弄1996年的政治游戏，”一位从宾夕法尼亚州开车到佛罗里达州的游客抱怨道，结果却被拒之门外。人们被拒绝进入大沼泽地国家公园。由于联邦住房管理局人手严重不足，人们无法获得抵押贷款批准，也无法办理护照。由于世界各地的美国大使馆关闭，有意前往美国的游客无法获得签证。在克林顿的家乡阿肯色州，依赖联邦拨款的残疾鉴定办公室在积压了8500份申请的情况下关闭。华盛顿州一家曾被《西北地区最佳接吻地点》一书评为“四吻”的海滨旅馆，由于位于国家公园内，不得不突然关闭，令许多度蜜月的新婚夫妇心碎不已。

All across the country, the federal government was shut, including some 397 national parks. In Florida, the entrance to the Everglades National Park was blocked by barricades and emblazoned with a sign that said CLOSED DUE TO BUDGET IMPASSE. Angry tourists were hardly mollified when they were turned away with a letter from the park’s superintendent explaining the nation’s budget problems. “They are playing 1996 politics with people’s lives,” said a tourist who had driven from Pennsylvania to Florida, only to be denied admittance to the Everglades park. People could not get their mortgages approved because the Federal Housing Administration was operating with a skeleton staff. Nor could they obtain passports. Would-be visitors to the United States could not get visas, because American embassies around the world were closed. In Clinton’s home state, Arkansas, the Office of Disability Determination, which depended on federal funding, closed with eighty-five hundred applications pending. A seaside lodge in Washington State that had won four kisses in the book Best Places to Kiss in the Northwest had to close summarily because it was in a national park, breaking the hearts of honeymooners.

政府停摆造成了混乱、困惑和愤怒。联邦雇员们不确定能否拿到工资，于是推迟了房贷和牙医账单的支付，同时也担忧着工作的稳定性。总而言之，对于刚刚赢得冷战的国家来说，这真是一场非常怪异的景象。1

The shutdown created confusion, befuddlement, and anger. Federal workers, unsure whether or not they would be paid, put off mortgage payments and dentist bills and also worried about the stability of their jobs. All in all, it was a very odd spectacle for the country that had just won the cold war.1

1993年，比尔·克林顿带着一套模糊不清的“新民主党”政治理念入主华盛顿。这种理念强调政府的克制，与批评者所称的“高税收高支出”的传统自由主义形成鲜明对比。1993年，克林顿总统不顾重重阻力，力推一项削减赤字的计划。此外，政府还启动了一项雄心勃勃的计划，旨在让联邦政府承担起经济最大部门——医疗保健——的责任，并建立一个全国性的医疗保健体系。然而，这项计划最终因其过于复杂而失败。

Bill Clinton had gone to Washington in 1993 with an ambiguous amalgam of “New Democratic” politics. This emphasized restraint by government in contrast to the more traditional liberalism that critics had taken to calling “tax-and-spend.” The president put all his prestige on the line in 1993 to push through a deficit-reduction program in the face of very tough opposition. The administration had also launched an ambitious plan for the federal government to assume responsibility for the largest sector of the economy—medical care—and to create a national health care system, but that program had foundered on its very complexity.

1994年，共和党强势回归，赢得了众议院和参议院的控制权。他们的竞选纲领是“与美国人民的契约”，这是一系列旨在安抚美国中产阶级焦虑的举措，尤其针对犯罪、“家庭价值观”和国家预算赤字等问题，同时承诺削减监管和干预。总而言之，“与美国人民的契约”承诺缩减美国政府规模。其核心是控制政府支出并平衡预算。共和党不仅提议大幅削减年度预算，还试图通过一项宪法修正案，要求从此以后实行预算平衡——换句话说，他们将禁止赤字。然而，正如民主党内部存在传统自由派和赤字鹰派的分歧一样，共和党内部也存在分歧，争论的焦点在于减税和削减赤字哪个更重要。但共和党人打算利用预算问题来推动美国政府的改革。如今，随着政府停摆，双方陷入了一场紧张而致命的政治斗争。每一步，他们都求助于现代版的“神谕”——不是鸡肠或德尔斐神谕，而是民意调查，以及其每日波动。

The Republicans came back with a vengeance in 1994, winning control of both the House and the Senate. Their manifesto was the “Contract with America,” a list of undertakings aimed to assuage the anxieties of middle America, in particular about crime, “family values,” and the national budget deficit, along with the promise to cut back on regulation and intervention. Altogether, the Contract with America pledged to shrink the American government. And at its heart was a commitment to contain government spending and balance the budget. Not only would the Republicans propose deep cuts in the annual budget; they would seek to pass a constitutional amendment to require, henceforth, a balanced budget—in other words, they would outlaw the deficit. Yet, just as the Democrats were divided between traditional liberals and deficit hawks, so the Republicans were at odds among themselves over which was more important, tax cuts or deficit reduction. But the Republicans intended to use the budget to force a makeover of the United States government. Now, with the shutdown, the two sides were engaged in a tense and deadly political struggle. Every step of the way, they consulted the modern version of the oracle—not chicken innards or Delphi but opinion polls, with their daily swings.

当然，这场斗争是1996年总统大选前夕的一部分，但它也是一场关于政府角色的斗争——究竟是扩大政府规模、维持现状，还是缩小政府规模。尽管克林顿本人尽管他常常显得比许多政治顾问更加保守，但双方始终无法达成一致。共和党的目标是制定一项能在七年内消除联邦赤字的预算。具体而言，他们提议限制医疗保险（老年人医疗保健）、各项福利项目以及医疗补助（穷人医疗保健）的增长，并将福利和医疗补助的管理权交还给各州。他们还希望大幅减税。克林顿否决了他们的预算，而共和党则拒绝通过一项持续拨款决议，该决议本可为政府提供临时资金以维持运转。这种情况在1995年11月首次发生，导致政府停摆六天，同年12月再次发生。政府停摆一直持续到圣诞节和元旦。双方互相指责对方。

Certainly, the battle was part of the run-up to the 1996 presidential election, but it was also a struggle over the role of government—whether to expand it, keep it as it was, or indeed contract it. Though Clinton himself often seemed more conservative than many of his political advisers, no accord could be reached. The Republicans’ goal was to enact a budget that would end the federal deficits within seven years. Specifically, they proposed curbing the growth in Medicare (health care for the elderly), various welfare programs, and Medicaid (health care for the poor)—as well as sending welfare and Medicaid back to the states to administer. They also wanted big tax cuts. Clinton vetoed their budget, and the Republicans in turn refused to pass the continuing resolution that would have provided the temporary funding to keep the government going. This had happened first in November 1995, leading to a six-day shutdown, and then again in December. The shutdown continued through Christmas and then New Year’s Day. Each side blamed the other.

今年早些时候，金里奇似乎已成为美国事实上的总理，而希拉里则像一只跛脚鸭。但现在，希拉里的支持率正在上升，而金里奇的支持率却迅速下滑。他的负面评价急剧上升。令众议院共和党人惊讶的是，他们发现自己正在失去公众的支持；他们低估了民众对联邦雇员的同情程度。尽管如此，他们仍然认为，通过将联邦政府逼到违约边缘，他们有能力迫使希拉里让步。他们以为，违约的灾难性后果会迫使政府屈服。然而，他们犯了一个重大的误判。几个月来，他们一直在暗示自己的意图；这给了财政部长罗伯特·鲁宾充足的时间做准备。鲁宾曾在华尔街工作，是一位经验丰富的“扑克高手”。根据1990年的立法，财政部有权从各种政府雇员退休信托基金中借款，到12月政府停摆时，财政部已经做好了充分的准备。它转而动用信托基金，从而将任何潜在的违约推迟了数月之久。当他们意识到鲁宾是如何智胜他们的之后，一些共和党人勃然大怒，甚至谈到要弹劾他。

Earlier in the year, Gingrich appeared to have become America’s de facto prime minister, while Clinton looked like a lame duck. But now Clinton was gaining in the polls and Gingrich was dropping fast. His “negatives” were rising steeply. To their surprise, the House Republicans discovered that they were losing the public; they had underestimated the depth of national sympathy for federal workers. Still, they thought they had the leverage to force Clinton to give in by driving the federal government to the edge of default. They assumed that the catastrophic specter of default would force the administration to capitulate. Here, however, they had made a major miscalculation. For months, they had been telegraphing their intention; and that had given Treasury secretary Robert Rubin, an expert poker player from his days on Wall Street, plenty of time to get prepared. Treasury had the authority from 1990 legislation to borrow from various government employee retirement trust funds, and by the time of the December shutdown, it was more than ready. It turned to the trust funds, thus pushing any potential default off for months. When they realized how Rubin had outmaneuvered them, some of the Republicans were so furious that they talked of impeaching him.

共和党人还犯了一个关键性的错误。圣诞节和新年之间，克林顿不顾一些顾问的反对，接受了共和党提出的其中一项提议。但众议院的共和党人——当时金里奇正努力维系着他们的团结——拒绝了克林顿的接受。“共和党人根本不接受‘是’这个答案，”克林顿的一位高级顾问后来说道。“历史往往取决于一些小事。如果共和党人接受了总统的提议，那将是金里奇的一次重大胜利，共和党人就可以宣称他们在不到一年的时间里就实现了他们通过‘与美国人民的契约’所设定的目标，联邦政府的规模将会进一步缩减，而克林顿或许会在1996年的大选中落败。但他们没有。”

The Republicans made one other critical error. Between Christmas and New Year’s, Clinton, going against some of his advisers, accepted one of the proffered Republican proposals. But the House Republicans, whom Gingrich was having trouble holding together, rejected Clinton’s acceptance. “The Republicans wouldn’t take yes for an answer,” one of Clinton’s senior advisers later said. “History turns on small things. If the Republicans had accepted the president’s offer, it would have been a great victory for Gingrich, the Republicans would have been able to say that they had achieved what they set out to achieve with their Contract with America in less than a year, the federal government would have shrunk more, and Clinton might have lost the 1996 election. But they didn’t.”

最终，在新年伊始，双方达成了一种妥协。预算削减幅度有所降低，减税幅度也有所减少。尽管如此，政府原则上还是接受了国会预算办公室评估的预算方案，该方案有望在七年内消除财政赤字。事情就是这样。共和党最重要的目标。1996年1月第一周结束时，一场罕见的暴风雪席卷了华盛顿。几乎所有车辆都无法出行，双方高级官员甚至无法会面继续谈判。但是，尽管大雪纷飞，政府停摆还是结束了。

Finally, early in the new year, a compromise of sorts was reached. The budget cuts were reduced, as were the tax cuts. Still, the administration accepted in principle, more or less, a budget that—as scored by the Congressional Budget Office—would end deficits in seven years. And that was the Republicans’ most important objective. At the end of the first week of January 1996, an extraordinary blizzard blanketed Washington. Hardly any vehicles could venture out, and senior officials on both sides could not even meet to continue their negotiations. But, snow notwithstanding, the shutdown was over.

事后看来，政府停摆和预算危机被视为民主党的胜利。然而，它们也成为了美国和民主党的转折点。几周后，克林顿在国情咨文中向全国发表讲话时，这一点变得显而易见：“大政府时代已经结束了。”事实上，他在那次演讲中两次提到了这句话。如同许多其他国家一样，美国的经济政策如今不仅受到民意的影响，也受到金融市场（包括数万亿美元的养老金资产）对这些政策合理性的判断的影响。而市场的观点再明确不过：巨额赤字是不可接受的。美国政治的主流已经改变了方向。在这个过程中，比尔·克林顿成为了这场变革的继承人，而这场变革实际上早在二十年前就已经开始了。2

In retrospect, the shutdown and the budget debacle were counted as a Democratic victory. Yet they were also a turning point for both the country and the Democratic Party. That became clear when, addressing the nation a few weeks later in his State of the Union address, Clinton said, “The era of big government is over.” In fact, he said it twice in that speech. As in so many other countries, America’s economic policies were now affected not only by public opinion but also by the judgment that the financial markets, including the trillions of dollars in pension assets, made on the probity of those policies. And the market’s view could not have been clearer: large deficits were unacceptable. The mainstream of American politics had changed course. And in the process, Bill Clinton had emerged as a legatee of a transformation that had begun, in fact, two decades earlier.2

在美国，国家与市场关系的重新定义不如其他国家那样剧烈，因为尽管二战后美国政府的规模也像其他国家一样有所扩张，但其扩张并非通过国有化实现的。如果说美国政府活动的扩张最初是基于市场失灵的理念，那么国家与市场关系的重新定义则反映了一种态度的转变——人们对政府纠正市场失灵的能力信心下降，而对市场自我调节的能力信心增强。然而，这种转变究竟有多少仅仅是语言和观念的改变？又有多少真正反映了政府与市场之间界限的重新划分？

The redefinition of the relationship between state and marketplace has been less dramatic in the United States than elsewhere because, while government did expand after World War II as in other countries, it did not do so through state ownership. If the great expansion of government activity in the United States was based originally upon the notion of market failure, then the redefinition of the relationship of state and marketplace reflected a shift in attitudes—toward less confidence in the ability of governments to correct market failures and more confidence in the ability of markets to sort things out themselves. Yet how much of this shift represented mainly a change in language and beliefs? And how much did it reflect a real redrawing of the frontier between government and the marketplace?

在共产主义与资本主义的二元对立中，美国一直被认为是资本主义真正的发源地。它被视为企业家精神、创新、冒险精神、机遇以及市场“创造性破坏”的沃土。然而，政府并非完全缺席。其他国家的干预往往以国有化的形式出现，而美国的干预则以监管为特征。此外，美国还发展出庞大且不断壮大的福利国家和福利制度。因此，美国的斗争过去是——现在仍然是——在监管、税收和支出、福利国家以及（尽管不那么显眼）私有化等领域展开的。监管本身正朝着两个方向发展。一个方向是减少对市场的经济干预。另一个方向是增加干预以维护社会价值观。然而，总体而言，美国在财政纪律方面进行的斗争与大多数国家在21世纪初所面临的斗争如出一辙。这场斗争始于20年前。

The United States was always thought to be the true homeland of capitalism in the Manichaean contest between communism and capitalism. It was considered the land of entrepreneurship, innovation, risk taking, opportunity, and the “creative destruction” of the market. Yet government was hardly absent. Whereas intervention in other countries often took the form of state ownership, its characteristic form in the United States was regulation. And the United States also developed a large and growing welfare state and system of entitlements. As a result, the battle in the United States was—and still is—being played out in the arenas of regulation, taxation and spending, the welfare state, and (although less visibly) privatization. Regulation itself is going in two directions. One direction is toward less economic intervention in markets. The other is toward more intervention to uphold social values. Overall, however, the nation has waged battles over fiscal discipline that parallel those in most countries on the eve of the twenty-first century. The struggle began two decades ago.

局外人

The Outsider

1980年罗纳德·里根赢得共和党总统候选人提名时，他似乎完全处于政治边缘，以至于在党代会期间，各方就任命前总统杰拉尔德·福特为副总统竞选搭档展开了激烈的半秘密谈判。但福特并非普通的副总统。他将肩负重任，成为类似总统的“共同总统”，负责外交和预算事务。他还将成为“总统办公室的超级执行者”。为了证明这一计划的严肃性，谈判大师亨利·基辛格——以及理财大师艾伦·格林斯潘——亲自代表福特，进而代表共和党建制派参与了谈判。

When Ronald Reagan won the Republican presidential nomination in 1980, he seemed so much on the political fringe that during the convention, there were intense semisecret negotiations about making former president Gerald Ford his vice-presidential running mate. But Ford was not to be a normal vice president. He was to have far-reaching responsibilities as a kind of coprésident with responsibility for foreign affairs and the budget. He would also be “super executive of the office of the President.” As proof of the seriousness of the initiative, none other than the master negotiator himself, Henry Kissinger—along with the master of money Alan Greenspan—represented Ford, and by extension the Republican establishment, in the discussions.

然而，几天后，整个计划就失败了，不仅是因为其本身就不切实际，而且明显违反宪法。还有那些笑话：福特会在九点前、五点后以及周末当总统。而里根也对在与吉米·卡特的竞选期间，自己会被称为“里根州长”，而福特会被称为“总统先生”感到十分不满。3

After a few days, however, the entire plan foundered, not only on its inherent implausibility and apparent constitutional infringement. There were also those jokes: Ford would be president before nine, after five, and on weekends. And Reagan was not exactly won over by the fact that during the campaign against Jimmy Carter, he would be known as Governor Reagan while Ford would be Mr. President.3

然而，正是这种怪诞想法的出现，凸显了里根被认为多么不可靠和缺乏经验。尽管他曾担任加利福尼亚州州长八年，而加利福尼亚州是美国人口最多的州（当时有2000万居民），相比之下，吉米·卡特只担任过佐治亚州州长四年（佐治亚州人口450万）。但里根被视为美国政治主流之外的人物，一位和蔼可亲的极右翼人士。他是一位意识形态家，使用的词汇早已被富兰克林·罗斯福的新政所淘汰。他主张缩减政府规模、削减项目；他提倡自由企业，并赞美市场的魔力。如果他曾是通用电气的代言人，或者像里根在从政前那样，在电视系列节目《死亡谷的日子》中接替“老淘金者”的主持工作，那么这一切就情有可原了。但美国总统绝不应该发表这样的言论。

Yet the very fact that this bizarre idea was considered underlined how unreliable and inexperienced Reagan was deemed to be despite his having been governor of California, the nation’s most populous state (at the time there were 20 million inhabitants) for eight years, compared to Jimmy Carter’s four years as governor of Georgia (which had a population of 4.5 million). But Reagan was regarded as outside the mainstream of American politics, a genial figure from the far right. He was an ideologue using a vocabulary made obsolete by Franklin Roosevelt’s New Deal. He talked about rolling back government and cutting programs; he promoted free enterprise and celebrated the magic of the market. That was understandable if one was a spokesman for General Electric, or even the successor to the “Old Prospector” as the host of the television series Death Valley Days—as Reagan had been in his final years as an actor—before going into politics. But surely that was not the kind of rhetoric that was expected of a president of the United States.

里根喜欢说他不介意被人低估。这反而对他有利。事实证明，罗纳德·里根及其总统任期确实改变了美国政治的语言，并且他推动了一场重新定义国家与市场关系的斗争。

Reagan liked to say that he did not mind being underestimated. It gave him an advantage. As it turned out, Ronald Reagan and his presidency did change the language of American politics, and he helped to set in motion a struggle to redefine the relationship of state and marketplace.

“被现实抢劫”

“Mugged by Reality”

思想为里根主义奠定了基础。其中，芝加哥学派的影响尤为显著。经济困境引发的怀疑主义……20世纪70年代进一步扩大了芝加哥学派经济学家的影响力，他们认为政府本身就是问题所在，而非解决方案。但持这种观点的并非只有芝加哥学派。哈佛大学的马丁·费尔德斯坦（曾任里根总统经济顾问委员会主席）等人做了大量工作，评估高税率造成的投资和创新能力损失。弗吉尼亚大学提出的公共选择理论为政府问题提供了一种颇具影响力的解释——特殊利益集团利用政府活动谋取自身利益。与此同时，一批被称为“供给学派”的作家和经济学家也应运而生。他们坚信通货膨胀是社会的主要敌人，控制货币供应量是抑制通货膨胀的最佳途径，国际货币体系应建立在固定汇率制之上，理想情况下以黄金为基础。但与供给侧相关的最著名概念是，减税造成的收入损失将被更高的增长率带来的额外税收收入所弥补。

Ideas created the context for Reaganism. In this, the Chicago School loomed very large. The skepticism generated by the economic difficulties of the 1970s helped to enlarge further the growing influence of the Chicago economists, who argued that government was the problem, not the solution. But the Chicago School was hardly alone in this. Harvard’s Martin Feldstein, who served for a time as the head of Reagan’s Council of Economic Advisers, and others did major work assessing the costs, in terms of lost investment and initiative, imposed by high tax rates. The public-choice theories emanating from the University of Virginia provided an influential explanation for government’s problems—that special interests turned government activities to their own benefit. There also emerged a group of writers and economists who quickly became known as “supply-siders.” This group fervently believed that inflation was society’s principal enemy, that the best way to fight inflation was by controlling the money supply, and that the international currency system should be based upon fixed rates, ideally gold. But the most famous concept associated with supply-side was the notion that the revenues lost through tax cuts would be more than made up by the additional tax revenues flowing in as a result of higher growth rates.

如果说不同经济学家群体对美国运行方式的既有假设提出了质疑，那么另一套理念则提供了与之并行的政治、社会乃至文化批判，从而强化了这种重新定义：新保守主义。这场运动于20世纪60年代末70年代初在美国兴起。其成员最初只有几十人，他们都是心灰意冷的自由主义者——用该运动领导人之一欧文·克里斯托尔的话来说，他们是“被现实狠狠打击的自由主义者”。许多人来自极左翼——来自各种形式的青年马克思主义。克里斯托尔本人表示，五十年后他并不介意被贴上“前托洛茨基主义者”的标签，因为他正是在布鲁克林的一次青年托洛茨基主义者聚会上结识了他的妻子。

If various groups of economists dislodged assumptions about the way America was working, a second set of ideas would provide a parallel political, social, and even cultural critique that bolstered the redefinition: neoconservatism. This movement emerged in the United States in the late 1960s and early 1970s. Its cadres, numbering only a few dozen at first, were disillusioned liberals—in the words of one of the leaders of the movement, Irving Kristol, “liberals mugged by reality.” Many had migrated from far on the left—from youthful Marxism of one kind or another. Kristol himself observed that he did not mind being tagged as an ex-Trotskyite fifty years after the fact because he had first met his wife at a meeting of young Trotskyites in Brooklyn.

新保守主义的兴起，源于20世纪60年代末的“反主流文化”浪潮和青年叛逆运动、新左派运动和学生对大学的冲击，以及对激进主义和战斗主义的推崇。新保守主义者的敌人不仅包括社会主义、马克思主义、共产主义和国家主义，还包括占据主导地位的美国自由主义思潮。他们认为，这种思潮已经渗透到政治、媒体和大学的各个领域，几乎不可撼动。新保守主义者坚信，自由主义滋生了松懈、衰败和道德沦丧，最终将导致美国的堕落。他们批评政府雄心勃勃的计划未能兑现承诺，反而滋生了依赖文化，并且使情况变得更糟。他们许多最有力的论点都基于“事与愿违”的法则。例如，公共住房项目非但没有消除贫民窟，反而制造了贫民窟，并且在这个过程中，还拆毁了原本为低收入工薪阶层提供的经济适用房。这些后来被称为“新保守主义者”的人，也反对“第三世界主义”。“第三世界主义”将美国描绘成发展中国家弊病的根源，第三世界的剥削者和压迫的始作俑者，以及人类抱负的破坏者——这与美国的仁慈截然相反。社会主义和苏联。在新保守主义者看来，将这一切联系起来的是自由主义者对罪恶感和自我鞭笞的偏好，以及自由主义者道歉和寻求赦免的文化，所有这些都导致了国内灾难性的政策和国外的失败。

Neoconservatism had been energized into existence in response to the “countercultural” explosion and the youth rebellion of the late 1960s, the New Left and student assaults on universities, and the celebration of militancy and radicalism. The enemies of the neoconservatives were not only socialism, Marxism, communism, and statism. Another enemy was the dominant American liberal ethos, which they believed had so permeated politics, the media, and universities as to be almost unchallengeable. The neoconservatives became convinced that liberalism spawned laxity, decay, and moral decline and that, ultimately, it would mean the degeneration of the United States. They criticized ambitious government programs for failing to deliver what they promised, for creating cultures of dependency, and for making things worse instead of better. They based many of their most potent arguments on the law of unintended consequences. Public housing, for example, created slums instead of eliminating them and, in the process, bulldozed what had been affordable housing for lower-income working people. The “neocons,” as they came to be known, were also reacting against “third worldism,” which portrayed the United States as the source of the ills afflicting developing nations, the exploiter of the third world and purveyor of oppression, and the blighter of human aspiration—in contrast to the benignity of socialism and the Soviet Union. Tying it all together in the minds of the neocons was what they saw as the liberal predilection for guilt and self-flagellation, and the liberal culture of apology and quest for absolution, all of which led to disastrous policies at home and surrender abroad.

新保守主义者都是知识分子，他们和哈耶克、弗里德曼一样，都认为他们的斗争关乎思想。他们与一套主导美国思想界数十年的主流思想展开了意识形态斗争。“事实是，思想至关重要，”克里斯托尔在20世纪70年代中期写道，“任何社会庞大而看似稳固的机构——经济机构、政治机构、宗教机构——都始终受制于身处其中的人们的思想。思想的影响力如此巨大。” 因此，新保守主义者的宣传活动并非在街头巷尾展开，而是在报刊上进行，他们在《公共利益》和《评论》等期刊上发展和塑造他们的思想，尤其重要的是，在《华尔街日报》的社论版面上——这是唯一一家刊登他们观点的主流媒体——他们更是发挥了重要作用。这个团体至少在某些时期囊括了美国一些最知名的知识分子——内森·格雷泽、詹姆斯·Q·威尔逊、诺曼·波德霍雷茨、珍妮·柯克帕特里克、迈克尔·诺瓦克、本·沃滕贝格、彼得·伯格，或许还有政治知识分子丹尼尔·帕特里克·莫伊尼汉（丹尼尔·贝尔虽然有时被贴上新保守主义的标签，但他与该运动保持距离）。尽管难以界定，新保守主义的影响却相当显著。它重新定义了政治辩论的边界，并为保守派提供了一套新的理念。“自由主义社会政策的弱点日益凸显，”克里斯托尔回忆道，“我们为保守派提供了一种批判社会和经济政策的方法。这种影响的部分原因在于，我们是一群社会科学家，而非文学知识分子，我们提出的研究成果国会能够理解，媒体也不能仅仅将其视为纽约知识分子的作品而予以驳斥。”

The neocons were intellectuals, and they, as much as the Hayeks and Friedmans, believed that their battle was about ideas. They were engaged in an ideological struggle against a set of dominant ideas that had held the commanding heights in American thinking for several decades. “The truth is that ideas are all important,” Kristol wrote in the mid-1970s. “The massive and seemingly solid institutions of any society—the economic institutions, the political institutions, the religious institutions—are always at the mercy of the ideas in the heads of the people who populate these institutions. The leverage of ideas is so immense.” Thus, the neocons carried out their campaign not in precincts but in print, developing and shaping their ideas in journals like The Public Interest and Commentary, and, of crucial importance, on the editorial pages of The Wall Street Journal, the only mainstream media outlet that carried their beliefs. The group included, at least some of the time, some of America’s best-known intellectuals—Nathan Glazer, James Q. Wilson, Norman Podhoretz, Jeane Kirkpatrick, Michael Novak, Ben Wattenberg, Peter Berger, and perhaps the political-intellectual Daniel Patrick Moynihan (Daniel Bell, although sometimes tagged a neocon, distanced himself from the movement). Though not easy to pin down, the influence of neoconservatism was considerable. It redefined the boundaries of political debate. It provided a new set of ideas for conservatives. “The weakness of liberal social policy was becoming evident,” recalled Kristol. “We gave conservatives a way of critiquing social and economic policies. Part of the impact arose from the peculiarity that we were a group of social scientists, not literary intellectuals, who came up with studies that Congress could understand and that the media could not dismiss merely as the work of New York intellectuals.”

新保守主义者至少在当时自认为是民主党人。他们中的许多人都是罗斯福新政的受益者。共和党是为乡村俱乐部成员服务的，而不是为那些上过纽约市立学院的人服务的。事实上，年轻时的欧文·克里斯托尔曾写过一篇关于乡村俱乐部歧视的文章，其灵感源于他对“为什么会有人想加入乡村俱乐部”这一问题的困惑。但1972年乔治·麦戈文被提名为民主党总统候选人，让大多数新保守主义者确信他们在党内已无立足之地，因为该党已被自由左派掌控。在他们看来，自由左派对共产主义和苏联的实力过于天真，在国防问题上也软弱无力。1 “虽然我们当中没有一个人是共和党人，而且我们当中很少有人是共和党人……”克里斯托尔回忆说：“我当时不认识任何共和党人，我们的政治格局正在发生变化。”

The neocons thought of themselves, at least at the time, as Democrats. Many of them were children of the New Deal. The Republican Party was for people who belonged to country clubs, not for people who had gone to City College. Indeed, as a young man Irving Kristol had written an article on discrimination in country clubs that had been informed by his underlying puzzle about why anyone would want to belong to a country club in the first place. But the nomination of George McGovern as the Democratic presidential candidate in 1972 convinced most of the neocons that they no longer had a home in the party, because it had been captured by the liberal left, which, in their view, was naive about communism and Soviet power and soft on defense.1 “Though none of us was a Republican and few of us even knew any Republicans,” Kristol recalled, “our political landscape was in the process of being transformed.”

新保守主义者呼吁缩小政府规模。他们也越来越积极地对资本主义和市场经济表示乐观和自信的肯定。《评论》杂志的编辑诺曼·波德霍雷茨曾建议克里斯托尔，由于“资本主义”一词有些“污名化”，他应该改用“自由企业”或“自由市场”来写作。克里斯托尔不为所动。在他看来，“除非资本主义的名称也摆脱了污名，否则重塑其声誉的斗争是不完整的。”正如他后来补充道，“就是这个词。用它。”

The neoconservatives called for a shrinking of government. With increasing vigor, they also offered an optimistic and confident affirmation of capitalism and the marketplace. Norman Podhoretz, the editor of Commentary, once suggested to Kristol that, since the word capitalism was somewhat “besmirched,” he should instead write aboutfree enterprise orfree markets. Kristol would not budge. In his view, “the fight to rehabilitate the reputation of the system would be incomplete unless its name was rescued from discredit as well.” As he later added, “That’s the word. Use it.”

克里斯托尔说：“ 《公共利益》杂志最初的团队成员中没有经济学家。当时我并不十分欣赏芝加哥学派。我仍然是一个自由主义者，一个持怀疑态度的自由主义者。大约在1980年，自由市场学派和新保守主义学派融合在了一起。也许里根促成了这一融合。”4

“We had no economist in the original group around The Public Interest,” said Kristol. “I was not then a great admirer of Chicago. I was still a liberal, a skeptical liberal. What happened was that around 1980, the freemarket school of thought and the neoconservative school of thought fused. Maybe Reagan did it.”4

讽刺的是，当时的市场体系似乎日益衰弱。但在保守主义经济学和新保守主义社会批判的影响下，人们对美国政府角色的看法开始发生深刻转变。这个过程漫长而曲折。它实际上始于里根政府之前的一场危机：20世纪70年代末的通货膨胀动荡。正如在其他工业化国家一样，这场危机暴露了当时经济体系的脆弱性，并最终导致了它的转型。

The irony was that the market system, as it was then, looked increasingly impaired. But under the influence of conservative economics and the neoconservative social critique, a profound change began to take place in views about the role of the American government. The process would take a long time. It really began with a crisis that preceded the Reagan administration: the inflationary turmoil of the late 1970s. As it had in the other industrial countries, that crisis signaled the weakness of the prevailing economic system and brought about its eventual transformation.

中央银行家

The Central Banker

1979年8月6日，白宫的就职典礼气氛异常凝重。通货膨胀率飙升至现代美国前所未有的水平，高得令人震惊。它似乎已经深深扎根于这个国家的肌理之中。民众信心正在消退。三周前，吉米·卡特总统宣布全国陷入“信心危机”，并解雇了部分内阁成员。此举意在展现决心，稳定国家局势，但结果却适得其反，进一步动摇了国家。卡特任命商人威廉·米勒为新的财政部长，这意味着总统必须填补米勒留下的空缺——美联储主席一职。这将是一个至关重要的选择，因为美联储作为美国独立的中央银行，在抗击通货膨胀的战争中扮演着决定性的角色。但究竟该任命谁呢？有人告诉卡特，长期从事货币政策研究、时任纽约联邦储备银行行长的保罗·沃尔克具备必要的才能和声誉，能够为美联储提供财政支持。事实上，卡特此前从未听说过沃尔克，但他急于恢复人们对经济管理的些许信心和权威。这就是沃尔克最终进入白宫东厅的原因。考虑到他随后的影响，考虑到这些政策对经济的影响以及它们对 1980 年总统选举结果的贡献，卡特后来可能希望自己从未听说过沃尔克这个人。

The White House swearing-in ceremony on August 6, 1979, was unusually sober. Inflation was rising to levels never seen before in modern America, frighteningly high levels. It seemed to have become embedded in the very fibers of the country. Confidence was ebbing. Three weeks before, President Jimmy Carter had proclaimed a national “crisis of confidence” and had fired members of his cabinet. The move was meant to show resolve and steady the nation, but instead it further rattled the country. Carter appointed a new Treasury secretary, businessman William Miller, which in turn meant that the president had to fill Miller’s former position—the chairmanship of the Federal Reserve Board. It would be a critical choice, for the Fed, which by statute operates as the nation’s independent central bank, had a decisive role in the war on inflation. But whom to appoint? Carter was told that Paul Volcker, a longtime monetary expert and at the time president of the New York Federal Reserve, had the necessary capabilities and reputation to provide financial backbone. In fact Carter had never heard of Volcker, but he was desperate to restore some modicum of confidence and authority to the management of the economy. That was how Volcker ended up in the East Room of the White House. Considering the subsequent impact that his policies would have on the economy and their contribution to the outcome of the 1980 presidential election, Carter may later have wished that he had never heard of Volcker at all.

但在那年八月的某一天，沃尔克非常清楚自己的任务是什么，即便他并不确切知道如何完成这项任务。“我们正面临着前所未有的经济困境，”他在就职宣誓时神情沮丧地说，“我们已经失去了十五年前那种对经济管理了如指掌的乐观情绪。”他后来表示，他的使命是“斩杀通货膨胀这头恶龙”。如果他失败了，后果可能是拉丁美洲式的持续通货膨胀，也可能是另一场大萧条。政治后果可能更加严重，甚至会威胁到美国民主的根基。他还坚信一点：渐进主义和折衷方案行不通。

But on that August day Volcker knew exactly what his task was, even if he did not know exactly how to achieve it. “We are face-to-face with economic difficulties really unique in our experience,” he said, suitably glum-faced at the swearing-in. “And we have lost that euphoria that we had fifteen years ago, that we knew all the answers to managing the economy.” His mission was, he put it later, “to slay the inflationary dragon.” If he failed, the consequences could either be a Latin American-style permanent inflation or another Great Depression. The political consequences could be even worse and would threaten the very foundations of American democracy. He was absolutely convinced of one other thing: Gradualism and half measures would not work.

在就职典礼后的白宫茶会上，沃尔克向一位记者吐露心声：“我很无趣。所有央行行长的工作就是尽可能地无趣。”对于这位即将向通货膨胀宣战，并在极低的胜算下取得胜利，并在此过程中引领美国走上新经济道路的人来说，这番自我评价未免过于苛刻。

At a White House tea party after the swearing-in, Volcker confided to a reporter, “I’m boring. It’s the job of all central bankers to be as boring as possible.” That was an exceedingly harsh self-appraisal for the man who would wage war on inflation and, against very high odds, win—and, in the process, set the United States on a new economic course.

沃尔克天生就是干这行的料。他身高六英尺七英寸（约2米），嘴里常叼着雪茄，多年来一直是国际金融界一位辨识度极高的人物。据说，他是唯一一个能同时居高临下地和你说话，又能让你高谈阔论的人。他虽然有些腼腆，但也自信满满、气场强大，拥有精湛的技术和政治手腕，对市场有着敏锐的直觉，而且为人正直，广受认可。他职业生涯的大部分时间都在为公众服务，一生恪守正直。他的家人住在纽约，他周末会回去探望家人，而工作日则住在华盛顿一间堆满旧报纸和鱼钩的小公寓里。每周一次，他会把脏衣服装进行李箱，送到弗吉尼亚州北部女儿家清洗。他的个人风格神秘莫测。多年来，沃尔克对中央银行的工具，包括出其不意和保密的重要性，都进行了深入的学习，他练就了一身故弄玄虚的本领，以及中央银行家特有的含糊其辞的说话方式，这种方式将深刻的道理、平庸的言论和不合逻辑的语句混杂在一起，故意让人难以理解。

Volcker was cut out for the part. At six-foot-seven, with a cigar often jammed into the corner of his mouth, he had been an unmistakable figure on the international financial circuit for years. It was said that he was the only man who could talk down to you and over your head at the same time. If somewhat shy, he was also self-confident and commanding, with considerable technical and political skills, a strong intuitive feel for markets, and a widely recognized integrity. In most of his career he was a public servant, and he lived a life of probity. His family remained in New York City, to which he returned on weekends, while during the week he lived in a small Washington apartment cluttered with old newspapers and fishing flies. Once a week, he packed up his laundry in a suitcase and took it to get washed at his daughter’s house in northern Virginia. His personal style was enigmatic. Well schooled over the years in the tools of central banking, including the importance of surprise and secrecy, Volcker had perfected a talent for obfuscation and the central banker’s mumble, which mixed profundities and banalities and non sequiturs in such a way as to be deliberately indecipherable.

沃尔克很早就意识到通货膨胀的严重性。在普林斯顿大学，他的一些经济学教授来自奥地利学派，哈耶克正是该学派的代表人物。对他们而言，第一次世界大战后的通货膨胀及其带来的毁灭性后果，是决定性的事件。尽管沃尔克吸收了凯恩斯主义的分析工具，但他始终对能否有效管理经济这种复杂体系持怀疑态度。“肯尼迪和约翰逊早期执政时期，经济学家们的傲慢达到了顶峰，”他说道，“他们自以为掌握了所有答案，知道如何操纵经济。我对此感到本能的反感。我始终认为这太过自负了。”“他自信满满。”沃尔克在美联储的经历也对他产生了影响。“我曾是一名中央银行家，”他说，“我一直担心通货膨胀，即使在20世纪50年代，2.5%的通货膨胀率也被认为非常危险。”在尼克松政府担任财政部副部长期间，他在从布雷顿森林体系的固定汇率制向浮动汇率制的转变中发挥了关键作用。5

Volcker had learned early to worry about inflation. At Princeton, some of his economics professors were from the Austrian School, which had spawned Hayek. For them, post-World War I inflation—with its devastating consequences—was the defining event. Although Volcker assimilated the Keynesian tools for analysis, he was always skeptical of the ability to manage something so complex as the economy. “The Kennedy and early Johnson administrations were absolutely the high point of hubris of economists,” he said. “They thought they had the answers, that they knew how to pull the levers. I had a visceral reaction against it. I always thought it was too cocksure.” Volcker was also shaped by his experience in the Federal Reserve. “I was a central banker,” he said. “I was always worrying about inflation, even in the 1950s, when it was considered very threatening at two and a half percent.” As undersecretary of the Treasury in the Nixon administration, he played a key role in the shift from the Bretton Woods world of fixed exchange rates to floating rates.5

作为美联储主席，沃尔克决心消除笼罩美国的通胀预期——他称之为全国性的“通胀赌注”。他的武器是改良版的货币主义。美联储不再直接设定利率（货币价格），而是通过管理银行准备金来控制货币的实际供应量。这是一种粗暴的手段，但沃尔克别无选择。其后果是巨大的。随着美联储收紧货币供应，利率飙升至20%甚至更高。经济放缓，随后萎缩，陷入自大萧条以来最严重的衰退。失业率高达10%，房屋滞销，企业面临流动性危机，汽车滞销。经济衰退——连同伊朗人质危机——是罗纳德·里根在1980年击败吉米·卡特的重要因素。里根当选后，美联储，尤其是美联储主席沃尔克，仍然是愤怒的政客们的主要攻击目标，他们担心会遭到政治反弹。然而，里根本人从未真正攻击过沃尔克。“白宫和财政部的人都给里根施加压力，但他们始终无法让里根批评我，”沃尔克说。“偶尔会有一些想法，但里根有一种发自内心的感觉，那就是抑制通货膨胀是一件好事。”谈到如何战胜通货膨胀，里根曾对他的国务卿乔治·舒尔茨说：“如果我们不做，谁来做？如果不是现在，那又是什么时候？”

As chairman of the Fed, Volcker was determined to extinguish the inflationary expectations that gripped the United States—what had become, as he called it, the national “bet on inflation.” His weapon was a modified monetarism. Instead of explicitly setting interest rates (the price of money), the Fed would control the actual supply (or quantity) of money by managing bank reserves. It was a blunt weapon. But Volcker saw no choice. The effects were dramatic. As the Fed restricted the money supply, interest rates shot up, to 20 percent and above. The economy slowed and then contracted, falling into the deepest recession since the Great Depression. Unemployment rose to as high as 10 percent, houses went unsold, companies struggled with liquidity problems, cars sat on dealers’ lots. The slump was—along with the Iran hostage crisis—a major factor in Ronald Reagan’s defeat of Jimmy Carter in 1980. After Reagan’s election, the Fed, and Volcker in particular, continued to be a prime target for angry politicians, who feared the political backlash. Yet Reagan himself never quite attacked Volcker. “People in the White House and Treasury put pressure on Reagan, but they could never get Reagan to criticize me,” Volcker said. “Slight musings, yes. But Reagan had this visceral feeling that fighting inflation was a good thing.” On the subject of conquering inflation, Reagan would say to his secretary of state, George Shultz, “If not us, who? If not now, when?”

与此同时，公众对沃尔克和美联储的愤怒情绪日益高涨。农民们包围了美联储大楼，抗议高利率。汽车经销商送来装有车钥匙的棺材，象征着因高利率而滞销的车辆。沃尔克本人也阅读了人们写给他的令人心碎的信件——信中讲述了他们如何省吃俭用多年，只为给父母买房，如今却因高利率而无力实现。这些信件令他深感痛心，但他仍然别无选择。2如果通货膨胀得不到遏制，经济崩溃的程度会更大。他确信，他终于获得了支持，可以正面应对通货膨胀。“当时人们觉得，你虽然赢不了多数选民，但肯定能赢得很多选票，”他说。“人们很害怕。必须采取行动。但我们谁也没完全意识到这会有多艰难。有些事情我们始料未及。利率竟然高达20%！”谁能想到利率会高达20%？但一旦陷入其中，就无法自拔。你也不想放手。放弃，放手——这根本不在我的考虑范围之内。

Meanwhile, public anger against Volcker and the Fed mounted. Farmers surrounded the Federal Reserve building to protest the high interest rates. Auto dealers sent in coffins with car keys to symbolize the vehicles that went unsold because of high interest rates. Volcker himself would read heartbreaking letters that people wrote to him—about how they had saved for years to buy a house for their parents, but now, because of the high rates, could not. He was deeply upset by these letters, but he still saw no choice.2 If inflation were not stamped out, there would be a much greater collapse. And he was convinced that, at last, he had support for tackling inflation head-on. “There was a sense that you wouldn’t have won a majority of voters but you would have won a lot of votes,” he said. “People were scared. Something had to be done. But none of us quite understood how tough it would be. Some things we never expected. Interest rates of twenty percent! Who ever expected twenty percent interest rates? But you get caught up in the process, and you can’t let go. You don’t want to let go. Letting up, giving up—that was not in my psychology.”

这花了三年时间。到1982年夏天，战胜通货膨胀的曙光已现。事实上，当年的通货膨胀率将降至4%以下。沃尔克最杰出的成就，是在失败主义盛行的时期成功战胜了通货膨胀。他为美国指明了新的经济方向。失败的风险始终萦绕在他的心头，历史也同样如此。当有人指责他行事作风像个德国央行行长时，他回答说：“我不认为这是批评，而是一种赞扬。我并不孤单。”6

It took three years. By the summer of 1982, the conquest of inflation was in sight. In fact, inflation that year would fall below 4 percent. Volcker’s singular achievement was to conquer inflation at a time when defeatism was rampant. He set the United States on a new economic course. The risks of not succeeding were often on his mind. So was history. Once confronted with the accusation that he was behaving like a German central banker, he replied, “I don’t take that as criticism. That’s a compliment. I’m in pretty good company there.”6

超越税收和支出

Beyond Tax-and-Spend

多亏了沃尔克的努力，里根政府在执政初期就实现了货币紧缩。里根在1981年空管人员罢工中采取的坚定立场，也帮助改变了劳资关系的基调，间接抑制了通胀情绪。但财政政策问题依然存在——政府如何增加收入以及如何支配这些收入。随着福利需求、津贴和对中产阶级、穷人，尤其是老年人的义务不断增加，支出在政治上成为一种必要的手段，因为它能带来选票。当然，问题在于如何为这些支出筹集资金。

Thanks to Volcker’s efforts, monetary restraint was obtained quite early in the course of the Reagan administration. And Reagan’s unwaverng stance in the air traffic controllers’ strike of 1981 helped change the tone of labor relations, indirectly contributing to the muting of inflationary psychology. But there was still fiscal policy to be dealt with—the ways that government raised its revenues and the ways that it chose to spend them. The rise of welfare demands, entitlements, and obligations toward the middle class, the poor, and especially the elderly made spending politically necessary as a source of votes. The problem, of course, was how to finance the outlays.

罗纳德·里根的顾问们上任之初的目标是削减税收和开支。但他们很快发现，实现税收目标比削减开支目标更容易。原因很简单：政治因素。减税很受欢迎，而且税收确实大幅下降。最高边际税率从70%降至28%，税基扩大，许多税收抵扣和漏洞也被取消。但削减开支却不受欢迎，民主党控制的国会对总统提出的削减幅度感到不满。里根没有削减中产阶级的福利。他还保留了国防部，并且在其两届任期内，启动了包括“星球大战”太空防御计划在内的国防开支大幅增长计划。

Ronald Reagan’s advisers came to office with the intention of cutting both taxes and spending. But they soon found out that it was easier to achieve the first of these objectives than the second. The reason was simple: politics. It was popular to cut taxes. And taxes did come down substantially. The top marginal rate was reduced from 70 percent to 28 percent, the tax base was broadened, and many deductions and loopholes were eliminated. But it was unpopular to cut spending, and the Democratic Congress bridled at the extent of the cuts that the president proposed. Reagan did not take on middle-class entitlements. He also spared the Defense Department from the ax, and indeed initiated, over the course of his two terms, major increases in defense expenditures, including the “Star Wars” space defense program.

尽管未能削减政府总支出，里根阵营中仍有一些人保持乐观。他们拥护传统共和党经济学家赫伯特·斯坦（Herbert Stein）——借用当时流行音乐的说法——所称的“朋克式”供给侧经济学。这种经济学大胆断言，减税导致的税收减少将被经济增长带来的更高税收收入所弥补。然而，事实并非如此。由于支出并未随着税收的减少而下降——事实上，国防开支反而大幅增长——而且减税措施并未如预期那样有效地刺激经济增长，联邦债务和年度赤字都急剧膨胀；1981-82年，美国经济陷入了深度衰退。1982年9月，里根政府为了弥补财政政策的弊端，在实施了“史上最大规模的减税”之后，又推出了“史上最大规模的增税”。然而，事与愿违。到里根第一任期结束时，许多人已经对供给侧经济学失去了信心，而税收和支出无法同时降低，与沃尔克成功控制通货膨胀形成了鲜明对比。里根的首任管理和预算办公室主任戴维·斯托克曼离开政府时，感到沮丧，他对供给侧经济学感到失望，并被政治进程的现实所打击。他认为，财政政策改革的失败清楚地证明了“政治的胜利”——福利凌驾于紧缩政策之上，美国立法中根深蒂固的“政治分肥”传统凌驾于任何冷酷的经济逻辑之上。“我当初以激进意识形态信徒的身份加入了里根革命，”他写道，“但我痛苦地认识到，这样的革命根本不可能实现。”

Some in the Reagan camp were optimistic, despite the failure to cut total government spending. They were the advocates of what traditional Republican economist Herbert Stein—echoing the music of the day—called “punk” supply-side economics, which made sweeping assertions that reductions in tax revenues resulting from tax cuts would be more than made up for by higher tax revenues generated by economic growth. It did not turn out that way. Because spending did not come down with taxes—and indeed defense spending went up sharply—and because the tax cuts did not feed back into the economy to the extent hoped, both the federal debt and the annual deficit ballooned; and in 1981-82, the economy was in a deep recession. In September 1982, in its first effort to repair the damage, the Reagan administration followed the “largest tax cut in history” with the “largest tax increase in history.” But there was no catching up. By the end of Reagan’s first term, the supply-side logic was discredited in the eyes of many, and the inability to bring taxes and spending down together stood in marked contrast to Volcker’s victory over inflation. David Stockman, Reagan’s first director of the Office of Management and Budget, left the administration dejected, disillusioned with supply-side economics, and chastened by the realities of the political process. Failure to achieve fiscal-policy change, he argued, was a clear vindication of the “triumph of politics”—of entitlements over austerity, and of the enduring pork-barrel tradition of American legislation over any cold economic logic. “I joined the Reagan Revolution as a radical ideologue,” he wrote. “I learned the traumatic lesson that no such revolution is possible.”

政治的胜利以及斯托克曼所称的随之而来的“财政错误”催生了一个新的怪物，它将成为政策辩论的焦点：赤字和联邦债务。在里根总统任期开始到结束期间，年度赤字几乎翻了三倍。国家债务总额也同样如此——从9950亿美元飙升至2.9万亿美元。或者，正如里根和布什政府官员理查德·达曼所说，“在里根执政时期，新增的联邦债务比美国此前整个历史上的债务总额还要多。”

The triumph of politics and what Stockman called the “fiscal error” that went with it spawned a new monster, which would come to occupy center stage in policy debate: the deficit and the federal debt. Between the beginning and the end of the Reagan presidency, the annual deficit almost tripled. So did the gross national debt—from ’995 billion to ’2.9 trillion. Or, as Reagan and Bush administration official Richard Darman put it, “In the Reagan years, more federal debt was added than in the entire prior history of the United States.”

如此庞大的支出规模，根本没有快速的解决办法。然而，在一些人看来，减税还有另一种逻辑：减少税收和政府收入，最终赤字的痛苦和规模——以及国家破产的威胁——将迫使政府削减开支。这种想法并非仅限于狂热的供给学派，最终也确实如此。但并非在几年之内，尤其是在里根执政时期。

There simply was no quick cure to the scale of spending. In the minds of some, however, there was another logic to tax cuts: Reduce taxes and government revenue, and eventually the pain and scale of deficits—and the threat of national bankruptcy—would force a retrenchment of government spending. That thought was not restricted to fervent supply-siders, and ultimately it would end up true. But not for some years, and certainly not during the Reagan years.

1989年乔治·布什就任总统时，年度财政赤字高达1520亿美元。由于强大的政治因素，大幅增税几乎不可能——布什后来背弃了竞选时“不增税”的郑重承诺，这成为他最大的政治包袱。因此，控制开支势在必行。幸运的是，国际形势为解决这一问题提供了契机。柏林墙的倒塌和苏联解体使得国防开支得以逐步削减。然而，这还远远不够。由于20世纪90年代初的经济衰退，税收收入下降，到1992年布什卸任之际，财政赤字达到峰值2900亿美元。

When George Bush took office in 1989, the annual deficit stood at ’152 billion. Taxes could not be raised substantially for devastatingly powerful political reasons—as Bush found out when his retreat from his solemn “read my lips” campaign promise of “no new taxes” became his most damaging political liability. There was no choice but to contain spending. And luckily, international events afforded a good opportunity to start tackling the problem. The fall of the Berlin Wall and the crumbling of the Soviet empire made possible a tapering-off in defense spending. Still, this was not enough. Owing to the recession of the early 1990s, tax revenues fell, and in 1992, as Bush was ending his term, the deficit peaked at ’290 billion.

到那时，那些自诩为财政保守派的人士，在两大政党中都已占据了一定的份额。支撑“里根革命”的理念也获得了更广泛的共鸣。“征税和支出”——毕竟，这是任何财政政策的两大基本功能——却变成了一个贬义词，一个避之不及的词语。在民主党方面，一个团体……新民主党人批评了传统的民主党做法，并逐渐对该党的议程产生了越来越大的影响。

By that time, out-and-out fiscal conservatives, proud to call themselves such, had gained ground in both major parties. The ideas that underpinned the “Reagan revolution” had acquired much wider resonance. “Tax and spend”—after all, the two basic functions of any fiscal policy—became a pejorative term, an epithet to avoid. On the Democratic side, a group calling themselves New Democrats criticized the traditional Democratic approach, and came to influence more and more of the party’s agenda.

他们最知名的代表人物之一是阿肯色州州长比尔·克林顿，他由此登上了总统宝座。民主党内部的分歧贯穿了他的整个政府。财政部长劳埃德·本特森和新成立的国家经济委员会主席罗伯特·鲁宾坚信，促进经济增长的最佳途径是削减赤字。这将降低长期利率。这样做不仅能直接降低利率，还能增强债券市场的信心，让人们相信赤字问题确实得到了解决，从而降低利率中的通胀溢价。而低利率将是刺激投资驱动型增长的最佳手段，远胜于传统的凯恩斯主义支出刺激措施。事实上，任何刺激方案带来的收益都会被市场随之而来的利率上涨所抵消。在这一点上，他们的观点与艾伦·格林斯潘非常一致。格林斯潘于1987年接替沃尔克出任美联储主席，他对不断膨胀的赤字感到日益担忧。格林斯潘坚信，赤字持续增长不仅意味着更高的税收和更慢的经济增长，而且很可能最终酿成灾难。克林顿的官员和顾问中的传统自由派人士对此感到震惊。他们认为，克林顿竞选总统并非为了推行“共和党的经济政策”。民主党为了讨好富人，背叛了他们的传统选民。他们想要刺激经济的计划、增加政府支出和提高税收，尤其是对高收入人群的税收。但克林顿早已做出了选择。“在过渡时期，”现任财政部长鲁宾回忆道，“总统明确表示，他将把控制赤字作为首要任务。”赤字是头号敌人。这意味着必须控制支出。

One of their best-known figures was the governor of Arkansas, Bill Clinton, who springboarded to the presidency. The division between Democrats ran right through his administration. Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen and Robert Rubin, head of the the newly established National Economic Council, were convinced that the best way to promote economic growth was by reducing the deficit. That would bring down long-term interest rates. It would do so directly; it would also do so by engendering confidence in the bond market that the deficit really was being tackled, which would reduce the inflation premium in interest rates. And lower rates would be the best stimulus to investment-led growth, much better than the traditional Keynesian spending stimulus. In fact, any gains from a stimulus package would be more than offset by the higher interest rates with which the market would respond. In this, they were much in accord with Alan Greenspan, who had succeeded Volcker as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board in 1987, and who had watched the swelling deficits with increasing dismay. Greenspan was convinced that the continuing growth of deficits not only would mean higher taxes and slower growth but could well end in catastrophe. The traditional liberals among Clinton’s officials and advisers were appalled. Clinton had not fought the election, they argued, to promote “Republican economics.” The Democrats were betraying their traditional constituencies in order to pamper the rich. They wanted stimulus programs, increased government spending, and higher taxes, especially on the upper income. But Clinton had already made his choice. “During the transition,” recalled Rubin, now Treasury secretary, “the president expressed his unequivocal commitment to making the deficit his priority.” The deficit was enemy number one. That meant that spending would have to be restrained.

1993年，总统全力推行一项削减赤字的计划，该计划既包括削减开支，也包括部分增税。正如一位参与者所说，这场政治斗争“异常激烈”。该计划勉强在国会获得通过；副总统阿尔·戈尔不得不打破参议院的僵局。“我当时就说过，只有当市场相信削减赤字的计划时，我们才能获得更低的利率，”鲁宾后来回忆道。“这需要多久才能实现呢？市场相信我们的赤字削减计划，而且速度比我预想的要快得多。”该计划于1993年8月获得通过，这的确成为了一个转折点。债券市场开始相信赤字将会减少。长期利率开始下降，经济也进入了合理的增长和低通胀状态。

The president went all out in 1993 for a deficit reduction program that involved both spending cuts and some tax increases. The political battle was, as one participant put it, “murderous.” The program just squeaked through Congress; Vice-Président Al Gore had to break a tie in the Senate. “I said at the time that we would only get lower rates if the market believed in the deficit reduction,” Rubin later said. “How long would it take for that to happen? The markets believed in our deficit reduction program, more quickly than I had thought they might.” Passage of the program in August 1993 indeed proved to be the turning point. The bond market became persuaded that the deficit would be reduced. Long-term rates started down, and the economy moved into a state of reasonable economic growth and low inflation.

然而，这种政治方向的转变并非发生在真空之中。1992年罗斯·佩罗以第三党候选人身份竞选总统，使其备受瞩目。削减开支的呼声在20世纪90年代初迅速高涨，最终促成了“与美国人民的契约”的出台、共和党掌控国会两院以及纽特·金里奇的崛起。克林顿领导的民主党政府与第104届国会中咄咄逼人的共和党人之间的冲突，以及由此导致的政府停摆，改变了美国经济政策的走向。共和党人利用围绕平衡预算修正案可能旷日持久的斗争，煽动了关于当前支出的辩论。他们几乎对所有传统上“不可触碰”的政府支出领域都提出了挑战。他们甚至提议关闭或合并整个行政部门，并在此过程中裁减内阁职位。所有这些都使得预算成为白宫与国会关系的核心议题。克林顿否决了较为自由派的顾问们的意见，采纳了这些改革的原则，包括平衡预算。但他并未完全按照共和党人的要求去做。这种策略——后来被称为“三角博弈”——使共和党的大部分议程落空。

Yet this reorientation did not happen in a political vacuum. It was given high visibility by the 1992 third-party presidential bid of Ross Perot. The drive for spending cuts gained immensely in popularity in the early 1990s, culminating in the Contract with America, the Republicans’ capture of both houses of Congress, and the ascendancy of Newt Gingrich. The confrontation between Clinton’s Democratic administration and the brash Republican crusaders of the 104th Congress and the resulting government shutdown shifted the center in American economic policy. The Republicans used the specter of a prolonged battle over a balanced budget amendment to galvanize debate on current spending. They challenged virtually every area of traditionally “untouchable” government expenditure. They even proposed shutting down or merging entire executive departments, eliminating cabinet positions in the process. All this made the budget the chief focus of relations between the White House and the Congress. Overruling his more liberal advisers, Clinton adopted the principle of the proposed changes, including the balanced budget. But he stopped short of going as far as the Republicans advocated. That maneuver—which became known as triangulation—deprived them of much of their agenda.

预算之争改变了美国经济政策乃至美国政治的中心。此后预算协议达成的相对容易程度，表明这一中心已经发展壮大。

The battle over the budget shifted the center of American economic policy, even of American politics. The ease—in relative terms—with which budget deals have been made since then shows how much this center has grown.

虽然经济扩张实际上始于布什政府时期，但随后的赤字削减对于其持续发展至关重要——这在一定程度上承认了美国，如同新兴市场国家一样，每天都受到资本市场的评判。正如鲁宾解释的那样，“关键问题必须是赤字，以及如何才能尽快赢得市场的信任，因为归根结底，利率才是经济的驱动力。”

While the economic expansion actually began in the Bush administration, subsequent deficit reduction was central to its continuation—an acknowledgment, among other things, that the United States, no less than an emerging-market nation, is judged every day by the capital markets. As Rubin explained, “The threshold issue had to be the deficit and how quickly you can gain credibility with the markets, since ultimately it’s interest rates that drive the economy.”

财政赤字下降的速度之快——从1992年占GDP近5%降至1997年的不足1%——几乎令所有人感到惊讶。在1993年的预算大战中，政府和国会预算办公室都预测1997年的赤字将超过2000亿美元。而实际赤字仅为预测的十分之一，即226亿美元，是自20世纪70年代初以来的最低水平。这种戏剧性的转变是如何实现的？部分原因是削减开支（主要来自国防开支），部分原因是提高税收，当然也得益于强劲经济带来的额外税收收入。无论原因如何，正如经济学家本杰明·弗里德曼所说，这是一个“伟大的成就，功劳应该归于所有人”。接下来的阶段很可能是一场关于如何处理预期盈余的争论——是将其通过减税惠及公众，还是用于偿还高达5.7万亿美元的国债，抑或直接用于消费。当然，这一切的前提是不会出现经济衰退，从而导致税收减少，需要增加转移支付。与此同时，赤字下降至少也带来了一个负面影响。“赤字消失得太快了，”一位参议员沉思道，“我们可能无法完全将赤字下降的功劳揽在自己身上。”

The speed with which the deficit has come down—from almost 5 percent of GDP in 1992 to less than 1 percent in 1997—has surprised almost everybody. During the 1993 budget battle, both the administration and the Congressional Budget Office predicted that the 1997 deficit would be over ’200 billion. It came in at only a tenth of that, ’22.6 billion, the lowest level since the early 1970s. How did this dramatic turnaround come about? Partly through reductions in spending (primarily from defense), partly through higher taxes, and certainly through the flow of additional tax revenues generated by a strong economy. Whatever the reasons, the result is, as economist Benjamin Friedman put it, “a great achievement, and there is plenty of credit to go around.” The next stage may well be a battle over …what to do with an anticipated surplus—whether to pass it on to the public through tax cuts, or use it to chip away at the ’5.7 trillion national debt, or spend it. All that assumes, of course, that there is no recession along the way that would reduce tax revenues and require increased transfer payments. In the meantime, at least one downside to the falling deficit has been detected. “The deficit is disappearing so fast,” mused one senator, “that we may not be able to take complete credit for the decline.”

1990年，美国在休斯顿主办七国集团经济峰会时，其经济正饱受赤字、衰退和普遍信心不足的困扰。美国民众对竞争力、就业和……感到焦虑不安。他们担忧创新，也担忧日本崛起成为世界经济的霸主，并执着地探寻其成功的秘诀。美国的“衰落”是当时的热门话题，“衰落论”一词正是用来描述那种关注美国经济明显下滑的思潮。然而，到了1997年丹佛峰会召开之时，一切都发生了翻天覆地的变化。美国成为主要经济体中表现最佳的国家。它创造了1200万个就业岗位，而欧洲和日本加起来却净减少了100万个；美国的失业率降至5%以下；通货膨胀率减半；预算赤字也大幅下降。美国经济已连续七年处于扩张期，而日本则经历了近七年的衰退。美国企业经历了一场痛苦的重塑过程，“硅谷”（不仅指实际的地理区域，还包括从西雅图到休斯顿，再到波士顿128号公路一带）正在推动世界经济的变革。所有这些加起来再次确认了美国的市场体系，并提振了人们的自信心。

In 1990, when the United States hosted the G-7 economic summit in Houston, its economy was hobbled by deficits, recession, and a pervasive loss of confidence. Americans anguished about competitiveness, jobs, and innovation; they worried about the rise of Japan to preeminence in the world economy, and obsessively tried to discover the secrets of its success. America’s “decline” was the theme of the day, and declinism was, in fact, the term coined to describe the school of thought that focused on America’s apparent fall from economic grace. By the time of the 1997 summit in Denver, everything had turned around. The United States was the bestperforming of the major economies. It had created 12 million jobs, compared to a net loss of 1 million for Europe and Japan combined, had brought unemployment under 5 percent, had cut its inflation rate in half, and had dramatically reduced the budget deficit. It was in the seventh year of an expansion, compared to almost seven years of slump in Japan. American business had gone through a wrenching process of remaking itself, and “Silicon Valley” (which included not only the actual geographic entity but stretched from Seattle to Houston to Boston’s Route 128) was driving change in the world economy. All that added up to a reconfirmation of America’s market system, and generated a recovery in self-confidence.

“自1990年以来发生的一切令人难以置信，”财政部副部长劳伦斯·萨默斯评论道。“从经济角度来看，这几乎是一个全新的世界。1990年，一个经济体很大程度上是由其汽车工业定义的。而如今，它是由服务业、软件业和‘内容’产业定义的。美国经济的转变首先是由美国自身产业的重组推动的。美国的一项比较优势在于，与其他大多数国家不同，美国的银行家愿意把钱借给没有关系的人。”7

“It’s unbelievable what has happened since 1990,” observed Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers. “It’s almost a new world in economic terms since then. In 1990, an economy was defined very much by its automobile industry. Today, it’s defined by its service industries, its software industries, and its ‘content’ industries. The change in the United States has been driven first and foremost by the restructuring of American industry itself. One of the country’s comparative strengths has proven to be that, unlike in most other countries, bankers in America will give money to guys without ties.”7

迟来的革命

A Delayed Revolution

从罗纳德·里根当选总统到逐渐淡化凯恩斯主义对政府政策的影响，历经了超过十五年的时间：货币政策趋于稳定，支出和税收大幅削减，最终形成两党能够讨论和妥协的局面。里根革命的实质是在里根退出政坛很久之后，也是在供给侧经济学的逻辑被证伪很久之后才得以实现的。因此，它并非里根主义者最初设想的那种革命。但就其长远影响而言，它同样是一场革命，因为它标志着政府痛苦但切实地减少了对经济的干预范围。

It had taken more than a decade and a half from Ronald Reagan’s election to dilute the Keynesian imprint on government policy: to steady monetary policy, and to significantly restrain spending and taxation in ways that both parties could discuss and compromise on. The substance of the Reagan revolution was realized well after Reagan’s passing from the political scene and well after the logic of supply-side economics had been discredited. It was not, therefore, the revolution the Reaganites had had in mind. But it was no less a revolution in its long-term effects, for it saw the government painfully but genuinely reducing its scope of intervention in the economy.

这一点也适用于监管。自罗斯福新政以来，美国在监管经济和避免滥用权力方面，很大程度上依赖于其庞大的监管机构网络，以及强大的司法反垄断传统。从20世纪30年代中期到70年代中期，这套体系变化不大。监管机构和法院各司其职，在程序和风格上也日趋相似。但从1975年开始，监管开始发生剧变。在许多方面，监管都发生了根本性的变化。在某些领域，美国经历了所谓的放松管制——这意味着取消了许多对经济活动的监管限制，尽管通常也要求制定新的限制。然而，在其他一些领域——特别是健康、安全、环境、雇员和消费者权益以及平权行动——却出现了大量的新监管。在某些情况下，这种平衡尚不明确，或仍在变化之中。但总而言之，监管仍然是美国政府影响市场和个人行为方式的重要手段。

That applied to regulation as well. Ever since the New Deal, America had placed much of its confidence, in terms of overseeing the economy and avoiding abuses, in its web of regulatory agencies, combined with the powerful judicial antitrust tradition. From the mid-1930s until the mid-1970s the system did not change much. The regulators and the courts played their appointed roles. They came to resemble each other in procedure and style. But from 1975 onward, regulation began to change—drastically. In many areas, America experienced so-called deregulation—meaning the withdrawal ofmany regulatory restrictions over economic activity, although often with the requirement that new ones be devised as well. Yet in some other areas—particularly health, safety, the environment, employee and consumer rights, and affirmative action—there has been a great deal of new regulation. In some cases, the balance is ambiguous or still shifting. All in all, however, regulation remains a central means for government in the United States to effect major changes in the way the market, and individuals, behave.

从捕获到竞争

From Capture to Competition

经济监管始于1887年州际商务委员会的成立。在接下来的几十年里，此类监管的理由逐渐被阐述，包括促进经济发展、维护公平正义、制衡垄断以及提供经济实惠的普惠公共服务。从罗斯福新政开始，市场缺陷和失灵成为监管的主要理由。战后时期，政府的影响力几乎渗透到所有经济活动中。

Economic regulation emerged with the establishment of the Interstate Commerce Commission in 1887. Over the next several decades, the rationales for such regulation were progressively elaborated. They included the promotion of economic development, equity and fairness, the requisite counterbalance to monopolies, and the provision of economically affordable universal services. From the New Deal onward, market imperfections and failures became a dominating rationale. And in the postwar years, government presence came to be felt in almost every economic enterprise.

尽管里根政府上任时承诺要放松经济监管，但这一进程实际上早在福特和卡特政府时期，也就是20世纪70年代中后期就已经开始了。那时，人们对经济监管的批判已经相当成熟，这得益于经济学家和其他社会科学家长达十五年的研究。芝加哥学派一直走在前列，这要归功于乔治·斯蒂格勒对美式监管的批判。斯蒂格勒在20世纪60年代花费了大量时间研究关于电力监管、股票交易规则和反垄断案件的大量数据。“我的发现常常令人惊讶，”他说，“对电力公司的监管并没有帮助到居民用户；对股票发行的监管也没有帮助到购买这些股票的寡妇和孤儿。”

Though the Reagan administration arrived with a promise to roll back economic regulation, the process had actually begun in the Ford and Carter administrations, in the middle and late 1970s. By then there was already a well-articulated critique of economic regulation, the result of the attention that economists and other social scientists had been devoting to the subject for a decade and a half. The Chicago School had been at the forefront, owing to the critique of American-style regulation by George Stigler. Stigler had spent much of the 1960s plowing through mountains of data on electric power regulation, stock exchange rules, and antitrust cases. “My findings were often surprising,” he said. “The regulation of electric utilities did not help residential users; the regulation of stock issues did not help the widows and orphans who bought these issues.”

基于这些发现，斯蒂格勒提出了著名的“监管俘获”理论。他得出结论：受监管企业总是比监管机构更了解自身的运营活动，并可以利用这种信息优势来改变监管方向，使其向自身倾斜。根深蒂固的监管最终反而服务于它原本旨在约束的企业。后来，斯蒂格勒的学生们进一步拓展了这一理论，探讨特殊利益集团和游说团体如何掌控监管过程。由于斯蒂格勒的监管俘获理论挑战了监管能够服务和保护抽象、公正的公共利益的观念，因此它直接挑战了詹姆斯·兰迪斯关于无私监管的理想。斯蒂格勒认为，恰恰相反，监管本身就带有太多的“利益”。

From these findings came Stigler’s famous theory of “regulatory capture.” He concluded that the regulated firm always knew more about its own activities than the regulator could find out, and could use this information advantage to shift regulation in its favor. Entrenched regulation had come to serve the firms it was once meant to restrain. Later, students of Stigler would extend this theory to explore how special-interest groups and lobbies could take over the process. Because it challenged the notion that regulation could serve and protect an abstract, impartial public interest, Stigler’s theory of regulatory capture was a head-on challenge to James Landis’s ideal of disinterested regulation. On the contrary, Stigler argued, it was all too “interested.”

芝加哥学派也低估了垄断和市场力量带来的风险，而这些风险在近一个世纪的美国政治思想中一直占据着核心地位。这种观点曾激励了包括西奥多·罗斯福和路易斯·布兰代斯在内的许多人。然而，芝加哥学派则强调政府管制带来的负面成本。到了20世纪70年代中期，这种论点得到了广泛的认可。通货膨胀、工资和物价管制带来的种种弊端，约翰逊和尼克松政府时期监管的迅速扩张，持续不断的通货膨胀，以及1973年油价飙升后引发的严重衰退，所有这些都导致人们对整个监管体系提出全面质疑。监管体系过于僵化、反应迟缓、扭曲经济，而且日益繁琐。它阻碍了技术和商业创新。应对通货膨胀的迫切性使得放松管制显得尤为重要。有人指出，监管不仅会固定价格，还会推高价格；而放松管制将鼓励竞争，从而降低价格。此外，监管机构不得不疲于应对技术变革带来的日益增多的经济问题。与此同时，国际贸易和全球竞争的增长也使得传统的反垄断法不再那么重要。

The Chicago School also minimized the risks of monopoly and market power that had been central to almost a century of American political thinking and that had animated, among others, Theodore Roosevelt and Louis Brandeis. Instead, the Chicago School emphasized the negative costs of government control. By the mid-1970s, such arguments found a welcoming audience. The unhappy experience of inflation and wage and price controls, the rapid growth of regulation in the Johnson and Nixon administrations, persistent inflation, and then, after the 1973 oil price hike, the deep recession, all led to wholesale questioning of the entire regulatory structure. It was too rigid, too slow, too distorting, and ever more cumbersome. It hobbled technical and commercial innovation. The need to do something about inflation made deregulation particularly urgent. It was said that regulation not only fixed but drove up prices; deregulation would encourage competition and thus lower prices. And regulatory bodies were having to run harder and harder to keep up with the multiplying economic issues that resulted from technological change. Meanwhile, the growth of international trade and global competition made traditional antitrust less relevant.

随着时间的推移，竞争越来越被视为优于监管。自然垄断的概念——经济学中用来描述多个供应商会导致成本上升而非下降的情况——受到了质疑。如果那些目前被阻止的人真的想进入某个行业，并且即使规模很小，也完全有可能进入，那么市场实际上就不是自然垄断。相反，它将是“可竞争的”——也就是说，它受到竞争的影响。或许竞争能够更好地实现监管原本想要达到的目标。其结果是降低消费者的成本。

With the passage of time, competition increasingly came to be seen as preferable to regulation. The very concept of natural monopoly—the economic name for a situation where multiple suppliers would lead to higher, not lower, costs—was questioned. If people who were now prevented from doing so really wanted to get into a business, and could feasibly do so even if only on a small scale, then the market would not, in fact, be a natural monopoly. Instead, it would be “contestable”—that is, subject to competition. And perhaps competition could better serve the objectives that regulation was supposed to achieve. The results would be lower costs to consumers.

斯蒂格勒和芝加哥经济学家们的批评绝非孤例。例如，1969年，政治立场中间的布鲁金斯学会发起了一项对监管体系的批判，最终形成了多卷本的著作，影响深远。此后，批判之声愈演愈烈。一些经济学家和政治学家构建了一套监管理论，其核心思想是参与者都是理性行为者，追求特定利益，并将政治和监管体系视为市场的不同变体，其中结果可以“买卖”。另一些人则着眼于体系的组织缺陷以及监管无法跟上技术变革的步伐。如果说市场失灵是监管的动因，那么“监管失灵”便成为了批判的焦点。监管之所以无法发挥作用，可能是因为设计缺陷、法规过时、技术进步使其落伍，或是陷入僵局和僵化。这些不同的分析之间存在着诸多差异和分歧。然而，所有批评都指向一个共同的结论：政府的监管部门本身存在缺陷，而且往往是“私人利益”而不是公共利益决定了结果。

Stigler and the Chicago economists were certainly not alone in their criticism. In 1969, for instance, the politically centrist Brookings Institution initiated a critique of the regulatory system that eventually ran to multiple volumes. That work had wide influence. The critique continued to mount.
