Some economists and political scientists built a theory of regulation based on the idea that participants in the process were rational actors, pursuing particular interests, and treated the political and regulatory systems as variants on markets in which outcomes were “bought” and “sold.” Others examined organizational flaws in the system and the inability of regulation to keep up with technological change. If market failure had been the goad to regulation, then “regulatory failure” became a focus for critique. Regulation would fail to do its job because of poor design or because regulations outlived their time or because technology made them obsolete or because of gridlock and rigidity. There was much variation and disagreement among these different analyses. Yet all the criticisms led to a common conclusion: The regulatory branch of government was inherently flawed, and all too often, it was “private interest,” not the public interest, that determined outcomes.

但率先迈出这一步的并非保守派共和党人。1974年，参议员爱德华·肯尼迪成为新成立的“行政实践和程序”小组委员会主席。至于首席法律顾问，他扳倒了哈佛法学院教授斯蒂芬·布雷耶，布雷耶曾参与水门事件调查。应肯尼迪的要求，布雷耶为小组委员会列出了一份可能的调查清单。其中一项——航空监管——最令布雷耶感兴趣。肯尼迪勾选了这项。美国放松管制的进程由此开始。8

But it was not a conservative Republican who took the first step. In 1974, Senator Edward Kennedy became chairman of a newly created subcommittee on “administrative practice and procedure.” For chief counsel, he brought down Stephen Breyer, a Harvard Law School professor, who had worked in the Watergate investigation. At Kennedy’s request, Breyer came up with a list of possible investigations for the subcommittee. One of the items, airline regulation, interested Breyer the most. Kennedy checked it off. And that is how deregulation began in the United States.8

“李子”和“狗”

“Plums” and “Dogs”

布雷耶曾在哈佛大学教授反垄断法和行政法。他信奉自由市场，并认为应该通过竞争来确保市场正常运作。事实上，他无法理解监管结构性竞争市场的合理性。“如果市场能够做得更好，为什么要监管呢？”他问道。与此同时，他对詹姆斯·兰迪斯所追求的“行政科学”也越来越持怀疑态度。“在罗斯福新政时期，”布雷耶说，“由于经济大萧条，人们对市场深感怀疑。人们对行政科学，也就是法律科学，抱有极大的信心。监管被视为一种科学方法，它能够通过有意识地运用这种纪律来产生正确的结果并约束产业。结果证明，根本不存在这样的科学。”布鲁金斯学会出版的大量关于监管的著作也对布雷耶产生了影响。“经济学正在证实人们的怀疑，即监管无法解决问题，”他说。“人们开始认为自由市场并没有那么糟糕。”

Breyer taught antitrust and administrative law at Harvard. He believed in free markets and in ensuring that they worked through competition. Indeed, he could not understand the rationale for regulating markets that were structurally competitive. “Why regulate something,” he asked, “if it can be done better by the market?” At the same time, he had become increasingly skeptical about the “science of administration” that had been the goal of James Landis. “During the New Deal,” said Breyer, “people were deeply suspicious of the marketplace because of the Depression. People had tremendous confidence in the science of administration, the science of law. Regulation was regarded as a scientific method, which would produce the correct results and hold industry in check by the conscious application of the discipline. It turned out that there was no such science.” Breyer was further influenced by the many volumes on regulation produced by the Brookings Institution. “Economics was verifying the suspicion that regulation can’t do the job,” he said. “People began to think that free markets were not so terrible.”

航空监管是一个特别诱人的目标。民用航空委员会（CAB）成立于1938年，旨在应对当时美国航空业“近乎混乱”的局面，以及“不经济、破坏性的竞争和服务重复浪费”。当时的问题是新兴航空业普遍存在的不稳定性。具体而言，问题出在航空邮件上。邮局授予的航空邮件合同为这项新兴业务提供了补贴，而那些渴望赢得合同的公司则竞相压价。失败者指责邮局存在偏袒行为。为了规范这项被视为公共服务的行业，并满足国家需求，以及在战争阴云密布的时期确保民用航空业的稳定（因为民用航空业将成为军事力量的重要基础），监管制度应运而生。

Airline regulation offered a particularly tempting target. The Civil Aeronautics Board (CAB) had been established in 1938 to deal with what was described at the time as “near chaos” and “uneconomic, destructive competition and wasteful duplication of services” in U.S. aviation. The issue then was the rampant instability of the fledgling airline industry. The specific problem was airmail. The contracts let by the post office for airmail provided subsidies for the new business, and companies that were desperate to win those contracts wildly undercut each other in their bids. Losers accused the post office of favoritism. Regulation was introduced to bring some order to what was seen as a public service, both to meet the nation’s needs and—at a time when war was on the horizon—to ensure stability in a civilian aviation industry that would be a very important foundation for military power.

随着时间的推移，最终形成了一个由政府主导的卡特尔，其基础是监管者和被监管者之间的共生关系。这一体系的特点是分配所谓的“肥差”和“肥差”。民航局决定所有航线的机票价格，这意味着所有航空公司在同一航线上都收取相同的价格。民航局还决定哪些航空公司可以执飞各条州际航线。具体来说，航空公司同意在某些航线上提供无利可图的服务——例如飞往较小城市的航线——作为回报，它们将获得补偿。那些货量大、利润高的路线——也就是所谓的“肥肉”。民航局举行冗长乏味的公开听证会，完全是布兰代斯式的做法，与实际的商业经济状况几乎毫无关联。之后，委员们会退到私人房间，做出决定，然后分配肥肉和肥狗。

What resulted, as the years passed, was a government-run cartel based upon a symbiotic relationship between regulator and regulatee, a system characterized by the allocation of what had become known as “plums” and “dogs.” The CAB decided what tickets would cost on all routes, which meant that all airlines charged the same price on the same route. The CAB also decided who could fly the various interstate routes. This was the deal: Airlines would agree to provide unprofitable service along some routes—the dogs—for instance, to smaller cities. In turn, they would be compensated with high-volume, profitable routes—the plums. The CAB conducted lengthy and tedious public hearings, very much in the Brandeisian tradition and without much relation to the actual economics of the business. Then the commissioners would retire to a private room, make their decisions, and hand out the plums and the dogs.

布雷耶说：“消费者咨询委员会（CAB）本应保护公众利益，但监管却导致了物价上涨。它95%的时间都花在防止物价过低，而不是努力降低物价。”在布雷耶看来，肯尼迪听证会的展开宛如一场交响乐。他说，听证会“精彩绝伦，一切都如乐谱所预示的那样，细节尽收眼底。”听证会揭示了该体系如何阻碍竞争，从而剥夺了公众本应享有的价格优势。

“The CAB was supposed to be protecting the public,” said Breyer. “But regulation was leading to higher prices. It spent 95 percent of its time keeping prices from being too low instead of pushing to get them lowered.” The Kennedy hearings, in Breyer’s mind, unfolded almost like a symphony. They were, he said, “beautiful. Everything emerged in detail just as the score had predicted.” The hearings demonstrated how the system prevented competition and thus denied the public the price benefits that would otherwise result.

然而，揭露体制的缺陷是一回事，在航空业大多数成员根深蒂固的反对声中改变体制则是另一回事。听证会结束后，福特总统的民航局开始探讨如何实施放松管制，但福特政府仅维持了两年半。卡特政府继承了这一主题。此后，对监管的攻击由一位与芝加哥学派毫无瓜葛的经济学家领导。事实上，除了经济理论之外，他在其他所有方面都是一位自由派民主党人。

Yet it was one thing to so demonstrate the flaws of the system; it was quite another to change it in the face of the entrenched opposition by most of the airline industry. In the aftermath of the hearings, President Ford’s CAB began to explore how to implement deregulation, but the Ford administration lasted only two and a half years. The Carter administration picked up the theme. The attack on regulation was thereafter led by an economist who was not at all part of the Chicago School. Indeed, he was a liberal Democrat in everything but, as it turned out, economic theory.

“边际成本与翅膀”

“Marginal Costs with Wings”

阿尔弗雷德·卡恩堪称天才，18岁便以最优等成绩毕业于纽约大学，随后前往耶鲁大学攻读经济学博士学位，24岁便获得博士学位。他思维敏捷，酷爱吉尔伯特与沙利文的轻歌剧，喜欢玩弄文字游戏，有时甚至颇为狡黠。作为康奈尔大学的经济学教授，他于1970年适时出版了其代表作《监管经济学》。该书被誉为“该领域最具影响力的著作”。

Something of a prodigy, Alfred Kahn graduated from New York University summa cum laude at age eighteen and then went on to Yale for his Ph.D. in economics, which he obtained at age twenty-four. Endowed with a quick mind and a passion for Gilbert and Sullivan operettas, he enjoyed playing with words, sometimes quite slyly. A professor of economics at Cornell University, he published his masterwork The Economics ofRegulation at the right time, in 1970. It has been described as the “most influential work ever written on the subject.”

卡恩指出，监管过多的问题在于它未能反映市场的真实情况，阻碍了价格发挥其根本作用。他解释说：“价格唯一的经济功能是影响行为——刺激供给并调节需求。”但许多监管措施似乎恰恰相反——它们发出的信号与供求的实际情况大相径庭。监管者往往并不了解他们所监管行业的经济运作，也不了解自身决策的经济后果。卡恩认为，监管的指导原则应该是边际成本定价——也就是说，价格应该由提供额外一单位商品或服务的成本决定。

The problem with so much regulation, said Kahn, was that it did not reflect the realities of the marketplace, and prevented price from doing its essential job. He explained, “The only economic function of price is to influence behavior—to elicit supply and to regulate demand.” But much regulation seemed to do just the opposite—it sent signals quite at variance with the realities of supply and demand. Regulators often did not seem to understand the economics of the industries they were regulating—or the economic consequences of their own decisions. The guiding star of regulation Kahn said, should be marginal cost pricing—that is, prices should be determined by the cost of providing one additional unit of whatever the good or service.

卡恩的书出版之时，正值传统监管体系瓦解之际。当时，整个系统已显露出严重故障的迹象，尤其是在能源和电力领域。他首次有机会着手改革监管，是在被任命为纽约州公共服务委员会主席之后。在任期间，他力推对电力价格进行全面改革，使其与边际成本挂钩。卡恩由此树立了监管改革者的声誉。1977年，卡特总统将他从奥尔巴尼召回，任命他为民用航空委员会主席。卡恩就任主席时，有多达六百份不同的航线申请等待审批。他目标明确：引入竞争，让市场接管目前由民用航空委员会五位委员做出的经济决策。那些行动迅速，或者至少“按时”提交申请的人将获得丰厚的回报。而那些决策失误的人则将面临损失，甚至最终破产。在此过程中，卡恩打算消除冗长而费力的听证会，这些听证会与其说是基于合理的经济分析，不如说是受到了他所谓的“佩里·梅森主义”（指著名虚构诉讼律师佩里·梅森）的影响。

Kahn’s book appeared just at the time when the traditional regulatory system was showing signs of severe malfunction, particularly in the energy and electric power sectors. His first opportunity to begin reforming regulation came when he was selected to head the New York State Public Service Commission, where he pushed through a complete redesign of electric power rates, keyed to marginal costs. Kahn developed a reputation as a regulatory reformer. In 1977, President Carter plucked him out of Albany and made him chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board. At the time Kahn became chairman, a daunting six hundred separate route applications were waiting adjudication. He knew what he wanted to do: introduce competition and let the market take over the economic decisions now being made by the five CAB commissioners. To the swift, or at least the “on-time”—the spoils. To those who got it wrong—losses or, the ultimate sanction, bankruptcy. In the process, Kahn intended to eliminate the long and laborious hearings that owed more to what he called “Perry Masonisms,” referring to the famous fictional litigator, than to sound economic analysis.

卡恩对听证程序缺乏耐心。“制定经济政策的正当程序，”他抗议道，“与刑事审判的正当程序截然不同。”但从民航局的运作方式来看，人们却丝毫看不出这一点。民航局被迫考虑的问题之多令他震惊：“空中出租车能否购置一架五十座的飞机？辅助承运商能否将马匹从佛罗里达州运送到东北部的某个地方？航空公司能否推出滑雪者特价票，如果没雪就退还票款？”还有一个最为重大的问题：“两家财务上相关的航空公司员工能否穿着相似的制服？”所有这些——以及更多——都由政府监管机构决定。“难怪，”卡恩说道，“我每天都在问自己：这样做有必要吗？这是我母亲教导我做的吗？”

Kahn had little patience with the hearing process. “Due process in the fashioning of economic policy,” he protested, “is not the same as due process in a criminal trial.” But one would not know that from the way the CAB operated. He was amazed by the kind of questions the CAB was forced to consider: “May an air taxi acquire a fifty-seat plane? May a supplemental carrier carry horses from Florida to somewhere in the Northeast? May a carrier introduce a special fare for skiers that refunds the cost of their ticket if there is no snow?” And one of the most momentous questions of all: “May the employees of two financially affiliated airlines wear similarlooking uniforms?” All this—and much more—was being decided by government regulators. “Is there any wonder,” said Kahn, “that I ask myself every day: Is this action necessary? Is this what my mother raised me to do?”

他对航空体系的主要攻击在于允许票价灵活调整，这意味着折扣票价的出现。到1978年夏天，超过一半的经济舱里程都是通过“花生票”、“超级特价票”和其他折扣票价实现的。卡恩亲自处理了许多愤怒的投诉。1964年共和党总统候选人、畅销书《保守派的良心》的作者巴里·戈德华特参议员写信给他，抱怨如今拥挤不堪的航班上糟糕的乘车环境。卡恩回复说，这是打破“类似卡特尔的体制”的必然结果。他还补充道：“如果您对自由市场体系的效率有任何疑问，请随时告诉我。我也强烈推荐您阅读巴里·戈德华特参议员早期的一些演讲和著作。”当一位朋友写信告诉他，在飞机上坐在嬉皮士旁边是多么不愉快时，卡恩回复说：“既然我没有收到嬉皮士的任何投诉，我想他应该没有表现出同样的厌恶。”

His major assault on the system was to allow flexibility in pricing, which meant discount fares. By the summer of 1978, over half of coach-class miles were being flown on “peanut,” supersaver, and other discount fares. Kahn personally fielded many irate complaints. When Senator Barry Goldwater, the 1964 Republican presidential candidate and author of the bestselling Conscience of a Conservative, wrote him to complain about unpleasant conditions aboard now-packed flights, Kahn replied that this was the inevitable consequence of breaking up a “cartel-like regime.” He added, “When you have further doubts about the efficiency of a free market system, please do not hesitate to convey them to me. I also warmly recommend some earlier speeches and writings of one Senator Barry Goldwater.” When a friend wrote him about how unpleasant it had been to sit next to a hippie on a flight, Kahn replied, “Since I have not received any complaints from the hippie, I assume the distaste was not reciprocated.”

卡恩面临的最大挑战来自那些在监管环境下成长起来、不愿改变现状的航空公司和团体。在一次听证会上，东方航空公司总裁、前宇航员弗兰克·博尔曼试图澄清一些问题。不同类型飞机的优势。“我根本分不清哪架飞机是哪架，”卡恩反驳道，“在我看来，它们不过是带翅膀的边际成本机器。”1978年10月，航空业放松管制正式生效：那些“李子和狗”的优惠政策不复存在。航空公司可以自由定价，展开竞争。它们可以自行决定是否进入或退出市场和航线。新公司也可以进入这个行业。民航局（CAB）本身于1985年解散。安全仍然是联邦航空管理局（FAA）的职责。

Kahn’s biggest battles were with the airlines and groups that had grown up with regulation and did not want it changed. In one hearing, former astronaut Frank Borman, president of Eastern Airlines, was seeking to clarify the advantages of different types of aircraft. “I really don’t know one plane from another,” Kahn shot back. “To me they are all marginal costs with wings.” In October 1978, airline deregulation became law: The plums and dogs were gone. Airlines were free to set fares competitively. They could decide whether to enter or exit markets and routes. And entry was now open to new companies. The CAB itself went out of business in 1985. Safety remained the province of the Federal Aviation Administration.

这就是放松管制——新政体系的首次重大倒退。结果如何呢？据估计，1996年航空旅客的平均出行费用比管制措施实施后节省了26%——尽管商务旅客与休闲旅客相比明显处于劣势。一些老牌航空公司已经破产，但也有一些航空公司在破产期间维持运营并最终扭亏为盈。美国的主要航空公司（即干线航空公司）数量从十家减少到六家。在放松管制的初期，一些小城镇要么失去了航空服务（尤其是喷气式飞机），要么面临失去航空服务的威胁。支线航空公司填补了这一空白，用更频繁的小型飞机航班取代了每天一两班喷气式飞机的起降。一个尚未解答的问题是，喷气式飞机服务的丧失对小城镇的经济发展产生了怎样的影响。但从更宏观的角度来看，航空业的放松管制确实标志着一个转折点，扭转了此前四十年的监管趋势，转向了市场化。9

This was deregulation—the first major rolling back of the New Deal system. And how did it work out? It is estimated that on average, air travelers in 1996 paid 26 percent less for trips than they would have if regulation had stayed in place—although business travelers are clearly disadvantaged compared to leisure travelers. Some of the most established carriers have gone bankrupt, although some operated through bankruptcy and came out on the other side. Instead of ten trunk (i.e., major) carriers in the United States, there are now six. In the early years of deregulation smaller cities and towns either lost their air service (especially jets) or were threatened with such loss. Commuter airlines stepped into the breach, replacing one or two jet touchdowns a day with much more frequent small-plane service. One of the unanswered questions is what effect the loss ofjet service has had on economic development in smaller cities and towns. But in the larger context, airline deregulation did mark a turning point, a reversal of the regulatory thrust of the preceding forty years and a turn to the market.9

航空公司只是经济放松管制最显而易见的例子。整个过程影响到日常生活的其他领域。铁路和卡车运输也成为了目标。铁路监管一直基于自然垄断的论点。早在20世纪30年代中期，一些罗斯福新政的支持者就指出，竞争确实存在——来自卡车，卡车也能运输货物。但这一观点一直被忽视，直到20世纪70年代，人们才意识到，高度不合理的监管体系不仅摧毁了铁路的经济生存能力，甚至还削弱了铁路服务客户的能力。运价设定并不符合铁路高效运营的经济规律。

Airlines were only the most visible example of economic deregulation. The overall process touched other areas of daily life. Railroads and trucking were also targets. Railroad regulation had been based upon the naturalmonopoly argument. As early as the mid-193Os, some New Dealers had pointed out that competition did exist—from trucks, which could also carry freight. But this was disregarded until the 1970s, when it became apparent that the highly irrational regulatory system was destroying not only the economic viability of railroads but even their ability to serve customers. Rate setting did not accord with the economics of efficiently running a railroad.

20世纪70年代铁路放松管制运动的领军人物之一是康雷尔铁路公司（Conrail）董事长爱德华·乔丹。康雷尔铁路公司是在70年代初紧急成立的，是一家政府支持的企业，旨在收拾宾夕法尼亚中央铁路公司（Penn Central）和其他几家铁路公司破产后的残局。“监管使管理者的思维模式僵化，使他们无法自主经营，”他解释道，“他们对收入的控制权微乎其微；收入由华盛顿的监管机构决定。这意味着他们无法根据客户的服务需求调整业务。典型的铁路高管要么是列车员，要么是律师——他们懂得如何与监管机构打交道——而不是商人。真正推动变革的人来自外部。他们不受监管思维的束缚。”这些努力最终在80年代初实现了几乎完全的放松管制，其后果显而易见。放松管制带来的成本节约估计在500亿至700亿美元之间。铁路公司开始重新盈利。创新得到鼓励。如今，货物运输走的是成本效益更高的路线，而不是监管机构强制规定的那些荒谬的环形路线。

One of the leaders in the decontrol movement in the 1970s was Edward Jordan, chairman of Conrail, which was created on an emergency basis in the early 1970s as a government-sponsored company to pick up the pieces after the bankruptcy of Penn Central and several other railroads. “Regulation froze managers into a mind-set that did not allow them to run their business,” he explained. “Their control over revenue generation was not significant; that was determined by regulators in Washington. This meant that they could not tailor their business to their customers’ service needs. The typical railroad executive was either a trainman or a lawyer—who knew how to interact with the commission—rather than a businessman. The people who made the change came from the outside. They were not bound by the regulatory mind-set.” These efforts culminated in almost total deregulation by the beginning of the 1980s, and here the consequences were unambiguous. Cost savings from deregulation are estimated at $50 to $70 billion. Railroads started making profits again. Innovation was encouraged. And freight now moves over cost-efficient routes rather than the ludicrously circular routes that were mandated by regulators.

丧钟为谁而鸣

For Whom the Bell Tolls

所有受监管公司中规模最大的当属AT&T——这家拥有超过100万名员工的美国最大企业，提供了美国绝大部分的本地和长途电话服务。其他公司，例如通用电话公司和电气公司（GTE），则在边缘地带与其展开竞争。AT&T的运营基于自然垄断的理念；而对其监管，则以维护公共利益为出发点。

The biggest regulated company of all was AT&T—the country’s largest enterprise, with over 1 million employees—which provided the bulk of telephone services, local and long distance, in the United States. Other companies, like General Telephone and Electric, competed around the edges. AT&T’s operation was based on the idea of a natural monopoly; and its regulation, on the preservation of the public good.

AT&T在19世纪末迅速崛起，其优势在于亚历山大·格雷厄姆·贝尔于1876年发明了电话，以及它对专利的控制和横向及纵向一体化的战略。其核心愿景是提供廉价的普遍服务——正如其1910年年度报告中所述，“通过电力传输消除时间和距离的限制”。西联公司早期决定退出电话业务，以保护其当时认为（事后证明是错误的）利润更为丰厚的城际电报业务，这无疑助长了AT&T的崛起。摩根大通为其通过收购实现的增长提供了资金支持。此外，联邦、州政府和公众普遍认为竞争是重复的、低效的、浪费的，并且会导致服务质量下降，这种观点也影响了AT&T的发展。电话业务应该实行垄断，但必须受到监管。在州一级，公共事业委员会负责监管。在联邦层面，监管权最初归州际商务委员会所有，但后来根据罗斯福新政1934年的《通信法》，该权力转移到了一个新的机构——联邦通信委员会。正如富兰克林·罗斯福的商务部长所说，电话服务“就其本身的性质而言”，如果“以垄断的方式运营，将会是最有效率和最令人满意的”。

AT&T had quickly risen to preeminence in the last part of the nineteenth century on the basis of Alexander Graham Bell’s invention of the telephone in 1876, its control of patents and its strategy of horizontal and vertical integration. At its heart was the vision of cheap universal service—in the words of its 1910 Annual Report, “annihilating time or distance by use of electrical transmission.” It was helped by Western Union’s early decision to get out of the telephone business in order to protect what Western Union thought—mistakenly, as it turned out—would be the much more lucrative business of intercity telegraph. Its growth by acquisition was financed by J. P. Morgan. AT&T was also shaped by a widespread belief at the federal and state level and in the public that competition was duplicative, inefficient, and wasteful, and would deliver inferior service. The phone business should be a monopoly, but a regulated one. At the state level, public-utility commissions did the regulating. At the federal level, regulatory authority was invested in the Interstate Commerce Commission but then shifted by the New Deal’s 1934 Communications Act to a new body, the Federal Communications Commission. As Franklin Roosevelt’s secretary of commerce put it, telephone service “by its very character” would be “most efficient and satisfactory if conducted as a monopoly.”

AT&T提供一切服务，从长途电话到家庭电话设备，应有尽有。而且，它的服务质量非常高。如果用户遇到问题，维修车会迅速赶到，问题会被追踪并解决，而且不会出现管辖权纠纷。监管历史学家理查德·维托尔指出：“与其他任何全国性网络相比，毫无疑问，无论从普及率、技术质量还是价格来看，这套系统都是最佳选择。” AT&T也严密维护着它的垄断地位。“外国配件”在任何地方都不允许使用。因此，这家电话公司有效地抵御了Hush-a-Phone带来的竞争挑战。Hush-a-Phone是一种小型杯状配件，套在电话听筒上，用于增强通话者的隐私。使用任何外国配件都意味着用户可能面临电话服务中断的风险。

AT&T provided everything, from the long-distance service to the equipmentin the house. And it delivered a very high quality of service. If a subscriber had a problem, the truck would speedily arrive, the problem would be traced and rectified, and there was no squabbling over jurisdiction. “By comparison to any other national network,” observed regulatory historian Richard Vietor, “there is no question that this system worked best—measured by penetration, technical quality, or price.” AT&T also jealously guarded its monopoly. “Foreign attachments” were not permitted anywhere. Thus the phone company effectively fought off the competitive challenge posed by the Hush-a-Phone, a sort of small cuplike attachment put around the mouthpiece to increase the privacy of the speaker. Using any foreign attachment meant risking the cutoff of one’s phone service.

这套系统已经形成并被广泛接受。只有最具冒险精神，甚至可以说是鲁莽的人，才敢挑战AT&T的强大地位——并为此投入时间和精力。而正是这样一位人物，威廉·麦克高恩，一位从咨询顾问转型为企业家的传奇人物，在20世纪60年代末从边缘地带开始了他的挑战，并在此后坚定不移地推进。麦克高恩抓住了一个千载难逢的机会：一家名为微波通信公司（Microwave Communications, Inc.，后简称MCI）的创始人前来咨询如何为他们的项目筹集资金，该项目旨在利用微波信号连接圣路易斯至芝加哥线路上的卡车。麦克高恩没有给他们提供建议，而是直接收购了这家公司的控股权。

The system was settled and accepted. Only the most adventurous, and perhaps even foolhardy, would dare to challenge AT&T’s formidable position—and expend the time and effort so doing. And it took such a character, William McGowan, a consultant-turned-entrepreneur, who started his attack from the fringes in the late 1960s and pursued it resolutely thereafter. McGowan had grasped a golden opportunity when the founders of a firm called Microwave Communications, Inc. (later just MCI) came to him for advice about securing finance for their venture to connect trucks on the St. Louis-Chicago run by microwave signal. Instead of giving them advice, he bought control of the firm.

麦克高恩发起了一场旨在削弱AT&T垄断地位的运动。第一步是获得联邦通信委员会（FCC）对其长途专线服务的批准。经过六年漫长的听证会、文件提交、上诉和复审——期间公司几乎破产——MCI最终获得了FCC的批准，得以开展这项服务。委员们的投票结果为四比三，差距微弱。一位投赞成票的委员解释说，他正在寻找“一些方法，给委员会和贝尔公司炮制出的这锅乏味的监管保护汤里加点竞争的盐和胡椒粉”。麦克高恩继续在法庭上与AT&T展开斗争。有时，打官司似乎成了公司唯一的谋生手段——正如公司内部的玩笑所说，这家公司“就像一家屋顶上装了天线的律师事务所”。但麦克高恩的坚持最终得到了回报。

McGowan embarked on a crusade to undermine AT&T’s monopoly. The first step was to win approval from the FCC for its long-distance privateline service. After six years of interminable hearings, filings, appeals, and rehearings—during which it almost went under—MCI won approval from the FCC to establish its service. The vote among the commissioners was a close four to three. One of those who voted yes explained that he was looking “for ways to add a little salt and pepper of competition to the rather tasteless stew of regulatory protection that this Commission and Bell have cooked up.” McGowan continued his campaign against AT&T in the courts. At times, it seemed that pursuing lawsuits was the company’s only vocation—as the in-house joke went, the company was “a law firm with an antenna on the roof.” But McGowan’s perseverance would pay off.

麦高恩或许比任何人都更能撼动长期存在的监管体系。但真正动摇AT&T垄断地位及其监管体系的，是技术变革。问题不再是像Hush-a-Phone那样的小杯子，而是计算机时代。计算机技术的飞速发展和数据传输的爆炸式增长，侵蚀了传统的长途概念，催生了新的客户需求和竞争动力。为了满足大型用户和数据流量的需求，专用网络正在迅速发展。交换设备和数据处理之间的界限已不再清晰。技术进步给AT&T的垄断地位带来了越来越大的压力。越来越多的人开始质疑现有体系的合法性，而该体系本身也在逐渐瓦解。此外，长途电话费补贴本地电话费的现象也变得显而易见；这种认识促使大型企业用户寻求绕过垄断的方法，以获得更低廉的长途和数据服务费用。

McGowan may have done more than anybody else to upset the longstanding regulatory system. But it was technological change that really undermined AT&T’s monopoly and the regulatory system that went with it. The problem was no longer a little cup like the Hush-a-Phone. It was the computer age. The development of computing technology and the tremendous growth in data transmission eroded the traditional concept of long distance, creating new demands by customers and new incentives for competition. Private networks were developing rapidly to meet the demands of large users and data flow. There was no longer any clear difference between switching equipment and data processing. Technological progress was generating a growing pressure on the AT&T monopoly. More and more people were doubting the validity of the existing system, which in any event was eroding. Moreover, it had become very clear that long-distance rates subsidized local rates; that recognition provided an incentive for large corporate users to seek ways around the monopoly in order to get cheaper rates for their long-distance and data services.

AT&T试图抵制变革的压力。“我们究竟相信什么？”AT&T董事长在一次州公用事业监管机构会议上反问道。“我们相信……公共利益……必然会因竞争的进一步侵蚀而导致的重复建设而受到损害……公共承运人原则有其合理之处。监管也有其合理之处。而且，鉴于我们行业的性质，垄断——受监管的垄断——也有其合理之处。”自世纪之交以来，这一信息或许一直清晰响亮，但如今却已不再适用。1974年，司法部对AT&T提起反垄断诉讼。联邦法官哈罗德·格林负责审理此案。审判于1981年开庭。格林法官驳回了AT&T的撤诉动议，并指出政府提供的证据表明，“贝尔系统在很长一段时间内以多种方式违反了反垄断法”。AT&T管理层认为公司已陷入绝境，最终决定接受公司拆分。经过公司与司法部近两年的谈判，最终促成了“商业史上规模最大、最复杂的重组”。该公司被拆分为独立的“本地”（即区域性）公司——小贝尔公司——和一家只从事长途业务的公司，即其继任者 AT&T，该公司现在在美国与 MCI（即将合并）、Sprint 和许多其他公司竞争，并且还在世界各地的市场上展开竞争。

AT&T sought to resist the pressure for change. “What do we believe?” the chairman of AT&T rhetorically asked a convention of state utility regulators. “We believe … that the public interest… cannot help but be impaired by the duplication … that will inevitably result from the further encroachment of competition… . There is something right about the common carrier principle. There is something right about regulation. And, given the nature of our industry, there is something right about monopoly—regulated monopoly.” The message may have rung with a clear tone since the turn of the century, but it did not ring true anymore. The Justice Department filed an antitrust suit against AT&T in 1974. Federal judge Harold Greene took responsibility for the case. The trial opened in 1981. Judge Greene rejected AT&T’s motion for dismissal, commenting that the government had presented evidence that “the Bell System has violated the antitrust laws in a number of ways over a lengthy period of time.” Concluding that the company was cornered, management made the decision to accept the breakup of the company. The consequence—the result of almost two years of negotiation between the company and the Department of Justice—was “the biggest, most complex restructuring in the history of business.” The company was divided into separate “local” (i.e., regional) companies—the Baby Bells—and a long-distance-only company, the successor AT&T, which now competes in the United States against MCI (soon to be merged), Sprint, and a host of others, and is also competing in markets around the world.

对美国而言，其结果是电信系统呈现出部分管制、部分放松管制的局面——实际上，这套系统被描述为“受监管的竞争”。长途电话业务基本放松管制；而原本受管制的本地电话服务如今也开始引入竞争。本地和长途电话公司，以及监管机构和消费者团体，都在争论长途电话费应该在多大程度上继续补贴本地电话费——如果不再补贴，又该如何确保低收入家庭仍然能够负担得起基本的电话服务。换句话说，如何才能维持普遍服务的承诺？对消费者而言，其结果是长途电话服务成本下降、创新蓬勃发展、选择更多、灵活性更大。但也意味着，消费者在寻找维修服务电话时会感到困惑，对无品牌公用电话的操作感到沮丧，并且对无数推销长途电话的晚餐时间电话感到愤怒。

For the United States, the result has been a telecommunications system that is partly regulated and partly deregulated—indeed, a system that has been described as regulated competition. The long-distance business is mostly deregulated; local service, which has been regulated, is now opening to competition. Local and long-distance phone companies, along with regulators and consumer groups, are struggling over the degree to which longdistance rates should continue to subsidize local rates—and if they do not, how to ensure that low-income families can still afford basic phone services. In other words, how to maintain the commitment to universal service? For customers, the results have been falling costs for long-distance service, an explosion in innovation, many more options, and much greater flexibility. It has also meant confusion in figuring out whom to call for repairs, frustration with the operations of no-brand pay phones, and rage at the innumerable dinnertime calls selling long-distance service.

钱都花到哪儿去了？

Where the Money Is

新政的监管遗产在金融领域也正被重新评估。“我们的方法不是放松管制，而是合理的监管改革，”货币监理署署长尤金·路德维希说道，他负责监管国家银行体系的重要组成部分。富兰克林·罗斯福1933年就任总统后做的第一件事就是宣布“银行假日”——暂时关闭银行以防止挤兑——自新政以来，金融领域一直受到严格监管。监管范围极其广泛——从直到最近才废除的《格拉斯-斯蒂格尔法案》（该法案禁止商业银行和投资银行之间的业务重叠），到联邦政府必须批准每一台新的自动取款机——通常，每台自动取款机的审批过程需要35个步骤，耗时37天。货币监理署一直致力于……他们对全部七十二项规章制度进行了逐一审查。“我们想把所有规定都摆到台面上来审视，”路德维希说，“然后扪心自问：这些规定合理吗？有价值吗？有多重要？付出的代价是否值得？有些规定在最初制定时就不合理。”

The New Deal’s regulatory legacy is also being reassessed in the financial sector. “Our approach is not deregulation but sensible regulatory reform,” said Eugene Ludwig, who, as comptroller of the currency, oversees a major part of the national banking system. One of the first things that Franklin Roosevelt did when he became president in 1933 was declare a “bank holiday”—temporarily shutting their doors to prevent runs—and ever since the New Deal, the financial sector has been heavily regulated. The range of control is extraordinarily broad—from the Glass-Steagal legislation, which until recently forbade overlap between commercial and investment banks, to the requirement that the federal government approve every new automated teller machine—a process that typically, for each ATM, requires thirty-five steps and takes thirty-seven days. The Office of the Comptroller has been reviewing every single one of its seventy-two regulations. “We want to hold up everything to the light,” said Ludwig “and ask: Does it make sense? Add value? How much does it matter? Is the burden worth the benefit? Some of the regulations didn’t make sense when they were first put in place.”

上世纪80年代末90年代初，储贷行业遭遇严重危机，这凸显了事情可能出错的严重性。这场危机既是部分放松管制的结果，也是保罗·沃尔克所说的“监管失灵”造成的。当时，这些机构可以支付的存款利率以及投资方向的限制都被取消了。用沃尔克的话来说，这使它们“陷入了诱惑——它们可能会犯下比平时更大的错误”。但由于存款由联邦政府担保，储贷机构可以肆无忌惮地承担越来越大的风险。政府审查人员本可以揭露真相，但作为政治捐款大户的储贷机构高管施加了巨大的政治压力，以避免风险曝光。直到大规模破产和违约迫在眉睫，丑闻的全部真相才浮出水面。最终，纳税人不得不承担3000亿美元的救助费用。这场危机也让人们重新认识到金融领域监管的复杂性。

That things can go wrong was underlined by the severe crisis that hit the savings and loan industry in the late 1980s and early 1990s. That crisis was the result of both partial deregulation and what Paul Volcker called “a failure of regulation and supervision.” Restrictions were lifted on the interest rates that these institutions could pay for deposits and on what they could invest those deposits in. This led them, in Volcker’s words, into “temptation—they could make bigger mistakes than otherwise.” But deposits were guaranteed by the federal government, meaning that the savings and loans could take ever-larger risks with a sense of impunity. Government examiners might well have blown the whistle, but executives of savings and loans, big political contributors, applied intense political pressure to avert exposure of the risks. It was only when massive bankruptcy and default were at hand that the full extent of the scandal became apparent. Taxpayers ended up stuck with the tab for a $300 billion bailout. The crisis also left a renewed sense of sobriety about the complexity of regulation in the financial sector.

路德维希说：“监管的诀窍在于找到合适的平衡点。有相当确凿的证据表明，20世纪80年代的一些金融崩溃是由于监管失误造成的。另一方面，市场中也存在骗子和傻瓜，你不能完全依赖市场本身。金融体系确实需要一定程度的监督和管理。一些参与者为了追求高回报，会冒险进入高风险状态。监管有助于将风险拉回中心，并确保个人的高风险/高回报比率不会导致传染或系统性危机。金融体系与其他行业不同，因为它在经济中占据核心地位。它容易被操纵。你不会因为芭比娃娃的谣言而导致玩具反斗城出现抢购潮，但银行却可能出现挤兑。非法活动会导致破产。维护金融行业的诚信比维护化妆品行业的诚信更为重要。”

“The trick in regulation,” Ludwig said, “is to get the right balance. There is pretty clear evidence that some of the financial unraveling of the 1980s occurred because of regulatory mistakes. On the other hand, there are knaves and fools, and you can’t rely entirely on the market itself. The financial system does benefit from a certain amount of oversight and supervision. Some participants will go way out on the bell curve toward high risk in pursuit of high rewards. Regulation helps to push back toward the center, and ensures that a high risk/reward ratio for individuals does not lead to contagion or a systemic crisis. The financial system is different from other sectors because of its centrality to the economy. It can be manipulated. You don’t get a run on Toys “Я” Us because of rumors about Barbie. You can get a run on a bank. Illegal activities can lead to insolvency. There’s more of a stake in keeping the financial sector honest than there is, for instance, in cosmetics.”

但迄今为止规模最大的放松管制仍在进行中。它正在改变一个全球资本密集度最高、规模超过航空和电信总和的行业——电力行业。没有什么比电力行业更能体现放松管制的精髓了。它影响着每一个人——以及每个人的每月账单。10

But the biggest deregulation yet is still very much in the process of unfolding. It is transforming an industry that is the most capital intensive in the world and is bigger than airlines and telecommunications combined—electric power. Nothing else is as emblematic of deregulation. It touches everyone—and everyone’s monthly bills.10

电力：契约的崩溃

Electricity: The Collapse of the “Compact”

1993年，伊丽莎白·莫勒和威廉·马西前往伦敦，介绍美国天然气市场放松管制的成果。当时，莫勒是联邦能源监管委员会主席，马西是该委员会委员。联邦能源监管委员会（FERC）负责监管州际电力和天然气贸易。它是1920年成立的联邦电力委员会的现代版本，并在罗斯福新政的推动下得到了加强。20世纪90年代初，FERC刚刚完成了天然气行业大部分领域的放松管制。莫勒和她的同事们开始关注电力行业。在英国期间，莫勒和马西考察了撒切尔政府对英国电力行业实施的改革。他们印象深刻的是，曾经垄断的国有企业是如何转变为竞争性企业的，价格如何根据供求关系不断变化。英国的经验激励他们加快美国电力行业的改革。莫勒和马西回到华盛顿后，他们和同事们一致认为，FERC应该采取一项大胆的举措：开放电力行业——而且要尽快。

In 1993, Elizabeth Moler and William Massey went to London to present the results of U.S. natural gas deregulation. At that point Moler was the chair and Massey a commissioner of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC), which regulates interstate commerce in electric power and natural gas. It is the modern version of the Federal Power Commission, established in 1920 and bolstered by the New Deal. In the early 1990s, the FERC had just completed deregulating a substantial part of the natural-gas industry. Moler’s attention, and that of her colleagues, was now turning to electric power. While in Britain, Moler and Massey investigated the changes in the British power industry that the Thatcher government had implemented. They were impressed by how the once-monolithic state-owned industry had been turned into a competitive business, with prices constantly changing in response to supply and demand. The British experience emboldened them to speed up change in the U.S. electric power industry. When Moler and Massey returned to Washington, they and their colleagues agreed that the FERC should do something bold, very bold: Open up the electric power industry—and as fast as possible.

挑战巨大。美国电力行业保守、行动迟缓、行事谨慎，其运作遵循着一套清晰却又僵化的规则。这套体系是在罗斯福新政时期，塞缪尔·英萨尔的电力帝国崩溃后建立的，并遵循着所谓的“监管契约”。公用事业公司是天然垄断企业。一条小巷里铺设两套电线毫无意义。公用事业公司获得垄断特许权的代价是有限的回报率以及政府的高度监督和监管。州际交易由联邦电力委员会（后来的联邦能源监管委员会，FERC）监管。州内交易，也就是电力业务的大部分，则由各州的公共事业委员会监管，这些委员会负责制定消费者需要支付的电价。他们通过一个繁琐、法律化且高度程式化的程序——电价听证会——来制定电价。在听证会上，律师、游说者、企业官员、专家、干预者、环保人士、消费者权益活动家和监管人员如同歌舞伎般，各自扮演着预设的角色。这些费率使公用事业公司能够获得受监管的利润，利润以资本回报率的形式确定。回报虽然并不丰厚，但却可预测、固定，并且基本上是有保障的。与此同时，服务可靠性也得到了极大的重视。绝不停电，绝不限速。1935 年的《公共事业控股公司法》严格限制了公用事业公司之间的合并，尤其是跨州合并。成立一家全国性公用事业公司的想法在当时是不可想象的。公用事业公司是当地经济和社区的核心。很多时候，其首席执行官还会领导当地的联合劝募活动。

The challenge was enormous. The U.S. electric power industry was conservative, slow-moving, and cautious, and it was run by very clear, if rigid, rules of the game. The system, as established by the New Deal in the wake of the collapse of Samuel Insull’s empire, operated under what was called the regulatory compact. Utilities were natural monopolies. It made no sense to have two sets of wires running down an alley. The utility was given its monopoly franchise in exchange for a limited rate of return and a very high degree of governmental oversight and regulation. Interstate transactions were supervised by the Federal Power Commission, and later the FERC. Intrastate activities, the greater part of the business, were regulated by the states’ public utility commissions, which set the rates that consumers would pay. They did so through a laborious, legalistic, highly ritualized process called rate hearings, in which—Kabuki-like—lawyers, lobbyists, corporate officials, experts, intervenors, environmentalists, consumer activists, and regulators all performed their stylized roles. The rates allowed the utility to earn a regulated profit, which was determined as a return on capital. There was nothing flamboyant about the return, but it was predictable, fixed—and essentially guaranteed. Along with that went an extreme emphasis on reliability of service. No blackouts. No brownouts. The Public Utility Holding Companies Act of 1935 sharply constrained combinations among utilities, particularly across state borders. The thought of a national utility was inconceivable. The utility was at the very center of the local economy and community. As often as not, its CEO headed the local United Way campaign.

直到20世纪70年代，这套系统运行得非常出色，为消费者带来了越来越低廉的电价。经通胀调整后，电价从1934年的每千瓦时37美分降至1970年的约5美分。这对消费者和经济来说都是一个巨大的福音。规模经济发挥了作用。规模更大、更新的电厂降低了成本。但到了20世纪70年代，高通胀、高投资和高成本开始让这套系统不堪重负。新建电厂的成本远高于老旧电厂，而不是更低。新建核电站尤其如此。由于施工期间需要不断修改设计以满足不断变化的安全法规，成本飙升。油气价格上涨也对电力系统造成了冲击。消费者发现，他们支付的价格不降反升，有时甚至大幅上涨。他们被“电价冲击”震惊了。电力行业的经济状况变得异常混乱。例如，伊利诺伊州北部地区的消费者支付的电费是威斯康星州南部居民的两倍。许多电力公司背负着巨额债务，高利率更是雪上加霜。其中一些公司濒临破产。

Until the 1970s, the system had worked brilliantly, delivering evercheaper prices to consumers. In inflation-adjusted terms, electricity prices had dropped from thirty-seven cents per kilowatt-hour in 1934 to about five cents in 1970. What an astonishing boon to consumers—and to the economy. Economies of scale worked. Bigger, newer plants lowered costs. But then the system began to buckle under the high inflation, high investment, and high costs of the 1970s. New plants were now costing much more, not less, than older plants. This was especially true of the new nuclear plants, whose costs spiraled up because of constant design revisions during construction to meet changing safety regulations. Higher oil and gas prices also hit the system. Consumers now found that the prices they paid were going up, and sometimes sharply, not down. They were stunned by “rate shock.” The economics of the industry had become wacky. For instance, consumers in northern Illinois paid twice as much for electricity as their neighbors in southern Wisconsin. Many utilities staggered under an enormous debt burden, made much heavier by high interest rates. A number of them teetered on bankruptcy.

到了20世纪80年代初，监管契约已被打破。一种应对措施是“加强政府干预”——加强监管、发布更多指令、加大干预力度——各州公共事业委员会实际上开始掌控大多数基本的经济决策。但还有另一种更为激进的应对措施——基于一种异端思想：或许公用事业公司，至少在其许多职能领域，并非天然垄断企业。或许至少部分业务可以实现竞争。这种思想的萌芽出现在1978年《公共事业监管政策法案》（PURPA）颁布之后。该法案允许企业家建造发电厂，并将电力出售给当地公用事业公司。其最初目的是为了促进节能和改善环境，并提供小规模的发电补充，而不是像大型核电站那样大规模地增加电力供应。但正如许多新举措一样，“独立发电”的发展也带来了一个意想不到的后果。它表明，公用事业公司并非天生垄断了经济高效的电力生产。其他人也可以设计、融资、建造和运营一座电厂，成本可能更低，甚至更低——然后将他们产生的电力卖给公用事业电网。

By the early 1980s, the regulatory compact was broken. One response was “more government”—more regulation, more directives, more intervention—as state public-utility commissions effectively began to assume control over most basic economic decisions. But there was another, more radical, response—based on the heretical thought that perhaps utilities, at least in many of their functions, were not natural monopolies. Perhaps at least parts of the business could be competitive. The first glimmer of this came in the aftermath of the 1978 Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act (PURPA), which permitted entrepreneurs to build a power plant and sell its power to a local utility. The original purpose was to promote conservation and a cleaner environment, as well as to provide bite-size additions to generation, as opposed to the massive additions of a huge nuclear power plant. But as so often happens with new initiatives, the development of “independent power” had an unintended consequence. It demonstrated that utilities did not have an inherent monopoly over the economical generation of electric power. Other people could design, finance, build, and operate a plant just as cheaply if not more so—and sell the electricity they generated to the utility’s grid.

到了20世纪80年代末，促进竞争的条件已经具备。重大的技术创新，特别是基于喷气发动机技术的新型涡轮机，使得天然气的利用效率大幅提高，也使得小型化、环保型电厂成为可能。许多雄心勃勃的企业家渴望大规模进军传统的公用事业领域。市场需求也已具备。大型工业用电企业希望降低电力成本。他们认为，降低成本的途径是货比三家，购买最便宜的千瓦时电。而这需要竞争。公用事业行业内部也存在严重分歧：一方支持更多竞争，另一方则认为传统的电力结构最能服务于客户，并警告说竞争可能会危及供电可靠性。

By the late 1980s, the elements were in place to promote competition. Major technological innovation, particularly in new turbines based on jetengine technology, made possible much more efficient use of natural gas—and smaller, environmentally attractive plants. A host of aggressive entrepreneurs were anxious to break into the traditional utility business in a big way. And the market was there. Big industrial consumers of electricity wanted to reduce their power costs. The way to do that, they believed, was to shop around and buy the cheapest kilowatt-hours. That required competition. The utility industry itself was deeply split between those who favored more competition and those who argued that the traditional structure served the customers best—and warned that competition might jeopardize reliability.

布什政府提出了一项提案，旨在减少对投资发电厂的投资者的监管。但很快，他们就遇到了第二个问题，而这个问题最终被证明至关重要——输电线路的接入。也就是说，地方电力公司是否必须向其他发电企业开放输电线路？换句话说，输电线路是否会变成一条高速公路，或者更确切地说，一条收费公路——任何支付电费的人都可以使用？事关重大，随之而来的斗争也异常激烈。“如果我们当中有人意识到这一点，我们就会明白……”“鉴于我们所处理问题的规模，”众议院关键小组委员会主席菲利普·夏普说道，“我们本应更加谨慎，因为这在政治上非常棘手。”但随着1992年《能源政策法案》的通过，这个问题最终得以解决。该法案原则上允许输电接入，但仅限于批发买家和卖家，而非个人用户。这项立法让业内所有参与者——以及那些希望进入该行业的外部人士——都相信，一个真正的竞争时代即将到来。但竞争的程度和速度究竟如何？这取决于联邦能源监管委员会（FERC），尤其是其新任主席贝齐·莫勒。

The Bush administration initiated a proposal to reduce regulation on investors who put money into power plants. But it soon came up against a second issue, which proved to be the critical one—access to transmission. That is, would the local utility have to open up its wires to competing generators? In other words, would the wires become a highway or, more properly, a tollway—open to anyone who paid the tariff? The stakes were very high, and the ensuing battle was very bitter. “If any of us had realized the scale of the issue we were taking on,” said Philip Sharp, who was chairman of the key House subcommittee, “we would have been more cautious, because it was so politically difficult.” But the matter was resolved with the passage of the Energy Policy Act of 1992, which provided, in principle, for transmission access but limited it only to wholesale buyers and sellers, not individual customers. This legislation persuaded all participants in the industry—and those outside, looking to get in—that an era of genuine competition was coming. But how far and how fast? That was up to the FERC and, in particular, to its new chairman, Betsy Moler.

“我们乐于学习”

“We’re Teachable”

几年前，莫勒曾在国会山担任参议院能源委员会的一名年轻的民主党工作人员。和许多人一样，她也经历了上世纪70年代末围绕天然气立法的激烈斗争。那项立法是经过精心制定的，旨在引导天然气市场从价格管制过渡到更加自由的市场。“我们努力提供过渡机制，使我们能够循序渐进地从管制市场过渡到非管制市场，”莫勒说。“民主党人追求公平。我们不希望消费者遭受价格欺诈。但一旦我们放松了商品市场的管制，我们发现市场参与者足够多，价格最终下降了，而不是上涨了。”她补充道：“我认为，民主党人越来越尊重市场的力量。我们认识到竞争的作用。我们乐于接受新事物。”

Some years earlier, Moler had worked on Capitol Hill as a young Democratic staff member of the Senate Energy Committee. Like many others, she had gone through the traumatic battle over natural-gas legislation in the late 1970s. That legislation had been laboriously constructed to manage a transition for natural gas from price controls to a freer market. “We tried to provide transition mechanisms that would allow us to inch along the way from a regulated to deregulated market,” said Moler. “Democrats do equity. We didn’t want consumers to experience price gouging. But once we had deregulated the commodity market, we discovered that there were enough players, and prices eventually went down, not up.” She added: “Democrats have, I think, increasingly come to respect the power of markets. We recognize what competition can do. We’re teachable.”

在1992年《能源政策法案》的授权下，莫勒和她在联邦能源监管委员会（FERC）的同事们开始发布实验性裁决，向电力行业开放竞争。三年的努力最终促成了影响深远的第888号命令，这是推翻罗斯福新政体系、实现竞争的重要一步。第888号命令允许美国某一地区的本地电力公司与另一地区的廉价发电厂签订电力合同。这些电力通过多家公司的输电线路输送，最终由本地电力公司出售给最终用户。那些拥有高成本电力的公司将无法再阻止低成本竞争对手进入市场。目前，各州正在制定允许零售竞争的计划。这意味着最终用户——无论是工业企业还是个人房主——都可以直接从发电公司购买电力，而发电公司之间将展开价格竞争。目前，公用事业行业中唯一被明确视为自然垄断的部分是“电线业务”——输电和本地配电：在一条小巷里铺设两组电线仍然是没有道理的。

With the mandate provided by the Energy Policy Act of 1992, Moler and her colleagues at the FERC began to issue experimental rulings, opening up the power industry to competition. Three years of work culminated in the mammoth Order 888, a major step in bringing down the New Deal system and implementing competition. Order 888 permitted a local utility in one part of the country to contract for electric power from a cheap generator in another part of the country. This power is “wheeled” across transmission lines belonging to a number of companies and finally sold through the local utility to the final customer. Those with high-cost power would no longer be able to block their low-cost competitors from getting to market. Various states are now working on plans that would permit retail competition. That means final customers—whether industrial firms or individual homeowners—would be able to buy directly from generating companies, which would compete on the basis of price. The only part of the utility industry that is now clearly regarded as a natural monopoly is the “wires business”—transmission and local distribution: It still does not make sense to have two sets of wires running down an alley.

竞争带来的经济影响是巨大的。让电力行业接受市场力量的约束，将会改变每座发电厂、每套输电系统以及该行业每项资产的价值。总而言之，这些在美国，资产占固定商业投资的10%——如今它们的价值与放松管制之前已截然不同。政府的退出也迫使公用事业公司进行巨大的组织和文化变革。过去专注于法律和监管体系的公司现在必须应对竞争对手，并考虑市场营销。各公司必须决定是继续从事发电、输电、配电和服务等业务，还是退出其中一个或多个环节。许多公司将通过合并来降低成本。另一些公司则希望利用其线路优势，转型成为服务提供商——不仅提供电力，还提供电话、视频、互联网和家庭安防等服务。一些公司将寻求在美国以外的市场实现新的增长。目前尚未涉足电力行业的公司将努力进入该领域。与此同时，新的公司将在美国各地涌现，争夺市场主导权。

The economic impact of competition is enormous. Subjecting the power industry to market forces will change the dollar value of every power plant, every transmission system, every asset of the industry. Altogether, these assets make up 10 percent of fixed business investment in the United States—and now they are worth something different than before deregulation. The retreat of government is also forcing utilities to make immense organizational and cultural changes. Companies that formerly focused on the legal and regulatory system now must contend with competitors and think about marketing. Companies will have to decide whether to stay in the generation, transmission, distribution, and service parts of the business, or exit one or more. Many companies will merge to lower their costs. Others, seeking to take advantage of their wires, will seek to become service providers—not only of electricity but also of telephone, video, Internet, and home security. A number will seek new growth in markets outside the United States. Companies not now in the power business will battle their way in. Meanwhile, new companies will spring up to market power across the United States.

随着电力行业从传统的受监管垄断模式转向更加市场化的体系，电力监管机构的职责也将随之改变。他们的新任务是确保市场竞争的持续性。“监管机构现在扮演的是裁判的角色，”莫勒说，“他们不再制定价格，而是负责判定好坏球。”11

Insofar as the electric power industry shifts from the traditional regulated-monopoly to a more market-based system, electricity regulators will change their jobs. Their new occupation will be to make sure that the market is competitive—and remains so. “Regulators are referees now,” said Moler. “They don’t set prices. They call balls and strikes.”11

社会规制：扩大其影响范围

Social Regulation: Expanding Its Reach

如果说经济监管的总体趋势是更加依赖市场，那么在所谓的社会价值监管领域，情况则恰恰相反。社会价值监管涵盖环境、反歧视和工作场所监管等领域。在这些领域，“第四权力”的影响力越来越大。自尼克松以来，无论是民主党还是共和党执政的历届政府都宣称监管过度，需要大幅削减。但实际情况却恰恰相反——第四权力大幅扩张，导致批评者所说的“几乎所有行为都被定为犯罪”。要全面了解不断膨胀的社会价值监管体系非常困难；只有那些受到监管体系某些方面影响的人才会意识到它的存在。更令人困惑的是，相关辩论异常激烈。人们情绪高涨，受正义与公平、安全与风险等观念的驱动，在事实和理论层面存在根本分歧。至少在某些人看来，两者之间也存在意识形态上的差异。

If the general trend in economic regulation is toward greater reliance on the market, somewhat the opposite is happening in the realm of what is called social-value regulation, which encompasses such areas as environmental, antidiscrimination, and workplace regulation. In these realms, the “fourth branch of government” is having a bigger and bigger say. Every administration since Richard Nixon’s, whether Democratic or Republican, has declared that there is too much regulation and that it needs serious pruning. But the trend has been the opposite—a vast expansion in the fourth branch, resulting in what has been described by critics as the “criminalization of just about everything.” It is very difficult to gain an overall view of the ever-growing edifice of social-value regulation; only those who are touched by this or that part of the regulatory system know it is there. To confuse matters further, the debates are passionate. Emotions run very high, driven by notions of justice and fairness, of safety and risk, and differing fundamentally on facts and theory. There is also, at least in the view of some, an ideological difference.

无论从哪个角度来看，风险监管——涉及健康、安全和环境——都面临着斯蒂芬·布雷耶（现任最高法院大法官）所说的“监管僵局”。风险监管可以追溯到19世纪美国迫切需要控制最直接、最严重的危险——火灾。在纽约市和费城等人口稠密的地区，市政法令禁止建造木制或石膏烟囱、茅草或芦苇屋顶以及干草堆。消防员在社区巡逻，检查烟囱的清洁度；州政府监管火药的储存。世纪之交，揭露丑闻的记者曝光了糟糕的卫生状况，促成了食品和药品监管的建立。但直到20世纪60年代末和70年代初，一股新的行动主义精神才推动了联邦、州和地方各级监管活动的蓬勃发展。环境保护署（EPA）和职业安全与健康管理局（OSHA）都是在尼克松政府时期成立的。污染——城市空气污染、国家湖泊和溪流水污染——催生了一系列新的要求。进步是巨大的。现在人们可以在哈德逊河钓鱼和游泳了。1997年在底特律下线的一辆新车产生的污染仅为20世纪70年代初生产的汽车的5%。洛杉矶是因雾霾而闻名的城市。然而，尽管洛杉矶的人口自那时以来增长了 30% 以上，但空气质量却改善了 36%。12

Whatever the point of view, risk regulation—involving health, safety, and the environment—suffers from what Stephen Breyer, now a Supreme Court Justice, calls “regulatory gridlock.” Risk regulation goes back to the desperate need in nineteenth-century America to contain the most immediate and gravest danger—fire. In densely populated areas such as New York City and Philadelphia, city ordinances prohibited wooden or plaster chimneys, straw or reed roofs, and haystacks. Fire wardens patrolled neighborhoods, inspecting the cleanliness of chimneys; state authorities regulated stores of gunpowder. At the turn of the century, the muckrakers’ exposés of deplorable sanitary conditions led to the establishment of food and drug regulation. But it was only in the late 1960s and early 1970s that a new spirit of activism initiated a great growth in regulatory activities, at the federal, state, and local levels. Both EPA—the Environmental Protection Agency—and OSHA—the Occupational Safety and Health Administration—were established during the Nixon administration. Pollution—dirty air in cities, dirty water in the nation’s lakes and streams—spawned a host of new requirements. Progress has been enormous. It is now possible to fish and swim in the Hudson River. A new car rolling off the assembly line in Detroit in 1997 produced only 5 percent as much pollution as a car built during the early 1970s. Los Angeles is the city that made smog famous. Yet, despite an increase in population of more than 30 percent in Los Angeles since then, the air is 36 percent cleaner.12

总体而言，美国和其他工业化国家的环境比二十年前清洁得多。这得益于监管和环保行动的结合，以及技术创新和知识的重新定义。然而与此同时，已发展起来的环境监管体系却日益被认为繁琐、僵化且过于死板。造成这种情况的原因之一是国会制定了极其详细的法规指令。这种“命令与控制”式的监管方式往往以非常具体的方式实施，而非提供总体指导方针和目标，从而阻碍了创新和效率的提升。此外，监管法规还常常出现混乱。政府的微观管理盛行，进一步削弱了技术创新和创造力的潜力。科学常常成为争议的焦点，而优先事项的确定往往取决于媒体、公众、特殊利益集团、政客以及布雷耶所称的“伪科学”之间难以预测的相互作用，而非基于对风险和紧迫性的排序。用布雷耶的话来说，“我们已经用对烟囱里飘出的东西的恐惧取代了对市场的恐惧。”

Overall, the environment in the United States and other industrial countries is much cleaner than it was two decades ago. This has been achieved by a combination of regulation and activism, along with technological innovation and intellectual redefinition. Yet at the same time, the system of environmental regulation that has evolved is increasingly seen as cumbersome, inflexible, and overly prescriptive. Among other reasons, this happens because the Congress writes extremely detailed statutory instructions. Instead of general guidelines and goals, “command and control” regulation tends to be imposed in very defined ways, which deters innovation and efficiency. Moreover, regulations have a habit of growing topsy-turvy. Governmental micromanagement is endemic, further reducing the potential for technological innovation and creativity. Science is often at the center of dispute, and priorities often result from the unpredictable interplay of press, public, special-interest groups, politicians, and what Breyer calls “pseudoscience,” rather than some ranking of risk and urgency. In the words of Breyer, “We have substituted fear of the market with fear of what goes up the chimney.”

他指出，在监管中融入灵活性是一项挑战。“如何在监管过程中赋予监管机构一定的自由裁量权，使其能够采取合理谨慎的监管措施，始终是个难题。因为人与人之间缺乏信任，自由裁量权减少，规则增多，监管结果也更加僵化。改善监管的唯一途径是赋予管理者更大的自由裁量权。但国会制定规则的目的正是为了限制自由裁量权。如果自由裁量权过大，就存在滥用的风险。如果限制自由裁量权，就会出现规则繁多、监管僵化的问题。这始终是真理。真正的挑战在于如何在规则和自由裁量权之间找到平衡。”

He points to the challenge of building flexibility into regulation. “It is always a problem to get discretion into the process so that the regulator can apply a reasonable amount of cautious regulation. Because no one trusts anyone else, there is less discretion, more rules, more rigid results. The only way to improve this regulation is to give administrators more discretion. But Congress writes the rules to prevent discretion. If there is too much discretion, there is a risk of abusing it. If you stop discretion, you get rules and rigidity. It’s always true. The challenge is to find balance between rules and discretion.”

现行制度的批评者担忧其合理性以及“最后5%或10%的问题”。治理90%或95%的污染问题可以高效且经济地完成。但最后5%或10%——即纯净度——几乎是无法实现的，而且会分散人们的注意力。资源被挪作他用，无法满足更紧迫的需求。“追求完美主义造成了巨大的混乱，”布雷耶大法官说道。在他最近出版的《打破恶性循环：迈向有效的风险监管》一书中，他引用了自己担任联邦法官时审理过的一个案例。这起案件涉及一场长达十年的斗争，旨在强制清理新罕布什尔州的一处有毒废料堆：“该场地大部分已被清理干净。除一家私人公司外，其余所有公司都已达成和解。剩下的那家私人公司就清理最后一小部分的费用提起诉讼，这笔费用约为930万美元，用于通过焚烧土壤来清除少量高度稀释的多氯联苯和‘挥发性有机化合物’（苯和汽油成分）。这930万美元究竟带来了多少额外的安全保障？长达四万页的十年诉讼记录表明（各方似乎也都同意），即使不进行这笔额外支出，该废料堆的清洁程度也足以让在场地玩耍的儿童每年食用少量泥土70天而不会受到显著伤害。焚烧土壤后，场地清洁程度将足以让儿童每年每天食用少量泥土245天而不会受到显著伤害。但该地区并没有食用泥土的儿童，因为那里是一片沼泽地。而且，由于未来不太可能进行任何建设，因此食用泥土的儿童也不太可能出现在那里。”双方还一致认为，至少一半的挥发性有机化合物可能会在2000年之前挥发掉。我所说的“最后10%的问题”，就是花费930万美元来保护根本不存在的吃土的孩子。

Critics of the current system worry about its rationality and the “last five—or ten—percent problem.” Remediating 90 or 95 percent of a pollution problem can be done in an efficient, cost-effective fashion. The last 5 or 10 percent—purity—is an almost unachievable goal, and one that diverts resources from more pressing needs. “The drive for perfectionism has created a very big mess,” said Justice Breyer. In his recent book Breaking the Vicious Circle: Toward Effective Risk Regulation, he cited a case he presided over when he was a federal judge. The case involved a ten-year battle to force the cleanup of a toxic waste dump in New Hampshire: “The site was mostly cleaned up. All but one of the private parties had settled. The remaining private party litigated the cost of cleaning up the last little bit, a cost of about $9.3 million to remove a small amount of highly diluted PCBs and ‘volatile organic compounds’ (benzene and gasoline components) by incinerating the dirt. How much extra safety did this $9.3 million buy? The forty-thousand-page record of this ten-year effort indicated (and all parties seemed to agree) that, without the extra expenditure, the waste dump was clean enough for children playing on the site to eat small amounts of dirt for 70 days each year without significant harm. Burning the soil would have made it clean enough for the children to eat small amounts daily for 245 days per year without significant harm. But there were no dirt-eating children playing in the area, for it was a swamp. Nor were dirt-eating children likely to appear there, for future building seemed unlikely. The parties also agreed that at least half of the volatile organic chemicals would likely evaporate by the year 2000. To spend $9.3 million to protect non-existent dirt-eating children is what I mean by the problem of the ‘last 10 percent.’”

整个体系都在努力解决如何评估和衡量风险这一根本问题。一种方法是分析监管成本与收益之间的平衡，但这种成本效益分析的结果却喜忧参半。挽救生命成本这一棘手的问题就凸显了其中的困难。其差异之大，几乎到了毫无意义的地步。据估计，禁止儿童穿着易燃睡衣的措施，每挽救一条生命的成本不到100万美元。相比之下，一项近期出台的限制甲醛暴露的规定，每挽救一条生命的成本估计高达930亿美元。

The entire system struggles with the fundamental issue of how to assess and measure risk. One way is to analyze the balance between the costs of a regulation and the benefits achieved, but the results of such cost-benefit analysis have been mixed. The vexing matter of the cost of lives saved demonstrates the difficulties. The range is so wide as to veer into the meaningless. It is estimated that the ban on flammable pajamas for children came out to less than $1 million per life saved. By contrast, a more recent rule limiting exposure to formaldehyde works out to an estimated $93 billion per life saved.

一种旨在提升环境保护灵活性和效率的新方法正在兴起。这种方法运用经济激励和市场机制来解决问题，取代了传统的官僚主义手段。显然，这代表了美国生态领域的前沿发展方向。“经过二十五年，我们正在迈入新一代的环境保护主义，”耶鲁大学环境法项目主任、前美国环保署助理署长丹尼尔·埃斯蒂解释道，“它将不再是命令控制，而是基于市场。”这源于人们对监管命令控制系统僵化的不满，以及对更高效率的追求——同时也反映了美国社会对市场解决方案的整体开放程度远超以往。

A new approach is evolving to bring greater flexibility and efficiency to environmental protection. It is the application of economic incentives and market mechanisms to solve problems, which supplants traditional bureaucratic methods. Clearly, this is the frontier for ecology in the United States. “After twenty-five years, we are moving into a new generation of environmentalism,” explained Daniel Esty, director of the environmental law program at Yale University and former assistant EPA administrator. “Rather than command-and-control, it will be market-based.” This emerges from dissatisfaction with the rigidities of regulatory command-and-control systems and a quest for greater effectiveness—along with an overall greater openness to market solutions in the United States than in the past.

这种新方法最明显地体现在“排放交易”的出现上，它被视为促进空气质量改善的一种途径。在被称为可交易权的体系下，公司可以通过购买或获得政府授权的方式，获得排放一定量污染物的许可。它可以……要么排放达到规定限额的污染物，要么将全部或部分配额出售给其他公司，并自行清理部分排放。其结果之一是，政府控制着特定区域内允许排放的污染物总量，而市场则负责分配这些污染物。因此，环境质量得以在整个区域内优化，而不是逐个公司或逐个设施地优化。尽管此类市场机制的尝试实际上始于20世纪70年代末，但直到1990年《清洁空气法修正案》通过后才得以成功制度化。

This new approach is most evident in the emergence of “emissions trading” as a way to promote better air quality. Under a system known as tradable rights, a company acquires from the government, either by purchase or as a grant, a permit to emit a certain amount of pollution. It can either emit pollution up to that point or sell all or part of its allotment to other companies and clean up some of its own emissions. One consequence is that the government controls the overall allowable pollution in a certain region, but the market portions it out. As a result, environmental quality is optimized for the entire region rather than on a company-by-company or facilitybyfacility basis. Although experiments with such market approaches actually began in the late 1970s, they became successfully institutionalized only with the Clean Air Act Amendment of 1990.

迄今为止的成果令人鼓舞。正如环境保卫基金会的丹尼尔·杜德克所言，就展现“市场力量在产生环境效益方面的力量”而言，其结果堪称“惊人”——这体现在“更优异的环境绩效、更低的成本以及监管机构与企业之间原本具有干预性的关系的逐步减少”。总排放量的减少速度远超预期，成本也更低。“还有什么其他环境项目能在如此短的时间内取得如此显著的成效？”杜德克问道。这种提供激励和允许选择的方法，也以高度指令性的法规无法企及的方式，鼓励了创新。基于市场的体系还有另一个非常有前景的特点：它们有可能减少环保主义者和产业界之间的对抗冲突，并为双方合作寻求解决方案提供框架。基于市场的体系能否跨越国界运作？这将通过建立应对全球气候变化问题的国际体系的尝试来检验。13

The record so far is very encouraging. Indeed, in the words of Daniel Dudek of the Environmental Defense Fund, the results have been “spectacular” in terms of demonstrating “the power of market forces to produce environmental benefits”—as measured in “superior environmental performance, lower cost and a ramping back of otherwise intrusive relationships between regulators and business.” Total emissions have been reduced much more rapidly, and at much lower cost than had been anticipated. “What other environmental program can show such dramatic performance in so short a time?” asked Dudek. This kind of approach—providing incentives and allowing choice—is also encouraging innovation in a way that overwritten, highly directive regulations cannot. Market-based systems have one other very promising characteristic: They have the potential to reduce the adversarial conflict between environmentalists and industry and, instead, provide a framework for collaborating on solutions. Can market-based systems work across borders? That will be tested by the attempts to create an international system to respond to global-climate-change concerns.13

“人权爆炸”

The “Rights Explosion”

自20世纪60年代以来，社会监管力度不断加大，这被称为“权利爆炸”。这一点在歧视定义的不断扩展上尤为明显，人们认为应该通过各种要求、测试和惩罚措施来纠正歧视。反过来，所有这些措施也都在加强。最引人注目的权利倡议是平权行动，这是民权运动的遗产，如今却引发了激烈的争论。支持者认为，平权行动是纠正过去错误、创造机会、对抗种族和性别歧视的有效方法。反对者则认为，平权行动将人们纳入特殊利益集团，违背了机会平等的原则，将受益者贴上低人一等的标签，阻碍了人们根据自身能力接受评判，并且依赖于对种族主义和性别歧视的争议性定义。随着配额和其他旨在纠正种族不平等这一根本问题的措施被扩展到其他诸多领域，以及新的价值观挑战传统的精英制度，争论愈演愈烈。权利的爆炸式增长催生了规则和执行这些规则的机构的激增。

Social regulation has also been mounting since the 1960s in what has been called the rights explosion. This is particularly evident in the expanding definitions of discrimination, which, it is argued, should be corrected through various requirements, tests, and penalties. In turn, all of these have increased. The most prominent rights initiative is affirmative action, the legacy of the civil rights movement, which now inflames opinion on both sides of a very bitter debate. To proponents, affirmative action is a method of correcting past wrongs, creating opportunities where they have been denied, and confronting the persistence of race and gender discrimination. Opponents argue that by submerging people into special-interest groups, the programs run counter to equality of opportunity, brand beneficiaries as inferior, prevent people from being judged on their merits, and depend upon controversial definitions of racism and sexism. Contention has increased as quotas and other methods devised to correct one fundamental problem—racial inequality—have been extended to a host of other issues and as new values are set against traditional meritocracy. The explosion of rights has bred a proliferation of rules and of agencies to administer them.

政府通过多种方式扩大对市场的监管和控制，这方面的例子不胜枚举。招聘和解雇流程的限制就是一个显著的例子。在招聘过程中，雇主被禁止询问应聘者的年龄、婚姻状况、家庭情况甚至健康状况，因为任何一项都可能被视为歧视。然而，批评者认为，为了了解应聘者并判断是否录用，这些都是合理的问题。此外，雇主为前雇员提供除最基本信息以外的任何推荐信都非常危险。现在，公司被建议将提及内容限制在“前雇员的职位名称和入职及离职日期”之内。否则，他们将面临诉讼风险。

There are many other examples of the ways in which government is extending its regulation and control over the marketplace. The constraints in the processes of hiring and firing are a notable example. In hiring someone, an employer is proscribed from asking about such things as the age of the applicant, his or her marital or family or even health status, for any one of these might be considered a basis of discrimination. Yet critics maintain that all those are reasonable questions in order to get to know applicants and make a judgment about whether or not to hire them. It is also very risky for an employer to provide anything more than the most banal reference for a former employee. Companies are now advised to restrict references to the “former employee’s job title and starting and ending dates of employment.” Otherwise, they open themselves to being sued.

社会价值监管和立法的直接影响，因美国特有的“对抗式法律主义”（即诉讼）现象而更加凸显。布鲁金斯学会高级研究员皮耶特罗·尼沃拉将这种诉讼形式描述为不仅是“解决个人纠纷的手段”，也是“治理或社会监管的机构”。他解释说：“民事陪审团对一家经营不善的企业判处数百万美元的惩罚性赔偿，这不仅仅是处理私人事务。就像消费者产品安全委员会或平等就业机会委员会的禁令一样，民事判决理应服务于公共目的，即遏制某种被认为对社会构成威胁的行为。”一位82岁的老妇人因在麦当劳得来速窗口购买的热咖啡烫伤自己而起诉了麦当劳。陪审团认定麦当劳因提供过热咖啡而存在故意疏忽，并判给她290万美元的赔偿金，以儆效尤（赔偿金额后来有所减少）。大学已经习惯于应对那些未能获得终身教职的教授提起的歧视诉讼。甚至公司业绩也可能成为诉讼的导火索。一家可能创造了数百个新就业岗位的公司在上市后也变得脆弱。因为如果由于业绩不佳导致股价下跌，该​​公司很可能最终成为被告。

The direct impact of social-value regulation and legislation is much accentuated by the peculiar American phenomenon of “adversarial legalism”—lawsuits. This form of litigation has been described by Pietro Nivola, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, as not merely a “means of resolving personal disagreements” but also as “institutions of governance or social regulation.” He explained: “A civil jury that levies millions in punitive damages against a maladroit business is addressing more than a private matter. Much like an injunctive order from the Consumer Product Safety Commission or the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, the civil verdict supposedly serves the public purpose of deterring some perceived threat to society.” An eighty-two-year-old woman sued McDonald’s after she burned herself by spilling hot coffee bought from a drive-through line. The jury found that McDonald’s was willfully negligent for serving coffee that was too hot and awarded her $2.9 million to send a message (the judgment was subsequently reduced). Universities have grown accustomed to expect lawsuits charging discrimination by professors who do not get tenure. Even corporate results provide a platform for litigation. A company that may have created hundreds of new jobs is vulnerable when it goes public. For if its share price falls because of a poor quarter, the company may well end up in the defendant’s chair.

鼓励诉讼的举措并非偶然。1991年的《民权法案》大幅加重了处罚力度，提倡惩罚性赔偿，允许精神损害赔偿，并提高了律师费。正如菲利普·霍华德所言，所有这些都符合该法案的明确宗旨，即“鼓励公民提起诉讼”，因为“反歧视原则与禁止攻击、殴打和其他故意伤害他人行为的原则同等重要”。因此，国会设想每位雇员都被赋予“私人检察长”的职责，以维护这些宝贵的权利。

The drive to encourage litigation has been deliberate. The 1991 Civil Rights Act greatly stiffened penalties, promoted punitive damages, allowed claims for emotional injury, and increased attorneys’ fees. All this was in line with the act’s explicit purpose, in the words of Philip Howard, “to encourage private citizens to sue” because “the principle of antidiscrimination is as important as the principle that prohibits assaults, batteries and other intentional injuries to people.” Thus, Congress envisions each employee as deputized to act as a “private attorney general to vindicate these precious rights.”

新立法至少有一个主要目标正在实现：就业歧视诉讼案件数量激增。事实上，监管/诉讼体系扩张如此迅速，以至于联邦地区法官斯坦利·斯波金警告说，“联邦法院正被大量此类案件淹没”。他还补充道：“我们正在成为这个国家几乎所有公私营企业的人事主管。”14

At least one major objective of the new legislation is being achieved: Employment discrimination litigation is mushrooming. Indeed, the regulation/litigation system is expanding so fast that Federal District Judge Stanley Sporkin has warned that “the federal courts are becoming flooded with employment cases.” He added, “We are becoming the personnel czars of virtually every one of this nation’s public and private companies.”14

美式私有化

Going Private, American-style

1987年3月26日，高盛投资银行的管理合伙人约翰·温伯格向美国政府签发了一张16.5亿美元的支票。这并非税款，而是当时纽约证券交易所史上规模最大的首次公开募股（IPO）的收益。美国政府出售了其在康雷尔铁路公司（Conrail）的股份。康雷尔铁路公司成立于十年前，旨在两家大型铁路公司破产后维持货运服务。此次出售的情况非同寻常。传统上，美国的公共所有制企业远少于其他国家，因此并没有很多大型资产需要出售。然而，康雷尔铁路公司的价值非常巨大，这16.5亿美元的交易也让“私有化”一词正式进入了美国政界的视野。

On March 26, 1987, John Weinberg, the managing partner of the investment bank Goldman, Sachs, signed a check for $1.65 billion to the U.S. government. It was not a tax bill. It was the proceeds of what up until then was the largest initial public offering ever made on the New York Stock Exchange. The United States government had sold off its holdings in Conrail, the railroad that had been created a decade earlier to keep freight service going after two major railroads went bankrupt. The circumstances of the sale were unusual. Traditionally, there has been much less public ownership in the United States than in other countries, so there was not a long list of major assets slated to be sold off. Yet the value of Conrail was very large, and the $1.65 billion helped project privatization into the American political vocabulary.

早在康雷尔铁路私有化之前，里根政府就已经开始借用撒切尔夫人领导下的英国新近提出的“私有化”一词。随着时间的推移，“私有化”一词已成为民主党和共和党共同使用的词汇。在副总统阿尔·戈尔的“重塑政府倡议”中，政府改革的主要方法之一就是私有化——用副总统的话来说，就是“将那些更适合私营部门完成的职能剥离出来”。私有化如今不仅包括出售资产；政府合同和采购方式的改变，以及服务外包的趋势，也都属于私有化的范畴。其目的在于引入市场力量和市场机制，以提高效率，降低成本和公共预算的负担，并提升服务的质量和效能。

Well before the Conrail privatization, the Reagan administration had already begun to borrow the newly minted term from Mrs. Thatcher’s Britain. With the passage of time, privatization has become part of the lexicon of Democrats as well as Republicans. One of the major methods for reinventing government in Vice-Président Al Gore’s Reinventing Government Initiative is by privatization—in the vice-president’s words, “spinning off functions to the private sector that are better accomplished there.” Privatization has come to include not only selling off assets; the government’s changed contracting and procurement practices and a shift toward outsourcing in the provision of services also fall under this rubric. The purpose is to bring market forces and market tests to bear—to increase efficiency, to reduce both costs and the drain on public budgets, and to improve the quality and effectiveness of services.

冷战结束后，在控制预算的背景下，军事体系的某些方面正受到新的经济审视。基地关闭和改造、出售不必要的设施以及缩减研发机构的规模，似乎都是朝着这个方向迈出的正确步伐。例如，位于安纳波利斯的美国海军学院并不需要其占地856英亩的奶牛场。毕竟，促使海军建立奶牛场的伤寒疫情爆发于一个世纪前。加利福尼亚州的埃尔克山海军石油储备站建于第一次世界大战之前，正值现代石油时代前夕，旨在缓解当时美国海军从煤炭动力转向石油动力时可能出现的石油短缺担忧。如今，它几乎不具备任何国家安全价值；其产量仅相当于全国总消费量的0.36%。1997年，该储备站被挂牌出售。铀浓缩设施也同样如此。国防部也开始求助于私营公司来管理政府部门正在推行类似的成本削减措施，包括对设施进行改造并提供后勤支持。此外，联邦航空管理局（负责空中交通管制）等机构的私有化也在讨论之中。但是，政府服务越是涉及公共安全（例如空中交通管制），政界人士就越不愿意推动出售。

In the aftermath of the cold war and in the context of controlling the budget, aspects ofthe military system are being subjected to a new economic scrutiny. Base closures and reconversions, the sale of unnecessary facilities, and the downsizing of its R&D institutions all appear to be good moves in this direction. The United States Naval Academy at Annapolis, for instance, did not need its own 856-acre dairy farm. After all, the typhoid epidemic at the academy that prompted the navy to establish a dairy farm broke out a century ago. The Elk Hills naval oil reserve in California was established before World War I, on the eve of the modern oil era, to allay fears of an oil shortage at a time when the United States was converting its navy from coal to oil. Today it hardly serves any national-security interest; it produces volumes equivalent to just 0.36 percent of the nation’s total consumption. In 1997, it went on the block and was sold. So is the uranium-enrichment facility. The Department of Defense is also turning to private firms to manage age facilities and provide supporting logistics. Similar cost-cutting initiatives are at work in other departments of government. Also under discussion are the privatization of such agencies as the Federal Aviation Administration, which controls air traffic. But the more a government service involves public safety, as with air traffic control, the more reluctant politicians will be to promote a sale.

美国各地的州首府、县政府和市政厅才是真正发挥作用的地方。政府对生产性资产的所有权主要集中在这些地方，政府也在这里监督、保障或亲自提供最广泛的公共服务。按照美国传统，地方政府有责任确保公共服务的数量和质量充足，并符合选民的普遍意愿。这适用于公共交通和港口、机场等基础设施服务；也适用于某些基本医疗设施，尤其适用于公立学校。

Much of the real action is taking place in state capitals, county headquarters, and city halls all across America. It is there that government ownership of productive assets is most concentrated, and where government oversees, guarantees, or itself provides the greatest range of public services. In the American tradition, local authorities are responsible for making sure that public services are provided in sufficient quantity and quality and according to the general wishes of voters. That applies to public transportation and to infrastructure services like ports and airports; it also applies to certain basic health facilities and, most of all, to the public schools.

在所有这些领域，政府权力下放都成为一个基层问题。它迫使地方社区的利益相关者重新思考长期以来根深蒂固的观念，即政府必须控制公共服务才能使其有效运作。毕竟，公共服务在过去曾得到扩展，以弥补私营服务提供商的不足。纽约市在1881年成立了街道清洁部门，此前数十年，私人承包商未能有效清理街道上的马粪——马粪是19世纪美国城市化进程中最大的污染问题。为了遏制腐败和裙带关系，公共服务得到了扩展，公务员制度也得以建立。然而，如今，地方政府雇员的独立性——其初衷是为了提高服务质量——却可能产生了相反的效果。用费城民主党籍市长埃德·伦德尔的话来说，“我清楚地意识到，我们的员工缺乏动力。由于工作规则、过去的做法、整体的集体谈判以及公务员制度，我们建立了一套管理体系，在这个体系中，我们消除了所有绩效激励……在费城，最难的工作……就是作为一名中层管理者，努力激发员工的积极性。”15

In all of these areas, the retreat of government becomes a grassroots issue. It is forcing stakeholders in local communities to rethink long-held beliefs that governments must control services if they are to work. After all, public provision of services was expanded in an earlier age, to make up for the inadequacies of private providers. New York City established its street-cleaning department in 1881 after decades of failure by private contractors to clean the streets of horse manure, which was the number-one pollution problem of urbanizing America in the nineteenth century. Services were expanded and civil-service systems were instituted to curtail corruption and cronyism. Yet now, the insulation of local government employment, which was intended to improve its quality, has arguably had the opposite effect. In the words of Ed Rendell, the Democratic mayor of Philadelphia, “It became clear to me that we had an incentiveless work force. Through work rules, and past practices, and the overall collective bargaining, and because of civil service, we had created a system of management where we had taken out every incentive for performance… . The most difficult job in Philadelphia … was being a middle-level manager and trying to get motivation out of your work force.”15

如果说私有化挑战了罗斯福新政时期乃至进步时代以来根深蒂固的观点，那么地方自治也为美国在私有化进程中带来了一些巨大的优势。特定私有化项目的支持者和反对者之间的分歧很少是意识形态或党派之争。诚然，在根本假设上仍然存在冲突——关键服务及其提供者，究竟应该以盈利为导向，还是应该以公共服务和共同利益的理念为导向？一个更直接的盈利理念会驱动一家私有化的公交公司，导致其减少不经济的服务。然而，这是否足以成为削减夜间服务的充分理由？这难道不会对在医院上夜班的护士造成不利影响吗？如果公交车减少，难道不会导致道路上的车辆增多，从而加剧污染、交通拥堵和……交通拥堵？私有化进程也可能贬低那些毕生致力于公共服务的人们的奉献精神。通常，围绕私有化的争论往往会将直接利益相关者卷入其中；他们争论的焦点在于谁将承担变革的成本，以及谁将从新机遇中获益最多。通常，最激动的是公共部门工会，他们正确地预见到，私有化将导致其成员失业、保障减少，以及工作实践将受到更严格的审查。

If privatization challenges views that go back beyond the New Deal to the Progressive era, local control also gives America some big advantages as it embarks on the privatization process. The rift between supporters and opponents of a particular privatization is rarely ideological or partisan. To be sure, there is still a clash of underlying assumptions—as to whether key services, and the people who deliver them, are to be most successfully motivated by profit or by conceptions of public service and the common good. A more straightforward concept of profitability will drive a privatized bus company, leading it to reduce uneconomic services. Yet is that a good enough reason to curtail night service? Does that not penalize the nurses who work the evening shift in a hospital? And if fewer buses run, won’t that bring more cars on the road and cause added pollution, congestion, and traffic delays? The drive to privatize can also devalue the commitment of those who have dedicated themselves to careers in public service. Often, fights over privatization tend to bring into opposition direct stakeholders; they argue over just who will bear the costs of the change and who will stand to benefit most from the new opportunities it sets up. Usually, the groups to become most exercised are public-sector unions, which see—correctly—a loss ofjobs for their members, less security, and a more critical evaluation of work practices.

有些私有化项目相当直接。将垃圾收集业务外包给私营公司在全国范围内已被广泛接受。旧金山早在1932年就开始实行这项业务。供水服务是另一个私有化目标。目前，全国约有20%的饮用水由政府所有但私营机构管理的设施提供。未来私有化的理由是降低成本，此外，大型公司在技术和技能方面也比市政运营的系统更具优势。目前，包括匹兹堡机场在内的许多主要机场都由私营公司运营。港口也是私有化的候选对象。印第安纳波利斯市强制要求市政服务部门与私营企业竞标合同。为了赢得城市车辆维护合同，市政工作人员必须击败三家全国性公司的投标。他们最终胜出——通过大幅降低成本、提高生产力以及接受工资和福利削减——以换取成本节约的一部分。纽约和新泽西港务局对肯尼迪机场国际到达大楼的破败状况感到失望，已将其移交给以阿姆斯特丹机场运营商为首的财团。

Some privatizations are quite straightforward. Turning garbage collection over to private companies is accepted across the country. San Francisco started doing it in 1932. Water services are another target for privatization. Currently, about 20 percent of drinking water in the country is provided by government-owned but privately managed facilities. The rationale for future privatization is lower costs, augmented by the comparative advantage in technology and skills that a large company will have over a city-operated system. Private companies now operate a number of major airports, including Pittsburgh’s. Ports are also candidates for privatization. Indianapolis compels city-owned services to compete for contracts against private-sector groups. To win the contract to maintain the city’s vehicles, city workers had to beat bids from three national firms. They won—by significantly reducing their costs, improving productivity, and taking wage and benefit cuts—in exchange for a share of the cost saving. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, disappointed with the decayed state of the international-arrivals building at Kennedy Airport, has turned it over to a consortium led by the Amsterdam airport operator.

有些职能正在被日益私有化，却不为人知。人们或许会认为警察和监狱是政府的“核心”职能。但实际上，警务工作已经稳步私有化；如今，私人保安的数量是警察的三倍。由于美国重罪犯数量激增，监禁需求迅速增长，监禁正逐渐演变成一项产业。到1996年底，已有132所私营监狱投入运营，另有39所正在建设中。预计1997年该行业的收入将超过10亿美元。各州和城市正在探索各种方式将福利服务外包；但随着“外包”和承包变得越来越普遍，对这一过程进行监督的必要性也日益凸显，以确保公共利益得到维护。此类私有化也为新型政府失灵打开了方便之门——旷日持久的官僚和政治纷争，充斥着无休止的程序性争议，而这正是美国政治体制的弊病之一。16

Some functions are being increasingly privatized without being recognized as such. One might think that police and prisons were “core” functions of government. But policing has, in effect, been steadily privatized; today the number of private security guards is three times that of police. Owing to the rapidly growing needs created by the production of felons in the United States, incarceration is emerging as a business. By the end of 1996, 132 private prisons and jails were in operation, with another 39 under construction. Industry revenues are expected to top $1 billion in 1997. States and cities are exploring various methods to contract out the provision of welfare services; but as “outsourcing” and contracting become more common, there is an increased need for overseeing the process—to ensure that the public interest is being served. Such privatizations also open the door to new versions of government failure—long, drawn-out bureaucratic and political wrangles that are dominated by endless due process, one of the banes of the American political system.16

教育与福利前沿

Education and the Welfare Frontier

教育领域的变革往往是最难思考和实施的——讽刺的是，这恰恰是当前教育体系危机最显而易见的领域之一。直到20世纪70年代，公共教育一直是美国经验的基石，是多元文化融合的熔炉。但此后，它饱受“权利爆炸”、纪律崩溃、暴力蔓延以及教育标准趋同的摧残。应对这些崩溃的措施多种多样，也引发了诸多争议。一些州现在允许设立“特许学校”——这些新的公立学校脱离地方学区，自行制定课程和标准，其目的或是为了推广某种特定的教育理念，或是为了适应特定族裔或移民社区的需求。结果喜忧参半。更具争议的是向家长发放教育券的提议，家长可以用这些教育券选择自己心仪的教育机构。教育券的广泛应用将在很大程度上导致教育体系事实上的私有化。这些改革之所以如此艰难，是因为公共教育不仅仅是一项基本服务，只需提高其效率即可。它关乎国家的未来，却又与美国在种族、民族和贫困问题上旷日持久的争论紧密相连——最鲜明的例证莫过于围绕强制校车接送制度的激烈斗争。

Some of the hardest changes to think through and implement are in education—ironically, one of the areas where the crisis of the current system is most plain to see. Public education was the foundation of the American experience, the flame under the melting pot, up until the 1970s. In the years since, it has been ravaged by the “explosion of rights,” the breakdown of discipline and the spread of violence, and the leveling of standards. Responses to the breakdown have been both diverse and controversial. A number of states now permit the establishment of “charter schools”—new public schools that secede from local school districts and set their own curricula and standards, whether to promote a particular educational philosophy or to adapt to the perceived needs of an ethnic or immigrant community. Results are mixed. Even more controversial are proposals to provide parents with vouchers, which they could use at the educational establishment of their choice. The widespread adoption of vouchers would go a long way toward the de facto privatization of the educational system. What makes these reforms the most difficult of all is that public education is not just a basic service that must merely be made to run efficiently. It is basic to the nation’s future yet also tangled up in America’s contentious struggle with race, ethnicity, and poverty—most vividly exemplified by the furious battles over forced busing.

重新思考政府在所有这些领域中的角色，意味着要应对过去项目往往模棱两可的结果，以及不同利益相关者出于善意而对这些结果的不同解读。如今，这一前沿领域的核心问题是如何处置福利制度。在美国政治语境中，福利制度指的是旨在帮助穷人的项目，例如医疗补助（Medicaid）、每月发放给受抚养儿童的补助金（AFDC）以及公共住房。许多不同的声音都提出了质疑，认为这些补救措施并非总能缩小问题的规模，有时甚至反而加剧了问题。这些批评的共同点往往在于，它们都认同现行制度未能兑现其承诺。这些批评既有中间派——即主要政党的温和派，他们主张在“福利转就业”的旗帜下进行渐进式改革——也有对制度所滋生的依赖性进行更彻底的批判，以及基于自力更生的更全面的解决方案。

Rethinking the role of government in all of these areas means contending with the often-ambiguous results of past programs—and the conflicting ways that different stakeholders, operating in good faith, interpret them.
